Ms. Christophe said the light was inspired by the chandeliers of the palace and by the gilded bees on vintage Guerlain bottles. Its wire frame is hung with crystals, some from flea markets and some made by contemporary artisans and embedded with gold paper. The LED chandelier is 7 feet high and 4 feet in diameter and sells for $60,000 through the design retailer Lisa Fontanarosa. Custom sizes are available. Information: (505) 872-1929 or lisafontanarosa.com.

title: Designing Small Tables for the Big Leagues
description: It was the last day of the Hospitality Design show in Las Vegas three years ago when Chris Hardy ventured into the Design Within Reach booth with his portfolio in hand. There, he stumbled on John Edelman, the companys chief executive. As a result, Mr. Hardy, a designer in Atlanta, found himself on a short list of hopefuls asked to submit ideas for small tables. He was among those who prevailed, and now his Helix side tables and coffee tables are ready for market. They feature asymmetrical walnut- and cast-bronze bases topped by glass. The brass not only stabilizes the base but creates a nice movement out from the center, with a layered effect, said Mr. Hardy, 29. The side table comes with a round top ($1,400), while the coffee table is available with a round or square top ($2,200) or an oval one ($2,400). The tables are at DWR Studios nationwide. Information: (800) 944-2233 or dwr.com.

title: An Oasis From Everything but Mosquitoes
description: A haven from hectic Ho Chi Minh City.

title: Where Coconuts Come Calling
description: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam  To Peter Arts and Hedwig Pira, it doesnt feel all that long since they uprooted themselves from a comfortable existence in their native Belgium and took on the formidable task of building a business, a house and a life in a foreign country.

title: Carving Nature into a Canvas of Wool
description: Two years ago, Angela Adams, a rug designer in Portland, Me., began using scissors and sheep shears to carve shapes into tufted wool. The second generation of this experiment, a collection called Landscape, is being introduced this week. Ms. Adams described the sculptural rugs as literal translations of nature, inspired by her favorite places: open areas in the woods; a garden in July with big bold bursts of color everywhere; a nice beach I like; and what it feels like to be on the water at night. The rugs are made in Thailand of hand-tufted New Zealand wool. They are available in four designs (Woodland, Garden, Harbor and Dune) and three sizes (9 by 11 feet for $12,000, 3 by 8 feet for $2,200 and 8-feet round for $8,000). Information: (800) 255-9454 or angelaadams.com.

title: Clutter Cleverly Put in Its Place
description: Henrybuilt, a Seattle manufacturer of custom kitchens, has plenty of experience helping buyers manage countertop clutter. Now its moving on to the rest of the home. The companys new Opencase Storage System is designed to work in an entry hall, library, office, pantry, closet, laundry room or childs room, among other places, thanks to an assortment of interchangeable attachments.

title: Sales at Judy Ross, Doris Leslie Blau and Others
description: Judy Ross is having a sample sale through Sunday, with up to 70 percent off many pillows and rugs (an 18-inch-square hand-embroidered Landscape pillow, shown, regularly $195, is $80; a 6-by-9-foot Tabla hand-knotted Tibetan wool rug, regularly $5,940, is $2,800); 22 East 17th Street, Suite 536, (212) 842-1705, judyrosstextiles.com.

title: New York Times/CBS News Poll on Gun Control, Immigration and the Federal Budget
description: In a New York Times/CBS Poll conducted April 24-April 28, Americans were asked about their views on gun control, immigration and the federal budget.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 24 through April 28 with 965 adults throughout the United States.

title: Americans Unity on Big Issues Doesnt Bridge Partisan Gap
description: While the public overwhelmingly supports background checks for gun buyers and a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants, Americans largely retreat into their partisan camps when asked whether President Obama or Congressional Republicans will make the right decisions on those and other domestic issues facing the nation, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: U.S. to Defend Age Limits on Morning-After Pill Sales
description: The Obama administration moved Wednesday to keep girls under 15 from having over-the-counter access to morning-after pills, as the Justice Department filed a notice to appeal a judges order that would make the drug available without a prescription for girls and women of all ages.

title: Americans on Obama, Guns and Immigration
description: The Timess Richard L. Berke and Ashley Parker break down the latest New York Times/CBS News poll and find a disconnect between ideology and political support.

title: Americans on Domestic Policy
description: The results of a poll by The New York Times and CBS News asking Americans their views on immigration, gun control, and other policy issues.

title: INGs U.S. Unit Prices Its Market Debut Below Expectations
description: The American arm of the Dutch financial services firm ING Group priced its initial public offering at $19.50 a share, below its expected range of $21 to $24.

title: Baby Toys Get an App Extension
description: As more of the very young reach for their parents smartphones, toy companies are responding with motion-sensing, app-infused toys like the Fisher-Price Apptivity Gym ($35, www.fisher-price.com).

title: Court Dismisses Craigslist Suit Against Competitors
description: Craigslist does not have exclusivelicensesto the postings on its classified advertising Web site, a federal court ruled on Tuesday.

title: Boeing Moves to Upgrade Popular 777 Passenger Jet
description: Boeings sales force is starting to pitch airlines and jet leasing companies on an updated, larger version of its 777 passenger jet, a crucial step toward winning approval from Boeings board to build the plane, Boeing officials said on Wednesday.

title: Quinn Announces Another Effort to Make Parking Meters More User-Friendly
description: There is a line from Bob Dylan, perhaps historys most prolific purveyor of misinterpreted lyrics, that reads: Dont follow leaders, watch the parking meters.

title: May Day Protests Around the World
description: Workers around the globe observed the international holiday with demonstrations and rallies.

title: Supporters Rally for Immigration Overhaul
description: Tens of thousands of immigrants, Latinos and other supporters of an overhaul of the immigration system turned out on Wednesday.

title: Custodians of Rules Say Woods Made Error
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  It is the drop that nobody in the golf world seems able to, well, drop. On Wednesday, the sports ruling bodies issued their interpretation of Tiger Woodss rules violation at the Masters, 19 days later.

title: Subway Delays Were Up in 2012, a Group Finds
description: Almost immediately after Hurricane Sandy delivered unprecedented flooding to New York Citys subway system, transit officials predicted that train delays could increase in the months and even years that followed.

title: Youkilis, Now on D.L., Gets Diagnosis and Epidural
description: Kevin Youkilis revealed Wednesday that a bulging L4 disk in his spine was the cause of his back pain, forcing him onto the disabled list and necessitating an epidural.

title: Amid Fealty to Socialism, a Nod to Capitalism
description: HAVANA  In many ways, it was a typical May Day: Hundreds of thousands of Cuban workers  doctors, sailors, dancers, bank clerks  marched Wednesday toward this citys vast Revolution Plaza, waving flags, holding aloft banners that proclaimed fidelity to socialism and tooting plastic horns.

title: Viacom and Time Warner Report Lower Revenue
description: Despite strong performances from their cable television channels, Viacom and Time Warner both suffered from sluggishness at their film divisions in the most recent quarter, which hindered the companies overall performances.

title: 13 Years After His Fathers Killing, a Bronx Teenager Meets the Same Fate
description: Two weeks before his fourth birthday, his father was fatally shot leaving a bodega.

title: Cond Nast Introduces Web Series for Magazines
description: Last year, the latest innovation every magazine wanted to release was an iPad edition. This year, its online video content.

title: Bob Brozman, Guitarist, Is Dead at 59
description: Bob Brozman, a guitarist and self-described roving guitar anthropologist who collaborated with musicians from Northern Ireland to Guinea to India to Papua New Guinea, died on April 23 at his home in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 59.

title: What the Oregon Health Study Cant Tell
description: The Oregon Health Study  one of the most important public-policy studies of the last decade  released a new round of results on Wednesday, showing that Medicaid coverage does not seem to make low-income adults much healthier, judging by biometric data. At least, that is one fair way to interpret the results, and it is basically the way the authors put it at the top of their new paper.

title: Trade Policy Notes
description: Just finished the semester (except for the grading); and I did promise to post class notes for WWS543, trade policy. Not all classes included slide shows, but here are the ones that did (for technical reasons, Ill have to finish a couple of links later this week). All links are pdf.

title: Orville Slutzky, a Founder of a Ski Resort, Dies at 96
description: Orville Slutzky, who with his brother founded the Hunter Mountain ski resort in upstate New York, known in the 1960s for its celebrity clientele and in the 1970s and 80s for its unmatched number of snow-making cannons, died on April 18 in Hudson, N.Y. He was 96.

title: A Commander Seeks to Chart a New Path for Special Operations
description: WASHINGTON  Not long after Adm. William H. McRaven led the mission to kill Osama bin Laden, he was put in charge of the nations entire contingent of Special Operations forces, and set to work revamping them to face a widening array of new threats as Americas combat role in the Middle East and southwest Asia winds down.

title: Is That God Talking?
description: I still remember how startled I was when a young woman I was interviewing told me God had spoken to her, audibly.

title: U.S. Agency Is Expelled From Bolivia
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia  President Evo Morales expelled the United States Agency for International Development from Bolivia on Wednesday, suggesting that it had conspired against his leftist government.

title: A Mortgage Agency Pick Is Likely to Cause Conflict
description: President Obamas overhaul of the mortgage market has been a long time coming.

title: Whos Sorry Now
description: Back when Sandra Day OConnor was still on the Supreme Court, busy saving affirmative action and the right to abortion, liberals who wanted a reason to forgive her vote in Bush v. Gore often asked me  begged me  to assure them that Justice OConnor was sorry.

title: Waiting and Waiting ... for Justice
description: LATE in the summer of 2011, police officers in New York City arrested a full-time college student named Luis in the lobby of his apartment building in the Bronx and charged him with two misdemeanor offenses, obstructing governmental administration and resisting arrest.

title: Cross-Country Solar Plane Expedition Set for Takeoff
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  When Bertrand Piccard was growing up in Switzerland, heady discussions about the boundless potential for human endeavor were standard fare.

title: A Surprise Favorite for Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Entering Kentucky Derby week, the undefeated Verrazano was expected by many to be the morning-line favorite. But after a blazing workout Monday that had the trainer Shug McGaughey smiling from ear to ear, Orb ran away with that honor when the field was drawn Wednesday.

title: Cablevision Picks Up Glenn Becks Internet Channel
description: Glenn Becks Internet channel TheBlaze has been picked up by the cable system operated by Cablevision, giving Mr. Beck television distribution in the New York metropolitan area for the first time since he left Fox News in 2011.

title: Immigration Is on Agenda for Obama in Mexico
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama flies across the southern border on Thursday to meet with his Mexican counterpart, the most delicate topic on the agenda will be immigration.

title: Here Comes the Buzz
description: IT may not be as grand as the wildebeest migrations across Africas eastern savanna or the march of emperor penguins across miles of Antarctic ice to their inland nesting areas. But it is a wildlife phenomenon not seen elsewhere in the world.

title: Why I Am Signing Marriage Equality Into Law
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

title: Defense in Fraud Trial Blames Failed U.S. Effort to Charge Liu
description: Lawyers for two former associates of John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller, asked a jury on Wednesday to acquit their clients of conspiring in an illegal campaign finance scheme that was to benefit Mr. Liu, now a Democratic candidate for mayor.

title: Banks Ease Capital Cost of Loans to Brokers
description: To attract financial advisers, brokerage firms often offer them loans. They are loans with a difference, however.

title: Exorbitant Prices for Leukemia Drugs
description: Last year we were heartened when doctors at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York refused to use an outrageously overpriced drug for treating advanced colorectal cancer because it was no better than a cheaper (but still costly) alternative. Neither did much to extend a patients life. Now the revolt against unjustifiably high cancer drug prices has been joined by more than 100 leukemia experts from more than 15 countries.

title: Preying on Pensioners
description: During the run-up to the mortgage crisis, elderly people were often duped into taking out subprime loans that earned a fortune for the lenders while leaving the borrowers with little or no home equity and headed for foreclosure. A similar brand of wealth stripping is alive and well in a new crop of companies that specialize in separating retirees from their pensions. Unless state and federal regulators get a handle on this problem, ever larger numbers of elderly people who are already battered by the recession will end up even worse off.

title: Italys New Government
description: More than two months after an inconclusive election, Italy at last has a new government, an essential first step on the road to political and economic recovery.

title: Fairness on Sales Taxes
description: Twenty-one years is a long time to wait. But that is how long local retailers have waited for Congress to undo a 1992 Supreme Court decision that exempted many online retailers, like Amazon.com, from collecting most state sales taxes. The exemption has given online sellers a 5 percent to 10 percent price advantage over Main Street stores.

title: The Juice, the Jousting and the Job
description: During Tuesdays presidential news conference, Jonathan Karl of ABC News asked the president if he still had the juice to get the rest of his agenda through Congress.

title: Federal Suit Claims Police Distort Marijuana Searches to Create Misdemeanors
description: One man was walking home with groceries. Another was on a break from his job at a meat market. A third was walking down the street listening to headphones.

title: The Luv Guvs Last Stand
description: Former South Carolina Gov. Mark Sanfords fight for post-Appalachian Trail forgiveness ends Tuesday with a big Congressional election. The focus, of course, is on issues, issues, issues.

title: Taxi-Hailing Apps Blocked by Judge
description: On Wednesday, a day after New York Citys taxi riders were allowed to hail yellow cabs with smartphones for the first time, an appeals court judge temporarily blocked the citys pilot program for the apps  forcing the Bloomberg administration to delay its plan for the second time in less than two months.

title: The Right to Speak Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexican Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Jobs and Fed Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Obamas Call to Close Guantnamo
description: To the Editor:

title: The Ethics of Force-Feeding Inmates
Times Names New Editors for Politics and Metro Desk
description: The New York Times on Wednesday named Carolyn Ryan, its metropolitan editor, the papers top political editor.

title: Health Care for the Young
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloomberg and Police Stops
description: To the Editor:

title: In Cyberspace, Forever
description: To the Editor:

title: Lottery Numbers
Online Video Woos Madison Avenue
description: During the week-long Digital Content NewFronts, companies like AOL, Hulu and Yahoo present new programming to attract advertising dollars from marketers and agencies.

title: In the Nets With M.S.
description: ST. PAUL  It happened too fast. Josh Harding, the backup goalie for the Minnesota Wild, never saw starter Niklas Backstrom crumple to the ice during warm-ups Tuesday night. The Wilds captain, Mikko Koivu, yelled for Harding to take over as trainers helped Backstrom to the dressing room at the United Center in Chicago with an apparent left leg injury.

title: Web Content Creators Focus on Spanish Speakers
description: For several years, networks and channels with programming aimed at Hispanic viewers have been increasing their presence during the annual television industry ritual known as upfront week, when advertisers and agencies are wooed before the coming fall season. Now, as creators of online video content are seeking the same money from Madison Avenue, they, too, are talking about their efforts to reach Spanish-speaking consumers.

title: An Effort to Add a Key Ingredient to the Slow Food Movement: Investor Money
description: BOULDER, Colo.  Welcome, pig lovers, and welcome, earthworms! Woody Tasch bellowed from the stage of the Boulder Theater, where 650 food entrepreneurs and investors had wedged themselves for the opening day of the fourth Slow Money National Gathering.

title: Political Chaos Grips Venezuela After Legislative Brawl and Rival Marches
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia  Venezuela stumbled deeper into political chaos this week as legislators brawled in the National Assembly and government supporters and opponents took to the streets for rival marches amid continuing tensions over the narrow election victory of President Nicols Maduro.

title: Cellphone Thefts Grow, but the Industry Looks the Other Way
description: When a teenage boy snatched the iPhone out of Rose Chas hand at a bus stop in the Bronx in March, she reported the theft to her carrier and to the police  just as she had done two other times when she was the victim of cellphone theft. Again, the police said they could not help her.

title: Video of Turkmen Leaders Spectacular Fall Foils Effort to Cover Up Accident
description: The leader of Turkmenistan learned this week just how difficult it can be to maintain a cult of personality in the Internet era, when the official account of his dashing triumph in a horse race on Sunday was undermined by video footage posted on foreign Web sites, showing what state television had failed to mention  the presidents spectacular fall to the track seconds after his horse crossed the finish line.

title: Crossed by a Center Line
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  I really enjoyed this crunchy, word drop puzzle by Josh Knapp, although it took me a while to tumble to the theme. Thankfully, theres a very clever reveal in the center of his 15-by-16 grid, and I especially liked the fact that the entry NEITHER/NOR is kind of a whole phrase unto itself even though the complete reveal is NEITHER [HERE] NOR [THERE]. Thats an elegant theme concept right THERE.

title: Florida Runs Out of Time on Medicaid
description: MIAMI  Prospects for Medicaid expansion in Florida, which was embraced, improbably, by the states Republican governor in February, are all but dead this year.

title: Thumping Barcelona Again, Bayern Eases Into the Final
description: In the end, Barcelonas mission was indeed impossible.

title: Libya: 3 Sought for Questioning in Benghazi Attack
description: The F.B.I. on Wednesday released photos of three men whom investigators want to question in connection with the attacks on a United States diplomatic mission and C.I.A. outpost in Benghazi, Libya, last September. A statement by the bureau said the three were on the grounds of the United States Special Mission when it was attacked. Four people  including the United States ambassador to Libya  died in the attacks.

title: Egypt: Critic of Morsi Is Jailed
description: Egyptian authorities jailed an anti-Islamist activist late Tuesday on charges that included insulting President Mohamed Morsi, state news media said. After turning himself in to prosecutors, the activist, Ahmed Douma, was transferred to a prison to be held for four days. Mr. Douma has been a vocal critic of Mr. Morsi and his allies in the Muslim Brotherhood, using social media and joining anti-Islamist protests. Human rights groups have accused Mr. Morsi and his allies of targeting their critics in politically motivated prosecutions  a charge Mr. Morsis aides deny.

title: Court Papers Offer Details in Terror Case
description: The terrorism case landed on the public docket in Federal District Court in Brooklyn last year like a riddle. Prosecutors charged three foreign men arrested overseas with supporting a Somali terrorist group. They did not reveal details of the allegations against the men, their nationalities or even their connections to the United States.

title: Knicks Leave the Door Open
description: They planned for a funeral, a chance to bury past failures, painful memories and, most of all, the Boston Celtics. It would be a memorial and a celebration all in one, with the Knicks  dressed in black for the occasion  presiding over the last rites at stately Madison Square Garden.

title: Turned Loose, Ovechkin Once Again Turns Heads
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  Alex Ovechkin was one of the last players on the ice for the Washington Capitals first postseason practice Monday, but he quickly made up for any lost time. While his teammates glided in circles around the rink, Ovechkin hit the ice at nearly full speed and dashed toward the first idle puck he saw, slamming it into the back of the vacant net.

title: In Russian Social Media, Glimpse of Students Accused of Hiding Boston Evidence
description: On April 18, the day before Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was captured as a suspect in the bombings at the Boston Marathon, a friend from the University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth posted photos of them together on VKontakte, the Russian social network.

title: In Nets-Bulls, Whos Hurt? Who Isnt?
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  On the eve of Thursdays Game 6 of a back-and-forth, battering series between the Nets and the Chicago Bulls, both teams appeared to be surviving on ice, athletic tape and willpower, and not in that particular order.

title: Guns and Political Suicide
description: Does Bill Daley, a former White House chief of staff, have the right to complain that Heidi Heitkamp, the first-year Democratic Senator from North Dakota, refused to commit political suicide after taking his $2,500 contribution?

title: Some Retailers Rethink Role in Bangladesh
description: Ever since a building with garment factories collapsed in Bangladesh last week, killing more than 400 people, Western apparel companies with ties to the country have scrambled to address public concerns about working conditions there.

title: Man Charged After Body Is Dug Up in Queens Yard
description: The search for a missing Queens man took investigators from a Broad Channel bird sanctuary to a Yonkers casino to a trailer on a dirt road in rural West Virginia.

title: Empty Seats at the State Department
description: Like many other areas of the administration, the State Department has many vacancies in its top ranks. As of the beginning of May, 16 of the departments 59 top jobs were vacant or filled with men and women performing the duties in an acting capacity.

title: Coachs Observation Helps Save Yankees
description: Moments before Houston Astros pitcher Wesley Wright threw the pitch, the Yankee first-base coach Mick Kelleher told Lyle Overbay to be careful. Kelleher, a former major league infielder, had noticed something seemingly small, but big enough to determine the outcome of the game.

title: For North Korea, Another Bargaining Chip?
description: BEIJING  Has North Korea got another American hostage? And will a former president have to pack his bags and head to Pyongyang to plead for the hostages release?

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday and Friday because of Orthodox Holy Thursday and Good Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: U.S. Rules Bar Aid to Co-ops Hit by Sandy
description: At the Beverly Hills co-op in Brooklyn, the wallpaper in the lobby is peeling by the yard. The walls themselves show cracks and holes, as if assaulted by a sledgehammer. The boiler is barely sputtering along and may not last the year.

title: Smith Back on Court, but His Shots Are Off
description: J. R. Smith said the word humble six times after the Celtics beat the Knicks, 92-86, on Wednesday night in Game 5 of their playoff series. It fit Smiths demeanor after one of his worst performances of the season.

title: Lending Web Site Gains a Shareholder in Google
description: A fast-growing marketplace for peer-to-peer loans, Lending Club, has attracted a prominent investor: Google.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, May 2
description: This is called slave labor.

title: Word of the Day | compliance
description: compliance \km-pli-n(t)s\ noun

title: Corrections: May 2, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Knicks vs. Celtics: Game 5
description: The Knicks stumbled through another four quarters Wednesday night as the Celtics took a 92-86 victory, extending this first-round series for at least another two days.

title: Spread of Hydrofracking Could Strain Water Resources in West, Study Finds
description: The rapid expansion of hydraulic fracturing to retrieve once-inaccessible reservoirs of oil and gas could put pressure on already-stressed water resources from the suburbs of Fort Worth to western Colorado, according to a new report from a nonprofit group that advises investors about companies environmental risks.

title: North Korea Imposes Term of 15 Years on American
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said Thursday that its Supreme Court had sentenced an American citizen to 15 years of hard labor for committing hostile acts against its government.

title: Celtics Take Exception to Comments and Color
description: Celtics guard Jason Terry sat in the visitors locker room with his knees, feet and right thumb covered in ice, reflecting on Bostons apparent rise from the dead in this first-round series against the Knicks.

title: Whats On Thursday
description: 6:30 P.M. (HBO2) THE IRON GIANT (1999) In this animated tale set during the height of cold-war nuclear anxiety, a young boy named Hogarth (voiced by Eli Marienthal) discovers and befriends a 50-foot-tall robot (Vin Diesel) from outer space that has crash-landed in his small town. Hogarth must hide the robot from his mother (Jennifer Aniston) and protect it from an overzealous government agent (Christopher McDonald) who wants it destroyed. Directed by Brad Bird, The Iron Giant is a smooth, skilled example of animated filmmaking, Lawrence Van Gelder said in The New York Times, adding, Many adults, including parents eager to have their children absorb lessons about the perils of guns and the merits of peace and tolerance, will doubtless approve of the films messages while they ponder how the passing years have smoothed the jagged edges of history.

title: Indian Prisoner in Pakistan Dies After Beating, Prompting Angry Reply From India
description: MULTAN, Pakistan  An Indian man on death row in Pakistan for espionage has died after being attacked by fellow inmates, Pakistans state television said early Thursday, prompting an angry response from India.

title: Singh, Citing Injury, Withdraws
description: After showing no signs of physical distress on the Quail Hollow range a day earlier, Vijay Singh, citing a back injury, withdrew from the Wells Fargo Championship in Charlotte, N.C., on Wednesday morning, roughly 90 minutes before his scheduled pro-am tee time.

title: Jets Make Changes in Scouting
description: In what could be a prelude to a larger shakeup in player personnel, John Idzik made his first two changes to the Jets scouting department. The team will not retain Michael Davis, the assistant director of college scouting, and an area scout, Joe Bommarito, who was primarily responsible for the West Coast. Idzik had retained the scouts he inherited after being hired in January to preserve continuity as the Jets prepared for last weeks draft. But with the draft over, it is likely that Idzik will revamp the Jets player personnel department and select his own people.

title: News Quiz | May 2, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: China Accused of Denying Care to Dissidents Imprisoned Nephew
description: BEIJING  Human rights advocates have accused the authorities in eastern China of denying urgent medical care to the jailed nephew of the blind dissident Chen Guangcheng, a move they say is aimed at punishing Mr. Chen for his continued antigovernment activism abroad after his daring escape to the United States Embassy in Beijing last year.

title: IHT Quick Read: May 2
description: NEWS As workers around the world observed the international Labor Day holiday with demonstrations and rallies, thousands of Greeks walked off their jobs on Wednesday in the second general strike against government austerity measures this year, shutting down tax offices, leaving state hospitals to operate with emergency employees and disrupting public transportation. The Greek protest came as workers in Asia, including Bangladeshis infuriated by the lethal collapse of a garment factory, demonstrated in cities including the capitals of Cambodia, Indonesia and the Philippines. In Istanbul, riot police officers sprayed throngs of people with water and tear gas as they gathered for a rally, defying an official ban. Niki Kitsantonis and Alan Cowell report.

title: Is Sexual Abuse of Minors Worse in India? Ink Readers Debate
description: The recent death of a 4-year-old girl from Madhya Pradesh, who succumbed to her injuries days after she was raped and dumped near a crematorium in her hometown of Ghansor, has evoked an overwhelming response from India Ink readers.

title: Test Yourself | English, May 2, 2013
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article As East Midtown Girds for Taller Buildings, Squat Relics Endure.

title: A Video Game Company That Pays Attention to Detail
description: In Where the Artists Are the Superheroes, Caitlin Kelly writes about the video game company Ubisoft.

title: In Pursuit of Happiness
High Fashions Ambassador From the Midwest
description: At 9 oclock on a Sunday morning during Fashion Week, Jonathan Simkhai, a 27-year-old designer, awoke to the sound of his cellphone ringing. It was Goods and Services, his showroom, calling. Ikram Goldman, the owner of the Chicago boutique Ikram, wanted to see him immediately. Simkhai, who had stayed out late celebrating his successful runway show, had fallen asleep only a few hours earlier. But I jumped out of bed, he said.

title: Robert Diamonds Next Life
description: In the sparse office he now occupies in the Seagram Building in Midtown Manhattan, Robert E. Diamond Jr., the former C.E.O. of Barclays, paced in circles and tried to explain how he had gone from being one of the highest-ranking and highest-paid bankers in Britain to a guy who takes the subway to this office in exile and waits in line for his coffee at a cart on Park Avenue. Not to suggest that times are too tough for Diamond  hes not complaining, and he still has more money than his grandchildrens grandchildren will ever need. But for the American investment banker who was arguably responsible more than anyone else for transforming the British finance industry, it has been a pretty spectacular fall.

title: Silicon Valleys Start-Up Machine
description: Michelle Crosby, an energetic 37-year-old lawyer in Boise, Idaho, applied for a loan last November from a local bank, Western Capital. She proposed to use the money, $10,000, to help start a new business, Wevorce, which could be described most reductively as an H&R Block for divorces. The bankers liked the idea, and Crosby was a strong candidate. They had even given her an earlier loan to open Wevorces first office. But after four weeks, the bank was stalling and Crosby had yet to receive a cent. At the height of her frustration, she received an e-mail from a small group of private investors in Mountain View, Calif. They invited her to an interview and, after listening to her story, promised her $100,000 in exchange for a 7 percent stake in Wevorce. Crosby accepted on the spot. The next day, she found a condo for rent, at $2,500 a month, in Mountain View, and left Boise, and her boyfriend, behind.

title: Capturing a Vanishing New York
description: Sid Kaplan, a master black-and-white printer and photographer, is the darkroom equivalent of the session man  the go-to guy famous musicians revere and want to work with, but known to few people outside the industry. He made most of Robert Franks prints for more than three decades, as well as many of Louis Stettners and Cornell Capas. Yet, people dont stand in front of those prints in galleries and say, I bet thats a Sid Kaplan.

title: The Case for Megabanks Fails
description: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Is Prom Worth It?
description: 7:47 a.m. | Updated

title: Boom, Bust or What?
description: One cold late-winter afternoon, Larry Summers was standing by the free-throw line at Lavietes Pavilion, on the Harvard campus, somberly shooting a basketball. In the past couple of years, Summers has sworn off Diet Coke, gluten and junk food and lost a fair amount of weight. As a result, his gray White House T-shirt billowed over his loose gym shorts. Summers, the former Treasury secretary and celebrated economist, is well known for his cutting wit and laserlike focus; he is less well known for his jump shot. But Summers, who recalls with anguish being cut from his high-school basketball team, never let his gaze wander as he took, and missed, nearly every shot. Two Harvard players ran down his rebounds.

title: Is This the Best Education Money Can Buy?
description: One night last winter, more than 120 parents filed into the black-box theater at Avenues: The World School in Chelsea, to learn about what their kids were eating. Ever since the $85 million for-profit start-up opened its doors in September, food had been a divisive issue. After the first week of classes, a group of parents sent a seven-page e-mail detailing concerns: there were not enough snacks, not enough worldly snacks like seaweed, zucchini bread with quinoa flour and bean quesadillas (so long as the beans came from BPA-free tin cans). Unlike other New York City private schools, with their decades of institutional wisdom, Avenues was founded on the premise that its parents were partners in building a new community. So it was ready to hear them out.

title: In Ikram Goldmans Hands, I Became a Model Student
description: I didnt think for a moment that anything I wore to Ikram, one of the most prestigious boutiques in the country, would ever be considered chic by anyone who knows anything about what chic actually is. So I went for a look that I hoped appeared, at least, as if it was not trying too hard, a look suitable for midwinter in Chicago, where Ikram is located: a knee-length black skirt, suede black boots, a delicate black and beige top and a short, thick, green cardigan. It was an ensemble meant to announce its own modest aspirations. In retrospect, I wish Id worn a black cardigan instead of the green one, but in the eyes of Ikram Goldman, the owner of the store, the details wouldnt have mattered anyway, since the very premise of my message, to her, would be considered absurd: for Ikram, the whole point of clothing is to broadcast something bold.

title: Shell Chief to Leave Next Year
description: LONDON  Royal Dutch Shells chief executive, Peter Voser, plans to retire next year, after a decade in top management jobs in which he helped the company recover from an accounting scandal and become the world leader in liquefied natural gas and related businesses.

title: Syrian Forces Strike Rebels in Wide-Ranging Assaults
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian forces carried out what antigovernment activists described as furious assaults against a range of insurgent enclaves on Thursday, seeking to snap a stalemate in the central city of Homs, attacking rebels ensconced in a seaport near Russias naval station and apparently destroying a historic bridge in the contested city of Deir al-Zour.

title: Think Like a Doctor: An Unusual Headache
description: The Challenge: A young woman develops a headache along with nausea and vomiting. Days later, she lapses into a coma. Can you figure out why?

title: The Early Word: Control
description: In Todays Times

title: Epic EV Torq: Three Wheels + One Electric Motor = Interesting
description: Morgan Motor Companys 1930s-retro 3-Wheelers are cool. Of that theres little doubt. Theyre light, fast and guaranteed conversation starters. But what if you took that same Morgan, made it look all futuristic and replaced its noisy V-twin motorcycle engine with a silent, powerful electric motor?

title: United States Calls on North Korea to Free American
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The United States said Thursday that North Korea should immediately release an American citizen who was sentenced this week to 15 years of hard labor, setting up a potential new source of confrontation between the two countries that could aggravate tensions that are still high over North Koreas nuclear war threats.

title: Fighting the Consultant Temptation
description: Most small businesses wont touch them with a 10-foot pole, but corporate America has had a long, slobbering love affair with them. I am talking about consultants. The question is, should fast-growth companies use them?

title: Obama Picks Nominees for Commerce Dept. and Trade Representative
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama rounded out his second-term cabinet choices on Thursday, nominating Penny Pritzker, his longtime financial backer and an heir to the Hyatt Hotel fortune, to be commerce secretary, and Michael Froman, a law school friend and White House adviser on international economics, as trade representative.

title: Activist Investor Seeks Breakup of UBS
description: LONDON  The activist investment firm Knight Vinke called for the breakup of the Swiss bank UBS on Thursday, days after it reported strong first-quarter earnings.

title: The Judgment that Acquitted Congress Party Leader Sajjan Kumar
description: NEW DELHI The acquittal of Sajjan Kumar, the Indian Congress Party leader, for his alleged role in the 1984 anti-Sikh riots that killed thousands in Delhi has sparked widespread protests.

title: Daily Report: Police Say Better Technology Is Needed to Cut Phone Thefts
description: Police officials say the cellphone industry has not done enough with technology to stanch the ever-rising numbers of handset thefts,  Brian X. Chen and Malia Wollan report Thursday in The New York Times.

title: Milestone Nears on Curve Charting the Human Imprint on the Atmosphere
description: For hundreds of thousands of years preceding the industrial revolution, the concentration of the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide in the atmosphere didnt exceed 280 parts per million. Now it is poised to pass 400 parts per million, thanks to the burst of fossil fuel combustion and forest clearing thats accompanied humanitys recent growth spurt.

title: With Benedicts Return, Vatican Experiment Begins
description: VATICAN CITY  When Benedict XVI, the pope emeritus, returned to Vatican City on Thursday, two months after his retirement, he inaugurated a living arrangement as unusual as it may be unpredictable.

title: A Rate Cut in Europe, and a Hint of Limits
description: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia  The European Central Bank cut its benchmark interest rate to a record low on Thursday. But its president, Mario Draghi, indicated that his promise last year to do whatever it takes to save the euro had limits.

title: Thursday Reading: Tile Your Bathroom Floor (if You Dare)
Bang, Boom: Terrorism as a Game
description: Right before I saw Iron Man 3, a publicist implored the several hundred attendees  professionals and civilians jammed into a multiplex box and throbbing with excitement  not to reveal any crucial information about the movie to anyone else. After the final credits rolled, and I staggered toward the exit, the booms of explosions still ringing in my ears, I wondered what I could possibly divulge that would spoil the pleasure of an innocent ticket buyer. After all, originality isnt the point of a product like Iron Man 3, which, despite the needless addition of 3-D and negligible differences in quips, gadgets, villains and the type of stuff blown up, plays out much like the first two movies.

title: Diamond, in the Rough
description: Robert E. Diamond Jr., former chief executive of Barclays, has gone from being one of the highest-ranking and highest-paid bankers in Britain to a guy who takes the subway to an office in exile, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in an article for The New York Times Magazine. Its hard for me to talk about it, Mr. Diamond said. Ive tried to move on.

title: What They Said: Indian National Sarabjit Singh Dies in Pakistan
description: Sarabjit Singh, an Indian man on death row in Pakistan, died Thursday after being attacked by fellow inmates in a Pakistani prison. He was convicted for espionage in relation to bombings in two Pakistani cities in 1990.

title: A Missed Opportunity to Drive the Subway
description: Dear Diary:

title: A Border Clash Stirs Emotions in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghan forces claimed on Thursday that they had overrun and destroyed a Pakistani-held border crossing in a remote area, an event that provoked a spontaneous outpouring of nationalist sentiment here, sending thousands of students into the streets to demonstrate and setting off lively debate on social networking sites.

title: What to do About Syria?
description: Obamas continuing conundrum over what to do about Syria.

title: In China, Iron Mans Muscle Is Fed by Inner Mongolian Milk
description: HONG KONG  When it comes to pop culture, Hong Kong and mainland China follow two sets of rules.

title: Indonesia Struggles to End Fuel Subsidies
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The fruit and vegetables that slowly gather flies in the morning heat at the Bendungan Hilir market in central Jakarta include both imported and Indonesian produce, but according to local sellers, origin does not matter: Everything is expensive.

title: Housing Project Meets Art Project in the South Bronx
description: Temporary public art projects are plentiful in New York City but they rarely make their way to the South Bronx and almost never to the grounds of public housing projects. But beginning this month the Swiss artist Thomas Hirschhorn, with the help of the Dia Art Foundation, will build the last in a series of temporary monuments at the Forest Houses, a New York City Housing Authority development in the Morrisania neighborhood of the Bronx.

title: Planning for Another 100 Million Web Sites
description: More than 20 years after the advent of the World Wide Web, some might argue that it has already yielded a surfeit of Web pages, mobile sites, and the digital equivalent of shiny time wasters.

title: Monochrome Wallpaper
description: Since remodeling my new London apartment, I have been on the look out for new wallpapers. I did a major trawl and returned to my office with quite a few black-and-white options.

title: Fire Devastates Businesses in Bronx, and Neighborhood Laments Loss
description: A call from a relative early on Thursday delivered the crushing news to Louleo Darga: The small hair salon she had owned in the Bronx since she came to the United States from Burkina Faso a quarter of a century ago had been consumed by fire.

title: Iraqs Kurds at the Eye of Regional Storm
description: ERBIL, Iraq  Hoshyar Zebari, the Iraqi foreign minister, has been on self-imposed gardening leave for the past few weeks, having moved from Baghdad to his native Kurdistan as part of a Kurdish boycott of the central government.

title: G.M.s Profit Falls 14% as It Speaks of Progress
description: DETROIT  General Motors said on Thursday that its net income declined 14 percent to $865 million in the first quarter, as it earned less money than a year ago in the surging North American car market.

title: SAC to Begin Clawing Back Compensation in Insider Trading Cases
description: 7:54 p.m. | Updated

title: Lesson From Bangladesh: Cheap Childrens Clothes Are Expensive
description: I shouldnt be able to buy a T-shirt for less than the price of a Frappuccino.

title: Forum for New Diplomacy
description: Fatou Bensouda, chief prosecutor for the International Criminal Court, in conversation with Marlise Simons, correspondent for The New York Times.

title: Partnering for Peace and International Security
description: There is a perception that Africa is not cooperating with the court...when in reality, this is not the case.

title: N.H.T.S.A. Investigates Dodge Viper, Ford Crown Victoria and Porsche 911
description: A pit of vipers sounds like trouble, which may be what the Chrysler Group is in concerning its 2005-6 Dodge Vipers. Citing a concern about rear suspension failures, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration opened an investigation covering about 2,500 of the sports cars, according to a report posted on the agencys Web site.

title: Exterminator, a Long Shot to Remember
description: A long shot will seize your attention during the Kentucky Derby television coverage. Among the biopics of sure things and heartwarming stories about trainers and owners will appear a brief moment with that horse who should not win the race. The announcer might mention Mine That Bird (2009 winner; odds of 50-1) or Giacomo (2005, also 50-1) to prove that sometimes the seemingly impossible happens.

title: In the Playoffs, There Is Room for Panic
description: The rumblings always start when an expected sweep turns into a 3-1 series. It grows into a howl when the series reaches 3-2 and everyone starts wondering if this is the year, finally, for the ultimate comeback. Maybe the favorite did not just nap through a game or two, people start to wonder, maybe they are just not as good as advertised. And then, almost always before things become really interesting, the favorite wins and everybody remembers this is the N.B.A., not hockey or baseball, and N.B.A. does not do upsets, at least not big ones. They are so unstylish. Celebrity fans find them so inconvenient.

title: What Were Reading
description: The New York Post: Chelsea Clinton on Mario Batali at the Food Bank for New York 30th Anniversary Can Do Awards Dinner: Its not hyperbole to say I could not imagine my life in New York or really my life in general without Mario. The first meal I shared with the man I am now very happy to call my husband and the people I am now very happy to call my husbands in-laws, otherwise known as my parents, was at Babbo. Thankfully, that went well.  Maria Newman

title: Shares of INGs U.S. Unit Rise 7% in Debut
description: 1:39 p.m. | Updated

title: New Chief at Intel Aims to Expand Chip Making
description: Brian M. Krzanich, who on Thursday was named Intels next chief executive, knows he faces a hefty challenge when he takes over the worlds biggest maker of semiconductors.

title: Lazard Hires Slaughter, a Former JPMorgan Deal Maker
description: The investment bank Lazard said on Thursday that it had hired Larry Slaughter, who was most recently a co-head of North American investment banking for JPMorgan Chase. He is the latest senior deal maker to join Lazard.

title: In First Round, Ovechkin Isnt the Only Story
description: WASHINGTON  The N.H.L. first-round series that begins Thursday night may seem like Ovechkin versus the Rangers, but there are many other tactical story lines at work, many of them hidden deep within the numbers. Here is a glance at some of them.

title: Feeling For | Fire Island Memories
description: This year, Fire Islands legendary enclave the Pines celebrates its 60th anniversary season, but its real heyday dates to the 1970s and early 80s, when fit young men started streaming into the area, earning the Pines its reputation as a sand-swept gay bacchanal. Tom Bianchis Polaroids captured the liberated mood of those days, and theyre now collected in a handsome book, Tom Bianchi: Fire Island Pines (Damiani).

title: Top Speed From T-Mobiles New Network
description: 11:03 a.m. | Updated to correct which carrier has the largest national LTE network.

title: If You Like Kool & the Gang, Try Daft Punk
description: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons generation.

title: Country Stars Tribute to George Jones Streaming Online
description: Not many funerals are held at the Grand Ole Opry in Nashville. But the service for George Jones, the hard-drinking singer considered by some critics to be the definitive country singer of the last half-century, is one of them. Today his funeral at the music hall, the closest thing that country music has to a cathedral, will be streamed live at 11 a.m. Eastern time on the Oprys Web site and in audio at wsmonline.com. It will also be broadcast live on several networks  CMT, GAC, RFD-TV and FamilyNet. The service is bound to feature some good music.The lineup of performers includes Charlie Daniels, Vince Gill, Alan Jackson, Ronnie Milsap, Brad Paisley, the Oak Ridge Boys, Tanya Tucker and Wynonna.

title: British TV Personality Pleads Guilty to Sex Abuse of Girls
description: LONDON  An elderly British television and radio personality has admitted to 14 counts of sexually abusing girls ages 9 to 17 decades ago, it emerged on Thursday. The broadcaster, Stuart Hall, 83, pleaded guilty to the charges last month, but the news media was prohibited from reporting the plea until now.

title: Rolls-Royce Aerospace Chief Resigns Unexpectedly
description: PARIS  Rolls-Royce, the British engineering group, on Thursday announced the surprise resignation of Mark King as chief of its aerospace business, barely four months after the 27-year company veteran had been appointed to run the groups most prestigious division, which builds engines for commercial and military aircraft.

title: From Church to Mosque to Museum Back to Mosque
description: ISTANBUL  In 1921 an ecumenical service was held in six languages at St. John the Divine, New York Citys Episcopal cathedral, to call for the return of Byzantiums most important monument to the Orthodox Church. Days after his 1453 conquest of Constantinople, todays Istanbul, Mehmet II decided to turn the 6th century basilica of St. Sophia into a mosque. Some 500 years later, with the city under Allied occupation, Christendom wanted the building back.

title: Tip of the Week: Find Your System Information Quickly
description: Want to buy that cool new video game but are unsure how much memory or what kind of processor your computer uses so you can make sure the software will work? Both Windows and Mac OS X keep these details, along with other hardware information, in a convenient place.

title: Q.& A.: Using Facebook Chat Heads
description: Q.

title: Life, Interrupted: All in a Days Work
description: The first time I fantasized about early retirement, I was 22 years old. It was a rainy spring morning in Paris, and as I waited for the Mtro to take me to my new paralegal job, it occurred to me that Id rather be sleeping in, or playing hooky at the movies, or sailing around the world. I felt grateful to have a job right out of college, but the real world that I discovered  long hours at the office making copies and taking orders from the all-male partners of the firm  was a rude awakening. I got a glimpse of a life that the French describe as Mtro boulot dodo (subway, work, sleep).

title: Poetry Pairing | Sales
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches Sales by W. S. Di Piero with the article Indo-Caribbean Content, Victorian Style by Vera Haller.

title: A Rag of Riches
description: CAIRO  This week I am one of many readers mourning the disappearance of Egypt Independent, a local English-language weekly that has provided sterling coverage of the Egyptian uprising in 2011 and the painful, deeply confusing transition that followed.

title: Unlikely Source of Energy Puts Celtics in Striking Distance
description: As the Celtics locker room emptied of players and reporters late Wednesday night, Terrence Williams peered over the shoulder of a team employee who was studying the box score on the screen of a laptop propped on a table.

title: Using the Old-School Method to Choose Between Amherst and Yale
description: The hardest part about choosing a college was making sure a schools brand name did not become a factor in my decision.

title: Big Opening for Iron Man 3 in China
description: LOS ANGELES Iron Man 3 has reasserted Hollywoods place in China, at least for the moment. Hollywood.com, citing a report from China, said the first days take on Wednesday for Marvel Entertainments action film was almost $21 million, beating the previous one-day record set by Transformers: Dark of the Moon in 2011.

title: Politics and Vetting Leave Key U.S. Posts Long Unfilled
description: WASHINGTON  John Kerry is practically home alone at the State Department, toiling without permanent assistant secretaries of state for the Middle East, Asia, Europe and Africa. At the Pentagon, a temporary personnel chief is managing furloughs for 800,000 civilian employees. There has not been a director of the Internal Revenue Service since last November, and it was only on Thursday that President Obama announced a nomination for commerce secretary after the job was open for nearly a year.

title: The Oregon Data and the Health Care Debate
description: The big news in health care today is the latest data from an ongoing study of Medicaid recipients in Oregon, which finds that while being on Medicaid improves peoples financial situation and boosts their mental well-being, in the interval studied the program seemed to have little or no statistically significant impact on their actual physical health. Ill try to have more to say about this over the weekend for now, I recommend readingMegan McArdle and Jonathan Cohn for a sense of the debate but since Ive been writing about the Republican Partys health policy problem this week I was struck by this line from Matt Yglesias, in a post mostly dismissing the significance of the new data:

title: The Gun Report: May 2, 2013
description: Last weekend, my new friend Jessica Mindich held a gun buyback in New Jersey. She really did. The company she runs, Jewelry For a Causewhich melts down guns and turns them into very cool-looking braceletsput up $33,000 in proceeds from bracelet sales, allowing the city of Newark to offer cash for guns. More than 200 guns were turned in, including a number of assault weapons. The city touted the success of the buyback with a press conference on Tuesday. Indeed, Mindich and Newark view the buyback as so successful they are planning to hold another one later this summer.

title: Europe Hopes Interest Rate Cuts Help
description: The Timess Nelson D. Schwartz on whether lowering interest rates can have sustained effects on slumping markets.

title: Use of Mortgage Interest Deduction Depends on Where You Live
description: An analysis from the Pew Charitable Trusts finds that the use of the mortgage interest deduction varies widely across the country, with concentrations on the East Coast and in the West, and in areas with higher property values. The average size of the deduction varies, too.

title: New Venture Firm Opens in New York
description: The field of enterprise technology has been particularly hot among investors recently, especially after a string of well-received public offerings.

title: Medicaid Nonsense
description: Busy day, no additional blogging until much later. But you should be reading The Incidental Economist on the Oregon Medicaid study thats creating a lot of fuss today. Basically, budget woes forced Oregon to allocate Medicaid access by lottery, giving a rare randomized experiment. Those who got Medicaid suffered much less financial distress and less depression; they received more preventive care; but on some (not all dimensions) their health wasnt significantly better than those who lost out in the lottery.

title: Talking to the 2014 Chevrolet Impala: G.M.s Improved MyLink
description: Talking to your car can be like trying to reason with a recalcitrant toddler. It often petulantly refuses to obey your commands or, worse, does the opposite of what you want. But in-vehicle voice recognition systems are gradually improving, as demonstrated by the new version of Chevrolets MyLink system.

title: For Sons of Raisin, a Back-to-Back Duel
description: BALTIMORE  When Kwame Kwei-Armah took the job of artistic director at this citys biggest theater, CenterStage, in the summer of 2011, he started hearing a drumbeat about one play in particular.

title: A Classics Behind-the-Scenes Drama
description: The tangled themes of Nikolai and the Others, a new play by Richard Nelson, swirl around the making of Orpheus, a work born from one of the most important partnerships in ballets history: the choreographer George Balanchine and the composer Igor Stravinsky.

title: Venture Capitals Rocky Road for Entrepreneurs
description: In my previous Deal Professor column, I wrote about a Delaware lawsuit involving a venture capital company, Bloodhound Technologies, and how it exposed venture capitals dirty little secret: in a sale, the founders are often left with nothing even if the venture capitalists profit.

title: Glencore Completes Deal for Xstrata
description: LONDON  One of the worlds largest deals in recent years has finally reached the finishing line.

title: American-Born Children Are at Higher Risk of Allergies
description: American children born outside the United States may have a significant advantage over the native-born: They are less likely to have allergies.

title: Market Report | Punk Pieces
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art pays homage to the style influence of iconic enfants terribles like Joe Strummer and Sid Vicious in the new exhibit Punk: Chaos to Couture, which will open to the public on May 9. T chimes in on the fashion conversation with a roundup of the chic counterculture legacy in todays market.

title: Instagram Deal Is Looking Better and Better
description: Facebooks Instagram option is looking like a better bet than it was a year ago. The social network agreed to shell out $1 billion for the revenue-free photo-sharing app. Even paid for partially in overvalued stock, the deal looked pricey. Instagrams growth spurt  it passed 100 million monthly users in the first quarter  suggests Facebook is turning a defensive move to its advantage.

title: For Mets Fans, Even 140 Characters Can Be Too Many
description: Those who use Twitter to comment about the Mets  from @MetsMerized and @kranepool to @TheHappyRecap and @metspolice  usually have plenty to say.

title: On the Outside, Looking In
description: Claire Messuds latest novel, The Woman Upstairs, is an incongruous mashup of a very self-consciously literary novel (invoking the likes of Chekhov) and one of those psychological horror films like Single White Female or The Hand That Rocks the Cradle, in which someone, ominously, is not who she appears to be.

title: Mapping Unwed Motherhood
description: The share of births to unmarried mothers is up, according to a new report from the Census Bureau.

title: Buyer & Cellar Moving to Larger Theater
description: Solo shows are having a mixed reception on Broadway, with the early closing of Testament of Mary (starring Fiona Shaw) on Sunday and the shut-outs of Ill Eat You Last (Bette Midler) and Macbeth (Alan Cumming) for Tony Award nominations this week. But Michael Uries one-man play Buyer & Cellar is flourishing Off Broadway: The critically acclaimed production, about a struggling actor who becomes an assistant of sorts to Barbra Streisand, will transfer from the 99-seat Rattlestick Playwrights Theater to a commercial run at the 199-seat Barrow Street Theater. After closing May 12 at Rattlestick, performances will resume June 18 at Barrow Street, initially for 10 weeks; the producers hope that ticket sales will be good enough to extend for an open-ended run.

title: Riding the Rail, Countryside
description: Korail, the Korean Railway, recently introduced two sightseeing trains that explore the countrys mountainous and rural areas. The O-train features observatory rooms and sightseeing monitors, and makes a five-hour loop around the central inland region, taking in deep gorges and stopping at 13 stations. The V-train travels round trip for 70 minutes down the Baekdudaegan mountain range, which runs most of the length of the Korean Peninsula.

title: Finding the Right Words to Confront a Showroomer
description: Two years ago, as Charles Kuhn struggled to steer Kopps Cycle, the bicycle shop he owns in Princeton, N.J., through a tenuous economic recovery, he noticed that fewer and fewer of the nominal customers in his shop were actually buying anything. Instead, he told The Agenda at the time, People come in with their smartphone and scan a bar code on a product that I have in my showroom, and what comes up on the phone is the three closest places and their price and then also what it is on Amazon.

title: Where China Meets India in a High-Altitude Desert, Push Comes to Shove
description: NEW DELHI  The disputed border region between India and China attracts troops from both countries, but two weeks ago the Chinese sent an unusual number of military patrols into the mountains of Ladakh, a remote high-altitude desert at the northern tip of India.

title: Photography and the Civil War
description: It isnt possible to tell the story of the American Civil War without recourse to the million photographic images that were created.

title: A Journey to the World of European Tech
description: Greetings from Germany!

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: An Invitation to Act Like Adults

title: Soccer Courses Through a Citys Veins
description: LONDON  There are 270 stations in the subway system here and, on a recent weekend afternoon, many were crowded with a brilliant palette of colored shirts and scarves that seemed to be moving in every direction.

title: Buffett Speaks and Tweets
description: Warren E. Buffett has built a following over the years with pithy and memorable aphorisms about investing.

title: British Activists Press Tax Case Involving Goldman Sachs
description: LONDON  A court case in Britain involving Goldman Sachs is drawing public attention to the tax breaks that the British government has used to tried to lure corporations.

title: Guns for Kids
description: There are many legitimate points of intense debate over the regulation of guns  including the question of whether the Second Amendment does or does not confer an individual right to own firearms. But surely there are some things we can agree on.

title: Air Pollutions Role in Heart Disease
description: Air pollution has been linked to cardiovascular disease, and now researchers may be closer to understanding why: it increases atherosclerosis, or hardening of the arteries, a known risk for heart attack and stroke.

title: Cameristas
description: Roughly 150 years ago, in March or April 1863, a shocking photograph was taken in Louisiana. Unlike most photos, it was given a title, The Scourged Back, as if it were a painting hanging in an art museum. Indeed, it fit inside a recognizable painters category  the nude  but this was a nude from hell. The sitter, an African-American male named Gordon, had been whipped so many times that a mountainous ridge of scar tissue was climbing out of his back. It was detailed, like a military map, and resulted from so many whippings that the scars had to form on top of one another. Gordon had escaped from a nearby Mississippi plantation to a camp of federal soldiers, supporting the great Vicksburg campaign of the spring. Medical officers examined him, and after seeing his back, asked a local photography firm, McPherson and Oliver, to document the scar tissue.

title: A Nutritious Meal, Even Faster
description: An hour just to make lunch?

title: Brantley, Isherwood Answer Readers Questions About the Theater Season
description: This week Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood, theater critics for The New York Times, took readers questions about the Broadway season and this weeks announcement of the Tony Award nominations. Below are their answers to selected questions.

title: Why a UBS Split Would Not Be the Best Move
description: UBS is the wrong target for an activist-led breakup. Knight Vinke has called on the Swiss bank to separate its risky investment banking business from the core wealth-management arm. The investment firm is right that no one would create a bank modeled on UBS as it is today. But it doesnt automatically follow that a breakup is the best strategy.

title: Quirks of the Game: Shooting Gets Tougher in the Playoffs
description: Quirks of the Game is a regular feature on The Timess sports blogs.

title: A Century of Proust
description: Staffers from The Times and other writers spend a week celebrating Proust to mark the 100th anniversary of Swanns Way, the first volume of his masterwork In Search of Lost Time.

title: Typed Lyrics to Unreleased Dylan Song Head to Auction
description: Izzy Young, who owned the Folklore Center in Greenwich Village during the height of the folk revival, is famous for having nurtured a young Bob Dylan when he first arrived in New York City. Mr. Dylan would hang around the back of Mr. Youngs store on Macdougal Street, listening to records and writing songs, and it was Mr. Young who organized Mr. Dylans first concert in the city in 1961.

title: Suicide Rates Rise Sharply in U.S.
description: Suicide rates among middle-aged Americans have risen sharply in the past decade, prompting concern that a generation of baby boomers who have faced years of economic worry and easy access to prescription painkillers may be particularly vulnerable to self-inflicted harm.

title: Decoded: YouTube and Television
description: The Timess Brian Stelter decodes a YouTube event designed to showcase offerings to advertisers, which highlighted the companys uneasy relationship with television.

title: Former Hedge Fund Trader Sentenced in Insider Case
description: It is a scene that has played out over and over at the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan.

title: Making Waves in Japan
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: A Leaders Test: Balancing Drive and Compassion
description: This interview with Wendy Lea, chief executive of Get Satisfaction, a customer experience platform, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Boyle Feels Good but Is Unlikely for Game 1
description: WASHINGTON  The injured Rangers Brian Boyle and Marc Staal skated with the team at the Verizon Center Thursday morning, but it did not seem likely that either would play in Game 1 of the playoff series against the Capitals Thursday night.

title: Crowning 1 World Trade Center
description: Looking a bit like a rocket taking flight, the spire of 1 World Trade Center was hoisted aloft on Thursday and set on a temporary platform atop the nearly completed building. When it is bolted into place at a later date, the spire will bring the building to a height of 1,776 feet.

title: Revisiting Some Well-Eyed Streets
description: The photographer Garry Winogrand refreshed classic street photography in the 1960s and 70s, influenced by (and influencing) the increasingly warped sensibility that had started to shape the broader culture. Using a snapshot style, he captured the nations unseemly nervous breakdown in stark black and white.

title: That Period Look, Ringlets and All
description: With her flowing red curls and the spray of freckles dusting her porcelain skin, Wrenn Schmidt looks like a Dante Gabriel Rossetti painting that has swanned off the canvas. She wears 1920s chiffons and cloches on the HBO series Boardwalk Empire, on which she plays Julia Sagorsky, the sympathetic girlfriend of the masked and disfigured tough guy Richard Harrow (Jack Huston), like a second skin. (HBO confirms that her character will return in the fourth season.) And the Mint Theater, which traffics exclusively in the curiosities of yesteryear, has drawn on Ms. Schmidts talents more than once, most recently in the title role of Katie Roche.

title: The Nance Extends Its Run
description: Performances of the Broadway play The Nance will be extended by eight weeks through August 11, Lincoln Center Theater announced on Thursday, aiming to capitalize on the Tony Award nomination this week for lead actor Nathan Lane.

title: Normandy Invasion Too Keen During Workout
description: The draw for post positions is complete, and the morning-line odds for the 139th running of the Kentucky Derby have been set. None of the key contenders appeared to be compromised by their post-position draw, so the Churchill Downs oddsmaker, Mike Battaglia, did not have to adjust the preliminary line he made before the draw. The favorites are Orb (7-2, Post 16) and Verrazano (4-1, Post 14).

title: My Tryout of Citis Price Protection Service
description: Awhile back, I wrote about a new service that Citigroup offers on its credit cards called Price Rewind. It lets cardholders register purchases, and then searches for the same items at lower prices. If it finds one, it refunds you the difference.

title: Corporate Jet Center Exposes Silicon Valleys Class Divide
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  The approval of a new corporate jet center at this citys struggling airport might have been just another losing skirmish in the battle between Silicon Valley billionaires and middle-class neighborhoods worried about noise pollution. Instead, it is becoming the latest symbol for the rapidly growing gap between the regions haves, with their private jets and untold wealth, and the have-nots, clinging to more modest lives in the dwindling number of communities they can afford.

title: Putting Politics Ahead of Science
description: Appearing before Planned Parenthoods annual convention last Friday, President Obama pledged his continuing support for womens reproductive rights. In a speech before the National Academy of Sciences on Monday, Mr. Obama promised to keep science a sphere not subject to politics or skewed by an agenda.

title: Albees New Play, Laying an Egg, Postponed Again
description: Edward Albees Laying an Egg, announced six weeks ago as a centerpiece of the Signature Theaters 2013-14 season, has been postponed for the second time, the company announced on Thursday. Mr. Albees work was originally to have had its world premiere as part of the Off Broadway companys 2011-12 season  its first at the Pershing Square Signature Center, its new Midtown space  but was postponed when the famously self-critical playwright, now 85, decided that it needed revamping.

title: Notes From the Recipe Tester: A Short Season for White Asparagus
description: Denise Landis has been testing recipes for The New York Times for more than 20 years. She is also the author of Dinner for Eight: 40 Great Dinner Party Menus for Friends and Family. She is @TheCooksCook on Twitter. Here, she explains how to prepare white asparagus, available only for a short time.

title: The Pritzker-Obama Relationship
description: The Timess Nicholas Confessore and Jodi Kantor on the long history between President Obama and his nominee for commerce secretary, Penny Pritzker.

title: Wheelies: The Electric Phantom Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Ill Seat You Last: Tony-Snubbed Shows Take Back Free Tickets
description: On Tuesday the Tony Award big shots had their say, spreading around nominations to 26 Broadway plays and musicals  and shutting out several others. Now some of the scorned are striking back: The producers of Bette Midlers hit play Ill Eat You Last and Alan Cummings mostly-one-man version of Macbeth are pulling back free tickets for many of the 868 Tony voters, and instead offering to sell them at standard prices of about $135 each.

title: Park Slope Food Co-op Takes Up New Cause: Saving a Hospital
description: The Park Slope Food Co-op, which fought a veritable civil war over whether to boycott Israeli products, has taken on a new cause clbre: the fight to save Long Island College Hospital.

title: Violations Found at Site of Garage Workers Drowning
description: The owners of a garage in TriBeCa where a worker drowned during Hurricane Sandy violated federal safety rules by leaving exit doors locked or improperly propped open as storm waters filled the underground lot, according to a report by federal investigators.

title: Ideas for English-Language Learners | Celebrating the End of the School Year
description: School calendars are different across the nation, so while classes may be in session for another two months where you teach, in another district, its time for prom, awards season and commencement.

title: Study Finds No Single Cause of Honeybee Deaths
description: WASHINGTON  The devastation of American honeybee colonies is the result of a complex stew of factors, including pesticides, parasites, poor nutrition and a lack of genetic diversity, according to a comprehensive federal study published on Thursday. The problems affect pollination of American agricultural products worth tens of billions of dollars a year.

title: Afghan Government Faces Cash Crunch
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government is supposed to cover less than half its own bills this year, yet achieving even that modest goal is proving an unexpected challenge, Afghan and Western officials said.

title: A Tobin Tax, Bankruptcy Style
description: The bankruptcy world just got its own financial transaction Tobin tax. Just like France. Sort of.

title: Cambodian Rattan: The Sculptures of Sopheap Pich
description: Metropolitan Museum of Art

title: How the Public Sees Obama
description: David Firestone wrote on this blog yesterday that Republicans in Congress want to deny the president anything he might want. Theyre driven by a desire to block him at every pass. Meanwhile, Maureen Dowd has been dissecting Mr. Obamas weaknesses, arguing that the president hates selling. (Read her two recent columns here and here).

title: Prospect
description: Inside the New American restaurant in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

title: Girl Found on Beach Was Killed, Autopsy Says
description: Nearly four months after the police found the naked body of a 14-year-old girl on a beach in Brooklyn, her death has been ruled a homicide, the citys medical examiner said on Thursday.

title: Feeling For | Tommy Hilfiger Surf Shack
description: The limited-edition Surf Shack capsule collection from Tommy Hilfiger features 12 laid-back, aprs-surf lifestyle pieces, like chambray playsuits and striped Baja-inspired pullovers, that will make packing for summer getaways a cinch. One standout accessory is a surfboard-shaped wooden clutch, which goes easily from seaside fun to evening drinks. The Surf Shack collection is available May 15 at Tommy Hilfiger stores throughout the United States and on the brands web site.

title: Basim Magdy: A Steady Progress of Nothingness
description: Newman Popiashvili

title: Sadie Benning: War Credits
description: Callicoon Fine Arts

title: Bloomberg Pays Tribute to The Financial Times, Reigniting Speculation on a Bid
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Wednesday night stoked speculation about his interest in acquiring The Financial Times at a breezy Upper East Side reception celebrating the newspapers 125th anniversary.

title: After the Entree, Far From an Afterthought
description: Here lies a grape, or what was once a grape, before it was rolled in powdered sugar, egg whites and grape juice, then left in a dehydrator until the frosting hardened into a shell and the grape inside deflated, becoming almost a raisin.

title: Kathy Ruttenberg: Nature of the Beast
description: Stux Gallery

title: Big Happens Here: Business Successes
description: An advertisement from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo's "The New New York Campaign."

title: Art and Antique Dealers League of America Spring Show NYC
description: Park Avenue Armory

title: Plans for a Memorial to Honor Tesla
description: Supporters of Nikola Tesla, who lighted the planet with alternating current but died penniless, announced on Thursday that they had completed the purchase of his decaying laboratory on Long Island and begun raising $10 million for its restoration and the establishment of a museum and educational memorial.

title: Defenseman Bounces Back, Taking Canadiens With Him
description: TORONTO  For defenseman P. K. Subban and the Montreal Canadiens, it felt like a long wait to erase memories of the 2011-12 season.

title: The Changing Face of Medical School Admissions
description: At an assembly during my first week of medical school, one of the institutions venerable deans took to the podium to announce that our class marked a turning point in the schools history: nearly half of us were female.

title: Israeli Premier Backs Referendum on Any Peace Deal
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said on Thursday that any peace agreement with the Palestinians should be put to a referendum, a move that some Israelis view as a potential obstacle to a deal even as Secretary of State John Kerry works intently to renew long-stalled Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

title: American Repertory Theater Announces Full Season
