description: The American Repertory Theater at Harvard University  a company that has been the birthplace of several Broadway hits, including the recent revival of Pippin and the controversial reworking of Porgy and Bess  will present six productions in its 2013-14 season in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Perelman Pledges $100 Million to Columbia Business School
description: Years from now, students at Columbia Business School will go about their studies in a pair of buildings named for two Wall Street giants. One is Henry R. Kravis. The other is now Ronald O. Perelman.

title: Rooms With a View of British History
description: BOSTON  There was a brisk trade in European architectural salvage in the early 20th century, when dealers would cobble together new and old parts into supposedly authentic period rooms. Curators have been sorting fact from fiction ever since.

title: Apples Move Keeps Profit Out of Reach of Taxes
description: Why would a company with billions of dollars in the bank  and no plans for a large investment  decide to borrow billions more?

title: Missy Robbins Will Leave A Voce
description: Missy Robbins, who came to New York from Chicago about five years ago to be the executive chef at A Voce Madison, and then added A Voce Time Warner to her rsum, is leaving both restaurants Saturday.

title: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 6
description: The Bats blog again tests our readers predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

title: U.S. Open Cup: Early Years
description: This is the first of a series on the U.S. Open Cup.

title: Kurtz Leaves Daily Beast After Blog Post Is Retracted
description: Howard Kurtz, the longtime media critic, is departing as the Washington bureau chief of The Daily Beast and Newsweek, the head of those publications said Thursday.

title: Tense Moments Described at Houston Airport After Shooting
description: 5:24 p.m. | Updated An exchange of gunfire at George Bush Intercontinental Airport in Houston produced tense scenes for travelers and shut down one of the airports terminals on Thursday afternoon. The authorities said an armed suspect had been shot and subsequently died in an ambulance.

title: Bloomberg Gives Sept. 11 Museum a $15 Million Loan
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has personally lent the Sept. 11 museum $15 million to help cover expenses until the institution opens at ground zero a year from now.

title: Boy With Frog to Be Removed in Venice
description: VENICE PLANS TO EVICT

title: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Bangladesh, Jerusalem, Romania and Kentucky.

title: Quinn Takes a Break From Candidate Forums
description: As the campaign for mayor of New York City intensifies, it is not unusual for the Democratic candidates to sit side-by-side many times a week, often fielding identical questions over and over again all around the five boroughs.

title: World Trade Center Spire Raised
description: Crane operators hoisted the American flag-draped spire of 1 World Trade Center on Thursday. (NBC)

title: British Lobbying Group Condemns a Proposed European Financial Transaction Tax
description: LONDON  A European tax on financial transactions would fall disproportionately on London firms, a business lobbying group said Thursday, highlighting growing tensions between Britain and its continental allies over banking regulation.

title: For a Nerdy Teacher, Its Time to Man Up
description: Joining Election in the annals of movies about morally compromised high school teachers, Clay Lifords Wuss conjures an agreeably bleak miasma of comic anomie and suburban self-loathing. Mitch Parker (a wan Nate Rubin, impeccably cast) is a 28-year-old substitute English teacher living with his mother and caustic, abusive sister (Jennifer Spies). He suffers from terminal timidity, which a thuggish student, Re-Up (Ryan Anderson), exploits, humiliating him in class and making threatening gestures. When Re-Up and his cronies eventually beat him up, Mitch must take action.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: What Maisie Knew
description: The directors Scott McGehee and David Siegel narrate a scene from What Maisie Knew.

title: Obama Arrives in Mexican Capital to Meet With New Leader
description: MEXICO CITY  President Obama and President Enrique Pea Nieto of Mexico labored Thursday to avoid engaging each other on the two most delicate, contentious issues between their countries: immigration overhaul in the United States and Mexican efforts to confront drug violence.

title: Two Former Liu Associates Are Found Guilty in Campaign-Finance Scheme
description: Two former associates of John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller and a Democratic candidate for mayor, were convicted on Thursday for their roles in attempting to funnel money to the Liu campaign through an illegal fund-raising scheme.

title: Even Vegan Vampires Cant Hold Out
description: Harking back to the cheesy sex-and-sucking extravaganzas of the 1970s  only with worse acting and shinier production values  Kiss of the Damned tries to give the vampire movie something it most definitely does not need: class.

title: Hagel Confirms U.S. Is Considering Arming Syrian Rebels
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel confirmed Thursday that the Obama administration was rethinking its opposition to arming the rebels in Syrias civil war, although he said that no decisions had been made.

title: The Sacred of the Material World
description: Its like The Shining, a young man said to his companion, who agreed with a chuckle. I was eavesdropping as they talked about one of William Egglestons 36 transcendentally beautiful photographs from the 1970s and early 80s in At War With the Obvious, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It depicts a grungy, turquoise-tiled shower and bath alcove. Shot straight-on with deadpan objectivity, the image does have an ominous feeling. Shower scenes being a staple of horror movies, and Stanley Kubrick, the director of The Shining, being a master of highly stylized dread, I could understand the comment.

title: For Love of the Game
description: Last May, the Santa Fe Fuego, an expansion team in the lowly Pecos League, the minor leagues of the minor leagues, threw their first pitch into baseball ignominy. Their starting pitcher was 47-year-old Rodney Tofoya, a former has-been in various Mexican and Canadian leagues, and a V.P. at the Albuquerque branch of Bank of the West. He was supported by an active roster of 22 players, each of whom the team paid $54 per week and 15 of whom Tafoya put up in his own house. The Fuego somehow won their opener, 14-8. Though some people believed the score was 16-8. Whatever. There wouldnt be too many more wins to savor all year long.

title: Home Is Where You Create It
description: What is the ideal home?

title: Off Camera, Hopper Wielded His Own Lens
description: DENNIS HOPPER made the black-and-white photograph in 1966: Claes Oldenburg, in blazer and skinny tie, standing tall among slices of white wedding cake laid out on the grass. The story the picture does not tell is that the two men were at a wedding whose guest list was the cream of the Los Angeles art scene, and that the slices were of inedible plaster, Pop objects made by Mr. Oldenburg as party favors. Hopper snapped the shot, then made off with 16 slices  enough to reconstruct a full cake, his first wife, Brooke Hayward, recalled in an interview.

title: Fighters With a Wardrobe to Match
description: BOSTON

title: Article Search API: Version 2
description: At last weekends TechCrunch Disrupt NY conference, we released version 2 of our Article Search API.

title: Egyptian Activist Defends Anti-Israel Tweets
description: Last Updated, 10:12 p.m. An Egyptian rights activist issued a defiant response on Thursday to critics who argue that her anti-Israel stance should disqualify her from consideration for a major international award.

title: For George Jones Fans, One Last Show
description: NASHVILLE  Fans began gathering outside the Grand Ole Opry House at noon on Wednesday, almost 24 hours before the funeral of the country singer George Jones, who died at 81 last Friday. By 8 a.m. Thursday, two hours before the service was scheduled to start, the throng had snaked its way through Opry Plaza onto the sidewalk to the Gaylord Opryland hotel, extending the equivalent of two to three blocks.

title: Sex Stars as People, With Dreams and Worries
description: For her first documentary,  Aroused, and its accompanying fine-art book, the photographer Deborah Anderson set out to change the public perception of female pornography stars. If they werent viewed in a lascivious way, obviously, that industry wouldnt make much money. Ms. Anderson is not trying to change minds about why they do what they do; instead she aims to humanize these objects of male desire.

title: Image of the Day: May 2
Two Pianists Show Off in Vastly Different Ways
description: On Tuesday night Nikolay Khozyainov, a bushy-haired 20-year-old Russian pianist, made his New York debut in a recital at Zankel Hall, part of his prize for winning the prestigious 2012 Dublin International Piano Competition. The music world is taking note of Mr. Khozyainovs stunning virtuosity. Videos of his performances are all over YouTube, including his account of Rachmaninoffs Third Piano Concerto from the final round of the competition last year. And from the program he chose for this recital, Mr. Khozyainov clearly came to town determined to show off his prodigious technique.

title: The Real and the Unreal on Reality TV
description: When last we checked in with the aggressive trio of brokers on Million Dollar Listing New York, the former hand model and soap actor Ryan Serhant was working the deal of his career at a SoHo loft, while the former Swedish porn actor Fredrik Eklund had opened himself up to love.

title: The Corporate Tax Game
description: Republicans and Democrats in Washington rarely agree on anything these days. But in recent months almost everyone seems to have coalesced around the notion that the corporate tax system is broken and needs to be fixed.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Flying Robot Insects and Drawing With Molecules
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Relay Race As Artists Improvise 2 at a Time
description: A Night of Improvised Round Robin Duets was the forgivable misnomer for the program on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Masonic Temple, the first live concert of the experimental-minded Red Bull Music Academy series that continues through May 31.

title: It Wasnt Supposed to End This Way for Tim Johns
description: The first time I heard Timmy Johns name, it was in a casualty report.

title: Adult Head Games, Focused on a Child
description: Henry Jamess short novel What Maisie Knew was suggested by a friends casual mention of some luckless child of a divorced couple caught in a custody fight. In the 1890s this kind of situation was perhaps more remarkable than it is now, but Jamess interest was, as always, less in the sensational aspects of the story than in the window it offered into the relational dynamics of human psychology.

title: From Garden State to Vineyard State
description: GO ahead, make the jokes about New Jersey wine. Theyre so easy.

title: Movie Listings for May 3-May 9
Dont Bring Daddy to School for Vocation Day
description: In The Iceman Michael Shannons mesmerizing portrayal of Richard Kuklinski, a notorious contract killer, has the paradoxical quality, peculiar to many great screen performances, of being unreadable and transparent. You cant really see through Richard, whose pale-blue eyes take in the world from a face as expressionless as a sphinx. But in its tiniest tremors you can sense explosive forces roiling below the mask and grasp the duality with a visceral feeling of dread. It is a performance that has the same life-or-death gravity Mr. Shannon brought to the role of a man driven half-mad by apocalyptic portents in Take Shelter.

title: Q & A | Jerry Hall and Georgia May Jagger
description: Jerry Hall, the modeling icon once married to Mick Jagger, radiates glamour even at 56. And her 21-year-old daughter, Georgia May Jagger, is following in her footsteps. Today in New York, the two shared their thoughts on everything from beauty (and vices) to summertime.

title: Theater Listings for May 3-May 9
description: Theater

title: Twitter Hires Morgan Stanley Banker
description: Twitter has turned to Wall Street for talent.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for May 3-May 9
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Director of State Ethics Panel to Step Down
description: A week after the resignation of the chairwoman of New York States ethics commission, the panels executive director said on Thursday that she would also step down.

title: Jazz Listings for May 3-May 9
Its Tough to Keep a Tune, but Easy to Fall in Love
description: Despite a subplot inspired by Mozarts comic opera Cos Fan Tutte, in which two men place a wager on a womans susceptibility to seduction, Christopher Menauls 1st Night is a pallid gloss of a work that teems with deception, disguise and mistaken identity, not to mention humor.

title: More Straw
description: The Reinhart-Rogoff rehabilitation tour has been really depressing. There are a number of routes they could have gone; unfortunately, they seem addicted to the notion that they can end the discussion by arguing with straw men. I noted one example in their Times piece, in which they tried to rebut the reverse-causation argument by associating it with a claim  that its all about the business cycle  that, as far as I know, nobody has made.

title: Matching Albarios With More Than Just Seafood
description: People say that no wine pairs well with asparagus. I beg to differ. And Eric Asimov wondered whether anything other than seafood should be put with the albarios we tasted. Again, I beg to differ. Seafood is an obvious choice, but there is a long list of cheeses that would work well. Satiny, funky Torta del Casar and rich Mahn come to mind, though there are many other options from beyond Spain. Perhaps cheese with asparagus; these wines, with their persistent citric notes and occasional herbal allure, easily tame that springtimewine challenger. I chose asparagus barely cooked, to dress pasta in pastel green.I kept the tips whole and used the stems to make a finely ground pestolike mixture with garlic, olive oil and cheese, this time Grana Padano. Asparagus done this way also couldenrich a risotto, fill an omelet or garnish a fillet of salmon.

title: Proposal for Changes in Food Aid Sets Off Infighting in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  A proposal by the Obama administration to overhaul the international food aid program has set off a jurisdictional fight among members of several House and Senate committees, threatening to derail the most significant change to the program since it was created nearly 60 years ago.

title: A New Garden in the Bronx
description: The New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx is opening a Native Plant Garden that is a culmination of a natural style that the institution has been exploring in recent years.

title: A Landscape, and a Concept, for All Seasons
description: When you visit the new Native Plant Garden at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx  and it should be a matter of when, not if  you will not see what I saw last week, and perhaps not even the garden that will attract visitors over the next two event-filled weekends. Gardens are like rivers. Not only cant you step into the same garden twice, but their evolution is so fluid, you also cant even step into the same garden once.

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for May 3-May 9
Dance Listings for May 3-May 9
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Le Carrs Latest
description: I have a theory which I suspect is rather immoral, George Smiley said in John le Carrs 1974 classic, Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy. Each of us has only a quantum of compassion. That if we lavish our concern on every stray cat, we never get to the center of things. This concept of necessary, if lamentable, sacrifice in the face of the Soviet monolith helped define the espionage masterpieces of the cold war. Such statements gave fans a rush of pleasure, partly aesthetic, partly clandestine  the feeling they were gaining a bit of secret Machiavellian wisdom.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for May 3-May 9
Fire Insurance Is Worthless!
description: After all, theres no evidence that it prevents fires.

title: A Feminists Beer Ads and Safaris
description: Recalling the shivery sensation of watching an African sunset and immediately hearing the pounding of tribal drums, the Austrian filmmaker Peter Kubelka sensed the drummers deep desire to communicate the feeling that you are alive now.

title: Before the Gavel Falls, Its All Free to Look At
description: MAYBE you havent been in Madonnas bedroom, but this weekend you can take a look at what has.

title: Why We Read Novels
description: To the Editor:

title: Wide Open
description: To the Editor:

title: Comedy Listings for May 3-May 9
The Bulgarian Equivalent
description: To the Editor:

title: Falling
description: To the Editor:

title: First Sighting
description: To the Editor:

title: State Grapes
description: Scenes from the New Jersey wine trail.

title: With a Museum for a Neighbor ...
description: The blogs are aflame with righteous indignation at the Museum of Modern Arts decision to demolish its new acquisition, the 2001 American Folk Art Museum, at 45 West 53rd Street, designed by Tod Williams and Billie Tsien. Its peculiar but much-admired facade of roughened bronze captures the dark side of high-style modernism, the spaceshiplike surface reminiscent of the planet-destroying Death Star in the Star Wars series.

title: Where the Raises Are: Trucking and Academia
description: I spoke today with Diane Swonk, chief economist at Mesirow Financial, who mentioned that she has been keeping an eye on which industries and occupations are giving raises. Unfortunately, not many fall under that category.

title: Blood Ties That Dont Quite Bind
description: Biopics come in a number of flavors, though most turn out either to be hagiographies that clean up the little and big messes of famous lives, burnishing legends for maximum nostalgia, or analytical postmortems that try to put their subjects into play with history and the world. Greetings From Tim Buckley takes a look at two musicians who died young and were largely strangers, Tim Buckley and his son Jeff Buckley, and goes right for worship: its sweet, sentimental, almost inevitably touching if not especially persuasive, brushing against the thorns in each mans life without drawing blood. Mostly it plays out as a virtual reunion tour and fantasy father-and-son encounter session.

title: A Spotlight on Crime in Santa Cruz, Bolivia
description: Bolivias most populous city is at the center of the countrys growing drug trade and an alarming crime wave.

title: Video of Killing Crystallizes Bolivian Anger Over Crime
description: SANTA CRUZ, Bolivia  The shocking video, taken from a security camera, showed the killer in a backward baseball cap and dark glasses, stalking his terrified prey in broad daylight on a city street. His victim seemed to plead for his life and tried to stumble away before the killer, gripping the pistol in two hands, shot the man dead beside a parked car.

title: Boston Plotters Said to Initially Target July 4 for Attack
description: WASHINGTON  The surviving suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings told F.B.I. interrogators that he and his brother considered suicide attacks and striking on the Fourth of July as they plotted their deadly assault, according to two law enforcement officials.

title: Spare Times for Children for May 3-May 9
description: CLASSICAL CONCERTS FOR CLASSY KIDS

title: Political Scuffle in Athens Bruises Young Bystander
description: ATHENS  The neo-Nazi Golden Dawn party, which has 18 seats in the Greek Parliament, has been widely criticized for attacking immigrants. But now its members seem to have a new target: politicians.

title: To Do: Wander Aimlessly
description: The title of generation Um ... distills the attitude of bored disenchantment shared by its three main characters, a pair of downtown Manhattan roommates  Violet (Bojana Novakovic) and Mia (Adelaide Clemens)  and John (Keanu Reeves), their pal and occasional chauffeur. John, who shares a ratty apartment with two other men, is a driver for an escort service for which Violet and Mia moonlight. In the opening scene, the young women, being driven home from a party, carry on a furious argument about the past tense of an obscenity, as John grows increasingly infuriated by their yammering and crashes the vehicle.

title: Senior S.E.C. Officials Depart
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has a new look to it.

title: Baruch Students Break Out the Ray-Bans
description: Columbia University has its verdant quad, New York University has Washington Square, but until recently, Baruch College, the City University of New Yorks outpost in the Flatiron District, had no outdoor space to call its own.

title: Robert Bly: By the Book
description: The poet and critic, whose correspondence with the poet Tomas Transtromer, Airmail, has just been published, was influenced by Kierkegaard: He predicts the rise of savagery.

title: Spare Times for May 3-May 9
description: World Nomads Tunisia This month the French Institute Alliance Franaise is presenting the fifth edition of its World Nomads festival, which celebrates French-speaking cultures. This time the festival focuses on Tunisia, where two years ago protests led to the ouster of the dictator Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali and set off the Arab Spring. Events will take place both at the institute and at sites around the city.

title: This Weeks Movies | May 3, 2013
description: The New York Times critics on Iron Man 3, What Maisie Knew and Something in the Air.

title: Rogue Philosopher, Great Communicator
description: For years, visitors to the Copenhagen City Museum wandered into a modest room that contains a few artifacts from the Danish philosopher Soren Kierkegaards life: portraits, meerschaum pipes, first editions and, best of all, the desk where he stood and produced with preternatural speed a series of original and difficult works, many of them written pseudonymously and published in editions that numbered in the hundreds  among them Either-Or, Fear and Trembling, The Concept of Dread and Repetition. The exhibit has been refreshed to mark Kierkegaards 200th birthday on May 5th. His belongings  a large library, furniture, paintings, and knickknacks were pretty well dispersed after his death in 1855, but the expanded version will add an outer circle of relevant material. Manuscripts and papers from the Kierkegaard archives will be on display at the Royal Library.

title: Learning to Love the Peoples Food in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
description: In the summer of 1996, fresh out of college, I moved to Ho Chi Minh City for one simple reason: I loved Vietnamese food. At restaurants in Virginia, Maryland and Washington, Id grown fond of the staples of the cuisine  grilled meats, startling herbs, crunchy vegetables  and particularly of pho, the aromatic beef noodle soup that is Vietnams national dish. As graduation approached, I knew I wanted to live overseas, and Communist Vietnam, which had just opened its doors to the West, was the obvious choice. In fact, it didnt even feel like a choice at all  it felt like destiny.

title: Love, Light, Strength (and Glue)
description: Five years ago, my husband, Miles, who led a tree crew, could work like a horse. A normal week for him was 60-plus hours. In his spare time he built fences and decks for our fixer-upper house. Meanwhile, I fed the kids and ran them around, shopped at Home Depot and paid the bills.

title: Admissions Anxiety Is Felt Around the World
description: This week on The Choice on India Ink, wed like to draw your attention to an international college search that is taking place elsewhere in the world.

title: What Money, Dear?
description: I had an extramarital affair for many years with a man I loved. Over time, our sexual relationship matured into a friendship. He died last fall, leaving me a large sum of money in his will, which I have yet to receive. Soon, my husband, whom I love, will learn of this windfall. What should I tell him when he asks where it came from? The affair was over, but the truth would still hurt. Is clearing the air the best protocol?

title: Drama, Uninvited, Is in the Wedding Party
description: The first sign of trouble in the romantic comedy Love Is All You Need is the clichd and incessant use of Thats Amore. Ever since that early-50s Dean Martin hit was used in Moonstruck in 1987, the song has been pop cultures Pavlovian signal to wallow in the jollier side of all things Italian. Much of this movie, about a wedding that goes awry, is set in Sorrento, overlooking the Bay of Naples. But as the story progresses the tunes insistent levity is contradicted by the awful behavior of some pigheaded characters.

title: Figuring Out How to Give Teachers Useful Feedback
description: When Texas lawmakers rolled out a framework for evaluating public schoolteachers more than 15 years ago, they intended to identify ways to strengthen the states teaching corps.

title: Sex and Sadness After a Failed Revolt
description: Baby-boomer coming-of-age stories are about as rare as superhero movies or career-girl romantic comedies, and no less bound by conventions. A sensitive child, growing up amid social and political turmoil, feels misunderstood by parents and the universe and discovers what a character in A Serious Man memorably called the new freedoms. Sex, drugs and heartbreak line the path to a sadder, wiser understanding of life, in which youthful rage and idealism are blunted but not entirely abandoned.

title: Seoul Out, Charlotte In
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The Wells Fargo Championship was not originally on Zach Johnsons schedule. He added it after pulling out of last weeks Ballantines Championship, an event outside Seoul, South Korea, that was co-sanctioned by the European and Asian tours.

title: What to Do in Tokyo
description: Eat, shop and squeeze through the crowds in the giant Japanese city.

title: 36 Hours in Tokyo
description: Japans population may be skewing older, leading the global march to demographic gridlock, but Tokyo feels like a city powered by the young. Sophisticated and sprawling, with half a dozen city centers that long ago grew together, it combines the life force of a national capital of everything  politics, finance, culture, style  with a talent for change and renewal that it earned the hard way, bouncing back after repeated flattening by earthquakes, fires and war over its 400 years of existence. The skyscraper race of the 90s has slowed down, but a new romance with the citys waterfront is flourishing, spots for sushi and pt de foie gras are always being added to its 160,000 restaurants, and the teenagers jamming anime-inspired shopping districts update the outlandish costume of the moment every few months.

title: House of Un-Representatives
description: Not long ago, the congressman from northeast Texas, Louie Gohmert, was talking about how the trans-Alaska oil pipeline improved the sex lives of certain wild animals  in his mind, the big tube was an industrial-strength aphrodisiac. When the caribou want to go on a date, he told a House hearing, they invite each other to head over to the pipeline.

title: Gangster Life Beckons for a Fresh Parolee
description: As a rule of thumb, the thicker a films publicity notes, the slimmer its rewards. So if I tell you that the notes for Once Upon a Time in Brooklyn (previously titled Goat) could probably choke a medium-size anaconda, you may not need to read further.

title: Amtrak Subsidy Gone, States Must Pay the Freight to Keep Rail Routes
description: HUNTINGDON, Pa.  The unmistakable wail of a locomotive horn and screeching steel wheels signal the arrival of the evening Amtrak train in this central Pennsylvania town just over an hour west of Harrisburg, the state capital. The train is one of two that stop here daily, a vital link to Harrisburg, Pittsburgh, Philadelphia and the entire Northeast Corridor.

title: Loan Qualifications for Retirees
description: Retirees trying to obtain a mortgage may find that a pristine credit history and healthy retirement accounts are not enough. Lenders are also looking for a consistent monthly income in line with their usual debt-to-income standards.

title: Neighborhood Joint: World Electronics
description: At World Electronics in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, fishing poles line the walls, and frozen clams, bunker and herring fill an ice cream cooler.

title: New Push to Capture Woman in 73 Killing of State Trooper
description: The end came suddenly for Werner Foerster, a 34-year-old state trooper executed with his own gun on the New Jersey Turnpike in 1973. For many others  his widow, the State Police and the woman convicted of his murder  the end remains elusive, postponed these 40 years by a fight over what justice really means.

title: Q & A
description: Fannies 10 Percent Rule

title: Agony Eased by a Gentle Art
description: Phie Ambos inoffensive documentary Free the Mind tries to depict the methodical ways in which meditation and mindfulness can be used to treat life-changing anxiety and trauma. Hitched to the research of the psychology professor Richard Davidson (who is featured), the film switches between a few haunted Iraq war veterans and a fearful foster child with lots of energy. Its patient and free of shame. But as it briskly shows their progress, broken up by dippy animations of neuron storms, it feels like a demonstration of a point.

title: Paramount Hopes New Star Trek Is a Global Crowd-Pleaser
description: LOS ANGELES  For Star Trek Into Darkness, the coming $190 million movie from J. J. Abrams, the mission is to boldly go where no Star Trek film has gone before  and get audiences overseas to care.

title: An Electronics Shop With Other Lures
description: World Electronics in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, doesnt do such brisk business in TVs and VCRs anymore.

title: A Diner, a Family and a Murder Plot
description: CLIFTON, N.J.  Explaining the success of Greek diners to an interviewer 15 years ago, Alex Sgourdos talked about kerdos  profit  and family. To show youre Greek, all you have to do is work 12 hours a day and have lots of relatives who like the business and work with you, he said.

title: Plenty of Dust, Bullets and Relationship Drama
description: Dead Mans Burden, Jared Moshs morally complex, stylistically minimalist western, begins and ends with a stone-cold killing. The emotions between, however, are anything but cool, as the films small group of primary characters slips from joy to fury to murderous suspicion with faultless fluidity.

title: Fashion and Sense Went Separate Ways
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

title: Bloomberg Unveils Budget Amid Race to Succeed Him
description: After racing through yet another PowerPoint presentation filled with numerous bar graphs and small-font economic data, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Thursday took a minidetour during his final budget address to praise someones record: His own.

title: U.S. Lifts Ban on Visas for Burmese Officials
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration lifted a sweeping ban on visas for officials from Myanmar on Thursday, further easing sanctions against the country despite growing fears that ethnic violence is threatening its nascent steps toward democracy.

title: Bulger Cannot Tell Jury About Immunity Claim, Judge Says
description: BOSTON  A federal judge said in a ruling filed Thursday that James Whitey Bulger cannot tell a jury at his coming trial he had immunity from prosecution  a decision that is likely to hobble the defense strategy for the New England mob leader.

title: From Central Park Five Case, a Lesson in Assigning Blame
description: On the night of April 16, Frank Chi, watching television, became upset by the documentary The Central Park Five, about an attack on a jogger in 1989 and how the world responded to it.

title: Venezuela: Legal Challenge to Vote
description: Lawyers for the opposition candidate in the recent presidential election, Henrique Capriles Radonski, on Thursday submitted papers to the Supreme Court challenging the result. Mr. Capriles lost to Nicols Maduro, the handpicked heir of former President Hugo Chvez, by less than two percentage points. Arguing that the voting was marred by irregularities, the lawyers said the goal was to force a new election. Mr. Capriles said this week that he did not expect a favorable ruling from the court, which many say is packed with government loyalists. But he said he hoped that international pressure would impel a change in Venezuela. He has refused to take part in a partial review of digital voting records planned by electoral authorities, calling it a sham.

title: Obama Cant Go It Alone in Syria
description: THE Obama administration is awash in advice about what to do in Syria. With the administrations having declared chemical weapons use by the government of Bashar al-Assad a game changer, many are advising the president to intervene militarily. The stakes are high: every day that Mr. Assad remains in power brings death and destruction to more Syrians; but after more than a decade of war in Iraq and Afghanistan, the prospect of American military intervention is daunting.

title: Handpicked Skeptic to Pitch Hardball Questions at Warren Buffett
description: In most years, Berkshire Hathaways annual meeting is a weekend-long ode to capitalism and generally a lovefest for  Warren E. Buffett.

title: Testing the Strength of a Magic Wand
description: Neither Tammy Caplan nor Joe Tyler Gold has directed a feature film before, so forgive them for not knowing how often or how bluntly filmmakers need to make a point for the audience to get it.

title: Why Maliki Must Go
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: From 4th Alternate to First-Round Co-Leader
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  On the road from New Orleans to Athens, Ga., site of this weeks Web.com tour event, Derek Ernsts career took a felicitous turn.

title: Rhode Island Joins States That Allow Gay Marriage
description: Overcoming years of resistance, Rhode Island on Thursday became the 10th state in the country and the last in New England to approve same-sex marriage.

title: Horrors Come Along for the Trip
description: The Happy House is trying to be a horror parody, but D. W. Young, the writer and director, forgot to bring along any humor.

title: U.S. Spending Cuts Seen as Key in Slowing Growth
description: Michael Kelly let go of another employee last month.

title: The Confidence Responses
description: A few columns ago, I asked readers to give me their feedback about questions having to do with self-confidence: Are women still less self-confident than men? Do we have more to fear from overconfidence or underconfidence?

title: The Importance of Testing for H.I.V.
description: An expert advisory group has recommended that Americans ages 15 to 65 be voluntarily screened for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, and that many of those found infected receive antiviral drugs even before symptoms develop. This authoritative advice reinforces similar recommendations from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. It is a reminder that doctors and clinics need to test and treat patients as early as possible.

title: Movement on the Death Penalty
description: On Thursday, Gov. Martin OMalley of Maryland signed a law making life without parole the states maximum sentence, repealing the death penalty after more than 300 years. Maryland is the sixth state in six years, and the 18th in the country, to abolish capital punishment.

title: One Step Forward
description: In any discussion of a negotiated peace between the Israelis and Palestinians, a crucial question involves what the Arab states would do. On Tuesday, the Arab League reaffirmed its 2002 peace initiative and suggested that the proposal could be modified to bring it more in line with American and Israeli ideas.

title: Celebrating Conspicuous Consumption
description: Its clear that top fashion designers aspire to a presence at Bergdorf Goodman, the high-end Manhattan department store, given the numbingly relentless litany of encomiums in Matthew Mieles documentary Scatter My Ashes at Bergdorfs. In this glossy, fawning valentine to conspicuous consumption (the title derives from a Victoria Roberts cartoon in The New Yorker), the stars  Karl Lagerfeld, Giorgio Armani, the Olsen twins, Marc Jacobs, Manolo Blahnik, Michael Kors and others  dutifully pay tribute. Thank heaven for a bubble-popping Joan Rivers, who blithely observes, People who take fashion seriously are idiots.

title: Las Vegas Web Site Is Test for Legal Online Gambling
description: LAS VEGAS  As the nations first legal, pay-to-play poker Web site embarks on a 30-day trial period, players from every state and Europe are logging on, even as casino companies, tech developers, regulators and lawmakers alike examine the technology for strengths and flaws.

title: Not Enough Inflation
description: Ever since the financial crisis struck, and the Federal Reserve began printing money in an attempt to contain the damage, there have been dire warnings about inflation  and not just from the Ron Paul/Glenn Beck types.

title: Taxing Online Purchases
description: To the Editor:

title: Georgia: Four Morehouse College Students Face Sexual Assault Charges
description: Four Morehouse College students have been accused of raping two female students from nearby Spelman College in Atlanta. Morehouse administrators said Wednesday that the charges stemmed from two separate episodes in March. Three of the defendants  Chukwudi Ndudikwa, Malcolm Jamal Frank and Tevin Mgbo  are members of the Morehouse basketball team, and the other, Lucien Kidd, has played for the football team. Lawyers for Mr. Frank, Mr. Kidd and Mr. Ndudikwasaid their clients were not guilty. A lawyer for Mr. Mgbo could not be reached for comment.

title: Chris Kelly, of Hip-Hop Duo Kris Kross, Dies at 34
description: A pair of moppets with braided hair who wore their clothes backward, the kid duo Kris Kross was one of the unlikely music success stories of the early 1990s, multiplatinum stars who bridged hip-hop to pop, had indelible style, and showed that rap could sustain a youth invasion.

title: Sanchez Asserts He Is Cool With the Jets Quarterback Competition
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Monitoring the N.F.L. draft is not as nerve-racking an experience as it once was for Mark Sanchez. He remembers watching the picks, waiting for the Jets turn, wondering if they would select a quarterback, and it was not pleasant.

title: In Online Video, Street Cred vs. Quality
description: AS online video becomes increasingly appealing to Madison Avenue as an advertising medium, a lively debate is under way that has all the intensity of those Tastes great! Less filling! arguments over Miller Lite beer in commercials made for a more traditional video medium, television.

title: Henry Hope Reed, Architectural Historian, Is Dead at 97
description: Henry Hope Reed, an architecture critic and historian whose ardent opposition to modernism was purveyed in books, walking tours of New York City and a host of curmudgeonly barbs directed at advocates of the austere, the functional and unornamented in public buildings and spaces, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 97.

title: Search for Identity Reaches an Impasse
description: During a party near the end of Turtle Hill, Brooklyn, a bunch of buddies soaking in a pool wonder what the name of the titular neighborhood means. No one is quite sure; then they laugh; then the subject changes.

title: Grieving Mother Tells of Her Sons Unpleasant Police Stop
description: It was the sort of street stop often pointed to by critics of the Police Department as demeaning: a teenage boy, grabbing a sandwich with friends at a corner deli, suddenly confronted by aggressive officers.

title: Flee Sweatshops or Stay and Change Them?
A Strategy for Syria
description: To the Editor:

title: Attention Deficit Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Need for Payday Loans
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumer Spending
description: To the Editor:

title: A Hands-On Queen
description: To the Editor:

title: Cash for Karzai: A C.I.A. Caper
description: To the Editor:

title: Lottery Numbers
Bangladesh Fears an Exodus of Apparel Firms
description: A day after the Walt Disney Company disclosed that it was ending apparel production in Bangladesh, that countrys garment manufacturers expressed alarm that other Western corporations might follow Disneys lead. They feared that could bring about a potential mass exodus that would devastate Bangladeshs economy and threaten the livelihoods of millions of people.

title: Kentuckys Own Hot Brown
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Mention a hot brown to most people outside Kentucky, and they look at you like you are making some kind of joke. But to people in the state, especially in Louisville, where the hot brown was invented, the open-faced sandwich is a point of pride.

title: Advice Is Plentiful for Davis, but Hits Are Not
description: MIAMI  Ike Davis hears everything. He hears fans who want him to swing away. He hears fans who urge him to stand closer to the plate. He hears fans who tell him to keep his hands higher. Everyone has advice, and no one seems particularly shy about sharing it.

title: Scientists Are Divided Over Threat to Pacific Northwest Salmon
description: SEATTLE  Like mariners scanning the horizon from the crows nest, scientists have for years been on the lookout in the Pacific Northwest for signs that a dreaded salmon-killing disease, scourge to farmed salmon in other parts of the world, has arrived here, threatening some of the worlds richest wild salmon habitats. Most say there is no evidence.

title: Bangladesh Arrests Engineer Who Warned of Dangers
description: SAVAR, Bangladesh  In an unexpected turn in the investigation into the deadly collapse of the Rana Plaza building, the Bangladeshi police on Thursday arrested the engineer who warned a day before the disaster that the building was unsafe.

title: JPMorgan Caught in Swirl of Regulatory Woes
description: Government investigators have found that JPMorgan Chase devised manipulative schemes that transformed money-losing power plants into powerful profit centers, and that one of its most senior executives gave false and misleading statements under oath.

title: A Tour Rookie Reaches Into His Past
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  After successfully navigating PGA Tour qualifying school, Derek Ernst made the cut in his 2013 season debut, in Honolulu. Then his fortunes turned cold. He missed the cut in his next five tour events before finishing in a tie for 47th last week outside New Orleans.

title: On the Ropes, in a Special Ring of Office Hell
description: The latest model in boxing rings, which has been installed at 59E59 Theaters, comes equipped with its own water cooler. Designed with a cold and canny eye by Soutra Gilmour, this ring has also been outfitted with gray industrial carpeting, chrome accents and, in place of rope-a-dope cords, sleek, hard plastic panels with built-in document storage space.

title: Crispy Twister
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Heres how you make an outstanding Friday puzzle: spend an inordinate amount of time listening and looking for terrific words and phrases that are fun to say, write and think about. Stash those nuggets of brilliance in your crossword database and wait patiently for the day when you can spring them on an unsuspecting public. Salt your blank grid with some of them, at least one in each sector to spread the love around. Eliminate all junk as you go. Resist the common temptation when feeling fill fatigue to add too many partials, obscurities and abbreviations. Rip those sections out when they appear. Harden your heart and rip again. When the grid is filled to within an inch of its life with awesomeness, clue that baby up (make it tough, now: its Friday) and then stand back as Will Shortz polishes it to a gleam.

title: Business Owners Take Aim at Proposed Smoking Laws
description: Small-business owners took aim on Thursday at the New York City Councils package of antismoking legislation, including a proposal to raise the minimum age to purchase cigarettes to 21.

title: Lessons in Expatriate Filmmaking
description: It is surprisingly boring to watch a movie being made, on the set or off, and a beleaguered production is not necessarily an exception. The unlovely documentary Unmade in China trudges through the setbacks and power grabs that befell the writer and filmmaker Gil Kofman while directing the thriller Case Sensitive in China.

title: Ex-Worker Created Havoc With Hacking, U.S. Says
description: Michael Meneses did not seem like the type of guy who would end up in federal court, pleading not guilty to charges of computer hacking.

title: An Intervention That Goes Awry
description: You think your sister has come into town to celebrate her birthday over home-cooked pot roast. But no, the plan is actually a surprise early birthday party for you at a nearby restaurant. But no again, its actually an intervention. Your supposed anorexia, your supposed substance abuse problems, your very existence seem to be bothering the people you thought you loved.

title: A Growing Egypt
description: The countrys birthrate has surged to a 20-year high, overwhelming the most populous Arab states resources.

title: Coaches Are Role Players in Yankees Quick Start
description: Last weekend, Kevin Long, the Yankees hitting coach, came up with a way to visualize a point he had been trying to make to Eduardo Nunez. Long superimposed two video images of Nunez at the plate  one demonstrating Nunezs old batting stance, the other his more recent, awkward stance.

title: New York Receives Top Magazine Prize
description: New York magazine took the top honor at the National Magazine Awards on Thursday, receiving magazine of the year for its print and digital coverage.

title: Egypts Birthrate Rises as Population Control Policies Vanish
description: CAIRO  More than two years after the Egyptian uprising, the countrys new Islamist government has struggled to confront a drop in tourism and the faltering economy. But the leadership has remained silent about another crucial indicator that has surged to a 20-year high: the countrys birthrate.

title: E-Mails From 2010 Show Rush to Get Stars to Endorse a Schools Chancellor
description: As a groundswell of criticism threatened to capsize her appointment as New York Citys schools chancellor, Cathleen P. Black, a publishing executive with no background in education policy, was increasingly focused on one question: What would Oprah say?

title: States Must Pay to Retain Some Amtrak Routes
description: After years of financial losses, Amtrak is looking at either closing 28 short-haul routes or getting 19 states to cover the costs.

title: Just Like That, Rangers and Lundqvist Let Game Get Away
description: WASHINGTON  Goaltending was expected to be the Rangers big advantage in their first-round playoff series, but the Washington Capitals scored twice in 46 seconds against Henrik Lundqvist in the second period, breaking a 1-1 tie and lifting the Capitals to a 3-1 victory in Game 1 Thursday.

title: Obama Backs Birth Control Rule Change
description: MEXICO CITY  President Obama said Thursday he was comfortable with a Food and Drug Administration decision to allow over-the-counter access to morning-after pills for girls as young as 15 years old.

title: Corrections: May 3, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: SEC Will Start TV Network in 2014
description: The Southeastern Conference will carry 45 football games and hundreds of other events on its own television network each year starting in August 2014, following the lead of the Big Ten and the Pacific 12 conferences and the University of Texas, which have their own channels. The SEC Network, like Texass Longhorn Network, will be owned and operated by ESPN.

title: Professors at San Jose State Criticize Online Courses
description: San Jose State University has publicly committed to using online courses to bring in more students  and bring down costs  but its philosophy department is balking. Faculty members issued a blistering statement this week about why they will not use materials from an online course called Justice, taught by Michael Sandel of Harvard, an academic superstar.

title: Law Would Halve Mixed-Drink Tax at Music Clubs and Promote More Concerts
description: Although the crowd of clubs and concert halls on Sixth Street, the famed Austin thoroughfare, is just a few blocks from the State Capitol, the worlds of live music and policy making seldom meet. But this session, lawmakers are considering subsidizing live music.

title: Jumping at Chance, Nets Even Series
description: CHICAGO  When the Nets shuffled off the United Center court Saturday, after a triple-overtime loss in Game 4 of their series with the Chicago Bulls, a return here seemed doubtful. A win here seemed improbable. A series win seemed like a laughable pipe dream.

title: Why Not All the Money Collected to Fight Fires Is Actually Used for That
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Already Depleted by Injuries, Bulls Are Also Hit by Virus
description: CHICAGO  When Bulls Coach Tom Thibodeau was asked before Game 6 on Thursday what kind of illness had kept forward Luol Deng out of practice Wednesday and Thursday, he said that it was a viral something and that Deng had flulike symptoms.

title: The Best Spot for One-Stop Shopping
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Stepping into Wagners Pharmacy outside Gate 5 of Churchill Downs is akin to taking a step back in time.

title: The Workout: Sofia Vergara Hates to Exercise
description: Sofia Vergara is among the most recognizable women in Hollywood  an Emmy-nominated actress and star of the hit ABC television show Modern Family. But one of the roles she is lesser known for is that of cancer survivor.

description: The events at Columbus Crew Stadium last Saturday gave new meaning to the term scoreboard watching.

title: After Weak Holiday Sales, Nook Tablets Will Add Googles App and Media Store
description: Barnes & Noble, in an effort to strengthen the digital offerings of its Nook devices, will outfit its color tablets with Google Play, the one-stop shop for Googles applications and software services, the bookseller said on Thursday.

title: Game 6: Nets vs. Bulls
description: The Nets 95-92 victory means there will be a Game 7 in Brooklyn on Saturday night.

title: Nine Years Later, an Uncanny Echo
description: No N.B.A. team has escaped a 3-0 hole to win a best-of-seven postseason series. Then again, no major league baseball team had ever done it, either, until the Boston Red Sox ousted the Yankees in the 2004 American League Championship Series. Hmmm. Red Sox, Celtics. Yankees, Knicks. You get the point. If the Celtics can win at home on Friday night, they will be one victory from matching what their baseball brethren accomplished nearly a decade ago, as unthinkable as that feat was. So lets review.

title: E-Mails Between Cathleen P. Black and New York Officials
description: The Bloomberg administration lost a legal battle to withhold a series of e-mail exchanges in 2010 between Cathleen P. Black and city officials over her appointment as schools chancellor.

description: Five people were shot at a home in Newark late Thursday night, police said.

description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) PAUL TAYLOR DANCE COMPANY IN PARIS Great Performances follows this modern-dance troupe, above, to Paris, where it presents two company classics  the 1988 Brandenburgs, set to Bachs Brandenburg Concertos Nos. 3 and 6, and the 2008 Beloved Renegade, performed to music by Poulenc  at the Festival les ts de la Danse 2012 at the Thtre National de Chaillot.

title: Forever, the Girl With the Unicorn Tattoo
description: After more than three decades, the green unicorn tattoo on my right buttock has significantly paled. At least parts of it have. The flanks of the animal, formerly outlined, are now a dotted line. The horn droops.

title: Game 1: Rangers vs. Capitals
description: The Capitals scored twice in 46 seconds against Henrik Lundqvist, breaking a 1-1 tie and lifting the Capitals over the Rangers.

title: Prosecutor in Bhuttos Death and Mumbai Attacks Is Killed in Pakistan
description: MULTAN, Pakistan  Gunmen on Friday killed a Pakistani prosecutor who had been investigating the murder of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and the 2008 Mumbai attacks.

title: With Curry and a Little Bit of Lee, Warriors Advance
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The end came the way the Denver Nuggets feared it could, with Golden States Stephen Curry lobbing 3-pointers, Andrew Bogut crashing the basket and a hyper-charged crowd shaking the arena with earsplitting noise. By the time the first scrap of yellow celebratory confetti fell, the Nuggets were off the court and through the tunnel, ushered out of the playoffs.

title: Stirring and Sad, a Jazz Montage of a Struggle
description: The trumpeter and composer Wadada Leo Smith talked to the audience and took questions for a little while after performing the first third of his five-and-a-half-hour work Ten Freedom Summers on Wednesday night at Roulette, and it was good that he did. The music had been heavy on elegy: alternately noble or mournful, sometimes formal, sometimes severe and agitated. But Mr. Smith was playful, open and demystifying.

title: Capitals Rookie Tastes Two Extremes of N.H.L. Life
description: WASHINGTON  The extremes of beauty and ugliness in hockey came quickly for Steve Oleksy in his playoff debut Thursday night.

title: IHT Quick Read: May 3
description: NEWS The surviving suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings told F.B.I. interrogators that he and his brother had considered suicide attacks and striking on the Fourth of July as they planned their assault, according to two law enforcement officials. Eric Schmitt, Mark Mazzetti, Michael S. Schmidt and Scott Shane report.

title: BNP Paribas First Quarter Profit Falls 45%
description: PARIS  BNP Paribas, Frances largest bank, said on Friday that first-quarter profit fell from a year earlier, but it still managed to beat market expectations.

title: News Quiz | May 3, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Rat Meat Sold as Lamb Highlights Fear in China
description: HONG KONG  Even for Chinas scandal-numbed diners, inured to endless outrages about food hazards, news that the lamb simmering in the pot may actually be rat tested new depths of disgust.

title: R.B.S. Prepares to Sell Shares as Profit Surges
description: 6:03 a.m. | Updated

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, May 3, 2013
description: This question was written by Katherine Schulten from Girls Bones Bear Signs of Cannibalism by Starving Virginia Colonists.

title: Insurgent Party in Britain Gains in Popular Support
description: LONDON  By winning about a quarter of all votes cast in local elections across England, the United Kingdom Independence Party, a hitherto gadfly force on the center right of British politics, appeared on Friday to have reset the political landscape, challenging all major parties, and the Conservatives in particular, with its demands for Britains withdrawal from the 27-nation European Union.

title: Scientists Uncover Evidence of Cannibalism Among Jamestown Colonists
description: In Girls Bones Bear Signs of Cannibalism by Starving Virginia Colonists, Nicholas Wade writes about new evidence that Jamestown settlers resorted to cannibalism to survive.

title: Behind the Walls With Argentinas 1 Percent
description: Correction appended, May 17.

title: Should Birth Control Pills Be Available to Teenage Girls Without a Prescription?
description: Would over-the-counter birth-control pills lead to fewer unwanted pregnancies? Are they safe enough to be sold next to products like aspirin or cold medicine?

title: Europe Warns of Harder Economic Times to Come
description: BRUSSELS  A deteriorating economy in the European Union is expected to drive unemployment to new highs this year in countries including Spain and Portugal that already are feeling acute pain, the Unions top economics official warned on Friday.

title: The Chinese Dream
description: BEIJING  Deng Xiaoping had reform and opening up and Hu Jintao had harmonious society. Now Xi Jinping has the Chinese Dream.

title: Man Group Faces Further Client Outflows
description: LONDON  Clients continued to withdraw money from the Man Group in the first quarter, as the worlds largest publicly traded hedge fund announced plans on Friday to buy back almost $500 million of its own debt.

title: Star Power at a Global Womens Conference
description: WASHINGTON  As the season peaked for international womens conferences, with corporate sponsors, rich donors and celebrity supporters filling well-appointed halls, the Global Fund for Women celebrated its 25th anniversary at a gala dinner at Cipriani 42nd Street restaurant in New York.

description: Laura DAndrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and served as chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Clinton.

description: In Todays Times

title: Financially Strapped Bharti Airtel Sells Stake to Qatar
description: MUMBAI Bharti Airtel, Indias largest mobile phone company by subscribers, said Friday it would sell a five percent stake to the Qatar Foundation Endowment for $1.26 billion.

title: The Small Picture: Ready to Take On the World
description: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the soul of their businesses in a single shot.

title: Daily Report: Intel Chief Sees Many More Devices and Connections
description: Brian M. Krzanich, who on Thursday was named Intels next chief executive, knows he faces a hefty challenge when he takes over the worlds biggest maker of semiconductors,  Quentin Hardy reports in The New York Times.

title: In China-India Border Battle, Some Echoes of Run-Up to 1962 War
description: The latest alleged Chinese military incursion into Indian territory, in the form of dozens of soldiers who Indian officials say are camped six miles over the border in the Himalayas, has caused turmoil within India about the proper response.

title: JPMorgan Runs Afoul of Energy Authorities
description: JPMORGAN RUNS AFOUL OF ENERGY AUTHORITIES | Government investigators contend that JPMorgan Chase devised manipulative schemes that turned money-losing power plants into powerful profit centers, and that a senior executive of the bank gave false and misleading statements under oath  findings that appear in a confidential government document that was sent to the bank in March, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook. The document warned of a potential crackdown by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, the regulator of the nations energy markets.

title: Business Investment Rebounds Even as Recovery Drags
description: THE economic recovery from the recession that officially ended in 2009 has been extremely disappointing for American consumers. But for business, it has been the best recovery in decades.

title: Off the Charts: For Business, a Strong Recovery
description: The recovery since the recession that ended in 2009 has been the weakest in decades, as measured by the change in gross domestic product. That is mainly due to a shrinking government sector and to relatively slow growth in consumer spending.

title: Learning by Doing in the Auau Channel
description: Blake Gillespie is an associate professor of chemistry at California State University Channel Islands and studies protein folding, stability and engineering. He and a group of students joined Rachel Cartwrights expedition studying trends in habitat use in mother-calf pairs of humpback whales in Hawaiian waters.

title: Glencore Shares Rise on Investor Optimism of Cost Savings
description: 4:34 p.m. | Updated LONDON  Shares in Glencore Xstrata rose on their first day of trading on Friday, as investors banked on potential dividends and future cost savings from one of the largest deals in recent years.

title: Friday Reading: Learning to Live With That Unicorn Tattoo
The Fresh Princes of Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH  Ten years ago, the children of Cambodias ruling elite were busy cementing interfactional alliances with a dizzying blitz of marriages. Having accomplished that, theyre now working on taking over the country.

title: No Flash at the Met
description: Dear Diary:

title: Jobs Data Eases Fears of Economic Slowdown in U.S.
description: Washington may be hitting the brakes, but the private sector is still rolling ahead, helping create nearly 200,000 jobs a month, on average, since the beginning of the year and forcing the overall unemployment rate in April down to its lowest level since the end of 2008.

title: Furs, Putin and Music and Ballet, Too, at New Mariinsky Theater Gala
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  At the gala concert on Thursday evening that formally opened Mariinsky II, the $700 million companion to the opulent 19th-century Mariinsky Theater here, the theme was the union of old and new. The point was to show off the technical capabilities of the limestone-and-glass house while assuring the well-heeled, well-furred audience, which included President Vladimir V. Putin, that the Mariinskys traditions would be upheld.

title: Israel Bombs Syria as the U.S. Considers Its Own Military Options
description: WASHINGTON  Israel aircraft bombed a target in Syria overnight Thursday, an Obama administration official said Friday night, as United States officials said they were considering military options, including carrying out their own airstrikes.

title: Last South Koreans Leave Industrial Park in North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The last remaining South Koreans in an industrial complex jointly run with North Korea returned home on Friday, terminating, at least temporarily, the final economic ties between the two Koreas.

title: Keeping Up, Not Getting Ahead
description: The American economy continues to add jobs in proportion to population growth. Nothing less, nothing more.

title: DNA from Tiger Scat Aids Conservation Efforts in Nepal
description: Ive drawn attention periodically to the output ofKashish Das Shrestha, a talented photographer and writer who splits his time between New York City and Nepal. Hes filed an interesting new piece on the Nepal Tiger Genome Project, developed with funding from the U.S. Agency for International Development, which is using genetic tools to help conserve Nepals hemmed-in tiger population. Heres my Twitter/Tumblr summary:

title: Outwitting Sanctions, Syria Buys Dell PCs
description: WASHINGTON  Large amounts of computer equipment from Dell have been sold to the Syrian government through a Dubai-based distributor despite strict trade sanctions intended to ban the selling of technology to the regime, according to documents obtained by The New York Times.

title: To Catch an (Almost) Thief
description: I work as an accounting assistant. Our bookkeeper stole a presigned check and issued it to herself for $80,000. When she tried to deposit it, her bank did due diligence and called our company. The bookkeeper was fired immediately. When my boss and I reported this incident to the police, the officers said that  since the crime was not actually committed  we could not file a report. They suggested reporting it to the local district attorney. But my boss has been reluctant to take that next step. Six months later, he makes excuses whenever I ask him why he hasnt gone to the D.A. Im outraged that the bookkeeper was let go without paying any price for her actions. Should I report the crime? K. W., NEW YORK

title: The 4.21.13 Issue
When Divas Attack!
description: America loves a cat fight  but characterizing the spectacular ongoing clash between the American Idol judges Nicki Minaj and Mariah Carey as such is like calling Godzillas battle with Megalon a slap fight. Anyone who has watched American Idol for more than a few seconds this season knows that their feud is no ratings-boosting prank; contempt of this magnitude cant be faked. When Minaj raves over a finalist, Carey winces; when Carey coos, Minaj rolls her eyes. The two divas dared to address each other directly a few weeks ago, but their talk quickly devolved into interruptions and condescension. Producers may have recruited these two in the hope that an occasional good-natured spat would reignite the spark that went out when Simon Cowell exited the show three years ago. As it turns out, Minaj and Carey trade harmless barbs about as well as North and South Korea.

title: Edith Windsor Takes Back What She Said About Topless Gay Activists
description: The case you took to the Supreme Court argues that because of the Defense of Marriage Act, you were unfairly taxed on the estate of your spouse, Thea Spyer, who died in 2009. What did you think when Bill Clinton signed DOMA into law?  Hated it. I hated him. I would trust no Clinton anywhere any time.

title: The People You Meet at McDonalds
description: A portrait of America through the Golden Arches.

title: 25 Gas Stations Fined for Price Gouging After Hurricane
description: Twenty-five gas stations in New York State agreed to pay a total of $167,850 in fines for price gouging in the wake of Hurricane Sandy, Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman announced on Thursday.

title: S.&P. 500 Surpasses 1,600 as Job Gains Top Forecast
description: Investors who had been bracing for another rough summer were breathing a little easier on Friday after the Standard & Poors 500-stock index climbed past 1,600 for the first time and the Dow Jones industrial average breached 15,000 during the day, both psychologically important barriers.

title: Neither a Swoon Nor a Surge
description: The April jobs report came as welcome news, largely because it showed that job growth had been stronger in February and March than initial estimates showed. The evidence for a so-called spring swoon no longer looks very good.

title: What Were Reading
description: Epicurious: Just in time for Cinco de Mayo, heres Diana Kennedy on the many varieties of Mexican cheeses and what to substitute if you cant find them.  Melissa Clark

title: The Small and Pleasurable World at the Track
description: With a little less than 36 hours remaining before the gates spring open for this years Kentucky Derby, theres enough time for a quick reader to polish off one of the books below. The others can be taken in at leisure through the rest of the Triple Crown season.

description: Q.

title: American Military Tanker Plane Crashes in Kyrgyzstan
description: MOSCOW  An American tanker airplane used for midair refueling over Afghanistan crashed soon after departure on Friday from the Manas airport in the Central Asian state of Kyrgyzstan, according to the United States Air Force.

title: Playing Whack-a-Mole With Expansionary Austerity
description: The rise and fall of Alesina-Ardagna didnt make as much of a public splash as the Reinhart-Rogoff saga, but in a fundamental sense it was the same thing. An academic paper purported to show something austerians very much wanted to hear  in this case that slashing spending in a depressed economy would actually create jobs; the authors were immediately feted and the paper promoted to sacred status; but then the result fell apart under both intellectual scrutiny and the weight of real-world experience.

title: Bipartisan Agreement: Blame Washington
description: 11:41 a.m. | Updated

title: My Desperate, Stupid, Emotional Hunt for the Perfect Pants
description: When I was a kid and my mom bought me Levis, they were stiff and uncomfortable for weeks. Then over time and multiple washings, theyd fade the way you wanted them to and start to contour themselves to your body. They became more than your pants. They were your skin. They grew with you. They saw what you saw, absorbed your pain, your mistakes, your spills and slides. They scarred and ripped with you. They seemed to last forever. Some part of me cant understand why I ever got rid of that pair of Levis that I had in seventh grade. How did I lose track of those pants?

title: Deconstructing a Lift in Jobs Numbers
description: The Timess Catherine Rampell on the 165,000 jobs added to the economy ahead of what is normally a spring slump.

title: Theft of an iPhone Sets Off a Cinematic High-Speed Chase
description: The woman was talking on her iPhone, and never saw coming her induction into a large and growing subset of crime victims. But there it happened shortly after noon on April 15, on a busy corner of Main Street in Flushing, Queens. A teenager zipped past, snatching the phone out of her hand and kept running.

title: The Missing Construction Workers
description: While the number of housing starts has surged  nearly doubling in the last two years  employment in residential construction has barely budged. And construction employment tracked down ever so slightly to 5.79 million workers in April, according to the preliminary data.

title: Childish Lucio Costs So Paulo
description: As far as continental club competitions go, the best drama of the last few days may have been on this side of the Atlantic.

title: Comparing Jobs in Recessions and Recoveries
description: For the 31st consecutive month, the country added jobs: 165,000 nonfarm payroll jobs in April, to be more precise.

title: Flawed Strategy Crimps Thunders Chances
description: The Oklahoma City Thunders offense thrives on two things: virtuosity and chaos. Whether you consider Coach Scott Brooks slim playbook a symptom or the cause of this, their philosophy is straightforward: get your most talented players the ball, and then give them space to make a mess of the defense.

title: I.S.S. Backs Elliott in Fight Over Hesss Board
description: An influential adviser to shareholders sided with Elliott Management in the fight over Hess Corporations board, recommending that investors support the hedge funds slate of five directors.

title: Varieties of Academic Temptation
description: These arent good times for austerian economics; and, to be honest, they arent too good for economics in general. Even if some economists have come out of the Reinhart/Rogoff/Alesina/Ardagna business looking pretty good, the reputation of the intellectual enterprise as a whole has clearly suffered.

title: A Late Show Worth Watching
description: The good news for N.B.A. fans is that they got to witness a quirky and truly terrific first-round series in which a spunky, overlooked team charged into the second round while its rabid fans created a spectacular racket. The bad news for N.B.A. fans is that it happened in Oakland. For a good half of the country, watching the plucky Golden State Warriors topple the Nuggets required superhuman stamina or gallons of coffee  particularly if you spent the intervening prime-time hours watching the Nets and Bulls claw at each other in a desperate attempt to be the team that does not completely implode.

title: Freedom Still Eludes the Press, Despite the Arab Spring
description: ERBIL, Iraq  Despite the upheavals of what was optimistically termed the Arab Spring, much of the Middle East still suffers a deficit of press freedom as turmoil continues to unsettle the region.

title: Meet the New N.R.A. President
description: At the White House Correspondents Dinner, Conan OBrien noted that Wayne LaPierre, the National Rifle Associations front man, is merely its executive vice president, which begs the question, how freaking crazy do you have to be to be the actual president of the N.R.A.?

title: This Weeks Movies: Iron Man 3, What Maisie Knew and Something in the Air
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Iron Man 3, What Maisie Knew and Something in the Air. Find all of this weeks reviews here.

title: Young Star Thrives as East-Leading Braves Forge a New Identity
description: ATLANTA  The referee is the arbiter of fairness, of playing the game right and following the rules. For more than 15 years, this has been a profession of Manny Upton, a mortgage broker from Virginia who works N.C.A.A. basketball games. Manny and his wife, Yvonne, tried to pass down those principles to their sons.

title: The Big Problem Is Long-Term Unemployment
description: Short-term unemployment in the United States has fallen below where it was in late 2007, before the Great Recession began.

title: The Get-Into-School Card
description: Moving to a particular neighborhood in order to land a seat at a coveted public school has long been the middle-class modus operandi for obtaining a high-quality education in New York, where placement in many elementary schools is determined by home address.

title: In a Churchs Sanctuary, Theater With a Dose of Reality
description: Over the last few weeks, moments sacred and profane have played out each night in the boxy, cinderblock sanctuary of Nativity Church on Second Avenue. The altar, candles and tabernacle have been put away, replaced by a bare-bones set where the youthful cast of Stand-Up Tragedy confront and comfort one another under the gaze of an unblinking Christ.

title: On Unburnable Carbon and the Specter of a Carbon Bubble
description: A new buzz phrase in the push to limit greenhouse gas emissions is unburnable carbon  an effort to define and then wall off the portion of the worlds still-vast reserves of coal, oil or natural gas that might, if combusted, cause unacceptably costly or dangerous climate change. The effort builds, to a large extent, on studies aiming to create a carbon budget for the worlds nations  divvying up the amount of emissions (and thus fuels) below that threshold. The most notable paper, published in Nature, wasGreenhouse-Gas Emission Targets for Limiting Global Warming to 2C. (2C being 2 degrees Celsius). (Earlier this year, Katherine Bagley wrote a nice piece on the influence of that paper.)

title: Wheelies: The Juiced Beetle Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Send In the Contractors
description: Luckily, David Rohdes new book, Beyond War: Reimagining American Influence in a New Middle East, doesnt live up to its name. American influence is too amorphous, and the new Middle East too broad, to be convincingly reimagined in 221 pages. To his credit, Rohde, a columnist for Reuters and The Atlantic, barely tries. What he does instead is expose the deep contradiction between Washingtons long experiment in slashing the civilian instruments of American power and its post-9/11 attempt to use those same instruments to remake the greater Middle East.

title: The Gray Man
description: During the Vietnam War, Bill Colby of the Central Intelligence Agency ran the Phoenix program, which set out to neutralize the Viet Cong by capturing or killing them. In 1972, when Colby came home to a nation that had turned against the war, his face began appearing around Washington on Wanted posters. He was jeered on the street and peppered with death threats. Every day at 5 a.m., he was awakened at home by the same crank caller, accosting him as a murderer and a war criminal. Colby did not bother to get his home number changed. Instead, he began to use the predawn call as an alarm clock.

title: Significant Others
description: Reading the title of Claire Messuds latest novel, anyone of a literary turn of mind will immediately think of the madwoman in the attic, the 19th centurys best-known woman upstairs. In Jane Eyre, Bertha Mason was the first wife of the master of Thornfield Hall, who shut her away and, in so doing, opened the door to more than a hundred years of impassioned feminist criticism. This connection is entirely intentional, as Messud quickly makes plain. Were not the madwomen in the attic, argues her reliable, organized protagonist, a teacher named Nora Eldridge, referring to unmarried women like herself, numerous in their 20s and 30s, positively legion in their 40s and 50s. Were the quiet woman at the end of the third-floor hallway, whose trash is always tidy, who smiles brightly in the stairwell. Outwardly they may seem benignant (to use a Brontan word), but inwardly, Nora declares, they seethe. People dont want to worry about the Woman Upstairs, she reflects. Not a soul registers that we are furious. Were completely invisible. In time, she will resolve to use that invisibility, to make it burn.

title: Basic Training
description: If you happened to visit the Royal Military Academy in Sandhurst, England, in April, you may have spotted neat ranks of red- and blue-coated soldiers converging on the front lines of a grassy battlefield  a miniature battlefield, that is, peppered with soldiers just over two inches tall. Their commanding officers were gathered to celebrate the centenary of the book that gave birth to their hobby and, in so doing, spawned a family tree that has since branched out to include tabletop role-playing pursuits and big-budget video-game extravaganzas.

title: Iowa Town Named for Muslim Hero Extols Tolerance
description: ELKADER, Iowa  Amid an expanse of undulating farmland, deep in the steep valley carved by the Turkey River, the town of Elkader sits most of the year in remote obscurity. Population 1,200 and gradually shrinking, it is the seat of a county without a single traffic light.

title: Dear Life
description: A good owners manual takes the unexpected into account; the more extreme the eventuality the better. In the same spirit, A Guide to Being Born, by Ramona Ausubel, the author of No One Is Here Except All of Us, deals with the desolation and surreptitious thrills that come to us through ownership of a body and its accompanying life. Or ownership of a life and its accompanying body: these tales allow the body to adjust as needed. In Chest of Drawers, a prospective father feels acutely underinvolved in preparations for the birth of his daughter, and so he develops chest cavities that can be pulled open and pushed shut, filling them with tiny babies from the toy shop.

title: Up Front
description: Helen Oyeyemi, who reviews Ramona Ausubels short-story collection, A Guide to Being Born, this week, cant remember when she started writing. It was surely long before her first novel, The Icarus Girl, was published in 2005, when Oyeyemi was still a 20-year-old student at Cambridge University, and she has published three more in the eight years since.
