title: The Language of Nobuyoshi Araki
description: Nobuyoshi Araki is one of the worlds most prolific photographers. In his 73 years, he has compulsively documented daily life in his native Japan and produced more than 450 books and collectors editions of film-only prints (a feat made more impressive today by the comparative ease of digital photography). His work appears in permanent collections at the Tate Modern and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and has been exhibited extensively throughout Europe and Asia. But in the United States, Araki is far less well known, and theres no real mystery why: a substantial portion of his prints feature naked women who, at times, are tightly bound using a method of erotic, Japanese rope-tying called kinbaku-bi.

title: Lucky Guy Pays Off for Investors
description: Lucky Guy, the Broadway play by Nora Ephron, which stars Tom Hanks as the newspaper columnist Mike McAlary, has recouped its $3.6 million capitalization after only eight weeks worth of performances, the shows producers said.

title: Helping Seniors Learn New Technology
description: Several years ago Garrison Phillips, a retired actor, bought himself a Dell computer. He soon recognized that he didnt know what to do with it. I needed instruction, he told me in an interview conducted  perhaps surprisingly  by e-mail. The technology of the Internet, cell and iPhones was like a foreign language.

title: Profit Dives at Washington Post Co., as Its Education Unit Falters
description: The Washington Post Company on Friday reported a sharp decline in profit in the first quarter of the year, largely from losses in its newspaper and education divisions.

title: Inside the List
description: ADJUST THE FACTS: The truth wars that have laid siege to publishing in the past seven years or so, ever since James Freys fabrications came to light, have claimed some high-profile victims: Margaret Seltzer (fake gang memoir), Herman Rosenblat (fake Holocaust memoir), Jonah Lehrer (fake Bob Dylan quotes).

title: Against Tyranny
description: Every city offers residents a way to chart the well-being of their surroundings. For the Albanian city of Gjirokaster, as depicted in Ismail Kadares tragicomic novel The Fall of the Stone City, a misperceived rivalry between doctors becomes a barometer to assess the political gales that battered Eastern Europe during World War II and the cold war.

title: Under Suspicion
description: In the spring of 1941 the Jewish cabaret singer Vera Gran began performing at the Sztuka, a cafe in the Warsaw ghetto frequented by intellectuals and remnants of Jewish high society. The place was also popular with collaborators, including the so-called Jewish Gestapo who selected and rounded up their fellow Jews for transportation to Treblinka.

title: Taxi Driver
description: Theres nothing like a college campus in summer. Its peaceful. You feel as if you finally own the place, as if you belong. The classrooms are empty, and you can wander the hallways alone. The undergraduates are gone, the professors traveling or holed up in their offices; a handful of shy grad students, the trees and grass, the fountains and libraries take over. Its like the vanished gardens of Crdoba.

title: Resetting the Clocks
description: In one of the more fanciful conceptions of nature, the British physicist and philosopher Julian Barbour proposed that the world is just a heap of moments, each an instant of frozen time. There is no order to the moments, no sequence, no cause-and-effect relationship. We exist only from moment to moment. If we experience time passing, its because this particular moment has memories of another moment woven into it. Some moments are interesting: they contain complexity, stars and planets, life. Others are boring: they contain only energy, or perhaps nothing at all.

title: Science Chronicle
description: LAST APE STANDING  The Seven-Million-Year Story of How and Why We Survived.  By Chip Walter.  Walker & Company, $26.

title: More Than 200 Colleges Are Still Taking Applications for Fall 2013
description: If you are disappointed about your college options or didnt complete the application process in time, its not too late to attend college this fall.

title: Death and the Maidens
description: Anne Perry has killed off a lot of women in a lot of ways since she began writing her atmospheric mysteries about Thomas Pitt, a detective in late-Victorian London, and his highborn wife, Charlotte. But, strange as it may seem for such an unflinching observer of the criminal justice system, until now Perry hadnt trained her exacting eye on the subject of rape. MIDNIGHT AT MARBLE ARCH (Ballantine, $27) makes up for that lapse with a vengeance. Without losing her grip on the refined language appropriate to the day, Perry has written a sweeping and scandalous expos of sexual brutality amid the upper classes.

title: The Dark Side
description: Can fiction make us better people? Harold Blooms Invention of the Human posits that Shakespeares plays forever altered human consciousness. Blakey Vermeule, the author of Why Do We Care About Literary Characters?, answers her titles question this way: We use them to sort out basic moral problems or to practice new emotional situations. . . . We use them in place of statistics as tools. Reading Peter Dimocks second novel, George Anderson: Notes for a Love Song in Imperial Time, didnt automatically make me a better person  but it did make me aware that, as an American, I should try to be one, even if my attempts are probably doomed.

title: Cracked
description: Angels do in fact walk among us, and they are not at all to be trifled with. Or at least thats the alarming state of affairs at the heart of Danielle Trussonis 2010 best-selling novel, Angelology. Called Nephilim, these angels  or, more properly, angel-human hybrids  are the descendants of traitorous, fallen rebel angels. No haloed guardians, these: they want nothing less than dominion over mankind. Set against them are the angelologists, a secret global group dedicated to thwarting the Nephilims unholy ambitions. Readers flocked to Trussonis first novel (shes also the author of a 2006 memoir, Falling Through the Earth) for its mix of fantasy and religious conspiracy, as well as for the improbable romance between its characters: the art historian Verlaine and Evangeline, an innocent young nun.

title: Face Value
description: Because our species evolved in stressful environments, the drive to grapple with scarcity is deeply embedded in our psychology. Severe and chronic shortages can of course wear people down. But just as the development of a sound immune system requires exposure to lots of microbes, sound mental health seems to require the challenges presented by moderate amounts of privation. An old cartoon by Gahan Wilson captures the idea. Two middle-aged angels, newly arrived in heaven, are playing harps while perched on a cloud. One, his face a mask of dismay, asks the other, You mean this goes on forever?

title: Common Core Practice | Kentucky Derby, Factory Disasters and Berlin Street-Naming
description: This week our humanities-class collaborators chose their usual eclectic mix of Times stories to read and write about.

title: The Little Spanish Grape That Could
description: Its impossible to tackle the subject of Spanish wines without recognizing their remarkable ascent in the last 30 years. The trajectory of Spanish white wines has been especially steep and fascinating.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE SELECTED LETTERS OF WILLA CATHER,  edited by Andrew Jewell and Janis Stout. (Knopf, $37.50.) Cather emerges as a strong and vivid presence, a woman at once surprisingly modern and touchingly  if not always sweetly  old-fashioned.

title: The Gun Report: May 3, 2013
description: This is a photograph of Greg Imhoff, taken by his partner, Shari Telvick, who described him to me the other day as the love of my life. On August 7, 2012, while checking on a house in his Florida neighborhoodsomething he did for many of his neighbors when they were awayhe was murdered. His death, and its larger implications for responsible gun ownership, will be the subject of my column on Saturday. Here is todays report.

title: The Concept: Downsize in Every Way
description: Twenty years ago, Nuna Alberts and Richard Kashuk moved their family from a Greenwich Village rental to a three-bedroom two-bathroom co-op nearby.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE STRUGGLE FOR EGYPT: From Nasser to Tahrir Square,  by Steven A. Cook. (Oxford University, $18.95.) Cook, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, traces Egypts transformation from pride of the Arab world to decaying autocracy. Drawing from archives and firsthand reporting, he weaves a narrative that encompasses the decline of British rule, the rise of Gamal Abdel Nasser, the assassination of Anwar Sadat, and the demonstrations that overthrew Hosni Mubarak.

title: Counseling Kept at an Arms Length
description: LOS ANGELES  Its a sunny afternoon in a Hollywood recording studio, and deep bass is thumping through the floor. This is a hip-hop studio, usually. But on this day it is doubling as a therapists office. A sex therapists office, to be exact  and a couple named Donald and Lamar are seated on a black leather couch, midsession.

title: In the Company of Rap, Garage Rock and a Country Firebrand
description: Wavves

title: From Country Rebel to Moody Rocker
description: AUSTIN, TEX.  The Central Presbyterian Church here turns into a concert hall during the annual South By Southwest Music festival, and on a Friday afternoon in mid-March, Natalie Maines of the Dixie Chicks was doing her soundcheck there for a midnight show. It was an early steppingstone for her new solo career, a preview of songs from her debut album, Mother (Columbia), which is due for release this week.

title: Black Onyx Scratches from Derby
description: 1:07 p.m. | Updated LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Long shot Black Onyx was scratched from the Kentucky Derby field Friday morning, leaving the rail position open and reducing the field to 19 horses, after trainer Kelly Breen said X-rays revealed a non-displaced chip in the colts left front ankle.

title: Book Review Podcast: Claire Messud and More
description: This week, Claire Messud discusses her new novel, The Woman Upstairs; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Ramona Ausubel talks about her new short-story collection, A Guide to Being Born; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: With Tiny Libraries, Bringing Free Literature to the Streets
description: They look like trellises and fishtanks, spacesuits and mailboxes. One squeezes into the cracks of a historic building. Others offer built-in seating.

title: Complaining Is Hard to Avoid, but Try to Do It With a Purpose
description: I RECENTLY had a mundane exchange with an acquaintance that took an odd twist.

title: Irish Catholic Church Condemns Abortion Legislation
description: DUBLIN  The Catholic Church in Ireland on Friday condemned the governments abortion legislation, which would permit abortions in cases where a threat existed to a womans life, including from suicide. The church called the legislation a dramatically and morally unacceptable change to Irish law.

title: A Daughter of the Cuban Revolution Visits the Liberty Bell
description: Last Updated, 4:55 p.m. Much to the chagrin of conservative Cuban-American exiles, a senior Cuban official was permitted to visit the iconic Liberty Bell in Philadelphia on Friday afternoon. The visitor was Mariela Castro, the daughter of President Ral Castro and Cubas premier sexologist, currently visiting Philadelphia as a guest of the Equality Forum, a gay rights organization that is holding its annual conference there.

title: Teenagers in The Times | April 2013
description: Once a month we round up all the latest articles and multimedia published on NYTimes.com about young people, so that teachers and students can find it all in one place.

title: Mold, Come Out With Your Hands Up
description: Bill Sothern, an expert at detecting residential mold, has a cedar-lined hot tub on his verdant south-facing terrace at Madison Avenue and 117th Street. The tub holds 3,000 liters of ionized water heated to 101 degrees Fahrenheit in the winter, 95 degrees in the summer, and the terrace has an elaborate irrigation system.

title: Letter From U.S. Attorney Loretta E. Lynch
description: Read the full letter regarding New York State Senator Shirley Huntley from U.S. Attorney Loretta E. Lynch.

title: Life Is O.K., if You Went to College
description: Despite all the questions about whether college is worth it or not, college graduates have gotten through the recession and lackluster recovery with remarkable resilience.

title: Lehanes Live by Night Wins Edgar Award
description: The 2013 Edgar Awards featured a few surprising winners when they were announced at a banquet ceremony in New York on Thursday night. Among them was Live by Night, the latest work by Dennis Lehane, which was crowned the best novel of the year over the best-selling Gone Girl by Gillian Flynn.

title: Jazzs Skinny Stepchild
description: In search of some live Brazilian music a few months ago, I found my way to Dizzys Club Coca-Cola, in the Time Warner Center, where the Brazilian percussionist Duduka Da Fonseca was leading a quintet. I cant say I knew much about Mr. Da Fonseca before I heard his band that night, and among the things I didnt know was that his quintets regular reed player was a 38-year-old Israeli woman named Anat Cohen, who has lived in New York since 1999.

title: With One Bet, Stablehand Becomes Stable Owner
description: GOSHEN, Ky.  Last spring, Conor Murphy was a hired hand who spent his days galloping racehorses, combing knotted manes and shoveling manure in a stable in Berkshire, England.

title: A Fresh Perch on the Career Ladder
description: For Hee Seo, becoming a soloist was a high point of her career. She reached that position in 2010 at American Ballet Theater, and the transition was as natural as breathing.

title: A Tough Fish Undaunted by Land
description: Even in an environment as man-made as New York Citys, nature stubbornly persists  in park woodlands, empty lots and between the cracks of the sidewalk. In an occasional series, Dave Taft, a senior-level park ranger in New York City with the National Park Service, will be offering close-in portraits of the citys plants and animals.

title: My Other Car Is: A 1965 Volkswagen Karmann Ghia
description: Vince Vespe admits that dating a German woman  and perhaps hoping to make points with her father, a Volkswagen owner and aficionado  influenced his decision to buy a red, white-topped Volkswagen Karmann Ghia convertible in 1961. As it turned out, his relationship with the German car outlasted the one with the German woman.

title: Obama Names Veteran Troubleshooter to Afghanistan-Pakistan Post
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday named James F. Dobbins, a veteran diplomat who oversaw the return of the United States to Afghanistan after the defeat of the Taliban in 2001, as his third special representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan, an administration official said on Friday.

title: The Met Will Return a Pair of Statues to Cambodia
description: Six weeks ago the Metropolitan Museum of Art sent two of its top executives to Cambodia to resolve a thorny dispute: whether two pieces of ancient Khmer art that the museum has long prominently exhibited were the product of looting.

title: Giant Finish, the Last to Arrive at Churchill Downs
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Arriving late creates a certain amount of stress, even for a horse. So trainers go to great lengths to keep their horses calm by adhering to strict schedules and acclimating them to new surroundings. This is why some trainers bring their horses to a new track weeks in advance so that everything feels comfortable by race day. For races as important as the Kentucky Derby, this can be crucial.

title: Second Albany Legislator Secretly Taped Colleagues
description: Soon after prosecutors and the Federal Bureau of Investigation revealed last month that a New York State assemblyman had been secretly making audio and video recordings for law enforcement, other legislators began nervously joking that they could never be sure who else was taping them.

title: Scrutiny Falls on a Pioneer at JPMorgan
description: It started with a summer internship in London in 1987, when Blythe Masters first encountered derivatives. In the years since, she rose through the ranks at JPMorgan Chase to become one of the most powerful executives on Wall Street.

title: The Moment | Afternoon in the Sun
description: From painted toes in the hot sand to the tickle of a silk scarf at your neck, simple pleasures make the best of summer.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Anguilla and Atlantic City
description: Anguilla Lit-Fest, Paradise Cove Resort Bookworms who are torn between a beach vacation and a literary tour now have a solution: the Anguilla Lit-Fest, May 23 to 26. The American poet Nikki Giovanni (shown) is the headliner of the event, which features readings and panels with authors, including the Haitian-American writer Edwidge Danticat and the Anguillan playwright Marcel Fahie. A pass to all events costs $150; hotel packages start at about $180 a night.

title: Movie Review | 'Iron Man 3'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Iron Man 3."

title: For Los Angeles, an End to the Free Subway Ride
description: LOS ANGELES  There is a startling new sight at the subway station at Hollywood and Vine these days, set amid the handsome trappings of vintage film projectors and movie paraphernalia: five subway turnstiles.

title: Obama Tells Mexico Audience of New Era in Relations
description: MEXICO CITY  President Obama, speaking to an enthusiastic crowd of young people here, on Friday declared a new era in relations with Mexico that will focus on strengthening the countries economic ties and that will play down the battle against drug gangs that has dominated the discourse for several years.

title: Book Review Podcast: An Invisible Woman
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Liesl Schillinger reviews Claire Messuds new novel, The Woman Upstairs. Ms. Schillinger writes:

title: Sessions Says Immigration Bill Is a Threat to U.S. Workers
description: Senator Jeff Sessions, the Republican from Alabama who may be the most determined and energetic opponent of an immigration overhaul bill now before the Senate, said on Friday that the legislation is dangerous for American workers, and he vowed to offer amendments in coming weeks to confront the fundamentals of the bill and slow its progress.

title: The Old vs. the Young
description: The Great Recession has been a disaster for the employment prospects of the young. Almost one in four teenagers looking for a job still cant find one.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Before Midnight
description: Richard Linklater, the director of Before Midnight, discusses a scene from his film featuring Julie Delpy and Ethan Hawke.

title: The Sweet Spot | Movie Blockbusters
description: From Jaws and Star Wars to Hangover 3 and other sequels, David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about the summer movie season.

title: The Sweet Spot: Blockbusters
description: From Jaws and Star Wars to Hangover 3 and other sequels, David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about the summer movie season.

title: Investigation Suggests American Journalist Missing in Syria Is Likely Held by Government
description: James Foley, an American journalist who has been missing in Syria for 162 days, was most likely abducted by a pro-regime militia group and subsequently turned over to Syrian government forces, the news site GlobalPost reported on Friday. Before he disappeared, Mr. Foley had contributed reports to GlobalPost and Agence-France Presse as a freelance correspondent.

title: Red Bull, Highly Caffeinated Tastemaker
description: Ben Sisario and Ben Ratliff discuss why and how the energy-drink company has gotten involved in funding at the intersection of vanguardist music and youth culture.

title: Surveillance at the Derby
description: In the days before the Kentucky Derby, officials will have 24-hour security surveillance of the 20 Derby horses in an attempt to restore confidence in a sport damaged by widespread drug culture.

title: Movie Review | 'What Maisie Knew'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "What Maisie Knew."

title: What Ray Kelly Said About Stop-and-Frisk
description: When Police Commissioner Ray Kelly told ABC News that cops had under-stopped black New Yorkers via the stop-and-frisk program, it didnt seem that he was arguing for pushing even more African-Americans up against the wall.

title: A New Fed Thought for Too Big to Fail Banks: Shrink Them
description: A nagging sense seems to pervade the publics mind that the nations biggest banks still pose a risk to the wider economy, despite all that has been done since the 2008 financial crisis.

title: Image of the Day: May 3
Aerosmith and James Taylor Join Benefit for Boston Bombing Victims
description: Aerosmith, James Taylor and Jimmy Buffett will perform along with several other bands to raise money for survivors of the April 15 bombings at the Boston Marathon and the families of the people killed in the attack, The Associated Press reported. The concert is scheduled for May 30 at the TD Garden. It will benefit One Fund, a collection for victims of the attack. Other musicians who have promised to perform include Jason Aldean, Boston, Extreme, Godsmack, the J. Geils Band, Carole King, and New Kids on the Block. The comedians Dane Cook and Steven Wright are also included in the lineup. Tickets range from $35 to $285 and went on sale Monday.

title: Ellen DeGeneress iPhone Game Quickly Becomes a Sensation
description: On her talk show, Ellen DeGeneres plays a game with celebrity guests where she holds a card up to her forehead showing a word or name, like Justin Bieber. The guest then gives clues to Ms. DeGeneres to help her guess the word.

title: Week in Pictures for May 3
description: Photographs include a five-alarm fire in the Bronx, a motorcycle club in Queens and the cherry blossoms blooming in Brooklyn.

title: Panama City Rising
description: Traffic into Panama City was flowing for once, so Miguel Fbrega had only a moment to point out the crumbling ruins in the distance. They were the remains of a 16th-century New Spanish settlement that the British privateer Sir Henry Morgan eventually sacked in 1671. Ahead of us rose Old Panamas modern replacement: a forest of green, blue and yellow glass skyscrapers that sifted the metallic Central American sky into great vertical columns.

title: Hotel Review: Capri by Fraser in Singapore
description: Rates

title: Restaurant Report: Found in Evanston, Ill.
description: With its walkable streets, rumbling L train, sprawling university campus and diverse population, Evanston, Ill., is a suburb that has long appealed to Chicagoans who vowed theyd never move to the suburbs.

title: Expanding Your Kitchen Literacy: Dukkah
description: This week, the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman explores the Middle Eastern nut and spice mix known as dukkah.

title: May 5  11
description: Booed at Cannes? Then Youre In.

title: Looser Guidelines Issued on Prostate Screening
description: In a major shift, the American Urological Association has pulled back its strong support of prostate cancer screening, saying that the testing should be considered primarily by men aged 55 to 69.

title: Q. & A. With David Axelrod
description: Two years after leaving the White House, David Axelrod continues to advise President Obama, even as he begins work on his memoir and oversees a new Institute of Politics at his alma mater, the University of Chicago. This week, he sat down with John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC to discuss his role in Mr. Obamas career, the presidents setback on guns, and Americas shifting political landscape, before an audience at Washington College in Chestertown, Md. What follows is a condensed, edited portion of their discussion.

title: The Idled Young Americans
description: WASHINGTON

title: Movie Review | 'Something in the Air'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Something in the Air."

title: Nine More Years On, and Still Talking
description: The courtship of Celine (Julie Delpy) and Jesse (Ethan Hawke), the bright, neurotic, hyperverbal pair who met in Richard Linklaters Before Sunrise (1995) and reunited in Before Sunset (2004), unfolded to the sound of ticking clocks  there was always a train or a plane to catch, another life to get back to. Nine more years have passed, and in Before Midnight (opening May 24), there are no more looming deadlines, save for the ones built into life itself. The screen romance that defined Generation X is now officially middle-aged.

title: Caffeine-Laced Foods Spur F.D.A. Investigation
description: Most people who want a quick caffeine fix look for it in liquid form. But lately it has become increasingly easy to find foods that are intentionally laced with it

title: Hooligan With Four Doors and a $200,000 Price
description: On a scale that ranges from coolly rational on the left to totally berserk on the right, Aston Martins newly updated Rapide S four-door sports car is way over to starboard  just short of monster trucks and jet-powered dragsters.

title: The Biggest Car Show You May Never Have Heard Of
description: ESSEN, Germany  Most American vintage-car enthusiasts are familiar with the big annual gatherings commonly known as Pebble Beach, Barrett-Jackson and Fall Hershey. In recent years, growing numbers of well-heeled gearheads have found room on their schedules for overseas events like Rtromobile in Paris and the Goodwood Festival of Speed in England.

title: Candy for the Eyes, Music to the Ears
description: As if playing musical chairs, ultraluxury carmakers have scampered to find a safe perch within the global automaking giants.

title: Germanys Well-Kept Secret
description: Techno Classica may be the closest thing the classic car world has to an all-encompassing trade show.

title: An Excess of Luxury
description: Aston Martins two-door Vanquish and four-door Rapide S are visually stunning models that work to justify their $200,000-plus price tags.

title: Taking Time to Go Back to the Beginning
description: Shortly before Miho Walsh and Roy Prieb were married in early in 2008 they kicked their video game habit, which was composed mainly of World of Warcraft. Actually, it was Mr. Priebs die-hard habit. For Ms. Walsh, playing video games with her fianc was more of an act of love.

title: An Orgiastic Gatsby? Of Course
description: Not to sound idiotic or pretentious, but I never start these things to be controversial, Baz Luhrmann said recently in his Australian drawl. He was pacing around an upstairs room in the Ace Hotel in Manhattans Flatiron district while tugging at the bottom of a several-sizes-too-small navy blazer he was wearing along with a rep tie, a pressed white shirt, carefully untucked, and shiny brown oxfords without socks. I never start thinking theyre going to be a big deal.

title: Ask a Property Manager
description: Next week, the Metropolitan sections Q. and A. series will feature Doug Weinstein, the director of operations and compliance for AKAM Associates Inc., a property management company for luxury co-op and condominium buildings in New York City.

title:
Obamas Defender of
Borders Is Again a
Voice for Migrants
description: MEXICO CITY  For two decades, Cecilia Muoz was a fiery immigration rights lobbyist who denounced deportations, demanded change in Congress and once wrote of that hollow place that outrage carves in your soul. When she was invited to a White House briefing in 1997 on immigration, Ms. Muoz, who was born in Detroit, was furious after staff members asked twice if she was an American citizen.

title: Taxes Influence Investment Strategy, and Not Always for the Better
description: FOR years, many investors didnt worry about the taxes they would pay on the gains in their investments until the bill arrived months later. But this year, with taxes higher, some investors have gone to the other extreme, choosing investments as much for their tax rates as for their risks and returns.

title: Mario Gabelli, the $750 Million Man
description: Mario J. Gabelli is more likely to be listed among the United States best-known money managers than among its highest paid chief executives. But that is not because he does not qualify for both lists. He does.

title: Popcast: Red Bull, Highly Caffeinated Tastemaker
description: This week: The Red Bull Music Academy, a traveling music workshop and festival, calls itself a place thats equal parts science lab, the Hanging Gardens of Babylon and Kraftwerks home studio. Its also a live-event series, and its bookings stretch out over New York City this month.

title: California Wildfire Jumps Pacific Coast Highway
description: Thousands of people fled their homes as a wildfire burned more than 10,000 acres across Ventura County, northwest of Los Angeles, damaging more than a dozen buildings and motor homes, fire officials said.

title: Investing With Taxes in Mind
description: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, looks at the role that higher taxes on investment gains are playing in investing decisions, especially in the wake of years of low tax rates. Indeed, financial advisers say more of their customers are asking about the tax implications of their buying and selling decisions.

title: A Beastie Boys Playground, Named in His Memory
description: The names MCA  made in Downtown Brooklyn, Adam Yauch sings on Oh Word?, the eighth track on the Beastie Boys 2004 album To the 5 Boroughs.

title: Bulls Out of Gas and Maybe Ideas
description: Bulls guard Nate Robinson was vomiting into atrash canin thethird quarter of Game 6 against the Netson Thursday night, but at least he was able to take the court. Forward Luol Deng, who missed the game, said on his Twitter account that he had a spinal tap Thursday to check for meningitis. Point guard Kirk Hinrich remained out with a bruised left calf. Taj Gibson and Joakim Noah played through debilitating leg injuries.

title: Betty Woodmans Playful Ceramics
description: The sculptor Betty Woodman is known for her exuberant riffs on the vase  boldly colored and patterned ceramic pieces which she has said could be functional, but I really want them to be considered works of art. Woodmans new exhibition, Windows, Carpets and Other Paintings, which opens May 7 at Salon 94 Freemans in New York City, includes more remixes of the vessel form, but also works that examine the relationship between indoors and outdoors. In Of Botticelli, a site-specific mural that fills an entire wall of the gallery, ceramic fragments represent columns wrapped in vines and crowned by vases, hinting at an unseen garden view. Other pieces, which combine ceramics with painting on canvas, hang on the walls and are framed to look like windows. Still others sit on the floor like carpets. And in Wallpaper, Woodman recycles 90 cast-off bits of clay  pieces cut away during the making of her ceramics  by glazing them and arranging them on a wall, where they will be free to visitors for the taking.

title: State of the Unions: Miho and Roy
description: Married for five years, Miho Walsh and Roy Prieb kicked a video game habit and gained a toddler, with another baby on the way.

title: Cuomo to Write Memoir for HarperCollins
description: The fate of another planned book about New York Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, written by Fredric Dicker, is uncertain.

title: Hes Baaack  Special 1 TV Lives
description: The Special 1, a k a Jos Mourinho, and the most precious and cheeky puppet friends in the soccer world are back  at least for a limited engagement on the YouTube channel of the online wagering outfit BetFair.

title: Squeezing More From Ethanol
description: WASHINGTON  Faced with a crop of lemons  too much ethanol, a population of cars not tuned to burn it effectively and a driving public leery of the fuels properties  the Environmental Protection Agency is proposing to make lemonade.

title: Hopping From One Galaxy to Another
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  A conversation with J. J. Abrams is more like a series of interruptions and distractions, punctuated by occasional exchanges of dialogue. The latest diversion to appear on his iPhone screen one evening in March, as he unwound here at the offices of his Bad Robot production company, was a photograph sent by his producing partner, Bryan Burk, of two tip jars side by side on a coffee-shop counter: one labeled Star Wars, and the other Star Trek.

title: When Jamaica Is Out of Reach
description: I was excited to be invited recently to a birthday party in Jamaica. That is, until I realized my work schedule wouldnt permit me to go under any circumstance.

title: A Revolutionary Ballet, Then and Now
description: A stripper with a heart of gold falls in with the wrong guys and dies in the arms of her one true love. This story was familiar, but the setting certainly wasnt when George Balanchines ballet Slaughter on Tenth Avenue had its premiere in the Rodgers and Hart musical On Your Toes in 1936. Balanchine would become famous for his revolutionary subversions of classical ballet, but at the time, the choreographers decision to put a sexy jazz-age ballerina on a Broadway stage  without point shoes  was one of his most radical moves yet.

title: New Faces Coming Sharply Into Focus
description: ALICE LOWE, Sightseers

title: Velazquez Declares Himself Fit for Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  One of the questions as the Kentucky Derby approaches has been about the readiness of John Velazquez, who will ride undefeated Verrazano.

title: High Tides, With a Rueful Undertow
description: Spring for Music, the annual weeklong festival of North American orchestras at Carnegie Hall, has in its two previous outings felt like a grand celebration. And it undoubtedly will again, beginning on Monday: a celebration of artistic ambition and achievement, of civic spirit and generosity. But this year there are also melancholy undercurrents. The festival has already announced that, having failed to secure sponsorship to continue its financing beyond next year, it will end after the 2014 season.

title: The Death of Jackson
description: It was around 9 p.m. on May 2, 1863, during what would later be known as the Battle of Chancellorsville in central Virginia. Gen. Thomas J. Stonewall Jackson, with a few aides, was in front of Confederate lines scouting the federal position. The day had been a horrible one; Jackson, a senior general under Robert E. Lee, had attacked the Unions right flank, demolishing the XI Corps. But the Union troops regrouped and counterattacked, and night fell on a confusing, bloody scene. Thousands were dead; thousands more would die in the coming days.

title: Big Ticket | Splendid Views Sans Noise, Sold for $13 Million
description: An artfully configured but never-before-inhabited combination of three penthouses on the 30th floor at 200 Chambers Street  a 2005 Costas Kondylis creation that bills itself as TriBeCas pioneer luxury condominium  sold for $13 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A three-bedroom co-op in Hudson Heights with a den, a Midtown condo in a prewar building with two bedrooms and Classic 7 overlooking Prospect Park.

title: Overweight Patients, Overweight Doctors: Readers Weigh In
description: Theres been much discussion this week on Well about weight in the doctors office.

title: Classic Car Show Season Kicks Off This Weekend in Rhinebeck
description: The trees are green, the birds are chirping and many area classic car enthusiasts are polishing their vintage rides for the annual Rhinebeck car show and swap meet, considered by many to be the beginning of show season. The show, held at the Dutchess County Fairgrounds in Rhinebeck, N.Y., will feature hot rods, customs, compacts and pickups on Saturday, with unmodified antique and classic cars (anything from 1988 back) taking the limelight on Sunday.

title: The Gentle Heroes of Churchill Downs
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Like the anonymous crowds in the backdrop of a major city, they are unsung heroes, day in and day out, working hard and serving a crucial purpose.

title: A Credit Score That Ignores the Innocuous Mistake
description: Megan Barringer had no idea that a medical billing mix-up over a $742 charge for a back evaluation six years ago could end up costing her more than $33,000.

title: Undoing an Honor Code
description: Los Angeles transit officials are planning to institute turnstiles at subway stations to counter years of lost revenue because of an honor system that let unpaid fares go unchecked.

title: Humorists At The European Commission
description: The EC is many things, but I didnt think of it as going in for self-mocking sarcasm. But the latest forecast is out; it predicts declining GDP and rising unemployment this year, stabilization next year (but weve heard that before), and displays a track record like this:

title: Partys On With Our 2013 Kentucky Derby Picks
description: The Rails contributors welcome this years Kentucky Derby guest picker, Patricia Barnstable-Brown, who each year co-hosts the celebrity-packed Barnstable Brown Gala with her twin sister, Priscilla Barnstable, on the eve of the Derby.

title: Scenic Views of the Constitution
description: To entice viewers who might be daunted by four hours of television devoted to the Constitution, PBS chose a host known for his comic touch with current events. Producers even put him on a specially decorated Harley-Davidson for jaunts around the country.

title: Opposition in Tight Race to Take Power in Malaysian Election
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Malaysians will go to the polls on Sunday to decide what appears to be the most closely contested election in their countrys history. Its results will bring either a continuation of decades of leadership by the current government or the nations first handover of power.

title: A Doubleheader at the Met for a Mezzo-Soprano
description: For any opera singer, one performance can be enough to put a strain on her vocal cords. But what about performing two major roles in the same day?

title: When Medical Billing Errors Weigh on Your Credit Score
description: A single collection action on your credit report can inflict significant damage to your credit score. And thats the case whether youre waiting for your insurance company to pay a medical bill that went to collections, or if youve simply decided to ignore the bill.

title: Bryants Latest Court Battle: Trying to Stop His Moms Auction
description: It has been no secret that Kobe Bryants family relationships have gone cold at times, but the latest twist might represent the frostiest moment of all. It seems Bryants mother, Pamela Bryant, received a $450,000 advance to auction off some of his memorabilia and Bryant launched a legal fight to stop the auction.

title: An Unconventional Look at Orthodoxy
description: Rama Burshteins new film, Fill the Void, takes place in a setting that will be unfamiliar to most viewers: the confined world of the ultra-Orthodox in Israel. In this sphere, gender roles are strictly defined and every aspect of life, from the spiritual to the mundane, is governed by a complex array of laws and customs designed to emphasize the perceived needs of the community over individual desires.

title: Classical Music Recordings
description: Reynaldo Hahn: Piano Works

title: Stars Picks From Sunny Seasons Past
description: Stand by Me

title: From Ordeal to Fairy Tale, but Not Without Obstacles
description: Russia, where Marc Schleifer spent the better part of a decade after college, is known for its literary tradition of suffering and pessimism. So it was with Mr. Schleifer, whose years there were spent singing in a punk/funk band, Detsky Panadol (Childrens Tylenol, in English)  while working at Moscow law firms and at the Eurasia Foundation.

title: Treescapes
description: For the past decade, the artist Myoung Ho Lee has been wandering around his native South Korea, shooting trees like some kind of arboreal Avedon, in stark relief against a plain white canvas. His pictures possess the glamour and focus of studio portraits, yet theyre set in the landscape  be it a golden meadow or a cloudy blue sky dotted with balloons. Its a deceptively simple trick, a way of foregrounding what would ordinarily be background. The purity of the final image belies the incredibly complicated rigging that makes it possible  a process that usually involves industrial cranes, ropes and numerous artisans. Lee, 37, retouches the photographs to erase any trace of his own hand. If the mechanics of the artwork were visible, it would be easier for people to recognize the scale and the method, he said. But I want to hide them, to infuse a magical and vague aspect to my work, so that viewers may question and try to find answers themselves.

title: Hardens Season in a Word: Great
description: Normally, the kind of season that Houstons James Harden has had would be garnering all kinds of attention and accolades. His combination of raw scoring output, relentless effectiveness, and well-rounded point creation stands with some of the greatest players of the modern era.

title: Friday Night Music: The Suburbs
description: Apparently it was too much to ask (listen to the lyrics); Win (lead singer) and Regine (drums in this video) just had a baby boy. But congrats  and theres a new album reportedly coming!

title: That Old Wildhorn Magic: Jekyll & Hyde to Close
description: The producers of the Broadway revival of the musical Jekyll & Hyde announced on Friday that the show would come to a premature end, with its final performance on Sunday, May 12, after only 15 previews and 30 regular performances at the Marquis Theater. It was scheduled to run until June 30.

title: Rose to Gold Makes for an Appealing Underdog Story
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Fans searching for an endearing long shot when the $1 million Kentucky Oaks is run at Churchill Downs Friday may not have to look beyond 15-1 Rose to Gold and jockey Calvin Borel. She was a $1,400 purchase as a yearling who has won 5 of 7 career starts for earnings of $717,889.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A Cos Cob colonial on a cul-de-sac and a restored 1911 lakefront cottage in Ocean Township.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: The Wonder of Childhood
description: Marble Season, by Gilbert Hernandez, arrives at No. 2 on our hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week. Mr. Hernandez is better known for his work on Love and Rockets, a critically acclaimed independent comic book series that he worked on primarily with his brother Jaime (and occasionally with their brother Mario). Confession time: Love and Rockets is beloved by many, but the parts of the sprawling tale that Ive read have left me cold. Marble Season had the opposite effect. In this semi-autobiographical tale, Mr. Hernandez captures the wonder of childhood  the joy of imagination, an appreciation for comic books and all the ultimately petty but seemingly world-shattering trials and tribulations of friendships during that time in ones life. The 120-page story is told in six-panel grids that reminded me of Sunday newspaper comic strips, which I devoured in my youth. Marble Season is published by Drawn & Quarterly.

title: Brain, Interrupted
description: TECHNOLOGY has given us many gifts, among them dozens of new ways to grab our attention. Its hard to talk to a friend without your phone buzzing at least once. Odds are high you will check your Twitter feed or Facebook wall while reading this article. Just try to type a memo at work without having an e-mail pop up that ruins your train of thought.

title: A Meeting of Two Elizabeths, Not at All Related
description: All of a Sudden, the title of the new Jack Ferver show that opened at Abrons Arts Center on Thursday, is a phrase you might use in describing a signature dynamic of any Jack Ferver production. One minute, everything is campy, outrageous, ridiculous, fake, not to be taken seriously. And then  all of a sudden  someone is slapped or spit upon, or real tears seem to flow, and the pain beneath is exposed.

title: How Diamonds Became Forever
description: Peggy Olson, that emblem of the pioneering ad woman in a mans world on the television show Mad Men, would have been all of 8 years old on the night in 1947 when the real-life copywriter Frances Gerety coined the phrase A Diamond Is Forever.

title: Is There Emergency Contraception in Your Medicine Cabinet?
description: This week, a judge ordered that emergency contraception be available over-the-counter to girls and women of all ages, and the Obama administration announced its intention to appeal that order with respect to girls under 15. The Food and Drug Administration announced that the most widely known morning-after pill, Plan B One-Step, would be available to girls and women ages 15 and older, and that it would be stocked on drugstore shelves, rather than behind the counter. Purchasers will have to show ID to buy the drug.

title: Sally Bowles Wasnt Alone
description: Its evident that Mark Nadlers Im a Stranger Here Myself: Musik From the Weimar and Beyond has cabaret DNA, but Mr. Nadler has done a thoughtful job of expanding and deepening the piece for its theatrical run at the York Theater Company.

title: This Womans Place Is in Her Kitchen
description: NIEDERMORSCHWIHR, FranceIt is definitely not a mans world in the Maison Ferber kitchen in Alsace.

title: Shakshuka, a Traditional Baked Egg Dish
description: Melissa Clark shows how to make a classic Middle Eastern dish featuring a spicy tomato sauce with eggs baked on top.

title: A Rich Egg Dish That Satisfies
description: The only time I visited Israel, it was during Passover. Gastronomically, this was not the ideal time, given the dietary restrictions of the holiday. There was no pita bread, no hummus, no falafel. But thankfully, there was shakshuka, eggs baked in fragrant tomato sauce, and a lot of it.

title: Focusing on Power Play, Nash Aims to End a Skid
description: WASHINGTON  Rick Nashs career record in the N.H.L. playoffs is 0-5  four losses with the Columbus Blue Jackets and one with the Rangers  after the Rangers 3-1 loss Thursday to the Washington Capitals.

title: Season Orders and Mixed Ratings for Cable Series
description: Wednesday was a big day for cable television renewals  HBOs Veep, TNTs Dallas and the Sundance Channels Rectify were all picked up for new seasons that are scheduled to air in 2014. How have those programs fared in the ratings?

title: Shine Starts to Wear Off a Little for Google Glass
description: The shiny new thing luster of Google Glass may already be wearing off, even before most people have been able to try one on.

title: 303 Gallery Finds a New Home
description: New York City art galleries tend to move around a lot. But even by those standards, the iconic 303 Gallery has been unusually itinerant. Since it was founded in 1984 at 303 Park Avenue South by its director Lisa Spellman, it has had homes in the East Village and SoHo, and at two addresses in Chelsea. Today, it throws open its brand-new industrial doors at a third Chelsea location, a bilevel space on West 24th Street tucked below the High Line. Designed by the architecture firm StudioMDA for 303, its an airy, light-filled space that doubles the gallerys square footage, with skylights, glass floors and the columns of the High Line running through, all protected by a cast concrete facade.

title: The New New York Ad Campaign
description: New York State has set aside $140 million over the last year-and-a-half for a national advertising campaign. The following commercials were the initial productions of the campaign.

title: Ad Effort Selling State as a Business Haven Is Criticized
description: ALBANY  The Cuomo administration has set aside nearly $140 million for an advertising campaign called New York State Open for Business, with the money drawn largely from a state authority created to lower electricity bills and from federal disaster aid, records show.

title: Death Toll in Bangladesh Building Collapse Tops 500
description: SAVAR, Bangladesh  The death toll in the Rana Plaza disaster soared to 517 on Friday, as rescue crews spent a 10th day digging through the rubble and investigators continued to interrogate the buildings owner and others arrested in the case.

title: Visitors From Outer Space, Real or Not, Are Focus of Discussion in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  While President Obama was promoting an immigration overhaul in Mexico, six former members of Congress gathered two blocks from the White House to consider what they see as the enforced government secrecy surrounding another kind of visitor: the kind who come from a lot farther away.

title: Weekend Fare
description: For home cooks who want to rub elbows with some of the most well-known chefs, the New York Culinary Experience on Saturday and Sunday at the International Culinary Center, 462 Broadway in SoHo, offers a chance to learn from and cook side by side with chefs like Andre Soltner and April Bloomfield. Tickets, at $1,395 per person for the all day affair are limited and can be purchased by calling (646) 314-4413 or e-mailing nyce@nymag.com.

title: Shakshuka Now or Later
description: In this weeks A Good Appetite column and video, I give a recipe for shakshuka, an Israeli baked egg and tomato dish (with North African roots). I use canned tomatoes since good local tomatoes arent available yet. But in season, feel free to substitute chopped juicy tomatoes. You might need to cook the mix down longer (by about 10 or 15 minutes) to reach a thick consistency, but the bright flavor will make the extra time worth it.

title: Think Like a Doctor: An Unusual Headache Solved
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to puzzle their way through the case of a 23-year-old woman who started out with what seemed like her usual migraine but who then became more and more ill. By the time the diagnosis was made, she had double vision and she was shaking and confused. And despite the right diagnosis, there was worse to come.

title: Queen Esthers Tale, in Yiddish, With Cartwheels, Puppets and a Union Label
description: Sometimes you could do without the whole megillah. Parts would be just fine.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 3
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

title: Hip-Hop Producer Recovering After Gunshot Wound During Robbery
description: The hip-hop producer AraabMuzik who was shot in the chest during a a robbery in Providence, R.I., last week remains hospitalized, the police said.

title: Do-Not-Track Talks Could Be Running Off the Rails
description: After nearly two years of negotiating and little progress, the international group trying to agree on a Do Not Track standard is convening its final official face-to-face meeting next week in Sunnyvale, Calif.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 3
description: More photographs.

title: Occidental Chairman Agrees to Step Down Ahead of Schedule
description: Conceding to a shareholder revolt, Occidental Petroleums longtime chairman, Ray R. Irani, on Friday stepped down from the board, essentially forced into retirement a year ahead of schedule.

title: Kodaks Fuzzy Future
description: When Eastman Kodak emerges from bankruptcy this summer or fall, it will be a shadow of the blue-chip corporate giant it once was.

title: A Diva Inspires Orchards of Sensuality
description: Ann Hampton Callaway, like the great jazz diva Sarah Vaughan to whom she paid tribute at Dizzys Club Coca-Cola on Thursday evening, has a voice so rich, flexible and extravagantly gorgeous that it hardly matters what use she puts it to. The sound always comes first and is what you most remember.

title: Take the Plunge With Hamiltons Pharmacopeia
description: On Tuesday, a new episode of the Web series Hamiltons Pharmacopeia appeared. Hamilton Morris is a chemist and general expert in the field of psychedelics and all things mind-bending. In past episodes, he has investigated rare hallucinogenic tree frogs in the Amazon, an abandoned missile silo in Kansas that became the worlds most productive LSD lab and a Haitian drug that supposedly turned people into zombies.

title: South Africa Is Outraged by a Shortcut to a Wedding
description: JOHANNESBURG  It was to be an affair to remember. The bride was a daughter of a powerful and politically connected immigrant family. Her parents booked all 338 rooms in one of South Africas most lavish resorts, complete with exclusive access to its artificial beach. Kathakali dancers with painted faces and turbaned Rajasthani musicians from the familys native country, India, performed for the guests. A pontoon carried the happy couple across an imitation Roman bath to greet their guests.

title: Pictures of the Day: California and Elsewhere
description: Photos from California, Pakistan, Iraq and Bangladesh.

title: Summer Movie Release Schedule
description: All dates are subject to change.

title: Too Many Lives to Live: Old Soaps Reborn Online
description: An older gentleman proposes to a woman he has apparently known for a long time, though we have no idea who either one is. An angry man is released from prison, though its not clear why he was there or what hes angry about. Some surly guy with a scar on his cheek annoys everyone he encounters by his mere presence. There are repeated references to dead babies, and DNA testing would help sort out the parentage of almost everyone under 25.

title: Coney Island, 1:51 P.M.
A House of Drone, Ecstatic and Raw, With a Potent Aura of Largess
description: Theres an irreducible element of music that connects metal, industrial music, power electronics and classical minimalism, and no word exists for it. It involves deep pulsations; excited provocation through sound and concept more than traditional technique; low-end frequencies rarely encountered in life; long sustained tones enlarged through overdrive; or distortion or just force of hands on instruments.

title: Israel Tightens Border Defense as Syria Erupts
description: MOUNT HAZEKA, Israel  Elite infantry and reconnaissance units have been moved into the long-quiet Golan Heights this spring. Bulldozers are making way for new military shelters. And at an Israeli Army outpost on a strategic hilltop here, a Merkava tank sits pointing toward Syria  poised to race up a dirt ramp at a moments notice.

title: A Dark Time in Hungary, Remembered
description: Time has shown that no subject or context is too complex or provocative for the conductor Leon Botstein to investigate in his programming for the American Symphony Orchestra, nor any topic so clear-cut that he will not muddy the waters by incorporating elements likely to prove provocative. Hungary Torn, presented on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, offered a textbook example of Mr. Botsteins professorial zeal for dislodging convention.

title: Artifacts | The Dinosaur in Anselm Kiefer
description: In person, Anselm Kiefer is much more self-mocking and relaxed than his enormous, heart-of-darkness German history paintings and titanic lead or concrete sculptures might suggest. On Thursday morning, clad in white yoga pants, a dark shirt and thin black flip-flops, the 68-year-old artist showed a light spirit as he walked through Morgenthau Plan, his exhibition opening tonight at the Gagosian Gallery on West 21st Street.

title: Beethovens Transcendental Meditations
description: Resignation, what a wretched resource! Yet it is all that is left to me, Beethoven wrote in 1801, despairing at his encroaching deafness and other physical ailments. A sense of resignation and acceptance pervades the triptych of sonatas that he completed in 1822, given majestic, profound readings by the pianist Richard Goode on Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall.

title: Unheralded Filly Beats Star-Studded Oaks Field
description: LOUISVILLE  Princess of Sylmar, overlooked among the galaxy of stars trained by Todd Pletcher, launched a prolonged rally to overtake Beholder by one-half length and pull a stunning upset in the $1 million Kentucky Oaks on Friday at Churchill Downs.

title: Little Ideas, Big Trouble
description: The other day I was chatting with a colleague (no, I wont implicate him) about what to wear to the punk-themed gala at the Met on Monday night, jewels or safety pins, and he suggested I visit a trimmings shop on Sixth Avenue.

title: Gourmet Twists on Tavern Food
description: Chiboust opened in Tarrytown in 2004 and quickly became popular for its imaginative Mediterranean-inspired menu. Jill Rose, the chef and owner, was especially loved for her desserts, which were announced by a huge refrigerated display case at the entrance to the restaurant.

title: Education and Employment
description: Employment for college graduates has increased by 9 percent since the start of the recession in 2007, while for those without a high school diploma, it has decreased by 14 percent.

title: Coming Soon
description: Images of select films releasing this summer.

title: Tapas That Tease the Eye and the Tongue
description: Widespread and varied as tapas have become in Connecticut, the arrival of Ibiza Tapas Wine Bar in Danbury in January serves as a refreshing reminder of the heights  and delights  this quintessential Spanish bar food can achieve. Ibiza is the fourth in a growing family of like-named restaurants owned by Ignacio Blanco (other Ibizas are in New Haven, Hamden and Northampton, Mass.). In contrast to the understated, rustic elegance of Mr. Blancos earlier venture in Norwalk, Maison Galicia (renamed Meigas and later sold), Ibiza brings a vibrant Barcelona-meets-Caribbean splash of bold colors to the dining experience.

title: Working Alone, Together
description: Whitney Tingle, a New York entrepreneur, once had the common fantasy of ditching the 9-to-5 world, starting her own business and working in the serenity of her home. It did not quite work out as planned.

title: Stories From Sons of a Storyteller
description: The brothers Bellow are the three sons of three different wives, and have never lived together for more than a weekend.

title: Urban Gardening: An Appleseed With Attitude
description: Ron Finley was home by the pool recently when his thoughts once again turned to dirt. People need to realize how powerful the transformation of soil can be, he said, with a hint of evangelism. Weve gotten so far away from our food source. Its been hijacked from us. But if you get soil, plant something in it and water it, you can feed yourself. Its that simple.

title: Documentary Is as Murky as Vietnam Itself Was
description: TORONTO  A new documentary strongly suggests that a man whos been living in Vietnam for the last 40 years is a former American prisoner of war, John Hartley Robertson, a Special Forces soldier who was aboard a helicopter that crashed in 1968 in Laos after coming under fire.

title: All of This Restraint in the Service of Beauty
description: Flourishing their hands like fans, the dancers of the Royal Ballet of Cambodia create a measured world of complete etiquette. Everything is recollected in tranquillity. Even a battle is depicted with patterned composure. Nothing is fast. Yet stasis seldom occurs; some flow of movement is almost always in evidence. The planting of the heel or the ball of a bare foot; the flexing of a foot raised behind; the soft, S-bend adjustment of the torso at hip and shoulder in certain prolonged balances: these are all sensuous ingredients of the style.

title: Seeing Sylvia Plath With New Eyes
description: This year, as anyone of a poetic temperament cannot fail to have noticed, is the 50th anniversary of Sylvia Plaths suicide. Her death occurred a month after the publication of her autobiographical novel, The Bell Jar, and not long after she completed a manuscript of her influential poetry collection, Ariel. Plaths estranged husband, the poet Ted Hughes, published a version of Ariel in 1965, ordering and choosing its poems as he saw fit, assuring her posthumous fame  and directing the shape that fame would assume.

title: Cyberparenting and the Risk of T.M.I.
description: It may be a timeless curse of parenthood to know simultaneously too much about ones teenager and yet never access the information one actually wants. But the unruly morass of todays social media and cellphone-infested landscape seems to have made both aspects of the curse worse.

title: Sandwiches, Rocket-Fast
description: Wild Rocket, a new sandwich shop in Huntington, is the first fast-food venture from the Reststar Hospitality Group, which also owns Bistro Citron in Roslyn and Bistro Cassis and Caf Buenos Aires in Huntington, among others. Wild Rocket, which opened in March, is run by Jason Machado, 34, of Huntington, and his brother, Eric, 41, two of the partners in Reststar. They hired Marc Anthony Bynum, a consultant and chef, to create a menu of sandwiches, salads and smoothies that took inspiration from the companys restaurants.

title: The Week in Pictures for May 3
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a five-alarm fire in the Bronx, a motorcycle club in Queens and the cherry blossoms blooming in Brooklyn.

title: Remembering Where They Came From
description: Ever dream about what you would do if you won the lottery? Richard and Mary Morrison, winners in 2010, decided to open a restaurant, Graceful Rose, in Port Jefferson, a tribute to Richards mother, Rose, and his grandmother Grace.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Internet Cats Sue, and Google Games
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Go the Same Way, or Go the Wrong Way
description: Not long ago, a friend of mine, a dear man with exquisite taste, took me to dinner at Momofuku M Pche in Midtown Manhattan. I point out his taste because, being from out of town, he chose the restaurant on the fly, based on some reviews he had read on Yelp, the social networking site that rates everything from eating establishments to vacuum cleaners to gastroenterologists. The supertrendy place had gotten some raves.

title: The Right Stance Can Be Reassuring
description: Watch celebrities on the red carpet, or models on a runway, and youll undoubtedly see the classic stop-for-the-flashing-cameras stance: chest open, legs apart, head level, usually with a hand on the hip.

title: Savoring the Exotic Spices, and the Heat
description: At Sigiri Sri Lankan Cuisine, ignore the folding tables with awkwardly placed legs.

title: The Real Rock of Ages
description: LOOKING AT THE STRANGE formation of mighty, 20-foot-tall bluestone totems outside Rockefeller Center, you might imagine them to be the unearthed ruins of some ancient temple: Stonehenge come to Saks. Upon learning that they are the work of the artist Ugo Rondinone, you might wonder if these sculptures (and the tabletop versions in a show opening Friday at Gladstone Gallery) are some kind of mystical portals to the Paleolithic.

title: In Broadway Tunes, Ballet Finds Its Inner Showgirl
description: Igor Stravinsky is a composer synonymous with New York City Ballet and its co-founder George Balanchine, but what about Richard Rodgers? On Thursday, as part of the companys American Music Festival at the David H. Koch Theater, City Ballet unveiled an all-Rodgers evening that opened a door to ballets jazzy, sensuous side. As the three-week festival continues, others, from Philip Glass to Nico Muhly, will be heard, revealing ways that music gains  or loses  flavor through ballet.

title: From Triple-A to the Mets Lineup
description: ATLANTA  The Mets were hitting .191 in the seven games before the start of the weekend series with the Braves, so they could use a serious jolt for their offense, especially among their outfielders. They called up Andrew Brown from Class AAA Las Vegas and immediately put him in the lineup to hit eighth and play right field against the Atlanta left-hander Mike Minor on Friday night.

title: Missionary Zeal, Baroque Style
description: Jesuit missionaries founded settlements in eastern Bolivia using European music as a means of rendering Roman Catholicism more palatable to the indigenous people. Choir directors, musical instrument makers and composers, including the Italian Baroque composer Domenico Zipoli, moved to South America and taught the locals.

title: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams Final
description: ST. LOUIS  Bold bidding often needs to be backed up with accurate card reading. The diagramed deal occurred during the final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in March. It resulted in a gain of 10 international match points for the winners, Sabine Auken and Morten and Dennis Bilde (father and son) from Denmark, and Roy Welland of New York City.

title: Early Wildfire Drives Thousands From Homes in Southern California
description: LOS ANGELES  Walls of wind-driven fire swept across Ventura County on Friday, forcing thousands of home evacuations, shutting down schools and offices and ravaging acres of woodland as firefighters struggled for a second day to bring an ominously early California wildfire under control.

title: New Yorkers Walked Over, for Once
description: You may like to look at art, or perhaps collect it. But if youve ever had fantasies of being an art piece, the Parisian street artist and photographer known as J R is offering you the chance, by way of his Inside Out project.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Crisp Images From a Faded Long Island Past
description: In 1897, before the commuter age began, the Long Island Rail Road hired Hal B. Fullerton, formerly a business executive, to lure more visitors and settlers to Long Island. During his 30 years as a special agent for the L.I.R.R., he produced many books, pamphlets and promotional events for the railroad, and he started two experimental farms to demonstrate how productive the Islands land could be.

title: New York Expands Its Recycling Bin
description: To the Editor:

title: In Waning Weeks of the Legislature, It All Can Change
description: No issue is really dead as long as the Legislature is in town.

title: The Day of the Locusts
description: To the Editor:

title: Cost of Cancer Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Bias and a Settlement With Black Farmers
description: To the Editor:

title: Digital, Not Dusty: The Archivists Tale
description: To the Editor:

title: A 24-Hour Race for Sightings
description: At 12:01 a.m. on May 11, the first of around 1,000 birders in about 100 teams will fan out across New Jersey to see as many species as they can in 24 hours. They will be compiling checklists, raising money and awareness for conservation and, most important for some of them, trying to beat the competition.

title: Yankees Bullpen Takes Another Hit
description: This season, while the rest of his roster seemingly dwindled day after day because of injuries, Manager Joe Girardi could always depend on the sturdy back end of the bullpen. Now, the vaunted Joba Chamberlain-Dave Robertson bridge to Mariano Rivera has also collapsed.

title: A Romantic Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man
description: Given that James Joyce was a leading avant-garde author of his day, it is a tad paradoxical that Himself and Nora, written and composed by Jonathan Brielle, has been devised as a conventional musical theater piece. Still, the intimate chamber musical, at the 199-seat Hamilton Stage in Rahway, is a lively, sometimes lusty, spin through the love life, troubles and literary times of the great Irish writer.

title: Library of Congress Treads Water
description: The budget cuts imposed by sequestration are likely to hamper the Library of Congresss efforts to copyright, digitize and store millions of books, photographs and other precious materials.

title: Bill Cunningham | Hats Off
description: At the Frederick Law Olmsted awards luncheon of the Womens Committee of the Central Park Conservancy, a favorite hat shape was the satellite dish, defying gravity on the side of the head.

title: Revival of Europes Economy Falls to German Leader
As Works Flood In, Nations Library Treads Water
description: WASHINGTON   The Sea Creatures, who recently sent their recording Naked in the Rain to the Library of Congress, probably did not ponder the impact of sequestration on their musics journey from dream to copyright.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: To Races Owner, Track Is No Longer at Center of the Business Universe
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Last year, Churchill Downs Inc., the company that runs the most famous track in horse racing, moved its corporate headquarters from beneath the tracks iconic twin spires to the top floor of a glass office building 15 miles away. Robert L. Evans, the companys chairman and chief executive, has frequently assured investors that while hosting the Kentucky Derby may be the companys most celebrated endeavor, it is hardly the most important.

title: JPMorgan Directors Feel Heat in a Vote
description: As JPMorgan Chases annual meeting nears, much of the tension surrounds a critical vote to split the chairman and chief executive roles  a decision that could strip Jamie Dimon, the banks influential leader, of the dual titles he has held since 2006. Behind the scenes, though, another battle is brewing.

title: A Lawyers Story, as Only He Could Tell It
description: Always open with a joke.

title: Where Have All the Jobs Gone?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Last of a Breed: Postal Workers Who Decipher Bad Addresses
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Inside a plain warehouselike office building filled with rows of cubicles, Melissa Stark stares at the image of an envelope on a computer screen. The handwriting is barely legible and appears to be addressed to someone in the cty of Jesey.

title: A Grandson Visits China in Footsteps of Nixon
description: BEIJING  Christopher Nixon Cox retraced his grandfathers historic 1972 trip to China on Friday, trailed through Tiananmen Square by an entourage of aging Nixon administration luminaries, state-news-media paparazzi and Chinese security agents.

title: Caravaggio, and Some of His Admirers
description: In spite of a life that was brief and often rowdy, Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio changed the face of painting. Rejecting the idealized and decorous classicism of his predecessors, he dramatized his compositions with his use of vivid lighting and insisted on humanizing his subjects by painting from life with all its particulars. Even his saints had dirty feet.

title: An Ode to Helium
description: We have not been paying nearly enough attention to helium legislation.

title: With Help of Two Veterans, Blues Maintain Their Composure
description: ST. LOUIS  Jay Bouwmeester is not overly excited about the first Stanley Cup playoff action of his career.

title: Prison Conditions Eased for Ex-Marine Held in Iran
description: A former Marine incarcerated in Iran for nearly two years on suspicions that he was an American spy has been granted monthly visitations by an uncle in Tehran since March and has been permitted to send letters to his family for the first time, according to his sister, who interpreted the eased conditions as possible signs that Iran eventually could release him.

title: As Old as the Bottles
description: Corey Kilgannons Character Study column about a long-serving Brooklyn seltzer man prompted the following letter.

title: Foreign Students to Face New Checks at U.S. Borders
description: The Department of Homeland Security has ordered new security checks for all foreign students entering the United States, according to officials familiar with instructions issued Friday to customs inspectors.

title: Warriors Use Hint of Lee, and Lots of Curry, to Win
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The end came the way the Denver Nuggets feared it could, with Golden States Stephen Curry lobbing 3-pointers, Andrew Bogut crashing the basket and a hyper-charged crowd shaking the arena with earsplitting noise. By the time the first scrap of yellow celebratory confetti fell Thursday night, the Nuggets were off the court and through the tunnel, ushered out of the playoffs.

title: Mississippi Inmates Bid for DNA Tests Is Denied With Tuesday Execution Set
description: The State of Mississippi has denied requests for DNA testing of evidence made by a prisoner set to be executed on Tuesday, potentially setting up what experts said would be a rare case in recent years in which a person is put to death with such requests unmet.

title: Send Judges to Guantnamo, Then Shut It
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Consuming Colonists
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.

title: Drug to Cut Cholesterol Is Approved by the F.D.A.
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved on Friday a combination drug developed by Merck that lowers a patients cholesterol but has not been shown to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease or death, the company said.

title: Leading at Midpoint, Mickelson Looks Sharp
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The surprise is not that Phil Mickelson is part-owner of a Kentucky-bred thoroughbred that once was considered a potential entrant in the Kentucky Derby. Mickelson, who enjoys placing wagers on major sporting events like the Super Bowl, grew up in San Diego, not far from the Del Mar racetrack. The surprise is that the horses never grabbed hold of Mickelsons imagination or wallet.

title: 2 Killings and 2 Guns, Unattended
description: On the afternoon of Aug. 7, 2012, Greg Imhoff  a big, friendly 61-year-old construction superintendent from Madison, Wis., who had moved to Florida with his partner, Shari Telvick  went to check on the home of a neighbor.

title: Stand Up, Cast Off, Reel In
description: Relaxing with a rod and a beer is not the way someone named Pierre A. Champion goes about landing a prize catch.

title: Winning the Field, but Not the War
description: One hundred and fifty years ago this week, more than 133,000 Union soldiers squared off against more than 60,000 Confederates in the Battle of Chancellorsville. Though the battle swung back and forth for several days, it ended with a decisive Southern victory. And yet the war ground on, for another two years. The war only ended when the devastation spilled off the battlefield, as Sherman and his army took the conflict to the farmland and cities of the South.

title: Florida Lawmakers Approve Overhaul of States Problem-Ridden Voting Process
description: MIAMI  Six months after Florida became the butt of late-night jokes for a chaotic voting process that bedeviled the 2012 presidential election, the State Legislature passed a bill on Friday to remedy many of those problems.

title: Jobs, Wages and the Sequester
description: The employment report released on Friday showed some economic resilience. Job growth for March was revised upward to 138,000 new jobs, while the tally for April, at 165,000 jobs, was stronger still.

title: Small, Cute Sinkhole Swallows Menu and Soda Bottle
description: If youre like us, youve probably read more than enough stories about horrible nightmare sinkholes that swallow up trucks and kill people. Join us, then, in praise of the Little Sinkhole of West Tenth Street.

title: City Futures, a Poets Past
description: One in eight Americans lives in metropolitan New York or Los Angeles, so exploring and comparing the regions is an instructive exercise in where the nation is heading. And in New York and Los Angeles: The Uncertain Future (Oxford University Press, $34.95), Andrew A. Beveridge and David Halle, sociology professors at Queens College and the University of California, Los Angeles, enlist experts from the social sciences to do just that.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 3, 2013
description: It is the baby boomer group where we see the highest rates of suicide. There may be something about that group, and how they think about life issues and their life choices that may make a difference.

title: The Mayor on Stop-and-Frisk
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg trotted out shopworn, discredited arguments this week while defending the constitutionally suspect police program under which hundreds of thousands of innocent New Yorkers have been detained and questioned on the streets every year. His speech, at 1 Police Plaza, castigated civil rights lawyers who oppose what they say is the practice of stopping people based on race instead of reasonable suspicion; Democratic mayoral candidates who want to rein in the stop-and-frisk program; and the City Council, which is considering a perfectly reasonable bill that would create the position of Police Department inspector general, with broad powers to review department policies.

title: Funeral Home Accepts Suspects Body, and Problems
description: WORCESTER, Mass.  Peter A. Stefan sat straight up in a leather chair in the funeral home he owns and looked purposefully at the city councilor who had come to ask him why he of all people was storing the body of Tamerlan Tsarnaev.

title: College Graduates Fare Well in Jobs Market, Even Through Recession
description: Is college worth it? Given the growing price tag and the frequent anecdotes about jobless graduates stuck in their parents basements, many have started to question the value of a college degree. But the evidence suggests college graduates have suffered through the recession and lackluster recovery with remarkable resilience.

title: As Senators Head for Exit, Few Step Up to Run for Seats
description: WASHINGTON  The retirement of Tom Harkin, a Democrat who has represented Iowa in the Senate for nearly 30 years, should be the kind of rare opportunity that sends the best and brightest of his states political class scrambling to get on the ballot.

title: Dear College Graduates...
description: Im scheduled to deliver the commencement address Friday at my alma mater, Grambling State University in Louisiana, so Ive been giving quite a bit of thought to the America into which these students are graduating.

title: Judge Says Cuban Who Spied on U.S. Can Stay in Cuba
description: MEXICO CITY  A Cuban man convicted in the United States of spying on behalf of Cuba can stay in Cuba, where he was allowed to go last month for his fathers funeral, if he renounces his American citizenship, a federal judge ruled Friday.
