title: Before Mayweathers Fight, a Conflict of Story Lines
description: LAS VEGAS  Floyd Mayweather Jr. entered the MGM Grand Garden Arena flanked by camera crews and boom microphones and four bodyguards roughly the size of Fiats. Sunglasses on, cellphones in hand, he trailed them upstairs, where a series of interviews would simultaneously bolster and diminish the chosen narrative for his latest fight.

title: A British Pubs Offense? Favoring the British
description: Longbow Pub and Pantry, an oak-paneled haven of sport and imbibition on a busy strip in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is a British pub through and through, from the Welsh national rugby jersey framed by the bar to the Old Speckled Hen ale in the fish-and-chips batter to the accents that ring loud off the walls during soccer broadcasts.

title: Early Voting Means Easier Voting
description: New York State is a national laggard when it comes to voting. The state has one of the worst voter turnout records in the country, not least because the act of voting is cumbersome and uninviting. In November, 53.6 percent of registered voters cast ballots, leaving New York 44th among the 50 states and the District of Columbia for voter participation.

title: Shooting His Own Foot
description: President Franois Hollande of France has recently been on a campaign to change the widely held perception that his administration is hostile to business. He has sounded more welcoming to foreign investment and has promised to lower capital gains taxes. But barely days into his charm offensive, one of Mr. Hollandes ministers was triumphantly claiming credit for preventing Yahoo from buying a controlling stake in a successful French online video streaming company, DailyMotion.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: Bangladeshis bury their dead as apparel companies discuss factory safety, Chinas factories slow down and American job growth exceeds forecasts.

title: A Sadrist Governor Is a Folk Hero to Iraqis
description: AMARA, Iraq

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 4, 2013
description: Im so jaded at this point that Im not surprised. And from my perspective, let them all wear wires. Lets catch everybody. Maybe if we clean out the whole system, we can move forward.

title: Amid Pending Investigation, President of St. Johns Says He Will Retire
description: The longtime president of St. Johns University, the Rev. Donald J. Harrington, announced his retirement on Friday, ending a tenure that included successes like soaring student enrollment and campus expansion, but also financial scandal: he acknowledged going on trips with a former dean who committed suicide while on trial for corruption.

title: May 3: Churchill Downs Replay
description: Images from Churchill Downs leading up to the Kentucky Derby.

title: Lottery Numbers
A 19-Horse Kentucky Derby
description: Post positions for the 19 horses in Saturdays Kentucky Derby.

title: Corrections: May 4, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Almost There
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Heres when I knew I was in trouble: at 23 Across, the devilishly wicked clue Resident of Angola, Brazil or Lebanon taunted me mercilessly as I tried to figure out who might reside in all of those countries. Sure, there were a few brain cells nagging at me that Lebanon was the name of a couple of American towns, but I ignored them. Big mistake.

title: Knicks Falter in Fourth Before Closing Out Celtics
description: BOSTON  The wait had been long, humiliating, often torturous, and it would not end without one final jolt of stress, one last anxious sensation before the moment of exhilaration finally, mercifully arrived. Delayed gratification never felt this good.

title: Seeking Flexibility During Storms
description: A preliminary map of expanded New York City evacuation zones includes nearly three million residents.

title: Questions Linger for Liu After Ex-Associates Trial
description: When John C. Liu hastily announced late Thursday that he would hold a news conference that night to discuss the convictions of two former associates in an illegal campaign-finance scheme, speculation began to build: Would he criticize the guilty parties and vow not to tolerate similar conduct? Would he be rattled, or even abandon the race for mayor?

title: Jeff Hanneman, Guitarist, Dies at 49
description: Jeff Hanneman, a guitarist for the influential metal band Slayer, who helped shape the groups sonic assault and wrote some of its most popular  and controversial  songs, died on Thursday at a hospital near his home east of Los Angeles. He was 49.

title: Adding Evacuation Zones in Response to Hurricane
description: The Bloomberg administration announced on Friday that it would double to six the number of evacuation zones along New York Citys coast and expand them to include an additional 640,000 residents, saying that the new map would provide more flexibility when major storms hit.

title: Trading Handshakes for Home Cooking
description: In his former life as a city councilman and candidate for city comptroller, David S. Yassky, 49, saw many weekend hours sacrificed to political events; handshaking, crowd stirring, park-cleaning. But though his current job, as commissioner of the citys Taxi and Limousine Commission, can intrude on any given weekend, he seems to have recaptured his Sundays. Now they begin with a trip to the dog run near his Brooklyn Heights home and an exercise outing with his wife, Diana Fortuna, the chief financial officer of the Metropolitan Opera. They typically end with a dose of classic television. In between, Mr. Yassky strives to prove his culinary chops to the couples 14-year-old daughter, Margaret, a Food Network fan with a discerning palate. Their other daughter, Susan, 19, is finishing her freshman year at Yale.

title: A Place for Vandals Turns Outdoor Gallery
description: The Brooklyn neighborhood of Bushwick had long been a target for graffiti until a lifelong resident decided to change that.

title: Mike Gray, China Syndrome Writer, Dies at 77
description: Mike Gray, a writer and filmmaker who tackled thorny contemporary issues in his work, including race relations in Chicago, American drug policy and, most notably, the safety of nuclear power plants  the subject of the 1979 film The China Syndrome, for which he wrote the original screenplay  died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 77.

title: Tom Knapp, Crowd-Pleasing Sure Shot, Dies at 62
description: Tom Knapp, an exhibition shotgun virtuoso who broke world records by picking off flocks of airborne clay targets with the flair of a western movie hero and dazzled crowds with his effortless precision shattering of golf balls, radishes, aspirin and other flying targets, died on April 26 in Rochester, Minn. He was 62.

title: Bushwick Gets a Fresh Coat
description: Growing up, Joseph Ficalora would sit on the roof of his familys steel fabrication business. In Bushwick, Brooklyn, in the 1980s, it was one of the few safe places outdoors. The view was grim. The streets were dirty. Graffiti was endless.

title: Sabathias Early Mistake Is All Griffin and As Need
description: In the moments leading up to his start Friday against the Yankees, Oakland Athletics pitcher A. J. Griffin serenaded his teammates by playing his guitar and singing in the middle of the clubhouse. The free-spirited Griffin even sang a song in Spanish for the Cuban outfielder Yoenis Cespedes.

title: Racing Family Dares to Dream of Victory
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  With an advertisement in a Pittsburgh newspaper  a willing boy wishes work  Henry Phipps Jr. entered the world of 19th-century industry and set out on a career that epitomized the American dream.

title: Keeping Troubled Youth Near
description: New York Citys juvenile delinquents used to be sent upstate to be incarcerated, but a new program is offering rehabilitation closer to home.

title: Googles Palestinian Home Page Recognizes Palestine
description: Five months after the United Nations General Assembly voted to upgrade Palestines status to a nonmember observer state, Google has followed suit, labeling its local home page Palestine instead of the Palestinian territories. The Palestine Liberation Organization and the Palestinian Authority began using State of Palestine on official documents immediately after the Nov. 29 United Nations vote, and urged international organizations to do the same. A Google spokesman said Friday that the company was making the change across all our products. Sabri Saadat, a spokesman for President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority, called the move a step in the right direction, but Yigal Palmor, a spokesman for Israels Foreign Ministry, voiced displeasure. It has no diplomatic or political significance, Mr. Palmor told an Israeli news Web site on Friday. Precisely because Google is not the U.N. or any international diplomatic institution, this begs the question of whether there is room for any political stance on controversial issues.

title: Path From Social Butterfly to Boston Suspects Widow
description: When Katherine Russell arrived as a freshman at Suffolk University just over five years ago, she seemed to bond so well with her new roommates in their lively dorm opposite Boston Common that one classmate likened them to sitcom characters. They reminded me of the show Sex and the City, he recalled. Two of them were free-spirited, one was materialistic and Katherine was the social butterfly.

title: Another Chance for Monet
description: The end of the road is a yellow brick house in East New York, Brooklyn, that was once a rectory. Monet arrived there on Dec. 28 with a bad attitude and four years of baggage.

title: As Nets and Bulls Go the Distance, the First Round Feels Like the 15th
description: The Nets first-round series against the Chicago Bulls will end exactly two weeks after it began, at Barclays Center on Saturday night, after seven games that twisted and stretched and tested the teams in ways they probably never could have imagined.

title: Braves Bullpen Falters, and Mets Take Advantage
description: ATLANTA  The Mets roughed up the National Leagues best bullpen. They handled the leagues best hitter in a key situation, and they beat the best team in the East. So it took Manager Terry Collins no time at all when asked if this was the Mets best win of the season.

title: Out, but Not About That
description: Thirteen years ago, Corey Johnson, then an 18-year-old high school student in Middleton, Mass., the son of a truck driver and a cafeteria worker, came out about his homosexuality, and it was no small thing. The captain of his football team, Mr. Johnson also wrestled and played lacrosse and baseball. Not long after his disclosure, he was asked to speak at the Millennium March for Equality in Washington. He became the subject of a  column by Robert Lipsyte in The New York Times, which, to Mr. Johnsons great surprise, ran on the papers front page on a Sunday. A certain celebrity quickly attended him.

title: A Roller-Coaster Game Mirrors a Tough Season
description: BOSTON  They played Dont Stop Believin before the game, perhaps a prophetic tune for the Celtics. But as it was for The Sopranos six years ago, the song proved to be endgame music for the Celtics on Friday night.

title: Game 6: Knicks vs. Celtics Replay
description: After blowing most of a 26-point lead, the Knicks stopped the Celtics comeback attempt to advance to the Eastern Conference semifinals.

title: City Hall Pushed Noted Women to Sign Letter Supporting Candidate for Chancellor
description: The idea was simple: a letter signed by some of the countrys most prominent women endorsing Cathleen P. Black, chairwoman of Hearst Magazines, to lead New York Citys schools.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (Showtime) SALMON FISHING IN THE YEMEN (2012) The director Lasse Hallstrom transforms Paul Tordays absurdist political satire  the tale of a visionary sheik (Amr Waked, above left, with Ewan McGregor) with unlimited financial resources intent on creating a recreational paradise for fishermen in a Middle Eastern desert  into a whimsical romantic comedy. Mr. Hallstrom is a shrewd commercial alchemist with a soft heart, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, and the result is the cinematic equivalent of turning salt into sugar. Mr. McGregor plays Dr. Alfred Jones, a British fisheries expert who is approached to evaluate the feasibility of the concept, which would involve either importing 10,000 North Atlantic salmon to Yemen from Britain, or using farmed salmon. Kristin Scott Thomas is Patricia Maxwell, the press secretary for the British prime minister, who seizes on the opportunity to distract the public from political conflicts and score points for her boss. And Emily Blunt is Harriet, the sheiks assistant, and the unspoken object of Freds affection, whose soldier boyfriend (Tom Mison) has gone missing in action. Whether Harriet and Fred will get together is a question that hovers over the movie, Mr. Holden said. The appeal of the film depends on the charm of Mr. McGregor and Ms. Blunt, whose polite but discreetly charged connection is the storys emotional center. And although the sheik is the target of an assassination plot by Islamic extremists, the biggest moment of suspense has nothing to do with international politics or terrorism, Mr. Holden said. It comes when those farmed salmon are finally released into the waters of their new home. Will they mill around in confusion or will they jump? It is enough to say that for this moment to be the films dramatic turning point is an indication of its softness.

title: IHT Quick Read: May 4
description: NEWS Even as the United States economy displays unanticipated resilience, with a healthy jobs report released on Friday, the outlook for Europes economy grows ever dimmer. As it does, the pressure builds on Europes most powerful leader, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, and her economic team to find a way to get the Continent growing again. But this puts Ms. Merkel in a bind, as she has to answer to German voters in September when the country holds parliamentary elections. While the European economy may be deteriorating at an alarming rate, the electorate here is still enamored of her as the Iron Chancellor, advocating the austerity policies that are rapidly falling into disfavor elsewhere, among economists as well as the public. Nicholas Kulish reports from Berlin.

title: Israel Targeted Iranian Missiles in Syria Attack
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A series of powerful explosions rocked the outskirts of Damascus early Sunday morning, which Syrian state television said was the result of Israeli missile attacks on a Syrian military installation.

title: Pakistani Prisoner Beaten Up in Indian Jail
description: NEW DELHI  A day after the death of Sarabjit Singh, an Indian national who died from his injuries from a brutal attack by inmates of a Pakistani prison, Sanaullah Ranjay, a Pakistani national imprisoned in Jammu, Jammu and Kashmir, was severely beaten up Friday morning by a fellow prisoner.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: One man was killed and more than 50 people, mostly school children, were injured in Kashmir when an earthquake measuring 5.8 on the Richter scale rocked parts of northern India on Wednesday, Hindustan Times reported.

title: The Weekend Word: Loyalty
description: Todays Times

title: 2 Big Changes Make Derby More Difficult to Predict
description: The Kentucky Derby, one of the most tradition-bound institutions in sports history, will leave the gate on Saturday without two of its time-honored customs. The changes are both good and bad, but they both make the winner more difficult to predict.

title: 2 Bodies Found at Crash Site of U.S. Tanker
description: MOSCOW  The authorities said Saturday that two bodies had been found in the wreckage of an American tanker airplane that crashed soon after taking off from the Manas airport in the Central Asian country of Kyrgyzstan on Friday.

title: A Bold New Morrokide Era: Classic Cars Then, Now and in Between
description: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x5Vml8hf5HM

title: The Gods Themselves Contend In Vain
description: The basic idea behind Keynesian support for stimulus/opposition to austerity under current conditions is that when private demand is weak and monetary policy is up against the zero lower bound, there is no offset to changes in government spending. This shouldnt be a hard concept to grasp  in particular, you would think that anyone posing as an economist could grasp the conditional nature of the statement. But, well  some short takes just from the past few days:

title: Berkshire Hathaways 2013 Shareholder Meeting
description: OMAHA  Even with the addition of a hedge fund manager meant to inject additional skepticism into Berkshire Hathaways annual meeting, Warren E. Buffett managed to escape making big news here on Saturday.

title: The Most Active Friends of the Court
description: According to an analysis of briefs filed over a recent three-year period, groups who favor business interests file the most friend-of-the-court briefs encouraging the Supreme Court to review a case.

title: One Year Into Hollande Presidency in France, a Sense of Drift
description: PARIS  The former French president Nicolas Sarkozy recently gave a speech to a telecommunications conference in Montreal. I feel good, he said, grinning. And when I look at those who succeeded me, I even feel very good.

title: Graduating to Next Level of Hard Lessons
description: BOSTON

title: When Attackers Become Defenders, Innovation Is Lost
description: This interview with  Steve Case, chief executive of Revolution, an investment firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. Mr. Case was also a founder of America Online.

title: A Pro-Business Court
description: The court led by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. has been friendlier to corporate interests than any other recent court, according to a new study of the votes of 36 justices serving since 1946.

title: Autistic Twins Are Hoping for Calm Races After the Trauma of Boston
description: BETHPAGE, N.Y.  Alex and Jamie Schneider run seemingly on instinct, saying nothing and drifting into a cone of concentration. They are autistic 22-year-old identical twins from Long Island whose passion is to run for miles at a time. The twins, who are nonverbal and can exhibit severe behaviors like self-injury and tantrums, have completed more than 120 races, including five marathons and eight half-marathons, over the past seven years.

title: The Branding of Rory McIlroy
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  It was time for Rory McIlroy to face the television cameras after another well-played round at the Wells Fargo Championship. Emerging Friday from the scoring area at Quail Hollow, McIlroy reached into his golf bag and slipped on an Omega Seamaster Planet Ocean watch with a blue rubber strap.

title: Variety: An Ephemeral Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  One of the things I really like about acrostic puzzles is that it is virtually impossible to fail completely at them. Even if youve never heard of an OVEN BIRD, for example, perhaps you might toggle back and forth from the entry to the quote just enough to complete the word. And now, thanks to Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, you will always know what an OVEN BIRD is.

title: Karzai Says He Was Assured C.I.A. Would Continue Delivering Bags of Cash
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The C.I.A.s station chief here met with President Hamid Karzai on Saturday, and the Afghan leader said he had been assured that the agency would continue dropping off stacks of cash at his office despite a storm of criticism that has erupted since the payments were disclosed.

title: In Latin America, U.S. Focus Shifts From Drug War to Economy
description: SAN JOS, Costa Rica  In February 2009, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. declared that international drug trafficking posed a sustained, serious threat to Americans. Two months later, President Obama, in his first visit as president to Mexico, made it clear that no issue dominated relations between the two countries more, saying drug cartels there were sowing chaos in our communities.

title: Lockout Hangover Is Persistent in Montreal
description: MONTREAL  Outside Bell Centre on Friday, it was as it should be. The Canadiens were in the playoffs, the unseasonably warm weather created a demand for beer that street vendors could not satisfy, and the usual small army of children in jerseys were filling tin cans with donations for their hockey teams.

title: The Game That Never Ends
description: Manny Schellscheidt likes to keep the game simple. He recalls setting up countless pickup games over the years, saying: We divide the kids up, whatever the numbers, play to five goals, and sometimes put conditions on them like two-touch. They can remember the rules and just keep going. Its the game that never ends.

title: Seeking to Lure Tourists to a Rugged Outpost Famed for a Deadly Feud
description: SARAH ANN, W.Va.  Standing on the back of an Appalachian hillside, Reo Hatfield fixed his gaze over the land of his infamous forebears, a scowl etched across his face.

title: Resorts Reborn in Decay
description: They were the grand palaces of her childhood, the fortress hotels where her family celebrated Jewish holidays, where a girl from the Catskills could run wild or hear stories about how her grandparents met. She learned to swim in the pool at one hotel and worked as a summer lifeguard at another. Then, when she left for college on the West Coast, Marisa Scheinfeld, 32, found herself grappling with homesickness.

title: This Year, No Waiting For Crackdown
description: The first games of this years Stanley Cup playoffs may be as belligerent as last years, but the N.H.L.s initial response has been far more proactive, and may signal a stricter stance against checks to the head.

title: Tobacco Lovers Discover Mystique of Perique
description: GRAND POINT, La.  About 15 years ago, the world supply of the pungent Cajun tobacco perique was down to about five barrels. One of the rarest tobaccos in the world, it comes from St. James Parish, about 50 miles west of New Orleans.

title: California Wildfires May Be Controlled This Weekend, Official Says
description: Wildfires gripping Ventura County, Calif., spread on Friday night but will most likely come under control during the weekend with the aid of favorable weather, a fire official said Saturday.

title: Hudson Joins a Club That Becomes Harder to Make
description: ATLANTA  Mark Mulder flew here Tuesday night, found a steakhouse for dinner and sat at the bar to watch his old friend Tim Hudson pitch on television. Mulder, 35, is two years younger than Hudson. Each won 81 games for the Oakland Athletics from 2000 through 2004. But Mulder is a broadcaster now for ESPN, nearly seven years removed from his last victory.

title: Keynes, Keynesians, the Long Run, and Fiscal Policy
description: One dead giveaway that someone pretending to be an authority on economics is in fact faking it is misuse of the famous Keynes line about the long run. Heres the actual quote:

title: Braves Formula: Swing, Miss and Win
description: ATLANTA  The strikeout has become an epidemic in major league baseball, and the Braves are one of the clubs most affected by the outbreak. Atlantas hitters are striking out 9.2 times a game, which puts them on a pace to become the second team to strike out more than 1,400 times in a season.

title: Chinese Rivers Fate May Reshape a Region
description: Those who treasure the Nu River in Bingzhongluo, China, say the construction of proposed dams would alter what guidebooks call the Grand Canyon of the East.

title: Plans to Harness Chinese Rivers Power Threaten a Region
description: BINGZHONGLUO, China  From its crystalline beginnings as a rivulet seeping from a glacier on the Tibetan Himalayas to its broad, muddy amble through the jungles of Myanmar, the Nu River is one of Asias wildest waterways, its 1,700-mile course unimpeded as it rolls toward the Andaman Sea.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jimmy Connors: From Lone Wolf to Open Book
description: Jimmy Connors showed signs of obsessive compulsive disorder and ocular motor sensory deficit as a child, long before he realized they were serious problems. He tried Gamblers Anonymous to curb a fix that still itches and took his grandmothers advice as a mantra: Keep a little mystery about yourself in life.

title: Welcome to Erbil, Tourism Boom Town
description: ERBIL, Iraq  Erbil is preparing to greet visitors as the Arab Capital of Tourism in 2014, a singular honor for a non-Arab city. It won out over Beirut, Sharjah and the Saudi resort of Taif.

title: Celtics Contemplate Future, Which May Include Swan Song for Their Core
description: BOSTON  Ear-splitting music is now as much a part of the N.B.A. experience as the game itself. It certainly was Friday night at TD Garden for Game 6 of the Celtics first-round playoff series against the Knicks.

title: Indecisive Battles (Feeding My Civil War Obsession)
description: Ive been loving the Timess Disunion blog, partly because it plays into my U.S. Grant obsession. And James Q. Whitmans post about how battlefield victories didnt seem to settle anything was definitely interesting.

title: Management, to the Barricades!
description: THE annals of business history abound with stories of entrenched corporate executives building fortifications to maintain their plush status quo. But recent maneuvers by the board of the CommonWealth real estate investment trust put the company in a class by itself. CommonWealth REIT owns office buildings in and around major metropolitan areas in the United States. Founded in 1986 and based in Newton, Mass., CommonWealth, like many REITs, is not taxed on its income, which it distributes to shareholders. Its hefty payouts  4.75 percent based on its share price of $21.04  have made it a favorite among individual investors looking for income.

title: It Takes James to Stop a Village
description: MILWAUKEE  The Heat were looking to sweep the Bucks last Sunday, but with about five minutes remaining in the third quarter, Miamis lead was down to 4 points. LeBron James, irritated by his teams lack of intensity on defense, punched the chair next to him during a timeout, inserted his mouth guard and methodically halted Milwaukees momentum.

title: The Apprentices of a Digital Age
description: JASMINE GAO, who is 19, just wasnt the classroom type. So instead of languishing in college, she dropped out after her freshman year.

title: With an Old Factory, Philadelphia Is Hoping to Draw New Teachers
description: PHILADELPHIA  A Victorian-era dye factory is taking on a new role to help this citys troubled public school system attract and retain teachers.

title: This Time, Theres No Reggie Miller for the Pacers
description: The Knicks and the Indiana Pacers have faced each other six times in the N.B.A. postseason, with each team winning three series. They first met in 1993; they last played in 2000. This will be their first playoff meeting without Reggie Miller hitting 3-pointers and taking on the role of Indianas comic-book villain. Without him, this series will probably not have the same edge, although the Knicks and the Pacers had some pointed moments this season in splitting four games.

title: Does Class Size Count?
description: As states cut education budgets in response to the nations continuing economic woes, student-to-teacher ratios are again on the rise after decades of decline. This resurrects an age-old debate in American education: does class size really matter?

title: Autopsy Says Boston Bombing Suspect Died of Gunshot Wounds and Blunt Trauma
description: WORCESTER, Mass.  Tamerlan Tsarnaev, the 26-year-old man who the authorities say is one of two brothers who carried out the Boston Marathon bombing, died of gunshot wounds and blunt trauma, according to his death certificate.

title: Electronics Dump
description: Most outdated electronics are thrown away rather than recycled. Charts show the percentage of U.S. electronics, by weight, that wound up in landfills or incinerators in 2006-10.

title: 102 Floors, 10 Million Bricks and One Tangled History
description: The Empire State Building stands as an enduring symbol of New York City  and of the mayhem and legal conflict to which New York City real estate titans are prone. The most recent conflict, however, seems to be inching toward a resolution.

title: N.R.A. Leadership Rallies Members for 2014 Elections
description: HOUSTON  In speech after speech at the National Rifle Associations annual convention here this weekend, its top leaders and political allies blasted President Obama and other gun control advocates, warned against all-out, historic attacks on the constitutional right to possess firearms, and issued a rallying cry to members to become a political force in next years midterm elections and the 2016 presidential race.

title: Trevor the Goat: A Stubborn Sweetheart
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  In a world of flashy, lean thoroughbreds, skinny jockeys, slender exercise riders and bony barn kitties, Trevor stands out from the moment you see him. Trevor looks like a heavy, swollen water barrel balanced precariously on four skinny legs and swings his head around to stare at you when you say hello. Whether curled up on a bale of hay or standing between barn rows, Trevor surveys all he sees through his raccoon-masked face with weird horizontal eyes that would seem more appropriate in a science fiction movie. If he decides to move, it might be with purpose. But then again, he might just stop and stare as he decides whether he wishes to move. You might swear that he is smiling at you the entire time.

title: More Tech Magic, if You Can Afford It
description: LAST week, I glimpsed the future. I tried on Google Glass, the much-anticipated computer eyewear that lets you skim e-mail and shoot video.

title: Am I an Immigrant Writer?
description: I learned recently, to my surprise, that I had written a novel about the immigrant experience. The novel I thought Id written was simply about a mother and daughter, but the inside flap of the book jacket made it clear I had written anew the immigrant experience.

title: National Rifle Association Holds Annual Meetings
description: Advocates of the second amendment met at the National Rifle Associations meetings and exhibits in Houston.

title: Another Order to Vacate at Site Threatened by Crane
description: One of the more dramatic moments as Hurricane Sandy raged last October took place in Midtown Manhattan when hundreds of people were forced to leave their homes because the winds accompanying the storm had damaged the boom of a crane that loomed 1,000 feet above the sidewalk from a soaring residential tower under construction just south of Columbus Circle.

title: Dow 15,000, and the Big Disconnect
description: ITS a ho-hum economy, at best. Four years after the end of the Great Recession, gross domestic product appears to be growing at a lackluster pace, labor productivity is lagging and, despite a slight improvement last month, the unemployment rate is still a painfully high 7.5 percent.

title: Sunday Dialogue: A Talent for Teaching
description: Readers discuss what goes into making a gifted teacher.

title: David Benioff
description: David Benioff is a novelist and screenwriter who co-created the popular HBO series Game of Thrones.

title: The Cancer of Optimism
description: BOSTON

title: Lost in the Geometry of Californias Farms
description: I drove down the San Joaquin Valley along Interstate 5 the other day. It was a tour of the less populous California, a route that  to borrow a 50-year-old phrase from Joan Didion  is also the trail of an intention gone haywire.

title: Repairing the Credibility Cracks
description: THE scandal that exploded 10 years ago last week was epic, as world-class as the newspaper where it happened.

title: European Stagnation
description: Economic conditions in Europe, especially in troubled nations like Spain, Portugal and Italy, have deteriorated sharply in recent months. Worse, new data released last week provides no hope for a recovery soon. The unemployment rate in the 17 countries that use the euro hit a record of 12.1 percent in March, up from 11 percent a year earlier. In Spain and Greece, more than half of the labor force under 25 is looking for work.

title: The House Prefers Chaos to Order
description: Regular order! That has been the demand of House Republicans for three years, insisting on a return to the distant days when Congress actually passed budget resolutions and spending bills, instead of paying for the government through shortsighted stopgap measures.

title: Academy Extends Voting Privileges in Foreign-Language Category
description: LOS ANGELES  Breaking with a practice that had narrowed Oscar voting in certain categories to those who had seen films on the big screen, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Saturday said it would provide members with DVD versions of nominees in the best foreign film and best documentary short categories, while allowing all voters to cast a final ballot in those races.

title: Warriors and Grizzlies Play to Strengths
description: There was not one right way to reach the second round of the Western Conference playoffs. Two teams that won in first-round upsets, Golden State and Memphis, embraced their strengths and waited for the other team to slip up.

title: Wheres My Ghost Money?
description: I WAS very excited to read, last week, about the ghost money that the C.I.A. is paying to the president of my country, Hamid Karzai. Id like to know: would it be possible for the C.I.A. to give me some, too?

title: Mr. Obama, Dont Draw That Line
description: THE use of chemical weapons is and would be totally unacceptable, President Obama warned Bashar al-Assads government last December. If you make the tragic mistake of using these weapons, there will be consequences and you will be held accountable.

title: A Childs Wild Kingdom
description: IN a couple of weeks, my daughter will turn into a dolphin. Right now, shes a fox. Last year, she was a cricket.

title: This Aint Yogurt
description: AN Arab friend remarked to me that watching the United States debate how much to get involved in Syria reminded him of an Arab proverb: If you burn your tongue once eating soup, for the rest of your life youll blow on your yogurt.

title: Worker Safety in Bangladesh and Beyond
description: The death toll from the collapse of a building in Bangladesh that housed several garment factories now stands at more than 500, with many still missing. While staggering, this tragedy is, sadly, not rare.

title: In a Gaudy Theme Park, Jay-Z Meets J-Gatz
description: WHEN I started out in journalism, I spent five long years as a reporter in Montgomery County, Md., a cosseted suburb of Washington.

title: What Health Insurance Doesnt Do
description: IN one of the most famous studies of health insurance, conducted across the 1970s, thousands of participants were divided into five groups, with each receiving a different amount of insurance coverage. The study, run by the RAND Corporation, tracked the medical care each group sought out, and not surprisingly found that people with more comprehensive coverage tended to make use of it, visiting the doctor and checking into the hospital more often than people with less generous insurance.

title: Beyond the Code of the Streets
description: ONE evening last week, I joined some friends for recreational beverages after work. These friends were all natives of a certain tribe  black men raised in the crack-era inner cities, now thriving in some other America. They were all college graduates (except me) and upstanding citizens of virtuous reputation. And like me, they were haunted by codes that aided their rise in the old world but might stunt their growth in the new.

title: Sexism and the Single Murderess
description: SEX game gone wrong, sex game gone awry, sex-mad flatmate, sex-crazed killer.

title: Where Do Old Cellphones Go to Die?
description: AMERICANS replace their cellphones every 22 months, junking some 150 million old phones in 2010 alone. Ever wondered what happens to all these old phones? The answer isnt pretty.

title: Capitals Take 2-0 Series Lead Over Rangers
description: WASHINGTON  The Rangers will remember their bitterly disappointing 1-0 overtime loss to the Washington Capitals on Saturday as a failure of their power play.

title: 8 Soldiers Die in Attacks in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Eight soldiers with the American-led military coalition were killed Saturday, making it the bloodiest day this year for Western troops fighting here.

title: When the Global Economy Was on the Brink
description: NEIL IRWIN admires central bankers, and maybe he has a point. With the interplay of Congress and the presidency bordering on the dysfunctional these days, is there a more accomplished Washington figure than the scholarly and respected Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve?

title: To Fight Pandemics, Reward Research
description: THAT frightening word pandemic is back in the news. A strain of avian influenza has infected people in China, with a death toll of more than 25 as of late last week. The outbreak raises renewed questions about how to prepare for possible risks, should the strain become more easily communicable or should other deadly variations arise.

title: The Groundwork for Good References
description: Q. Of the many ways that companies evaluate job candidates, references still hold much weight. How can you ensure that managers or co-workers will say the right things when asked about you?

title: A Family Perspective
description: IM the second-youngest of six brothers. My dad owned a packaging company in Stratford, Conn., and most of my brothers worked there at some point, along with our aunts and uncles. I never did. Dad was selling the business by the time I reached my midteens, and he wanted me to get some experience elsewhere.

title: Highlights and Analysis: Orb Wins Kentucky Derby
description: Orb rallied down the homestretch on Saturday to win the 139th running of the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky.

title: In First Victory, a First-Class Outing for Hughes
description: Even though Phil Hughes had not recorded a win, he still felt good about the beginning of his season. And for good reason: his fastball had been alive, his confidence was up, and the Yankees had been victorious in his previous two starts.

title: A Simpler Bank System
description: To the Editor:

title: Prizes With a Message
description: To the Editor:

title: In Malaysia, a Historic Chance for Reform
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia

title: Corporations Find a Friend in the Supreme Court
description: NOT long after 10 a.m. on March 27, a restless audience waited for the Supreme Court to hear arguments in the second of two historic cases involving same-sex marriage. First, however, Justice Antonin Scalia attended to another matter. He announced that the court was throwing out an antitrust class action that subscribers brought against Comcast, the nations largest cable company.

title: Crunch Time
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  This is going to be a divisive one, and Ill tell you why. Theres nothing offensive in this puzzle, but there are those solvers who feel that if they are going to commit their time to a bigger grid on the weekend than they do for the daily puzzles, then the larger puzzle should be that much more entertaining. The theme should sparkle, nay, gleam. The entries should be lively and the clues should be both witty and spot on.

title: Wise Dan Wins 6th Straight
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Wise Dan, reigning Horse of the Year, earned his sixth consecutive victory dating to last season when he took the $546,400 Woodford Reserve Turf Classic by 4  lengths over Optimizer on Saturday as a prelude to the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs.

title: Latest Product From Tech Firms: An Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The television advertisement that hit the airwaves in Florida last month featured the Republican Partys rising star, Senator Marco Rubio, boasting about his get-tough plan for border security.

title: British M.P. Is Questioned in Rape Inquiry
description: A senior lawmaker from Britains ruling Conservative Party was arrested and questioned by the police on Saturday over allegations of rape and sexual assault involving two men, according to a person familiar with the investigation.

title: Highlights From the N.R.A. Convention
description: A sampling of the speakers  including Sarah Palin and Senator Ted Cruz  at the National Rifle Associations annual convention in Houston.

title: John Williamson, Co-Founder of the Sandstone Retreat, Dies at 80
description: John and Barbara Williamson always insisted that Sandstone Retreat was about more than sex. By all means, help yourselves to each other, they would say. But the goal was larger than spouse-swapping or fulfilling forbidden lust.

title: Alaska Media Battle Pits Old Power vs. Cable Rival
description: ANCHORAGE  Yes, Alaska is woolly and wild. But here is the paradox: it functions in many ways like a medium-size city with a big backyard. Nearly 54 percent of the population, in a state more than twice the size of Texas, clusters here in the largest metropolitan area. That degree of single-city dominance is matched in only a few other places in the United States, notably Nevada, where a tail named Las Vegas wags its dog.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, May 5
description: The carriers are not innocent in this whole game. They are making profit off this.

title: Emil Frei III, Who Put Cancer Cures in Reach, Dies at 89
description: Dr. Emil Frei III, an oncologist whose trailblazing use of combination chemotherapy  in which anticancer drugs are administered simultaneously rather than singly  helped make certain cancers curable for the first time, died on Tuesday at his home in Oak Park, Ill. He was 89.

title: Orb Finds Joy in Mudville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The revelers were sloppy, the grounds were sloppy and the racetrack was sloppy, but Orb apparently did not mind much, and afterward his owners and trainer could not have been happier with the way the day played out.

title: State Sale of 100 Longhorns Stirs Debate, and Proposed Law, on the Breeds Future
description: The resilient longhorn, able to survive on sparse foliage and water, has endured in Texas for more than 100 years. But the recent sale of about 100 longhorns by the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department has spurred debate about the breeds future in the state.

title: Texas Legislators Set to Restore Womens-Health Budgets
description: The political fireworks and high-octane drama that accompanied lawmakers 2011 fight over womens health care and abortion have been absent this legislative session. They have been replaced with some semblance of concession, as legislators on both sides of the aisle work quietly to restore financing for womens health services.

title: Revisiting L.B.J.s Austin, One Address at a Time
description: Long before Austin became a bustling hub of live music, technology and food trucks, it was a simple capital city, dominated by politicians and lobbyists. That city was the Austin of Lyndon Baines Johnsons day. Though Johnson did not live in Austin for much of his life, the city made a mark on him from an early age. He was only 10 when he began accompanying his father, a state representative, to the Capitol, where he became enchanted with the legislative process.

title: Small-Town Mayors Millions as Exhibit A on Graft in Spain
description: LA MUELA, Spain  In the good times, the former mayor of this small, wind-swept village of 5,000 in northern Spain was busy building: the olive oil museum, the wind museum, the museum of life. If that were not enough, there was the new bullring, the sports center with 25,000 seats and the zoo with the exotic-bird park.

title: The Last Refuge From Scandal? Professorships
description: After a sex scandal forced Eliot Spitzer from the governors mansion in Albany, he turned up at City College, teaching a course called Law and Public Policy. After another sex scandal forced James E. McGreevey from the governors mansion in New Jersey, he turned up at Kean University, teaching in the global M.B.A. program.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 5
description: With Aprils jobs reporteasing concerns about an economic slowdown, Warren E. Buffett, chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, joins ABCs This Week to share his thoughts on the economy.

title: Federation Agrees to Lead Effort Against Cheating
description: The Association of Chess Professionals announced on Monday that the World Chess Federation had finally agreed to create a committee to come up with ways to detect and stop cheating.

title: Kentucky Derby Replay
description: Orb, ridden by jockey Joel Rosario, found a way to win despite muddy conditions at the 139th running of the Kentucky Derby.

title: Berkshires Bear on Tangling With a Master of Question-Dodging
description: OMAHA  When Douglas A. Kass first learned that Warren E. Buffett had selected him to be the official skeptic at Berkshire Hathaways annual meeting this year, the hedge fund manager knew he had a lot of work to do.

title: Winning Battle of Nerves Against Himself, a Player Takes On the Tour
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Robert Karlssons round of three-under-par 69 Saturday at the Wells Fargo Championship began with a single swing, which is not as simple as it sounds. Karlsson, who moved into a tie for fourth at Quail Hollow at six-under 210, had to pull out of last years British Open after developing a nervous tic that made it torture to take the club back. During practice rounds, he stood frozen over his ball, unable to make a swing as the seconds turned into a minute or more.

title: Rangers Fall as Pucks Sail Into Stands
description: WASHINGTON  Delay-of-game penalties loomed large for the Rangers in a 1-0 overtime loss to the Washington Capitals on Saturday.

title: Song Critical of Pakistani Generals Is Blocked Online, With No Official Explanation
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Pakistani band with a reputation for satirizing the countrys military may have finally gone too far.

title: Life in North Korean Complex: A Glimmer of Hope
description: SEOUL, South Korea  When the order came last weekend to evacuate an industrial park in North Korea, Kwak Kyung-dock, a South Korean factory manager, said he was forced to flee with the suit on his back  and his car filled with so many boxes of the plastic machinery parts made at his factory that he had to tie several on the roof.

title: How Wright Prevailed in Duel With Top Closer
description: ATLANTA  David Wright smiled and offered no rational explanation for crushing a 97-mile-per-hour fastball from Craig Kimbrel 10 rows deep over the center-field wall in Turner Field on Friday night. Wright was an accidental hero, he said. He made it sound as if he simply ran into Kimbrels pitch. It was luck, he said.

title: Off-the-Cuff Obama Line Put U.S. in Bind on Syria
description: WASHINGTON  Confronted with evidence that chemical weapons have been used in Syria, President Obama now finds himself in a geopolitical box, his credibility at stake with frustratingly few good options.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 5, 2013
description: Im worried about the broader damage to U.S. credibility if we make a statement and then come back with lawyerly language to get around it.

title: Islanders Looking to Ride Momentum in Front of Home Crowd
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  There was a buoyant atmosphere in the Islanders locker room after practice and their surprising Game 2 victory at Pittsburgh. Now they had a chance to contemplate Sundays afternoon matchup  their first playoff game at home since 2007  at what is expected to be a raucous Nassau Coliseum.

title: Two Are Arrested in Fatal Shooting of Bronx Teenager
description: The police on Saturday arrested two suspects in the fatal shooting of Alphonza Bryant III, the Bronx teenager whose death last month has helped fuel an increasingly rancorous debate over police anti-crime tactics.

title: Up Next for Knicks: a Young, Healthy Copy of the Celtics
description: Before they departed the postseason stage Friday night, the Boston Celtics dealt the Knicks a warning shot: a furious fourth-quarter rally to remind them of their frailties. Before he left the postgame podium, Coach Doc Rivers delivered his own warning, shrouded in a compliment.

title: The Dark Side, Carefully Masked
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  On the day after two bombs exploded near the finish line of the Boston Marathon, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev tapped out an early-afternoon text message to a classmate at the University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth. Want to hang out? he queried. Sure, his friend replied.

title: Corrections: May 5, 2013
description: NATIONAL

title: Nets Show Up Late And Miss Out on Celebration
description: The Nets fought back from a three-games-to-one deficit against the Chicago Bulls to earn this opportunity, a win-or-go-home game in their new arena and another chance for their black-clad fans to shower this rebranded franchise with full-throated adoration.

title: Divided Over Bangladesh
description: A look at two companies with different responses to the tragedy in Bangladesh.

title: Su Casa Es Mi Casa
description: You may not get room service or a terry cloth robe, but what Airbnb vacation rentals lack in amenities, they make up for in unbelievable, sometimes rather bizarre experiences.

title: Game 7: Nets vs. Bulls Replay
description: The banged-up Bulls held off the Nets to advance to the second-round series against the Heat.

title: For Capitals, Its Pass First (and Often)
description: WASHINGTON  No matter how many times they eagerly drew up a new offensive plan Saturday afternoon, the Washington Capitals found themselves in the same old spot.

title: Jennifer Maxwell, Robert McBride
description: Jennifer Lauren Maxwell, the daughter of Theresa M. Maxwell and John G. Maxwell of Warren, N.J., was married Saturday to Robert Lane McBride, a son of Barbara A. McBride and David F. McBride of North Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Elias R. Lorenzo, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Holy Rosary Church in Washington.

title: Samantha Jacobs, Andrew Miller
description: Samantha Alexandra Jacobs and Andrew Nathan Benbasset Miller were married Saturday evening in Old Westbury, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik officiated at the Old Westbury Golf and Country Club.

title: Jennifer Lieber and Kathryn Murray
description: Jennifer Beth Lieber and Kathryn Lynn Murray were married Saturday evening at the Venetian Yacht Club in Babylon, N.Y. Denise Munoz, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Anna Diehn, Benoit Bewley
description: Anna Katharina Diehn, the daughter of Barbara Charlotte Diehn of Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Dietrich Arndt Diehn, was married Saturday evening to Dr. Benoit Richard Bewley, a son of Anne-Franoise Lamine Bewley and Truman Fassett Bewley of Guilford, Conn. The Rev. Dennis Andrews, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Community Presbyterian Church in Deerfield Beach, Fla.

title: Christina Daniels, William Schweitzer Jr.
description: Christina Learson Daniels, a daughter of Elizabeth L. Daniels and Leslie B. Daniels of New York, was married in Palm Beach, Fla., Saturday evening to William Hoefler Schweitzer Jr., a son of Leslie M. Schweitzer and Mr. Schweitzer Sr. of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. James R. Harlan performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea, where he is the rector. The Rev. Brenda Husson, another Episcopal priest, took part.

title: Christina Lee, Kevin Wong
description: Christina Ling Yin Lee and Kevin Wong were married Saturday by the Rev. John Flack, a Lutheran minister, at the Queens Botanical Garden in Flushing, Queens.

title: Diana Uhimov, Christopher Leahy
description: Diana J. Uhimov, a daughter of Mila Uhimov and Joseph G. Uhimov of Langhorne, Pa., and Christopher Michael Leahy, a son of Blitz F. Leahy and Michael J. Leahy of Manhattan, were married Saturday evening in Brooklyn. The father of the bride, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at Milk and Roses, a restaurant.

title: A Silly Question From the License Clerk
description: Gabrielle Rae Marcus, a daughter of Madelynne and Howard Marcus of Miami, is to be married Sunday evening to Brian Adam Marcus, the son of Judith and Andrew Marcus of Manhattan. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas is to officiate at the Pierre in Manhattan.

title: Nicole Lonsway, Alan Schindler
description: Nicole Stephanie Garber Lonsway and Alan Daniel Schindler were married Saturday evening in Middletown, Md. Rabbi Kenneth B. Block officiated at the Stone Manor Country Club.

title: Alexis Oliver, Alan Wilkis
description: Alexis Eden Throux Oliver and Alan Joshua Wilkis were married Saturday in the lobby of the Woolworth Building in New York. Geordie Broadwater, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Rebecca Lambert, Michael Kalin
description: Dr. Rebecca Lynn Lambert and Michael Hart Kalin were married Saturday evening at the Tarrytown House Estate in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Guy Greene officiated.

title: Rebekah Enderle, Erin Simonds
description: Rebekah Elizabeth Enderle and Erin Forbes Simonds were married Saturday at the Alger House, an event space in New York. Dr. Kara L. Davis, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, performed a ceremony that included poetry readings.

title: Burgers and Other Burning Issues
description: Dr. Jessica Kraft Sayre, a daughter of Marcia Kraft-Sayre and Steven E. Sayre of Charlottesville, Va., was married there Saturday to Dr. Matthew John Meyer, a son of Teresa Canal Meyer and John H. Meyer of Shelburne, Vt. The Rev. Dr. Barry Penn Hollar, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at Panorama Farms, an event space.

title: Devon Giddon, Jason Bordenick
description: Devon Lindsay Giddon and Jason Scott Bordenick were married Saturday evening at Fresh Meadow Country Club in Lake Success, N.Y. Rabbi Matthew A. Reimer officiated.

title: Hilary Horvat, Lisa Mody
description: Hilary Laura Horvat and Lisa Jean Mody were married Saturday in Manhattan. The Rev. Rosemary Bray McNatt officiated at the Fourth Universalist Society, where she is the senior minister.

title: Alison Speranza, Casey McGrath
description: Alison Jo Speranza and Casey Thomas McGrath were married Saturday. The Rev. Mary-Rose Engle, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Grounds for Sculpture, a sculpture garden in Hamilton Township, N.J.

title: Sarah Daniels, Kevin Cook
description: Dr. Sarah Ruth Daniels and Dr. Kevin Andrew Cook were married Saturday at the Ashford Estate, an event space in Allentown, N.J. Noah S. Daniels, a brother of the bride, who was ordained by the American Marriage Ministries, officiated.

title: Jacqueline Friedman, Benjamin Brogadir
description: Jacqueline Leigh Friedman, the daughter of Susan Pilch Friedman and Richard A. Friedman of New York, was married Saturday evening to Benjamin Tureck Brogadir, a son of Ilene Brogadir and Dr. Stuart Brogadir of Bedford, N.H. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein performed the ceremony at the Central Synagogue in New York.

title: Margot Kearney, Creighton Navins
description: Margot Helen Kearney and Creighton Lee Navins were married Saturday at the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Thomas E. Collins, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Ingi Lee and David Yoon
description: Dr. Ingi Lee and David Seungro Yoon were married Saturday in Blue Bell, Pa. The Rev. Byeong Eun Lee, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Normandy Farm, a hotel and conference center.

title: Jessica Oliff, Robert Daly
description: Jessica Lee Oliff and Robert Michael Leo Daly were married Saturday evening at the Rittenhouse Hotel in Philadelphia. The Very Rev. Msgr. Jim St. George of the Old Catholic Apostolic Church of North America performed the ceremony.

title: Alyssa Beaver, Daniel Gomez II
description: Alyssa Leid Beaver, a daughter of Thea S. Beaver and William S. Beaver of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there Saturday to Daniel James Gomez II, a son of Alexis D. Gomez and Mr. Gomez of Wayne, Pa. The Rev. Dr. William P. Crawford performed the ceremony at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church, where he is the senior pastor, with Msgr. Thomas F. Petrillo, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: A Charity Auctioneer Gets First Dibs
description: Willa Jane Bernstein and Kevin Michael Murphy were married Saturday evening at the Down Town Association, an event space in New York. The Rev. Ann V. Corbett, a minister ordained by the New Seminary for Interfaith Studies in New York, officiated.

title: Hannah Richard, Robert Coody
description: Hannah McBride Richard and Robert Andrew Coody were married Saturday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Greenville, Ala. The Rev. M. Dow Sanderson, an Episcopal priest and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Jennifer Piston, Ki Whelan
description: Jennifer Sarah Piston and Ki Aron Whelan were married Saturday aboard the yacht Atlantica, which was docked at Pier 61 in New York. Peter Tulba, a friend of the couple who was ordained by American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated.

title: Clare Smith, John Kerrigan
description: Clare Elizabeth Smith and John Joseph Kerrigan were married Friday in Brooklyn. The Rev. Marek W. Sobczak performed the ceremony at the St. Stanislaus Kostka Roman Catholic Church, where he is pastor.

title: Virginia Harper and Tomas Foulger
description: Virginia Italia Harper and Tomas Foulger were married Saturday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Joseph G. Marina, a Roman Catholic priest and an associate pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Julie Greilsheimer, Ryan Silverman
description: Julie Bennett Greilsheimer and Ryan David Silverman are to be married Sunday evening at Battery Gardens Restaurant in New York. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein is to officiate.

title: Bombings at Marathon Lead to Tighter Security
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Churchill Downs thought its security policy for the Kentucky Derby, in the planning since last autumn, was in place when spring arrived. But after the Boston Marathon bombings on April 15, everything changed.

title: With Mental and Physical Mastery, Mayweather Stays Undefeated
description: LAS VEGAS  Floyd Mayweather Jr.s latest boxing triumph followed a familiar pattern. For weeks, he toyed with Robert Guerrero, made him angry, made him jumpy, drew him right into the usual vortex of opponent overconfidence.

title: Noah, Hobbled, Wills Bulls Into the Second Round
description: The emotion that Bulls center Joakim Noah showed as he walked off the court victorious, hugging his mother before triumphantly marching down the tunnel, was gone by the time he sat down to discuss the game. He simply had no energy left to expend.

title: Australia Strives to Balance China and the United States
description: BEIJING  The official Chinese news media responded in a low-key, if apparently approving, fashion to a shift by the Australian government toward a more conciliatory strategic approach to China, judging by reactions over the weekend.

title: A Billionaire Who Breaks the Mold
description: PARIS  Xavier Niel is not what you would expect in a billionaire.

title: Palestinian Leader Seeks Chinese Support
description: HONG KONG  The president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, arrived in Beijing on Sunday seeking support from Chinese leaders, days before Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is to make a visit of his own, although Israeli officials have said there are no plans for a meeting between them.

title: C.I.A. Ghost Money and the Fight Against Terror
description: Its game-on for Karzai with C.I.A. ghost money.

title: Naive Fiscal Cynicism
description: Expansionary austerity has been refuted and even the IMF sayis that short-run multipliers are big. The 90 percent red line on debt was an artifact of fuzzy math. The bond vigilantes remain invisible, and the confidence fairy refuses to make an appearance. Clearly, austerian economics has imploded (and some prominent austerians seem to be personally imploding too).

title: Talking With My Daughter About My Service in Iraq
description: Mom, what did you see over there? What was it like? Did you have a gun? Did you kill anyone?

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: Caravan magazine digs deep in a profile of the attorney general of India, the federal governments top law officer, the Inside Man. Its an important piece and one thats long overdue, as the story correctly and articulately points out: In an era when fortunes can be made and lost on the whims of government policy (or the manipulation thereof), billions of rupees hinge on the decisions of the Supreme Court, which has become the ultimate arbiter in innumerable disputes between corporates and the state. Today, the countrys top lawyers, who charge upwards of Rs. 10 lakh (Rs 1 million) for a single court appearance, are some of the capitals most powerful figures, Delhis closest equivalent to the Wall Street investment bankers that Tom Wolfe once dubbed masters of the universe.

title: Syria Blames Israel for Fiery Attack in Damascus
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian government publicly condemned Israel for a powerful air assault on military targets near Damascus early Sunday, saying it opened the door to all possibilities, as fear spread throughout the region that the countrys civil war could expand beyond its borders.

title: North Korea Says Prisoner Wont Be Used as Leverage
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said Sunday that it would not use an imprisoned American citizen as a political bargaining chip, rejecting the possibility of allowing any prominent Americans to visit the North to request his release, as it has in similar cases.

title: Disruptions: New Motto for Silicon Valley: First Security, Then Innovation
description: At Facebooks headquarters in Palo Alto, Calif., are stark white posters with bright red statements like Done is better than perfect and Move fast and break things.

title: The Board of Education Lives On, if Only to Be Sued
description: On Jan. 9, 2003, Jamie Perez was slashed by two fellow students at Evander Childs High School in the Bronx. He recovered, and his mother, Nancy Torres, sued the City of New York for negligence, claiming lax security.

title: McCain Says Airstrikes in Syria Put Pressure on Obama to Act
description: Senator John McCain, who has long advocated for more forceful United States support of the Syrian rebels, said Sunday that the two airstrikes just outside of the Syrian capital in recent days  which the Syrian government said were carried out by Israel  were likely to increase pressure on President Obama to act.

title: British M.P. Rejects Accounts of Assaults
description: LONDON  Nigel Evans, the senior Conservative member of Parliament who has been questioned by the police over accusations of rape and sexual assault involving two men, said Sunday that the allegations were completely false.

title: Regulation Scoreless Ties Are Rare for Rangers in Playoffs
description: Saturdays 1-0 overtime loss at Washington marked the first time in 80 years that a Rangers playoff game went scoreless through regulation.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: NOON (13) UN BALLO IN MASCHERA Marcelo lvarez, above with Kathleen Kim, performs the role of the ill-fated King Gustavo III; Dmitri Hvorostovsky is his best friend and eventual rival, Count Anckarstrom; and Sondra Radvanovsky is Amelia, Anckarstroms wife and the object of the kings secret passion, in this Metropolitan Opera production of Verdis drama about political intrigue and thwarted romance. The most interesting aspect of David Aldens disappointing, metaphor-laden new production, Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times of this Great Performances at the Met presentation, is that he uses an early-20th-century setting and film noir imagery to emphasize not just the works darkness but also its strangeness. Still, he said, Ms. Radvanovsky was splendid, and Mr. Hvorostovsky sang with his trademark dark sound and supple phrasing, which poignantly brought to life this suffering husbands love.

title: Neighbors Resist a Plan to Clean a Toxic Canal
description: Almost everybody wants the Gowanus Canal cleansed of its toxic gunk.

title: A New Way to Care for Young Brains
description: BOSTON  The drumbeat of alarming stories linking concussions among football players and other athletes to brain disease has led to a new and mushrooming American phenomenon: the specialized youth sports concussion clinic, which one day may be as common as a mall at the edge of town.

title: Anecdotal Evidence Provides Clues to Youth Concussions
description: Youth sports concussion clinics operate at the center of Americas heightened awareness and increasing worry about concussions among young athletes. Listening to the hundreds of stories of how concussions have occurred, examining patients and monitoring their recoveries, the doctors and staff members are a repository of anecdotal and medical concussion information.

title: Frederic Franklin, Inventive and Charismatic Ballet Star, Is Dead at 98
description: Frederic Franklin, a charismatic British-born dancer and ballet master who was known for his stylistic versatility and his inexhaustible energy  he performed into his 90s  died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 98.

title: Flubbing a Baseline Test on Purpose Is Often Futile
description: In 2011, quarterback Peyton Manning suggested he purposely flubbed a preseason neurocognitive baseline test to make the results of any postconcussion test look better, which might have improved his chances of returning to play sooner.

title: Obama Delivers Message of Optimism to Class of 13
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Acknowledging that commencement addresses are no place for partisanship, President Obama nonetheless skirted close to that political line on Sunday, telling graduates at Ohio State University to ignore antigovernment voices that gum up the works and instead aspire to be citizens who value both individual rights and community responsibilities.

title: Slovenia Falls From Economic Grace, Struggling to Avert a Bailout
description: LJUBLJANA, SLOVENIA  Only a few years ago, Bine Kordez was feted as Slovenias star entrepreneur. After transforming a home-improvement chain, Merkur, into a regional giant, he drew on easy credit from state-run banks to help orchestrate a 400 million management buyout of the company, the largest in the countrys history.

title: Obama Comments on Airstrikes in Syria
description: President Obama speaks about the airstrikes in Syria, which the country immediately blamed on Israel.

title: On the Town: Glimpses of Americana, Through the Young
description: Jerome Robbinss first two dances mapped out his creative life. After choreographing Fancy Free, a 1944 hit about three sailors on shore leave, he was clearly headed down the golden path of musical-theater. But a year later he created the playful Interplay, which integrated classical steps with a jazzy, American style of moving. This showed his range; Robbinss other foot belonged in ballet.

title: In Russia, a Modern Theater Is the Star
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  Let no one say Valery Gergiev doesnt know how to give a party.

title: Nets Will Replace Carlesimo After Being Out-Toughed by Bulls
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Nets off-season began late Saturday, after a Game 7 loss that will sting long into summer. Less than 24 hours later, the team took its first step toward the future, announcing that the interim coach P. J. Carlesimo would not return.

title: Last Hope in Ruins: Bangladeshs Race to Save Shaheena
description: SAVAR, Bangladesh  The rescuers discovered her by a faint, distant sound. They had spent four days crawling through the wreckage of Rana Plaza, tons of concrete and steel pressing down, saving hundreds of people. Now only the dead remained. Except for a lone woman, a garment worker.

title: Man Accused of Lying Seeks Release as Cemeteries Reject Tsarnaev Family
description: BOSTON  Robel K. Phillipos, the former University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth student who is accused of lying to the authorities investigating the Boston Marathon bombings, will seek to be released from federal custody on Monday, his lawyers said in court papers filed over the weekend.

title: Tensions Rise After Airstrikes in Syria
description: Syria blamed the airstrike Sunday on Israel, and it was believed to be Israels second in three days.

title: Succession at Berkshire Is Minor Concern for NetJets Chief
description: OMAHA  Many of the questions at Berkshire Hathaways annual shareholder meeting here dwelled on what life after Warren E. Buffett will look like.

title: In Iron Man, Hopes for Strong Summer for Movies
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywoods all-important summer season began with a sonic boom over the weekend as Iron Man 3 flew to a superheroic $175.3 million in ticket sales in North America, for a new global total of $680.1 million.

title: Spring North American Championships
description: ST. LOUIS  The Spring North American Championships here in March featured a lot more excellent deals than is usual for a Nationals. In some ways the diagramed deal was the best of them all, although, to be fair, declarer had one opportunity to ruin the story. It was first reported by Sven-Olov Flodqvist from Sweden.

title: Stories of Struggle and Creativity as Sequestration Cuts Hit Home
description: Facing the task of cutting 142 children from the Head Start program in Colorado Springs this fall, the teachers and administrators came up with a creative response: Have the children decorate empty chairs, then sell them for $500 apiece to stave off the worst of the across-the-board federal cuts heading their way. So far, in a month, their Fill a Seat fund-raiser has filled just two slots in the program.

title: A Ring Virtuoso, Fighting for Respect
description: LAS VEGAS

title: For a Night, Three-Part Harmony and Multipart Orchestra Are One
description: This is sort of like three children being let loose at NASA, David Crosby said. But boy, is it fun. With his longtime colleagues Graham Nash and Stephen Stills, Mr. Crosby was the most voluble participant in an outlandish musical experiment at Rose Hall at Jazz at Lincoln Center on Friday evening: the conjoining of Crosby, Stills and Nash with the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra. Talk about worlds colliding.

title: Up Two, Down Two, Isles Tie It and Lose
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Pittsburgh Penguins forward Chris Kunitz is exceptionally glad that Sidney Crosby is back on the ice. So are his teammates, who escaped with a win Sunday over the pesky Islanders.

title: Evoking a Time and Place for Daring Experiments
description: From the end of the 19th century through the first decades of the 20th century Vienna was a hotbed of cultural, social and political ferment. The soprano Rene Fleming chose this era as the focus of the final program in her Perspectives series this season at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night.

title: An Intentional Spectacle
description: I hate the harpsichord, it reminds me of a sewing machine, the composer John Cage is reported to have said. Yet a commission from Antoinette Vischer, a Swiss harpsichordist who specialized in modern music, prompted Cage to conceive one of his most audacious creations: HPSCHD, fashioned in collaboration with another composer, Lejaren Hiller.

title: Accessories No Longer Tethered to Apple
description: For years, Apples clout in the electronics world could be gauged by how easy it was to bump into devices tailor-made for a connection to an iPhone or iPod.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: A Return to the Nine-Hole Round
description: Less than 30 years ago, nearly half of the golf courses in America had nine holes. There was no stigma to that number. The nine-hole golf round was as common as a slice off the first tee.

title: Foreign Bride as a Fetish and a Person
description: Steven is a 60-year-old parking-garage attendant who lives in a small apartment above a store in the Northern California suburbs. Hes white, which is significant because he has what is politely known as an Asian fetish and popularly known as yellow fever. Theyre all so beautiful, he says, looking at a display of thumbnail images of prospective Asian brides.

title: Honoring Songbooks Dean
description: What would the composer Jerome Kern have made of Woodstock? That question was asked but not answered on Saturday evening at the 92nd Street Y by Deborah Grace Winer, the artistic director of the venerable Lyrics and Lyricists series, in the opening-night concert of its seasons second-to-last program.

title: With Pettitte Missing His Touch, Yankees Fall to Athletics
description: After more than 18 seasons in the major leagues, Yankees starter Andy Pettitte knows what the ball is supposed to feel like once it leaves his hand. There is a certain subtlety that makes it difficult for him to explain the feeling, but he knows by touch. He knows almost immediately after he throws a pitch how it will arrive at home plate without even seeing it land in the catchers mitt.

title: On Script and Off, Giving Voice to the Yankees
description: The day after the Boston Marathon bombings, the New York Yankees honored the fallen in a pregame ceremony at their stadium in the Bronx. The task of leading the fans in thistribute went to Paul Olden, the teams public-address announcer. He felt something was missing, though.

title: Mail Letters
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Warning: vowel run. But not the kind youre thinking of.

title: A Fund-Raisers Finale
description: There are many artists at Lincoln Center. Reynold Levy, president of the performing arts center, likes to think of himself as one of them. His art is putting the arm on donors, and he is acknowledged to be one of the very best nudges in New York. Ive asked everyone for money, Mr. Levy said in an interview. They hide behind pillars when they see me.

title: Fighting Words Against Big Data
description: As its title indicates, Jaron Laniers new tech manifesto asks, Who owns the future? But for many of those who will be captivated by Mr. Laniers daringly original insights, another question comes first: Who is Jaron Lanier? He is a mega-wizard in futurist circles. He is the father of virtual reality in the gaudy, reputation-burnishing way that Michael Jackson was the king of pop. Mr. Lanier would undoubtedly be more of a household name if he were not a large, dreadlocked, anything but telegenic figure with facial hair called mossy in a 2011 profile in The New Yorker.

title: A Dancing Queen Extends Her Reign
description: Dance-floor hits like Waterloo, S.O.S. and Gimme! Gimme! Gimme! (A Man After Midnight) hardly seem to be any less ubiquitous in the more than 30 years since they were first recorded by Abba, the best-selling Swedish pop quartet. But if its music is everywhere, its band mates are not: in particular, its been almost a decade since listeners last heard from Agnetha Faltskog, the singer whose distinctive voice helped give Abba its carefree Scandinavian charm.

title: TED Teams Up With PBS on Ideas for Education
description: Television viewers  even those who watch the more sober-minded PBS  are generally not keen on sitting through long speeches. But TED, the nonprofit group that sponsors conferences on ideas, thinks it has found a way to bring its signature 18-minute talks to a TV audience that may not have found them on the Web or through mobile apps.

title: Lottery Numbers
Mets Fielding Miscues Lead to Loss to Braves
description: ATLANTA  The Mets wrestled with themselves all afternoon Sunday. Wild pitches, misplayed balls, bad swings and walks ruined them. The team that looked spectacularly poised Friday night in a dramatic victory over Atlanta lost to the Braves, 9-4, at Turner Field.

title: Compensation Compared
description: The pay of top media company chief executives compared with other industries.

title: Wrongfully Convicted Often Find Their Record, Unexpunged, Haunts Them
description: In Wisconsin, Audrey Edmunds served 11 years in prison in the shaking death of an infant girl for whom she had been baby-sitting. In 2008, a mountain of new medical evidence cast so much doubt on the case that a higher court overturned her conviction and set her free. Leaving prison, Ms. Edmunds hoped that would be the end of it.

title: George Osbornes Fear of Ghosts
description: Truly, we live in bizarro world. The stern taskmasters of the IMF are coming to Britain, to demand that the government live it up and spend more; the government, defiantly, will insist on continuing to impose suffering.

title: Kierkegaards Antigone
description: Perhaps the most central theme in Soren Kierkegaards religious thought is the doctrine of original sin: the idea that we share in some essential human guilt simply by being born. But guilt is an important concept also in Kierkegaards secular writings. He thought that the modern era was defined by its concept of guilt. Kierkegaards 200th birthday gives us an occasion to assess the modern relevance of his legacy and the viability of his own view of modernity.

title: Media Giants Chase Online Ads With Original Shows
description: Everyone wants to be in show biz, and these days  on the Web at least  it seems as if everyone is.

title: With Aggressive Defense, Pacers Shut Down Knicks
description: The challenge necessarily grows bigger as the N.B.A. playoffs progress, and the Knicks are a seasoned enough group to understand this basic truth. It was, however, not the size of the challenge but the actual size of the players standing in their path that put the first real crimp in the Knicks postseason thrill ride.

title: A Call for New Blood on the JPMorgan Board
description: An influential shareholder advisory firm has recommended that investors withhold their support for three JPMorgan Chase directors, citing material failures of stewardship and risk oversight in the wake of a big trading loss last year.

title: Eleanor R. Adair, Microwave Proponent, Dies at 86
description: Eleanor R. Adair, a scientist who spent decades exposing monkeys and eventually people (including herself) to microwave radiation to determine whether it posed serious health risks  she concluded, emphatically and somewhat controversially, that it did not  died on April 20 in Hamden, Conn. She was 86.

title: Airstrikes Tied to Israel May Be Message to Iranians
description: JERUSALEM  The twin airstrikes in Damascus on Friday and Sunday attributed to Israel appear to be more about Jerusalems broad, mostly covert battle with Iran and Hezbollah than about the bloody civil war raging in Syria.

title: Mickelson Fades Late as Tour Rookie Secures First Victory in Playoff
