description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Who can take some rainfall, create cover with his smile and give fans the thumbs-up on Quail Hollows thorny Green Mile? Phil Mickelson can. But on a damp, dreary Sunday, Mickelsons sunny demeanor could not light his way to victory at the Wells Fargo Championship.

title: Buyout Consortium Said Near a Deal for BMC
description: 8:28 p.m. | Updated

title: BuzzFeed Takes Steps to Expand Foreign News
description: BuzzFeed, the swiftly growing social news site, has decided it is time to move beyond top 10 lists, animal videos and political coverage. It is going foreign.

title: Economic Reports for the Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Information to be released includes the euro area purchasing managers index for April (Monday); United States consumer credit for March and China trade data for April (Tuesday); China inflation for April (Wednesday); and weekly initial jobless claims and United States wholesale inventories for March (Thursday).

title: Malaysias Governing Coalition Keeps Hold on Power
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Malaysias governing coalition won a majority of parliamentary seats in national elections on Sunday after the largest turnout in the countrys history, but a bitter coalition of opposition parties claimed that the result was tainted by illegal voting and other irregularities.

title: An End to Scrounging for Plus-Size Clothing
description: NEARLY three in four American men over 19 are overweight, so it should come as no surprise that most men shopping at big-and-tall stores are of average height but considerable girth. Marketing for such stores, however, features models built more like professional football players than their beer-drinking fans.

title: Cabinet Picks Finances May Foreshadow Battle
description: WASHINGTON  In November 2008, as President-elect Barack Obama began putting together his cabinet, reports emerged that he was considering nominating Penny Pritzker, the billionaire Hyatt Hotels heiress and businesswoman who had served as his chief campaign fund-raiser, as commerce secretary. But faced with awkward questions about her financial dealings, she declared that she did not want the nomination.

title: Merkels Flagging Coalition Partner Tries to Bolster Its Image
description: MUNICH  The struggling junior partner in Germanys coalition government tried over the weekend to overcome its image as a bickering party lacking in leadership and solid policies at a party congress in Nuremberg where delegates heard rousing speeches, sharp attacks on the opposition and an election plan intended to attract voters concerned about maintaining German prosperity.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Poetry of the Streets, Written by Those Who Know Them Best
description: The poets work from 5 to 5, day shift or night, conducting their research with the meter running.

title: Strict Limits on Giving in City Races Are Upheld
description: A judge on Friday rebuffed an attempt by George T. McDonald, a first-time Republican mayoral candidate, to overturn New York Citys strict limits on campaign contributions, ruling that the city had the right to try to reduce the influence of money in politics.

title: Behind the Scenes at Fox
description: A few days before the presidential election last November, Roger Ailes, the chief executive of Fox News, ordered that Geraldo Riveras microphone be cut off after Mr. Rivera angrily defended the Obama administration against charges levied by others on Fox. So says a forthcoming book about the 2012 campaign by Jonathan Alter, a columnist for Bloomberg View and a contributor to MSNBC, a Fox competitor.

title: One Race Down, Its Off to Next for Orb
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  By noon Sunday, Barn 43 at Churchill Downs had been practically wiped clean. There were no horses in the stalls, no signs of what had happened there throughout the week, culminating in Orbs thrilling come-from-behind Kentucky Derby victory, save for a few scribbled notes on a message board that included a veterinarians phone number and the horses feed schedules.

title: Extremists Pursue Mainstream in Pakistan Election
description: KHALID WALID, Pakistan  Dust swirled as the jeep, heralded by a convoy of motorcycle riders and guarded by gunmen in paramilitary-style uniforms, pulled up outside the towering tomb of an ancient Muslim saint.

title: Israeli Attacks on Syria Fuel Debate Over U.S.-Led Effort
description: WASHINGTON  The apparent ease with which Israel struck missile sites and, by Syrian accounts, a major military research center near Damascus in recent days has stoked debate in Washington about whether American-led airstrikes are the logical next step to cripple President Bashar al-Assads ability to counter the rebel forces or use chemical weapons.

title: For Media Moguls, Paydays That Stand Out
description: Whats the difference between a media mogul and a chief executive elsewhere in the business world? About $10 million in compensation, give or take.

title: Caught in Methodisms Split Over Same-Sex Marriage
description: NEW HAVEN  It started out as a deeply personal act, that of a father officiating at the wedding of his son.

title: Rangers Are Looking for Solution on Offense
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Washington goalie Braden Holtby made a statement Saturday that the Rangers have taken as a rallying point as they look to overcome a 2-0 deficit in their first-round playoff series.

title: New Law in Libya Bans Some From Office
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Young Libyans call their government rule of the mooq-mooq, a nonsensical neologism used to mock the armed militias left over from the uprising against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. And on Sunday, some said, Libyas transitional General National Congress handed a new triumph to the mooq-mooq.

title: Kennedy Library Gives Courage Award to Giffords
description: BOSTON  Caroline Kennedy was not even 6 years old when her father was assassinated 50 years ago. And on Sunday, she said the hurt never heals.

title: Closing the Social Gap in Schools
Q. and A. With Penny Pritzker in 2008
description: In November 2008, after Senator Barack Obama won the presidential election, reports circulated that he was vetting one of his major campaign donors, the businesswoman and Hyatt Hotels heiress Penny Pritzker, as his commerce secretary nominee. The New York Times sent a list of detailed questions to Ms. Pritzker, through her publicist, about her business dealings. Several hours later, she issued a statement saying she did not want to be considered for the position, but she still answered The Timess questions. On Thursday, President Obama announced that he was nominating Ms. Pritzker to be commerce secretary for his second term. Here are her written answers from 2008.

title: German Outpost Born of Racism in 1887 Blends Into Paraguay
description: NUEVA GERMANIA, Paraguay  The year was 1887 when two of the best-known German anti-Semites of the time put down stakes here in Paraguays remote jungle with 14 German families screened for their racial purity.

title: USA Network to Explore Sitcoms and Reality Shows
description: For most of the past decade the USA Network has lived by the mantra blue skies, which has translated into programming a string of upbeat hourlong drama hits, like Burn Notice and Royal Pains.

title: An Unfair Barrier to Employment
description: Sixty-five million Americans have criminal records that might cause them to be denied jobs, even for arrests or minor convictions that occurred in the distant past. Last year, the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission reaffirmed a longstanding ruling that it was illegal to screen out employees unless the offense was directly related to the job.

title: Real Gun Control From Sacramento
description: A continent removed from Washingtons shameful resistance to new gun controls, California has just enacted a law that will speed up the confiscation of firearms from an estimated 20,000 people who bought them legally but were later disqualified because of a conviction for a violent crime, a finding of mental illness or a restraining order for domestic violence. The law, signed Wednesday by Gov. Jerry Brown after passage by the Democrat-controlled Legislature, is a sign that enlightened lawmaking unhindered by gun lobby scare tactics and Capitol Hill filibustering is possible in American politics.

title: A Bit of Sunshine Returns at Last for Fans in the Twilight of an Era
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.

title: In Place of Compassion, Cruelty
description: The Justice Departments inspector general last week issued a report on the appalling failure of the Federal Bureau of Prisons to do its duty in assisting in the release of terminally ill inmates and others in extreme situations. The 85-page report by the inspector generals office criticized the bureaus compassionate release program, which has been poorly managed and implemented inconsistently, likely resulting in eligible inmates not being considered for release and in terminally ill inmates dying before their requests were decided.

title: A Disappointing Debut
description: Mary Jo White, the new chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has gotten off on the wrong foot. Last week, in her first commission vote, Ms. White led the commissioners in approving a proposal that, if finalized, could leave investors and taxpayers exposed to the ravages of reckless bank trading.

title: Transformation of a Town Underscores Immigrants Impact
description: PORT CHESTER, N.Y.  Nearly 20 years after he arrived penniless in this country from Mexico, Moises owns two restaurants, with a third on the way. He has five employees, an American wife and a stepdaughter. His food even has a following on Yelp.com.

title: Syria Is Not Iraq
description: IN the search for an American response to the civil war in Syria, the favorite guidebook seems to be our ill-fated adventure in Iraq. We have another brutal Middle East autocrat holding power on behalf of a sectarian minority. We have another dubious cast of opposition factions competing for foreign patronage. We hear some of the same hawks  John McCain, Paul Wolfowitz  exhorting us to intervene, countered by familiar warnings of quagmire. We even have murky intelligence claims that the regime has used weapons of mass destruction.

title: How Social Networks Drive Black Unemployment
description: Its easy to believe the worst is over in the economic downturn. But for African-Americans, the pain continues  over 13 percent of black workers are unemployed, nearly twice the national average. And thats not a new development: regardless of the economy, job prospects for African-Americans have long been significantly worse than for the country as a whole.

title: The Chutzpah Caucus
description: At this point the economic case for austerity  for slashing government spending even in the face of a weak economy  has collapsed. Claims that spending cuts would actually boost employment by promoting confidence have fallen apart. Claims that there is some kind of red line of debt that countries dare not cross have turned out to rest on fuzzy and to some extent just plain erroneous math. Predictions of fiscal crisis keep not coming true; predictions of disaster from harsh austerity policies have proved all too accurate.

title: Harvey to Get Extra Rest Because of Rainout
description: ATLANTA  The last thing the Mets wanted was a day off.

title: Finding Traces of a Failed Aryan Colony
description: Nueva Germania was founded in the late 1800s by German immigrants looking to start an Aryan colony in Paraguay. It failed, but remnants of German culture remain.

title: Jet Makers Avoid Risk by Redoing Old Models
description: After a decade of pushing hard on the edge of technology, Boeing and Airbus are turning more cautious in building new jetliners.

title: Denmark's Work-Life Balance
Beloved Childrens Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Preventing Evictions
description: To the Editor:

title: A Silent Majority on Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx County Bar Is Working to Improve the Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: Egyptian Premiers Motorcade Comes Under Attack
description: CAIRO  An armed man fired birdshot pellets at a motorcade escorting the Egyptian prime minister on Sunday, but officials characterized it as an accidental episode of road rage rather than an assassination attempt.

title: The Piano Lesson and The Whale Win Lortel Awards
description: Signature Theaters revival of August Wilsons Piano Lesson and the Playwrights Horizon production of The Whale were the big winners on Sunday night at the ceremony for the Lucille Lortel Awards, which honors Off Broadway works. The Piano Lesson won the most awards in competition  four  for outstanding revival, director (Ruben Santiago-Hudson), lead actress (Roslyn Ruff) and featured actor (Chuck Cooper). The Whale, by Samuel D. Hunter, won for outstanding play and lead actor for Shuler Hensley, who played a morbidly obese man coming to terms with his mistakes and fears. Jessica Pabst also won for her costumes for The Whale.

title: Solving Equation of a Hit Film Script, With Data
description: LOS ANGELES  Forget zombies. The data crunchers are invading Hollywood.

title: A Homemade Style of Terror: Jihadists Push New Tactics
description: WASHINGTON  Aware that intensified American counterterrorism efforts have made an ambitious Sept. 11-style plot a long shot, Al Qaeda propagandists for several years have called on their devotees in the United States to carry out smaller-scale solo attacks and provided the online education to teach them how.

title: Cross-Dressing Onstage Isnt What It Used to Be
description: Strange as it may seem in these days of increasingly blurred gender norms, watching a woman dressed as a man singing songs of love for women may actually be a more exotic entertainment today than it was a century ago. In The Girl I Left Behind Me, a lovely show that opened on Sunday night at the 59E59 Theaters, the gorgeously gifted singer Jessica Walker and the writer Neil Bartlett conjure a vanished novelty of the theater, the cross-dressing female performers who once fascinated large audiences in England and America in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

title: By Himself, Hibbert Seems to Outnumber the Knicks
description: The Knicks tried to challenge Roy Hibbert from every angle. J. R. Smith tried to drive past him. Tyson Chandler attempted to go above him for rebounds. Carmelo Anthony, his jump shot inconsistent, at one point tried to dunk over Hibbert. But Hibbert, the Indiana Pacers 7-foot-2 center, stood his ground.

title: Lottery Numbers
Girls Death by Gunshot Is Rejected as Symbol
description: BURKESVILLE, Ky.  Last Monday, Kristian Sparks and his sister, Caroline, visited a Freds Super Dollar store here. A store manager recalled that it was an ordinary shopping trip, saying that the boy was outgoing and energetic, his little sister was cute and their grandmother was like any grandmother  she bought them anything they wanted.

title: Corruption Charge Expected for Senator
description: John L. Sampson, a state senator from Brooklyn and a former leader of the Democratic caucus, will be charged on Monday in connection with a continuing public corruption inquiry, according to law enforcement officials close to the investigation.

title: Sport of Many Nations Finds a Home in the Bronx
description: The ball came flying. The batter, in crisp game whites, slammed it into the ground, then bounded across a clay strip and back again, bat still in hand. His teammates cheered. And there was not a stray soccer ball or an invading rugby player in sight.

title: Walshs Past and Present Clash, and He Wins Either Way
description: A generation ago, the small-market Indiana Pacers had to climb a figurative mountain inside Madison Square Garden before realizing they had what it took to win a playoff series in the big, forbidding city.

title: A Court Rule Directs Cases Over Friskings to One Judge
description: After an attempted police stop in 1999 led to the shooting of an unarmed Guinean immigrant named Amadou Diallo, a civil-rights group sued the New York Police Department over the stop-and-frisk practices of its elite Street Crime Unit. From one of the wooden wheels used to assign cases in Federal District Court in Manhattan, a judges name was drawn: Shira A. Scheindlin.

title: Dinosaur Skeleton to Be Returned to Mongolia
description: After a little detour through the American criminal justice system, Mongolias celebrity dinosaur, Tyrannosaurus bataar, is heading home, the most recent stage in a journey spanningsome 70 million years.

title: Houlihan Lokey Hires Lazard Banker to Lead Its Asian Unit
description: HONG KONG  Houlihan Lokey, a privately owned investment bank based in Los Angeles that specializes in advisory services, has hired a former top regional banker from Lazard to lead its business in Asia.

description: I actually wasnt thinking of this as an act of civil disobedience or church disobedience. I was thinking of it as a response to my son.

title: Griner Says She Is Part of Mission to Help All Live in Truth
description: When the N.B.A. center Jason Collins announced he was gay last week, I was thrilled. Not only was I extremely happy for him, I thought that maybe, just maybe, his courage and the wave of positive reaction meant that we were on the verge of an era when people accept and celebrate one anothers differences. I think thats what makes life beautiful: everyone is different and we can all learn from one another.

title: The Baselworld Watch Fair Gets an Extreme Makeover
description: Baselworld, the annual watch fair in Basel, Switzerland, got a face-lift this year, care of Herzog and De Meuron, the local architecture firm best known for creating the Birds Nest Stadium for the 2008 Beijing Olympics and converting a London power station into the Tate Modern in 2000; the firm completed its three-year transformation of the vast exhibition space just in time for the show, which concluded last week. The buildings exterior is now clad in a woven skin of undulating, interconnected bands of aluminum, while its interior is more open and easily maneuverable. Many exhibitors got in the spirit, hiring star designers to redesign their booths. Above, six of the best.

title: Beauty and the Beast

title: Sucking Your Childs Pacifier Clean May Have Benefits
description: For years, health officials have told parents not to share utensils with their babies or clean their pacifiers by putting them in their mouths, arguing that the practice spreads harmful germs between parent and child. But new research may turn that thinking on its head.

title: How Colonoscopies Are Like Home Renovations
description: ITS a law of nature: Everyone who undertakes major home renovations ends up loathing their contractor. When I was recently redoing my kitchen and bathroom, I finally figured out why. It has nothing to do with the contractors honesty, quality of work, punctuality or the mess they make. Its about behavioral economics and human psychology  in particular, the unusual way that we assess pain.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 10 P.M. (Lifetime) DEAR MOM, LOVE CHER In what started as an 86th birthday gift, Cher chronicles the life of her mother, Georgia Holt, (above right, with Cher) from her childhood in rural Arkansas through her eight tumultuous marriages (to six men) as she pursued a career in Hollywood as a singer and actress. Among those interviewed are Chers sister, Georganne LaPiere Bartylak, and her children, Chaz Bono and Elijah Blue Allman. Ms. Holt has just released her first album, Honky Tonk Woman, featuring tracks she recorded in the 1980s with Elvis Presleys band as well as a duet with Cher.

Anne Barnard reports from Beirut, Lebanon.

The rebels denied the assertion.

description: BRUSSELS  The European Commission on Monday made a preliminary antitrust finding against Googles mobile communications unit, Motorola Mobility, for seeking and enforcing an injunction against Apple in Germany over patents essential to smartphones and tablets.

title: The Ballot Against the Bullet
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  At the start of last week I was in the nations capital, Islamabad, which adjoins the countrys most populous and most powerful province, Punjab. Almost all the political talk there was about Punjab, the home province of former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, where he and his Pakistan Muslim League-N(P.M.L.-N) have been holding rallies, urging supporters to vote them into power. Most analysts believe that is exactly what will happen, even though Sharif wont have the easy ride that he might once have expected: The cricketer-turned-politician Imran Khan and his Pakistan Tehrik-e-Insaf (P.T.I.) party have strong support in Punjab, and Khan has been traveling the length and breadth of the province to prove the pundits wrong. This is as it should be in a democracy the week before an election.

description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

Apple, though, has not sought those endorsements. It seems to be getting them anyway as several of the sponsored celebrities have let it slip that, oops, theyre using iPhones.

Mark Sanford, a Republican, 46 percent to 47 percent, in the special election to represent South Carolinas First Congressional District.

description: Institutional Shareholder Services, the influential advisory firm, has recommended that JPMorgan Chase investors withhold their support for three directors, citing material failures of stewardship and risk oversight after last years huge trading loss, Susanne Craig and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. The directors, David M. Cote, James S. Crown and Ellen V. Futter, serve on the boards risk policy committee. Only under extraordinary circumstances does I.S.S. consider recommending that shareholders oppose directors, the advisory firm said in its report.

title: Giulio Andreotti, Premier of Italy 7 Times, Dies at 94
description: Giulio Andreotti, a seven-time prime minister of Italy with a rsum of signal accomplishments and checkered failings that reads like a history of the republic, died on Monday. He was 94 and lived in Rome.

Now, in a campaign that is to begin on Monday, the companys commercials will be devoted to a different aspect of television: sitcoms.

Every time I ask about the recipe and every time Steve tells me its from the Momofuku cookbook. Then I go home and forget about it.

title: Fortunes Change in a New York Minute
description: It is occasionally startling just how fast things change. Yes, this seems to be a particular phenomenon in New York, where the minute is now officially down to about 20 seconds, faster if there is a cab involved. One minute you are a triumphant Knicks team celebrating dispatching the pesky Boston Celtics and the Empire State Building is aglow in your colors. The next minute some guy named Roy Hibbert is stealing your lunch money and people are talking up the Pacers as potential upset contenders, five minutes after realizing Indiana was in the playoffs.

title: Helen Mirren Is Not Amused as Drummers Disrupt Performance

title: In a Spiritual Outpouring, a Return to the Holy Land
description: There is a woodcut map by Heinrich Bnting dating from 1581 that shows the world as a clover, with Europe, Asia and Africa as the leaves, and Jerusalem at the center, confirming its position as the emotional and spiritual nexus of the great monotheistic cultures. On Wednesday evening the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine hosted a concert by its Cathedral Choir and the outstanding instrumental ensemble Rose of the Compass, offering the musical equivalent of the clover map. The fascinating and well-researched program encompassed Coptic and Armenian chant, Sephardic songs, Sufi melodies and Thomas Talliss Lamentations of Jeremiah on the historic destruction of Jerusalem.

title: Area Attack!
description: This week well be featuring a set of geometry challenges regularly featured at the Julia Robinson Mathematics Festival, a half-day math event held throughout the year at various locations. The festival is designed for sixth- through 12th-graders who are interested in math, games and puzzles; participants include students who enjoy exploring problems collaboratively as well as math contest competitors looking for a more relaxed setting. (The next festival will be held this Saturday at Stanford University. Check the bottom of this post for details.)

title: Feeling For | Jennifer Meyers Bejeweled Bobby Pins
description: The Los Angeles jewelry designer Jennifer Meyer makes her first foray into hair accessories next month with an elegant trio of flapper-inspired, 18-karat gold bobby pins adorned with diamonds, rubies and turquoise. I had just spent six months in Australia on The Great Gatsby set immersed in the most beautiful Tiffany jewelry imaginable, says the Malibu-reared mother of two, whose husband, Tobey Maguire, stars in the forthcoming Baz Luhrmann film that has already inspired a Jazz Age revival in fashion. The arrow shape was often featured in that period, and I wanted to bring it back with a contemporary spin, says the 2013 CFDA Fashion Award nominee, adding that she plans to roll out new styles in the coming months. Ive always loved hair jewelry but havent challenged myself until now.

title: Two Actors Join Repertory Pairing of Pinter and Beckett on Broadway

Mr. Crudup will play Foster in No Mans Land and Lucky in Waiting for Godot, while Mr. Hensley will take on Briggs in No Mans Land and Pozzo in Godot. They will join the previously announced cast members Ian McKellen and Patrick Stewart for a 14-week run at the Cort Theater that is scheduled to begin with previews on Oct. 26 and an opening night set for Nov. 24. Both works will be directed by Sean Mathias. The specific schedule and performance dates for each play have not been announced.

description: 3:21 p.m. | Update The Derby contenders Vyjack and Normandy Invasion are also being considered for the Preakness. Fear the Kitten is no longer in the mix.

Analysts said the results left Prime Minister Najib Razaks position far from secure.

title: Government by Random Comment
description: Senator John McCain was at it again on Sunday, attacking President Obama for not taking military action in Syria, especially after Israel struck Syrian missile sites. We need to have a game changing action, Mr. McCain said on Fox News. And that is no American boots on the ground, establish a safe zone, and toprotectit and to supply weapons to the right people in Syria who are fighting for obviously, the things we believe in.

He weighed that perplexity in light of two narrow losses that have left the Rangers desperately needing a win Monday night.

title: Ads Proclaim, Hail, Finlandia
description: A common approach in advertising is called product as hero, which celebrates the sponsors soup, soap or soda as the be-all, end-all, cure-all and whatever-all-else. But in an era when skeptical consumers dismiss straightforward chest-thumping as hopelessly outdated, whats a marketer to do?

title: Video: Bill Cunningham On the Street, Hats Off
description: Louisville has its Kentucky Derby. England has its Royal Ascot. And New York has its Frederick Law Olmsted awards luncheon of the Womens Committee of the Central Park Conservancy. The luncheon drew more than 1,200 elaborately hatted guests, and all of the garden flowers were in tiptop bloom. A favorite hat shape was the satellite dish, defying gravity on the side of the head  a look that in the late 30s was called the profile brim. The most amusing headdress was one of veiling that covered the face and had an appliqud eye and lips, evoking a Dadaist mood. The most interesting fashion silhouettes were the revival of Diors New Look of 1947 and the Chanel nipped waists, full skirts and flyaway boleros.

title: Inspiration for Art in the Glowing Seas
description: In an 1853 letter, the glass sculptor Leopold Blaschka described the first time he was mesmerized by what is known today as bioluminescence. The letter was translated from Old German by Henri Reiling, a scholar at Utrecht University in the Netherlands:

title: In Pursuit of an Underwater Menagerie

description: MOSCOW  Thousands of people turned out Monday for a protest here that was intended to draw attention to what organizers said was the return of political prosecutions in the Russian courts.

title: Where the Jobs for the Young Are and Arent
description: In three regions  the upper Midwest, New England and the area around Washington  the job market for younger adults is considerably stronger than in the rest of the country. These three regions are the closest thing to an exception to the trend I described in a Sunday column: the sharp decline in employment rates for adults 25 to 34 years old. Whereas the United States had perhaps the highest employment rate for this age group among large, wealthy economies in 2012, it has one of the lowest today.

title: Chinas Changing Internet Landscape
description: China was on vacation much of last week for the May 1 Workers Day holiday, but executives at two of Chinas most important online companies were busy completing a deal that could reshape the countrys Internet.

title: N.H.T.S.A. Solicits Public Comment on Vehicle Safety Evaluations
description: In an effort to improve its New Car Assessment Program, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is seeking comments from the public on several areas of vehicle safety, including new rules to protect pedestrians and children.

title: Walkabout  5/6: Sungnyemun Gate Reopens in Seoul; Stockholm Welcomes Back ABBA
description: Restoration Celebration The 600-year-old Sungnyemun Gate in Seoul, which was destroyed in an arson attack in 2008, reopened this weekendwith great fanfare, including a visit from President Park Geun-hye of South Korea. (Gadling)

title: On Wall Street, Recovering Money From Rogue Employees
description: It seems it should be a fairly intuitive policy: employees who violate the law should not be entitled to keep big bonuses earned based on illegal behavior.

title: Questions and Answers on Syria and the U.S.
description: Syrias bloody civil war took a dramatic turn over the weekend, with the government blaming Israel for strikes on military targets near the capital, Damascus. And questions about the use of chemical weapons became even murkier after a United Nations official suggested that the Syrian rebels, not the government, had used sarin gas. Here are some questions and answers on the debate over how the United States should respond.

title: A Warm, Messy Take on Meatless
description: When Mary McCartney and her three siblings were young and vacationing on a family farm in Scotland, their father endeavored to teach them about all the beautiful food that sprang from the earth.

title: Tax Proposals Open a Debate on Airline Industrys Troubles
description: A $300 domestic airline ticket now includes about $60 in taxes  or 20 percent of the total fare  which pays for things like air traffic controllers, airport improvements, customs and immigration inspections and checkpoint screening.

title: The Monday In-Box: What Readers Are Telling the Public Editor
description: Heres a look at what readers of The Times had to say over the weekend, based on what came across my desk.

title: About Half of Adults Lacked Adequate Health Coverage in 2012
description: About half of United States adults ages 19 to 64 didnt have health insurance for at least part of last year or were underinsured, a new report from the Commonwealth Fund says.

title: Raising Awareness About Maternal Deaths
description: Last year at this time, Christy Turlington Burns, the fashion model turned maternal-health advocate, asked mothers across America to celebrate No Mothers Day by not answering their phones or e-mail all day, even when their children called.

title: A House Built Close to the Train, but Only Temporarily
description: Among the items that have passed through or made a temporary home in Grand Central Terminal in the last 100 years: Three elephants on the way to a circus in Boston; an art school; a tennis court; a Redstone rocket; a Philippe Petit tightrope walk; a model train show. And now, a two-story house.

title: A Forgotten Pioneer of Vaccines
description: We live in an epidemiological bubble and are for the most part blissfully unaware of it. Diseases that were routine hazards of childhood for many Americans living today now seem like ancient history. And while every mother could once identify measles in a heartbeat, now even the best hospitals have to call in their eldest staff members to ask: Is this what we think it is?

title: Really? Most of the Added Sugar in Our Diets Comes From Sugary Drinks
description: THE FACTS

title: Harper Lee Sues Agent Over Copyright on Mockingbird
description: Harper Lee, who skillfully chronicled courtroom drama in To Kill a Mockingbird, is tangled in a legal drama of her own. Ms. Lee, 87, filed a lawsuit last week accusing her literary agent, Samuel Pinkus, of improperly collecting royalties from Mockingbird since 2007. According to the complaint, filed in federal court in New York, Mr. Pinkus engaged in a scheme to dupe Harper Lee, then 80 years old with declining hearing and eyesight, into assigning the books copyright to his company. Ms. Lee does not recall signing the document or discussing it with Mr. Pinkus, the complaint said.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Wandering Cheese Truck

title: Illustrator Nigel Peake Brings His Mysterious World to Colette
description: Nigel Peakes rural Irish roots were the muse for his 2011 book of drawings, In the Wilds. This year, the artist moved to Lausanne, the Swiss city on the shores of Lake Geneva, to teach architecture. The new setting influenced a series of 26 pen drawings that will be on view for a month starting today at the Paris boutique Colette. Peakes story of drawings, as he calls it, tells the tale of a young boy who is afraid of the dark and takes solace in building boats. As with his other work, there is no visible human presencethe boy is only implied through images that hint at a larger narrative. For those who cant make it to Paris to see the originals, Peake has self-published a limited-edition compilation of the images, called In the Dark.

title: Workers Claim Race Bias as Farms Rely on Immigrants
description: VIDALIA, Ga.  For years, labor unions and immigrant rights activists have accused large-scale farmers, like those harvesting sweet Vidalia onions here this month, of exploiting Mexican guest workers. Working for hours on end under a punishing sun, the pickers are said to be crowded into squalid camps, driven without a break and even cheated of wages.

title: BMC Deal Shows How an Activist Strategy Can Work
description: Elliott Management has once again pushed a technology firm into selling itself.

title: Photo Replay: May 6
description: A look at the day in sports, including boxing in Tokyo and snooker in England.

title: Fast Food
description: Q. Other than increasing the risk of choking, is eating fast bad for you?

title: After Years of Battling, Bank of America and MBIA Settle Mortgage Dispute
description: 8:29 p.m. | Updated

title: A Remote-Controlled Robot the Size of a Fly
description: Researchers have developed a remote-controlled robot about the size of a fat housefly that mimics a flys aerial prowess.

title: Want Your Name on a Building? Prepare to Be Generous
description: Dont look back, Donald Trump; when it comes to having ones name emblazoned all over New York City, Ronald Perelman might be gaining on you.

title: Print Your Own Gun
description: In the 1993 movie In the Line of Fire, the deranged would-be assassin played by John Malkovich builds a plastic gun that he smuggles past the metal detectors and into a presidential campaign event to kill the President. Clint Eastwood, thankfully, is on the spot to foil that dastardly plot.

title: David Ferrucci: Life After Watson
description: To the degree there was a human face of Watson, the Jeopardy! computer champion, it was David Ferrucci. He was the I.B.M. researcher who led the development of Watson, an artificial intelligence engine. The goateed computer scientist was always articulate and at ease in front of a camera or a microphone.

title: Boneworms Secret Revealed
description: Boneworms are gutless and mouthless, but somehow they live off the carcasses of whalebones. Now researchers say that the worms produce and secrete an acid that can dissolve bone.

title: Frank Bascombe Back in Short Form, for Now
description: When Richard Ford read from a story featuring his beloved character Frank Bascombe at 92nd Street Y last week, one had to ask if this meant Bascombe would soon return in a fourth novel. Mr. Ford had told interviewers he was done writing about Bascombe when he concluded his trilogy of novels, The Sportswriter (1986), the Pulitzer Prize-winning Independence Day (1995) and The Lay of the Land (2006).

title: Christian de Duve, 95, Dies; Nobel-Winning Biochemist
description: Dr. Christian de Duve, a Belgian biochemist whose discoveries about the internal workings of cells shed light on genetic disorders like Tay-Sachs disease and helped give birth to the field of modern cell biology, earning him a Nobel Prize, died on Saturday at his home in Nethen, Belgium. He was 95.

title: Abdication, Dutch-Style
description: For someone who makes a special trip to the Netherlands, nominally timed to the investiture of a new monarch; for someone who has always been a fan of regalia; for someone who enjoys a costumed parade of nations as much as the next person  youd think Id at least get to the Dam on time.

title: World Science Festival; Cicada Songs; Coffee, Deconstructed
description: Starting this week, The Scan will appear monthly, previewing events and books for the entire month. Updates can be found at nytimes.com/science.

title: A Drones-Eye View of Nature
description: Monte Vista National Wildlife Refuge, Colo.  An electric whir filled the air of this high desert valley as Jeff Sloan, a cartographer for the United States Geological Survey, hurled a small remote-controlled airplane into the sky. The plane, a four-and-a-half-pound AeroVironment Raven, dipped; then its plastic propeller whined and pulled it into the sky.

title: Amid the Tenements of New York, 2 Immigrants From Very Strange Lands
description: The title characters of Helene Weckers inventive novel, The Golem and the Jinni, are only slightly more bewildered than the thousands of other immigrants who end up in the teeming tenements of New York in 1899. Despite a handful of unusual powers, these two mythic creatures are still strangers in a strange land, caught between the folk traditions from which they spring and the modern world.

title: Studying Birds, With a Drones Help
description: Drone technology, developed for warfare, is now being used to study the natural world. In Colorado, sandhill cranes are counted with a small drone called the Raven.

title: Samsung Could Soon Surpass Apple in Handset Profit
description: Apple and Samsung Electronics are sucking up every penny of profit in the handset business. But Samsungs mobile business is growing fast, and the question is: Could it surpass Apple in profit next quarter?

title: Zero to Hacking in Five Months
description: This is pretty great.

title: Knowingly Navigating the Unknown
description: LOS ANGELES  On a recent morning the novelist Rachel Kushner stood in the parking garage of the Petersen Automotive Museum, where the Green Monster, a lean, turbo-jet-powered vehicle used to set land speed records, was displayed in a roped-off corner. In her new, rapturously reviewed novel, The Flamethrowers, set in the 1970s, the narrator finds herself driving just such a vehicle on the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah, where those records are set.

title: A Quartet, Changing, Looks Ahead and Back
description: The Kronos Quartet took to the stage of a sold-out Zankel Hall on Friday evening with what would be its last Carnegie Hall performance with Jeffrey Zeigler, its cellist of eight years who will leave this month. As the ensemble celebrates 40 years of blazing trails in the string-quartet repertory, it was appropriate that the program was largely about looking back. Just as appropriately, it was entirely made up of new music.

title: When Madison Avenue Went Public, as Seen on Mad Men
description: 8:22 p.m. | Updated

title: Slowdown in Health Costs Rise May Last as Economy Revives
description: WASHINGTON  One of the economic mysteries of the last few years has been the bigger-than-expected slowdown in health spending, a trend that promises to bolster wages and help close the wide federal deficit over the long term  but only if it persists.

title: Triple Play: Week 5 Results
description: Chris Sale, the answer to Question No. 1, struck out seven Texas Rangers in the Chicago White Sox 5-2 victory Wednesday on his way to improving to 3-2. When Steve Carlton helped the Philadelphia Phillies beat the San Francisco Giants, 6-4, on May 4, 1981, he struck out eight.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iran and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Iran, Bangladesh, Turkey and Pakistan.

title: Now Arriving From Taiwan, Kinetic Salutations
description: The Asian Cultural Council turns 50 this year, and at New York Live Arts on Sunday four Taiwanese choreographers presented works to show their gratitude for the organizations support. The program, Dance Taipei, was an evening of obscurity and obviousness, brilliance and frustration.

title: The Philosophical Rumble of That Living Document
description: Peter Sagal begins Constitution USA, his four-part exploration of the founding American document, with look-at-me gimmicks that are more annoying than enlightening, but the series, which begins on Tuesday night on PBS, grows more substantive as it goes along.

title: Art Meets Science Deep Underwater, Drones Learn to Count Birds, Pregnancy and Dentistry
description: One scientist uses a glass time capsule to check the health of todays oceans; the government undertakes a new kind of unmanned aerial surveillance; dispelling some of the misconceptions surrounding dental care during pregnancy.

title: Needing to Solve Pacers Big Man in the Middle
description: Of all LeBron Jamess marvelous talents, his capacity for adaptation may be the one most vital to his postseason success. In no series was this more evident than last years second-round bout with the Indiana Pacers, when he suddenly revealed a new weapon in his arsenal of offensive moves. After hardly ever having attempted the shot in his career, James began deftly dropping in 12-foot running floaters over the outstretched arms of Roy Hibbert, the Pacers 7-foot-2 center.

title: ACT to Move Toward Computer-Based Testing
description: High school students will take the ACT college admissions exam by computer starting in the spring of 2015  but at least for a while, the paper and pencil version will be available, too.

title: Oral Health and Pregnancy
description: The Times's Catherine Saint Louis reports on the misconceptions many pregnant women have about going to the dentist.

title: Medicaid and Mortality
description: As a rejoinder to my Sunday column, which citedthe new Oregon Medicaid data to cast doubt on the oft-heard promise that health care reform will save tens of thousands of lives annually, Brian Beutler of Talking Points Memo offers an interesting thought experiment. He notes that the study (or at least this years version) looked at health indicators but not mortality rates, and then goes on:

title: Israel and Turkey in Talks Over Deadly Flotilla Raid
description: JERUSALEM  Talks here on Monday between Israeli and Turkish officials over compensation for a deadly Israeli commando raid on a Gaza-bound flotilla almost three years ago demonstrated that while relations between the two countries are improving, they will not be as warm as they once were.

title: RuPaul Revealed
description: The worlds most famous drag queen tells The Timess Marcus Mabry that despite progress on gay rights, the pendulum could swing the other way.

title: A Magazine or a Living Fossil?
description: A new kid has arrived on the science journalism block, a monthly magazine named Nautilus: Science Connected. Its first issue, which appeared online on April 29, focuses on a single theme: what does or does not make the human race special.

title: Medical Devices Fall Short for Children
description: Only 15 months old, Vivian Andorf underwent her sixth cardiac catheterization. Her cardiologist inserted a flexible tube through a tiny artery in her leg and wended it to her heart in an attempt to treat her narrowed veins and arteries, the result of a congenital condition.

title: Promises From the Powder Room
description: Light-reflecting. Acne-fighting. Energizing. Face powder, long associated with grandmothers and a dusty, chalky look, has been remade. Some companies say the product is not only a cosmetic, but also a face treatment, and are loading it with SPF, antioxidants and vitamins.

title: In Performance: Alan Cumming
description: Alan Cumming plays Lady Macbeth in a scene from a reimagining of Shakespeares tragedy Macbeth, now on Broadway at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.

title: Another Side of RuPaul
description: LOS ANGELES  Have you ever worn a wig or done drag? RuPaul Charles, the host of RuPauls Drag Race, asked me recently as he shopped for wigs on Hollywood Boulevard.

title: Kindness Amid the Slaughter
description: On the afternoon of May 2, 1863, Cpl. Rice Bull looked out over the position that his newly formed regiment, the 123rd New York Infantry, was assigned to defend, just south of the Chancellorsville crossroads. He and his fellow upstaters had not yet seen the elephant  the soldiers expression for experiencing combat  and he was reassured to see that they were supported by more veteran units, including the Second Massachusetts and the 27th Indiana. He noted the striking contrast between those units faded, bullet-ridden battle flags and the crisp, spotless condition of his regiments colors.

title: Long a Staple of Fox, Cops Lands in the Eager Arms of Spike TV
description: Cops, one of the original reality shows on television, is moving to cable after 24 years on network television.

title: Omega-3s Dont Provide Extra Eye Protection
description: Adding omega-3 fatty acid supplements to a vitamin regimen to protect against age-related macular degeneration, the leading cause of blindness in the United States, did not slow progression of the disease, a large new study has found.

title: F.D.A. Proposes New Tanning Bed Warnings
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Monday proposed new regulations for tanning beds that would require their makers to affix labels warning young people not to use them.

title: No Joke: Syrians Hack The Onion
description: On Monday, The Onion, a news parody site, became the latest publication to have its Twitter account hacked by the Syrian Electronic Army.

title: Jeweler Is Charged in KPMG Insider Case
description: A Los Angeles-area jeweler has been formally charged with making illegal stock trades based on secret information obtained from a former senior partner at the accounting giant KPMG.

title: Hope Seen for Afghanistan After Coalition Exits
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Under Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., the new commander of international forces here, the American-led military coalition is no longer aiming to change Afghanistan. Its focus now is on a far more narrow goal: readying Afghan forces to withstand the Taliban regardless of the countrys looming political and economic troubles.

title: Sorting Through the New Political Alignments in Small Business
description: In a post for our colleagues at Economix on the divide between small and big  and local and global  businesses, Nancy Folbre, an economics professor, raises a number of issues important to Youre The Boss readers.

title: Obstacles for Pregnant Women Seeking Dental Care
description: In pain because of infected teeth, Luatany Caseres, 34, then a factory worker in Durham, N.C., was desperate to see a dentist.

title: Objects | Star Light, Star Bright
description: A colorful gem added to a simple white shirt and slicked-back hair creates a look as classically decadent as a long summer night.

title: Intels Impressive Design Meets a Tricky Market
description: Intel formally introduced on Monday a new semiconductor architecture for its Atom chip, with all sorts of advanced features and technology that the company says will give it an edge in the operation of computer servers, lightweight personal computers, tablets, phones, cars and perhaps a whole lot of other things.

title: Iran Warns Syrian Rebels After Report of Shrine Desecration
description: TEHRAN  Irans Shiite leaders warned of regional sectarian conflict after reports that Syrian rebels raided a Shiite shrine in a suburb of Damascus last week, destroying the site and making off with the remains of the revered Shiite figure buried there.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,196 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: A Stunning Error in Mississippi
description: Mississippi is scheduled to execute Willie Manning on Tuesday for his 1994 conviction for two murders. Mr. Manning is seeking DNA testing of hair, fingernail scrapings and other evidence connected to the crimes. His lawyers argue that no physical evidence links him to the crimes and that DNA testing could prove him innocent and identify another killer.

title: Bike Share 101
description: As New York Citys long-awaited bicycle-share program approaches its start date, riders are signing up for lessons about how it works, and how to ride safely.

title: Lil Wayne Puts Mountain Dew in Crisis Mode
description: How much street cred is too much?

title: No Exit
description: If You Give a Mouse a Cookie, the popular childrens story about a demanding rodent, has given rise to more than a dozen sequels and now one architectural parody. Described as a house-warning gift by its author, Seth Kaufman, If You Give an Architect a Contract (Sukuma Books) adapts the style of Laura Joffe Numeroffs 1985 illustrated classic in presenting a series of anxiety-provoking hypothetical statements about home renovation.

title: New Albums by Rod Stewart and the Uncluded
description: ROD STEWART

title: Celebrating the Web; an Atomic Movie; a Hurricane Over Saturn
description: So many piquant tidbits this week: We were able to see a revival of the worlds first Web site (which had no funny cat photos), watch the first movie starring tiny atoms, and view the first images of a surprisingly Earth-like hurricane swirling over Saturn.

title: In Angola, a Dollar and a Meal
description: In the last slanted softening of late afternoon light, against the squealy repeated note of one small insects cheep, under the bird-haunted acacia tree towering over the bare trampled compound, and near Camillos derelict-looking car, dirt footprints on its doors  Camillo had been kicking it barefoot in fury for its refusal to start  an old woman approached through the sunlit risen dust.

title: Early Images of American Indians Found in a Vatican Fresco
description: ROME  Vatican officials say they have found what could be the first European images of American Indians in a fresco painted within two years of Christopher Columbuss first voyage to the so-called New World.

title: The Doors Play Again in an Encore for the iPad
description: A new iPad app chronicling the rock legends the Doors has all the bells and whistles you would expect of electronic entertainment in 2013: immersive multimedia, cloud integration with iTunes, a ready connection to Facebook. The driving force behind it, however, is no 20-something Silicon Valley consultant. It is the 81-year-old Jac Holzman, who started Elektra Records as a teenager in 1950 and remains one of the music industrys most passionate and punctilious tech nuts.

title: The Nuns Who Revolted Against the Revolution
description: It is only natural for the Metropolitan Opera to refresh its offerings regularly with new productions, even when an old one has been successful. But it is hard to imagine the Met retiring John Dexters 1977 staging of Francis Poulencs masterpiece Dialogues des Carmlites (Dialogues of the Carmelites).

title: Lauryn Hill Sentenced to 3 Months in Tax Case
description: Lauryn Hill, the Grammy-winning singer and songwriter, was sentenced to three months in prison on Monday afternoon for failing to pay income taxes on about $1.8 million in earnings.

title: Spoiler Alert: Mad Men Shifts Gears
description: Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce, the fictional advertising agency portrayed on the AMC series Mad Men, has given up Jaguar for a new automotive client: Chevrolet. The agencys mandate, as seen in Sunday nights episode, is to introduce a hot new model referred to as the XP-887.

title: A Place to Hang Out (Read, Too)
description: It is definitely not your mothers Donnell.

title: Protesters Target Weiner on School Discipline Stance
description: Anthony D. Weiner has not yet entered the New York City mayors race, and may never become a candidate. But that did not stop some protesters from converging on his doorstep on Monday afternoon to challenge one of his educational policies should he decide to run.

title: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
description: WASHINGTON  A bipartisan coalition in the Senate easily passed legislation on Monday to force Internet retailers to collect sales taxes for state and local governments, sending the issue to the House, where antitax forces have vowed to kill it.

title: Questioning Farms Reliance on Migrant Labor
description: Workers who live near farms in Georgia that use immigrant labor say they want the field work but cannot get it because it is going to Mexicans.

title: A Push for a Bitcoin Buttonwood
description: Amid the incense, cheap art and herbal remedies for sale in Union Square in Manhattan on Monday, a very different kind of product was changing hands: bitcoins.

title: A Key Senator on Drones and Aiding Syria
description: Senator Jack Reed, Democrat of Rhode Island, speaks about increasing American action in Syria and revising the use of drones worldwide.

title: Death Row Inmates Request for DNA Testing Is Rejected
description: The State of Mississippi rejected on Monday a DNA testing request made by a prisoner scheduled to be put to death Tuesday evening.

title: Estimate of Immigration Overhauls Cost Gets Mixed Reviews on Right
description: A researcher whose fiscal calculations have provided crucial support in the past for conservative opponents of an immigration overhaul released a report on Monday, predicting that a proposal now in the Senate would vastly increase the government deficit in coming decades. But this year the estimates, by Robert Rector of the Heritage Foundation, have received decidedly mixed reviews from conservatives.

title: Jails Broken Elevators Delay High-Profile Sentencing
description: There are all sorts of reasons, legitimate and otherwise, why a trial or court proceeding might be delayed. But seldom does a high-profile sentencing in Manhattan get waylaid by something so mundane: a broken elevator.

title: A Taste of Spring That Reeks of Tradition
description: CAIRO  Every year, Egyptians mark the arrival of spring by flocking to the rare patches of green in this sprawling, crowded megalopolis to celebrate a holiday believed to be passed down from the pharaohs. Sham el-Nessim, the holidays Arabic name, means literally smelling the breeze.

title: In Egypt, a Pungent Ritual Divides Noses
description: As Egyptians celebrate spring with Sham el-Nessim, the holidays central meal of aged fish brings pride to some and a case of olfactory overload to others.

title: G.O.P. Opponents Plan Immigration Bill Attack
description: WASHINGTON  Republican opponents of legislation to overhaul the nations immigration laws are readying an offensive intended to hijack the newly released bill as the Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday begins a review that will offer the clearest sign yet of how difficult a path the legislation faces.

title: Social Media Images of Protesters in Moscow
description: As our colleague Andrew Kramer reports, about 26,000 protesters rallied in Moscows Bolotnaya Square on Monday, on the first anniversary of a protest in the same location that was marred by violence and followed by mass arrests and a police crackdown.

title: Video of Police Hunt for Drug Trafficker Raises Concern in Brazil
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  A video taken from a Rio de Janeiro police helicopter depicting the frenzied hunt for a fugitive drug trafficker, involving heat-seeking technology and spraying the suspects car with gunfire from the air in a densely populated residential area, is raising new concerns in Brazil over the heavy use of force by the police against some adversaries.

title: Israel Allows Gazan Children to Visit Imprisoned Parents
description: BEIT HANOUN, Gaza Strip  Raghed Hilless was 6 months old when Israel arrested her father, Ahmed, for being involved with Hamas, the militant Islamist group that rules the Gaza Strip. Now 5 , Raghed saw her father on Monday for the first time since then, one of the first young Gazans allowed to visit their parents in Israeli prisons since 2006.

title: Suit Claims Energy Drink Maker Markets to Children
description: The city attorney of San Francisco sued Monster Beverage Corporation, the nations biggest maker of highly caffeinated energy drinks, claiming Monday that it was marketing its products to children who might suffer ill effects from them.

title: Speedy Customs Program Works, at Least Usually
description: IS the popular Global Entry program working as advertised? Thats the program that gives members who have been prescreened quick re-entry into the United States at major international airports.

title: Limousine in Deadly Fire Carried an Added Passenger
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The limousine that burst into flames Saturday night on the San Mateo Bridge, killing five female passengers on their way to a wedding shower, was carrying more people than was authorized, the authorities said, adding that they did not know if this had contributed to the deadly outcome.

title: Trailing in Series, Islanders Like Their Odds Better at Even Strength
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The Islanders could be demoralized after a wrenching 5-4 overtime loss to the Pittsburgh Penguins on Sunday, but that did not appear to be the case as they prepared for Tuesdays Game 4.

title: From Jungle, Brazil Aims to Extend Its Reach
description: MARECHAL RONDON BASE, Brazil  Maj. Jos Maria Ferreira smiled as he listed the threats to human survival in the canopied jungle enveloping this remote military outpost in the Brazilian Amazon.

title: Brazilian Militarys Crucible: Jungle Warfare Instruction
description: In courses lasting about nine weeks, soldiers endure long hikes, swim in waters infested with piranha and survive for days without rations, hunting or foraging for their own food.

title: Foxconn Tries to Move Past the iPhone
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Terry Gou did almost everything that Apple could ask for. He made all those iPhones  and he made them cheap. When Apple was subsequently criticized for low wages and poor working conditions at his factories in China, it was Mr. Gous company, the Foxconn Technology Group, and not Apple, that caught the most heat.

title: Sheiks Vision Could Trump Plan for Park in Queens
description: There is a grand plan to be found for Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, a face-lift for this dowdy old dame.

title: An Outspoken Punter Finds Himself Out of Work
description: No one had to interpret the situation for Chris Kluwe, the opinionated Minnesota Vikings punter. Kluwe, who gained national attention last fall for his support of same-sex marriage, figured his time in Minnesota was coming to an end when the Vikings chose Jeff Locke, a U.C.L.A. punter/kicker, in the fifth round of the N.F.L. draft.

title: Assault-Prevention Officer in Air Force Is Arrested
description: The officer in charge of sexual assault prevention programs for the Air Force was arrested early Sunday and charged with sexual battery, the Arlington County, Va., Police Department said on Monday.

title: Intelligence on North Korea, and Its New Leader, Remains Elusive
description: WASHINGTON  The black hole of North Korea intelligence gathering is getting blacker.

title: U.S. Hopes Russian Aid in Inquiry on Boston Bombings Signals Future Collaboration
description: WASHINGTON  Despite years of differences on how to approach the terrorist threat, Obama administration officials said Monday that the American authorities investigating the Boston Marathon bombings were working effectively with their Russian counterparts and that they hoped the experience would usher in a new era of cooperation on counterterrorism.

title: In Manhattan Real Estate, Wealth and Power Are Relative
description: AT 10 p.m. Friday, my wife, my dog and I will be forced to evacuate our home because the boom of a construction crane atop a luxury condominium tower going up next door might possibly destroy our building. It wont be the first time: Last October, we had to evacuate for six days after Hurricane Sandy left the boom dangling precariously over West 57th Street, a situation that drew headlines worldwide. But this time, were being forced out merely because the city government wants to save the developer of the tower money and time.

title: The Best Little Boy in the World  Thats Me
description: WASHINGTON

title: New Rules Proposed for Tanning Beds
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Monday proposed new regulations for tanning beds that would require their makers to affix labels warning young people not to use them. Nearly 28 million Americans use tanning beds every year, according to the American Academy of Dermatology. The agency said the proposal was its first step toward potentially restricting access to the beds altogether for minors. Manufacturers would have to apply to the F.D.A. to get approval for their tanning bed products before selling them,The science is clear, said Dr. Mary Maloney, vice president of regulator policy at American Academy of Dermatology. The risk of developing melanoma increases by 75 percent for individuals whove been exposed to ultraviolet radiation from indoor tanning.

title: California: Court Upholds Ban on Marijuana Dispensaries
description: The California Supreme Court on Monday upheld the right of local governments to ban medical marijuana dispensaries. As dispensaries have proliferated since 1996, when California became the first state to allow medical marijuana, many municipalities across the state have used zoning laws to prohibits dispensaries from opening inside city limits. Patients and dispensary owners have argued that these local laws violate the state medical marijuana statutes by reducing patients access to the drug. But the court unanimously upheld a ban in the City of Riverside, paving the way for more municipalities to prohibit marijuana dispensaries.

title: Vigilante Copy Editor
description: A filmmaker searches for a mysterious vandal who has been correcting grammar on placards in the sculpture garden of the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn.

title: Vigilante Copy Editor
description: In the sculpture park at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, one of the nations oldest art schools, a clandestine struggle is under way  over grammar. In recent months, a vandal (or team of vandals) has used permanent markers to correct grammar and punctuation mistakes on the informational placards near the sculptures.

title: White House Holds Firm on Cautious Path in Syria Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  The White House insisted Monday that it would not be thrown off its cautious approach to Syria, despite Israeli military strikes near Damascus and new questions about the use of chemical weapons in the civil war there.

title: Google Glass Picks Up Early Signal: Keep Out
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Googles wearable computer, the most anticipated piece of electronic wizardry since the iPad and iPhone, will not go on sale for many months.

title: Religion Beyond the Right
description: As the Boy Scouts of America reassesses its ban on gay scouts and leaders, were hearing a lot about the organizations need to remain sensitive to people whose religions condemn homosexual behavior. Their morals must be properly respected, their God aptly revered.

title: Facing Black Market, Pfizer Is Looking Online to Sell Viagra
description: Pfizer has taken the unusual step of selling its erectile dysfunction drug, Viagra, to consumers on its Web site, in an effort to establish a presence in the huge online market for the popular blue pill, considered to be one of the most counterfeited drugs in the world.

title: Psychiatrys Guide Is Out of Touch With Science, Experts Say
description: Just weeks before the long-awaited publication of a new edition of the so-called bible of mental disorders, the federal governments most prominent psychiatric expert has said the book suffers from a scientific lack of validity.

title: A Succession of Items, Lost in Transit
description: MY family traveled a lot when I was growing up, and one of the more memorable trips was to Tanzania. We went on this amazing safari, and I dont know if it was the jet lag or just some bad curry, but I convinced myself that I had caught malaria.

title: As Midterms Loom, Democrats Worry About Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  As the administration struggles to put in place the final, complex piece of President Obamas signature health care law, an endeavor on a scale not seen since Medicares creation nearly a half-century ago, Democrats are worried that major snags will be exploited by Republicans in next years midterm elections.

title: A Carbon Trading System Worth Saving
description: The European Union became a pioneer in tackling climate change by starting the first major cap-and-trade system designed to reduce carbon-dioxide emissions by putting a price on them. But analysts are increasingly worried that technical mistakes, Europes prolonged recession and the failure of policy makers to strengthen the system is undermining its effectiveness.

title: Taliban Bomb Kills at Least 20 at a Pakistan Political Rally
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Taliban bomb ripped through a crowded political rally in Pakistans tribal belt on Monday, killing at least 20 people and wounding 45 in the deadliest attack so far of the campaign for next Saturdays national election.

title: Mr. Watt, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
description: There are many reasons to be bullish on housing. Valuations, affordability and supply and demand are moving in the right direction. But there are also causes for concern. Home sales and home prices can rise only so far given todays high level of unemployment and low level of wage gains. And millions of homeowners are still in financial distress. At the end of 2012, some 11.3 million homeowners  nearly one-fourth of all those with a mortgage  still owed more on their mortgages than their homes were worth, according to Moodys Analytics. Of those, three million are currently in or near foreclosure.

title: Corruption in Albany
description: For all the talk among Gov. Andrew Cuomo and other leaders about cleaning up New Yorks rancid state government, it is the F.B.I. that is doing the cleaning  indictment by indictment. State Senator John Sampson is the latest Albany politician to face corruption charges. On Monday, he was taken into custody by federal agents on charges of embezzling about $440,000 from the sale of foreclosed properties, obstruction of justice and witness tampering.

title: Several in New York Take Top Beard Awards
description: Danny Bowien, who owns Mission Chinese Food in New York and San Francisco, was named the Rising Star Chef for 2013 at the annual James Beard Foundation awards ceremony Monday night. Its one of the most significant of the many awards and medals handed out by the foundation for achievement in the world of restaurants and their chefs.

title: Professor Apologizes for Remarks on Keynes
description: The Harvard professor and economics commentator Niall Ferguson issued an unqualified apology over the weekend for suggesting that John Maynard Keynes was indifferent to the long-term implications of his economic theories because Keynes was gay and had no children.

title: For Buffett, the Past  Isnt Always Prologue
description: OMAHA  A little under an hour into the question-and-answer session at Berkshire Hathaways annual meeting here on Saturday, a name searing with history but now largely forgotten was mentioned: Henry E. Singleton.

title: Changing Sex, and Changing Teams
description: LOS ANGELES  Not so long ago, Toni Bias dreamed of playing in the W.N.B.A. But after starring on the girls junior varsity basketball team as a high school freshman, Toni came out as transgender last summer, began going by the name Tony and started transitioning to male.

title: Germany: Ex-Nazi With Link to Auschwitz Is Arrested
description: German authorities on Monday arrested a 93-year-old former Nazi soldier, saying that they had compelling evidence that he had worked as a guard at the Auschwitz concentration camp and was complicit in murders there. The man, Hans Lipschis, whose name is fourth on the Simon Wiesenthal Centers list of most wanted Nazi war criminals, was taken into custody at his home in the southern German state of Baden-Wrttemberg, according to Claudia Krauth, a spokeswoman for the prosecutors office there. Mr. Lipschis, who emigrated to the United States after the war but was deported in 1983 after an investigation by the Office of Special Investigations brought his Nazi past to light, admitted to the German newspaper Die Welt last month that he had served with a Nazi SS unit at Auschwitz but only as a cook. Charges have not yet been filed, Ms. Krauth said, adding that prosecutors are still investigating Mr. Lipschiss role at the camp. They believe he worked there from 1941 to 1945.

title: Beyond the Fence
description: The opponents of immigration reform have many small complaints, but they really have one core concern. Its about control. America doesnt control its borders. Past reform efforts have not established control. Current proposals wouldnt establish effective control.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 7, 2013
description: We are all now going to be both the paparazzi and the paparazzis target.

title: A Candidate With a Store Chain Around His Neck
description: Katie Couric was discussing the New York City mayors race with Donald Trump in the Pool Room of the Four Seasons the other day when the topic of John A. Catsimatidis, the billionaire Republican candidate, came up.

title: Does Gomez Have a Real Chance in Massachusetts?
description: A common cognitive bias in political analysis is what Daniel Kahneman calls the availability heuristic: the tendency to focus on recent or familiar examples as opposed to the broader course of history and the richer volume of precedents.

title: Lottery Numbers
Knicks Shooting Problems Start With Top Scorers
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The search for answers began anew on Monday, the first day in two months that the Knicks were forced to confront their imperfections, rather than accent their strengths.

title: Surveillance Footage of Painter
description: The house painter Joselito Vega is shown stealing some art from a waterfront mansion in Long Island.

title: House Painter Is Charged in Long Island Art Thefts
description: He painted houses for a living, but prosecutors say Joselito Vega had a discerning eye for the more rarefied practitioners of his craft  Pablo Picasso, Jean Dubuffet and Frank Stella.

title: Father Is Charged With Assaulting His Sons Training Partner
description: Volatile parents have long posed a problem for tennis. Jim Pierce, Damir Dokic and Arsalan Rezai are among those who have received extended bans for abusive behavior.

title: Mayoral Hopefuls Express Support for Animal Rights
description: Bill de Blasio bragged that his two children were vegetarians.

title: Corrections: May 7, 2013
description: THE ARTS

title: A Weekend With the Boss and Co-Workers? Such Good Fun
description: Anyone who has done time in a corporate environment will recognize the soul-killing atmosphere conjured all too precisely in Core Values, a wan comedy by Steven Levenson that opened on Monday night at Ars Nova.

title: Famous Russian House Guests, With Plenty of Baggage
description: What is it with Lincoln Center Theater and Russians who take their time? Six years ago, New Yorkers fought for the chance to spend nine precious hours watching the late-imperial-age intellectuals of Tom Stoppards Coast of Utopia talk about revolution. Now we have been invited to a leisurely confab with the transplanted post-revolutionary Russians of Richard Nelsons Nikolai and the Others, which lasts only two and a half hours, but feels closer to nine.

title: Story That Goes On and On
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Are you feeling a little bloated? That may seem like a personal question, but it would make perfect sense after doing Jeff Chens puzzle.

title: Bicycling in the City and Living to Tell a Skittish Class
description: If a taxis window is down, listen for the sound of a receipt being printed. It means a door is about to open.

title: Intersection: Dumbos Style Mash-Up
description: Martin Medina, a visual designer, draws fashion inspiration from his youth in the Lower East Side and bright colors.

title: The Chancellors Lament
description: By most measures, Holden Thorps five-year tenure as the chancellor of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, which is coming to an end next month, was a roaring success. The university went from 19th to 9th in federal research grants. Undergraduate applications rose 43 percent. And, at a time when university budgets are under extreme pressure, Thorp helped keep U.N.C. an affordable public university.

title: U.S. Blames Chinas Military Directly for Cyberattacks
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Monday explicitly accused Chinas military of mounting attacks on American government computer systems and defense contractors, saying one motive could be to map military capabilities that could be exploited during a crisis.

title: Worst of the What Were They Thinking? Contracts
description: The sense that New York teams operate with Monopoly money rather than actual cash was never more prevalent than when Alex Rodriguez tore up the largest contract in American sports history, only to be handed back one by the Yankees that was even larger.

title: Heat May Have M.V.P., but Bulls Have Series Lead
description: MIAMI  When Nate Robinson chased after a loose ball in the second quarter of Mondays second-round playoff game, he quickly discovered that he had company in the form of the 6-foot-8, 250-pound LeBron James. At 5-8, Robinson paid the price. He retreated to the locker room to receive 10 stitches on his upper lip, and the Bulls pressed on without him.

title: Teacher Pay Hurt by Recession, Report Says
description: During the recession and its aftermath, public schools took a hit as both state coffers and local property taxes shriveled. That showed up in shrinking employment, but also in teacher salaries.

title: Victims in Boston Marathon Bombings Turn to Crowdfunding for Support
description: It was Brittany Lorings 29th birthday. She and a fellow graduate student at Boston College, Liza Cherney, were making their way to the finish line of the Boston Marathon to meet a runner when the two bombs exploded.

title: The Scar Miller Left in 1995 Is Still Fresh
description: Reggie Miller still hears about the game whenever he comes to New York. Fans recognize him and want to talk about that Game 1 of the Knicks-Pacers playoff series in 1995, the one that became Page 1 of his New York legend. They all want to know how he scored 8 points in 18.7 seconds, flipping a 6-point Knicks lead into a preposterous Pacers victory.

title: Two Men Are Charged With Murder in Shooting of Bronx Teenager
description: The authorities charged two men with murder on Monday in the shooting of a Bronx teenager whose death the Bloomberg administration singled out in its campaign against gun violence.

title: Augustin Has Breakout Game Against Friend and Former Teammate
description: D. J. Augustin realized how far he and his friend Raymond Felton had come.

title: A Night When Chic Met Tough
description: Shortly after 6:30 p.m. Monday, waiting for the first of 800 celebrities and supermodels to make their way up the long staircase of the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the annual Costume Institute gala, Anna Wintour tapped a young man with a spiky blond mohawk on the shoulder. He wore a red blazer with the words the government is lying scrawled on the back.

title: Toronto Enjoys Moment, Despite Home Playoff Loss
description: TORONTO  George W. Bush was in his first term as president. Twitter was two years from appearing. The last time the Maple Leafs hosted a Stanley Cup playoff game was May 4, 2004.

title: Three Women, Missing for Years, Found in Cleveland
description: Three young women from Cleveland who disappeared about a decade ago, and who friends and relatives feared were gone forever, were found on Monday and appeared to be physically unharmed, the authorities said.

title: A Late Goal, and Then a Late Stand
description: Everything could have gone wrong for the Rangers on Monday. But everything went right. Marc Staal returned from a serious eye injury and gave his teammates and the Madison Square Garden crowd a huge emotional boost. The power play awoke from its slumber. Derek Stepan and Rick Nash, the Rangers top scorers during the regular season but blanked in the playoffs, combined for the winning goal with time running down and a 3-0 series deficit looming.

title: Delft Touch
description: The enduring, evolving and utterly beguiling influence of blue-and-white porcelain.

title: Keyness Biggest Mistake
