title: Quinn Offers Plan to Add Slots for Gifted in City Schools
description: Seeking to address pervasive racial disparities at the top echelons of New York City schools, Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, plans on Tuesday to propose a significant overhaul of gifted and talented programs that would provide space for more children and loosen admissions requirements.

title: Word of the Day | barefaced
description: barefaced \ber-fast\ adjective

title: M.L.S. Salary Figures Are Out, and One Star Shares Some of His
description: Major League Soccers players union released salary figures for the leagues players on Monday, an annual rite that opens a window into how much (and how little) value the league gets for its money.

title: Rodriguez Returns to Field, but Nowhere Near the Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla.  It felt like March at the Yankees training facility. Balmy weather. Postcard blue sky. An assortment of star players working out on various practice fields, and the parking lot outside lined with luxury vehicles.

title: Some Silent Protests in Malaysian Malls After Disputed Election
description: BEIJING  After the Malaysian opposition parties failed to win in Sundays election, some Malaysians staged silent protests in the countrys malls, dressed in black with their mouths taped shut, according to photographs posted online and #TheSilentWalk, a Twitter feed.

title: Tortorella Said It Was Close, and He Was Right
description: John Tortorella was right after all: the Rangers-Capitals series is a lot closer than a lot of people thought.

title: Even With Extra Attacker, Capitals Cant Find Opening
description: The Rangers had a daunting task. Ahead by a goal in the closing two minutes but down two games to none against the Washington Capitals, they were skating shorthanded by two men.

title: Met Gala Red Carpet
description: The biggest names in fashion turned out for the The Metropolitan Museum of Arts Costume Institute benefit celebrating PUNK: Chaos to Couture.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 10 P.M. (13) TED TALKS EDUCATION In this first television special from TED, the nonprofit devoted to ideas worth spreading, speakers address the nations high school dropout rate. Among them are Pearl Arredondo, a sixth-grade teacher in the Los Angeles Unified School District; Geoffrey Canada, president and chief executive of the Harlem Childrens Zone; Bill Gates, the philanthropist and Microsoft chairman; Malcolm London, a Chicago slam poet; Rita F. Pierson, an education and antipoverty advocate; and the social activist Ken Robinson, whose presentations on creativity in education have been viewed on TED.com more than 18 million times. The singer-songwriter John Legend hosts and performs.

title: A Night of Karaoke, and Moms in the Lead
description: It was my husbands first trip to my hometown of Snellville, Ga., and to ensure that wed return, my mother was determined to show us a good time.

title: A Whistle, a Punch, and a Soccer Referee Is Dead
description: A little more than a week after a 17-year-old soccer player punched a recreation-league referee in the head in suburban Salt Lake City, the referee is dead, the player faces charges, and youth sports are left with questions about the seeming rise in severity of assaults on officials.

title: News Quiz | May 7, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Missing for Years, Three Women Are Found in Cleveland
description: Help me, Im Amanda Berry, the woman said to a 911 operator. Ive been kidnapped and been missing for 10 years. I am here. Im free now.

description: When Carmelo Anthony joined the Knicks in 2011, he joined the ranks of New Yorks most debonair athletes, with a rotating collection of pocket squares, tailored suits, chunky glasses and skinny ties.

description: HONG KONG  Baidu, Chinas biggest search engine company, announced on Tuesday that it would pay $370 million for the online video business of PPStream.

description: REDMOND, Wash.  Windows Blue, the code name for an update to the Microsofts flagship operating system, sums up the current melancholy in the PC business pretty well, though Microsoft didnt intend it that way.

description: Derek Stepan and Arron Asham scored tie-breaking goals, Henrik Lundqvist had 28 saves and the Rangers survived a late power play by the Capitals to win Game 3.

description: WASHINGTON  The White House insisted on Monday that it would not be thrown off its cautious approach to Syria, despite Israeli military strikes near Damascus and new questions about the use of chemical weapons in the civil war there.

description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article With an Old Factory, Philadelphia Is Hoping to Draw New Teachers.

title: Syria Accuses Israel of Powerful Air Assault
description: In Syria Blames Israel for Fiery Attack in Damascus, Anne Barnard writes about a new development in the ongoing Syrian civil war.

title: A Conversation With: Bollywood Actor Ranbir Kapoor
description: LONDON  Ranbir Kapoor, 30, was in London recently to promote Yeh Jawani Hai Deewani, or, loosely translated, Being Young, Being Crazy, in which he co-stars with his former girlfriend Deepika Padukone. Directed by Ayan Mukherjee, the movie follows the lives of four young college graduates and the evolution of their relationships over nearly a decade. Bunny (Ranbir Kapoor) and Naina (Deepika Padukone) meet at two separate points in their lives in the film, first when they are just out of college and then as 30-year-olds, holding on to certain unfulfilled dreams. (Spoiler alert: Somewhere along the line, they also fall in love.)

title: Societe Generale Announces New Cuts as Profit Falls 50%
description: Paris  The French bank Socit Gnrale announced on Tuesday that it was planning a new-cost cutting drive that would result in hundreds of job losses in France, as its first-quarter net income fell sharply.

title: Atop a Mountain, South Africas Ghosts
description: High up in the Amatola Mountains in South Africas Eastern Cape province, the village of Hogsback sits atop a plateau, surrounded by mist and a primeval forest. Its a small place, with one main road, a handful of shops and a large, aching history.

title: The Food-Truck Business Stinks
description: Stefan Nafziger seemed oddly downbeat for a guy watching a dozen or so hungry people line up to buy his falafels. Three years ago, when it seemed as if food trucks might take over Manhattan, he planned to have a fleet of his Taim trucks dispensing Middle Eastern fare throughout the city. He even got a Wall Street investor. Now, he says, his one truck barely justifies the cost.

title: How Do You React When Provoked?
description: When someone provokes you  with verbal taunts, a rude comment, a shoulder bump or even a push  how do you react? Are you likely to respond in kind, escalating the conflict? Or do you try to let it pass or defuse the situation?

title: Missed a Play on Broadway? Catch It in London
description: LONDON  Dont look now, but the London theater is suddenly looking very American. A swift glance through the current and imminent lineup of openings indicates a neat bakers dozen of American titles alighting in the British capital for the late-spring/summer season.

title: Another British TV Personality Is Identified in Child Sex Investigation
description: LONDON  Another well-known television personality was drawn into Britains growing child sexual abuse scandal on Tuesday when British news media identified a 73-year-old man arrested over allegations dating from the late 1970s as the entertainer Jimmy Tarbuck.

description: Q.

title: Where the Happy Talk About Corporate Culture Is Wrong
description: Tell me something I dont know, is what I think every time I see another article, blog post or book on the value of happy employees. And here is what I find disturbing about these happy-employee propagandists. They are mostly off about what it takes to motivate employees and keep them happy in a fast-growth culture.

title: Keyness Not So Big Mistake
description: Bruce Bartlett, unusually, gets one wrong, although not in too bad a way. In his post Keyness Biggest Mistake, he misconstrues what Keynes meant by calling his book the General Theory of employment etc., and seems to imply something untrue about Keyness views on the liquidity trap.

title: The Stimulus Debate, Revisited
description: Brad DeLong finds Clive Crook making some easily refuted claims about the nature of the stimulus debate in the winter of 2008-2009, and my role in particular.

title: Standoff on Bolotnaya Square
description: MOSCOW  Under a menacing gray sky, people walked across the Great Stone Bridge, which spans the Moscow River at one end of the Kremlin. Dressed mostly in dark clothing, they walked purposefully, with somber faces, almost as in a funeral procession.

title: Lately, Its All Orb All the Time
description: Too much Orb? Not enough Orb? Just the right amount of Orb? When you run a racing Web site with only three writers, you ask about the formula all the time.

title: Pondering a Berkshire Without Buffett
description: At the Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting, Warren E. Buffett rejected the notion that the company would go the way of Teledyne, a conglomerate that was broken up after its leader, Henry E. Singleton, stepped down as chief executive. Mr. Singleton, who might be called the Buffett of his time, decided Teledyne had become too big and unwieldy for a single manager to effectively oversee and expand, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. A breakup of Berkshire, Im convinced would create a poorer result, Mr. Buffett said.

title: Verizon to Move 1,100 Workers From Lower Manhattan to Brooklyn
description: Verizon announced on Tuesday that it would move 1,100 employees out of its headquarters and switching center at 140 West Street in Lower Manhattan and offer half of the 31-story tower for sale or lease.

title: In Performance: Alan Cumming of Macbeth
description: Alan Cumming is on Broadway playing the title role  and every other major one  in Macbeth, a reimagined version of Shakespeares tragedy set in a mental institution. In this scene Mr. Cumming plays the ruthless Lady Macbeth asking the spirits to unsex me here. Directed by John Tiffany and Andrew Goldberg, Macbeth continues through June 30 at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.

title: China Cuts Ties With Key North Korean Bank
description: HONG KONG  The state-controlled Bank of China said on Tuesday that it had ended all dealings with a key North Korean bank in what appeared to be the strongest public Chinese response yet to North Koreas willingness to brush aside warnings from Beijing and push ahead with its nuclear and ballistic missile programs.

description: When the markets and the economy are out of sync.

title: Weight Led Governor to Surgery
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey ascended to become one of the countrys top political stars almost in spite of his weight  dismissing those who questioned whether his size disqualified him for higher office as ridiculous and irresponsible.

title: GE Capital Puts on a Lending Roadshow
description: GE CAPITAL this week is embarking on an elaborate advertising campaign with Slate.com featuring a six-month roadshow across the United States meant to stimulate its lending to midsize businesses.

title: Mayoral Candidate Says Clintons Have Used His Private Jet
description: The Gulfstream IV, an airborne lap of plush-leather luxury, hopscotched around the country over the past few days, breezing into Chicago; Orlando, Fla.; and Little Rock, Ark.

title: Torture Against Terrorism
description: NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania  Outside our tent on a beach about 100 miles north of the capital, the Atlantic Ocean was glittering under the midday sun and a fresh tuna was searing on a grill. Inside, the conversation with my Mauritanian friends turned to torture and detention. One described how hed been chained up naked for weeks; another talked about his brother who had a pin inserted under his fingernails. Both victims had been arrested during a crackdown on political dissidents in 2003, in the twilight of the 21-year dictatorship of Maaouya SidAhmedOuld Taya.

title: Before Escape, Fleeting Clues to Long Ordeal
description: CLEVELAND  One neighbor remembered occasional late-night deliveries of groceries to the boarded-up shoe box of a house in a rough-edged West Side neighborhood here.

title: The N.B.A.s Improbable Night
description: For a night at least, the N.B.A. was to be ruled by the stubborn. Forget youth, spunk, talent, a four-time league most valuable player in his prime, logic and common sense. No, instead you had the San Antonio Spurs, who have personified stubbornness since cellphones were as big as bread boxes, and the Chicago Bulls, a collection of spare parts being held together by duct tape and baling wire, and whose official team fragrance is an antiseptic.

title: What Were Reading
description: Narratively: A day in the life of a third-generation New York City hot dog vendor. You really have to be in tune with the cart, she says.  Julia Moskin

title: Fill-In | Prom is Easy. The Ask Takes Planning.
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first six paragraphs of the article Prom is Easy. The Ask Takes Planning. by Nancy M. Better.

title: Ted Cruz: The Schoolyard Bully
description: Unable to hide his anger behind the usual facade of Senate brotherhood, Majority Leader Harry Reid stretched protocol last night and called Senator Ted Cruz of Texas a schoolyard bully. Actually he diluted it just slightly by saying, My friend from Texas is like a schoolyard bully. But there was no friendship involved, and its not hard to see why.

title: From 2010: Christie on Health and Weight
description: In a 2010 interview, The Timess Michael D. Shear asked Governor Chris Christie about his struggles with his weight.

title: Looking Past Sex Scandal, South Carolina Returns Ex-Governor to Congress
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C.  As political rehabilitations go, few can match what happened to Mark Sanford on Tuesday night.

title: Otis R. Bowen, Governor and Health Secretary, Dies at 95
description: Otis R. Bowen, who served two terms as governor of Indiana and later became the first physician appointed as secretary of health and human services, serving under President Ronald Reagan amid the rising debate about AIDS, died on Saturday in Donaldson, Ind. He was 95.

title: A Film to Help Students Face Their Debt
description: Its that dreadful, suffocating feeling you get when you know you have something difficult to face, but you dont want to admit it.

title: Foreign Food Inspections on Decline as Illnesses From Imported Goods Rise
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y.  Inside a warehouse near the Canadian border, boneless hams bound for Philadelphia are coming off a tractor-trailer from Toronto under the gaze of a federal food inspector. Each week, about 20 of the 150 food trucks from Canada are rejected because of paperwork problems or contaminated meat.

title: Jeeves Lives, as New Author Picks Up Where Wodehouse Left Off
description: Nearly 40 years after the last book by the comic novelist P.G. Wodehouse, the aristocratic Bertie Wooster and his faithful valet, Jeeves, are making a comeback.

title: After Auction, the 1967 2000 GT Is Now the Most Expensive Toyota in History
description: It received little more than passing mention in the Lavishly Expensive Roadster Edition of Wheelies, but something significant happened a couple of weekends ago. It wasnt earth shattering, but it was noteworthy: RM Auctions sold a 1967 Toyota 2000 GT for nearly $1.2 million. It ended up being one of the higher priced cars in a batch that included Ferraris, Porsches and one-off concept cars like a 1954 Chrysler GS-1 Special that sold for $616,000.

title: Candidate Hoping to Be First Hispanic Mayor May Be 100 Years Too Late
description: The demography of the New York City mayoral campaign may already have shifted under at least one candidates prospective feat, even before November, when Adolfo Carrin Jr. hopes to be elected the citys first Hispanic mayor.

title: Rank Something! The Top 5 Most Talented American Idol Contestants Ever
description: In last weekends Riff, Heather Havrilesky examined what the difference between Mariah Carey and Nicki Minaj (hint: think anodyne glamor versus outsize freakiness) can tell us about our changing notions of musical talent.

title: Alzheimers Treatment Failed Trial, Maker Says
description: In yet another setback for the treatment of Alzheimers disease, Baxter International said Tuesday that its drug, Gammagard, had failed to halt the mental decline caused by the disease in a late-stage clinical trial.

title: Exploring Environmental Issues and Communication With Students in Japan
description: Dot Earth is relatively quiescent at the moment because were in the final sprint finishing the spring term at Pace University, including preparing for the launch ofViva La Tortuga! Meshing Conservation and Culture in Magdalena Bay,our documentary on sea turtle conservation in Mexicos Baja region (there are public screenings this afternoon on the Westchester County campus andWednesday in New York City, and of course youll be able to watch the video here on Dot Earth, as with previous efforts).

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Bangladesh Lessons
Amanda Berrys 911 Call
description: Amanda Berry told a dispatcher Monday that she had been kidnapped and pleaded for the police to come before the man who was holding her captive returned. Ms. Berry, who is now 27, was last seen leaving her job at a Cleveland Burger King in April 2003.

title: Costume Institute Gala Is an Experience, From Head to Toes
description: As I bid goodnight to my friend Jessica Diehl, the Vanity Fair style director, on the steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, she wailed, My feet are on fire. And well they should be after a night of punk and couture.

title: Air Bag Recall Spreads to BMW; G.M. Recalls Some eAssist Models
description: The widespread air bag recall affecting about 3.3 million Japanese vehicles last month has apparently spread to BMW as well. BMW says it will recall about 42,000 of its 2002-3 3 Series models because a passenger side air bag defect could send shards of metal into the passenger compartment.

title: U.S. and Russia Plan Conference Aimed at Ending Syrian War
description: MOSCOW  Russia and the United States announced on Tuesday that they would seek to convene an international conference within weeks aimed at ending the civil war in Syria, jointly intensifying their diplomatic pressure on the combatants to peacefully settle a conflict that has taken more than 70,000 lives and left millions displaced and desperate.

title: The Gun Report: May 7, 2013
description: Weve written several times about an anti-gun violence organization called Evolve, which aims to change the culture around gun violence by reframing it as a public safety issue. A big part of these efforts is enlisting responsible gun owners in the movement to reduce gun deaths.

title: A Wunderkind Artist Summons a Barely Bygone New York
description: Hes just 24, but Lucien Smith has arrived. In the past two years the assemblage artist, known for canvases that mix paint with found objects, has shown in prestigious galleries from L.A. to Milan, including Half Gallery, OHWOW and Brand New. Smiths new solo show at the Suzanne Geiss Company, A Clean Sweep, which opens tomorrow, is an homage to Giuliani-era New York in three parts. The first is a group of free-standing brooms, collected off New York City streets by Smith and his friends, that are meant to signify the citys gentrification. The second is a series of Polaroid grids featuring relics of the citys urban landscape, including trash cans, crosswalks and playground signs. The third is a film (seen here) made in collaboration with a New York institution: Glenn OBrien.

title: Indias Parliament Descends into Chaos, Threatening Landmark Bills
description: NEW DELHI Indias lower house of Parliament, under pressure to pass two pieces of legislation this week deemed crucial to the poor, farmers and development projects, descended into a shouting match Tuesday before adjourning.

title: Daily Report: The Google Glass Resistance
description: Months before it goes on sale, Google Glass, a wearable computer, is already generating resistance, David Streitfeld reports Tuesday in The New York Times.

title: Queen Elizabeth to Skip Commonwealth Meeting
description: LONDON  Queen Elizabeth, 87, will skip this years meeting of the heads of the Commonwealth governments, the first time she has failed to attend since 1973, Buckingham Palace said on Tuesday. She will be represented at the biennial meeting, which this year is to be held in November in Sri Lanka, by her son Prince Charles, 64, the heir to the throne.

title: G.I. Stones a Portrait of Karzai, Causing a Stir
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An American soldier would have been well served to remember the childhood adage about sticks and stones before he threw rocks at a wall-size portrait of President Hamid Karzai that graces a town square in northeastern Afghanistan.

title: Senegalese Singer and Finnish Composer Share the Polar Prize
description: The Senegalese singer Youssou NDour and the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho were named the winners Tuesday of the 2013 Polar Music Prize. Each will be awarded one million Swedish kronor, or about $150,000, and will be invited to a ceremony in Stockholm on Aug. 27.

title: For Democrats, Corruption Arrest Is One More Barrier to Control of the State Senate
description: ALBANY  There are many more Democrats than Republicans in New York State. There are even more Democrats than Republicans in the State Senate.

title: SAP Takes It All to the Cloud
description: SAP, the German software giant, is making one of the largest pushes into cloud computing yet seen from a large incumbent company. It may even be destroying its own business, in order to build for a new one.

title: Son of Cleveland Kidnapping Suspect Wrote About Missing Girl in 2004
description: The son of Ariel Castro, the Cleveland man suspected of abducting three women and keeping them hidden in his home for years, wrote about the disappearance of one of the victims, Gina DeJesus, for a local newspaper in 2004.

title: The Challenges Ahead for HSBC
description: HSBC is digging in for a low-interest-rate world. Economic malaise in the West has depressed demand for loans. Central bank money printing is weighing on the lenders large deposit base. With no pickup in sight, HSBCs returns depend on its ability to keep cutting costs.

title: Fox News Anchor Megyn Kelly Renews Contract
description: Two of the best-known anchors on the Fox News Channel, Greta Van Susteren and Megyn Kelly, have renewed their contracts, possibly foreshadowing the first change to the channels prime time schedule in over a decade.

title: A Clean Sweep
description: An exclusive premiere of a film by Lucien Smith and Glenn O'Brien.

title: A Main-Course Salad With Spinach and Chickpeas
description: In Whats for Dinner?, a column appearing every other week on Diners Journal, Melissa Clark answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

title: Why I Would Rather Pay My Employees Too Much
description: Thank you to everyone who commented on my last post, Why I Pay What I Pay, about the performance I expect from workers at different wage rates. I was surprised by the number of comments, but I guess that any discussion of pay is going to push someones button. That said, Id like to respond to a couple of points that were raised and also make a few new ones.

title: Limited Options for Airline Check-In
description: Back when air travel was new and glamorous, the check-in desk, where an elegant air hostess would greet you, was a delightful way to start your journey. Nowadays, it is more often the site of overwhelmed agents contending with long lines of frustrated travelers.

title: How to Tell Google Now to Stop Peeking
description: It used to be that every new phone was heralded as the iPhone killer. Now the preoccupation is with the Siri killer, the app that will replace the sometimes frustrating Siri personal assistant on the iPhone.

title: In the N.B.A., Celebrate at Your Own Risk
description: Celebrations in the N.B.A. exist at the margins. They might not be as rigorously scrutinized as touchdown dances in the N.F.L., but there are consequences. When LeBron James stared down Jason Terry after knocking him to the floor on an alley-oop, he received a technical foul. When Kevin Durant topped off a slam in transition with a throat slash, the league fined him $25,000. But their transgressive nature is what gives these gestures their power. This goes double when theyre taken from an opponent, as when the Knicks Iman Shumpert stole Jason Terrys flight plan and broke out Terrys signature JET celebration after draining a 3-pointer in the Knicks Game 6 win over the Celtics.

title: Celebs Channel Punk With Bleached Hair and Studded Jackets at the Met Ball
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: If You Like the Sex Pistols, Try Green Day or the Gaslight Anthem
description: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons generation.

title: South Carolina Voters Think Economics
description: In Charleston, S.C., voters in a special election pitting Elizabeth Colbert Busch against the states former governor, Mark Sanford, care most about jobs.

title: Bernardauds New Collection of Tableware
description: To celebrate its 150th anniversary, the French porcelain manufacturer Bernardaud has created a collection of tableware designed by several artists, including Sophie Calle, Jeff Koons and David Lynch. Weve always worked with the world of creators, whether theyre artists or designers, said Michel Bernardaud, the companys chairman. But this year, we decided to put a special emphasis on this relationship.

title: Revisiting Post-9/11 Law
description: Politico reported today that senators from both parties want to revisit the Authorization for the Use of Military Force, the Congressional resolution passed in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: New Video Games
description: INJUSTICE

title: Thompson Gets Key Endorsement From Bronx Borough President
description: In another sign of his deep ties to established leaders in minority communities, William C. Thompson Jr. collected a key endorsement in his bid for mayor Tuesday from Ruben Diaz Jr., the Bronx borough president.

title: Liberal Party Backs Catsimatidis
description: John A. Catsimatidis, the billionaire businessman and Gristedes supermarket owner running for mayor of New York City, picked up the endorsement of an obscure but potentially influential political group on Tuesday, adding another wrinkle to the Republican primary.

title: Sexual Assaults in Military Raise Alarm in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  The problem of sexual assault in the military leapt to the forefront in Washington on Tuesday as the Pentagon released a survey estimating that 26,000 people in the armed forces were sexually assaulted last year, up from 19,000 in 2010, and an angry President Obama and Congress demanded action.

title: Mens Final Four Is Moving to TBS
description: TBS will start televising the Final Four of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament in 2014 and 2015, advancing the schedule contemplated in its 14-year, $10.8 billion contract with CBS that went into effect three years ago. In those two years, CBS will continue to carry the championship game.

title: Video of Imran Khans Fall at Election Rally in Pakistan
description: Last Updated, 2:36 p.m. Imran Khan, a former cricket superstar who has been drawing huge crowds to campaign rallies in Pakistan ahead of Saturdays election, was rushed to a hospital in Lahore on Tuesday after he was knocked off a forklift at the edge of a stage and fell headfirst to the ground, nearly 15 feet below.

title: Congress Set to Begin Work on Farm Bill
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee announced on Tuesday that it would begin working on a new farm bill next week, reviving efforts to pass the once-every-five-years spending bill that sets the nations food and farm policy. The last farm bill was passed in 2008.

title: Cherry Jones to Return to Manhattan Theater Club in New Play
description: The two-time Tony Award winner Cherry Jones will return to Manhattan Theater Club next spring to star in a new drama by Sarah Treem, When We Were Young and Unafraid, playing a woman in the early 1970s who turns her bed and breakfast into a refuge for women in need. It will be the first time Ms. Jones has acted on Manhattan Theater Clubs Off Broadway stage since her critically acclaimed, Tony-winning performance as Sister Aloysius in John Patrick Shanleys play Doubt, which began there in 2004 before moving to Broadway a few months later.

title: Albanese Criticizes 2 Elected Rivals Over Office Staff Hiring
description: Sal F. Albanese, a former city councilman and a Democratic candidate for mayor, on Tuesday accused two of his rivals, Christine C. Quinn, the Council speaker, and Bill de Blasio, the public advocate, of having hired political operatives at taxpayer expense as they readied their own campaigns.

title: Recognition Grows for Poets of Streets, Main or Otherwise
description: FRESNO, Calif.  This city has long been an object of ridicule. Even seemingly innocuous details like the flatness of the land, reinforced by the sea of ranch-style houses, take on a pejorative hue. Midway between San Francisco and Los Angeles, the western gateway on Highway 99 to Yosemite National Park, Fresno is not a destination but a bathroom stop, in the words of its poet laureate.

title: New York State Investigating Pension-Advance Firms
description: New Yorks top banking regulator has begun an investigation into pension advance firms, the lenders that woo retirees to sign over their monthly pension checks in return for cash.

title: Hasty Deal to Save Chrysler in Depths of Crisis Returns to Haunt
description: All deal makers have a number they want to hit. In the case of Chrysler, the United Automobile Workers union has one number, and Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of both Chrysler and Fiat, has another.

title: President Obama on North Korea
description: Meeting with President Park Geun-hye on Tuesday, President Obama reaffirmed Americas ties with South Korea and said North Koreas days of eliciting concessions were over.

title: Autistic and Coming (Reluctantly) of Age
description: In the last few months, my 14-year-old son, Jonah, has grown taller than his mother. Which means just one thing: Im next. In our below-average-size family, this doesnt exactly qualify him for March Madness; still, it should be cause for celebration.

title: Amanda Knox: By the Book
description: The author of Waiting to Be Heard says that reading Marilynne Robinsons Housekeeping in prison helped, because it explores themes of loneliness and alienation.

title: Is The Times Really Ignoring Benghazi?
description: If theres a story  or even a word  thats more fraught with divisive American politics than Benghazi, Im unaware of it.

title: Pearl & Ash
description: Inside a very high-functioning wine bar on the Bowery.

title: Image of the Day: May 7
The Wine and the Dine Go Hand in Hand
description: First things first. Lets drink some wine.

title: Ray Harryhausen, Whose Creatures Battled Jason and Sinbad, Dies at 92
description: Ray Harryhausen, the animator and special-effects wizard who found ways to breathe cinematic life into the gargantuan, the mythical and the extinct, died on Tuesday in London. He was 92 and lived in London.

title: Vows | Miho Walsh and Roy Prieb
description: Images from the wedding of Miho Walsh and Roy Prieb at the Penninsula hotel in Bangkok.

title: Living South of Delancey
description: Venturing south of Manhattans East Village, one finds a neighborhood where a quiet residential atmosphere prevails.

title: Reasons for Crossing Delancey
description: The Lower East Side, whose tenements teemed with immigrants for generations beginning in the 19th century, has in recent years become known north of Delancey Street for crowds of a different sort: the whooping revelers who stream down its streets and cascade from its scores of bars, restaurants and falafel shops on weekends. Indeed, the density of raucous nightspots has earned the nickname Hell Square for the area between East Houston and Delancey from Allen Street east to the Delancey, a club near Clinton Street.

title: Rap, Both Good and Bad for Business
description: In hip-hop, as in all things, you get what you pay for, even if you dont read the fine print.

title: New Head of C.I.A.s Clandestine Service Is Picked, as Acting Chief Is Passed Over
description: WASHINGTON  John O. Brennan, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, has replaced the acting head of the agencys clandestine service, a woman who was at the center of the agencys detention and interrogation program and played a central role in the destruction of interrogation videotapes, American officials said on Tuesday.

title: Bulls Star Standing Out for Not Toughing It Out
description: In Los Angeles, Kobe Bryant tore his Achilles and limped out to shoot free throws in a valiant effort to make the playoffs. In Oakland, after being injured in his first postseason game after an eight-season wait, David Lee suited up with a torn hip flexor and took a minute to rise up for a rebound.

title: Be Wary of Debt Settlement Calls
description: It may sound like a solution: You are mired in debt and a telemarketer calls, offering to help reduce the amount you owe, in exchange for a fee.

title: Pleased by Apples Move, Einhorn Raises His Bet
description: When Apple  agreed to extensively expand its stock buyback program last month, David Einhorn was pleased.

title: OMelveny & Myers Hires 3 Senior Bankruptcy Lawyers
description: Three partners in the bankruptcy group at the law firm Cadwalader Wickersham & Taft are leaving to join OMelveny & Myers.

title: Cooking Fried Chicken
description: Julia Moskin makes a fried chicken recipe from Norman Kings new cookbook, The Way to Fry.

title: Five Travel Problems and the Sites That Try to Solve Them
description: Ah, the problems budget travelers used to have. Hours on the phone with the airlines trying to pin down the cheapest fare. A bargain B&B that looked great in the brochure  if only there were a way to access feedback from previous guests. I wish there was a way to tell the world in 140 characters or less that I made it to the top of this Mayan temple!

title: Guest Post | Sliding Into Homelessness': A Student Essay and Teaching Resources
description: Occasionally we collaborate with an organization called Youth Communication to feature true stories by young people that help add a new voice or angle to a topic weve covered on the blog.

title: The Art of Frying
description: Recipe Lab, a monthly feature, invites you to cook with the Dining section. Well publish a standout recipe from a new cookbook for you to try; the next week, the books author will join Julia Moskin and readers in a live video chat about the recipe and cooking techniques. This month were making Southern fried chicken from The Way to Fry, by Norman King; you can watch the video chat here on Diners Journal on Wednesday, May 15, at 8 p.m. Eastern. If youd like to appear in the video chat, more details are here.

title: Sweet and Spicy or Assertive Wines With Eggplant
description: Eggplant is often described as a polarizing food, one that people either love or hate. Im the counterexample. I like it well enough, unless its overcooked, which emphasizes the mushy texture and slight bitterness that seem to repel so many. That tendency toward bitterness, especially when combined with the spinach in Mary McCartneys dish of eggplant wraps, makes it a difficult pairing. I think of reds first, but nothing too tannic, which would clash with the bitterness. The sweet and spicy fruit of a lighter-weight zinfandel would work well. So might a lively Sicilian red like a nero dAvola or a cerasuolo di Vittoria. Assertive whites would work well, too, like a sauvignon blanc, even a flamboyantly styled example, or a good, dry chenin blanc, like a Vouvray or Savennires.

title: The Garden He Left Behind
description: My dad John and I started growing garlic about 20 years ago. I purchased my planting stock at a harvest festival, John through mail order. Eventually I came to admit his variety was much nicer than ours for both marketing and culinary purposes. Hed always announce sometime in April that it was up and about a foot high. Even though dad lived south of us in the upper Hudson Valley, my husband Jim and I assumed he was just embellishing, and wed smirk to each other. He was always positive and optimistic, whether gardening, dealing with three different cancer episodes or rooting for Philadelphia sports teams. I finally grew enough garlic from his stock to completely replace my varieties. And yes, it is quick to emerge in the spring, gaining good height early. This years is already up. It looks good  a summer harbinger of the grilling season ahead.

title: Shorter Hours, but Not for Truckers and Temps
description: One of the more disappointing data points in last Fridays jobs report was the decline in average weekly hours worked, which fell to 34.4 hours in April from 34.6 hours in March. Its not clear what was behind the decline, which occurred in multiple industries across the private sector. (The monthly jobs report does not include the length of the workweek for government workers.)

title: Ruling Clears Way for $7 Billion A.I.G. Suit Against Bank of America
description: A California judge has opened the door for the American International Group to pursue a fraud claim of more than $7 billion against Bank of America for losses it suffered on mortgage securities sold under duress after the federal government rescued A.I.G. in 2008.

title: The Office Gets an Extra 15 Minutes to Say Goodbye
description: NBC is having a hard time saying goodbye to its most successful comedy of the last decade, The Office. Its one-hour finale just got longer.

title: An Encounter in Overtime Highlights the Rise of Swiss Hockey
description: DETROIT  After more than an hour of tense playoff hockey Monday, the Game 4 fates of the Detroit Red Wings and the Anaheim Ducks came down to two players who grew up 29 miles apart in Switzerland.

title: Father Barred From Receiving Credentials for ATP Events
description: The ATP, the governing body of the mens tennis Tour, announced Tuesday that it had barred John Tomic, the coach and father of the rising Australian player Bernard Tomic, from receiving credentials at all of its events until further notice.

title: In Store | Amanda Hearsts Ethical Fashion Pop-Up
description: I think some people still dont really know what ethical fashion is, Amanda Hearst says. The editor and activist, a contributor to Town and Country and a former Marie Claire columnist, has for several years sought to spread the word by promoting (and wearing) labels that use organically grown, recycled and sustainably harvested fabrics and employ artisan collectives in the developing world. When Hearst met the young New York designer Hassan Pierre  whose Way It Should Be and Basic collections use materials ranging from organic cotton jersey to discarded cassette tape  the two discovered a shared wish to create a retail platform for the movements best offerings. The resulting collaboration is Maison de Mode, a series of ethical fashion pop-up boutiques whose second event happens this weekend at the Hole Gallery as part of the Frieze Art Fair.

title: Roving in the Bronx
description: The New York Times' roving runner, Brian Fidelman, takes a running tour of The New York Botanical Garden.

title: The Roving Runner: The New York Botanical Garden
description: These are glorious days to run in New York City.

title: Wheelies: The Flying Car Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Chris Christies Surgery and 2016 Hopes
description: The Timess Carolyn Ryan on Gov. Chris Christies weight-loss surgery and what it means for how he might approach the 2016 race.

title: Untimely Metaphysics
description: The Stones weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.

title: No Easy Answers on Syria, Obama Says
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday defended his cautious response to evidence that the Syrian government had used chemical weapons on its citizens, saying that he could not make high-stakes decisions based on a perceived use of those weapons.

title: Play Hurt, or Play Smart
description: The Bulls' Derrick Rose has taken a lot of criticism for not returning sooner from a serious knee injury. William C. Rhoden says Rose has to look out for himself.

title: Backing Grows for European Bank Plan
description: BRUSSELS  The European Unions halting effort to create a more unified banking system, which many experts consider necessary for avoiding future financial crises, received fresh impetus on Tuesday.

title: Brazilian Tapped to Lead World Trade Organization
description: PARIS  Roberto Carvalho de Azevdo of Brazil will be the next leader of the World Trade Organization, a Brazilian official said Tuesday, and will take the reins at a time when the group is fighting to remain relevant.

title: Japan Says It Will Abide by Apologies Over Actions in World War II
description: TOKYO  Japans conservative government will abide by official apologies that the countrys leaders made two decades ago to the victims of World War II in Asia, top officials said Tuesday, backing away from earlier suggestions that the government might try to revise or even repudiate the apologies.

title: Barrage of Beef, Argentine Style
description: Sometimes disappointments lead to happy accidents. By any measure, a long-anticipated fishing trip to the Iber Marshes in Argentina was a bust. The week before we arrived in February, a biblical rainstorm inundated a half-million acres of wetlands, scattering the fish into deep cover. In such conditions you can tough it out (a resolutely macho course of action that rarely ends well), or you can bow to fate and head to Buenos Aires for a few days.

title: The Horrors of Chechnya, With Humor
description: Some good novels catch fire immediately, as if a writer had simply opened a Zippo lighter. Others come into being more gradually. The author cautiously tends to his or her kindling.

title: Video: Play Hurt, or Play Smart
description: The Bulls Derrick Rose has taken a lot of criticism for not returning sooner from a serious knee injury. But Rose has to look out for himself because no one else is going to do it for him.

title: At Home on the Range and in Tasty Suburban Backyards
description: In the suburbs there are no deer. There are only (intensifier) deer, with intensifier replaced by one of several words not publishable here.

title: Scene City: Inside the Met Ball
description: A parade of stars for fashions biggest night, the Costume Institute Gala at the Met.

title: Off the Menu
description: Headliner

title: Pakistani Sports-Star-Turned-Candidate Is Injured in Fall
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Imran Khan, the Pakistani sports star who has emerged as a rising force in the countrys politics, was seriously injured when he tumbled from a mechanical lift at an election rally on Tuesday.

title: Front Burner
description: To Shop: Is It a Bar? A Grocery? Actually, Its Both

title: Tradition Performed With a Twist
description: At the center of Sonia Mbareks concert on Friday night at the French Institute Alliance Franaise in Manhattan was a song she performed a cappella: Al Kalimat (The Power of Words), with lyrics by the 20th-century Tunisian poet Mnaouer Smadeh: Speak up and suffer, even if you die for the sake of the words, it urged. She sang it with delicacy and strength, with mourning and determination, with intricate ornament and open passion  and, perhaps, with thoughts of the Arab Spring, which began in Tunisia, and its Islamist aftermath.

title: The Rust Belt, Reborn in Green
description: The American food revolution has reached the Rust Belt by way of ambitious chefs who are cooking sustainably and supporting local agriculture.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Afghanistan, Bangladesh, South Korea and Italy.

title: Searching for Clues in Cleveland
description: Three young women, who disappeared about a decade ago and who friends and relatives feared were gone forever, were found on Monday after a frantic 911 call made by one of the abductees.

title: Gains at Disney Parks Help Lift Profit
description: LOS ANGELES  The Magic Kingdom is on fire.

title: One More Field Where the Continent Trails Germany
description: BERLIN  Frances finance minister, Pierre Moscovici, warned on Tuesday against caricatures and misunderstandings over Germanys handling of the euro crisis, but quickly qualified his conciliatory statement about the European Unions most powerful country.

title: More Islamists Join Cabinet in Shuffling Within Egypt
description: CAIRO  President Mohamed Morsi swore in nine new cabinet members on Tuesday in a reshuffle that increased the role of Islamists in the upper ranks of the government but is not expected to herald any immediate policy shifts.

title: Scene City: After the Met Ball, Punk Goes Downtown
description: Lauren Santo Domingo and Riccardo Tisci host an after-after party at the Top of the Standard.

title: Spanish Court Drops Subpoena Against Princess
description: MADRID  A Spanish court on Tuesday dropped a subpoena for Princess Cristina, the younger daughter of King Juan Carlos, in an embezzlement case that has tarnished the monarchy.

title: A Slipper Made of Glass, Worn to a Fateful Ball
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On Wednesday the choreographer Christopher Wheeldon will present a world premiere and an update of an old ballet at New York City Ballets spring gala. Yet over this past weekend he was presenting a different premiere in the Bay Area: the North American one of his three-act Prokofiev Cinderella, danced by three casts at San Francisco Ballet; two further casts will perform it this week. The ballet, which has a scenario by the playwright Craig Lucas, is a co-production with the Dutch National Ballet in Amsterdam, where it had its world premiere last December.

title: Once Upon a Woods, Stripped Down
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Little Red Riding Hood turns into Rapunzel. A feather duster turns into a living creature. A prince turns into a stepsister who turns into a cow.

title: Delaware, Continuing a Trend, Becomes the 11th State to Allow Same-Sex Unions
description: Delaware on Tuesday became the 11th state to permit same-sex marriage, the latest in a string of victories for those working to extend marital rights to gay and lesbian couples.

title: Aboriginal Artworks to Return to Australia
description: In a homecoming sweetened with poetic justice, a collection of drawings and paintings by Aboriginal children living in a settlement camp in the 1940s and 1950s will be returned to Australia.

title: A Bit of Party for the Home
description: An owner as well as the creative director of the New York event-design firm Fte, Jung Lee has spent more than a decade producing lavish weddings and parties. But when the events are over and the distinctive tablescapes have been cleared, her clients often ask to take elements from the festivities into their everyday lives.

title: Marginalia, Added by the Author
description: Here at the magazine, you might say we have a thing about marginalia. So perhaps its not a surprise that Im mildly infatuated with Nieman Storyboards Annotation Tuesday! (Thats not an unwarranted exclamation mark.) Its a series produced every other week in which authors answer questions about their reporting and writing, which is obviously cool. (Who doesnt want to know how a reporter got a witness to talk? Or where that detail about the marigolds came from?) But Annotation Tuesday! serves up the answers in the body of the story itself  kind of like the obsessive highlights and notes I tend to make with my Kindle, but in this case with actual answers.

title: Replanting the Rust Belt
description: Pittsburgh in springtime is an edible city.

title: Coty Said to Seek $700 Million in I.P.O.
description: Coty is seeking to raise about $700 million in its forthcoming initial public offering, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday, as the cosmetics maker moves forward with its market debut.

title: White Makes Case for Bigger S.E.C. Budget
description: Mary Jo White cleared a rite of passage on Tuesday: she asked Congress for more money.

title: Judge Criticizes Obama Administration as It Appeals Contraception Decision
description: A federal judge on Tuesday angrily accused the Obama administration of hurting poor and minority women by seeking to restrict their access to morning-after contraceptive pills.

title: White House Plans to Add Technology Adviser
description: The White House is looking to Silicon Valley to expand its team of technology advisers.

title: A Spiritual and Musical Journey
description: Meditation is a way to practice letting go of expectations. In that spirit, One Track Heart: The Story of Krishna Das is a fine enough documentary, a nice enough introduction to a charismatic figure with a fascinating life, an unusual art and worldwide fans.

title: Staying Up Late at the Met
description: After the last tables had been cleared, the loins of lamb with mint mustard sauce devoured, the flutes of Paul Goerg premier cru brut ros quaffed and the dinner portion of the Costume Institute gala ended, that is when things really got interesting at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Rubios Letter to Heritage Foundation on Immigration
description: Senator Marco Rubio wrote to the Heritage Foundation ahead of its report on the economics of the immigration proposal encouraging it to use a different type of fiscal analysis.

title: Yanking Broadband From the Slow Lane
description: It has been almost two decades since @Home Network offered perhaps the first broadband plan in the country. It was right after the 1996 Telecommunications Act allowed cable companies to get into the business. Milo Medin, one of @Homes co-founders, still recalls the price of the pioneering service, offered to residents of Fremont, Calif.: $34.95 a month  $51.85 in todays money  for a maximum speed of 10 megabits per second. The memory inspires not a little frustration about the Internets progress since then: 17 years after @Home plugged in its first customer, the residents of Kansas City pay Time Warner, their local cable company, $46.90 for a 3 Mbps connection and $55.40 for a top speed of 15 Mbps.

title: Met Gala 2013: Punk Done Well Pinterest Board
description: Granted, interpreting punk style for the red carpet is challenging. Its probably why some at the Met Gala last night chose to forgo the idea altogether, so many so that there were moments where it was difficult to distinguish the punk-themed Met Gala red carpet from say, the Golden Globes. Others, like Taylor Tomasi Hill, Cameron Diaz and Carey Mulligan treaded lightly by including touches of punk flair on dress details or through their hair or makeup choices  a few studs here or a faux hawk there.

title: No Teaching Gig for Galliano
description: After receiving a volley of complaints and support for a planned classroom discussion with the designer John Galliano, Parsons the New School for Design said on Tuesday that it would not go forward with the class after all.

title: Red Bulls Put Streak on the Line
description: One month ago the Red Bulls appeared to be a team on the verge of an early-season meltdown. But as they say, its a marathon, not a sprint.

title: South Koreas President Visits the U.S.
description: As President Park Geun-hye makes her first visit to Washington, South Koreans discuss the importance of their countrys relationship with the United States in light of the conflict with North Korea.

title: A Coach Takes Dunk City Style to Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  As a special guest for Southern Californias spring football game on April 13, Andy Enfield had a sideline pass. After taking care of his news media responsibilities, which have become part of his daily routine, he wanted to pay close attention to the game. Enfield considers himself a big football fan.

title: Celebrate Brooklyn Summer Concert Schedule Announced
description: The folksinger Patty Griffin will give the opening concert of the 35th annual Celebrate Brooklyn! festival in Prospect Park on June 5, kicking off an eclectic 29-performance series featuring acts like Big Boi, Calexico, Os Mutante, the Waterboys and the gospel star Bebe Winans.

title: Test Run: Dots, a Simple but Addictive Game From Betaworks
description: A couple of years ago, the Apple iPhones graphics reached a point that allowed developers to make video games for mobile phones that felt as immersive and complex as those for traditional hand-held game systems. But as the games became ever more complicated, I stoppeddownloading them.

title: At Hurricane-Ravaged Seaport, New Forecast Calls for Glitter Rain
description: This summer at the almost defiantly unhip South Street Seaport, there shall be pop-up boutiques housed in shipping containers. There shall be outdoor film screenings with lounge-chair seating. There shall be SmorgasBar. And, the lords of artificial weather willing, there may be glitter rain.

title: A Mets Twitter Account Strikes Again
description: During the winter, the Mets chief operating officer, Jeff Wilpon, invited the team spokesman, Jay Horwitz, to have fun with his newly created Twitter account. Since then, Horwitz has used the account to poke fun at himself and to jokingly report false news items. Recently, he claimed that the Mets would be playing a tripleheader against the Colorado Rockies to make up for the snowed out series in Denver.

title: With Hours to Go, Execution Is Postponed
description: A Mississippi man scheduled to be put to death on Tuesday was granted a stay of execution by the State Supreme Court, after the United States Department of Justice sent lawyers and officials involved in the case several letters disavowing the degree of certainty expressed by F.B.I. forensic experts at the mans trial.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,201 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Bodies Pour In as Nigeria Hunts for Islamists
description: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria  A fresh load of battered corpses arrived, 29 of them in a routine delivery by the Nigerian military to the hospital morgue here.

title: Woods Takes a Stroll Down the Red Carpet
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  On Monday night, a tuxedo-clad Tiger Woods accompanied his girlfriend, the Olympic ski champion Lindsey Vonn, to the Costume Institute Gala at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Woods, the world No. 1 who has traditionally been red carpet-shy, met Anna Wintour, the editor in chief of Vogue, which hosted the event, the theme of which was Punk: Chaos to Couture.

title: Group Says Netanyahu Has Put Hold on Settlements
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has quietly suspended the issuing of bids for new settlement construction, according to a watchdog group, in an apparent gesture to Secretary of State John Kerry as he works to restart Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

title: Melanie Meyers
description: Ms. Meyers, 53, is a partner at the law firm Fried Frank, specializing in land use. She represents several large developers, including the Related Companies, Forest City Ratner and the Rudin Management Company.

title: Butler Shows He Is No Mere Fill-In for Bulls
description: MIAMI  Before the 2011 N.B.A. draft, Jimmy Butlers junior college coach, Mike Marquis, received a phone call from Matt Lloyd, who was part of the Chicago Bulls scouting department. Lloyd, who now works for the Orlando Magic, had a highly specific question for Marquis.

title: A Humbled Kleiner Perkins Adjusts Its Strategy
description: During the dot-com boom, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the venture capital investment firm, all but minted money, making prescient early investments in Netscape Communications, Amazon.com and Google and delivering astonishing returns to investors. Along the way, it became a symbol of Silicon Valley.

title: Syria Loses Access to the Internet
description: Syrias access to the Internet was cut on Tuesday. The most likely culprit, security researchers said, was the Syrian government.

title: In 2005, Kidnap Suspects Daughter Spoke of Seeing Her Friend for the Last Time
description: A year after 14-year-old Gina DeJesus vanished in 2004 while walking home from her middle school, Americas Most Wanted interviewed her classmate, one of the last people believed to have seen her alive. On Tuesday, the DeJesus family learned that the classmate, Arlene Castro, is also the daughter of the Cleveland man accused of kidnapping Ms. DeJesus and hiding her and two other women in his basement for years.

title: Snedeker Not a Fan of Fans Having a Say in Policing Players
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  Five years before a television viewer flagged Tiger Woods for a violation at the Masters, Brandt Snedeker was summoned to a Saturday meeting of the rules committee at Augusta National, same as Woods last month, to explain something they said raised a red flag after his Friday round.

title: Lee and Miller, 18 Years Later
description: Spike Lee walked to his courtside seat on Tuesday night, smiling as he was greeted by fans, security guards and Madison Square Garden employees. He wore an orange fedora hat, a neon orange Knicks jacket and blue and orange dress shoes.

title: Mens Fifth Major May Remain Mythical
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.

title: China Blasts Hacking Claim by Pentagon
description: HONG KONG  Chinas Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Tuesday criticized a Pentagon report that explicitly accused Chinas military of staging attacks on the computer systems of the American government and military contractors.

title: Washington Gardeners Battle a Persistent Pest: A Flower Thief
description: WASHINGTON  It starts each April with the violation of lilacs. Peonies are the next to fall, then Asiatic lilies. Then, in a painful botanic denouement, hydrangeas meet their demise, yanked at times straight from the roots.

title: Iraqs Worsening Sunni Protests Revolve Around Antiterrorism Tactics
description: BAGHDAD  The Sunni protest movement here is turning increasingly violent, freshening memories of the brutal sectarian conflict of 2006 and raising troubling parallels to the Syrian civil war.

title: Colorado: Massacre Suspect Pursues Insanity Defense
description: Defense lawyers for James E. Holmes, who is charged with opening fire in an Aurora movie theater last summer, said in court filings Tuesday that he intended to plead not guilty by reason of insanity. Mr. Holmes is accused of killing 12 people and wounding dozens more. Earlier this year, after Mr. Holmess defense team said it was not ready to enter a plea, Judge William B. Sylvester entered a standard not guilty plea on Mr. Holmess behalf. A new judge in the case, Carlos A. Samour Jr., will rule on the plea change.

title: Some Complications as U.S. Soccer Enters a Busy Summer
description: Ladies and gentlemen, start your DVRs. Or at least clear them out. There is a big summer of soccer approaching.

title: Mexico: Gas Tanker Explodes; 22 Dead
description: A double tanker transporting gas struck a containment wall on a highway in a Mexico City suburb on Tuesday and burst into flames, killing 22 people and injuring 31, the authorities said.

title: Public Hearing in Albany Is Held Without the Public
description: ALBANY  Something was missing at a public hearing held by the State Senate on Tuesday to examine New York Citys campaign finance system: the public.

title: Adobe Sends Boxed Software to the Cloud
description: Adobe Systems this week announced that its popular Creative Suite, which bundles Photoshop, Illustrator and a number of its other products, will be available only by subscription through Adobes cloud service, Creative Cloud. No more boxes and disks.

title: A Historic Textile Mill Begins a New Chapter
description: After a complicated 20-year effort to save a redbrick mill in North Carolina that was once considered the largest in the world for textiles and that played a significant role in the Souths textile history, the plant is finally moving toward a new life as a multiuse complex.

title: Start-Up Diplomacy
description: IN 2011, a group of American high-tech executives and angel investors traveled to North Africa as part of an innovative State Department economic development program. Local entrepreneurs flocked to workshops in Tunisia, Morocco and Algeria, where the Americans judged their business proposals and encouraged them to open start-ups. The initiative embodied the economic statecraft at the heart of Secretary Hillary Rodham Clintons vision for American foreign policy.

title: Kitchen Little
description: When you argue, as I frequently do, that cooking has the potential to help us deal with many of our dietary problems, you often elicit a kind of I dont care, I hate cooking response in addition to the expected I dont have time. And thats fine; cooking isnt the only route to eating better, and besides, those who hate cooking, or cant make the time for it, may be lucky enough to have someone else cook for them. As long as they wash the dishes.

title: SoHo Nonprofits Expansion Upsets Some Neighbors
description: After spending several years searching for a larger home, Gods Love We Deliver, a charity that prepares and delivers meals to the sick and homebound, decided that the best place for it to grow was in the building it already owned. To help pay for the major expansion, the group plans to sell about $4 million of its development rights to a developer to build a 14-story condo next door.

title: Four Legs Are Good
description: A mayoral forum on animal rights, held at the Union Theological Seminary on Monday, offered the strange sight of New York politicians trying to outdo one another in gentleness and compassion. Five candidates sat beneath organ pipes, professing their love of four-legged creatures and easily eliciting cheers, claps, woos and hoots from an audience that seemed neither to know nor care how expertly it was being played.

title: A 30-Month Legal Fight to Conceal E-Mails About a 95-Day Schools Chancellor
description: If you have lost three consecutive times in court on the same legal fight, with not a single judge giving you the time of day, and one of them saying that your main argument is particularly specious, what would you do?

title: Back Home, Pacers Stephenson Is Leaving Fresh Marks on Gardens Hardwood
description: During a game against the visiting Knicks in February, Lance Stephenson of the Indiana Pacers sent home a postcard of sorts: a Statue of Liberty dunk, the ball held high in his right hand for an extra second before he jammed it through the net in the midst of a Pacers onslaught.

title: China and Cyberwar
description: Despite denials from Beijing, there seems little doubt that Chinas computer hackers are engaged in an aggressive and increasingly threatening campaign of cyberespionage directed at a range of government and private systems in the United States, including the power grid and telecommunications networks.

title: Hezbollah Takes Risks by Fighting Rebels in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Near Damascus, Hezbollah fighters are defending the shrine of Sayida Zeinab, revered by Shiite Muslims, from encroaching Sunni rebels. To the north, they are not just part of a Syrian government drive to take back the strategic town of Qusair, rebels say, they are leading it.

description: Recent Sale

title: The Militarys Sexual Assault Crisis
description: Transforming the militarys entrenched culture of sexual violence will require new approaches and a much stronger effort than what the Pentagon has done so far.

description: TAIZ, Yemen

title: F.T.C. Warns Data Firms on Selling Information
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Trade Commission said on Tuesday that it had sent warning letters to 10 data brokerage firms, telling them that their practices, which involve gathering and selling consumer information, could violate federal privacy laws.

title: Investors Get a Settlement by Fannie Mae
description: Fannie Mae, the government-sponsored mortgage finance company, and KPMG, its former auditor, have agreed to pay $153 million to investors who bought Fannies stock from 2001 to 2004, a period when Fannies regulator determined the firm had overstated its income and violated generally accepted accounting principles.

title: Obama Backs South Korea Presidents Policy on North
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama offered an endorsement Tuesday of South Koreas new president, Park Geun-hye, and her blueprint for defusing tensions with North Korea, but warned that the first move was up to the erratic, often belligerent young leader in Pyongyang,Kim Jong-un.

title: A Dream of Trees Aglow at Night
description: Hoping to give new meaning to the term natural light, a small group of biotechnology hobbyists and entrepreneurs has started a project to develop plants that glow, potentially leading the way for trees that can replace electric streetlamps and potted flowers luminous enough to read by.

title: Yanks Eager for Return of Nunez, a Backup
description: DENVER  Eduardo Nunezs rib-cage injury has been of great concern to the Yankees for the past few days. How long will he be out of action? Will it linger when he returns and affect his play? How will Jayson Nix perform in his place?

title: As Price of Nuclear Energy Drops, a Wisconsin Plant Is Shut
description: WASHINGTON  The Kewaunee nuclear power plant in Wisconsin shut down for the last time on Tuesday, but it is preparing to break new ground for the American nuclear industry.

title: Mexico: U.S. Penalizes Drug Traffickers
description: The Treasury Department announced sanctions against eight Mexicans on Tuesday whom it identified as the main bosses for the Sinaloa Cartel just south of Arizona and Mexicali, Calif. A joint investigation including the Drug Enforcement Agency and United States Customs and Border Protection identified the cartel leaders, and law enforcement officials said they expected additional penalties to follow, including the freezing of assets and bank accounts. We rely on these types of enforcement actions to really lower the hammer, said Adam Szubin, director of the Office of Foreign Assets Control at the Treasury Department. He added, These are some pretty serious players. Several other Sinaloa operatives have already been penalized, including Joaquin Guzmn, also known as El Chapo, the cartels leader.

title: Rubio Disputes Report on Immigration Bill Costs
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, aggressively pushed back Tuesday against a Heritage Foundation report that estimated new immigration legislation would cost taxpayers $6.3 trillion by using the foundations longstanding support for dynamic scoring  which takes into account projected economic growth when determining the cost of legislation  as a cudgel against it.

title: Solid Sales, and Criticism, for Latest Version of Windows
description: SEATTLE  With Windows 8, Microsoft made bold changes to the look of the software that powers most personal computers. But those moves may have been too aggressive for some customers, the company now concedes.

title: Russia: F.B.I. Director in Moscow to Discuss Boston Bombings
description: The F.B.I. director Robert S. Mueller III met with Russian law enforcement and intelligence officials in Moscow on Tuesday to discuss the bureaus investigation of the Boston Marathon bombings, according to American officials. The investigation has focused in part on intelligence the Russian government provided the F.B.I. in 2011 that one of the bombing suspects was a Muslim extremist. Since the attacks, President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia have pledged to work closely together as law enforcement officials in both countries have tried to determine how they could have thwarted the attacks. In 2011, the F.B.I. investigated the Russian warning about one of the suspects, Tamerlan Tsarnaev, but ultimately told the Russians that it had not found any information to back their assertions. In response to several follow-up requests from the F.B.I., the Russians declined to provide more information about the intelligence. In recent weeks, however, the Russians have provided F.B.I. agents with that additional information.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 8, 2013
description: Yesterday they came in and just threw five corpses on the ground.

title: Court Bars Notice to Workers on Right to Unionize
description: A federal appeals court on Tuesday struck down a National Labor Relations Board rule requiring most private sector employers to post a notice informing employees of their right to unionize.

title: U.S. Weighs Wide Overhaul of Wiretap Laws
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, resolving years of internal debate, is on the verge of backing a Federal Bureau of Investigation plan for a sweeping overhaul of surveillance laws that would make it easier to wiretap people who communicate using the Internet rather than by traditional phone services, according to officials familiar with the deliberations.

title: Not Even Close to Creaky
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Oh, how sweet. Its an early Mothers Day card from Bruce Venzke and Will Shortz. So thoughtful, those guys.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: In the Scrim of Memory, Reality Itself
description: Hello again, Richard Foreman. Its been four years since the last time you walked out on us, leaving us with nothing but memories of intimate nights too crazy to be true. But in our hearts we knew you couldnt quit us. So now youre back, expecting to mess with our heads like you used to, and of course were going to let you. We just cant help it.

title: The Personal and the Political on a Candidates Diet
description: In the image-conscious world of politics, the subject of a politicians weight is not off limits. Here, statements from some politicians who openly discussed their weight struggles at various points in their careers.

description: The Defense Department released its annual survey on sexual assault in the armed forces during the fiscal year 2012.

title: Herbert Blau, Pioneering Theater Director, Dies at 87
description: Herbert Blau, a fiercely iconoclastic theater director, scholar and theorist who staged some of the earliest productions of Beckett, Brecht and Genet in the United States, died in Seattle on May 3, his 87th birthday.

title: State Dept. Official to Testify on Benghazi Attacks
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional Republicans, who have been aggressively pursuing information about how the Obama administration responded to the attacks last September on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, say the testimony that a State Department official will give Wednesday will be a damning indictment.

description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  John Tavares and his feisty Islanders teammates have confounded the critics through four games of their opening-round playoff series against the Pittsburgh Penguins.

description: The Knicks evened the series with the Pacers at one game apiece.

title: Nothing but Late Win to Show for Harveys Gem
description: The play was decided, as happens often in potentially history-making performances, by the smallest of margins, a split second, the time it takes for one to clap a hand or blink an eye.

title: Czanne and Modigliani Push Sothebys Impressionist and Modern Art Sale to $230 Million
description: The first of the big spring auctions began Tuesday night at Sothebys, where paintings and sculptures by Czanne, Braque and Lger topped expectations as bidders from 35 countries put money on their walls rather than in the shakier financial markets. The crowd  including the rapper L L Cool J and the New York businessman Donald L. Bryant Jr.  watched as bidders competed for Impressionist and modern artworks.

title: Amid Creeping Mold, Calls for Citys Help
description: Kelly Lotz sits in her house on Moreland Street on Staten Island and smells mold in all directions. Since Hurricane Sandy, the house next door and all its contents  books, couch cushions, a refrigerator overturned in the hallway  have been sitting and rotting. The house on the other side has black mold climbing out of the broken windows and across the white wooden siding.

title: Tennis Group and City Swap Parkland for U.S. Open
description: The United States Tennis Association said on Tuesday that it had reached an agreement with New York City over a contentious plan to acquire a strip of parkland in Queens as part of an overhaul of facilities for the United States Open tournament.

title: Lottery Numbers
In California, Push for College Diversity Starts Earlier
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  As the Supreme Court weighs a case that could decide the future of affirmative action in college admissions, California offers one glimpse of a future without it.

title: Pacers Go Cold While Knicks Embark on 30-2 Run
description: On a whiteboard in the Pacers locker room, above a long checklist of prerogatives and diagrams, was written the word Believe! For a long period in Game 2, Indiana had that calm, casual edge to its play.

title: At Elite Colleges, an Admissions Gap for Minorities
description: Despite the widespread use of affirmative action at elite colleges, blacks and Latinos are much more likely to attend colleges with low graduation rates.

title: Recruiting Minority Students
description: Universities in states that have banned affirmative action reach out to disadvantaged communities to identify promising teenagers and get more of them into college.

title: Rangers Discover Gem Buried on Depth Charts
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  With each game, defenseman John Moore seems like a hidden treasure for the Rangers.

title: China Trade Figures Rise, but Weaknesses Persist
description: HONG KONG  Trade figures for April released by the Chinese government on Wednesday morning were slightly better than economists expected, but still indicated that demand was fairly weak in foreign markets and in China itself.

title: California: 4 Will Share Reward in Manhunt
description: Four people will share the $1 million reward for the capture of Christopher Dorner, the former Los Angeles police officer who is suspected in four murders and became the subject of a manhunt across Southern California this year, the police said Tuesday. Karen and Jim Reynolds will receive 80 percent of the reward. Mr. Dorner tied them up and stole their car, after they found him hiding in their Big Bear Lake condominium. They freed themselves and called the police. He killed himself hours later, surrounded by law enforcement officers. Daniel McGowan, who reported seeing Mr. Dorners burning truck, will receive 15 percent of the reward. Lee McDaniel, who spotted Mr. Dorner and his truck in Corona, Calif., will receive 5 percent.

title: A Bar Thats Also a Piece of Art
description: One of the most exciting installations in New York City the week of the Frieze Art Faircan be found not on Randalls Island but in Chelsea, in the basement of the Htel Americano. There, the German artist Tobias Rehberger has constructed Bar Oppenheimer, a facsimile of his favorite Frankfurt watering hole, which he describes as both a sculptural artwork and a utilitarian space. The space, which opens May 10 and will remain open until July 14, dazzles the senses with its salonlike atmosphere, tight dimensions and prismatic black-and-white stripes; its also a functional bar where anyone can stop in for a drink during the life of the project.

title: Diamond in the Rough
description: The Mexican architect Tatiana Bilbao may favor Brutalist forms, but with her signature light touch shes creating her countrys most elegant buildings.

title: Jordan in Thick of World Cup Race
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  A result that stood out in the latest round of World Cup qualifiers was Jordans 2-1 home win over Japan, its first victory against the reigning Asian champions. Jordan moved into second place in Group B. It may not last  in earlier games Jordan was beaten, 6-0, by Japan, and lost against Oman and Iraq.

title: How Much Hospitals Charge Medicare
description: An interactive map shows how hospitals across the country charge Medicare different amounts for the same procedure.

title: New Test Improves Assessment of Prostate Cancer Risk, Study Says
description: A new test can help distinguish aggressive prostate cancer from less threatening ones, potentially saving many men from unneeded operations for tumors that would never hurt them, researchers are reporting.

title: Hospital Billing Varies Wildly, Government Data Shows
description: A hospital in Livingston, N.J., charged $70,712 on average to implant a pacemaker, while a hospital in nearby Rahway, N.J., charged $101,945.

description: Winning streaks in sports may be more than just magical thinking, several new studies suggest.

title: Nets Moving On as Jackson Is Said Not to Be Interested
description: Phil Jackson, a Hall of Fame coach and 11-time N.B.A. champion, has informed the Nets that he is not interested in returning to coaching, according to a person with knowledge of the situation.
