Although neither conservative nor a Republican, I had libertarian leanings and appreciated the societys openness to debating its political opponents. I felt slightly illicit in crossing ideological lines: once, when the dean spotted me leaving a meeting, I felt as if Id been caught walking out of an X-rated movie. But the discussions themselves were always intellectually engaging, and my fellow law students seemed more interested in converging around a shared approach to interpreting the Constitution than in squabbling about partisan differences.

title: NBC News Is Said to Pick a Woman as Its Chief
description: NBC News is on the verge of naming Deborah Turness, the head of ITV News in Britain, as its next president, according to several people with knowledge of the appointment.

title: The One Least Likely
description: Theres always a boy, and theres always a girl. They may not like each other at first, but they find a way to work together. Friendship always blossoms, sometimes romance. Theres a society they have to fight against and a secret to uncover that changes the world. They win in the end, though theres heartbreak along the way and more danger ahead.

title: What Price Beauty?
description: When I was 5 years old, my mother explained the world to me: Beauty is pain, she said, yanking my hair into submission with Dippity Do-slimed fingers and some bobby pins. If I didnt sleep in scalp-scraping pin curls to look my best for Sunday school, the terrorists would win.

title: Over, Under and Through
description: Spring is for busting out and rediscovering the world, so these four picture books come along just in time to help kids do some exploring  from the backyard to overseas to underseas to outer space  and they all let the visuals lead the charge.

title: Endangered Daughters
description: Middle-grade and adult fiction share territory largely ignored by young adult literature: the exploration of countries and eras beyond the borders of the contemporary teenagers navel. Two new middle-grade novels, The Vine Basket, by Josanne La Valley, and A Girl Called Problem, by Katie Quirk, are set, respectively, in a Uighur community in Central Asia and rural Tanzania in the late 1960s.

title: The Playings the Thing
description: Leopold Mozart shuttled Wolfgang Amadeus around Europe for years, parading his son in front of endless royalty to secure commissions and performances. More than two centuries later, a bullying stage father helped propel the Chinese pianist Lang Lang to superstardom.

title: The Stuff of Legend
description: Want to write a middle-grade fantasy adventure series? Its easy! First, conjure up a plucky, prickly team of three  children who have to learn to trust one another and work together. Make the stakes really high; saving the world is always good. Use lots of wisecracking humor. Ensure the parents are absent (dead, missing, away  youll figure it out). Invoke classic themes and figures from folklore and mythology, but dont bother becoming slavishly wedded to them. Be sure to include an intellectually or physically butt-kicking girl.

title: Rites of Passage
description: For some girls who grew up in suburbia in the 80s and early 90s, the defining cultural touchstone of the time might be New Kids on the Block or Saved by the Bell. For me, its The Baby-Sitters Club, Ann M. Martins blockbuster middle-grade series.

title: Fragile Things
description: In Holly Blacks newest middle-grade novel, Doll Bones, the main characters, Zach, Poppy and Alice, are at that intermediate stage between childhood and adolescence, when alliances shift and friendships subtly develop into something more, when children outgrow identities as quickly as they outgrow clothing, when boys and girls sometimes appear awkwardly patched together with emotional and physical features from various stages of development, like an evolutionary experiment gone haywire. For years, the three best friends have played a continuous, ever evolving game of make-believe embracing fictional kingdoms, characters and allegiances, using toy figurines and hastily assembled objects to stand in for the real thing. The Queen, a porcelain doll with vacant eyes and blond ringlet curls, presides over the kingdoms from her position in Poppys moms glassed-in cabinet.

title: Ordinary Courage
description: Historical fiction has an interesting place in the world of childrens literature. Regularly celebrated by adults with awards like the Newbery, these books nonetheless raise the question of whether the intended audience feels the same enthusiasm. What Ive observed as a classroom teacher is that while not in the multitudes that flock to the goofy fun of Wimpy Kid or the wild fantasies of Percy Jackson, there are still plenty of young readers who cant get enough of the past.

title: Uneven Field
description: Of all the young adult genres  the Dystopian Hellscape, the Human-Monster Romance, the Elite School-or-Camp for Nonmortals  the most popular right now may be the quietest: Aspiring John Green. GreenLit, as I like to call it, consists of realistic stories told by a funny, self-aware teenage narrator. These novels tend to have sharp dialogue, defective authority figures, occasional boozing, unrequited crushes and one or more heartbreaking twists.

title: Make No Mistake
description: James, a scrawny, thoughtful 15-year-old, is trapped in brutal penury in upstate New York. His father walked out long ago. His defeated mother, a barely functioning cocktail waitress, has brought home an abusive addict of a boyfriend. And his older brother, Louis, who left in a fury, is a muscle-bound drug dealer whom the police have in their sights.

title: All in the Family
description: Extended family is not in the full-time business of being your family, and that is mostly to their advantage. They visit, they leave  even when they live with you, it is rarely forever.

title: The Stratospherians
description: No sooner do acquisitive urbanites negotiate their peace with the manic pulse of New York City than some escape it without actually leaving. The strategy is an aggressively vertical lifestyle, and prescient developers are enabling it.

title: Common Core Practice | Hit Films, Glowing Trees and an Underwater Menagerie
description: A few weeks ago, Mrs. Gross, Mr. Olsen and their students explored how they might pair Times content with basic computer coding to practice Common Core skills. This week they show how the news and the standards can be jumping-off points for exploring video design and gaming.

title: Married With Children, a Dedication That Held It All Together
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: Gatsby in a Duesenberg? More Fiction
description: Jay Gatsby, the mysterious title character of F. Scott Fitzgeralds The Great Gatsby, fancied luxury cars, but he would not have been driving a 1929 Duesenberg Model J.

title: Paperback Row
description: HOUSE OF STONE: A Memoir of Home, Family, and a Lost Middle East,  by Anthony Shadid. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $15.95.) In 2006, after years spent covering the Iraq war, Shadid began renovating the abandoned house of his great-grandfather in the Lebanese town of Marjayoun. (A correspondent for The New York Times, Shadid died last year while reporting from Syria.) This elegiac memoir combines stories of Shadids struggles with workmen, tales of his ancestors and their world, and reflections on his familys journey to America.

title: Considering the Universe From Deep in West Texas
description: FORT DAVIS, Tex.  With a lime-green fleece blanket over his shoulders, Samuel David, 10, of Houston, bounced on his toes as dusk raced over the mountains. Attending his first Texas Star Party this week with his family, Samuel could not wait for a rare phenomenon in a lighted-up, night-denying world  a sky full of nothing but stars.

title: Editors Choice
description: A DELICATE TRUTH,  by John le Carr. (Viking, $28.95.) Le Carr seems to hold the moral relativism of his old cold-war heroes up to a harsh light in his 23rd novel, in which  to the benefit of a private American security firm  wars gone corporate.

title: The Demented Imagineer
description: Now, I see this as pantsless, the artist Paul McCarthy announced one winter morning to a group of male actors standing at the edge of a massive soundstage in a warehouse east of downtown Los Angeles, flanked by a plumbing supply and an auto impound yard. Normally, McCarthy looks like a hipster carpenter, broad and bandylegged, with gnarled fingers and wiry white hair poking out around his baseball cap. But this morning he was nearly unrecognizable in a tuxedo and gray toupee, a regal prosthetic nose glued over a neatly trimmed mustache.

title: Singing Proust
description: Kelli OHara sings the love song If It Is True, accompanied on piano by composer Ricky Ian Gordon. Gordons music was inspired by the work of Marcel Proust.

title: Rummaging Among Skins and Skulls
description: Mary E. Blair is a postdoctoral researcher in the American Museum of Natural Historys Center for Biodiversity and Conservation, where she coordinates the Enhancing Diversity in Conservation Science Initiative.

title: Getting the Full Picture on Annuities and Insurance
description: LIFE insurance and annuities are supposed to accomplish straightforward goals: life insurance provides for your family if you die unexpectedly and annuities guarantee a steady stream of income in retirement. But right now, both are being promoted for their tax benefits.

title: When Taxes Arent the Only Consideration
description: Paul Sullivans Wealth Matters column this week is about the marketing of two straightforward financial products  life insurance and annuities  for their tax benefits. As Paul has written before, the increase in taxes this year is prompting many people to make taxes their priority  its determining what to invest in or how to set up their estate or buying life insurance  when taxes should be only one factor in the decision.

title: Set to Lead, From the Podium Anyway
description: Its one week and counting until James Levines return to the podium.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Origins of World War I and More
description: This week, Harold Evans discusses two new books about the events leading up to World War I; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Pamela Paul talks about the spring childrens books section; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: If You Knew Then What You Know Now
description: When you live in a foreign country, a lot more than you might have expected can be foreign.

title: In Big-Dollar Philanthropy, (Your Name Here) vs. Anonymity
description: One hundred million dollars. As The New York Times reported this week, thats how much Ronald O. Perelman pledged to Columbia University for the planned Ronald O. Perelman Center for Business Innovation. Its the amount Stephen A. Schwarzman promised to the New York Public Library, which renamed its main building after him.

title: Kicking Off Uncomfortable Toe Shoes
description: For the past year, Pam Tanowitz has been haunted by a ballet. Her own.

title: Blind Teenagers Compete in Pole Vault
description: The legally blind students Charlotte Brown and Aria Ottmueller practice and compete in the pole vault.

title: Its Just Another Hurdle for Blind Athletes
description: CHANDLER, Ariz.  Holding a fiberglass pole, Aria Ottmueller bent and touched the runway to locate her starting mark. A coach helped position her front foot. The foam vaulting pit at her high school appeared only as a blue smudge. The crossbar was invisible to her.

title: In Nature | Room With a View
description: Some of the most thrilling nuances of a great landscape only become apparent in the brightness of dawn or when the afternoon light casts sharp shadows. But since many of the best gardens are private, gaining access to them at these magic hours can be a challenge. Thankfully, this is changing, as hoteliers across the globe have tapped major landscape architects to plant and design the greenery around their hotels. The result: a set of properties with outdoor spaces that are destinations in and of themselves. From the manicured grounds of a manor house in the Cotswolds, to a walled courtyard in Stockholm, to a working Cape Dutch farm in South Africa (and even to the lush tropicals planted by Arnaud Maurires and Eric Ossart at Dar Al Hossoun in Morocco), these are gardens worth traveling for.

title: Student Debt Slows Growth as Young Spend Less
description: The anemic economy has left millions of younger working Americans struggling to get ahead. The added millstone of student loan debt, which recently exceeded $1 trillion in total, is making it even harder for many of them, delaying purchases of things like homes, cars and other big-ticket items and acting as a drag on growth, economists said.

title: Think of It This Way: Stairs Are an Amenity
description: Having visited Manhattan on several occasions, Sofia and Christian Hasselberg of Stockholm knew New York was one place they wished to live.

title: Own a Mysterious Artifact? Go Show It to a Scientist
description: Life is full of mysteries. Some lives are full of mysterious objects. The necklace-looking thing you found on the beach that looks as if it probably came from an animal or maybe a plant. That rock your grandfather always told you was a meteorite. The dead turtle in a box on your desk  bog turtle or box turtle?

title: A Cagney & Lacey With Constables
description: One of the more interesting crime dramas currently on either side of the Atlantic started with a concept that was only about three decades old.

title: Garbled Noise, Playful Blues and Whispery Echoes
description: The Fall

title: TowerBrook to Purchase True Religion Apparel for $835 Million
description: Its a high-priced deal for high-priced denim.

title: Maxwell
description: A new song by Terre Roche.

title: In a Pickle
description: Barbecue season is just around the corner, which means that its time to break out the Mason jars and make some crisp, briny pickles to accompany your smoky sandwiches and slaw. But why should pickling be relegated to cucumbers alone? In this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman writes:

title: The Gun Report: May 10, 2013
description: Did you know that some sex offenders in Iowa can openly carry guns? An astute reader pointed us to this recent exclusive in The Des Moines Register, which revealed that 50 sex offenders in Iowa are currently carrying a gun in public. Its news that has surprised some state lawmakers and alarmed a few Iowa and national law enforcement officers, Jason Clayworth reported.

title: A Dual Review of Whats New, Starring Tyler Brl and Jan Morris
description: A dual review of whats new, by magazine impresario Tyler Brl and Welsh historian Jan Morris. See the chart, and watch the stop-motion airplane safety video for VistaJet, below.

title: Hip-Hop Stars as Disposable Spokesmen
description: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the conflicts between commercial interests and art in several recent cases of rappers losing corporate endorsement deals over their edgy content.

title: United Nations Agency to Discuss Internet Governance Again
description: Here we go again. The United Nations is trying to take over the Internet! Or maybe it isnt.

title: A Pioneer, Reluctantly
description: SCHAUMBURG, Ill.  Fallon Fox climbed inside the steel cage, past the sign that read The Beating Will Continue, and onto a black mat. She followed right jabs with left hooks and kicks flung at imaginary kneecaps, safe, if only for a moment, from the questions and insults and the suffocating fame that descended overnight.

title: The Sweet Spot: Everyones Nostalgia
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about how were permanently nostalgic for everything: music, clothing, our own lives, and now, the World Wide Web.

title: Rescue in Bangladesh
description: How a woman trapped beneath the rubble of a collapsed building in Bangladesh was able to survive for over two weeks before being rescued.

title: Airplane Safety Video
description: Tom Sachs and Van Neistat's stop-motion safety video for VistaJet.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Stratford, Ontario; Nashville; Venice
description: Venice Biennale This biennial exhibition, dedicated to chronicling contemporary art, opens June 1, with artists works (colorful gondolas from 2011, above) showcased in pavilions divided according to country. Angola, Maldives and the Republic of Kosovo are among the 10 countries that will participate for the first time in the exhibition, which spreads across the Giardini park and the winding galleries of the Arsenale.

title: How to Stop Government
description: In a recent Pew Poll, 80 percent of respondents said the president and Republican leaders were not working together to address important issues  and, by a two-to-one margin, said the G.O.P. was more to blame for gridlock.

title: Obama to Bookend Group of Eight Summit With Belfast and Berlin Visits
description: President Obama and his wife, Michelle, will make a three-day trip to the United Kingdom and Germany around the Group of Eight summit in June, the White House said Friday.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Origins of World War I
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Harold Evans reviews two new books about the complicated web of events leading up to World War I: The Sleepwalkers, by Christopher Clark, and July 1914, by Sean McMeekin. Mr. Evans writes:

title: Wheelies: The Best-Car-Ever Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: A Dream Is a Wish Your Id Makes
description: Theres certainly a twinkle in Uncle Walts blue eyes, but its not the glimmer of benevolence youd expect from the man who brought joy to countless children as the creator of Mickey Mouse and the Magic Kingdom.

title: Hey Mom, Call Me When You Find My Wife
description: Some mothers  and some fathers, too  will do just about anything to see their marriage-age offspring settle down, even if that means going where parents ordinarily should never go  online and into their childrens posted dating profiles.

title: Heat-Trapping Gas Passes Milestone, Raising Fears
description: The level of the most important heat-trapping gas in the atmosphere, carbon dioxide, has passed a long-feared milestone, scientists reported Friday, reaching a concentration not seen on the earth for millions of years.

title: Sport Gains Hoofhold on a Scholastic Level
description: Many polo players will tell you that it is not really the horses that most effectively propel them across the field, it is the adrenaline.

title: Popcast: Hip-Hop Stars as Disposable Spokesmen
description: Advertisers, theoretically, love hip-hop. They love it until it gets loud and messy, challenges taste and morals, causes offense. And then advertisers pull away.

title: The Sweet Spot: Going Way Back
description: In this weeks video, David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about how were permanently nostalgic for everything: music, clothing, our own lives, and now, the World Wide Web.

title: Technology as a Driver of Growth (or Not)
description: 4:21 p.m. | Updated with table on relative adoption levels.

title: Charles Reads Raider
description: On May 6, 1863, the same day that Gen. Joseph Hookers Union Army retreated northward over the Rappahannock River following defeat at Chancellorsville, Va., Second Lt. Charles Read of the Confederate commerce raider Florida began one of the most astonishing adventures of the war.

title: Caregiver and Patient, Bound by Blood and Whining
description: Were on the same side.

title: Rangers Staal Says He Decided to Sit Out Game 4
description: WASHINGTON  Speaking to reporters for the first time since his surprising absence from Game 4 because of the lingering effects of an eye injury, defenseman Marc Staal explained Friday that it was his decision to sit out, and that he was not sure when he would come back.

title: Russian Revelation
description: Not long ago, a woman in Florida contacted Vika Gazinskaya, a designer in Moscow, and bought $12,000 worth of clothes. Ms. Gazinskayas designs can be seen online, and purchased at Net-a-Porter, Moda Operandi and the Manhattan boutique Fivestory, as well as Forty Five Ten in Dallas. Maybe it didnt occur to the Florida woman to contact those outlets, or maybe there were sizing or availability issues, but she ended up writing a letter to the designer.

title: A Social Media View of the Davos of Hedge Funds
description: A look at some of the social media dispatches from SALT conference in Las Vegas. The SkyBridge Alternatives Conference brings together more than 1,800 wealthy investors and hedge funds for four days of conferences, concerts and revelry.

title: A Creative Partnership, in Life and in Art
description: The first time Yotam Haber was introduced to Anna Schuleit, in 2010 at the MacDowell artists retreat in Peterborough, N.H., she was helping a fellow artist bend steel spikes over a flame. She wore a bandanna over her blond hair and seemed utterly dedicated to her task  so much so that she took no notice of him. Still, he thought she had an aura.

title: Singer Accused of Trying to Hire Hitman Pleads Not Guilty
description: Prosecutors say the lead singer of the band As I Lay Dying, who is accused of trying to hire someone to kill his estranged wife, handed an envelope containing $1,000 in cash to an undercover officer, along with instructions, a photograph, an address, security gate codes and dates when he would have an alibi, The Associated Press reported.

title: A Mockumentary Digs for Roots
description: When Christopher Guest has his directors hat on, as for films like Best in Show and A Mighty Wind, droll is generally the order of the day. He carries that tradition to the small screen with Family Tree, a new comedy series that he created with Jim Piddock, which has its premiere Sunday night on HBO. The show, shot mockumentary style, centers on a 30-year-old named Tom Chadwick (Chris ODowd) who inherits a trunk that is full of family memorabilia. He begins poking through it and tries to learn more about the family members he encounters, beginning in the premiere with the man in full uniform whose photograph he finds.

title: Indie in Brooklyn, Electric in Queens
description: Its May, and dueling outdoor festivals have arrived. Theres a clear aesthetic choice  synthetic and transnational versus handmade and local  between Electric Daisy Carnival, at Citi Field on Friday and Saturday, and the Great Googa Mooga Festival, in Prospect Park Friday to Sunday. Electric Daisy presents more than 80 electronic dance music acts on five stages in and around the stadium. Trance, house, techno and dubstep dominate the lineup, with acts like Steve Angello, Dirty South, Afrojack, Richie Hawtin and 12th Planet. (electricdaisycarnival.com; two-day tickets are $239.83 general admission, one-day $132.05.)

title: Sweden and Israel Via Chicago
description: When it comes to trendy, glamorous repertory, its hard to think of an American company as well stocked as Hubbard Street Dance Chicago. The list of choreographers who have worked with this immaculately technical group reads like an international whos who of contemporary dance. Take, for instance, Swedens Mats Ek, revered in Europe but rarely seen in the United States; Aszure Barton, originally from Alberta, Canada; and Israels Ohad Naharin, the director of the Batsheva Dance Company, whose improvisation method, Gaga, has a global following.

title: From Romanticism To Apocalypse
description: Though the conductor Simon Rattles work has been defined for over a decade by his adventurous tenure as principal conductor of the great Berlin Philharmonic, he has continued to maintain associations with other important ensembles, especially the Philadelphia Orchestra. As a guest conductor, Mr. Rattle will lead the orchestra in its Carnegie Hall concert on Friday night. The program opens with Weberns Passacaglia, Op. 1, a glittering score written in 1908 when the composer was in his mid-20s and still under the allure of lush, late Romanticism. Then Mr. Rattle conducts Three Fragments from Bergs opera Wozzeck.

title: New Cooking Show on Fox to Feature Children as Chefs
description: How else to tinker with cooking reality shows? How about putting children in the kitchen?

title: At Met, Park Views Big and Small
description: In 1998 when Ellsworth Kelly became the first living artist to exhibit on the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, he called the picture-postcard setting an instant background. When his sculptures  as tall as 14 feet  were installed there they looked enormous and the skyscrapers behind them tiny. Mr. Kelly compared this reversal of scale to Chinese landscape painting in the way it played with perspective.

title: Judge Refuses to Drop His Order Allowing Morning-After Pill for All Ages
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge on Friday stepped up his criticism of the Obama administration, accusing the Justice Department of making frivolous and silly arguments in its attempt to delay making the morning-after emergency contraceptive pill available to women and girls of all ages without a prescription.

title: N.H.T.S.A. to Investigate Corvette Headlight Failures
description: After receiving complaints from owners of 2005-7 Chevrolet Corvettes about low-beam headlights failing, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is opening an investigation, according to a report posted on the agencys Web site. The action comes as the agency continues to mull over whether to investigate low-beam failures on about 248,000 General Motors crossovers.

title: Early Salvos From Bloody Sam
description: Sam Peckinpahs life, like many of his movies, ended in a kind of apocalyptic debacle. Too many arguments with producers, too much alcohol-fueled misbehavior and (always the real problem) too many disappointments at the box office had rendered the director of The Wild Bunch (1969) effectively unemployable by the time he died in 1984, at 59.

title: Small-Batch Pulled Pork
description: Melissa Clark demonstrates a way to make tender pulled pork slathered in a tangy barbecue sauce for a smaller crowd.

title: A Midsummer Days Dream in Sweden
description: Bring wine? To Midsummer? That is a funny joke, said my Aunt Anna-Greta with a hearty peal of laughter and a knee slap. Maybe you think you are in Italy!

title: A Long, Lively Swedish Party
description: Welcome to Midsummer, where the fun includes everything from flowers to a feast.

title: I.R.S. Apologizes to Tea Party Groups Over Audits of Applications for Tax Exemption
description: WASHINGTON  The Internal Revenue Service apologized to Tea Party groups and other conservative organizations on Friday for what it now says were overzealous audits of their applications for tax-exempt status.

title: Tasting Modern Hungarian in Budapest
description: Budapest is a city of coat-takers. Walk into any restaurant, no matter how humble, and you will barely be through the door before someone is graciously easing you out of your wrap. That warm hospitality, coupled with menus filled with creamy soups and meaty stews, can make dining in this city feel like stepping back in time. But all is not so sepia-tinged. A movement that began several years ago toward lighter and brighter food, served in more modern environs, has been gathering steam.

title: Bookshelf: Bicycles
description: New picture books about people of all ages and their bikes.

title: Bookshelf: Misbehavior
description: New picture books about throwing things, pitching fits and breaking the rules.

title: Smaller Forkfuls of Pulled Pork
description: The first time I made pulled pork, it involved a huge seven-pound bone-in pork butt and an entire day of gentle smoking on the barbecue. It fed a backyard full of guests, and there were plenty of leftovers, too.

title: James Levine Returns
description: On May 19 at Carnegie Hall, Mr. Levine will conduct the Met Orchestra in his first performance in over two years.

title: Bookshelf: Misbehavior
description: TIME-OUT FOR SOPHIE  Written and illustrated by Rosemary Wells.  32 pp. Viking. $15.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

title: An Indiana Town Where Big Names Built
description: Before he helped bring the Finnish architect Eliel Saarinen to his hometown to design one of the first contemporary churches in America; before he commissioned Eliels son, Eero, to design an elegant midcentury modern house for his young family; and before he turned Columbus, Ind., into a living museum of striking 20th-century modern architecture, J. Irwin Miller lived in a large 19th-century house that could not have been more of a contrast to the Modernist buildings that have put this rural city on the map.

title: Bookshelf: Bicycles
description: EVERYONE CAN LEARN TO RIDE A BICYCLE  Written and illustrated by Chris Raschka.  32 pp. Schwartz & Wade. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)

title: An Unlikely Architecture Hub
description: In Columbus, Ind., the buildings are a star attraction.

title: Blogger Emerges From Hiding After Fleeing Bahrain
description: After months of secret plans that involved disguises, code names and a body double, a prominent blogger who had been sentenced in absentia to 15 years in prison for his activism in Bahrain has fled the country by hiding in a compartment in a car, according to media reports and human rights groups.

title: Common Sense: The Fight for Cooper Union
description: Cooper Union, once a premier institution of higher learning with free tuition, will begin charging students. The Timess James B. Stewart and Marcus Mabry discuss how it mishandled its endowment.

title: Still Licensed to Be Indie
description: W. W. A. D.?

title: Food Matters | When Eating and Art Became One
description: A few months before the artists Carol Goodden and Gordon Matta-Clark opened their restaurant-slash-art installation, FOOD, on the corner of Prince and Wooster Streets in New York City in the fall of 1971, they roasted a pig beneath the Brooklyn Bridge. Alanna Heiss, who would soon found P.S.1, installed work by Matta-Clark, Carl Andre, Sol Le Witt and Keith Sonnier in a raw, junk-filled space. On nearby Pier 14, Philip Glass performed and the year-old avant-garde theater company Mabou Mines staged a Samuel Beckett play. The artist Tina Girouard, who would cook at FOOD during its nearly three-year run, helped out with the hog. The pig burnt on the outside, she recalled, and raw on the inside.

title: How Cooper Unions Endowment Failed in Its Mission
description: Since Peter Coopers heirs gave the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art the land under the Chrysler Building in 1902, the schools endowment has enabled it to offer students a high-quality, tuition-free education through two world wars, the Great Depression and multiple stock market crashes and financial crises.

title: A Jay-Z Sighting  in 1939 Harlem
description: Yes, the New York Public Library swears, the old photo of the guy who looks scarily like Jay-Z really is an unretouched, un-Photoshopped image from 1939. Were 100 percent certain its legitimate, Adenike Olanrewaju, a library spokeswoman, said on Friday. Heres the original:

title: Jaydens and Aidens Are Taking Over
description: Its not your imagination: Jaydens, Aidens, Ethans and Masons really are taking over, at least among baby boys.

title: In the Darkness, a Parade on the Rails
description: Sixteen vintage cars were pulled through Harlem to Grand Central Terminal by two separate locomotives, late Thursday night and into Friday morning.

title: Pulled Pork, for Crowds Large or Small
description: In this weeks column and video, I give a recipe for a small batch of pulled pork. Instead of the usual 7-pound bone-in hunk of meat, I use a 3-pound chunk. That said, if you want to use the same recipe with the larger cut, you certainly can. Double the spice rub and barbecue sauce, and if you love coleslaw, consider making one and a half times that recipe. You will very likely need to cook the meat longer. Just check it every 30 minutes or so after the four-hour mark, and when it reaches an internal temperature of 200 degrees, its done. The recipe for pulled pork is here.

title: Katherine Boos Beautiful Forevers Headed to the Stage
description: Katherine Boo brought the Annawadi slum to vivid life in Behind the Beautiful Forevers: Life, Death, and Hope in a Mumbai Undercity, one of the most acclaimed books of 2012. The National Theater in London hopes to do the same in a stage version of the book next year.

title: A Parade of Vintage Trains, Unnoticed in the Harlem Night
description: The trains lurched through the Harlem darkness, rattling above an all-night pawnshop, a swell of reggaetn music and a man in a headdress, squawking from his bicycle.

title: Great Gatsby  Is Poised for a  Strong Opening, No Thanks to Critics
description: LOS ANGELES  As very early box-office numbers for The Great Gatsby rolled in  a strong $3.25 million from the Thursday late-night shows, Warner Brothers said on Friday morning  it was already becoming clear that the audience has a mind of its own.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Santa Teresa, a Venezuelan rum producer, will conduct four free tastings of its flagship rum, Santa Teresa 1796, at Union Square Wines and Spirits, 140 Fourth Avenue. The rum will be served neat, on the rocks and in cocktails. The first session is on Friday from 6 to 9 p.m., paired with chocolates for Mothers Day. The three other sessions are on May 17, 24 and 31.

title: An Eclectic Automotive Wish List From Counting Cars
description: If youve seen Counting Cars, the reality show on the A&E Networks History, youre used to the sight of Danny Koker, known as the Count, and his best buddy, Kevin Mack, cruising the streets of Las Vegas in search of restoration projects for their Counts Kustoms shop. They spot old cars and trucks in parking lots, peeking out of garages and sometimes even cruising in the next lane. Some they restore and pass on to new owners whose smiling faces are displayed prominently on the show. Other cars Mr. Koker keeps; he owns at least 58 cars and 10 motorcycles.

title: Health Law Is Defended With Vigor by President
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama came out fighting in defense of his health care law on Friday, saying that he was 110 percent committed to delivering its benefits on schedule, and that consumers should not be bamboozled by critics spreading misinformation about the law.

title: A Brazilian Designer Finally Gets Her Due in New York
description: Brazilian designers have reached higher levels of recognition (and sales) lately, but for every Oscar Niemeyer and Sergio Rodrigues there are flocks of Brazilian designers flying under the radar. Claudia Moreira Salles could be considered a real find by many, despite more than 30 years creating furniture and interiors for architects including Ricardo Legorreta and projects like the rooftop bar of the Hotel Americano in Chelsea.

title: A Tongue Made for Slurping
description: How does Pallass long-tongued bat collect nectar mid-flight? Using a long, barb-lined tongue, of course.

title: Tables Inspired by African Stools
description: Though theyve been in business for five years, the product designers behind Grain, a firm based on Bainbridge Island off the Seattle coast, have only just gotten around to doing furniture. Before this, the team  Chelsea Green, 32, and James Minola, 30  designed what they call personal accessories, like a recyclable shower curtain and a hand mirror. At the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, May 18to 21 at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, they plan to introduce two versions of their Dish table (one is a side table, the other a coffee table). The models were hand-carved African stools that Ms. Green received from her parents and grandparents, who grew up in Africa (her father was born in Nigeria; her mother lived for a time in Ethiopia and Ghana). We were a bit inspired by the scooped-out shape but wanted it to be more functional, so we flattened it out and cleaned it up a bit, she said. The tables are made of ash and available in either a clear oil finish or black stain; the side table is $1,950, and the coffee table is $2,500. Grain also plans to present a new mirror and candlesticks at the fair. Information: (206) 965-9302 or graindesign.com.

title: A Strong Response to Paying Board Nominees
description: The stakes just got higher for shareholder activists.

title: Tongue Like a Mop
description: Certain bats, like Pallass long-tongued bat, hover over flowers and suck nectar. Hovering takes a lot of energy, so the bats need to gather as much liquid as possible with each flick of their long tongues. Scientists have long known that hairlike structures known as papillae at the tips of the bats tongues help trap the nectar. Now, using high-speed video cameras, researchers at Brown University have seen that as the tongues extend, the papillae flare outward, becoming perpendicular.

title: Kiefer Sutherland and Fox Ratings
description: Fans of the Fox drama Touch, which stars Kiefer Sutherland, would be wise to savor the Season 2 finale on Friday. A day before, the network announced that this episode would in fact be the series finale.

title: Week in Review: Big Names and Big Money in Las Vegas
description: Hedge fund manager and S.E.C. reach deal. | JPMorgan sued over credit card debt cases. | Enrons Skilling strikes a deal for a shorter prison sentence. | Hedge fund impresario plays host in Las Vegas. | Errors afflict more checks issued to aid homeowners. | Small firm could turn the vote on Jamie Dimon. | New York investigates advances on pensions. | A humbled Kleiner Perkins adjusts its strategy. | Two big banks face suits in mortgage pact abuses. | Andrew Ross Sorkin says that for Warren Buffett, the past isnt always a prologue. | A call for new blood on the JPMorgan board.

title: Food for the Epicurean Cinephile
description: LOS ANGELES  For four hours, the filmmakers Natasha Subramaniam and Alisa Lapidus constructed a four-tiered dessert out of whipped cream, amaretto cookies, baked meringue and locally sourced edible flowers. Its a Pavlova meets a croquembouche, Ms. Subramaniam said.

title: Karl Rove Versus Hillary Clinton
description: American Crossroads, the Karl Rove-led super PAC, has released the first attack ad of the 2016 campaign, accusing Hillary Clinton of mishandling the Benghazi killings. Its a pretty shameless spot, filled with innuendo and as many unflattering pictures of the former secretary of state as possible.

title: Big Ticket | $16.295 Million for Wraparound Views
description: A pristine 12-room sponsor unit at 535 West End Avenue, a 1920 brick building reinvented, expanded and marketed as a luxury destination by the Extell Development Company, sold for $16.295 million and was the most expensive residential sale of the week, according to city records. The 6,637-square-foot residence, No. 16, had an original listing price of $16.9 million.

title: NBC Adds 3 More Shows, Including an Updated Ironside
description: The busy rounds of television shows coming and going continued on Friday as NBC added new series to a growing list for fall, while others found themselves facing a last roundup.

title: In Immigration Bill Talks, House Group Raises Voice
description: WASHINGTON  A bipartisan group in the House of Representatives has been meeting on and off for four years behind closed doors, working on its own version of legislation to overhaul the nations immigration laws. But with a comprehensive bill already making its way through the Senate Judiciary Committee, the House group is fast losing its chance to shape the debate percolating on Capitol Hill, let alone put forth a proposal of its own.

title: In Vancouver, Its Time to Re-evaluate
description: Mike Gillis, who took over as the general manager of the Canucks in April 2008, says it is time to hit the reset button after Vancouver was swept in the first round of the playoffs by the San Jose Sharks.

title: A Director Who Doesnt Fake It
description: The Icelandic director Baltasar Kormakur made his international reputation with such offbeat films as 101 Rekjavik, a comedy about a sexually confused slacker, and The Sea, about dark family secrets in a remote fishing village. Yet he is making an impressive transition to American filmmaking with action fare like Contraband, a hit last year, and the comic-book-based 2 Guns,coming this summer.

title: When Helping Hurts
description: AMERICAN parents are more involved in our childrens lives than ever: we schedule play dates, assist with homework and even choose college courses.

title: What Lies Ahead for Dell After Icahns New Demand
description: The new proposal by Carl C. Icahn and Southeastern Asset Management for Dell presents some new complications that a special committee of the computer companys board must consider.

title: Week in Pictures for May 10
description: Photographs include a Cinco de Mayo celebration in the Bronx, art on Randalls Island and a new cooperative space at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: About Last Night | Neville Wakefields Arty Bash for Playboy
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Activist Is Detained in Egypt for Inciting Protests Against Morsi Government
description: The Egyptian police arrested Ahmed Maher, a high-profile figure from the countrys 2011 revolution, at Cairo International Airport on Friday as he returned from a 13-day trip to the United States. The authorities ordered that he be detained for four days pending investigation into charges of inciting protests in connection with a demonstration held in March, according to local media reports.

title: Mammas by Isabella Rossellini
description: Ms. Rossellini explores the concept of maternal instinct in Mammas, a series of shorts she conceived and directed, which will be broadcast Mothers Day on the Sundance Channel.

title: A Day in the Gym, a Life in Transition
description: Fallon Fox, the first openly transgender athlete in mixed martial arts, considers the training center her second home and her fellow fighters her replacement family.

title: A Record-Setting Gala for Lincoln Center, With a Bonus Tribute for Reynold Levy
description: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts raised $9.4 million at its spring gala on Thursday night, a record for the organization. The gala honored Lincoln Centers president, Reynold Levy, who is stepping down in December after 11 years. The evening started with the total at $8.2 million, but during the speeches, Katherine Farley, Lincoln Centers chairwoman, announced that an additional $1.2 million had been raised for the creation of the Reynold Levy Fellowship for Harvard Business School graduates interested in nonprofit organizations.

title: On Eve of Pivotal Election, Pakistan Orders Times Reporter to Leave
description: Pakistans Interior Ministry has ordered the expulsion of the Islamabad bureau chief for The New York Times on the eve of national elections, the newspaper said Friday. The Times has strongly protested the move and is seeking his reinstatement.

title: Despite Convictions, Brazil Corruption Case Drags On
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Just six months ago, Brazils highest court handed down stiff prison sentences to powerful political figures found guilty in a vast vote-buying scheme, a move widely praised here as a watershed moment in a country where citizens long expected little more than impunity from politicians caught in corruption scandals.

title: Image of the Day: May 10
Band Members Say Slayer Guitarist Died of Cirrhosis of the Liver
description: The surviving members of the metal band Slayer said that the guitarist Jeff Hanneman had died of alcohol-related cirrhosis of the liver, not from an infection of flesh-eating bacteria.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Bangladesh, Pakistan, Egypt and Israel.

title: In Celebration of Food, and Art
description: The iconic SoHo restaurant FOOD, run by Carol Goodden and the artist Gordon Matta-Clark in the 1970s, was recreated at the Frieze Art Fair on Randalls Island on Thursday, offering a $15 prix fixe meal for survival: beef jerky, hardtack, dried fruits and cheese on a divided paper plate, along with a pickle; a cup of Jjigae, or Korean stew, and a cup of Tang.

title: Straying a Bit Beyond Its Own Comfort Zone
description: Big, puffy and comfortable, the Avalon has served Toyota like a trusty Barcalounger. Since 1995 its been a staid sedan, in a staid full-size class, from a staid company.

title: Toyotas Once-Sleepy Sedan Gives a Wake-Up Call
description: The 2013 Avalon finds itself the unlikely avatar of a purportedly new  more adventurous and design-driven  Toyota.

title: Using a Trowel to Erase Time
description: Mohammed Ashraf Uddin grew up in a round wooden house on the Bangladeshi island of Sandwip, on a 30-acre farm where his family grew rice, eggplant, peas and green peppers. The farms inhabitants included cows, goats and chickens  so many animals, Mr. Uddin said, that we never had to buy anything from the market. While helping till the soil, he studied accounting at the local college, where he also learned English.

title: Creating an Ad Campaign for Oreos, as They Turn 101
description: The question What do you do for an encore? may be asked after a hit almost as often on Madison Avenue as it is in Hollywood or on Broadway. No sooner does a popular advertising campaign conclude, it seems, than everyone begins to wonder what an appropriate follow-up or next step would be.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: 3-D Smartphone and Hacking the Onion
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Tavares, Islanders Star, Is Hart Trophy Finalist
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The Islanders had just lost, 4-0, in Game 5 of their playoff series with the Pittsburgh Penguins, but there was some good news for the star center John Tavares.

title: A Change of Plans, Thanks to a Bird
description: Sandra Lee, 46, is the host of Semi-Homemade Cooking, in its 15th season on the Food Network. Her first novel, The Recipe Box, will be out this summer. Born in Santa Monica, Calif., she lives in Manhattan and shares a home in Westchester County with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: A Roving Art Fair Finds a Home Court Advantage
description: The roving NADA art fairs have set up camp at some distinctive places, including an oceanfront hotel in Miami Beach and a former factory in Hudson, N.Y. But they have found their best home yet on a set of basketball courts on the Lower East Side. On Thursday, a day before the fair opened to V.I.P.s at Basketball City, a complex on Pier 36, gray carpet covered the hardwood, and white wallboard had been erected to create neat grids. The scoreboards were still up, but that somehow felt right in this packed week of fairs, shows and events.

title: On the Market in the Hamptons
description: Properties include an 1800s village cottage, a house with a lush garden, a barn conversion near the beach, a home with Montauk water views and a five-bedroom near the village.

title: A Peasant Pie Comfortable at Any Table
description: In the sunnier climes of Italy, Greece and the south of France, theres a long tradition of frugal, savory pies made with a humble filling of cooked greens (usually wild foraged ones, like dandelion or nettles), stewed onions and a little grated cheese. Though tasty, they were meatless  this was peasant food. The family cook probably heard, What, pie again? more often than not. But it was a way to stay alive.

title: Exploring His Tunisian Roots, With His Father by His Side
description: At the start of The Ulysses Syndrome, Jonah Bokaer and Tsvi, his Tunisian-born father, take their places at the back of a stage illuminated by six fluorescent tubes, arranged in a hexagon, each dangling like a low swing. Sitting on the floor, the men remain still, leaning against the wall with one knee up.

title: The Trek to a Yogurt Less Sweet
description: WHITE PLAINS  Dannon yogurt had a secret it didnt want you to know. Until recently.

title: 2 Key JPMorgan Directors Back Dimons Dual Roles
description: Jamie Dimon has received a spirited defense against calls by some shareholders to split his jobs of chief executive and chairman of JPMorgan Chase.

title: Author of Study on Immigrants I.Q. Leaves Heritage Foundation
description: Jason Richwine, a senior policy analyst at the conservative Heritage Foundation who argued in a graduate school dissertation that Hispanic immigrants were less intelligent than white Americans, resigned from his post with the foundation on Friday.

title: Inside the Frieze Art Fair
description: A parade of the fine and fancy made an appearance at Frieze Art Fair, including Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Renee Rockefeller.

title: At Frieze, the Elite Browse and Forage
description: Just go with it, Patty Smyth, the rocker, said to her husband, the tennis legend John McEnroe, urging him to tip up a coupe of Bobby Burns, a potent cocktail of whiskey, sweet vermouth, Bndictine and a twist of lemon. Go with the flow.

title: Complaint Against Bryce Reed
description: Bryce Reed, a paramedic who helped evacuate people after the fertilizer plant explosion in West, Tex., was charged with possessing bomb-making materials.

title: Student Debts Impact on Young Graduates
description: Student loan debt now exceeds $1 trillion, and as Annie Lowrey writes, that debt is an increasing burden to the financial lives of young graduates. It is forcing them to delay purchases of things like homes, cars and other big-ticket items and acting as a drag on growth, economists say.

title: All the Rage | This Years Frieze New York Artists Are Mad About Plants
description: Considering the dozens of languages, thousands of artworks and billions of dollars coursing through the tent at Frieze New York  the second edition of which opened to the public on Friday and runs through Monday  you might expect the fair to offer a decisive statement about what matters in art right now. In truth, thats probably expecting too much from what is ultimately a highbrow pop-up shopping mall, but certain motifs always emerge from these extravaganzas, and whats more fun than sussing out the pattern? This year, the predominant trend is flora, with plant life sprouting up in photographs and potted into sculptures. A reflection of the mania for sustainability and urban gardens? A nod to the season? Decide for yourself. Well see if the greenery rakes in the green, but watch out for some of these leafy highlights as you venture past the air kisses and hipster restaurants into Frieze New Yorks white cube jungle.

title: Actavis in Preliminary Talks With Warner Chilcott
description: Actavis is in talks with another drug maker about a potential merger after talks with Valeant Pharmaceuticals International fell through.

title: Printable-Gun Instructions Spread Online After State Dept. Orders Their Removal
description: The State Department, citing possible compliance concerns regarding the export of firearms, has ordered a Web site to remove what are believed to be the worlds first online instructions on how to build a 3-D printable handgun.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 10
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

title: El Museo del Barrios Board President to Leave
description: El Museo del Barrios board president, who was named in a recent discrimination claim by the museums former director, will leave her position at the end of her term on June 30, museum officials said on Friday. The official, Yaz Hernndez, is departing as the museum searches for a new director and struggles to find its fiscal footing.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 10
description: More photographs.

title: Searching for Roots, Finding Characters
description: Family Tree is a half-hour HBO comedy about a lethargic, unemployed young British man who becomes obsessed with tracking down his ancestors. Its largely improvised and poses as a documentary, though to such a slight degree that it hardly matters. That this does not sound like a terrible idea for a television show is largely because of the past work of Christopher Guest, who, as it happens, created and wrote Family Tree with Jim Piddock. Depending on your taste, thats either a tribute or a reproach.

title: Keeping Peace in a Vertical Village
description: As director of operations and compliance for AKAM Associates, a property management company for luxury co-op and condominium buildings in New York City, Doug Weinstein is responsible for all physical projects in 125 buildings. He fields daily calls from cooperative and condominium boards about everything from code issues to job bids. Mr. Weinstein started in the business nearly 30 years ago, working for his cousin, Martin Raynes, of M. J. Raynes Inc., a large real estate developer in the city in the 1980s.

title: Using Darkness, With Enlightenment in Mind
description: The Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas has written several works to be performed in pitch darkness, including In Vain, his hourlong masterpiece for chamber orchestra. With artificial light everywhere, we do not have any night in our modern life, he said in an interview in 2011. But I think our body and our souls desire night, and I give this in my art.

title: The Boy Toys Story
description: RENO, Nev.  Soon after moving into Liberaces gaudy Las Vegas mansion in 1977, Scott Thorson, then a teenage hunk in the foster care system, learned that the jewel-smitten showman could love just as extravagantly as he decorated. Touring the premises before their relationship began, Liberace pointed out some decorative highlights, which included 17 pianos, a casino, a quarrys worth of marble and a canopied bed with an ermine spread. On the ceiling was a reproduction of the Sistine Chapel with Liberaces face painted among the cherubs.

title: Details Emerge About Syrian Electronic Armys Recent Exploits
description: At The Onion its all fun and games, except whenthe companys Twitter accountgets hacked.

title: Braving Frostbite in Search of Ratings
description: The weather in much of the United States is finally beginning to warm up, but on television things are getting noticeably colder. A burst of new and returning reality series seem intent on leaving us envious of, or in awe of, or terrified for, those who live where the wind blows cold almost year-round.

title: A French Jet Maker Is Approaching a Crossroad
description: SAINT-CLOUD, FRANCE  As Jrme Camps, an engineer at Dassault Aviations main design center, showed off a ghostlike 3-D model of one of the companys small jets here recently, his hand passed through the planes skin to reveal an intricate web of support structures as well as a jumble of multicolored cables and pneumatic tubes, rendered in vivid detail.

title: 40 Nations, 1,000 Artists and One Island
description: Some people hate art fairs all of the time, and most people hate them some of the time. Its fashionable to be snarky and condescending about them, but thats too easy. Art fairs are here for the foreseeable future and represent the collective efforts  if not the hopes and dreams  of thousands of people who want art to be at the center of their lives.

title: In Blow to NBC News, Rock Center Is Canceled
description: Among the cancellations announced this week in anticipation of Mondays unveiling of a new prime time schedule, surely the hardest to take for NBC News is the closing notice for Rock Center, the ambitious newsmagazine program that hoped to stake out new territory for both the news division and its chief anchor, Brian Williams.

title: A Line Between Sweet and Skimpy
description: It first happened to me this spring. My daughters, who had just turned 8, came bounding into the room to show off new outfits they were wearing to an extended-family gathering. My eyes bulged. The dresses drooped provocatively off the shoulder and offered other peekaboos of their bodies. Sure, as a parent, I figured I would one day face clothing battles with my children. Politicians arent the only ones who draw red lines.

title: Ever Separated by Sound
description: The man looks like an aging bachelor bank teller in a 1962 episode of The Twilight Zone. Or like the hopelessly square dad in a midcentury sitcom. But Michael Bonnabel  in his suit, narrow tie and eyeglasses  is the son in the Abingdon Theater Companys production of his autobiographical solo show, The Good Boy.

title: Fort Lauderdale Regional Play
description: The most successful players at the Fort Lauderdale, Fla., regional over the first seven days of April were Robert Rosen of Delray Beach, Fla.; Alan Osofsky of Palm Beach, Fla.; David Berkowitz of Boca Raton, Fla.; and Alan Sontag of Gaithersburg, Md.

title: E.M.T. at Fertilizer Plant Blast Faces Charge of Possessing Bomb Parts
description: Texas authorities said on Friday that they had opened a criminal investigation into last months deadly explosion at a fertilizer plant that killed 14 people and injured some 200 others.

title: Not Just the Standards, but Storytelling, Too
description: Absolutely thrilling. That describes Audra McDonalds Avery Fisher Hall performance at Lincoln Centers spring gala on Thursday evening. The very sound of the word thrilling, with its suggestion of an embedded trill, evokes qualities inherent in Ms. McDonalds soprano, which seemed to unfurl in ever-richer textures as she imbued songs with a sense of bursting possibility.

title: An Artist Recreates a Smoking Room With Flowers and Perfume
description: Maria Lobodas newest installation, an artfully arranged flower bed called Smoking Room in a Private Palais in Brussels as Seen From the Entrance, 1905, greets visitors as they exit the tents of the Frieze Art Fair on Randalls Island in New York. The outdoor exhibition is a tribute to two early 20th-century design phenomena: a smoking room in Vienna, designed by the secessionist production cooperative Wiener Werksttte, and color-charted gardens, a bygone fad for mapping flowers by shade to create a plot that feels almost like a Pantone chart. Loboda potted groups of different plants in an arrangement that mimics the floor plan of the smoking room. The idea is to take the domestic situation, an interior, and to translate it into something wild, into a landscape, she said.

title: Bumpy Road for Trophy Cars
description: MUMBAI  Its not easy being the owner of an exceedingly expensive car in India. Just ask Rishabh Jain, whose Lamborghini Murcilago LP640, in a shade of metallic gray called Grigio Telesto, spends an inordinate amount of time under a cover in the parking lot of his apartment building in the affluent Malabar Hill neighborhood here.

title: Conspicuous Consumption, With a Few Caveats
description: Facing rough streets and high taxes, Indias owners of supercars and high-end luxury vehicles are finding that riding in style isnt always easy.

title: Country Stars Playing Musical Chairs
description: For Lady Antebellum, lipstick represents optimism. For Pistol Annies, its a tool of the oppressor.

title: A New Town, a New Focus on Dinner
description: Sweet Basils Cafe and Grill made its reputation as a place for brunch and lunch, first in West Orange and later in Livingston, where it moved last July. An expanded menu and new talent in the kitchen now make it an equally fine place for dinner.

title: Recalling Chimps and Brel, in Her Own Way
description: Not many people know that the grandiose Sinatra anthem My Way, had an earlier life in France under the title Comme dhabitude (As Usual) whose morose narrator describes a deteriorating relationship that has settled into a chilly routine. Juiced up with new lyrics by Paul Anka, it became the triumphal ego trip we all know and have learned to tolerate.

title: 13-Year-Old Playwright Awaits His Big Night
description: Kyle Abrahams had never tried to write a play before his drama teacher, John McEneny, required him to try for a middle school class in Brooklyn. Kyle had always liked acting  he recently performed in a production of Frankenstein. Now, though, hed be the one giving other actors instructions.

title: Kobe Bryants Sentimental Shot
description: Yesterday a friend and fan of all Philadelphia sports directed me to a Philly.com story about the former Notre Dame football player Manti Teos girlfriend making the Maxim Hot 100; his reaction was basically Phew, glad the Iggles didnt draft this guy.

title: Isabella Rossellinis Sly Maternal Instinct
description: Some Mothers Day tributes are less wholesome than others, and thank heaven for that. Mammas  a set of short films, two to three minutes each, appearing Sunday on the Sundance Channel and sundancechannel.com  reflects the distinctive character of its creator, Isabella Rossellini: a blend of innocence, sophistication and sly smuttiness. Its a long way from flowers, chocolates and brunch.

title: Lots of Room, and a Festive Vibe
description: The Rose Room, which opened in Mount Kisco in February, is a place of hits and misses.

title: Umpire Suspended for Blown Call
description: In a week in which umpires twice became the story of games because of high-profile mistakes, Major League Baseball took action on Friday, handing a two-game suspension to Fieldin Culbreth, the umpire who on Thursday incorrectly allowed an illegal pitching change in a game between the Houston Astros and Los Angeles Angels.

title: Thai Discoveries in a Spare Setting
description: Two suggestions if you visit Rainbow Thai in Westport: first, reserve ahead, as this tiny place seats only 40, and second, request, if it is available, a table overlooking the Saugatuck River. If you are lucky you might even catch a glimpse of crews rowing below you on the river.

title: Friday Night Music: Sarah Jarosz, Tell Me True
description: I was looking for a live version with the full trio, and here it is. Theyre performing in New York in a couple of weeks.

title: Editors Letter | Away We Go
description: Travel journalism often falls into one of two camps  the highly didactic and servicey piece, go here, stay there, see that, or the long-winded narrative in which the writer has the experience and we are meant to be satisfied by the first-person blow-by-blow he or she has brought back for us: the road into town was dusty and unpaved and the driver kept getting lost. The former is best served up by the Internet on demand. (You can find all of our hotel and restaurant suggestions for the stories in this issue at tmagazine.com.) And the pure version of the latter is perhaps best left to brilliant writers who promise to reward you for coming along (Edith Wharton, Patrick Leigh Fermor, Evelyn Waugh, Jan Morris). There are of course also intellectual and cultural histories of locales, in which the writer seeks to tease out the influences  historical, economic, social, stylistic, culinary and political  that make the place uniquely what it is (V. S. Naipaul, Bruce Chatwin, Ryszard Kapuscinski). The type we favor at T is a hybrid of the three, in which great writing and personal narrative is done in the service of not just traipsing along with the writer who got to go on an amazing journey that we didnt, but of bringing you back a new understanding of a place that is enlightening and satisfying regardless of whether you ever plan to visit. And yet, if you do choose to go, were there to guide you.

title: For Casual Crowds, Second Labels
description: When the number of guests at a party or a barbecue threatens to overwhelm the wine budget, second labels can come to the rescue.

title: A Lively Little Party of Plenty
description: As we walked into La Cucina, a year-and-a-half-old Italian restaurant in Hewlett, on a recent Saturday night, something resembling a dinner party was in full swing. The owner, Luigi Muto, greeted us with a warm smile and a worried glance over his shoulder. Behind him, the small minimalist dining room  awash in soft jazz, seductive aromas and animated conversation  was packed.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Where the Musical Meets the Visual
description: It may look at first like a simple compilation of abstract art, but the new show at the Art League of Long Island in Dix Hills possesses an extra dimension: It is actually a collection of 63 musical scores or parts of scores by composers from around the world.

title: The Week in Pictures for May 10
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a Cinco de Mayo celebration in the Bronx, art on Randalls Island and a new cooperative space at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Safeguarding the Past, in an Uncooperative Present
description: ATHENS

title: How Class Size Affects Students Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: Meals of Imagined Bounty
description: Sometimes its easy to tell which part of the 20th century we are seeing in The Dining Room. When one man mentions the horrors of instant coffee on Eastern Airlines, for instance, you know were in the era of the beloved hourly shuttle to Washington or Boston. At other times, it can be more difficult, as when a father complains, The government is systematically ruining this country.

title: The Secret of Baxters Success
description: In trying to figure out why Mike Baxter has been such a good pinch-hitter for the Mets, Manager Terry Collins pointed to his attention to detail. It is a rare player who pays such close attention while being stuck on the bench. But Baxter does. This season, he is 5 for 9 as a pinch-hitter, including leading the Mets to two final-inning wins this week. After Thursdays hit, Baxter became the first pinch-hitter since 1991 to have game-ending at-bats twice in a three-day span.

title: T Summer Travel 2013
description: Ts Summer Travel issue is all about trying something new: whether its staying in a strangers home (Gideon Lewis-Kraus writes about Airbnb), taking a trip alone (Andrew OHagan delights in traveling solo) or considering a place off the beaten path (Adam Sachs has a love-hate relationship with Marin County, Calif.). Inside, there is Ts usual mix of art, entertainment and fashion with a profile on the artist James Turrell by Edward Helmore, a visit with the actor Rupert Everett by Sarah Lyall and a round-up of black bikinis and leather cover-ups photographed by Craig McDean and styled by Joe McKenna. And dont forget to drop in on Saturdays Surf NYC in Japan, check out our selection of hotel gardens or read about Italys Spoleto Festival. See all from the issue >>

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Is Too Skimpy for an 8-Year-Old in the Eye of the Beholder?
description: Bruce Feiler, This Life columnist for the Styles section, has a problem he never expected to confront so soon. When his twin 8-year-old girls appeared recently to show off the new clothes they planned to wear to a family function:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: For a Festival, Back to the Future
description: Before Bamboozle, the music festival that started as the Great Bamboozle in Asbury Park in 2003, there was the Skate and Surf Festival.

description:
The Met Costume Institutes Punk: Chaos to Couture exhibition. 
Correction: An earlier version of the audio misstated the surname Malcolm McLaren. This audio has been edited to remove that portion.

description: To the Editor:

title: A View of the Heavens From Texas
description: Amateur astronomers gathered for the 34th Texas Star Party, which offered them a chance to gaze at a sky full of nothing but stars.

title: An Actress, a Director and a Power Struggle
description: Venus in Fur is a smart, seriously sexy comedy by David Ives that has steamed up three successive New York playhouses in recent seasons. The George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, where the play is currently onstage, is among the dozen regional companies that have put it on their 2013 schedules, with good reason.

title: Seamless Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Why Federal Efforts to Ensure Clean Tap Water Fail to Reach Faucets Nationwide
description: MONSON, Calif.  Laura Garcia was halfway through the breakfast dishes when the spigot went dry. The small white tank beneath the sink that purified her undrinkable water had run out. Still, as annoying as that was, it was an improvement over the days before Ms. Garcia got her water filter, when she had to do her dishes using water from five-gallon containers she bought at a local store.

title: Missing: Jonathan Winters. Badly.
description: (This is the second part of a two-part article.)

title: Egypt: Prominent Activist Jailed
description: A prominent Egyptian activist was jailed Friday on accusations of inciting protests in front of the Interior Ministry in March, state news media said. The activist, Ahmed Maher, was arrested at the Cairo airport upon arriving from abroad and transferred to a high-security prison where he will be held for four days while the accusations are investigated. Mr. Maher is a leader in the April 6 Youth Group that help organize the protests that ousted President Hosni Mubarak in February 2011. He has recently spoken out against President Mohamed Morsi and his allies in the Muslim Brotherhood.

title: Pre-1492, Artistic Notions Worth Borrowing
description: If modern art was characterized by the shock of the new, recent decades have seen an obsession with recycling. History is treated like an archive from which images and objects can be borrowed, appropriated, and repurposed  just like in popular music, where sampling was born, and which is alluded to in the title of Pre-Columbian Remix: The Art of Enrique Chagoya, Demin Flores, Rubn Ortiz-Torres, and Nadn Ospina at the Neuberger Museum of Art, Purchase College.

title: Pakistans Tyrannical Majority
description: JUST after the stroke of midnight on Aug. 14, 1947, the Peshawar broadcast station of All India Radio crackled to life: This is Pakistan Broadcasting Service. Next came the words of the Urdu-language poet Ahmed Nadeem Qasmi: Pakistan bananay walay, Pakistan Mubarak  Oh, maker of Pakistan, congratulations on Pakistan.

title: Rebuilding After Sandy, but With Costly New Rules
description: Its been more than six months since Hurricane Sandy hit the East Coast, yet many people whose homes were ravaged by the storm still do not know how to put all the pieces back together.

title: Shunned Elsewhere, Body of Marathon Bombing Suspect Is Buried in Virginia Cemetery
description: BOSTON  The mystery surrounding the burial of the body of Tamerlan Tsarnaev has come to an end. The Boston Marathon bombing suspect was buried this week at a small Muslim cemetery in Doswell, Va.

title: Report Your Hurricane Sandy Repair Stories
description: This weeks Your Money column looks at the tough position of many homeowners whose houses were severely damaged by Hurricane Sandy. They are still figuring out the best way to put their homes back together, and how they will pay for the repairs.

title: CBS to Add 4 Comedies, Including Another From Chuck Lorre
description: CBS joined other networks in sending out orders for new series Friday and, for CBS, that list was longer and included some untraditional ideas.

title: George Sauer, Jets Receiver and Rebel, Is Dead at 69
description: George Sauer, who as a wide receiver for the Jets played a pivotal role in the teams stunning victory in Super Bowl III, and who later quit professional football because he considered it dehumanizing, died on Tuesday in Westerville, Ohio. He was 69.

title: The Hitless Songwriter
description: Michael Tannen, The Roches manager, was yelling into the phone at me. Why dont you just listen to the radio and figure out how to write a commercial song? Then the phone went dead.

title: The Family Unfriendly Act
description: There are two good things to say about the Working Families Flexibility Act, which passed the House this week with 220 Republican and three Democratic votes.

title: Samuel Noyes, Mountaineer
description: Few Union units were as esteemed for their collective strength as the 12th New Hampshire Infantry. It was magnet for strapping young fellows from the farms that dotted the states White Mountains. No wonder that a regiment, having so many giant-like men, should have been called the New Hampshire Mountaineers, mused one of its captains, Asa Bartlett, about the origin of the units nickname.

title: Privacy Breach on Bloombergs Data Terminals
description: A shudder went through Wall Street on Friday after the revelation that Bloomberg News reporters had extracted subscribers private information through the companys ubiquitous data terminals to break news.

title: New Technology and Risks Enter a Venerable Event
description: On a sun-kissed afternoon in the Bay Area last week, Larry Olson, a 39-year-old from San Francisco, backed his car into a parking space next to Marina Green, flipped up the hatch to create a viewing platform and watched with his young children as Artemis Racings Americas Cup catamaran sped by in the stiff breeze on San Francisco Bay.

title: Former Leader of Guatemala Is Guilty of Genocide Against Mayan Group
description: GUATEMALA CITY  A Guatemalan court on Friday found Gen. Efran Ros Montt, the former dictator who ruled Guatemala during one of the bloodiest periods of its long civil war, guilty of genocide and crimes against humanity.

title: Retailers Are Pressed on Safety at Factories
description: A wide spectrum of government officials, investors and religious groups are warning major retailers like Walmart, Benetton and Gap that they could face financial repercussions from consumers, damage to their stock value or sustained public protests if they do not adopt stricter garment manufacturing standards.

title: Technology Industry Lobbying Group Loses Supporters
description: Elon Musk, a founder of the electric carmaker Tesla and one of the technology industrys most outspoken exponents of clean energy, has stepped down from a prominent Silicon Valley advocacy group that is pushing for changes to the nations immigration laws and that has sponsored advertisements that promote a contentious oil pipeline.

title: A Meal in Borough No. 5: Manhattan
description: Consider the crush of publicity and the lines that have formed on Second Avenue outside Wylie Dufresnes newest restaurant. Note that Mr. Dufresne and his muttonchops are television celebrities. Add that last week Mr. Dufresne won the James Beard Award for New Yorks Best Chef. So how refreshing it was that not everybody in Alders rustic-chic dining room on Wednesday was caught up on the places reputation. One food-loving couple transplanted from San Diego and Venice (Italy) came for their own adventure: the end of a five-borough birthday tour. They were delightfully unaware of WD-50, Mr. Dufresnes celebrated flagship. And instead of debating the hype, they reveled in the whimsy of the evening and Alders modernist spin on comfort food, savoring their journey as much as the dehydrated pastrami.

title: Former Major Winner Provides Tough Love as a Caddie at the Players
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  A seven-time PGA Tour winner missed the Players Championship cut by two strokes without even hitting a shot. Mark Brooks, whose tour victories include one major, the 1996 P.G.A. Championship, caddied for J. J. Henry, who finished at two over, 13 strokes higher than the 36-hole leader, Sergio Garca.

title: Troubled Life in Malcolm Xs Shadow Comes to a Violent End
description: Last week, Malcolm Shabazz, the grandson of Malcolm X, was talking to his friend Daniel Stevens when he learned that Mr. Stevens was worried that his fledgling rap career was going nowhere. Mr. Shabazz vowed to help, saying that he could get Mr. Stevenss music into the right hands.

title: With Many Despairing, Bulgaria Heads to Polls
description: VARNA, Bulgaria  Early one morning this past winter, Plamen Goranov, a 36-year-old photographer, stood on the steps of City Hall in this once grand and now crumbling port city on the Black Sea and held up a sign demanding that the mayor and City Council resign. He then took a bottle of gasoline from his backpack, poured it over himself and set himself on fire. He died 11 days later in a hospital.

title: A Composers Best Friend
description: On Wednesday, Lucy Mann was out there again, standing behind her table just inside the entrance to the Manhattan School of Music.

title: New Error Found in Scoring of Test for Gifted Programs
description: Three weeks after New York City disclosed that thousands of students had been wrongly excluded from eligibility in public school gifted programs, the Education Department said that roughly 300 additional students received incorrect scores because of another mistake by the testing company.

title: Rodman Says Hell Ask North Korea to Free American
description: Dennis Rodman, the flamboyant former basketball player who has managed to engage with North Koreas leader  something United States officials have been unable to do  said he planned to return to the North to try to gain the release of an imprisoned American citizen, according to a video posted Friday on the celebrity news Web site TMZ.

title: Pay People to Cook at Home
description: THE home-cooked family meal is often lauded as the solution for problems ranging from obesity to deteriorating health to a decline in civility and morals. Using whole foods to prepare meals without additives and chemicals is the holy grail for todays advocates of better eating.

title: Storm Plans for Disabled Are Inadequate, U.S. Says
description: New York City is in violation of federal law because its emergency management plans do not adequately protect the rights of individuals with disabilities, federal authorities said in a court filing on Friday.

title: Five Children. Any Questions?
description: On Sundays, the comedian and actor Jim Gaffigan, 46, takes a day off from stand-up. Instead of performing, he collects new fodder during family outings with his wife, Jeannie Noth Gaffigan, and their five children, Marre, 9; Jack, 7; Katie, 4; Michael, 22 months; and Patrick, 7 months, and time spent at their home, a fifth-floor walk-up on the Bowery.
