title: In Suit Over Death, Boogaards Family Blames the N.H.L.
description: The family of Derek Boogaard has filed a wrongful-death lawsuit against the National Hockey League.

title: An Orchestra in the Throes of a Lockout
description: When the Finnish conductor Osmo Vanska took over as music director of the Minnesota Orchestra in 2003, he told the players that he wanted it to be the best orchestra in this country in four or five years, he recounted in a 2006 interview.

title: Music for Violin, With Faustian Strings Attached
description: Everyone knows that the Devil has the best tunes. And we also know what he plays them on: a fiddle. From Tartinis Devils Trill Violin Sonata of 1713 to the Charlie Daniels Bands 1979 country music ballad The Devil Went Down to Georgia, the instrument most readily associated with the Crafty One is a violin.

title: Rocking and Rapping in Assorted Spots Below Houston Street
description: Why throw a music festival? There are so many easier things to do. An undertaking of such scale requires aesthetic vision, pinpoint organization, an ability to corral like-minded listeners into one place and at least a little hubris, but hopefully not too much.

title: Searching for Meaning With Britten as a Guide
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center concluded its Britten centennial series with a program at Alice Tully Hall on Friday night that, on paper, looked like a curious collection of pieces. In the first half there were four chamber works, three written when Britten was in his early 20s. One was composed when he was just 18: the Phantasy Quartet for oboe and strings, played dazzlingly by the virtuosic young oboist James Austin Smith and three members of the Orion String Quartet.

title: There Is Something Rotten in the Kingdom of Rome
description: Its been a strong few weeks for productions of operas from the 1930s and 40s at New York conservatories. First, on April 24, came a powerful vision of Brecht and Weills Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny at the Manhattan School of Music, a reminder of the continued relevance of that sharp and moving work.

title: ABC to Live-Stream Its Shows via App
description: This week ABC will quietly revolutionize its app for iPhones and iPads with a button called live. Users around New York and Philadelphia will be able to live-stream all the programming from ABCs local stations there, the first time that any major broadcaster has turned on such a technology.

title: Youve Heard It Many Times Before
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Mondays are tough enough, but did Allan E. Parrish have to get us all mixed up as well?

title: Greek Crackdown on Tax Evasion Yields Little Revenue
description: ATHENS  If ignominy were tax revenue, Greece might be a big step closer to ending its budget problems.

title: Rivera Again Finishes Where He Left Off
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  As Mariano Rivera jogged in from the Kauffman Stadium bullpen in the ninth inning for the 28th and probably final time, the fans gave him a loud ovation, even if it meant they were cheering for the opposing team.

title: Its Ballet, With Booze and Bulls
description: WASHINGTON  The very idea of a ballet adaptation of Ernest Hemingways novel The Sun Also Rises ought to invite snickers. I confess that I was looking forward in cynical spirit to solemn ballet mime grandly indicating Jakes erectile dysfunction  not to mention the war wound that caused it  and, of course, a frisky dance version of the running of the bulls at Pamplona. Yet there was no derision in evidence on Thursday night, when the Washington Ballet gave the world premiere of Septime Webres two-act staging at the Kennedy Centers Eisenhower Theater.

title: The Outlook for the Next TV Season, as Presented to Advertisers Upfront
description: A roundup of what worked  and what didnt  in the 2012-13 television schedules, and what to expect from the coming upfronts.

title: NBC Looks to Past Stars as It Rebuilds Its Schedule for a Turnaround in Prime Time
description: Looking for what has been an elusive turnaround in prime time, NBC announced an aggressive new schedule on Sunday, crowded with new shows and familiar names both in front of and behind the camera.

title: Public University Presidents Are Prospering, Annual Compensation Study Finds
description: In the 2011-12 fiscal year, the nations highest paid public university president was Graham B. Spanier, the president of Pennsylvania State University, who was forced out in November 2011 over his handling of a child sex abuse scandal involving a football coach.

title: Warriors Young and Old Help Square the Series
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  When Golden State Coach Mark Jackson spotted guard Stephen Curry on Sunday morning before the Warriors faced the San Antonio Spurs, he asked Curry for an update on his injured left ankle.

title: Big Vote on Dimon May Hinge on Views on JPMorgans Top Director
description: In his 12 years as chief executive of Exxon Mobil, Lee R. Raymond had a reputation for bulldozing analysts and long-winded shareholders and going toe-to-toe with government authorities.

title: Giving Voice to Womens Game
description: SUMMERFIELD, Fla.  When Rhonda Glenn was a young woman in 1966, she was the publicity coordinator for the L.P.G.A.s Louise Suggs Invitational in Delray Beach, Fla. She was an amateur at that event and was paired in the first round with Mickey Wright and Betsy Rawls, who went on to become Hall of Famers.

title: No Rest and No Margin of Error for the Rangers
description: The fans were tense and worried in the second period at Madison Square Garden on Sunday afternoon. The Rangers were locked in a scoreless tie in an elimination game against the Washington Capitals. They began to nervously overpass, declining to shoot, flubbing scoring chances. The crowd responded with chants of Shoot the puck! Shoot the puck!

title: Afghans Say an American Tortured Civilians
description: MAIDAN SHAHR, Afghanistan  The authorities in Afghanistan are seeking the arrest on murder and torture charges of a man they say is an American and part of a Special Forces unit operating in Wardak Province, three Afghan officials have confirmed.

title: Officials Say Homophobia Motivated Murder in Russia
description: MOSCOW  The brutal murder of a 23-year-old man in the southern city of Volgograd was motivated by homophobia, investigators said Sunday, a rare acknowledgment that comes during a period of rising conservative and antigay sentiment from Russian officials.

title: Sophomore Slump Afflicts Once-Promising TV Shows
description: The last thing network television needs is a sophomore slump.

title: Hospital Mergers Reset Abortion-Access Battle
description: MOUNT VERNON, Wash.  Politicians seeking to restrict access to abortion, a marked trend this year from North Dakota to Arkansas, tend not to get much traction in this part of the country.

title: Higher Bid for Kings Adds Twist to Battle
description: The fight for ownership of the Sacramento Kings, one of the N.B.A.s most beleaguered franchises, will take a big step toward resolution Wednesday when the leagues owners vote on a recommendation that the team be prohibited from moving to Seattle.

title: Newspaper Monopoly That Lost Its Grip
description: A year after announcing a plan to reorganize The Times-Picayune of New Orleans into a more digitally focused enterprise that produced a newspaper just three days a week  enraging local residents  its owners have added a new innovation: they will go back to producing a printed product every day.

title: Jack Butler, an Undrafted Football Hall of Famer, Dies at 85
description: Jack Butler, who was ignored in the National Football League draft but became a Hall of Fame defensive back with the Pittsburgh Steelers and was chosen for the leagues all-decade team of the 1950s, died on Saturday in Pittsburgh. He was 85.

title: Catskill Cultural Center Saved, and Renewed, Thanks to a Fiddlers Tune
description: OLIVEBRIDGE, N.Y.  On a spring Sunday in the Catskill Mountains, Jay Ungar, a fiddler wearing a black vest and hiking boots, and his wife, Molly Mason, playing guitar, stood on a stage in a barnlike performance hall that did not exist a year ago. Can you stand to hear this tune one more time? he asked the audience.

title: A New Direction for a Hasbro Stalwart
description: Hasbro, the toy company that brought its Transformers and G.I. Joe properties to movie theaters, has set its sights on its next summer blockbuster: My Little Pony.

title: A Self-Defeating Change in Course for the Knicks
description: INDIANAPOLIS

title: Cyberattacks Against U.S. Corporations Are on the Rise
description: WASHINGTON  A new wave of cyberattacks is striking American corporations, prompting warnings from federal officials, including a vague one issued last week by the Department of Homeland Security. This time, officials say, the attackers aim is not espionage but sabotage, and the source seems to be somewhere in the Middle East.

title: Equestria Girls Trailer
description: Hoping to build on the popularity of My Little Pony, Hasbro is planning a theatrical release as part of a campaign for its brand extension, Equestria Girls.

title: Seeking Clues to Heart Disease in DNA of an Unlucky Family
description: Early heart disease ran in Rick Del Sontros family, and every time he went for a run, he was scared his heart would betray him. So he did all he could to improve his odds. He kept himself lean, stayed away from red meat, spurned cigarettes and exercised intensely, even completing an Ironman Triathlon.

title: Aces Moral Victories Move the Mets Closer to Real Ones
description: None of the Pittsburgh Pirates had faced Matt Harvey before Sunday, but they were familiar with him. It is hard to miss the first pitcher in the last 100 years to strike out at least 125 and allow fewer than 25 runs in his first 17 career starts.

title: Pakistani Party Leader Looks Forward, as Claims of Vote-Rigging Swirl
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif began talks on Sunday to form a new government, as partial election returns suggested that he and his party would have a commanding hold on Parliament. But Pakistani election officials said final results would take days, even as outrage grew over accusations of rampant vote-rigging, particularly in Karachi.

title: E Pluribus Me
description: Logic, thy name is not Ted Cruz. The very junior senator from Texas is a well-credentialed windbag, with degrees from Princeton and Harvard Law, and a stint clerking at the Supreme Court. After a few months in Congress promoting Ted Cruz, smartest guy in the room, it looks as if he now wants to be Ted Cruz, extremely obnoxious president. But he keeps saying things that make no sense.

title: New York State to Ask Smartphone Makers to Help Prevent Thefts
description: Concerned about an increase in smartphone thefts, the New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, is trying to get the nations largest cellphone makers to do more to discourage the thefts.

title: Pilotless Planes, Pacific Tensions
description: AUSTIN, Tex.

title: How Austerity Kills
description: EARLY last month, a triple suicide was reported in the seaside town of Civitanova Marche, Italy. A married couple, Anna Maria Sopranzi, 68, and Romeo Dionisi, 62, had been struggling to live on her monthly pension of around 500 euros (about $650), and had fallen behind on rent.

title: Googles Offer to Europe
description: Googles competitors, like Microsoft, Expedia and Yelp, have long complained that the company uses its dominant search engine  it has more than 90 percent market share in Europe and about 70 percent in the United States  to promote its own services, like YouTube, Google Maps and others, at the expense of rivals.

title: Last Word to Woods as Garcas Game Sinks on Last 2 Holes
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  As the Players Championship wound down Sunday, there were as many compelling stories on the leader board as there were golf balls in the water surrounding the tournaments signature hole, the par-3 17th.

title: Student Debt and the Crushing of the American Dream
description: A CERTAIN drama has become familiar in the United States (and some other advanced industrialized countries): Bankers encourage people to borrow beyond their means, preying especially on those who are financially unsophisticated. They use their political influence to get favorable treatment of one form or another. Debts mount. Journalists record the human toll. Then comes bewilderment: How could we let this happen again? Officials promise to fix things. Something is done about the most egregious abuses. People move on, reassured that the crisis has abated, but suspecting that it will recur soon.

title: San Diego Mayor Building Economic Bridges to Tijuana
description: SAN DIEGO  Opening a satellite city office in a far-flung neighborhood is not unusual in sprawling cities like this one. But one thing sets apart Mayor Bob Filners newest outpost: it is in another country.

title: Another Round of Promises in Bangladesh
description: Under pressure to respond to the collapse of a factory building that killed more than 1,100 people, the government of Bangladesh recently pledged to impose reforms to its labor laws and safety standards. If carried out fully, the much-delayed changes could go a long way toward improving working conditions in the countrys garment industry. But that is a big if.

title: Scrutiny on Prosecutors After Questions About Brooklyn Detectives Work
description: As the Brooklyn district attorneys office pledged a complete review of about 50 murder cases after questions arose regarding the conduct of the detective assigned to them, renewed scrutiny has also focused on the role prosecutors play in what turn out to be wrongful convictions, and whether they should be held responsible when justice goes awry.

title: Who Can Take Republicans Seriously?
description: It is time for President Obama to abandon his hopes of reaching a grand budget bargain with Republicans.

title: Winning in Washington Has Been Difficult
description: As impressive as the Rangers were against the Washington Capitals on Sunday, their strong all-around performance left them to face a grim reality.

title: City Plans New Approach to Disciplining Mentally Ill Inmates
description: New York City will soon change the way mentally ill inmates are disciplined after breaking rules while in jail, creating alternatives to the more traditional approach of solitary confinement used for most inmates.

title: Cabinet Secretary Solicits Large Donations to Publicize Health Care Law
description: WASHINGTON  Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, has solicited sizable donations from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and H&R Block, the tax preparation service, as part of a multimillion-dollar campaign to ensure the success of President Obamas health care law, administration officials said Sunday, even as a leading Senate Republican raised questions about the legality of her efforts.

title: As Minutes Add Up for Bulls Starters, Time Seems to Be on Heats Side
description: CHICAGO  The Chicago Bulls want to play rough, and they have made no secret of it. They have turned their second-round Eastern Conference playoff series against the Miami Heat into a black-and-blue affair, defined by bumps, bruises, elbows and shoves.

title: Judging Hillary Clinton as Secretary of State
Chinese Creating New Auto Niche Within Detroit
description: DETROIT  Dozens of companies from China are putting down roots in Detroit, part of the countrys steady push into the American auto industry.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

Food Aid Reforms

title: Alarm Bells in Albany
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo, who promised to clean up state government in his 2010 campaign, has now become so alarmed by the latest scandals in Albany that he has issued a threat lawmakers ought to take seriously. If the Legislature does not pass a package of electoral reforms, including public financing, before the session ends in June, he says he will consider appointing a Moreland Act Commission that can investigate and subpoena government officials suspected of misconduct. The commission would be able to make public its findings and pass those findings on to local or federal investigators.

title: Dark Heritage
description: Last week the Heritage Foundation delivered a report claiming that legalizing undocumented immigrants will create a more-or-less permanent underclass of benefit-sucking, wage-lowering, economy-crippling parasites, with a cost to American taxpayers of  megaphone, please  SIX POINT THREE TRILLION DOLLARS! The report was promptly denounced, not least by reputable conservative economists, for example here and here and here. Then one of the reports co-authors resigned from Heritage after The Washington Post discovered that he had once proposed blocking immigrants with low I.Q. scores. (More on that later.)

title: As TV Ratings and Profits Fall, Networks Face a Cliffhanger
description: As the major television networks prepare to unveil their new fall lineups in New York this week, they face threats from seemingly every corner.

title: What Racial Profiling? Police Testify Complaint Is Rarely Made
description: He had naturally heard the accusations of racial profiling, from civil rights organizations and some politicians. But in more than a decade as the top chief in the New York Police Department, Joseph J. Esposito said he never once heard a private citizen complain about a racially motivated stop-and-frisk encounter.

title: Central Park Group Is Seeking Better Playgrounds
description: The Central Park Conservancy, the nonprofit group that manages Central Park, said it would initiate a $40 million fund-raising campaign on Monday to pay for the restoration and improvement of the parks 21 playgrounds.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Stranger Bearing Gifts
description: Domestic disintegration seems to be taking place in real time in A Family for All Occasions, a grindingly dull new play by Bob Glaudini that opened on Sunday night at the Bank Street Theater in a production directed by Philip Seymour Hoffman.

title: Walters to Announce 2014 Retirement on The View
description: On the program she invented, on the network where she worked for the past 37 years, on the medium where she broke barriers and rules for more than 50 years, Barbara Walters will announce on Monday morning, definitively and with no regrets, that she is calling it a career.

title: Detroits Emergency Manager Offers Dire Report on City
description: DETROIT  An emergency manager assigned to lead this city back from the brink of financial ruin has taken his first detailed look at Detroits woes, and the picture of debt and disarray he paints may be bleaker even than earlier grim portrayals.

title: A Groundbreaking Career
description: Barbara Walters, who announced her retirement Monday, made headlines over more than 50 years with interviews with Fidel Castro, Michael Jackson and others.

title: Newark Archbishop Is Criticized for His Handling of an Abuse Case
description: COLTS NECK, N.J.  With 10 children knelt around the altar for their first communion and the pews at St. Marys Church packed with families gathered for Mothers Day, there was little sign on Sunday of the turmoil that has struck the parish, and threatens the Archdiocese of Newark.

title: When the Pinstripes Get Ruffled
description: The Yankees have long gone by the nickname the Bombers, but they could just as easily be known as the Bronx Bickersons. And this weekends latest version is no exception.

title: Valuable as Art, but Priceless as a Tool to Launder Money
description: According to the air bill slapped on the crate that arrived at Kennedy International Airport from London, an unnamed painting worth $100 was inside. Only later did federal investigators discover that it was by the American artist Jean-Michel Basquiat and worth $8 million.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 13
description: We need to make the border the center, not the end  but the biggest problem we have is not security, it is openness and communication.

title: Game 6: Rangers vs. Capitals
description: Goalie Henrik Lundqvist made 27 saves as the Rangers defeated the Capitals, 1-0, and forced a Game 7 in their first-round playoff series.

title: Photo Replay: May 12
description: The day in sports worldwide, from diving in the United States to kayaking in Hungary.

title: Travel Essentials | Marin County, Calif.
description: In our Summer Travel issue, which hit newsstands on Sunday, Adam Sachs professes his love for Marin County, a place he calls the most beautiful, bucolic, privileged, liberal, hippie-dippie place on the earth. Heres where to eat, sleep and shop in San Franciscos neighbor to the north.

title: Bottled Secrets of the Geisha
description: The San Francisco-based skin care expert Victoria Tsai has built her business by studying the beauty secrets, passed down over generations, of the traditional Japanese entertainers known as geisha. After many trips east and countless hours studying makeup regimens, Tsai founded Tatcha, a line of 95-percent-natural products made and formulated in Japan. One of her first discoveries was aburatorigami, the traditional handmade blotting papers used in ancient Japan to protect gold as it is hammered into delicate gold leaf. Several centuries ago, geisha realized that the papers could also absorb facial oil, without disturbing their signature stage makeup. I tried to do exactly what the geisha were doing, but also make products that are a little bit easier to use, Tsai said. And they use our stuff now.

title: Bloomberg Admits Terminal Snooping
description: Reporters at Bloomberg News were trained to use a function on the companys financial data terminals that allowed them to view subscribers contact information and, in some cases, monitor login activity in order to advance news coverage, more than half a dozen former employees said.

title: The Care and Feeding of Small Business
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: 2 Award-Givers Thumbs Turn Up for Durang
description: Two associations of theater writers and reviewers, the Outer Critics Circle and the New York Drama Critics Circle, have named Christopher Durangs comedy Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike, with David Hyde Pierce, as the best play of the 2012-13 season. They did not agree, though, on best musical: The Outer Critics gave that award to Kinky Boots, and the New York Drama Critics went with Matilda the Musical.

title: How Formula Can Complement Breast-Feeding
description: Good news for new mothers: A study suggests that carefully regulated formula feeding before your milk comes in will not harm your babys ability to breast-feed, and done properly, it may even help in the long run.

description: cabal \k-bl, -bal\ noun

description: It was a wild weekend for Manchester and its two biggest clubs, so maybe a quick recap is in order:

title: Whats on Monday
description: 10P.M. (13) THE INVISIBLE WAR (2012) The Department of Defense estimates that there were 22,800 sexual assaults in the United States military in 2011. Veterans Affairs studies have shown that one-third of women seeking assistance have been sexually assaulted, and that more men than women are assaulted while in service. This Academy Award nominee for best documentary feature, directed by Kirby Dick and produced by Amy Ziering, uses interviews with retired and active service members to investigate the epidemic of rape within the military. (A female soldier in a combat zone is more likely to be attacked by a fellow soldier than killed by enemy fire.) Military service is often a family tradition, and the military itself, with its customs of loyalty, solidarity and shared sacrifice, can be a kind of family for its members, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. This means that the violations chronicled in The Invisible War are compounded by a deep and terrible betrayal, which ripples outward from the various branches of the service into the society as a whole. This is not a movie that can be ignored. (Above Kori Cioca, who served in the Coast Guard, and her husband, Rob.)

title: News Quiz | May 13, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: A Bugs Life in Central Park
description: Dear Diary:

title: From Todays Paper: Hoping to Find Asylum
description: A boat carrying more than 80 people believed to be from Middle Eastern countries was intercepted Sunday near Bali, Indonesia.

title: IHT Quick Read: May 13
description: NEWS Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan began talks on Sunday to form a new government, as partial election returns suggested that he and his party would have a commanding hold on Parliament. But Pakistani election officials said final results would take days as outrage grew over accusations of rampant vote-rigging, particularly in Karachi. Salman Masood reports from Islamabad.

title: Indias Middle Class: Growth Engine or Loose Wheel?
description: They are the bird of gold, the star performers who have led Indias rapid economic ascent of the last two decades.

title: April Growth in China Fails to Impress
description: HONG KONG  Chinese factory activity and retail sales picked up a notch in April, according to data released on Monday. But expansion remained underwhelming, analysts said, reinforcing the conclusion that the once surging Chinese economy is making a long-term transition toward slower growth.

title: Test Yourself | Math, May 13, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the obituary Kenneth I. Appel, Mathematician Who Harnessed Computer Power, Dies at 80.

title: South Koreas Leader Apologizes for Aides Behavior in U.S.
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Park Geun-hye of South Korea struggled on Monday to contain the biggest setback of her three months in office, offering her apology over a scandal in which her main spokesman was accused of sexual abuse and indecent exposure in a Washington hotel during her state visit last week.

title: From Raised on the Land to Engineered in the Lab
description: In Engineering the $325,000 Burger,  Henry Fountain writes about scientists efforts to create meat in the laboratory.

title: Lloyds Chairman to Retire as Bank Landscape Shifts in Europe
description: LONDON  The face of European banking continues to change.

title: Garry Winogrand  Nonstop and Unedited
description: New Yorks photographic community was small enough in the 1970s that you could spot Garry Winogrand and Lee Friedlander patrolling opposite sides of Fifth Avenue on the same day. But it was Garry, with his big presence and personality, whom I saw more often.

title: Should Children Be Allowed to Wear Whatever They Want?
description: Should children have complete control over the clothes they wear, and other aspects of their physical appearance, like hairstyles and makeup?

title: North Korea Names Armed Forces Minister
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea has removed a hard-line general from the post of armed forces minister, filling the job with a little-known three-star general, according to official North Korean news reports on Monday.

title: Advice From a Dean of Admissions on Selecting High School Courses
description: Weve heard it time and again: rigor is one of the most important aspects of a college students application. But how exactly does a student present an awe-inspiring college application  one replete with challenging classes and impressive activities  without compromising his or her performance in those areas?

title: Should Manmohan Singh Resign?
description: NEW DELHI  Manmohan Singh is the third-longest-serving prime minister in Indias history, but his control of the worlds largest democracy is increasingly being questioned.

title: The Early Word: Deeper
description: In Todays Times

title: Behind the Cover Story: Jon Mooallem on Disentangling the Politics of a Hawaiian Murder Mystery
description: Jon Mooallem, contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this weeks cover story about a mysterious rash of monk-seal killings in Hawaii. His new book, Wild Ones: A Sometimes Dismaying, Weirdly Reassuring Story About Looking at People Looking at Animals in America, comes out this week.

title: Taking the Russian Police for a Ride
description: MOSCOW  I will take part in almost any activity that involves bicycling, so when I saw that someone was organizing a protest ride in Moscow, I knew I would go even though its purpose and logistics were not entirely clear.

title: Daily Report: New Wave of Cyberattacks Against U.S. Corporations
description: A new wave of cyberattacks is striking American corporations, prompting warnings from federal officials, including a vague one issued last week by the Department of Homeland Security. This time, officials say, the attackers aim is not espionage but sabotage, and the source seems to be somewhere in the Middle East, David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth report in The New York Times on Monday.

title: Elan in Deal on Drug Royalties
description: LONDON  Elan, an Irish drug maker that is the target of a hostile takeover, said on Monday that it had agreed to buy a share of royalties on new drugs from Theravance of the United States for $1 billion.

title: A Look Back at Reporting on Tailhook
description: Eric Schmitt, national security correspondent, recounts how he followed the Navys sexual assault scandal from its beginnings through the revelations of sexual inequality across the armed forces.

title: Is Canadas Oil Too Dirty for Europe?
description: As the debate over the construction of the Keystone XL pipeline continues in the United States, a Canadian trade delegation is insisting that Canadian oil extracted from tar sands  the product that would be transported by an expanded pipeline  should not be classified as being dirtier than other types of oil.

title: The Legacy of Tailhook
description: Retro Report: Military sexual assault is not a new phenomenon. A second look at the Tailhook scandal in 1991 reveals what happened then. And what it all means now.

title: Revisiting the Militarys Tailhook Scandal
description: In 1992, a young Navy lieutenant named Paula Coughlin said she had been sexually assaulted at the 35th Annual Tailhook Symposium in Las Vegas.

description: Updated: May 14, 2013

description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.
