description: Q.

title: British Life Insurer Plans to Go Public
description: LONDON  The Partnership Assurance Group, a British life insurance company, announced plans on Monday for an initial public offering that could value the company at $1.5 billion.

title: As British Prime Minister Visits Washington, His Party Splits Over European Union
description: LONDON  His visit to the White House overshadowed by toxic divisions at home over Europe, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain won the support of President Obama on Monday in seeking to calm a clamor within the Conservative Party for further and faster moves toward an exit from the European Union.

title: A Few More Ways to Enjoy the Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The Super Bowl of horse racing, the Kentucky Derby, is the longest continuously held sporting event in the United States. It was first run in 1875, and it truly is a spectacle to behold. More than a week removed from the festivities, Ive had time to reflect on this years experience.

title: Many Happy Returns
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Defying threats from Taliban suicide bombers, almost 60 percent of registered voters in Pakistan headed to the polls on Saturday. It was the greatest turnout since 1970.

title: JPMorgans Lead Director in Focus
description: The shareholder vote at JPMorgan Chase on splitting Jamie Dimons roles of chairman and chief executive could hinge on whether Lee R. Raymond, the lead director, is seen as strong enough to stand up to Mr. Dimon, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Susanne Craig report in DealBook.

title: Fox Looks to Shore Up Comedy Lineup on Tuesdays
description: The Fox network unveiled a prime-time schedule on Monday that includes sweeping changes and  like the schedules expected from its network competitors  a copious injection of new programming.

title: Before It Built the Enclave, Buick Built Tanks
description: Tank is a word sometimes used, both affectionately and otherwise, to describe the massive and sturdy Buick vehicles of the mid-1950s. Powered by V-8 engines and built with liberal amounts of steel and cast iron, those Buicks handily earned the name. But just a decade earlier, Buick built a real tank: the M18 Hellcat tank destroyer that helped Allied forces defeat the Axis powers in both Europe and the Pacific.

title: China Warns Officials Against Dangerous Western Values
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese Communist Party has warned officials to combat dangerous Western values and other perceived ideological threats, in a directive that analysts said on Monday reflected the determination of Chinas leader to preserve top-down political control even as he considers economic liberalization.

title: Monday Reading: Parents Seek Mates for Their Children on Dating Sites
Dell Demands More Details From Icahn and Southeastern
description: The special committee of Dells board overseeing the sale of the computer maker asked Carl C. Icahn and Southeastern Asset Management on Monday to furnish more information about their recent demand for a special dividend.

title: Pakistani Leader Moves Quickly to Form Government
description: LONDON  Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif moved confidently to form a new government in Pakistan on Monday, signaling his choice to be the next finance minister even as votes from Saturdays election were still being tallied and protests continued over alleged vote-rigging in some cities.

title: Mad Men Recap: The Woman in Room 503
description: Season 6, Episode 6

title: In the Family: Heart Disease
description: How can a former Ironman triathlete get heart disease? For Rick Del Sontro and most of his family, theres no escape. Its a genetic defect that has plagued generation after generation.

title: After DVD Shipping Error, BBC Asks Fans Not to Spoil Doctor Who Finale
description: Ah, if only the BBC had some sort of device  possibly one thats bigger on the inside than it appears from outside  that would allow it to traverse time and space so it could prevent a few lucky viewers from getting their hands on the season finale of Doctor Who ahead of schedule. But it does not, and instead the broadcaster can only plead with those audience members not to reveal the details of that episode before it is shown on Saturday, and thus not risk shattering the fabric of the science-fiction fan community.

title: Major Retailers Join Bangladesh Safety Plan
description: Three weeks after a building collapse in Bangladesh that killed more than 1,100 workers, several of the worlds largest apparel companies  including the retailing giant H&M and Inditex, owner of the Zara chain  agreed on Monday to sign a far-reaching and legally binding plan that requires retailers to help finance fire safety and building improvements in the factories they use in Bangladesh.

title: N.H.T.S.A. Investigates Ford Super Duty Steering Loss
description: Citing a concern over possible steering loss, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether about 340,000 2008 F-250 and F-350 Super Duty pickup trucks should be recalled. According to a report posted over the weekend on the safety agencys Web site, it has received five complaints about an internal failure of the steering gear box resulting in a complete loss of steering control.

title: Mike Keenan Will Coach in K.H.L.
description: Mike Keenan, who coached the Rangers to the Stanley Cup in 1994 as part of a long and controversial N.H.L. coaching career, has signed as coach of Metallurg Magnitogorsk on the K.H.L.

title: Which Textbook Is That, Exactly?
description: OK, on the road, and a quick post over coffee.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Guardian: Yotam Ottolenghi helps you figure out how to cook with sorrel.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Weekend Gun Report: May 10-12, 2013
description: As our report today grimly documents, the Mothers Day weekend offered no reprieve from gun violence. Rebecca Bond, a mother of three and the co-founder, with her husband Jon, of Evolve, a group attempting to change the culture around gun safety and gun violence, wrote this piece over the weekend about how a mothers fierce love for her children might be the best tool we have to reduce the horrifying number of senseless killings in America. It is well worth reading.

title: Tough Times at Homeland Security
description: A new wave of cyberattacks is hitting American companies at a particularly vulnerable time for the Department of Homeland Security, the federal agency charged with fending them off.

title: Performance at De Blasio Fund-Raiser
description: Bridget Everette, an actress, danced on stage with Bill de Blasio at a fund-raiser on Sunday night.

title: What Will Go Unsaid at the Upfronts
description: The Timess Brian Stelter offers a preview of televisions upfronts, highlighting what network broadcasters will leave unspoken.

title: A Second Chance for Sea Lions
description: A video from 2013 when an an epidemic of starvation struck Southern Californias baby sea lions. Some animals had died, but the Pacific Marine Mammal Center was nursing many of them back to health.

title: After Vote in Pakistan, Some Hope in India
description: NEW DELHI  The bitter and sometimes violent rivalry between India and Pakistan shows no signs of abating, but many in New Delhi greeted Sundays election results in Pakistan with measured optimism on Monday.

title: At a Racy Fund-Raiser for de Blasio, the Target Is Quinn
description: An ample-bodied drag queen (stage name: Flotilla DeBarge) declared that just because its gay doesnt mean it thinks our way.

title: Focaccia: One Basic Bread, Endless Delicious Options
description: A couple of weeks ago I gave you a recipe for a walnut fougasse, or focaccia. The bread was so easy to make, and such a great vehicle for the walnuts, that I got onto a focaccia kick and started making it just about every day, topping it with vegetables and sometimes filling it with them. I tried different proportions of whole-wheat and all-purpose flour, never using less than half whole-wheat, and found that the same overall recipe worked no matter how I varied the proportions. Im working with a terrific whole-wheat flour produced in California, available online and now carried by Fairway, called Community Grains. But I also made the focaccia with King Arthur white whole-wheat flour (I used 100 percent in that version; the result had a slightly denser, tighter texture than the other focacce).

title: Overtimes, Game 7s and Dj Vu in the N.H.L.
description: Apparently, the remedy for everything wrong in the N.H.L. is a Game 7. Its as if the league went to a doctor  O.K., a faith healer, because hockeys gatekeepers are not keen on all that actual medical information  and said: We had this shameless money grab of a lockout, our players keep trying to take one anothers heads off even though weve mildly suggested they stop, our tickets are astronomically expensive and casual sports fans have to keep being reminded we exist. So what do we do?

title: In Soccer and Investing, Bias Is Toward Action
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at The BAM Alliance. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published this year. His sketches are archivedon the Bucks blog.

title: Really? Never Go Grocery Shopping on an Empty Stomach
description: THE FACTS:

title: Triple Play: Week 6 Results
description: Three of the players in Question No. 1 greeted May with hot streaks, collecting hits in every game they played last week. Adam LaRoche was the correct answer, going 8 for 19 for a .421 average.

title: Building Condos by the Numbers, Skipping Some Along the Way
description: Belvedere LXX is a brand-new condominium on Eckford Street in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, built of burgundy brick. It is so new that its permits still hang in the window, the closets are bare of clothes, and the apartments have yet to hit the market.

title: I Was Groped on the Subway
description: I was late as usual, weaving through the 72nd Street subway station, rushing down the stairs to catch a departing train, and managed to squeeze into one of the packed cars just in time. It was Friday, a few weeks after my 29th birthday. I was on my way downtown to my job at my familys taxi business, casually dressed in leggings and a striped orange dress. I pushed my still wet hair out of my face and found a sliver of space to stand. As the doors were closing, one more person shoved his way in and the car let out a collective groan.

title: YogaFit Tries to Escape the Discount Trap
description: At the last She Owns It business group meeting, Beth Shaw, who owns YogaFit, started the discussion by sharing some painful lessons she has learned from discounting her companys yoga teacher training.

title: Global Retailers Join Safety Plan for Bangladesh
description: Under mounting pressure to improve working conditions in Bangladeshs garment factories, several of the worlds largest apparel companies agreed on Monday to a landmark plan to help pay for fire safety and building improvements after the collapse last month of the Rana Plaza factory complex, which killed more than 1,100 people.

title: Supreme Court Supports Monsanto in Seed-Replication Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court ruled unanimously on Monday that farmers could not use Monsantos patented genetically altered soybeans to create new seeds without paying the company a fee.

title: The Birth of the Stainless Banner
description: On May 1, 1863, the Confederate Congress approved a new national flag  colloquially dubbed the Stainless Banner  to replace the so-called Stars and Bars, the Confederacys national flag since March 1861. The new flag was a plain white field emblazoned with what was already a powerful and famous Confederate symbol, the Southern Cross, the star-bedecked blue saltire, or diagonal cross, that had been a famous battle flag since the fall of 1861. Its incorporation into the national flag confirmed the Southern Cross as the de facto symbol of Confederate nationalism.

title: Street Style: Overalls
description: The best of readers photos from the week of May 6.

title: Test Tube Burger, A Lucky Stroke, Coming of the Cicadas
description: Can you get the burger without the cow? A clot in Andrew Revkins brain pushes him to learn about strokes  from his hospital bed. The (insect) buzz around Carl Zimmers new column.

title: As Chinas Economy Stumbles, Government Eyes Reform
description: Another week, another set of weak economic data out of China. Fixed-asset investment slowed and industrial production grew less than projected. And while retail sales growth met expectations, it was driven almost entirely by a 72.2 percent increase in jewelry purchases, apparently by consumers taking advantage of the drop in gold prices.

title: Triangle Mysteries
description: This weeks puzzle is based on a beautiful discovery by Steve Humble, who teaches primary and second school trainee teachers in the education department at Newcastle University in northeastern England. The conundrum is based on Mr. Humbles research that appears in the current issue of The Mathematical Intelligencer.

title: New Amtrak Engines Unveiled for Northeast
description: WASHINGTON  Amtrak rolled out three new locomotives on Monday, the first step in the railroads plan to modernize its aging fleet of trains.

title: An iPhone Jury-Rigged as a Microscope
description: By sticking a little $8 lens to an iPhone with a piece of double-sided tape, a Canadian doctor has produced a microscope that works reasonably well at diagnosing intestinal worms in children.

title: The Bruins Make an Unhappy Trip to Game 7
description: TORONTO  Not only did Toronto become the 48th team to rally from down 3-1 in a playoff series to force a Game 7 with its 2-1 victory over Boston Sunday, the Bruins were stuck in Toronto overnight, forcing the team to travel home Monday morning for Monday nights game in Boston.

title: Science Bookshelf
description: 1 BRAIN ON FIRE by Susannah Cahalan. Simon & Schuster. A medical mystery in which doctors struggle to discover why a young reporter suddenly experiences seizures, hallucinations and eventually near catatonia.

title: Astronaut Covers Space Oddity From Space
description: The Canadian astronaut Chris Hadfield, who has documented his five months in charge of the International Space Station in great detail in Twitter photographs and YouTube videos, celebrated his last day aboard the craft by releasing an elaborately produced cover version of David Bowies Space Oddity.

title: President Obama on I.R.S. Scrutiny
description: Speaking at a news conference at the White House on Monday, President Obama addressed the topic of the I.R.S. targeting and auditing of conservative groups applying for tax-exempt status.

title: Cuccinellis Dj Vu Tax Plan
description: Ken Cuccinelli, the Republican candidate for governor of Virginia and current state attorney general, has been running a classically aggressive, Nobama sort of campaign. In his book, The Last Line of Defense, he calls the Obama administration the biggest set of lawbreakers in America, and the E.P.A. an agency of mass destruction. He is perhaps most notorious for trying to reinstate Virginias Crimes Against Nature law, which made both oral and anal sex a felony.

title: Cyprus Gets First Installment of Bailout Funds
description: PARIS  After striking an unprecedented deal in March to make many bank depositors help pay for an international bailout, Cyprus on Monday received 2 billion, the first installment of that money, aimed at buttressing the economy after the near-collapse of its banking sector.

title: New Plan to Auction Banksy Mural Rekindles Battle
description: For a work scarcely a year old, Slave Labor (Bunting Boy), by the British graffiti artist Banksy, has been at the center of more than its share of battles, and a new one has broken out with the Sincura Group announcing that it will auction the mural at the London Film Museum on June 2.

title: Hearing of Moths Surpasses All Others
description: Dont say anything that you wouldnt want the greater wax moth to hear. Researchers from the University of Strathclyde in Glasgow, Scotland, reported that the moth has the worlds most extreme hearing.

title: President Obama on Benghazi
description: At a news conference at the White House on Monday, President Obama answered questions about his administrations handling of the deadly terrorist attack in Benghazi, Libya, on Sept. 11, 2012.

title: Obama Dismisses Benghazi Furor but Assails I.R.S.
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, facing re-energized Republican adversaries and new questions about the administrations conduct, on Monday dismissed a furor over the handling of last years attacks in Benghazi, Libya, as a political sideshow but joined a bipartisan chorus of outrage over disclosures that the Internal Revenue Service had singled out conservative groups for special scrutiny.

title: Landlords Double as Energy Brokers
description: The trophy high-rises on Madison, Park and Fifth Avenues in Manhattan have long commanded the top prices in the country for commercial real estate, with yearly leases approaching $150 a square foot. So it is quite a Gotham-size comedown that businesses are now paying rents four times that in low, bland buildings across the Hudson River in New Jersey.

title: After an Artist Steps Away From His Bag, a Summons and a Legal Battle
description: Enrico Miguel Thomas, 42, an artist who has been drawing subway stations for years, arrived at Grand Central Terminal one night in February, plopped down his bags and began drawing.

title: Readers Are Bothered by I.R.S. Coverage, an Amanda Knox Feature, and Too-Thin Models
description: Heres the Monday roundup:

title: Cleveland: Disappointing Fans Since 64
description: CLEVELAND  As a Cleveland sports fan, I hold these truths to be self-evident: no matter how promising the plan or how high the draft pick, someone will screw it up.

title: Monday Motorsports: Alonso Brings Formula One Victory to Spain
description: Fernando Alonso, driving for Ferrari, deftly executed a four-stop pit stop strategy that yielded an emotional victory Sunday in the Grand Prix of Spain. Kimi Raikkonen of Lotus finished a distant second, followed by Alonsos teammate Felipe Massa.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Maaco Puts Uh-Oh in the Rearview Mirror
description: A chain that spruces up customers cars is trying to spruce up its own image.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Julie Atherton joined the New York office of SapientNitro as vice president for strategy. She succeeds Steve Zaroff, who is now the chief strategy officer at McCann Erickson New York. Ms. Atherton had been a global digital director on Team Colgate, the WPP unit that is devoted to the Colgate-Palmolive account. McCann Erickson New York is part of the McCann Erickson Worldwide division of the McCann Worldgroup, which is owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: In Afghanistan, Taliban Release 4 of 8 Turks in an Image Offensive
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Even with their spring offensive under way, the Taliban seemed bent on showing their softer side on Monday.

title: Capitals Cry Foul on Dorsett Play in Game 6
description: WASHINGTON  What would a Game 7 be without a little controversy?

title: Fill-In | The Hidden World Under Our Feet
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first 10 paragraphs of the article The Hidden World Under Our Feet by Jim Robbins.

title: Ex-Hedge Fund Manager Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
description: During the sentencing of the former hedge fund manager Anthony Chiasson on Monday, Judge Richard J. Sullivan marveled at his prodigious wealth, ticking off the annual income listed on his tax returns. $16 million, $10 million, $23 million, he said.

title: A Focus on Syria for Obama and Cameron
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said on Monday that it was urgent to bring the fighting in Syria to an end. But Mr. Obama portrayed the diplomatic effort to stem the bloodshed as an uphill struggle that might well fail.

title: Upfronts 2013: NBC
description: The Times's Bill Carter discusses NBC's programming, after the broadcaster unveiled its plans to advertisers.

title: A Change in Temperature
description: Since 1896, scientists have been trying to answer a deceptively simple question: What will happen to the temperature of the earth if the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere doubles?

title: As European Acquisition Struggles, Tata Takes $1.6 Billion Write-Down
description: Tata Steel, Indias largest steel producer, said on Monday that it would take a $1.6 billion write-down, citing the weaker macroeconomic and market environment in Europe.

title: An S.E.C. Settlement That Seems to Favor Falcone
description: There is an adage that a good legal settlement is one in which no one leaves the courtroom happy. That appears to be the case if the terms of the tentative agreement between the hedge fund manager Philip A. Falcone and the Securities and Exchange Commission to resolve civil fraud charges are approved.

title: Walkabout  5/13: Fitzgerald Grave Site Attracts Fans; Small Airports Suffer
description: Paying Respects With the premiere of Baz Luhrmanns film adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgeralds The Great Gatsby, more and more fans have been visiting the writers grave site in Rockville, Md. (Washington Post)

title: An Artwork Turns to Mush, All According to Plan
description: In December 2006 James Grashow, a sculptor and illustrator, went to Purchase, N.Y., to visit the family of Allan Stone, the art dealer who had recently died after representing him for four decades.

title: Money on the Bench
description: How much money Major League baseball teams are paying to players on the disabled list. Updated daily.

title: A Social Security Site for Smartphone Users
description: The Social Security Administration is now offering a version of its Web site that is designed specifically for smartphones.

title: Shaking Off Loneliness
description: I now know why I gained more than 30 pounds in my early 20s: I was lonely. I had left my beloved alma mater upstate for graduate school and a job in the Upper Midwest. I knew no one and felt like a fish out of water.

title: Hard Cases: The Traps of Treating Pain
description: I hadnt seen Larry in a dozen years when he reappeared in my office a few months ago, grinning. We were both grinning. I always liked Larry, even though he was a bit of a hustler, a little erratic in his appointments, a persistent dabbler in a variety of illegal substances. But he was always careful to avoid the hard stuff; he said he had a bad problem as a teenager and was going to stay out of trouble.

title: Ginsburgs Roe v. Wade Blind Spot
description: During a public conversation at the University of Chicago Law School on Saturday, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg yet again expressed her well-known misgivings about Roe v. Wadethat the Supreme Court went too far, too fast.

title: Geno Smith, Tim Tebow, Victor Cruz: Answers to Readers Questions
description: Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, answers questions from readers.

title: Indians and the Yankees Take Turns Throwing Shutouts at Each Other
description: CLEVELAND  Just before Vidal Nuno spoke to reporters after his first major league win, Lou Cucuzza, the Yankees clubhouse manager, handed him the lineup card from the game, an honor bestowed upon players when they reach notable achievements.

title: A Tale of Two Coffee Shops
description: Inside the newest outposts of Stumptown Coffee Roasters and Intelligentsia Coffee.

title: Want Coffee Brewed Your Way? Be Specific
description: When Starbucks installed its first espresso bar in downtown Seattle, in 1984, it effectively reordered the hierarchy of coffee in this country: brewed coffee might be nice, but nothing beats the theater of a latte.

title: Philadelphia Abortion Doctor Guilty of Murder in Late-Term Procedures
description: PHILADELPHIA  A doctor who was responsible for cutting the spines of babies after botched abortions was convicted Monday of three counts of first-degree murder in a case that became a sharp rallying cry for anti-abortion activists.

title: Family Ghosts, Kept at Bay
description: Incest, alcoholism, robbery, gunfire, murder, sensational court trials  these are among the building blocks of the dysfunctional-family memoir, and in She Left Me the Gun Emma Brockes puts a check mark next to each.

title: In Performance: Leslie Kritzer
description: Leslie Kritzer, accompanied by Katherine Cherbas on cello, sings Me and My Mother from The Memory Show, a musical about the tensions of caring for someone with Alzheimers disease.

title: Image of the Day: May 13
Sales Tax Talk and Reality
description: The nations brick-and-mortar retailers are promoting the Marketplace Fairness Act, which would force Internet retailers to collect sales taxes based on where the product was being shipped. It passed the Senate last week, but may have more trouble in the House.

title: Preserve24, Where Food, Exploration and Fantasy Meet
description: Starter, an occasional column, takes a look at newly opened restaurants.

title: We Embrace Our Heartaches
description: Scenes from Cleveland, which has not had a professional sports championship of any kind since the Browns N.F.L. title in 1964, before the first Super Bowl.

title: Farm-to-Hotel Dining
description: For years, most hotel restaurants could easily be dismissed as unremarkable and unsurprising, their menus seemingly unchanged from year to year. But lately, they have been following the lead of upscale restaurants and offering ingredients grown or produced nearby.

title: European Leaders Grapple With Youth Unemployment
description: FRANKFURT  Record youth unemployment is emerging as the most urgent problem in the euro zone, if the political rhetoric of recent days is any measure. But leaders are struggling to come up with effective ways to prevent jobless young people in countries like Spain and Greece from becoming a lost generation and source of social upheaval.

title: Googles Developer Conference to Be Light on New Products
description: In the past few years, Googles annual developers conference has grown from being an insiders event for software geeks to one in which big announcements about new hardware like Google Glass are made.But this year the conference, which starts Wednesday, will not have much to show in terms of new products, according to a company executive.

title: Fewer Rain Forests Mean Less Energy for Developing Nations, Study Finds
description: The loss of tropical rain forests is likely to reduce the energy output of hydroelectric projects in countries like Brazil that are investing billions of dollars to create power to support economic growth.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Restaurants and seafood businesses are participating in what they are calling sustainable seafood week, with menu specials and demonstrations. The opening event is Monday from 6:30 to 9:30 p.m. at Riverpark, 450 East 29th Street in Kips Bay. Tickets are $70. The Web site has the latest schedule of events, which run through Sunday.

title: Signals of a Stroke
description: The Timess Andrew C. Revkin speaks about his experience of having a stroke, as well as warning signs to watch out for.

title: Enough to Curl Your Hair
description: Q. How far are we from a medication that could change the shape of the hair follicle and therefore the texture of the hair?

title: Test Tube Burger
description: The Times's Henry Fountain reports on one researcher's quest to show the world that meat doesn't have to come from the farm.

title: My Typical Day in Sweden
description: And after a time you may recognize that the proper measure of success is not how much youve closed the distance to some far-off goal but the quality of what youve done today.  U.S. Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor

title: Success of Iron Man 3 Hasnt Reduced Tension Over U.S. Films in China
description: LOS ANGELES  Ticket sales for Iron Man 3 are still piling up at the Chinese box office. By Sunday night, the film was approaching the $100 million mark there. But that success hasnt resolved a building tension over American films at the Chinese box office.

title: A Trudge to the Roots of Autism
description: Much of autisms mystery and fascination lies in a paradox: On one hand, autism seems to create a profound disconnect between inner and outer lives; on the other, it generates what the neuroscientist Oliver Sacks calls an essential and most intricate interaction between the disorder and ones other traits.

title: The Commercial Side of Fast Wi-Fi on Flights
description: I WOULD last maybe one shift as a flight attendant. By the end of that initial flight, I would be so demonstrably miserable over the demands of the job that theyd fire me, assuming I didnt beat them to the punch by pulling a Slater.

title: Q&A: New Speeds for Old Machines
Book Covers: Before and After
description: Designers discuss their work on recent book covers.

title: Taking Jobs Versus Growing Jobs
description: In a blog post on Monday for our colleagues at Economix, Nancy Folbre talks about economic development and the comparative advantages for states that hunt for existing jobs and those that garden for new jobs. An economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, Ms. Folbre writes:

title: Prosecution Rests in Sex Case Against Berlusconi
description: MILAN  The prosecution of former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on charges of paying for sex with an under-age prostitute and then abusing his powers to cover it up concluded on Monday with a call for a six-year jail sentence and a lifetime ban from public office.

title: Big Retailers Quit Stalling on Factory Safety
description: After much delay and many excuses, several western retailers and brands on Monday agreed to a plan that should help improve building safety in the garment factories of Bangladesh. The announcement, which came nearly three weeks after the collapse of the Rana Plaza factory building killed more than 1,100 people, is significant because it includes big companies such as H&M, which is the largest buyer of clothing from Bangladesh, and Inditex, the worlds largest fashion retailer whose brands include Zara and Massimo Dutti.

title: Richards Has Game 7 Experience, But Has Not Earned the Minutes
description: WASHINGTON  Brad Richards has more Game 7 experience, and more Game 7 success, than anyone else on Coach John Tortorellas Rangers roster. But dont expect to see much of him on the ice at the Verizon Center when the Rangers and Washington Capitals play the deciding game of their opening-round series Monday night.

title: Forging Its Own Path, British Hedge Fund Finds Success
description: Ewan M. Kirk never quite fit the Wall Street mold.

title: Lamborghini Surprises Its 50th Anniversary Faithful With a New Concept
description: BOLOGNA, Italy  Lamborghini surprised participants in its 50th anniversary Grande Giro celebration Saturday with a bizarre concept car.

title: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Turkey, Bangladesh, Pakistan and Somalia.

title: Talking Talent | Sarah Polley
description: For her latest film, the Canadian writer, director and actress Sarah Polley turned to her own life. Stories We Tell, her first documentary, examines her familys secrets and mythology  including the question of Polleys own true parentage  in the wake of her mothers death from cancer when Polley, now 34, was 11. The documentary, which took her five years to complete, has already kindled Oscar talk for the director, who received an Adapted Screenplay nomination in 2008 for her first film, Away From Her. Poignant and moving, Stories We Tell confirms that Polley is as good behind the camera as she is on screen.

title: A Little Improvisation Punctuates the Mundane
description: If the words audience participation make you queasy, then Everyone Was Chanting Your Name probably isnt for you. The lights are up at the Abrons Arts Center, and the rectangular seating arrangement is small enough to mean that everyone has a front-row seat: theres nowhere to hide in this latest production by the rising young theater company 600 Highwaymen.

title: Upgrades on Schedule for Gowanus Canal Pumping Station Despite Hurricane
description: As Hurricane Sandy swept across the Gowanus Canal last year, a pumping station that redirects sewage to a pollution-control plant was damaged and went offline for almost 33 hours, according to a report released by the city after the storm. About 13 million gallons of raw sewage flowed into the canal before the city installed a generator that restored power to the station.

title: Mental Evaluations Endorse Insanity Plea in Colorado Shootings, Defense Says
description: CENTENNIAL, Colo.  Mental health experts who evaluated the man accused of killing 12 people in a Colorado movie theater last year have offered a diagnosis that bolsters an insanity plea in the case, his lawyers said at a hearing here on Monday.

title: How to Take a Break From Your Technology
description: Hello, my name is Nick, and this is my first time at Technologists Anonymous.Im addicted to my gadgets.

title: Poverty as a Childhood Disease
description: Poverty is an exam room familiar. From Bellevue Hospital in New York to the neighborhood health center in Boston where I used to work, poverty has filtered through many of my interactions with parents and their children.

title: Groups Call for Deportation Suspension for Immigrants Affected by Overhaul
description: Labor, Latino and immigrant advocate groups called on President Obama on Monday to suspend deportations of illegal immigrants who could be eligible for a pathway to citizenship under a bipartisan bill to overhaul the immigration system that is under consideration in the Senate.

title: Doctors Lucrative Industry Ties
description: Dr. Alfred J. Tria is the chief of orthopedic surgery at St. Peters University Hospital, a 478-bed facility in New Brunswick, N.J., and to the medical technology company Smith & Nephew, his good word is worth a million bucks. Well, $940,857, to be precise.

title: My Stroke of Luck
description: Twenty-two months ago, I interrupted my nonstop reporting about paths toward a sustainable future for our species to focus on sustaining myself. The hiatus was not by choice, but wasmandated by a stroke  the out-of-the-blue variant, the rare kind of brain attack (the term preferred by some neurologists) that is most often seen in otherwise healthy, youngish middle-aged people.

title: Boy Toys Yearning to Be Free
description: You know youre in a bad way when youre having imaginary conversations with Gloria Estefan.

title: The Envelope Please: Chandler Buckingham
description: This week, Chandler Buckingham, a student at Rogers High School in Rogers, Ark., will be the third person in her family to graduate from high school. She is headed to John Brown University this fall.

title: More on a Sensitive Climate Question
description: June 18, 5:24 p.m. | Updated |Justin Gilliss latest By Degrees report is focused on the recent flurry of findings and discussion related to one of the most important and enduring questions in climate science: How much warming will result from a given buildup of heat-trapping greenhouse gases?

title: A Guilty Verdict in the Gosnell Trial
description: The Times's Erik Eckholm on the implications for the abortion debate after a West Philadelphia doctor known for performing late-term abortions was found guilty of three counts of first-degree murder.

title: Walking 20 Miles for a (Canceled) Flight to Antarctica
description: I DONT mind business travel at all. Ive got it pretty much down to a science.

title: Minnesota Senate Clears Way for Same-Sex Marriage
description: ST. PAUL  Gay couples will be permitted to wed in Minnesota starting in August, making it the 12th state to permit same-sex marriage and the first in the Midwest to take such a step outside of a court ruling.

title: My Lucky Stroke
description: Twenty two months ago, I interrupted my nonstop journalistic pursuit of paths toward sustainable human progress to focus on sustaining myself. The hiatus was not by choice, but was mandated by a stroke  the out-of-the-blue variant, the rare kind of brain attack (the term preferred by some neurologists) that is most often seen in otherwise healthy, youngish middle-aged people.

title: A Paternal Pull, Found Unexpectedly in Uganda
description: Here is the kind of life that Johnny OCallaghan used to lead. When he broke up with his boyfriend (he came home to find him having sex with twins) he rushed to Chateau Marmont to get drunk, slept with an actress (whose work I dont respect) and woke up to find a Post-it that said, Gone to Pilates. End of relationship.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Spy Drone and Revenge Pornography
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Peter Pan Creators Feminist Vision
description: A woman needs a man like a fish needs a bicycle.

title: Transcendent, Populist and American All Over
description: Cowboys, horses, disaffected teenagers snapping fingers, pedestrian traffic  the three ballets danced by New York City Ballet at the David H. Koch Theater on Friday included images of all those. The music was all American, for the ballet companys American Music Festival, and it all had populist appeal. George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins knew how to exploit that appeal choreographically while remaining themselves.

title: Letting Go of Whimsy in Favor of Feeling
description: Heres a traditional sitcom setup: A new person is introduced into a circle that has established relationships and routines, and high jinks ensue. Everyone regards the contagion funnily, moves around him or her to avoid confrontation, and professes not to understand the mannerisms of the intruder, which dont neatly align with How Things Have Always Been Done. Eventually, of course, things line up  sweet, sweet resolution.

title: The Sacred and the Secular, Both Extolling Love
description: The distinguished, ever-curious vocal quartet Anonymous 4, which recently performed the premiere of David Langs love fail, returned on Sunday afternoon to the early music that is the core of its reputation.

title: Revival of 24 Is More Like 12
description: Everythings quicker these days. Even 24.

title: Shes 88, and Swings From Saucy to Somber
description: One of the many reasons Barbara Carroll has been called the first lady of jazz piano is her quietly expressive breadth. At Birdland on Saturday evening, Ms. Carroll, who is 88 but exudes the spirit and enthusiasm of a very sophisticated teenager, played a set whose moods ran from playful to reflective to a light stomp, sometimes all in the same song. Ms. Carroll has always had special simpatico with the rarefied wit of Cy Coleman and Carolyn Leigh. Singing and playing the obscure I Wanna Be Yours, she evoked the golden age of screwball comedy with the sly, teasing innuendo of lines like, I wanna be all the cream in your dairy/your favorite tooth fairy.

title: Detroit Stands Up for Ives, and Stands In for Oregon
description: Spring for Music  the annual festival of North American orchestras at Carnegie Hall, created in the main to foster imaginative and ambitious programming  did itself proud over the weekend in the last three concerts of its third season. Leonard Slatkin conducted the Detroit Symphony Orchestra on Thursday and Friday, and Christoph Eschenbach led the National Symphony Orchestra on Saturday.

title: I.R.S. Targeting of Conservative Groups Could Resonate in 2014
description: My rule of thumb is that a vast majority of alleged political scandals will have less electoral impact than the conventional wisdom initially holds.

title: Setting Off Political and Pianistic Fireworks
description: The rhythmic chant The people united will never be defeated! has become so ubiquitous at protests worldwide that it is hard to imagine that there was a time when it was actually composed.

title: New Albums by Demi Lovato and Talib Kweli
description: DEMI LOVATO

title: Congresss Role in the I.R.S. Focus on Conservative Groups
description: Outrage continues to escalate over the revelation that Internal Revenue Service employees focused on conservative groups applying for tax-exempt status. The indignation is understandable: political targeting is an abuse of power, and the idea of using the I.R.S. to go after ones enemies is a classic dirty trick. Unfortunately, the incident provides a new fuel source for the paranoid style in American politics.

title: Notes on Southern Livings Fried Chicken
description: So, dear readers, how have you fared so far with this months Recipe Lab assignment? One home cook, Erin P. of Brooklyn, N.Y., said her attempt at the featured recipe, by Norman King, a food editor at Southern Living, resulted in the best fried chicken she had ever made on her own. Does this ring true for you?

title: No Rain on Me
description: As a photographer, I would normally avoid using my camera in the middle of a downpour. But yesterday, at the opening of EXPO 1, a show at MoMA devoted to ecological issues, I photographed people inside the rain, and not a drop of water fell on my equipment.

title: Grind of Euro Crisis Wears Down Support for Union, Poll Finds
description: BRUSSELS  Europeans have never been wild about the European Union. With the region sapped by the euro crisis, confidence in the institution and the benefits it was supposed to provide is flagging faster and further than ever before, according to an influential opinion survey released Monday.

title: Patrick Demarcheliers Bodies of Desire
description: The French photographer Patrick Demarchelier famously started out taking passport pictures as a teenager, and ever since then hes been creating images that take people to unfamiliar places. Now 69, he is internationally renowned for his portraits of supermodels, princesses and celebrities for publications like Vogue, Harpers Bazaar, Elle and Vanity Fair. Since his career took off in the 1970s, he has had an outsize influence on the way artists portray fashion and stardom. Desire, a new exhibition of his black-and-white photographs opening tomorrow in Paris, is a testament to Demarcheliers ability to capture the female body. The 20 images include Laetitia Casta, stretching her naked ribcage taut; Helena Christensen, crouching and eyeing the camera with a panther stare; and Kate Moss and Carla Bruni, sitting together like interlocking puzzle pieces. Every contour suggests both purity and provocation, speaking to the very essence of desire.

title: Car Bomb Kills at Least 4 in Libya
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  A car explosion on a busy street killed at least four people and injured more than a dozen on Monday, stirring new anger at the failure of the transitional government to fill the security vacuum left by the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Basking in a Fonder Farewell, 19 Years Later
description: THESSALONIKI, Greece  No one noticed when Nick Galis, a former Seton Hall guard, left the Boston Celtics after attending their training camp in 1979 as a fourth-round N.B.A. pick with another newcomer, Larry Bird.

title: New Musicals Continue Broadway Box Office Streak
description: Three new musicals that will be vying for Tony Awards next month continue to be big draws at the Broadway box office. Last week, Kinky Boots, which received 13 Tony nominations  more than any other production  was the top show among the new musicals of the 2012-13 season, grossing $1,250,718.

title: Hedge Fund Rejects Proposal by Hess to End Proxy Fight
description: 8:22 p.m. | Updated The Hess Corporation on Monday offered a concession to an activist investor after the investors board nominees waived their rights to a contentious compensation plan.

title: Examining Pakistans Election
description: Declan Walsh, the Pakistan correspondent of The New York Times who was expelled from the country, reports on the results of the recent election and his personal experience.

title: Nepotism in Bavarian Politics Creates a Scandal Merkel Could Do Without
description: MUNICH  Its a family affair, but one that is very public and very political.

title: Dr. Joyce Brothers, On-Air Psychologist Who Made TV House Calls, Dies at 85
description: Joyce Brothers, a former academic psychologist who, long before Drs. Ruth, Phil and Laura, was counseling millions over the airwaves, died on Monday at her home in Fort Lee, N.J. She was 85.

title: Germany Accuses Man of Being Somali Pirates Accountant
description: BERLIN  Who knew that buccaneers had bookkeepers?

title: In Abortion Protests, Which to Protect, Children or Speech?
description: WASHINGTON  Kenneth T. Scott opposes abortion, and he says so in public. Sometimes he holds up large pictures of aborted fetuses. Sometimes he makes his points near churches that he believes are not doing enough to combat abortion.

title: It Wasnt the Day to Ask Cuomo About the Mood in Albany
description: ALBANY  Maybe it was just Monday. Maybe its the constant bad news regarding corruption surrounding the Capitol. Maybe it was just quitting time.

title: Israels Austerity Budget Draws Citizen Protests
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli government was debating the final points of a two-year austerity budget early Tuesday that would cut spending and raise taxes, outraging many Israelis who voted in a new government this year after promises of economic relief.

title: Upfronts 2013: Fox
description: The Times's Bill Carter discusses Fox's programming, after the broadcaster unveiled its plans to advertisers.

title: Orbs Breezy Speed Stirs Talk of a Crown
description: The Kentucky Derby victor, Orb, does not pack light. Hay, hoses, food, blankets, stall gates and two equine travel companions were loaded onto his van to Baltimore for the second leg of his Triple Crown quest.

title: Crucial Carbon Dioxide Reading Revised Downward
description: One of the two programs that monitor greenhouse gases said on Monday that it had revised a reading from last week suggesting that carbon dioxide in the air had surpassed the symbolic level of 400 parts per million.

title: Barbara Walters's Memorable Moments
description: A selection of interviews conducted by Barbara Walters with world leaders and celebrities over the decades.

title: Temporary Limit Put on Sales of Morning-After Pill
description: At least through the end of May, the Plan B One-Step morning-after contraceptive will not be sold over the counter for all ages. A federal appeals court on Monday temporarily granted the Obama administrations request for a stay of an order by Judge Edward R. Korman of Federal District Court that the pill be available without a prescription for everyone. The Justice Department has appealed that order and the appeals court said it would keep the order from being implemented until it hears from both sides. In the interim, the pill is available without a prescription for women and girls ages 15 and older.

title: Women Forced Into WWII Brothels Served Necessary Role, Osaka Mayor Says
description: TOKYO  The mayor of one of Japans largest cities, who is seen by some as a possible future prime minister, drew an outcry on Monday after he said women forced into wartime brothels for the Japanese Army during World War II had served a necessary role in providing relief for war-crazed soldiers.

title: Preakness Field Dwindles as Contenders Complete Works
description: And then there were nine. The Preakness field continues to be in flux as two more horses defected: Vyjack (18th in the Kentucky Derby) and Normandy Invasion (fourth). Perhaps we will see one or two additions in the next day or two.

title: Broadcast Networks Are Amply Filling Schedules
description: As the television upfronts week for the 2013-14 season gets under way in New York, one trend is already apparent: strength in numbers  or is it safety in numbers?

title: A Colorful Bolivian Bastion, Floating Above It All
description: EL ALTO, Bolivia  Turn a corner in this sprawling, bustling, fast-growing city and the Ovando family home suddenly bursts into view, a party-colored mirage floating above the drab, brick-red metropolis like a beacon of an alternate Andean future.

title: Leader of Teachers Cheating Ring in Memphis Gets 7-Year Term
description: Clarence D. Mumford Sr., a former teacher and assistant principal in Memphis, was sentenced Monday to seven years in federal prison for orchestrating a scheme to help teachers cheat on certification exams.

title: France Confirms Second Case of Virus Linked to SARS
description: PARIS  France confirmed a second case of a new coronavirus belonging to the same family as SARS on Monday, saying a man who shared a hospital room with the first victim had been infected.

title: Antique Bridge Closed to Traffic While Its Open for Repairs
description: Brooklyn was still an independent city when the Carroll Street Bridge vaulted over the Gowanus Canal, allowing horse-drawn wagons to travel among the areas farms.

title: Look, but Dont Touch
description: The photographer Mark Laitas new book, Serpentine, seeks to capture the snake in its many colors and the sensual forms its movement creates. It is science best appreciated from a distance.

title: A Star Who Jumped at the Chance to Stay
description: SEATTLE  On the day the Mariners made Felix Hernandez the highest-paid pitcher in baseball history, about 100 team employees waited for him outside an elevator, clad in gold T-shirts that read simply King. They held K signs as they clapped and screamed and chanted his name.

title: Twisting and Turning
description: Nature photography  stills and live action  is a cultural staple, like Honest Abe Lincoln, celebrity self-immolation and the myth that Shakespeare didnt write his own plays. But why?

title: Balancing Anthonys Need to Shoot and Need to Share
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Some Knicks were ill, some Knicks were aching and some Knicks were bickering, or at least giving the appearance of it, all on the eve of a game labeled a must win by the franchise star, who is shooting too much or not shooting enough.

title: Matter: Cicadas
description: Carl Zimmer talks about the life cycle and evolutionary adaptations of the insect.

title: More Clients Ask Questions of Bloomberg
description: With new concerns emerging about practices at its news division, Bloomberg L.P., the sprawling financial services company founded by Michael R. Bloomberg, scrambled to shield its lucrative terminal business and appease nervous customers.

title: Generic Drug Maker Pleads Guilty in Federal Case
description: The generic drug maker Ranbaxy pleaded guilty on Monday to federal drug safety violations and will pay $500 million in fines to resolve claims that it sold subpar drugs and made false statements to the Food and Drug Administration about its manufacturing practices at two factories in India, the company and federal prosecutors announced Monday. The settlement is the largest in history involving a generic manufacturer and drug safety, the Justice Department said.

title: Phone Sounds Good, but How Is the Deal?
description: The Ooma Telo is advertised as a free home phone service, and while its nowhere near free, it has excellent sound quality and may still be a better deal than your current phone service.

title: Is the N.R.A. Un-American?
description: The more militant members of the N.R.A. and most of its leaders may be un-American.

title: The Art of Repetition
description: In the months after my mother died, we started the task of sorting. Its a strange process that makes you part curator and part detective. You read every letter in every file, empty every box, open every drawer. We werent looking for clues  my mother was remarkably transparent  but I found one anyway. A clue to why I had become a writer.

title: A Concrete Plane, the Nectar Mops of Bats and More
description: If you watch only one video about bat tongues this week, let it be one made by biologists at Brown University, who figured out how to illuminate the animals long tongues without bothering their sensitive bat eyes. We shot color high-speed video of the bats gathering nectar, which is challenging to obtain because color cameras require a lot of light, said Cally J. Harper, lead author of a paper on the research. The nimble camera work, she said, produced the aha moment of the study  read on for the results.

title: Once-Softer Hibbert Is Wearing Out Knicks
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Integrated Fighting Academy sits in a well-manicured office park along the southern rim of the city, sharing a flat concrete building with a security system supply company and a lawn with a flock of geese. Two truck tires, weighing about 300 pounds each, lie in the back of the parking lot.

title: Victory in Guatemala? Not Yet
description: THE conviction last Friday of the former Guatemalan dictator Efran Ros Montt on charges of genocide and crimes against humanity is of monumental significance. It was the first time in history that a former head of state was indicted by a national tribunal on charges of genocide. It offers hopes to those similarly seeking justice in El Salvador, Honduras and Nicaragua.

title: Making a Case for One Leader at JPMorgan
description: This isnt about good governance; its about busybodies without a clue, trying to do the dumbest thing  slapping and shaming a superb C.E.O. for utterly no practical reason.

title: The Deeper Blame for Benghazi
description: THE spectacle in Washington over the terrorist attack last Sept. 11 in Benghazi, Libya, is focusing on the wrong thing.

title: Our Ceaseless Circus
description: Four Americans died in Benghazi, Libya: people with unrealized hopes, unfinished plans, relatives who loved them and friends who will miss them.

title: Becoming Invisible, at Least to Microwaves
description: Using an off-the-shelf 3-D printer, nearly anyone can make an invisibility cloak to make objects disappear, researchers report. But if youre thinking about using one for snooping, Harry Potter style, you should know it works only for microwave radiation, which humans cant see anyway.

title: Video Appears to Show Syrian Rebel Mutilating a Soldiers Corpse
description: Supporters of the Syrian government posted a graphic video to YouTube on Sunday that appeared to show a rebel commander cutting out the heart and liver of a government soldier and threatening members of the countrys Alawite religious minority. He then held the organs up to his mouth and appeared to take a bite.

title: Bulls Physical Approach to James Is Familiar
description: CHICAGO

title: Sharif vs. Army, Round 3
description: LONDON  The last time that Nawaz Sharif had close dealings with the Pakistani Army, soldiers handcuffed him and imprisoned him in an ancient fort overlooking the Indus River, physically dragging him from office in a coup.

title: No Time to Cut Food Stamps
description: Families who are living in poverty did not spend this nation into debt, says Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, and we should not be trying to balance the budget on their backs. That humane principle will guide the New York Democrat as she seeks to persuade colleagues to resist a proposed $4.1 billion cut in food stamps in an omnibus farm bill heading toward Senate agriculture committee vote.

title: Soybeans and the Spirit of Invention
description: Vernon Bowman, an Indiana farmer, bought a mix of soybean seeds from a grain elevator, planted them in a late-season crop and used seeds harvested from that crop to plant his late crop the following season. Included in that mix (intended mostly for animal feed) were Monsantos patented genetically altered seeds, which allow farmers to use herbicide, like Roundup, to kill weeds without damaging the soybean plants.

title: The Next Scapegoat
description: Twenty years ago, when she was a young Foreign Service officer in Moscow, Victoria Nuland gave me a dazzling briefing on the diverse factions inside the Russian parliament. Now she is a friend I typically see a couple times a year, at various functions, and I have watched her rise, working with everybody from Dick Cheney to Hillary Clinton, serving as ambassador to NATO, and now as a spokeswoman at the State Department.

title: Laser
description: When the Navy announced last month that it was deploying a shipboard laser weapon in the Persian Gulf, it seemed that the future of warfare had arrived, in which the enemy could be blasted from the sky by a beam of light.

title: A Bumbling Response on Talking Points
description: No matter how often Republicans denounce them, the initial talking points used by the White House to describe the attack in Benghazi, Libya are not the real point. But they have become a major political issue in large part because of the White Houses inept response to questions about how they were written.

title: The I.R.S. Audits Are Condemned
description: The Internal Revenue Service was absolutely correct to look into the abuse of the tax code by political organizations masquerading as social welfare groups over the last three years. The agencys mistake  and it was a serious one  was focusing on groups with Tea Party in their name or those criticizing how the country is run.

title: Phone Records of Journalists Seized by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  Federal investigators secretly seized two months of phone records for reporters and editors of The Associated Press in what the news organization said Monday was a serious interference with A.P.s constitutional rights to gather and report the news.

title: In Barbara Walterss Highlight Reel, TVs Rise and Fade
description: Pope Benedict XVI retired.

title: 2 Waiters Arrested in Killing of Malcolm Xs Grandson
description: MEXICO CITY  The police here arrested two men on murder and robbery charges on Monday in the beating death last week of Malcolm Shabazz, the grandson of Malcolm X, though many questions about the case remained unresolved.

title: Police Inspector Rules Out Racial Profiling
description: It promised to be a clarifying moment in a federal lawsuit against the New York Police Department: A commander whose comments about race had been secretly recorded by a patrol officer took the stand on Monday to address what he had said.

title: Commander Denies U.S. to Blame in Afghan Deaths
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The highest-ranking international military commander in Afghanistan has categorically denied any American or NATO responsibility for the deaths of at least 17 women and children after nearly seven hours of intensive airstrikes near their compound in eastern Afghanistan, in the latest development in a case that has greatly raised tensions with the Afghan government.

title: Lawyers Say DNA Clears Florida Inmate in Two Killings
description: MIAMI  Seven years after he was sentenced to death in the fatal stabbings of two Florida women, Clemente Javier Aguirre appeared in a Seminole County courtroom on Monday to present DNA evidence that could win him a new trial.

description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Status-Seeking Sort
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  So I was e-mailing with Will Shortz the other day  did I mention that I know Will Shortz?  and he was telling me about all of the really cool people hes met in his travels as the editor of the New York Times crossword puzzles. Its fascinating stuff really, and between that and all of the insanely interesting celebrities Ive met while cultivating the Celebrity Guest Blogging feature, why, I

title: Uneven I.R.S. Scrutiny Seen in Political Spending by Big Tax-Exempt Groups
description: Over the last two years, government watchdog groups filed more than a dozen complaints with the Internal Revenue Service seeking inquiries into whether large nonprofit organizations like those founded by the Republican political operative Karl Rove and former Obama administration aides had violated their tax-exempt status by spending tens of millions of dollars on political advertising.

title: New Charge for Brooklyn Legislator Is a State Favorite: Pilfering From a Nonprofit Agency
description: William F. Boyland Jr., the Brooklyn legislator who had already been charged with soliciting more than $250,000 in bribes and filing false travel vouchers to the State Assembly worth tens of thousands of dollars, is now facing a new charge.

title: Lottery Numbers
Traffic Eased on Brooklyn Bridge Access Ramps
description: Sinatra sang about it. Bugs Bunny schemed to sell it. Mayors Edward I. Koch and Michael R. Bloomberg traversed it in gestures of populism during separate transit strikes, and P. T. Barnum directed his fleet of elephants over it to prove its sturdiness.

title: $10 Newsstand Umbrella? Its No Longer Unthinkable
description: The newsstands of New York City cater to all kinds of demands: a craving for spearmint gum, an impulse to enter the lottery, a failing device in want of new batteries, a sudden downpour that makes an umbrella not only necessary, but urgently so.

title: When the Politicians Who Should Be Helping Are Only Out to Help Themselves
description: I find Jacqueline Babich sitting on a bench in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, clasping a green bag filled with the detritus of her battle to save her home.

title: China: Former Police Official Detained
description: A former deputy police chief in Chongqing, Tang Jianhua, has been placed under detention in the Communist Partys disciplinary system on suspicion of taking nearly $3 million in bribes, according to an article on Monday in the online version of Peoples Daily, the official mouthpiece of the party. Mr. Tang was a close associate of Wang Lijun, the former Chongqing police chief who had a falling out with Bo Xilai, the disgraced Communist aristocratic politician. Mr. Wang was sentenced last year to 15 years in prison for various crimes, and Mr. Bo awaits trial. Mr. Tang was detained last year after the fall of both of those men. Mr. Tang received an award on Feb. 28, 2010, for his role in the strike black campaign, a drive led by Mr. Wang that ended up with many innocent civilians under detention and being tortured. Mr. Tang was promoted to deputy police chief after receiving the award.

title: Schools Chief Blasts Mayoral Candidates Over Remarks at Education Forum
description: Dennis M. Walcott, the New York City schools chancellor, lashed out at the Democratic candidates for mayor on Monday, saying that he did not believe any of them had a compelling vision to lead city schools and that they had been pandering to gain the support of the teachers union.

title: Heat Take Control From the Start
description: CHICAGO  A placard was laid on each seat at United Center before Game 4 on Monday night between the Chicago Bulls and the Miami Heat. In capital white letters on a red background, the words encapsulated these playoffs for the Bulls, an injury-riddled team that has made its way into the second round on grit and guile.

title: Ankiel Arrives Without a Bat, and Thus Fits Right in With the Mets
description: ST. LOUIS  Terry Collins, the manager of the Mets, a team descending ever deeper into a late-spring slump, began his workday Monday extolling the virtues of positive thinking.

title: Young Americans Lead Trend to Less Driving
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Dan Mauney keeps misplacing his car.

title: In Manhattan, Obama Tells Supporters That He Intends to Govern
description: President Obama, his troubles piling up in Washington, traveled to Manhattan for a busy evening of fundraising for the Democratic Party, telling audiences that progress was being stymied by a persistent wave of hyper-partisanship in the Capitol.

title: Intersection: Artfully Chic in Chelsea
description: Alexis Johnson draws style inspiration from her boss at the Paula Cooper Gallery.

title: Kenneth Battelle, 86, Hairdresser to the Stars, Dies
description: In 1961, Vogue magazine said that almost every famous female head in the world has gone or will go to Kenneth, the hairdresser who created Jacqueline Kennedys legendary bouffant and softened the golden locks of Marilyn Monroe.

title: For Skeptical Lawmaker, Doubts on Attack Were Sown in Whirlwind Trip to Libya
description: WASHINGTON  On Oct. 6, 2012, an Air Force Gulfstream jet landed in Tripoli, Libya, carrying a four-star Army general, a brash Republican congressman from Utah, and a young State Department lawyer  an unlikely group there to investigate a harrowing tragedy.

title: Daughter of a Detained Chinese Rights Activist Speaks
description: BEIJING  8:32 a.m. | Updated Liao Minyue last saw her mother, the rights activist Liu Ping, in mid-April, when she returned home from college to help after Ms. Liu had an operation to remove gallstones.

title: Down Three Goals Late, Bruins Rally and Advance
description: BOSTON  They were minutes from another playoff collapse capped by a Game 7 defeat at home. They trailed by three goals midway through the third period, unable to generate any offense. Their fans were booing. Their season was on the brink.

title: Tax Exemptions and Political Activity
description: The Internal Revenue Service disclosed that it had more closely scrutinized applications for tax-exempt status from conservative-sounding 501(c)(4) groups to insure they were not abusing limitations on political activity.

title: One-Sided Ending to a Tense Playoff Duel
description: WASHINGTON  The Rangers vanquished a rather significant playoff ghost Monday night. They won a Game 7 on the road for the first time in their 87-year existence with a 5-0 victory over the Washington Capitals at Verizon Center.

title: Lundqvist Impervious to Capitals Once More
description: WASHINGTON  More eyes may have been fixated on the 5 that the Rangers had put on the scoreboard, but perhaps just as impressive was the 0 next to the Capitals, thanks to the performance of Henrik Lundqvist.

title: Keynes and Keynesianism
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

description: surly \sr-le\ adjective

description: Action from the Rangers 5-0 victory in Washington, which sent them to the Eastern Conference semifinals.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (CBS) NCIS Gibbs (Mark Harmon) and his team are assigned legal counsel in this Season 10 finale after an investigator (Colin Hanks) from the Defense Department questions their unconventional methods in the search for the killer of Eli David and Jackie Vance. (Above, from left, Brian Dietzen, David McCallum and Pauley Perrette in the season finale.) In NCIS: Los Angeles, at 9, Season 4 ends as Hetty (Linda Hunt) sends Callen (Chris ODonnell) and Kensi (Daniela Ruah) overseas, while Sam (LL Cool J) and his wife (Aunjanue Ellis) go undercover when an explosion in the desert reignites the search for stolen nuclear weapons.

title: After Citizen Protests, Israel Approves Austerity Budget
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli government approved a two-year austerity budget early Tuesday that would cut spending and raise taxes, outraging many Israelis who voted in a new government this year after promises of economic relief.

title: News Quiz | May 14, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Rural Upstarts Move In on Colonial Lackeys
description: To understand Indias middle class as it is now, it helps to think of it as two waves that came 150 years apart.

title: Council Speaker Recounts Her Struggles With Bulimia and Alcoholism
description: The summer she turned 16, Christine C. Quinns world seemed to shatter.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 14, 2013
description: I just want people to know you can get through stuff.

title: American Investor Targets Sony for a Breakup
description: 3:42 a.m. | Updated

title: IHT Quick Read: May 14
description: NEWS Europeans have never been wild about the European Union. With the region sapped by the euro crisis, confidence in the institution and the benefits it was supposed to provide is flagging faster and further than ever before, according to an influential opinion survey released Monday. James Kanter reports from Brussels.

title: Test Yourself | English, May 14, 2013
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article The 700-Doll Question.

title: An International Tournament Dedicated to Medieval Battle
description: In The Holy Grail of Battle Re-enactments,  Mike Tierney writes about an annual full-contact medieval battle competition held in Europe every year.

title: Economic Recovery, Made in Bangladesh?
description: A couple of years ago, I was in an industrial park in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, as a textiles executive pitched me on becoming a rich T-shirt manufacturer. It was easy, he said, to teach basic sewing to even the most poorly educated farmers. If I could spend $500,000 on used sewing machines (he knew a guy), rent a concrete building with no air-conditioning and hire a few dozen peyizan (Creole for peasants) for around $3 per day, I could recoup my investment within two years. And if it didnt work out, he noted, I could sell the equipment to an entrepreneur in another poor nation.

title: The Man Who Loved Women, and Cameras
description: Grace Coddington walked down the rain-slicked streets of East London one afternoon in 1959, clutching her models portfolio as she searched for Terence Donovans studio. All of 18 and aspiring to be a model, she knew she had to pose for him if her career was to take off.

title: Do You Have Helicopter Parents?
description: How involved are your parents in your life? How much do they step in to help you with your schoolwork, social life, college applications, hobbies, sports or anything else? How often do they try to solve your problems? Do you like having their help, or do you find it burdensome? Why?

title: Thrilling and Maddening Senior Year Was an Adventure Worth Taking
description: This Friday, I will be the third person in my entire family to graduate from high school. This is so important to me, and its so strange that my senior year is coming to an end. Sometimes it has been exciting and sometimes it has been mundane, but it has certainly been an adventure worth taking.

title: Wheelies: The Bearded Lady Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: For Local Businesses, the Internet Threat Isnt Just the Sales Tax
description: I am a third-generation retailer. My father and grandfather owned a dime store (Google it), and working there gave me a foundation that would allow me to become a successful entrepreneur.

title: What Is the Right Way to Come Out as Bisexual at Work?
description: Every other Tuesday,  Steven Petrow, the author of Steven Petrows Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners, (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience.  Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

title: Shanty China
description: BEIJING  Western tourists who visit Beijing often remark on its lack of slums. Although it is home to seven million migrant workers, the capital appears to be without the squalid shantytowns that pockmark or ring other developing cities, like Mumbai and Rio de Janeiro.

title: Former BlackRock Fund Manager Arrested in Insider Trading Inquiry
description: LONDON  Mark Lyttleton, a former BlackRock fund manager, has been arrested in connection with an insider trading investigation in Britain, according to two people briefed on the matter.

title: Daily Report: Surging Data Center Industry Blurs Boundaries
description: Data centers in New Jersey that provide huge banks of remote computer storage, which require enormous amounts of electrical power and ultrafast fiber optic links, are commanding rents four times as high as prime high-rises in Manhattan, James Glanz reports in The New York Times.

title: Loeb Takes On Sony
description: Daniel S. Loeb, an American hedge fund billionaire known for starting big fights, has called for a breakup of the entertainment and electronics giant Sony, possibly setting off a battle that could roil Japans staid corporate culture, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook. The call, which came on Tuesday, will most likely be viewed by government officials and corporate leaders in Tokyo as a shot across the bow from Wall Street, just as Western investors begin piling into Japanese stocks.

title: Ken Burns to Oversee Emperor of All Maladies Project for Public Television
description: Siddhartha Mukherjees Pulitzer Prize-winning book The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer, is being developed as a six-hour documentary series for public television, with Ken Burns as executive producer. An official announcement is not expected until June, but several of the project participants confirmed their roles.

title: Bill Hader to Leave Saturday Night Live
description: With just one departure, Saturday Night Live is losing its excitable Weekend Update city correspondent, Stefon; its frenetic incarnations of James Carville, Al Pacino, Vincent Price and Julian Assange; and any number of unctuous, self-satisfied game show hosts.

title: In Performance: Leslie Kritzer of The Memory Show
description: In the musical The Memory Show, Leslie Kritzer plays a woman, identified simply as Daughter, who has moved home to take care of her aging mother, who is in the early stages of Alzheimers disease. In the song Me and My Mother, Daughter has just witnessed her mothers first major episode of dementia. The show, with a book and lyrics by Sara Cooper and music by Zach Redler, continues through Saturday at the Duke on 42nd Street.

title: South Korea Proposes Meeting With North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea proposed on Tuesday to hold a border meeting with North Korea to discuss bringing finished goods and raw materials from an industrial park that the two countries jointly operated until last month.

title: Press Play
description: Press Play is the place where The New York Times debuts noteworthy new music. Every week, we present tracks from upcoming new albums. Listen to them here exclusively.

title: Tuesday Reading: Shaking Off Loneliness, for Your Health
Syria Gives Russia List of Envoys to Peace Talks
description: STOCKHOLM  President Bashar al-Assads government has given Russia the names of officials who would attend international talks intended to end the war in Syria, Secretary of State John Kerry said Tuesday, even as representatives of both sides in Syria publicly expressed skepticism about the prospect of a political settlement.

title: Thanks, Mom, but a Care Package Is Not Needed
description: Dear Diary:

title: From Russia, With Wig: American Spy Suspect Is Ejected
description: MOSCOW  He arrived at the meeting with two wigs  the blond one on his head held in place by a baseball cap, a brown one in his knapsack, which also held a compass, a Moscow street atlas and $130,000 in cash. He was an operative for the Central Intelligence Agency, Russian officials say, and his goal was to recruit a Russian security officer as a spy.

title: Thiel Brings Money and Some Credibility to Europe
description: LONDON  Peter Thiel is coming to Europe.

title: Cameron Seeks to Calm Party on Europe Vote
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron tried once again to quell mounting dissent within his party over Britains place in the European Union, publishing a draft law on Tuesday that promises a referendum on British membership in the bloc by the end of 2017.

title: A Video Link With Pakistan
description: Americas drones are keeping an eye on Pakistans political developments.

title: Europeans Move to Stave Off Hollywood
description: LONDON  France is spearheading a campaign within the European Union to ensure that closer trade ties with the United States do not lead to further Hollywoodization of European culture.

title: Black Male Turnout Higher Than Official Data Suggest
description: Although a recent Census Bureau study showed a stark gap between black male turnout and black female turnout in the 2012 election, the large number of black men ineligible to vote because of felony convictions explains much of the gap.

title: Should India Provide Direct Military Aid to Afghanistan?
description: Over the past decade, India has invested heavily in Afghanistans reconstruction. Recognizing Indias significant economic and development contributions, the United States has called on New Delhi to play an important role in the new Silk Road initiative aimed at transforming Afghanistan into a regional trade hub.

title: Aquino Allies Take Lead in Election in Philippines
description: MANILA  Philippine voters appeared to have strengthened President Benigno S. Aquino IIIs hand in advancing his political agenda, according to early unofficial election returns on Tuesday that showed his political allies poised to take control of the Senate.

title: The New Case for Liberal Arts
description: LONDON  All through elementary school and junior high, whenever anyone asked me what I wanted to be when I grew up I always gave the same answer: a marine biologist. Until I got to biology class in high school and got turned off by my teacher  which does happen, even if wed rather talk about teachers who inspire their students. By the time I applied to college an interest in government had displaced gills  or so I thought, listing political science as my intended major.

title: U.S. Open Cup: 1958 to 1987
description: This is the third of a series on the U.S. Open Cup.

title: What Were Reading
description: Time Out New York: Caesar salad, banana cream pie, Frank Sinatra on the jukebox: a look at new restaurants that specialize in bringing back the old.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Western Conference Semifinals: Divisional Rivalries on Display
description: The semifinals in the West feature matchups of division rivals. In a meeting of Central Division foes, the Blackhawks face the Red Wings in the playoffs for the 16th time, while Los Angeles and San Jose from the Pacific Division square off for the only the second time in the postseason.

title: Tucked Into the Citys Budget, Thousands of Body Bags
description: Buried in New Yorks $70 billion annual budget are thousands of unexpected expenses that define the citys cradle-to-grave benefits. Take body bags.

title: Book Covers: Before and After
description: For the first installment of a new series, I asked four book designers to discuss recent examples of their work. Each designer shared an earlier idea for a cover as well as the final design that ended up on the book.

title: Defining Submissive in the Vocabulary of Womens Choices
