description: Glenn Beck recently called me one of the bravest people alive. At the same moment, I felt as if the Internet unleashed a tidal wave of fury on me. People were up all night on Twitter, telling me Id set womens causes back 50 years.

title: Indonesian Police Kill Suspect in Attempted Bomb Attack
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The Indonesian police said on Tuesday that they had shot and killed a man they suspected of being an Islamist militant who tried to bomb a roadside police traffic post in West Java Province in retaliation for a series of recent counterterrorism raids across the country.

title: In Fight With Hess, Elliott Proposes Seating All Board Nominees
description: 11:17 a.m. | Updated

title: Bike Share: Nimby vs. Yimby
description: New rental bicycle-share stands on streets across Manhattan and Brooklyn are drawing mixed reactions among New Yorkers, from not in my backyard to yes, in my backyard and all points in between.

title: Bike Sharing? Sure. The Racks? No Way.
description: Bike share was easy for New York City to love in the abstract. It was not about adding bike lanes at the expense of something else; it was about sharing something that did not yet exist.

title: Q&A: Covering Up Your Amazon Tracks
description: Q.

title: Loebs Bold Bet on Sony
description: Daniel S. Loeb is taking Japans economic renaissance at face value. The hedge fund manager wants Sony to spin off its entertainment arm. Though activists rarely prevail in Japan, Mr. Loebs idea may have merit, and Sony should take him seriously.

title: Vermont Passes Aid in Dying Measure
description: Vermont will become the fourth state to make it legal for a physician to prescribe lethal medication to a terminally ill, mentally competent patient who wants to end his life. It has also become the first state to approve the practice through legislation, instead of via a public referendum (as in Oregon and Washington) or a court decision (in Montana).

title: Downton Abbey to Return in January, After British Broadcast
description: The fourth season of Downton Abbey will begin on Jan. 5, an executive producer said on Tuesday, dashing hopes that American and British viewers could watch the hit show at the same time.

title: Bruins Save Best for Last
description: You have to hand it to the Boston Bruins. They have this Game 7 thing down to a science. Seriously. How do you top a 2011 Stanley Cup run that featured three Game 7 victories, including a first-round tightrope walk/grudge match in overtime against Montreal? How do you make fans forget last years Game 7 overtime loss at home in the first round against Washington? How do you wipe away the epic face plant of 2010, losing not only a 3-0 series lead to hated Philadelphia, but also a 3-0 lead in Game 7 at home?

title: What the Gosnell Case Doesnt Mean
description: A jury in Philadelphia on Monday convicted Kermit Gosnell, a doctor who clearly does not deserve that title before his name, of three counts of first-degree murder.

title: At Goldencents Side, a Star in His Own Way
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  They are often the unknowns. Even when they stand right in front of thousands, few know grooms names or acknowledge them. Yet they know more about the horse at the end of their lead line than anyone else at the racetrack. Often, by the time the horse is loaded into the starting gate, their groom has already spent more than nine hours by their side that day.

title: Japanese Aide Makes Rare Trip to North Korea
description: TOKYO  A political aide to the prime minister of Japan made a sudden, rare visit to North Korea on Tuesday. Japanese officials refused to say what he was doing there.

title: Nuances of Credit Scoring Still Elude Consumers
description: Consumers still have many misunderstandings about the details of credit scoring, like the impact of having several inquiries on their report around the same time, according to the Consumer Federation of America.

title: No Benefit Seen in Sharp Limits on Salt in Diet
description: In a report that undercuts years of public health warnings, a prestigious group convened by the government says there is no good reason based on health outcomes for many Americans to drive their sodium consumption down to the very low levels recommended in national dietary guidelines.

title: For Republicans, Incentives to Strike a Budget Deal With Obama
description: WASHINGTON  Ask around the White House and the Capitol, and you will quickly find reasons to doubt that Republicans will compromise with President Obama on a budget deal that includes more tax increases and spending cuts in social programs.

title: New Entrant to Venice Biennale: the Vatican
description: VATICAN CITY It commissioned the Sistine Chapel, countless portraits of popes and even Matisses chapel in Vence. Now the Roman Catholic Church will host its first pavilion at the Venice Biennale, featuring the Czech photographer Josef Koudelka, the Milan-based multimedia group Studio Azzurro and the artist Lawrence Carroll.

title: Beyonc Cancels Show in Belgium
description: Beyonc has canceled a concert in Belgium that was scheduled for Tuesday night because she is dehydrated and exhausted, The Associated Press reported. The pop divas publicist told the wire service that she has been ordered by her doctors to rest. She had been slated to perform at the Sportpaleis in Antwerp. She has another show at the arena on Wednesday, and her publicist said she is awaiting word from her doctors before making a decision about that performance. Beyonc, 31, started her Mrs. Carter Show World Tour last month in Belgrade, Serbia, and it will finish on Aug. 5 at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn.

title: Lots of Lancaster at Lincoln Center
description: With the possible exception of Marlon Brando, no male star of his era radiated more raw magnetism than Burt Lancaster, whose centennial is being celebrated by the Film Society of Lincoln Center this Friday through May 23. Nowadays, macho preening too often passes for the kind of feral grace radiated by Lancaster in films like The Killers, the 1946 noir classic adapted from a Ernest Hemingway short story and directed by Robert Siodmak.

title: States Urged to Cut Limit on Alcohol for Drivers
description: WASHINGTON  Thousands of people are killed or injured every year by drivers who have not reached the legal standard for being drunk but who have a reduced ability to see, make decisions or operate a vehicle, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Tuesday, and it recommended that the states reduce the allowable blood-alcohol concentration by more than a third, to 0.05 percent from 0.08 percent.

title: Travel Essentials | Taroudant, Morocco
description: In our Summer Travel issue, which hit newsstands on Sunday, Christopher Petkanas waxes poetic about Taroudant, an out-of-the-way, stylish haven from Moroccos well-trodden tourist route. Heres where to stay, eat and sleep in this remote market town.

title: Billy Crystal Bringing  700 Sundays Back to Broadway
description: If Billy Crystal keeps this up, he eventually will have performed 700 Sundays for, well, 700 Sundays. On Tuesday, Mr. Crystal, the comedian, actor and erstwhile Oscars host, said that he will bring 700 Sundays, his Tony Award-winning one-man show about growing up on Long Island, back to Broadway in the fall for a nine-week run that is being described as the productions final engagement.

title: Cellphone Case Helps to Alleviate Wi-Fi Woes
description: Cellphone cases are designed to provide protection, but Absolute Technology thinks they should offer something more: better Wi-Fi reception.

title: Intersection: Artfully Chic in Chelsea
description: In the latest Intersection we visited Chelsea during the Frieze Art Fair and spotted people who said their style influences range from their grandmothers to the avant-garde fashion company Comme des Garons.

title: Video of Americans Arrest in Moscow
description: Last Updated, Wednesday, 12:06 p.m. As my colleague Ellen Barry reports from Moscow, Russias Federal Security Service, the successor to the Soviet-era K.G.B., announced Tuesday that it had arrested a Central Intelligence Agency officer posing as an American diplomat as he tried to recruit a Russian agent.

title: The Gun Report: May 14, 2013
description: Last month, Brandon Holt, 6, was shot and killed by a 4-year-old boy in Toms River, N.J., kicking off a bloody month in which several toddlers accidentally shot other toddlers. The 4-year-old got a hold of his fathers .22 caliber rifle and brought it into the yard, where it went off, hitting Holt in the head. Yesterday it was announced that Anthony Senatore, 33, the father of the gunman, was arrested for having multiple unsecured weapons accessible to children.

title: Regulatory Pressure Drives Commerzbank to Seek Out New Capital
description: LONDON  European banks have gone on a capital-raising binge.

title: A New Executive Director for Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has appointed Suzanne Davidson as its new executive director, starting on July 1. She succeeds Norma Hurlburt, the societys director since 2000. Ms. Hurlburt is leaving to start her own consulting business for nonprofit organizations. The society also announced that its artistic directors, the cellist David Finckel and the pianist Wu Han, who are married, had renewed their contract for a third term, which will take them through the 2018-19 season.

title: The Rickshaw Drivers Curry
description: Kumily, India  One of the best parts of traveling, at least for me, is bringing back a food story, a new ingredient or a recipe. My family journeyed last year from the verdant tea plantations of Munnar down to the Cardamom Hills of Kerala, in southwestern India. Our driver, Janaki Raman, who had proved himself by dodging many a cow on the winding mountain roads, asked whether we might like to go to a local cooking class.

title: More Details About the New Windows
description: Microsoft is shedding the Windows Blue code name for the next installment of its operating system. The official name of the software will be  drumroll, please  Windows 8.1.

title: French Entrepreneurs Strive for Success
description: As immigrant enclaves in the Parisian suburbs struggle with 30 percent youth unemployment, some entrepreneurs are trying to build businesses that will create jobs for their communities.

title: Square Unveils Hardware for iPad Registers
description: Square, the payments start-up, on Tuesday morning introduced new hardware to accompany its cash register software for iPads. The accessory is essentially a stand that doubles as a credit card reader.

title: In Poor Margins of Paris, New Recipe for Success Is Local
description: PARIS  Mourad Benamer remembers the day his parents first visited the sleek new sushi restaurant he had just opened near the Champs-lyses. Against all odds, Mr. Benamer had broken out of the rough suburb, or banlieue, where he grew up in a family of poor Moroccan immigrants just northeast of Paris, and hit on a formula that would soon turn into a business success beyond his dreams.

title: A Governor and a Prince, Down at the Shore
description: SEASIDE HEIGHTS, N.J.  Chris Christie takes pride in being the unfiltered everymans politician.

title: In 125 Years, Much Has Changed, but the Pastrami Is the Same
description: Im from out of town, and I like a good pastrami sandwich, said Jeffrey A. Devore, a lawyer from West Palm Beach, Fla., who was sitting in Katzs, the Lower East Side delicatessen that, like the neighborhood itself, has become a study in contrasts.

title: Cracking Down on Drinking and Driving
description: Its better not to drink and drive, but if you do, keep it under 0.05. So rhymed William N. Plymat, an Iowa insurance company president and former Prohibitionist who became one of the earliest anti-drunken driving activists in the 1950s.

title: 3 G.I.s Killed in Afghan Bombing
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A roadside bomb tore through an American military convoy in southern Afghanistan on Tuesday, killing at least three soldiers in a volatile district of the Taliban heartland.

title: Deborah L. Bernstein, Private Equity Partner, Dies at 41
description: Deborah L. Bernstein, a partner at the private equity firm Aquiline Capital Partners, died on Friday in New York. She was 41.

title: Fighting for the Union  and Equal Pay
description: Shortly after the Emancipation Proclamation declared that African-Americans, of suitable condition, will be received into the armed service of the United States, the governor of Massachusetts, John Albion Andrew  one of the most aggressively antislavery officials to hold public office during the Civil War  put out a call across the North for men to fill the ranks of an exclusively black volunteer regiment.

title: The Obama Synthesis Under Siege
description: The true ideological inclinations of the Obama White House can be endlessly debated, but slightly more than halfway through this presidency I think its fair to make the following generalization: Obama has governed as a business-friendly social democrat and an aggressive social liberal, as a hawkish interventionist when intervention seems cheap and easy (drones, missiles, etc.) and a cautious realist when it doesnt, and as a surprisingly vigorous defender of presidential prerogatives across a variety of fronts. A few weeks ago, I characterized Obama-era liberalism as featuring an imperial presidency, a corporatist economic policy, and then a libertarian turn on almost every social issue, and while that line misses various nuances and complexities, as one-sentence summaries go I think its pretty good.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: A Permanent Job Crisis
Jolies Disclosure of Preventive Mastectomy Highlights Dilemma
description: One of the defining moments in the history of breast cancer occurred in 1974 when the first lady, Betty Ford, spoke openly about her mastectomy, lifting a veil of secrecy from the disease and ushering in a new era of breast cancer awareness.

title: If You Like Fleetwood Mac, Try the Kopecky Family Band
description: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons generation.

title: All-Female Julius Caesar to Open New Season at St. Anns Warehouse
description: An all-female production of Julius Caesar, first staged at the Donmar Warehouse in London last year, will open the 2013-14 season at St. Anns Warehouse. It will be the first of several collaborations between St. Anns and other adventurous companies during the season. Others include the world premiere of Lee Breuers Divina Caricatura Part 1, The Shaggy Dog which the company is presenting with La MaMa, and a staging of Bartoks Bluebeards Castle, a co-production with the itinerant New York City Opera.

title: Watching Washington This Week
description: The Timess Congressional correspondents Ashley Parker and Jeremy W. Peters analyze the key players to watch on Capitol Hill this week.

title: Sore Knee Is Bothering Shumpert
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Iman Shumpert skipped the Knicks Tuesday morning shootaround because of soreness in his left knee before playing a little more than 16 minutes in the Indiana Pacers 93-82 victory in Game 4.

title: Justice Dept. Defends Seizure of Phone Records
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Tuesday defended the Justice Departments sweeping seizure of telephone records of Associated Press journalists, describing the article by The A.P. that prompted a criminal investigation as among the top two or three most serious leaks that Ive ever seen in a 35-year career.

title: A Way to Make Phone Records Not So Easy to Track
description: The ease with which the Obama administration was able to secure the Associated Press phone records may have demonstrated once and for all that privacy is dead.

title: Objects | amfAR Goes for the Gold at Cannes
description: Midway through this years Cannes film festival, A-listers will take a break from the red carpets to attend amfARs annual Cinema Against AIDS benefit at the glamorous Hotel du Cap-Eden-Roc on the French Riviera. The highlight will be the Ultimate Gold Collection Fashion Show, an all-gold runway presentation curated by Carine Roitfeld. It will feature 40 models (including It girl Karlie Kloss and Daria Strokous, one of the faces of the current Christian Dior ad campaign) in one-of-a-kind gowns by the likes of Comme des Garcons, Alexander Wang, Giorgio Armani and Valentino, which will be auctioned after the show. Theyll be wearing bespoke jewelry made from the precious metal, commissioned by Roitfeld, including the cuffs seen above by the chic, celebrity-endorsed designers (from left) Kimberly McDonald, Hoorsenbuhs and Ana Khouri. The pieces will subsequently be made to order at LoveGold, an online community dedicated to gold jewelry. The site, in its first year as a presenting sponsor for the gala, will live stream exclusive footage of the catwalk on May 23.

title: Eastern Conference Semifinals: No Love Lost Between Foes
description: Like the West, the East has one matchup of Original Six teams. But that is just one subplot as rivalries old and new are renewed.

title: Pack an Umbrella, or Not?
description: Just in time for beach season, the private forecaster AccuWeather has started a 30-day forecast that aims to help people plan their trips and outdoor events. In the 1960s, AccuWeather started its five-day forecast; this new feature, accessible through the companys Web site, follows that model, and will include high and low temperatures, sky conditions and chance of precipitation.

title: Video: Watching Washington This Week
description: The Timess Ashley Parker and Jeremy W. Peters, Congressional correspondents, analyze the key players to watch on Capitol Hill this week.

title: ABC Unveils a Fall Schedule With 13 New Series
description: ABC introduced a new fall schedule on Tuesday that, like those unveiled by the networks competitors, was heavily dependent on new series  13 in all, in ABCs case.

title: Negligence Is Debated in Jackson Death Case
description: LOS ANGELES  After only two weeks of testimony, no side has a clear advantage in the civil trial pitting the mother of Michael Jackson against A.E.G. Live, the promoter of his attempted comeback concerts, over the question of who was responsible for Jacksons death.

title: A Quest for Justice in Guatemala
description: Daniel Hernndez-Salazar is used to waiting. Two decades ago he abandoned his photojournalistic career to devote himself to documenting the search for justice in the wake of Guatemalas 36-year civil war. He stood at exhumations alongside indigenous Maya, as they waited to spy a bracelet or scrap of muddy fabric that would allow them to finally locate the bones of a loved one. More recently, he stood among them in a Guatemala City courtroom as the former dictator, Gen. Efran Ros Montt, was sentenced to 80 years for genocide and crimes against humanity.

title: Image of the Day: May 14
No Comment Necessary: Freedom of No Information
description: Via ABC News

title: A Politicians Disclosure Offers a Lesson in Eating Disorders
description: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker and a Democratic candidate for mayor, revealed in The New York Times on Tuesday that she battled bulimia for over a decade, from her midteens until she entered a rehabilitation program at age 26. Though other public figures have discussed their struggles with bulimia  Katie Couric and Jane Fonda are two examples  its a rare disclosure for a politician. Ms. Quinn also said she considered herself a recovering alcoholic, which is a less unusual distinction.

title: As Firms Line Up on Factories, Wal-Mart Plans Solo Effort
description: As American retailers face mounting pressure to join a landmark plan to improve factory safety in Bangladesh, newly found documents indicate that apparel had been produced for Wal-Mart at one of the operations in the factory building that collapsed last month, killing more than 1,100 workers.

title: St. Louis Development Makes a Play for a Home Team Advantage
description: When the new Busch Stadium opened in 2006, the occasional mudhole along adjacent property symbolized the failure of a planned companion project aimed at revitalizing downtown St. Louis.

title: David Stark Creates Classic Pop-Up Books
description: A few years ago, the New York-based event planner David Stark and his team began making sculptural art pieces out of paper and using them as centerpieces or decorative props. Not quite origami, the sculptures are often created with strategic cuts to antique books, so the pages open into a fruit or flower.

title: For Chelsea, Small Consolation
description: This was not the championship match that Chelsea had in mind.

title: New York City Tycoon Cars Heading for Auction
description: On May 31, Dragone Classic Motorcars will hold its second annual auction, featuring 65 cars (compared with last years 47) at its showroom in Westport, Conn. Theres plenty to savor, including a magnificent supercharged 1937 Cord 812 SC Sportsman and a 1938 Mercedes Benz 320 N Speciale Kombination Roadster bought by a American serviceman from a Berlin used-car lot in 1946, then left for decades in an Orange, Conn., barn.

title: Shopping Snapshots: May 16
description: What the singer and songwriter Kilo Kish is wearing now; Nike and A.P.C. collaborate again; tuxedo looks for women return; and Personnel of New York opens.

title: A Car Towing Tale of Woe
description: 5/17/13 | Updated with comment from towing companys lawyer.

title: Android Phones Gain Ground
description: Googles Android operating system for smartphones, which is used in Samsung phones and devices from other manufacturers, including Huawei and LG, has expanded its domination of the market.

title: Finding Frugal Toulouse, Despite Two Holidays
description: Some are unlucky in love, others in business. I am unlucky in calendars. Wherever I travel, local holidays materialize from thin air  shutting down attractions, slowing down public transport and sending the locals fleeing to country homes.

title: Scolari Goes With Youth in Brazil
description: Five months into another stint as the coach of Brazils national team, Luiz Felipe Scolari gave a clear indication Tuesday that he would not be wedded to the past when he named his squad for next months FIFA Confederations Cup, which Brazil will host.

title: Snooping and the News Media: Its a 2-Way Street
description: Word on Monday that the Justice Department had obtained the records of more than 20 phone lines at The Associated Press sent the Fourth Estate into a frenzy. Big Government, Big Data, Big Brother, all the symbols of an increasingly surveillance-driven age were invoked.

title: Contributions Piling Up in Race for Mayor
description: 9:15 p.m. | Updated Bill de Blasio, the New York City public advocate, reached a crucial milestone in his bid for mayor on Tuesday when his campaign reported that he had raised all the money he is allowed to spend in the coming primary.

title: Tech Industry Weighs In as Senate Panel Works on Immigration Bill
description: 3:34 p.m. | Updated

title: Europe Raids 3 Companies in an Inquiry on Oil Prices
description: LONDON  The authorities on Tuesday raided the offices of several oil companies and an industry data provider as part of a broader inquiry by the European Commission into potential price manipulation.

title: Designers Unite Again for a Good Cause
description: In December, 24 New York City designers banded together to organize a charity auction for victims of Hurricane Sandy. Contributing furniture made from salvaged materials or that in some way alluded to the wreckage, the group, called Reclaim NYC, raised some $15,000 for the Red Cross.

title: Links for the Middle of May
description: Its a busy time for ag-gag bills: The Tennessee attorney general ruled that the states ag-gag bill is constitutionally suspect before it was vetoed by Gov. BillHaslam; Indianas version was killed: a new one was introduced in Pennsylvania (a local newspaper wrote that it goes against everything this country has stood for since its inception); and a woman was arrested in Utah for taking photos of a slaughter plant from public property.

title: BlackBerry Messaging Is Set for iPhones and Android
description: BlackBerry said on Tuesday that it would open its BlackBerry Messenger service to users of iPhones and phones running the Android operating system while it also tries to turn the instant messaging system into a competitor of Twitter.

title: Dissecting the A.P. Phone Log Seizure
description: The Timess Charlie Savage breaks down the governments subpoenas of phone records of Associated Press journalists.

title: I Believe I Can Fry
description: When did frying chicken become so intimidating? There are cooks out there who have spherified martini olives and piped buttercreams without ever biting into a piece of homemade fried chicken.

title: Angelina Jolies Preventive Surgery
description: To the Editor:

title: Tip of the Week: Customize the Windows 8 Start Screen
description: For many people who upgrade from earlier versions of the system, Windows 8 and its colorful Start screen can be a little overwhelming. The Start screen, like the Start menu in older Windows editions, is meant to be the go-to place for all the computers files and programs. Like the Start menu, the Start screen can be customized according to personal needs and tastes.

title: A Focus on Border Security and Temporary Visas as Senators Return to Immigration
description: 4:53 p.m. | Updated  The Senate Judiciary Committee continued to plow through amendments to an immigration overhaul bill on Tuesday, revisiting border security provisions before moving on to measures related to temporary guest worker programs.

title: For Fried Chicken, a Bubbly Companion
description: Sometimes the classics cannot be bested. Im falling back on an old favorite with fried chicken: Champagne.

title: Rutgers Reinstates Lacrosse Coach After Inquiry
description: Rutgers on Tuesday reinstated its mens lacrosse coach, Brian Brecht, after suspending him with pay as it investigated allegations of verbal abuse.

title: Senate Panel Approves Farm Bill
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee approved a $955 billion farm bill on Tuesday, the first step toward completing an overhaul of the nations food and farm policy that was derailed last year when the House failed to vote on its version of the bill.

title: Larry Page Says Vocal Cord Paralysis Causes His Voice Problems
description: 5:28 p.m. | Updated

title: Eating Disorders and Public Life
description: Kate Taylor, the Times reporter who interviewed the mayoral candidate Christine Quinn about her bulimia, discusses her own challenges with anorexia.

title: Miller Theater Announces New Season
description: The highlights of the 25th season of the Miller Theater at the Columbia University School of the Arts will include a festival celebrating the 60th birthday of John Zorn, the new music maverick; and an evening of 125 short compositions modeled after John Cage, whose centennial was last year. And back for the 2013-14 season is the Composer Portraits series, featuring the work of and discussions with Georg Friedrich Haas, Rand Steiger, Anna Thorvaldsdottir, Roger Reynolds, Unsuk Chin, Jean-Baptiste Barrire and Liza Lim.

title: As Culture Moves Online, France Tries to Follow It With a Tax
description: PARIS  Frances cultural exception  the policy that creative works like books, music and movies deserve protection beyond what is accorded ordinary goods  is in line for a digital update.

title: Paris Cancels Celebration for Soccer Champions
description: PARIS  Officials canceled a city hall ceremony for the champions of Frances national soccer league on Tuesday after hundreds of rampaging fans attacked stores, cars and police officers in the capital during celebrations on Monday night. The violence, which left 32 people injured and 38 fans in police custody, erupted at an official celebration for Paris Saint-Germain, the winning team, near a neighborhood overlooking the Eiffel Tower.

title: Suspicious Substance Disrupts U.S. Consulate in China
description: BEIJING  Staff members at the United States Consulate in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou discovered a suspicious substance in an envelope on Monday, prompting the closing of some operations. The substance, which was found in a part of the consulate not open to the public, has yet to be identified. No consulate workers have suffered any ill effects and no visitors are believed to have been exposed, said Nolan Barkhouse, a spokesman for the United States Embassy in Beijing. The consulate has notified Chinese authorities and is maintaining close contact with them in case any assistance becomes necessary, Mr. Barkhouse said. The consulate was closed for visa interviews on Tuesday and will remain closed Wednesday pending an investigation. The consulate handles 121,000 visa applications annually and processes all immigrant visas for Chinese children adopted by American citizens.

title: Teslas Stock Is Trading at Rich Multiples
description: Teslas shareholders seem to be assuming that its chief executive, Elon Musk, is infallible. Tesla, the electric carmaker, is on a roll. Last week, it recorded its first quarterly profit and received the best score that Consumer Reports has bestowed on a car for six years. The companys stock has since surged as much as 70 percent, leaving Tesla worth more than Fiat and Peugeot combined. Its stock is also trading at a whopping 27 times estimates for earnings in 2016.

title: Time Lapse of World Trade Center Spire
description: A time lapse of a video released by the Port Authority shows the spire being raised to the top of One World Trade Center.

title: Front Burner
description: To Bake: Top-Notch Pizza Starts With the Dough

title: Oddball Travelogue That Is All Detours
description: David Sedaris doesnt write like a writer. He writes like someone who writes for a living. Thats a different thing, and not necessarily a bad one: Mr. Sedaris can be the life of your two-person party if you turn to his essays for quick, easy diversion and nothing more. But only a man with column space to fill would devote the first eight pages of a book to the experience of having dental work done in France.

title: Ex-Wife of SACs Cohen Hires New Lawyer in Revived Lawsuit
description: The former wife of the hedge fund mogul Steven A. Cohen has a new lawyer in her bitter legal dispute with her former husband.

title: The Envelope, Please: Will Walker
description: Although Will Walker, who will attend Williams College, counts himself lucky, he encourages other students with unfulfilled college plans to wait: the universe usually has a way of working things o

title: A Gala That Skipped the Kitchen Sink
description: Trying to trot out an entire stable of stars and preview the many ballet war horses that dominate an eight-week season, American Ballet Theaters opening-night galas can be tedious affairs. The one at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday, though, was significantly less wearisome. The excerpts were fewer and more varied, and they were grounded by two full works of the highest quality and exhilaration: Alexei Ratmanskys Symphony #9 and Balanchines Symphony in C.

title: Lawyers Press Pentagon to Abide by Detainee Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Lawyers for a detainee at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, who is scheduled to be transferred out of the prison in December under a 2011 plea deal have asked a judge to order the Pentagon to live up to its agreement, recently unsealed tribunal papers show.

title: Caravaggio
description: Inside the restaurant on the Italian Upper East Side.

title: Front-Runner in Pakistan Offers Truce, and Flowers
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans former and future prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, visited his main political rival, Imran Khan, at a Lahore hospital on Tuesday, and Mr. Sharif later said both leaders had vowed to work together without acrimony.

title: White-Linen Italian Civility
description: IN HIS LANDMARK STUDY FROM 1971, The Food of Italy, Waverley Root divided that nation into 19 distinct culinary regions. The book is a classic, its insights and prose recipes still tantalizing four decades later, but it contains a major oversight. Mr. Root says nothing at all about the Italian Upper East Side.

title: Start-Up Hopes to Help Freelance Writers Get Paid
description: It looks as if the futurists from the early days of the Internet got quite a bit wrong when it comes to business online. The idea that no one would pay for musicwas wrong. No one would buy books was also incorrect.And the idea that writers would have to work free in the face of so-called citizen journalists wasinaccurate, too.

title: Appeals Court Says Judge Went Too Far in Forcing Fire Dept. to Revamp Its Hiring
description: A federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled on Tuesday that the district court judge presiding over a long-running lawsuit against the New York Fire Department claiming discrimination against minority applicants went too far in forcing the department to revamp its hiring process, and that he had raised enough doubts about his impartiality to require assigning a key part of the case to another judge.

title: Corporate Irresponsibility? Fashions Hidden Cost in Bangladeshs Garment Industry
description: A look at two companies with different responses to the building collapse in Bangladesh.

title: Dispute at JPMorgan Grows, for All the Wrong Reasons
description: The fight over whether to split the jobs of chief executive and chairman at JPMorgan Chase is a silly one. Thats not just because its a lot of drama over something so unimportant in the scheme of things, but because it has turned into a backdoor referendum on one man, Jamie Dimon.

title: U.S. Budget Deficit Shrinks Far Faster Than Expected
description: WASHINGTON  Since the recession ended four years ago, the federal budget deficit has topped $1 trillion every year. But now the governments annual deficit is shrinking far faster than anyone in Washington expected, and perhaps even faster than many economists think is advisable for the health of the economy.

title: The Real Problem With Soccer
description: Few goals and fewer commercial breaks are not what is slowing soccer's growth, according to William C. Rhoden. Racism is, and the true lovers of the game -- its fans -- are the ones who can save it.

title: Video: The Real Problem With Soccer
description: Few goals and fewer commercial breaks are not what is slowing soccers growth. Racism is, and the true lovers of the game  its fans  are the ones who can save it.

title: Video: High-Speed Look at Trade Centers Spire Installation
description: What could be cooler than the dizzy-making nine-minute spires-eye-view video of the spire being installed atop 1 World Trade Center last Friday?

title: Off the Menu
description: Headliner

title: Familiar Forest, Made New
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Sometimes you cant perceive the true beauty of something until youve seen it naked. This observation probably doesnt apply to most human beings, especially those over 25. But it certainly holds true for a certain venerated, usually overdressed musical that has been kicking around for a quarter-century.

title: Photo Replay: May 14
description: A view of the day in sports, from a baseball field in New York with Prince Harry to the Italian Open with Roger Federer.

title: Some Kinds of Prisons Dont Need Any Bars
description: So what are you in for? Patricia asks Sean. These two are inmates, as Patricia might say, not in a jail but in a nursing home in Ireland. But what theyre in for  infirmity (Patricia) and old age (Sean)  matters less to the playwright Deirdre Kinahan in These Halcyon Days than who they are and who they were, their accommodations, regrets and rebellions.

title: California Governor Issues Cautious Budget, Disappointing Democrats
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Gov. Jerry Brown on Tuesday proposed a smaller budget than projected earlier this year and repeatedly cautioned against new spending, disappointing Democratic lawmakers who had hoped that rising state tax revenues would finance social programs after years of austerity.

title: T-Mobile USA Bumps Up Price of iPhone by $50
description: When T-Mobile USA first started offering the iPhone 5, it had the cheapest deal in town: $100 up front (not including the monthly bill)  which is half the cost of the iPhone on a rival network like AT&T or Verizon Wireless. But now the cost of the iPhone on T-Mobile is closer to the competition, at $150.

title: No, Hes Not, but the Bullies Still Wont Give Him a Break
description: Every day of high school is a fresh hell for the unhappy young hero of queerSpawn, a slight but compassionate and bleakly funny play by Mallery Avidon that opened at Here Arts Center on Tuesday night. If one tormentor is not spray-painting a gay slur across his locker in vivid neon, another is shoving him in a big cardboard box and taping it shut.

title: Feeling For | Asprey Private Collection Handbags
description: As a second act to her debut collection for Asprey last summer, the accessories designer Katie Hillier unveils another line of handbags, called the Private Collection, for the English jewelry and leather goods brand early next month. Hillier worked with a small team to create 41 bespoke pieces that, she says, appeal to clients that are looking for a unique piece of art. Influenced by hand-painted mosaic motifs, Hillier used a rainbow of exotic skins and semiprecious stones to dress up the simple, timeless designs. One standout is this Rothkoesque bag in crocodile with over four carats of diamonds.

title: Vagabonds, Sharing Wine and Bonhomie, Traverse Their Inner Worlds
description: Most rudest people I have ever met!

title: Revolutionary Coming-of-Age in Wisconsin
description: Pinkolandia runs a tad long and talks a little too much and could use a slightly sharper plot. Yet Im not sure how much Id change about this ambitious and often beautiful new play.

title: A Museum Plot for Green-Wood Cemetery
description: Death may not be pretty, but for 175 years many families have chosen a grave site at the bucolic Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn to help make eternity a charming affair.

title: Church Plans Art Pavilion at Biennale
description: VATICAN CITY  It commissioned the Sistine Chapel, countless portraits of popes and even Matisses chapel in Vence, France. Now the Roman Catholic Church will sponsor its first pavilion at the Venice Biennale, featuring the Czech photographer Josef Koudelka, the Milan-based multimedia group Studio Azzurro and the artist Lawrence Carroll.

title: Leak Investigations Are an Assault on the Press, and on Democracy, Too
description: This was supposed to be the administration of unprecedented transparency. President Obama promised that when he took office, and the White Houses Web site says so on this very day. It reads:

title: The Envelope Please: Sush Krishnamoorthy
description: In the beginning, my dream of attending college in the United States with limited funds seemed to be just that: a dream. However, I am grateful to have had friends and family who were supportive.

title: An Opera Star, Freckles, Blemishes and All
description: A behind-the-scenes look at an Aix-en-Provence staging of Verdis Traviata, the impressionistic, handsomely shot Becoming Traviata, directed by Philippe Bziat, may not be fully satisfying as a documentary. But it has what any good movie needs: a star  the ever-game soprano Natalie Dessay.

title: Wigs and Whips, Songs and Maces, and Legislation, Too
description: It was with a leaden sense of duty that I dragged myself  through a stinging March snowfall, no less  to the National Theater to see This House, by James Graham. What lay before me was nearly three hours of re-enactments of life in the House of Commons four decades ago. What did I know from parliamentary politics, especially from the 1970s?

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Hidden Online Audiences and Cicada Math
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: A Scruffy Hound That Money Cant Buy
description: The beast at the center of Old Dog  a Tibetan tale of pride, principle and family priorities  is one of the sorriest-looking creatures ever to grace a movie screen. Scruffy, matted and with a tail that resembles a filthy feather duster, this forlorn specimen, known locally as a nomad mastiff, is nevertheless the catalyst for an astonishing tug of war.

title: Revisiting a Previvor
description: In 2007, Deborah Lindner, then 33, underwent an elective double mastectomy after finding out she had a gene carrying a high risk of breast cancer. Six years later, Dr. Lindner offers an update.

title: Q. & A. | Daft Punks Secret Weapon: Producer Todd Edwards
description: The storied house music producer Todd Edwards is two decades into a groundbreaking career in which he pioneered the cut-up sample technique that gave birth to the U.K. garage style of dance music, earning him the nickname Todd the God with aficionados. But it feels like hes only been warming up the decks. A frequent collaborator with Daft Punk  he wrote and sang Face to Face from their 2001 album Discovery  Mr. Edwards reunites with the helmet-wearing pair for a track on their much-anticipated album Random Access Memories, out May 21 (and streaming now on iTunes).

title: Google Expected to Start a Competitor to Spotify
description: Google is set to introduce a subscription music feature to compete against fast-growing streaming services like Spotify, according to several people briefed on its plans.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Bangladesh, Turkey, Kenya and Iraq.

title: Management Flaws at I.R.S. Cited in Tea Party Scrutiny
description: WASHINGTON  An inspector generals report issued Tuesday blamed ineffective Internal Revenue Service management in the failure to stop employees from singling out conservative groups for added scrutiny. Congressional aides, meanwhile, sought to determine whether the Obama administrations knowledge of the effort extended beyond the I.R.S.

title: Living in Mariners Harbor, S.I.
description: The residential and industrial coexist in this corner of New York City.

title: Coastal Perch; Varied Nests on Offer
description: The city trend toward transforming decayed industrial shoreline into public space has not yet made landfall in the northwestern Staten Island neighborhood of Mariners Harbor. But Jos Marrero, betting that the tides of gentrification wash over every area eventually, moved here a decade ago from a two-bedroom rental in Coney Island.

title: In the Living Room, Still No Sign of Google
description: If you walk into my living room you will see a standard, flat television surrounded by a dozen gadgets. Theres a Microsoft Xbox, a Sony PlayStation, the Apple TV, and theres even a computer with a wireless mouse. But you might not recognize one of the gadgets, a round black ball that I havent used in a year: theNexus Q made by Google.

title: Is the I.R.S. an Independent Agency?
description: There is no evidence that President Obama knew about the Internal Revenue Services recent practice of singling out conservative groups that applied for tax-exempt status, subjecting them to unusually detailed questioning. Calling the reports outrageous, he has promised to make sure that we find out exactly what happened on this. Thats as it should be. But the president misspoke on Monday when he said that the I.R.S. was an independent agency. It is not.

title: Billie Sol Estes, Texas Con Man Whose Fall Shook Up Washington, Dies at 88
description: Billie Sol Estes, a fast-talking Texas swindler who made millions, went to prison and captivated America for years with mind-boggling agricultural scams, payoffs to politicians and bizarre tales of covered-up killings and White House conspiracies, was found dead on Tuesday at his home in Granbury, Tex. He was 88.

title: Syrian Rebel Reportedly Defends Sinking Teeth Into Dead Soldiers Flesh on Camera
description: A Syrian rebel commander who appeared to bite into the flesh of a government soldiers corpse in a horrifying video clip posted on YouTube this week defended his actions in an interview with Time magazine on Tuesday. The rebel, Khalid al-Hamad, known by the nom de guerre Abu Sakkar, confirmed that he sank his teeth into an internal organ that he had laboriously carved out of the dead soldiers chest as a colleague recorded the scene. Our slogan, he said, is an eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth.

title: If Youre a Tree-Hungry Beetle, Run
description: The tree-devouring Asian longhorned beetle has not yet been driven from the gates of the city, but, by Jove, pest-control authorities have it on the run. The state announced on Tuesday that the beetle had been eradicated from Manhattan and Staten Island.

title: Greek Civil Servants Walk Out Over Ban on Teachers Strike
description: ATHENS  Greek civil servants walked off the job on Tuesday to protest the governments use of an emergency law to ban a planned strike by teachers. But a popular rally in the capital was the smallest in several months, a sign that public support for the countrys once-mighty unions may be dwindling.

title: Washington Projects Invite the Small Local Investor
description: The practice of crowdfunding real estate is spreading from South America  where Prodigy Network recently raised around $239 million from 3,100 Colombians to build a 66-story skyscraper in Bogot  to New York, where the developer Urban Muse is hoping to offer a slice of a Brooklyn Bridge Park project to the public.

title: Three Foes Unite to Keep Wrestling in Olympics
description: UNITED NATIONS  Rarely, if ever these days, do you hear the United States making nice with Russia and Iran at the United Nations.

title: Subscribers Fear Bloomberg Is Becoming Their Rival
description: Long thought of as a company that serves the needs of Wall Street firms, Bloomberg L.P. is quietly becoming more like them, moving recently into businesses that have been the domain of the largest banks.

title: Inspector Generals Report on I.R.S. Audits
description: A report offered new details on the scope and duration of the Internal Revenue Services effort to target conservative non-profit groups for scrutiny.

title: Brooklyn Race Grows; So Does Security
description: When New York Road Runners reinvented the Brooklyn Half Marathon, turning a sleepy March race into an event that will host about 25,000 competitors this weekend, it was meant as an economic boon to Coney Island. But recent events have turned it into something bigger, including a much larger security challenge in the wake of the Boston Marathon bombings last month.

title: A Better Picture
description: The budget deficit is now projected to be less severe than it was previously and much less than it has been in recent years.

title: As Thieves Troll Spanish Farmland, Villagers Begin Patrols
description: ALBELDA, Spain  Jos Bri finds it hard to sleep these days. Sometimes when he wakes up in the middle of the night, he drives out to his farmland a few miles from the center of this tiny village just to make sure everything is all right.

title: Bob Sickinger, Chicago Stage Innovator, Dies at 86
description: Bob Sickinger, a director whose mostly nonprofessional productions in the 1960s seeded a Chicago theater scene that evolved into one of the countrys greatest, died on May 9 at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 86.

title: An Atrocity in Syria, With No Victim Too Small
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  After dragging 46 bodies from the streets near his hometown on the Syrian coast, Omar lost count. For four days, he said, he could not eat, remembering the burned body of a baby just a few months old; a fetus ripped from a womans belly; a friend lying dead, his dog still standing guard.

title: For Insurers, No Doubts on Climate Change
description: If there were one American industry that would be particularly worried about climate change it would have to be insurance, right?

title: South Carolina: Sex Surgery Unnecessary, Lawsuit Alleges
description: A Southern legal advocacy group has claimed in a lawsuit that the State of South Carolina should not have surgically altered a 16-month-old child in its custody who was born with both male and female genitalia. The suit, filed in both state and federal courts, was brought on behalf of the childs adoptive parents and is intended to restrict the practice of medically unnecessary sex assignment surgeries on infants, said lawyers with the Southern Poverty Law Center. The child was in the care of the South Carolina Department of Social Services when doctors, in cooperation with social services employees, removed the childs male genitals. The child, now 8, identifies himself as a boy, according to his parents, Mark and Pam Crawford of Richland County. They disfigured him because they could not accept him for who he was, Mrs. Crawford said in a statement, not because he needed any surgery. Increasingly, doctors and those who were born with a condition once called hermaphroditism recommend that children be assigned a gender at birth but postpone surgery until they are old enough to choose. A spokeswoman for the states Social Services Department said there would be no comment on pending legal action.

title: How They Do It Elsewhere
description: THE United States can boast that it has the worlds best basketball players, fighter jets and country and western singers. But hardly anyone would ever boast that the United States has the worlds best retirement system.

title: R. Donahue Peebles
description: Mr. Peebles, 53, is the chairman and chief executive of the Peebles Corporation, one of the largest African-American-owned development companies in the country. The company, which has its headquarters in Coral Gables, Fla., specializes in residential and hospitality developments.

title: Virginia Tech President to Retire
description: Charles Steger, the Virginia Tech University president who led the college during the 2007 mass shooting, this week announced plans to retire as soon as a successor is found. Dr. Steger, 65, has had a long Virginia Tech career, as a student, instructor, department head, dean  at 33, the youngest architecture dean in the nation  vice president and, since 2000, president. After the shooting, in which a student, Seung-Hui Cho, killed 32 people, Mr. Steger was criticized for not warning the campus quickly. Next month, in a case brought by the parents of two slain students, the State Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether he should stand trial for his actions during the massacre.

title: Afghan Commandos Step Up Their Combat Role
description: AT A CLASSIFIED COMMANDO BASE, Afghanistan  One day this month, a pair of Russian Mi-17 assault helicopters delivered two teams of Afghan commandos, their faces obscured by black masks, in a touch-and-go landing at this camp in a lush valley encircled by frosty peaks about 50 miles from Kabul.

title: Georgia Tech Will Offer a Masters Degree Online
description: Starting in the fall, the Georgia Institute of Technology, together with AT&T and Udacity, an online education venture, will offer a masters degree in computer science that can be earned entirely through so-called massive open online courses, or MOOCs. While the courses would be available free online to the general public, students seeking the degree would have to have a bachelors degree in computer science, and pay tuition that is expected to be less than $7,000 Initially, the program will be limited to a few hundred students from AT&T and Georgia Tech corporate affiliates, but enrollment is then expected to expand in the fall of 2014.

title: ABCs Programming
description: The Timess Bill Carter discusses ABCs programming, after the broadcaster unveiled its plans to advertisers.

title: Chuck Muncie, Troubled N.F.L. Star, Dies at 60
description: Chuck Muncie, who blended speed and power to become one of the N.F.L.s leading running backs of the late 1970s and early 80s, but whose career was cut short by drug abuse, died on Monday at his home in Perris, Calif. He was 60.

title: Iranian Officials Threaten Two Candidates for the Presidency
description: TEHRAN  Iranian officials on Monday issued blunt threats of violence against two last-minute registrants for the June 14 presidential election whose unwanted presence on the ballot has angered the countrys governing establishment.

title: Pleased by Effort, if Not by Ending, Isles Pledge to Build on a Breakout Season
description: As the ice at Nassau Coliseum melted and workers used heavy machinery to dismantle its hockey rink, the Islanders resolutely spoke of building for the future.

title: Minnesota: Governor Signs Same-Sex Marriage Into Law
description: Gov. Mark Dayton signed a measure Tuesday giving gay couples the right to marry, making Minnesota the 12th state in the nation to permit same-sex marriage. During a signing ceremony outside the State Capitol in St. Paul, where thousands of Minnesotans gathered and cheered in 90-degree weather, Mr. Dayton, a Democrat, praised the choices of state lawmakers as changing the course of history.

title: French Lawmakers Loosen Labor Rules in a Victory for the President
description: PARIS  The French legislature gave President Franois Hollande an important victory on Tuesday, passing a modest loosening of the countrys labor code even as Mr. Hollandes foreign minister, Laurent Fabius, revealed severe tensions within the Socialist government by criticizing the stewardship of the economics and finance minister, Pierre Moscovici.

title: Pentagon Furloughs Are Set
description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, left, announced Tuesday that most civilian Pentagon employees would be ordered to take unpaid furloughs of up to 11 days between July 8 and the end of September. The measure, which is a response to across-the-board spending reductions called sequestration, is less punitive than plans that would have seen Pentagon civilians forced to take 14 to 22 days of unpaid leave. The department has been doing everything possible to reduce this shortfall while ensuring we can defend the nation, sustain wartime operations and preserve D.o.D.s most critical asset  our world-class civilian and military personnel, Mr. Hagel said.

title: Transactions
description: Recent Sale

title: Wheeler, Mets Top Pitching Prospect, to Miss Next Start
description: ST. LOUIS  The proper level of concern will become clearer Wednesday, but regardless, it was precisely the type of injury news the Mets and their fans did not want to hear.

title: A Full House at an Older Age
description: Rebecca Gawboy, 60, and her husband, Jim, 76, take care of 12 adopted children.

title: Bad Enough
description: Things are bad enough in the food world that we dont need to resort to hyperbole to be worried or even alarmed.

title: Filling Up an Empty Nest
description: RETIRING from work? Then it might be time to think about raising a family. Some brave older adults are turning the idea of retirement on its head by choosing to adopt children  this when many of their peers are traveling, socializing, taking up intellectual or entrepreneurial pursuits, or just plain relaxing.

title: No Frills on the Road Back
description: LANDISVILLE, Pa.  There were a lot of tennis tournament essentials missing on Sunday at the $10,000 U.S.T.A. Pro Circuit tournament at Hempfield Recreation Center here.

title: Univision Resets Sights After a Ratings Victory
description: AT its upfront presentation on Tuesday, Univision continued to promote its dominance of the Hispanic media landscape in the hope of attracting more advertising dollars to the networks expanding empire.

title: Entertainment News
description: BARBARA WALTERSS announcement this week that she would soon bring her long career to a close elicited the obligatory tributes to her as a trailblazer for women and an exemplary figure in broadcast journalism.

title: A Visit to Yemens Zoo
description: SANA, Yemen

title: A Long Ride Toward a New China
description: Every summer, the blogger Tiger Temple bikes around China to report on rural news stories censored by state-run media.

title: Doubts About Restricting Salt
description: After years of warnings to cut sodium consumption to reduce heart attacks and strokes, it is disturbing to learn how little evidence exists that such reductions would actually be beneficial to health. There is even emerging evidence that some groups in the population could suffer harm from levels that are too low.

title: The Knicks One-Man Play Badly Needs Stagehands
description: INDIANAPOLIS

title: Sony Meets Outspoken Activist Investor, but Courtesy Reigns
description: For a hedge fund manager whose fame first came on writing invective-filled letters, Daniel S. Loebs latest missive was a model of politeness.

title: A Long Ride Toward a New China
description: Every summer, the 59-year-old Chinese blogger Zhang Shihe rides his bicycle thousands of miles to the plateaus, deserts and hinterlands of North Central China. In this Op-Doc video, we meet Mr. Zhang, known to his many followers online as Tiger Temple, as he goes to great lengths to document the stories of struggling rural villagers whose voices are seldom heard in Chinas state-monitored media.

title: Brazilian Court Council Removes a Barrier to Same-Sex Marriage
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The council overseeing Brazils judiciary ruled on Tuesday that notary publics cannot refuse to perform same-sex marriage ceremonies, a decision that opens the way for gay couples across Latin Americas largest country to marry.

title: With Detroit Under State Control, Candidates Seek Posts Stripped of Power
description: DETROIT  Candidates seeking to become the next mayor of this deeply troubled city are calling it a historic election. They spend their days dashing around the potholed streets they hope to save, their schedules a tireless series of living-room meetings and church gatherings, nursing homes and barbershops.

title: Grotesque Speed for Florida Capital Cases
description: The Timely Justice Act, a grotesquely named bill passed by the Florida Legislature, could get to Gov. Rick Scott as soon as this week for him to sign into law. The measure would require a governor to sign a death warrant within 30 days of a review of a capital conviction by the State Supreme Court, and the state would be required to execute the defendant within 180 days of the warrant.

title: In Role Reversal, Goldman Chief Advises Dimon
description: Jamie Dimon has consulted lawyers, public relation experts and bankers as JPMorgan Chase wrestles with the fallout from a multibillion-dollar trading loss. But the bank chief has received advice from an unexpected corner: Lloyd C. Blankfein of rival Goldman Sachs.

title: In World of Wrestling, Trying to Keep It Real
description: Dave Meltzer was gravely ill, but the phone would not stop ringing. It was December 1993, and someone had circulated the number of the hospital where Meltzer was being treated for a ruptured appendix, the delayed diagnosis of which had caused a life-threatening abdominal inflammation.

title: Uninvited Guest Gives Japans Business Culture a Jolt
description: TOKYO  Devil. Vulture. Saboteur.

title: A Roller Coaster Comes Down
description: The submerged Jet Star roller coaster in Seaside Heights, an iconic image of the destruction of the Jersey Shore from Hurricane Sandy, was dismantled on Tuesday.

title: Pakistans Hopeful Election
description: The news from Pakistan is often terrible, as it was last week when the government expelled a New York Times bureau chief. There was also violence leading up to the parliamentary election over the weekend. At least Pakistan did manage to have an election in which about 60 percent of voters participated and has achieved a peaceful transition of power in a country where coups have predominated. The election was a welcome repudiation of militants who are trying to overthrow the state.

title: Spying on The Associated Press
description: The Obama administration, which has a chilling zeal for investigating leaks and prosecuting leakers, has failed to offer a credible justification for secretly combing through the phone records of reporters and editors at The Associated Press in what looks like a fishing expedition for sources and an effort to frighten off whistle-blowers.

title: Making a Move Abroad, and Working There, Too
description: WHEN Patrice Wynne shuttered her independent bookstore, Gaia, in Berkeley, Calif., and retired, she knew three things. She wanted to move to a place where she could slow down the tempo of her life, and it was cheaper to live, but where she could continue to work in some fashion.

title: Rangers, Bruins and a Rivalry That Once Raged
description: Yankees vs. Red Sox, Giants vs. Patriots, Knicks vs. Celtics. Postseason clashes among those teams in recent years have poured fuel on the New York-Boston rivalry.

title: Austerity in the New York Review of Books
description: I have been spending my time doing my best to take a break from the alleged real world, and will continue doing so for a bit. I should, however, let readers know that my longish-form essay on the great austerity debacle is now up at The New York Review of Books.

title: Test Gas Attack Is Coming to the Subway, This Time With Fair Notice
description: Rolling along the back roads and highways of the Internet, a picture of a poster hints faintly at sinister doings underground.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 15, 2013
description: How can we reach a point of national forgiveness?

title: After a Rough Move, a Much Easier One
description: It is possible that teams should stop underestimating the opinion of Hisashi Iwakuma. As the Seattle Mariners starting pitcher continues to prove his critics wrong, he is making any number of baseball people look foolish for doubting his ability.

title: Granderson Is Back Under Lights, but Out in Left Field
description: While his teammates considered Tuesdays matchup against the Seattle Mariners only another May game at Yankee Stadium, Curtis Granderson anxiously prepared as if there would be pageantry similar to opening day.

title: Doctor Avoids Death Penalty in Murders at His Clinic
description: Kermit Gosnell, the doctor convicted of murdering babies after failed abortions in his Philadelphia clinic, avoided the death penalty on Tuesday by agreeing to a sentence of life in prison without parole.

title: Taking a Closer Look at a Proposal to Limit Tax-Deferred Savings
description: IN his 2014 budget, President Obama proposed limiting how much money a person could put into a retirement account on a tax-deferred basis.

title: Cascading Confessions
description: Two of the hot topics trending on Twitter Tuesday were Angelina Jolie and the I.R.S.

title: Corrections: May 15, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: What Worries You, Masters You
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Im not sure why it took me as long as it did to see the theme here, but when I did, I thought it was very clever and a bit different than the usual hump day fare.

title: 4% Rule for Retirement Withdrawals Is Golden No More
description: ONE thing most retirees want to avoid is outliving their money. Since the mid-1990s many of them have relied on a staple of retirement planning known as the 4 percent rule to avoid that. Although the name says 4 percent, the rule is that if retirees withdraw 4.5 percent of their savings every year, adjusted for inflation, their nest egg should last 30 years, the length of time generally used for retirement planning.

title: And the Award Goes to...
Cyberbullied Businesses
description: To the Editor:

title: The I.R.S. Scandal: Criticism From All Sides
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Lindgren, 89, Ballet Dancer and College Dean, Is Dead
description: Robert Lindgren, a Canadian-born dancer who appeared with major American ballet companies before becoming the founding dean of the influential dance school at the North Carolina School of the Arts, died on Friday at his home in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 89.

title: Taking the Measure of Risk
description: BIG market moves always give investors a bit of portfolio vertigo. Are you too close to the edge in terms of risk? Could you get burned again as in 2008?

title: Army Sergeant Is Accused of Sexual Abuse
description: WASHINGTON  An Army sergeant who served as a sexual assault prevention and response coordinator at Fort Hood, Tex., is under investigation for allegations of pandering, abusive sexual contact, assault and maltreatment of subordinates, Pentagon officials said late Tuesday.

title: Gone, but Still Linked to the Home Office
description: A FEW years after John McGowan, a former contracts negotiator at Hewlett-Packard, took early retirement in 2006 at age 59, a friend persuaded him to join the H.P. Agilent Retired Employees Club-Bay Area, one of more than a dozen H.P. retiree clubs in the United States and abroad. Last fall he became president of the 1,300-member group, whose activities include lunches, hikes, bowling, golf outings and community service.

title: Special Parking Rules in New York City
description: On Wednesday and Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City because of Shavuot. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Bigger Knicks Fall Just as Hard
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The stakes were higher, the desperation greater and the Knicks bigger, or at least as big as the laws of physiology and N.B.A. rosters would permit. They upsized. They expanded. They tinkered. Mostly, they hoped  for a turnaround, for a spiritual lift, for some magic solution to match the might of the Indiana Pacers.

title: To Run Victim Fund, Boston Calls on the Specialist
description: BOSTON  In the aftermath of a national tragedy, Kenneth R. Feinberg has become the essential man.

title: John LaMontaine, Pulitzer-Winning Composer, Dies at 93
description: John LaMontaine, a Pulitzer Prize-winning American composer whose works were performed widely and included the orchestral music for John F. Kennedys presidential inauguration, died on April 29 at his home in Hollywood, Calif. He was 93.

title: U.S. Now Paints Apple as Ringmaster in Its Lawsuit on E-Book Price-Fixing
description: WASHINGTON  The e-mail, from Steve Jobs of Apple to James Murdoch of News Corporation, reads as if one old sport were trying to cajole another into joining a caper: Throw in with Apple and see if we can all make a go of this to create a real mainstream e-books market at $12.99 and $14.99.

title: Covering the Rising Cost of Long-Term Care
description: FEW sticker shocks are as bracing as the price of hiring someone to help with the simplest activities  bathing, toilet use, dressing, eating and moving. Whether recovering from surgery or a stroke or suffering a chronic illness like arthritis, those needing skilled help need deep pockets indeed.

title: Suit by a Prosecutors Rival Seeks to Block a TV Show
description: The news that Charles J. Hynes, the longtime Brooklyn district attorney, had provided television producers access to his office to film a six-part series provoked an immediate outburst of criticism from rival candidates that it would give him an unfair edge in the Sept. 10 primary. On Tuesday, one opponent filed a lawsuit asking a state court to block CBS from broadcasting the series, calling it an unlawful campaign contribution and saying it would cause irreparable harm to his campaign.

title: Turning Hobbies Into Profits, With a Little Help
description: THE newest breed of entrepreneur may not be the digital whiz kid, but the retirement-age grandparent looking to replenish savings, become his or her own boss or just keep busy.

title: House to Vote Yet Again on Repealing Health Care Law
description: WASHINGTON  The 37th time wont be the charm. But House Republicans are charging forward anyway this week on a vote to repeal President Obamas signature health care overhaul, which will put the number of times they have tried to eliminate, defund or curtail the law past the three-dozen mark.

title: Not Moving on, but Still Starting a New Chapter
description: NOAH AND BERNA LEVINE were making those steps toward retirement two years ago  trying to figure out where they wanted to live. They had moved to Marietta, Ga., about 30 years before from their native New Jersey with three young children. Mr. Levine, 62, had taken a job with the Atlanta Jewish Federation, and Mrs. Levine figured her teaching skills would quickly land her a job, which they did soon enough.

title: Two Musical Minds Seek a Different Kind of Mogul
description: LOS ANGELES  The record producer Jimmy Iovine and his business partner Dr. Dre have a keen eye for talent. Between them, the two have jump-started the careers of stars ranging from Lady Gaga to 50 Cent to the Black Eyed Peas.

title: Celebrating, in Spite of the Risk
description: NEW ORLEANS  Each year in the weeks leading up to Mothers Day, when the members of the Original Big 7 Social Aid and Pleasure Club drew up the sheet outlining their parades route through the back streets of town, they would include a warning: Leave your guns and foolishness at home.

title: Back to School, but for the Degree, Not Just the Fun
description: SCHOOL was out, and Jack Kaufmann, who teaches 8th and 9th grade Latin at the elite Hewitt School in Manhattan, was on his way to catch the train home to Westchester.

title: Big Forum? For Cuomo, Its Always a Summit
description: ALBANY  Some call them conferences. Others prefer forums. For old-timers, of course, they were just meetings.

title: A Slim Travel Budget, but Otherwise No Limits
description: THE first time I video-chatted with my 67-year-old mother, she was staying at a youth hostel in South Africa. As we talked, young, tanned adventurers crossed the screen behind her. Only $19 a night. What a deal, right? she exclaimed, and then called over a woman half her age whom she had been biking with that day.

title: Game 4: Knicks vs. Pacers
description: Roy Hibbert and the Pacers handed the Knicks another loss to take a 3-1 lead in their Eastern Conference semifinal.

title: Archbishop Presses Cuomo Over Abortion
description: ALBANY  Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan declined on Tuesday to say whether Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was a Catholic in good standing, as he ratcheted up his criticism of the governors continued advocacy for abortion rights.

title: Shumpert, Kidd, Martin: 61 Minutes and 0 Points
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The defining number for the Knicks in Game 4  and perhaps the series at large  was zero, the astounding absence of any offensive production from three of their key supporting role players: Iman Shumpert, Jason Kidd and Kenyon Martin.

title: Record Auction Price for Barnett Newman, $43.8 Million, Is Set at Sothebys
description: In a hushed salesroom at Sothebys on Tuesday night, a packed audience watched intently as six bidders fought over Barnett Newmans Onement VI, a deep blue abstract composition from 1953. The winner, a telephone bidder speaking Italian, ended up paying $43.8 million, a record price for the artists work at auction  beating out the previous record of $22.4 million, paid just a year ago for another canvas in the same series. Faint applause could be heard from the onlookers.

title: Lottery Numbers
E-Book Sales a Boon to Publishers in 2012
description: E-book sales, especially in the thriving romance genre, gave the book business a lift in 2012, according to a survey of publishers released Wednesday.

title: Grandersons Return Steps to the Side of the Yankees Comeback Victory
description: The Yankees have cobbled together a first-place team with an offense of spare parts, a Frankenstein roster of sorts, while several of their stars are on the disabled list.

title: When Athletic Shoes Cause Injury
description: Sometimes innovative science requires innovative machinery, like a moveable, four-legged robotic sled that can wear shoes, a contraption recently developed and deployed by researchers at the University of Calgary to test whether grippy athletic shoes affect injury risk.

title: Patterns of Changes in Health Insurance
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: For Mets, It Seems Like 10 Things After Another
description: ST. LOUIS  A desolate feeling seemed to envelop the Mets on Tuesday night.

title: Word of the Day | adjutant
description: adjutant \a-j-tnt\ noun

title: Fatal Encounter With Police Is Caught on Video, but Kept From the Public
description: LOS ANGELES  When Maria Melendez emerged from Kern Medical Center in Bakersfield, Calif., just before midnight last Tuesday, she said, she heard screams that have kept her awake at night for an entire week.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (13) GREAT ZEBRA EXODUS In its final episode of the season, Nature travels to the Kalahari Desert in Botswana, where 20,000 zebras go in search of grass and water each year in a trek across the lunarlike landscape of the arid Makgadikgadi Pans. This documentary from the husband-and-wife filmmakers Adrian Bailey and Robyn Keene-Young views the journey through a single family: a stallion, its three mares and their offspring, which will walk more than 2,500 miles to feed themselves.

title: News Quiz | May 15, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Meet the Upwardly Mobile Middle-Class Indian
description: Yogesh Chile is the real face of Indias new middle class. Mr. Chile, 30, earns the equivalent of $500 a month supplying sand to construction sites in Mumbai, and after decades of urban poverty and living in the slums, his family has finally broken into the lower end of Indias middle class.

title: Taiwan Recalls Its Envoy in Manila Over a Killing
description: BEIJING  Taiwan announced the withdrawal of its representative in Manila on Wednesday and said it had stopped accepting applications for Filipino workers, a retaliatory step for the killing of a Taiwanese fisherman by the Philippine Coast Guard last week.

title: IHT Quick Read: May 15
description: NEWS As the United States and Russia work to organize peace talks next month between the Syrian government and its opponents, the ever more extreme carnage of combat makes the prospect of reconciliation seem more remote. Anne Barnard and Hania Mourtada report from Beirut.

title: Euro Zone Politics Hinder Response as Slump Persists
description: PARIS  Europe slipped deeper into a widespread recession, according to data released Wednesday. But when European heads of state meet next week in Brussels, no big announcements about plans to stimulate growth are expected.

title: Test Yourself | Math, May 15, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article Two Promising Places to Live, 1,200 Light-Years From Earth.

title: Cameron Survives Challenge on Europe Policies, but Vote Is Closer Than Expected
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron survived a potentially humiliating challenge to his policies toward the European Union on Wednesday by a closer margin in Parliament than had been forecast, illuminating the depth of dissent within his party over an issue that has divided it for decades.

title: Angelina Jolies My Medical Choice
description: Note: As a general rule, we dont use Op-Eds for this feature  but, as a general rule, movie stars dont break news by writing them. Given the content of, and the response to, this piece, we thought an exception was warranted.

title: Honoring a Fallen Photographers Spirit
description: Toms Munita has won the second annual Getty Images and Chris Hondros Fund Award, and Bryan Denton was named a finalist. The award is a memorial to Chris Hondros, who was killed two years ago while photographing in Misurata, Libya.

title: When Has a Sports Team Most Disappointed You?
description: What sports teams do you follow or play for? How loyal a fan are you? What bitter defeats have they suffered, and how did you react? When have you been most disappointed by a team? Why?

title: Arctic Council Adds 6 Nations as Observer States, Including China
description: KIRUNA, Sweden  The Arctic Council agreed on Wednesday to expand to include six new nations, including China, as observer states, as a changing climate opens the Arctic to increasing economic and political competition.

title: The Early Word: Spreading
description: In Todays Times

title: The Long and Unacceptable Wait for a Veterans Benefit
description: We wrote last fall about a form of government assistance for aging veterans called the Aid and Attendance pension benefit (A&A), which reimburses veterans and their families for the costs of caregivers working in the home (including sons and daughters who are paid to be caregivers, though not spouses) or can be used to pay for assisted living or nursing home care. The benefit is worth as much as $2,019 monthly for a veteran and spouse, and up to $1,094 for the widow of a veteran.

title: Another College Search Outside the Familiar, This Time for a Roommate
description: Such a big part of my high school experience has been spent thinking about how I could prepare for the college application process.

title: The Silence of the Shams
description: NEW DELHI  Ten suicides, one murder, $5.5 billion in losses and more than 1,300 journalists without a job  the toll from one of Indias biggest Ponzi schemes continues to mount.

title: Daily Report: Prosecutors Say Apple Had Greater Role in Fixing E-Book Prices
description: The Justice Department said on Tuesday that Apple was the ringmaster in a conspiracy to fix e-books prices, a more direct leadership role than portrayed in the departments April 2012 antitrust lawsuit, Edward Wyatt and Nick Wingfield report in The New York Times.

title: HSBC Plans More Job Cuts in Effort to Save Up to $3 Billion
description: LONDON  After two years of far-reaching cost cuts and asset sales, HSBC said on Wednesday that it planned to find an additional $2 billion to $3 billion in savings by 2016 that would include the elimination of as many as 14,000 jobs.

title: Some Nissan NV200 Vans Will Wear Chevrolet Bow Ties
description: General Motors will begin selling Nissans small cargo van, with Chevrolet badging, by the end of 2014. In a joint announcement on Tuesday, G.M. and Nissan said they had signed an agreement for Nissan to produce the 2015 Chevrolet City Express, which is based on the Nissan NV200. The compact commercial vehicle is sold in many international markets, including the United States and Canada.

title: How a Fast-Growing Start-Up Practices Decision-Making
description: Last week in my post  If Practice Makes Perfect, Why Dont Companies Practice More?  I described the types of training programs and practice sessions that we use at H.Bloom.
