The comments that I received at the end of the column were especially insightful and offer a great segue to todays post.

title: Kobos New E-Reader Is Sharp, but Maybe Not Sharp Enough
description: Kobo has produced what it said was the highest-resolution e-ink reader, the Aura HD, which means it should have the best-looking screen, right?

title: The Nomads Kitchen
description: When The Hakka Cookbook appeared last year, I immediately set up a cooking date with its author, Linda Lau Anusasananan, who lives in the exotic and far-flung city of San Mateo, south of San Francisco.

title: Some of My Best Friends Are Germs
description: I can tell you the exact date that I began to think of myself in the first-person plural  as a superorganism, that is, rather than a plain old individual human being. It happened on March 7. Thats when I opened my e-mail to find a huge, processor-choking file of charts and raw data from a laboratory located at the BioFrontiers Institute at the University of Colorado, Boulder. As part of a new citizen-science initiative called the American Gut project, the lab sequenced my microbiome  that is, the genes not of me, exactly, but of the several hundred microbial species with whom I share this body. These bacteria, which number around 100 trillion, are living (and dying) right now on the surface of my skin, on my tongue and deep in the coils of my intestines, where the largest contingent of them will be found, a pound or two of microbes together forming a vast, largely uncharted interior wilderness that scientists are just beginning to map.

title: Drones Take Off in Silicon Valley
description: American skies arent supposed to open for another couple of years to drones flown by commercial operators, but theyre already getting liftoff with Silicon Valley investors.

title: British Water Utility Rejects Takeover Offer
description: LONDON  The British water utility Severn Trent rejected a takeover approach on Wednesday from a consortium of investment firms that could have valued the company at more than $8 billion.

title: Daft Punk Gets Human With a New Album
description: LOS ANGELES  Thomas Bangalter, half of the influential French dance-music act Daft Punk, has a house high in the Hollywood Hills here. He and his musical partner, Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo, divide their time between Los Angeles and Paris, where their families live. But for all their jet-setting, theres little evidence of rock star flash to be seen (well, apart from the Porsche that Mr. de Homem-Christo has parked in the driveway). Built in the midcentury style called post and beam, the bungalow exudes a subtle retro feel, with white carpeting, a cross section of a tree trunk as a coffee table, and a gravel fireplace in the living room. The swimming pool, a small square of radiant Hockney blue, is visible through the glass walls.

title: Q&A: Closing (or Merging) Two LinkedIn Accounts
description: Q.

title: Dimon and Blankfein, Foxhole Buddies
description: Jamie Dimon, wrestling with the fallout from JPMorgan Chases multibillion-dollar trading loss, has received advice from a rival, Lloyd C. Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Susanne Craig and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook. The two executives have talked privately a number of times in recent months about the challenges that Mr. Dimon is facing, people with knowledge of the relationship but not authorized to speak on the matter, have said.

title: Japanese Reactor Is Said to Stand on a Fault Line
description: TOKYO  Seismologists said Wednesday that a nuclear reactor in Tsuruga, in western Japan, stands above an active seismic fault, a finding that could lead to the first permanent shutdown of a reactor since the Fukushima crisis two years ago.

title: Science Tackles Mystery of the Teenage Brain
description: LONDON  Science may have split the atom and put a man on the moon but it has yet to solve the mysteries of the teenage brain.

title: Wednesday Reading: Discovering Frugal Toulouse, Despite the Holidays
A Window Concert in Brooklyn Heights
description: Dear Diary:

title: For His Latest Transformation, Shia LaBeouf Discusses His Short Film Haunted Love
description: Though theres been no shortage of talk in recent weeks about work that Shia LaBeouf didnt do, heres a look at something that this unpredictable actor did do. Mr. LaBeouf, 26, is better known for his acting roles in movies like Transformers, Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull and The Company You Keep, but he has also dabbled in the occasional bit of film directing, including his short films Maniac (with the hip-hop star Kid Cudi) and Born Villain (with Marilyn Manson).

title: Market Report | The G.M.T. Watch Makes a Comeback
description: Rolex debuted the first G.M.T. watch, which featured an additional hour hand to represent Greenwich Mean Time, in the 1950s. Pan Am pilots popularized the dual-time display, which allowed them to keep track of local time while flying across time zones, and inspired a slew of watchmakers to create their own G.M.T. products. Although theyve been less popular in recent years, a recent wave of releases shows that these watches are coming back in a big way. Here are 12 of the best newcomers.

title: Battlefield Update: The Fight for Isolated Government Outposts in Northern Syria
description: In recent weeks considerable public attention has turned to questions of whether government forces in Syria have used chemical weapons. And all the while, conventional fighting with conventional weapons  the dominant form of violence and source of killing in this and most every war of our time  has continued to rage. As world leaders and commentators of every stripe have debated President Obamas red line, there have been developments on the ground, which might herald tactical shifts and point to the verifiable, actual slog that is the Syrian civil war.

title: In Andhra, Maoist Rebels Pin Hopes on Memories of the Dead
description: On April 16, Maoist rebels, operating in the dense forests of central and eastern India received a major blow when security forces killed one of their senior commanders, along with his wife and seven other rebels in Chhattisgarh, very close to the border of Andhra Pradesh. The slain commander, Marri Ravi, alias Sudhakar, was entrusted by the outlawed rebel group Communist Party of India (Maoist) to revive its movement in Andhra after the rebels were crushed seven years ago in their erstwhile bastion following a sustained military operation against them.

title: Bank of England Raises Outlook for British Economy
description: LONDON  After five years of dire warnings about the state of the British economy, the governor of the Bank of England raised the outlook for growth on Wednesday and said a recovery was in sight.

title: Krawcheck Agrees to Buy the Womens Network 85 Broads
description: Sallie L. Krawcheck, a former executive of Bank of America and Citigroup, has agreed to buy 85 Broads, a global organization that supports women.

title: The Daddy Business Trip
description: I was in a pile of men on the floor of a suite at the Ritz-Carlton in Laguna Niguel, Calif., a wineglass in one hand and a remote in the other. My pilemates brandished cocktails and bonbons. One of them had his head lodged in the open minibar. Two dozen fellow conference-goers surrounded us, their iPhone cameras flashing at the slovenly heap. Isnt this what business trips are all about?

title: What Were Reading
description: The Guardian: Sometimes, Emma Sturgess argues, white bread is the right bread.  Jeff Gordinier

title: A Team Approach to Get Students College Ready
description: When Parker Sheffy, a first-year teacher in the Bronx Leadership Academy II, a high school in the South Bronx, talks shop with friends who are also new teachers, he often hears about the problems they are facing: students not showing up to class on time, not understanding their work, not doing homework. Im thinking: I dont have that problem I dont have that problem Sheffy recalled. In his ninth grade integrated algebra class, he estimates that 80 to 90 percent are on track to pass the Regents exam, more than double last years figure.

title: Building a Playground
description: As the wildly successful Goodnight, Goodnight, Construction Site has shown, stories about trucks need not be tough. There can be warm, fuzzy elements amid the concrete and scrap metal. Even a teddy bear can find its way in. Perhaps theres just something appealing about the juxtaposition of soft, fluffy animals and heavy-metal loaders, which feature in two new picture books this season. In both Construction Kitties, by Judy Sue Goodwin Sturges, with illustrations by Shari Halpern, and Dig, Dogs, Dig, by James Horvath, a crew of smiling pets get to work building  what else?  a playground.

title: Statement by the Richmond County District Attorney Regarding Vito J. Lopez
description: Read the full statement from Daniel M. Donovan, Jr., the Richmond County District Attorney, concerning the investigation into Vito J. Lopez

title: As Larger British Rivals Perk Up, a Heralded Small Bank Stumbles
description: Just as larger banks in Britain are recovering from the financial crisis, a smaller one championed by lawmakers as an alternative to institutions like Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland is floundering, complicating the governments plan to shake up the industry and testing its new regulatory system.

title: About That Debt Crisis? Never Mind
description: Link fixed

title: CBSs Schedule Adds 4 Comedies, Each Guarded by a Successful One
description: Four new comedies are coming to the CBS schedule in the fall, each guarded by comedies that are already successful, like How I Met Your Mother and The Big Bang Theory, the network announced on Wednesday morning.

title: Why Retirement Savings Are Falling Short
description: Its not just the recession that has set back Americans retirement savings, a new survey from Ameriprise Financial says.

title: Report Finds Lawmaker Was Shielded by Leaders
description: One woman who worked for Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez said she contracted pink eye after he pressured her to put drops in his eyes. Another woman described being repeatedly groped by him until he forced his hands up her legs. Several employees said Mr. Lopez told them to wear low-cut blouses and high heels, or stay in hotel rooms with him overnight. Two women were so repulsed that they began secretly taping their interactions with Mr. Lopez.

title: Food Matters | Get Your Kicks at River Styx
description: Disco globes and vintage car pulleys dangling from the ceiling. A fire-engine-red wood-burning oven capped by a wooden, wagon-wheel-like formation. Handcrafted tables that form a heart shape when pushed together. Its clear from these quirky design details what River Styx  the newest restaurant from the team behind Brooklyns Roebling Tea Room, which opened last night on a quiet, riverside street in Greenpoint  is not: another neighborhood eatery that takes itself too seriously.

title: Image of the Day: May 15
Meanwhile, Syria Burns
description: ISTANBUL  The first request of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, when he visits the White House on Thursday, will surely be that his hosts stop dragging their feet on Syria. Turkey wants the United States to show the same muscle there that it displayed in Libya in order to bring down Bashar al-Assad.

title: Jana Reveals Big Stakes in Groupon and Zynga
description: Barry Rosenstein seems to think he has found bargains in the Internet company aisle.

title: Online Hiring Tools Are Changing Recruiting Techniques
description: It can seem improbable given the still-sluggish monthly unemployment reports, but in some sectors small businesses are desperate to find qualified candidates to fill jobs.

title: Israel Hints at New Strikes, Warning Syria Not to Hit Back
description: WASHINGTON  In a clear warning to Syria to stop the transfer of advanced weapons to Islamic militants in the region, a senior Israeli official signaled on Wednesday that Israel was considering additional military strikes to prevent that from happening and that the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, would face crippling consequences if he retaliated.

title: Wheelies: The Change the Batteries Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Dwindling Support
description: A team falls behind, three games to one, in a seven-game series, and the verdicts are quickly delivered.

title: A Black Nurse, a German Soldier and an Unlikely WWII Romance
description: The nurse and the soldier may never have met  and eventually married  had it not been for the American governments mistreatment of black women during World War II.

title: Has LinkedIn Changed the Way You Hire?
description: A small-business guide weve just published discusses several examples of how companies are using online tools to revamp their hiring processes. One example is Eldridge Capital, an asset-backed lender based in Toronto that recently introduced an offshoot, Zillidy, to issue small loans to small businesses.

title: Despite Focus on Spectacle, Russia Hints Spy Case Wont Disrupt U.S. Ties
description: MOSCOW  Senior Russian and American officials said on Wednesday that they were prepared to put a bizarre spy case behind them, even as the episode remained a matter of intense fascination to the Russian news media and the public.

title: Playing Host to Reality
description: Louisiana has become home to many new reality TV shows, including ones featuring alligator trappers, garbage collectors, bad girls and pawnshop owners.

title: Lincoln Center Turns to Broadway for Its Next Chief
description: In a sign that the countrys largest nonprofit performing arts center may be taking a page from the world of commercial theater, Lincoln Center has chosen a Broadway producer as its next leader.

title: Seeking Fame in the Bayou? Get Real
description: NEW ORLEANS  If I had a dollar every time they asked me for the next Honey Boo Boo Child, said James Bearb, a Louisiana native and the president of Hollywood South Casting, I swear I would be the next millionaire.

title: Why Fund Managers May Be Right About the Fed
description: The economics world has been having a lot of fun with hedge fund managers.

title: Should Baseball Right Umpire Wrongs?
description: Quirks of the Game is a regular feature on The Timess sports blogs.

title: Hunting Pesky Pigs in Paradise
description: Our plan the first day was not to kill the beast but to follow him, to observe his home and habits, to see the evil that he did and maybe get in his face.

title: How Ken Burns Explores New England
description: In 1979, Ken Burns, then a little-known documentary filmmaker, up and left New York City for Walpole, N.H. What first drew him to the small New England town was its cheap rent. I thought I had just taken a vow of anonymity and poverty, if I was going to be a documentary filmmaker concentrating in American history for PBS, he said.

title: Seeking Solitude (With a Guide)
description: The farthest Ive ever felt from civilization was when I spent two nights in an old fire lookout in the Sierra Nevada of Northern California. Built in the 1930s and situated at almost 6,000 feet, the tower had tremendous views of the dense pine forest blanketing Tahoe National Forest. What I remember most was the retreat of city lights, the lack of cellphone reception and the kind of stillness that makes the hours seem to hold more time: for reading, for hikes, for star-spotting, for meandering conversations around the campfire.

title: New York State Joint Commission on Public Ethics Report on Vito J. Lopez
description: Read the full investigation report from the New York State Joint Commission on Public Ethics regarding complaints against Vito J. Lopez.

title: Criticized on Seizure of Records, White House Pushes News Media Shield Law
description: WASHINGTON  Under fire over the Justice Departments use of a broad subpoena to obtain calling records of Associated Press reporters in connection with a leak investigation, the Obama administration sought on Wednesday to revive legislation that would provide greater protections to reporters in keeping their sources and communications confidential.

title: The Secret to One Cabs Success: Candy
description: Most cabdrivers in New York pick passengers up and drop them off without much of a fuss. But Mansoor Khalid is trying something different.

title: I Do and the A.C.L.U.
description: For a marker or metric of just how rapidly the marriage-equality movement has progressed, consider this:

title: The Gun Report: May 15, 2013
description: Did you know that the gun lobby doesnt want you discussing handgun safety with your doctor? In June 2011, Florida governor Rick Scott signed a bill that made it the first state in the nation to prohibit doctors from asking patients if they own guns. Oklahoma, Tennessee and West Virginia all introduced physician gag law bills that would restrict physician firearm counseling. Shortly thereafter, the American Academy of Pediatrics reaffirmed its commitment to advocating for the strongest possible firearm regulations, arguing that fewer guns means safer homes for children.

title: House Hunting Outside Buenos Aires
description: A three-bedroom with a geometric theme is on the market for $1.35 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Argentina
description: A THREE-BEDROOM HOUSE WITH A POOL OUTSIDE BUENOS AIRES

title: Warner Music Gains Approval to Buy Parlophone, a Last Piece of EMI
description: European regulators on Wednesday approved the Warner Music Groups purchase of the Parlophone Label Group, tying up one of the last loose ends from the $4.1 billion breakup of EMI.

title: Did Japan Need Comfort Women?
description: In recent years, Toru Hashimoto, a 43-year-old former television commentator who is mayor of Osaka, Japans third largest city, has been making political waves, challenging the status quo with a brash, very un-Japanese approach. Hes known for provocative right-wing statements, quick, the-buck-stops-with-me decisions, and a willingness to battle labor unions and the establishment in a culture known for consensus-building. Last September, he formed a new political party, the Japan Restoration Association, and named about 350 candidates, most political neophytes, to run in the next parliamentary elections.

title: The Envelope, Please: Candice Childress
description: I, for one, do not believe that a roommate profile is the proper place to demonstrate ones self-restraint. Or it could be that my profile is utterly repugnant.

title: Picasso Museum Reopening Is Delayed
description: PARISThe grand doors of the Muse National Picasso Paris will remain closed for another summer, extending a nearly four-year wait for its reopening.

title: What You Get for ... $1 Million
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Google Introduces New Features for Android Apps and Games
description: Google kicked off its annual developers conference in San Francisco on Wednesday with no new products to show. But it highlighted new tools and services that will allow software makers to make Android apps and games more powerful.

title: U.S. Envoy Talks With Chinese About North Korea
description: BEIJING  The State Departments senior envoy on North Korea said Wednesday that he had discussed all aspects of the North Korea issue with Chinese officials, including sanctions on the North, during a one-day visit to Beijing.

title: Homes for $1 Million
description: An 1883 house in Philadelphia, an adobe in New Mexico and a cottage in Seattle.

title: The Obama Synthesis, Vindicated?
description: Having noted the ways in which the the recent scandals (and other developments) pose a challenge to this administrations distinctive political/policy synthesis, I should also take note of the piece of recent news that makes that synthesis look better than it sometimes has. That news would be the latest deficit projections, as summarized by my colleague Annie Lowrey:

title: Roundabout Theater Announces Changes to Fall Season
description: A Broadway revival of Philip Barrys classic comedy The Philadelphia Story, which the Tony Award nominee Alex Timbers (Peter and the Starcatcher) was to direct this fall, has been postponed, Roundabout Theater Company announced on Wednesday. Replacing that show will be a revival of Terence Rattigans 1946 drama, The Winslow Boy, starring Roger Rees (a Tony winner for The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby) and Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio and directed by Lindsay Posner, who recently staged the play at the Old Vic in London.

title: For Rent: Airstreams
description: If ever a recreational vehicle could be called iconic, it would be the Airstream. The sausage-shaped silvery aluminum trailer has been a fixture of American road trips since the companys founding in 1931, but before this year it was available only for purchase. Starting this month, the travel company Airstream 2 Go will rent current-model Airstream trailers outfitted with flat-screen televisions, camping chairs, tables and barbecue grills, as well as GMC Yukons to pull them for journeys of at least five days. Initial rental locations include Las Vegas and Los Angeles, but there are plans to expand to other cities across the country.

title: Subaru to Recall 5,400 Vehicles for Possible Steering Failure
description: Subaru will recall nearly 5,400 2013 Outback and Legacy models because the steering may fail, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. In a report posted on the agencys Web site, Subaru said the inner and outer shafts of the steering column assembly could lose contact with one another, in which case the driver would lose the ability to steer the vehicle.

title: Advice on Practicing Yoga in Middle Age, Part 2
description: This is the second set of answers to reader questions from Dr. Loren Fishman, a back-pain and rehabilitative medicine specialist who has long incorporated yoga into patient care. In 1972, before applying to medical school, he studied yoga with B.K.S. Iyengar for a year in Pune, India. Dr. Fishman is the medical director of Manhattan Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation in New York City, an assistant clinical professor at Columbia Medical School and an associate editor of the journal Topics in Geriatric Rehabilitation. He is also an author of eight books, including Yoga for Osteoporosis: the Complete Guide.

title: Myanmars President to Visit White House
description: Myanmars president, U Thein Sein, will visit the White House on May 20, another step in the warming of relations between the United States and the military-backed regime that rules Myanmar, once known as Burma.

title: Guest Lesson | Gearing Up for a Summer of Making, Connecting and Learning by Doing
description: We asked Suzie Boss, who has done a series of guest posts on project-based learning for us, to focus her final post of the school year on ideas for summer.

title: I.R.S. Chief Out After Protest Over Scrutiny of Groups
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama announced Wednesday night that the acting commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service had been ousted after disclosures that the agency gave special scrutiny to conservative groups. Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., meanwhile, warned top I.R.S. officials that a Justice Department inquiry would examine any false statements to see if they constituted a crime.

title: The Taxman Cometh
description: Gail Collins: David, as you know, Im from Cincinnati. Some people may think of it as just another city in Ohio, but there has been a lot of drama coming out of Cincinnati over the years. One of the stars of the savings and loan scandal of the 80s, Charles Keating, used to lecture at the Catholic girls high school I went to. The lectures were not about finance but rather on the sinfulness of wearing shorts in the summertime. However, my point is that stuff happens in Cincinnati.

title: The Envelope, Please: Candice Childress
description: In her final post, Candice Childress, a high school senior in Las Vegas, describes her ambition to become the next Kevin Brownlow.

title: Archbishop Clarifies Remarks About Cuomo
description: ALBANY  Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan did not intend to question Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos standing in the Roman Catholic Church, despite the governors support for abortion rights, the cardinals spokesman said on Wednesday.

title: See Topless Woman? Just Move On, Police Are Told
description: In the cold of February, as New York City police officers gathered for their daily orders at roll call, they were given a rather unusual command, for both its timing and its substance: If they happened upon a topless woman, they were not to arrest her.

title: A Photographers Unfiltered Account of the Iraq War
description: Photojournalists on War, an oral history of the Iraq war by those who documented it from the front lines, was published this month by the University of Texas Press. The book consists of interviews conducted by Michael Kamber, who covered the war for eight years for The New York Times and is a co-founder of the Bronx Documentary Center.

title: Kirk and Spock, in Their Roughhousing Days
description: There is some intermittent complaining, in Star Trek Into Darkness, about the militarization of the Federations Starfleet. You may recall that the historic mission of the starship Enterprise was to explore strange new worlds, to seek out new life and new civilizations. While the crew on the first television series found its way into plenty of fights, the show itself always tried to stay true to the ideals of peaceful intergalactic ethnography.

title: The Music Teachers Raid
description: After months of failed efforts to take Vicksburg by assaults from the north, by the early spring of 1863 Ulysses S. Grant had settled on a radically different approach. He would send a force over to the western bank of the Mississippi River; his troops would then march down through northern Louisiana, cross back over the river and establish a base of operations at Grand Gulf, Miss., about 30 miles south of Vicksburg, where there was less of a rebel presence. Grant could thus exploit advantageous terrain and weaker rebel defenses to move against the Confederate stronghold from the south.

title: Photos Take the Spotlight in Updates to Googles Social Network
description: Google may dominate Web search, but when it comes to social networks, the companys Google Plus service is an underdog against Facebook and Twitter. As of December, Google Plus users were spending about 12 minutes a month on the service, according to the company, a smidgen of time compared with the hours that Facebook users spend on that site every month.

title: Google to Sell Its Own Version of Samsungs Galaxy S4
description: 11:46 a.m. | Updated This post was updated to add the price of Googles version of the Galaxy S4 phone.

title: In the Candy Cab, Sweets That Delight, and Heal
description: No eating or drinking inside this car, reads a sign in Mansoor Khalids cab, Except candies.

title: Google Introduces New Search Tools to Try to Read Our Minds
description: Google keeps trying to read our minds.

title: Giving Students Credit for Programming Classes
description: SEATTLE  One of the great frustrations for advocates of computer science education is that programming classes are treated as electives in most high schools across the country, rather than as a core part of students education.

title: Yankee Stadium Will Host Two N.H.L. Games
description: The N.H.L. officially announced on Wednesday what had been widely reported for weeks: Yankee Stadium will host two hockey games in January as part of a series of outdoor stadium contests to be played across North America next season.

title: Lady Antebellum Bests Great Gatsby on Album Chart
description: The country-pop trio Lady Antebellum, and Jay-Zs soundtrack to the new Great Gatsby film lead a passel of new releases on the Billboard album chart this week.

title: Knicks Get Away From What Worked
description: All stretching limbs and sturdy trunks, the Indiana Pacers once again turned the paint into an impenetrable thicket of defenders in their Game 4 victory over the visiting Knicks on Tuesday night. The Pacers starting five may be the biggest in the N.B.A., and Coach Frank Vogel uses every last inch to swallow up drives and obscure passing angles.

title: Cranky Is Contagious (Part Two)
description: Earlier this spring I wrote a post describing the ways I am trying to teach my children all of the lessons surrounding the idea of emotional contagion. You catch more flies with honey than you do with vinegar, I tell them (they say they dont want flies). You get what you give, I say. A soft answer turneth away wrath, but grievous words stir up anger.

title: Graham Motion Praises Animal Kingdoms Versatility
description: Animal Kingdom, winner of the 2011 Kentucky Derby and the 2013 Dubai World Cup, is the first Derby winner to win a Grade 1 race at age 5 and the first Derby winner to win a major race at age 5 since Citation in 1950.

title: Major Redesign of Google Maps Is Unveiled
description: Google is taking on a new challenge in mapping  creating real-time, personalized maps for everyone on the planet.

title: A Tech M.&A. Machine Hits the Brakes
description: Over the last decade, Nuance Communications has been on a frenetic shopping spree.

title: New Chief Revamps Warner Brothers, Clearing Way for Rival to Leave
description: LOS ANGELES  In his first moves as the new chief executive of Warner Brothers, Kevin Tsujihara on Wednesday revamped the studios TV and home entertainment operations, clearing the way for a onetime rivals departure.

title: Objects | Chopards Red Carpet Collection
description: The French premiere of The Great Gatsby isnt the only high-profile event at the opening of the 66th annual Cannes Film Festival. Also making its debut this evening is Chopards decadent collection of 66 one-of-a-kind pieces, one for each year of the festivals history. Jewelry made with pastel-colored gems like kunzite, paraiba tourmaline and mauve spinel plays a supporting role to diamond pieces. But the real showstopper is a choker and ring set (above) featuring poppy flowers fashioned with rubies, emeralds and tsavorites. Festivalgoers will get to view the collection up close on beguiling beauties on the red carpet, where the likes of Cara Delevingne and other A-listers will model it over the course of the festival.

title: The Suggestion of Fried Chicken
description: Outtakes is a behind-the-scenes glimpse of images in the Dining section. Andrew Scrivani (@AndrewScrivani on Twitter and Instagram) is a freelance photographer and a regular contributor to The New York Times. He writes the blog making SundaySauce.

title: Reacting to Angelina Jolies Breast Cancer News
Pininfarina and BMW Collaborate on a Concept Car
description: CERNOBBIO, Italy  Pininfarina, the Italian design house, and BMW have collaborated on a design study called the Gran Lusso Coupe, which will be officially unveiled here next week in connection with the Concorso dEleganza at the Villa dEste. Although this is not the first BMW-Pininfarina collaboration, it may be the most extensive. Last year at the concours event, BMW showed the Zagato Coupe concept that built upon a creative exchange between the two companies.

title: Google Isnt Afraid of Building for Apples Turf
description: At its annual developers conference, Google reinforced that it isnt afraid to set up shop on the territory of its biggest rival, Apple. Several of the new services that it announced Wednesday are available for Googles devices as well as Apples.

title: Flu in Pregnancy Is Linked to Bipolar Disorder
description: Flu infection during pregnancy may increase the risk for bipolar disorder in the child, according to a new report.

title: Idzik Continues Jets Shakeup
description: Two more high-ranking Jets officials will not be retained as John Idzik continues his purge of the previous regime. The latest departures are Scott Cohen, the assistant general manager, and Ari Nissim, the director of football administration.

title: Bronx Judge Dismisses Charges in 12 Killing by Officer; New Indictment Is Possible
description: A Bronx judge dismissed manslaughter charges on Wednesday against a New York City police officer who had shot and killed an unarmed 18-year-old in his familys home.

title: Estimated Health Costs in Retirement Drop
description: In its annual update of retirees medical costs, Fidelity Investments reports that its estimate of those expenses for a 65-year-old couple has dropped by about $20,000.

title: For the Spurs, Parker Is the Steady Hand (Again)
description: Throughout Golden States first-round upset of the Denver Nuggets, and for fleeting moments in their series with the San Antonio Spurs, Stephen Curry and Klay Thompson have taken turns as the toast of the N.B.A. playoffs. But with the Spurs now leading 3-2 in the series, the spotlight has begun to illuminate the steady presence of San Antonios Tony Parker.

title: Breakdown Imperils NASAs Hunt for Other Earths
description: NASAs planet-hunting Kepler spacecraft has been shut down by the failure of one of the reaction wheels that keep it pointed, the space agency announced Wednesday.

title: Taming Your Mane With a Topknot
description: Youve seen them on the street, looking like Pebbles Flintstone running late for ballet practice. Theyve sat in front of you at the movies, their giant, messy hairdos obliterating your view of the screen. Their chunky buns have brushed against your chin on the subway. Theyve invaded your television screen, from Girls to Bunheads, which is named for dancers who pile their hair high up on the crown of their heads in a defiant challenge to gravity.

title: E.L. Doctorow and Mark di Suvero Strike Gold at American Academy of Arts and Letters
description: The novelist E.L. Doctorow and the sculptor Mark di Suvero have been awarded gold medals for the arts by the American Academy of Arts and Letters. The awards were announced on Wednesday at the academys headquarters in Upper Manhattan, as part of a ceremony inducting three new regular members and one honorary member, Bob Dylan, to the 250-person group.

title: Attorney General Clashes With Rep. Issa
description: While answering questions about Thomas E. Perez, the presidents Labor nominee, Attorney General Eric H. Holder, Jr. exchanged sharp words with Representative Darrell Issa.

title: Chia Seeds Are Latest Wonder Ingredient for Skin
description: Chia seeds have gone from being the basis of Chia Pets to becoming one of the biggest so-called superfoods on the market. They are rich in omega-3 fatty acids and high in antioxidants, protein and fiber. Now they are cropping up in skin care products. Proponents say the seeds, often pressed into an oil, increase skin hydration and have anti-inflammatory properties.

title: At Hearing, Holder Calls Issas Accusations Shameful
description: The possibility of contentious moments during the testimony of Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. at a House subcommittee hearing on Wednesday already seemed high, coming just days after the administration faced anger over seizures of journalists records. However, the tensest exchange of the hearing seemed to catch both Mr. Holder and members of the House Judiciary Committees oversight panel off guard, and ended with Mr. Holder calling a congressmans behavior shameful.

title: Scouting Report
description: Openings

title: Injury Likely to Keep Murray Out of French Open
description: A balky lower back prompted Andy Murray to retire from his second-round match at the Italian Open on Wednesday, and he said he doubted that he would be able to play in the French Open.

title: Still Hitching the Plow
description: Horses work the fields at Cedar Mountain Farm.

title: Farm Equipment That Runs on Oats
description: HARTLAND, Vt.  It was a perfect day for plowing, a little overcast with a cool breeze. You could hear the sound of the birds, the chink-chink-chink of the harness.

title: Moscow Rejects Bid to Hold Gay Rights Parade
description: MOSCOW  Moscow officials rejected on Wednesday an application by gay rights advocates to hold a parade this month, saying the event could undermine a campaign to instill patriotic values in the citys youths.

title: Choose One: Marriage Or Passion
description: There are no happy endings in Onegin, John Crankos three-act ballet inspired by Alexander Pushkins narrative poem. There are, however, many swooning pas de deux. By backbend standards, this is a heavy-dipping ballet.

title: Recipe Lab Video Chat on Frying Techniques
description: Its time to turn off the burner and join Julia Moskin of The Times and Norman King, the author of The Way to Fry, to talk about fried chicken, and frying in general.

title: Sexagenarians Gone Wild
description: I had dinner with an age-appropriate fellow from out of town recently and when talk turned to his 14-hour drive home, he said rather than spend money on a motel, he just put the passenger seat down, got out his sleeping bag and slept in the car.

title: Roving Downtown, From Opera to Folk
description: Introducing a concert at Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday evening, Peter Gelb, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, thanked the club for putting their downtown cred at risk by supporting the Met.

title: Cholesterol Levels No Longer Declining
description: Average levels of LDL, the so-called bad cholesterol, declined significantly in Americans from 2001 to 2008, but have remained steady ever since. No one knows why.

title: Car-Sharing Service Suspended Over Insurance Concerns
description: The car-sharing service RelayRides has agreed to stop operating in New York, after state authorities said the company was violating state insurance laws.

title: Theres a Wilder Kingdom When a Marriage Expands
description: In Abby Rosebrocks promising new play, Different Animals, a broke, deeply unhappy husband and wife in the South take on a couple of ill-fitting lovers. The wife, Jessica, picks the local pastor (and heartthrob), Will, while the dumpy Leo chooses his effusive, unbalanced office mate, Molly. After some blackmail, an unplanned pregnancy and other semi-Gothic meanderings, Jessica, Leo and Molly come to an unconventional romantic arrangement that would make even Jerry Springer blush.

title: Conservatives and Health Care Costs
description: Nested within the news about falling deficitsis news about slowing health care cost inflation, which seems to be outlasting the recession and which is driving the long-term projections for Medicare spending downward. Since one of the big questions in the Great Obamacare Debate was whether the new health care law would accelerate cost growth (as expanded subsidies and regulations often tend to do) or reduce it (thanks to the various cost-containing experiments and pilot programs embedded within the bill), the news that costs are falling in advance of the bills implementation has some liberals crowing. Jonathan Chait, in particular, has taken to explaining why the growing mass of evidence that the health-care-cost inflation problem is indeed solvablecuts the legs out from under the entire right-of-center take on health care, deficits and entitlements, and puts the data squarely on the side of health care reforms proponents. Heres his elaboration on this theme:

title: Couple Settle Fraud Case Involving Chinese Company
description: A husband-and-wife team that ran a Chinese maker of pollution control equipment agreed on Wednesday to pay $3.75 million to settle accusations that they had defrauded American investors.

title: Horns Find a Haven in a Sacred Setting
description: After a long season that recently culminated in punishing marathon performances of Wagners Ring cycle, the brass players of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra could have been forgiven for taking a breather. Instead, they assembled in full force on Tuesday evening at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine for a scintillating if acoustically challenging concert of sacred and secular music arranged and conducted by John Sheppard.

title: The Thrill of Visiting Japan. . . And Thinking Youre in Ireland
Travel Essentials | Spoleto, Italy
description: In our Summer Travel issue, which hit newsstands on Sunday, Elaine Sciolino talks to Carla Fendi, who aims to revive the faded glories of the once majestic Spoleto Festival in Italy. Heres where to stay, eat and sleep in this Umbrian hill town.

title: Bossa Nova Civic Club
description: From the fratty pubs of Murray Hill to the kiddie beer gardens of Park Slope, bars reflect the spirit of their neighborhood. Bossa Nova Civic Club, which opened deep in Bushwick last December, is no exception. Co-owned by John Barclay (who was involved with 285 Kent and other underground Brooklyn spaces), Bossa Nova is another indicator that this industrial hinterland has become a destination for more than just warehouse parties of dubious legality.

title: Another Ratner, Another Brooklyn
description: The last name Ratner usually conjures up one of two images among New Yorkers. Theres Ratners, the bygone Jewish dairy, and then theres Bruce Ratner, the developer of the Atlantic Yards in Downtown Brooklyn, on whom opinion is notably more mixed. One thing that doesnt often come up, however, is literature.

title: As Cisco Adapts, Profit Rises 14.5%
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Trends in technology are being good to Cisco Systems.

title: A Leader Behind the Curtain Shows His Creative Side
description: It has been 30 years since the death of George Balanchine, the unsurpassed choreographer and co-founder of New York City Ballet, which also means it has been 30 years since Peter Martins took over the stewardship of the company. In addition to running City Ballet and its affiliate School of American Ballet, Mr. Martins has choreographed nearly 90 ballets for the troupe. Yet only once, in 2000, did he present a program made up exclusively of his own shorter works. On Tuesday night at the David H. Koch Theater, he did it again.

title: Oh, How the Humble Has Risen
description: Along with midriff-baring tops and all things Gatsby, another trend has swept the spring social circuit: kale salads.

title: Seeking Retrial, Simpson Is Demure but Unbowed
description: LAS VEGAS  His hands cuffed to his belt, his legs shackled, O. J. Simpson shuffled to the front of a courtroom here Wednesday after four years in prison, testifying in an effort to overturn the kidnapping and armed robbery conviction that sent him to state prison after he was acquitted of the double murder that made him notorious.

title: The Man Who Cried Filibuster Reform
description: Republicans will get yet another chance to block the confirmation of a totally uncontroversial nominee next week, when Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid holds a vote on Richard Cordray, the would-be director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

title: Pictures of the Day: Jerusalem and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Jerusalem, Spain, Afghanistan and Turkey.

title: Big Banks Get Break in Rules to Limit Risks
description: 9:33 p.m. | Updated

title: Jimmy Kimmel on Mean Tweets and Upfronts
description: The Timess Bill Carter talks with Jimmy Kimmel about the Upfronts, Jimmy Kimmel Live and his upcoming plans.

title: Attorney General on the I.R.S.
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. addressed the issue of the I.R.S.s specifically targeting conservative groups during a House Judiciary Committee hearing on Wednesday.

title: Leaping to Conclusions on a Pilots Speculation
description: An article on the Bloomberg News Web site on Wednesday noted an airline pilots claim that an iPhone could interfere with a planes compasses during takeoff and landing.

title: Early E-Mails on Benghazi Show Internal Divisions
description: WASHINGTON  E-mails released by the White House on Wednesday revealed a fierce internal jostling over the governments official talking points in the aftermath of last Septembers attack in Benghazi, Libya, not only between the State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency, but at the highest levels of the C.I.A.

title: Rediscovering a Tune Unplayed Since 1942
description: The Gil Evans Project, a large-format repertory band in residence at the Jazz Standard this week, brings painstaking precision to its task but also an air of unburdened pleasure. Its driving purpose isnt re-enactment so much as revelation, which helps guard against the pull of nostalgia. Thats tantalizingly rare in the jazz repertory game. And sometimes the bands chosen music proves rarer still.

title: A Child of Two Lands
description: When things fall apart, the children of the land scurry and scatter like birds escaping a burning sky, NoViolet Bulawayo writes in her deeply felt and fiercely written debut novel. They flee their own wretched land so their hunger may be pacified in foreign lands, their tears wiped away in strange lands, the wounds of their despair bandaged in faraway lands, their blistered prayers muttered in the darkness of queer lands. They leave behind their mothers and fathers and the bones of their ancestors in the earth  they leave behind everything that makes them who and what they are, leaving because it is no longer possible to stay.

title: Band Flies in From Norway to Say Hello and Goodbye
description: As high-profile debuts go, the circumstances could hardly be odder for Kaizers Orchestras first American performance, on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Hair Goop, Presented With Wit
description: SIMON DOONAN is slumming.

title: Keeping Wi-Fi Always Within Range
description: Its enough to give tech devotees the shivers: imagine being stuck on a train with no Wi-Fi, or out of range of the free access provided by coffee shops and bookstores.

title: A Franchise Boldly Continues
description: Images from Star Trek Into Darkness.

title: Practicing for the Bermuda Bowl Trials
description: The open trial to pick the two United States teams for this years Bermuda Bowl world championship will start in Orlando, Fla., on May 31.

title: Arena-Rock Masters, Unafraid to Leave the Lights On
description: The Killers made an unconventional entrance for their Madison Square Garden show on Tuesday night. The arena didnt go dark.

title: Cloning Is Used to Create Embryonic Stem Cells
description: Scientists have finally succeeded in using cloning to create human embryonic stem cells, a step toward developing replacement tissue to treat diseases but one that might also hasten the day when it will be possible to create cloned babies.

title: Wounded Soldiers Race to the South Pole
description: This November, I will join a team of three other wounded American veterans  Therese Frentz, Ivan Castro and Margaux Mange  on a 225-mile race across Antarctica for the Walking With the Wounded South Pole Allied Challenge. We will travel on skis while dragging sleds packed with approximately 150 pounds of survival equipment through the harshest climates on the planet. We will be racing for more than two weeks against similar teams of wounded veterans from the United Kingdom, Canada and Australia. Our goal is not just to win the race, but also to raise awareness.

title: Larry Page Gets Personal at Googles Conference
description: Googles I/O developers conference was light on major announcements. But the companys chief executive, Larry Page, made news with a surprise appearance on stage, during which he took questions from software developers in the audience.

title: Inspiration in Self-Acceptance
description: A look at the work of the artist Jeffrey Gibson.

title: At Peace With Many Tribes
description: HUDSON, N.Y.  One sunny afternoon early this month Jeffrey Gibson paced around his studio, trying to keep track of which of his artworks was going where.

title: Meet Orb
description: After impressively winning the Kentucky Derby, Orb tried to become the first horse to conquer the Triple Crown in 35 years.

title: Carey Mulligan Arrives in Forties Glamour at Cannes
description: The Girl: The leading actress of The Great Gatsby at its French premiere at the Cannes Film Festival.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Anonymous Sharing and Historic Embarrassment
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Cambodia Presses U.S. Museums to Relinquish Antiquities
description: Buoyed by the Metropolitan Museum of Arts decision this month to return two stolen statues, Cambodia is asking other museums to examine any Khmer antiquities they acquired after 1970, when a 20-year period of civil war and genocide gave thieves free range to loot the countrys ancient temples.

title: Little Is Said About Google Glass at Developers Conference
description: 12:04 p.m. | Updated to reflect the role of Sergey Brin, Googles co-founder, in a demonstration of Google Glass.

title: Frog Once Used in Pregnancy Tests Spread Deadly Fungus
description: A species of frog that was used from the 1930s to the 1950s in human pregnancy tests is a carrier of a deadly amphibian disease that is now threatening hundreds of other species of frogs and salamanders.

title: Third Point Sells Morgan Stanley Stake
description: Daniel S. Loeb has ended his engagement with Morgan Stanley.

title: A Rise in Military Suicides
description: Military suicides hit an all-time high in 2012.

title: Still Shooting After the End of War
description: Stacy Pearsall never wanted to stop being a combat photographer.

title: The Wind Collector
description: This week, Merel Karhof, a 34-year-old Dutch designer who lives in London, set up a small, temporary factory in the Netherlands to make furniture with wind. For the project, called Windworks, she collaborated with the owners of two neighboring windmills in Zaanse Schans, in the province of North Holland: one, a sawmill that cut the wood used in her collection of chairs, stools and benches; the other, a paint mill that ground the minerals with which she dyed wool upholstery fabric produced through her own wind-powered knitting machine. Speaking by phone from the Netherlands, Ms. Karhof, who studied at the Design Academy Eindhoven in the Netherlands and at the Royal College of Art in London, discussed the evolution of her interest in the invisible forces of nature.

title: And the Best Part Is, No Grass to Mow
description: A houseboat in San Francisco sits in a small marina with 20 floating homes.

title: Their Floating World
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Sarah and Kimo Bertram never imagined living in a floating house. But nearly three years ago, after being outbid on more conventional homes, Ms. Bertram spotted an ad on Craigslist offering a furnished houseboat for rent. On a lark, they checked it out.

title: Owner Takes a Chunk Out of an Unofficial Community Garden
description: For years, the Childrens Magical Garden de Carmen Rubio on the Lower East Side has been known for the peach and nectarine trees that grow there and the roosters that roam the lot. Although the garden is not recognized by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, it has existed since 1982 with little official objection.

title: Eat My Dust
description: For the allergy sufferer, there is truth to that adage linking April with cruelty. May isnt much kinder.

title: Heavy Metal Accessories
description: Kara Mann first became known for interiors with a subversive side when her former home in Chicago appeared in Metropolitan Home six years ago. It was all dark, and it had a lot of Chrome Hearts pieces and Blackman Cruz skull lamps, she said. It was truly an expression of me. I dont want things too pretty or too decorated  I like a twist.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. I have a turntable and a large collection of records. Do I need to remove them before showing my home to buyers?

title: Where Basic Ingredients Rule
description: The town of Hudson, N.Y., is where people go to renovate Victorian houses, sell chunky raw-edged wood furniture and install restaurants in former blacksmith shops. Zakary Pelaccio, the chef behind the Fatty Crew group of restaurants, went down the third path with Fish & Game.

title: Shopping for Heavy Metal Accessories
description: Kara Mann, an interior designer known for her Goth-inspired subversive side, goes shopping for heavy metal accessories.

title: In Defense of an Impatiens Abuser
description: A selection of comments from readers of the Home section, drawn from letters and postings at nytimes.com, about Anne Ravers article on a mysterious strain of downy moldkilling one of the home gardeners favorite annual flowers, Impatiens walleriana.

title: Bedding Fit for a Dreamer
description: The Milanese designer Paola Navone is famous (at least in Europe) for mixing North African and Asian artisanal handicrafts into modern goods. But now her reputation is about to make an Atlantic crossing. She recently introduced an outdoor furniture collection for Janus et Cie, and shes working on interiors for the Como Hotel in the South Beach district of Miami, which will be presented in the fall. This week, Anthropologie, the quirkily stylish lifestyle chain, will release what Ms. Navone has described as her dream bedroom collection. This 20-piece line includes bed linens, furniture, suitcases, lighting and accessories. Prices range from $10 for a mercury-glass mushroom to $4,200 for a four-poster bed. Information: (212) 343-7070 or anthropologie.com.

title: Even Duchesses Have Tag Sales
description: Most people dont associate bathrooms with patinated floor lamps that have carved bronze birds for feet. Then again, most people dont live in a palace. In the early 1920s, Armand Albert Rateau, an Art Deco master, created furniture for the Liria Palace in Madrid for the apartments of the Duchess of Alba, Mara del Rosario de Silva y Gurtubay, who married the 17th Duke of Alba in 1920. The palace was damaged in the Spanish Civil War, and some of Rateaus pieces are lost to time. Now, the House of Alba is selling the rest of her collection at Christies France. Among the seven Rateau pieces included in the May 23 sale are the lamps (estimated at about $1.95 million to $2.6 million each); a carved and gilded wood daybed (shown, $520,000 to $780,000); and a Carrara marble tub (about $195,000 to $260,000). If only we could all scrub like royalty. Information: christies.com.

title: Wireless Accessories and More
description: From Friday through Sunday, Modernica will take 15 percent off all furniture, lighting, ceramics and garden accessories on its Web site, including items already on sale (a Case Study fiberglass rocker, originally $439, will be about $373; a George Nelson medium saucer Bubble lamp, originally $329, will be about $280). Use FactorySale as the code at checkout; modernica.net, (323) 933-0383.

title: A Construction Set for Enterprising Adults
description: Paola Petrobelli grew up in Padua, Italy, only 30 miles from Venice and its celebrated glassmakers.

title: Grading on the Curve
description: Pregnant women add to the conversation about who is wearing what, and how, on the red carpet.

title: Pregnancy Takes a Turn on the Red Carpet
description: Last week, the most talked-about moment from the Met Gala, the annual black-tie event to benefit the museums Costume Institute, did not involve Anna Wintour, the host committee headlined by Rooney Mara and Beyonc or Madonna going pantless.

title: Swipe Away Photo Imperfections on a Smartphone
description: Not so many years ago, when photographers needed to adjust a photo, theyd have to spend time in the darkroom tinkering with equipment and chemicals. Then along came digital imagery and the magic of Photoshop, which brought photo manipulation out of the dark. Nowadays, smartphone apps can manipulate photos in myriad ways.

title: Channeling the Flapper Girl
description: Slick.

title: You Snooze, You Lose
description: Marc Jacobs in his new jammies uniform is the belle of the ball. Rihanna, Rita Ora and Elisa Sednaoui, in pajamas on the red carpet, obviously were invited. Why not you?

title: Pakistan: Imran Khan Seeks Vote Inquiry
description: Imran Khan, the politician and former cricket star, gave a three-day ultimatum to the national election commission on Wednesday to look into his political partys claims of vote-rigging in the contests for 25 parliamentary seats during last weeks general election. Mr. Khan warned that his party would start countrywide protests if the grievances were not addressed. Most of the accusations of voter fraud concern election districts in Lahore and Karachi. Election officials say repolling of 43 election stations in a wealthy Karachi district will take place on Sunday. According to the latest official tally, the party of Nawaz Sharif, the presumptive prime minister, leads with 124 seats in the 272-seat assembly. The Pakistan Peoples Party, the former governing party, won 31 seats, while Mr. Khans party won 27. The counts for 11 seats have yet to be officially verified.

title: Scene City: Park Gala on a Pier
description: Friends of the High Line held a benefit that honored Ethan Hawke and other supporters.

title: A Party Thats Outgrown Its Park
description: Strangely enough, the Friends of the High Line benefit did not take place on the High Line, but at the semi-abandoned Pier 57 across the street. Blame it on the parks success.

title: Egypt: Reports of Embassy Plots
description: Three Egyptian men arrested last week and accused of plotting terrorist acts in Egypt sought to carry out suicide attacks against the United States and French Embassies, the state news media said Wednesday. One of the men had been deported from Iran and another from Algeria for engaging in militant activities. All three were imprisoned in Egypt in 2009, but broke out during the uprising that toppled President Hosni Mubarak in 2011. The men, who the government says have ties to Al Qaeda, said they planned to attack the French Embassy in revenge for Frances military intervention against militants in Mali, the state news media said. After their arrests were announced Saturday, a Western official identified the United States Embassy as one of their targets.

title: A World and an Artist Transformed
description: A few words of warning to the Hamptons socialites and view-to-the-ocean magnates who mingle with the artist Eric Fischl on their summer rounds: Hes watching you.

title: Derby Winner Orb Draws the Rail for the Preakness
description: Orb, the Kentucky Derby winner, drew the inside post for the Preakness Stakes on Saturday, but does it matter?

title: N.B.A. Owners Vote to Keep Kings in Sacramento
description: In a decision that may end a long struggle over the Sacramento Kings, N.B.A. owners voted on Wednesday to prevent the team from moving to Seattle.

title: On Capitol Hill, Sanford Picks Up Where He Left Off
description: In some ways, Mark Sanford, the newly elected Republican representative from South Carolina, felt as if he had never left Capitol Hill.

title: The White Houses Benghazi E-Mails
description: The White House released 100 pages of e-mail exchanges among top officials as they negotiated talking points about the attacks in Benghazi, Libya.

title: Upfronts 2013: CBS
description: The Times's Bill Carter discusses CBS's programming, after the broadcaster unveiled its plans to advertisers.

title: Delivering KFC by Tunnel, Not Too Fast but Satisfying
description: GAZA CITY  The French fries arrive soggy, the chicken having long since lost its crunch. A 12-piece bucket goes for about $27 here  more than twice the $11.50 it costs just across the border in Egypt.

title: From Jungle to Museum and Back?
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Arts recent decision to return two statues to Cambodia may put pressure on other museums that own works said to be from the same 10th-century Khmer temple, Prasat Chen.

title: A Tribute to Boston Bombing Victims, a Step at a Time
description: BOSTON  This city is full of history, but mostly devoid of outsize monuments  there is no Statue of Liberty, no Space Needle. A blinking LED sign for Citgo might be the most prominent landmark in the popular consciousness here, while the citys storied past is, for the most part, embedded more quietly in graves, buildings and statues visible only when one happens to be near them.

title: U.N. Calls for Political Transition in Syria
description: UNITED NATIONS  As the bloodletting continued unabated in Syria, the 193-member General Assembly passed a nonbinding resolution on Wednesday calling for a political transition to end the civil war there, putting the onus on the government of President Bashar al-Assad to stop the killing.

title: Doctor Starts His Life Term in Grisly Abortion Clinic Case
description: PHILADELPHIA  Dr. Kermit Gosnell was sentenced on Wednesday to life in prison without parole for the murder of a baby born alive in a botched abortion, who prosecutors said would have survived if the doctor had not snipped its neck with scissors.

title: Suddenly, Its Woodsons Fault
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  On the day he inherited the Knicks  the Linsanity, the insanity and the rest of it  Mike Woodson was handed a singular challenge: get Carmelo Anthony to play like Carmelo Anthony. Everything else would fall into place.

title: After Bangladesh, Seeking New Sources
description: SEMARANG, Indonesia  Bennett Model helped pioneer the exporting of garments from China in 1975, the year before Mao Zedong died, and ever since, his New York fashion company has searched for other countries, from Guatemala to Vietnam to Indonesia, capable of supplying top retailers like Bergdorf Goodman and Neiman Marcus.

title: Training for Mass Production
description: A national training center for seamstresses in Indonesia helps produce thousands of highly trained workers for the country.

title: Bid for Cash by Tesla Motors Is Likely to Energize Company and Critics Alike
description: Tesla Motors announced plans on Wednesday to tap the markets for more cash, a move that will buy it time to meet its ambitious goals but will also fuel debate over its prospects.

title: Mexico: Official Whose Daughter Forced Restaurant Closing Is Fired
description: The head of the federal consumer protection agency was fired Wednesday, weeks after his daughter got inspectors to briefly shut down a restaurant that refused her the table she wanted. Four officials from the agency had been suspended after the episode became a Twitter sensation highlighting the deep sense of entitlement of the privileged in Mexico. The father, Humberto Bentez Trevio, had defied calls to resign, but President Enrique Pea Nieto, who had promised more accountability from his government, decided to fire him. A government statement said that while Mr. Benitez Trevio did not play a role in the inspection that led to the closing, the case had damaged the image and prestige of the agency.

title: Jets Know Bizarre: Balky Knee Forces Garrard to Retire
description: The Jets had a plan. They would sign a veteran quarterback, which they did. They would draft a dynamic rookie, which they also did. And they would put both in an honest-to-goodness competition, challenging the incumbent for the right to start the season opener.

title: Acting Chief Wins Confirmation to Run Medicare and Medicaid
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Wednesday approved President Obamas nominee to run Medicare and Medicaid, Marilyn B. Tavenner, providing the agency with its first confirmed chief in six and a half years.

title: Abercrombie & Fitch Signs Bangladesh Safety Plan
description: Abercrombie & Fitch said on Wednesday that it had signed on to a landmark plan to improve factory safety in Bangladesh, becoming just the second American company to join an accord that more than two dozen European retailers and brands have embraced.

title: Weighing Bid for City Hall, Weiner Is Said to Be Struggling to Fill Out His Team
description: In a city with no shortage of political strategists and pollsters, Anthony D. Weiner has long stood out as a do-it-yourself candidate, known for trusting his own instincts.

title: Nigerias President Gives Military More Power in Struggle Against Militants
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Struggling to contain a smoldering Islamist insurgency, the president of Nigeria, Africas most populous country, has ordered in more troops and granted the military more powers to arrest, more authority to seize any building or structure and more leeway in any area of terrorist operation.

title: Inquiry on Potential Oil Price Manipulation Intensifies
description: When a BP rig exploded in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010, Richard Fry, a top executive at a trucking company, said he noticed something strange about the oil market. Prices spiked quickly, he recalled, and they took much longer to drop.

title: Media Companies Aim to Woo Advertisers and Latinos
description: Hispanic media companies continued to aggressively target advertisers this week with some major announcements from Fox Hispanic Media executives kicking off Wednesdays upfront presentations.

title: At 41, Jagr Is Bruins Elder Statesman
description: BOSTON  There are flecks of gray in Jaromir Jagrs playoff beard. He turned 41 three months ago, and he is the only player in the Eastern Conference semifinal series between the Boston Bruins and the Rangers who was alive in 1973, when the two franchises last met in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Childhood Friends Battle in Western Conference Playoffs
description: LOS ANGELES  There are many intense rivalries in the Stanley Cup playoffs, but few have a competition that dates back to puberty, PlayStation and pond hockey.

title: Thomas M. Messer, Museum Director Who Gave Guggenheim Cachet, Dies at 93
description: Thomas M. Messer, whose leadership of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum over more than a quarter-century established its place among the worlds great museums of modern art, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Favorite in Preakness Will Start on the Rail
description: BALTIMORE  He is the Kentucky Derby champion, after all, so Orbs installation Wednesday as the even-money favorite to run away with the 138th running of the Preakness Stakes is hardly surprising. Two weeks ago, he caught a sloppy track for the first time but still came from the clouds to effortlessly defeat 18 rivals.

title: Knicks Face Elimination
description: William C. Rhoden of The Times talks with the Knicks coach Mike Woodson about Game 5  an elimination game for the Knicks  against the Pacers on Thursday.

title: Drivers Seat
description: I got a letter the other day from Joe Arpaio  Sheriff Joe Arpaio, that is, the sheriff of Maricopa County, Ariz., scourge of undocumented immigrants and of anyone who might look like one. He was, remarkably enough, asking me for money to combat an effort to recall him from the office he has held for 20 self-aggrandizing years.

title: Shareholders Denied Access to JPMorgan Vote Results
description: When it comes to shareholder votes, the running tallies are a closely guarded secret. Only a handful of parties get a peek into how these corporate battles are shaping up.

title: Melanoma Treatment Harnesses Immune System to Combat Cancer Cells
description: Cancer researchers are growing increasingly enthusiastic about harnessing the bodys own immune system to fight tumors. And new research shows that two drugs that use this approach may be even better than one.

title: Raucous Cheers for Irans Wrestlers in Grand Central Terminal
description: Cheered on by a raucous crowd waving flags and chanting, a team of Iranian wrestlers defeated the United States, 6-1, in an exhibition match staged in New Yorks Grand Central Terminal on Wednesday.

title: Tired of Bad News, Rutgers Makes News With Its New Athletic Director
description: Four years ago, Rutgers made an unconventional choice when it selected Tim Pernetti, a television executive, to lead its athletic department.

title: When to Talk to Monsters
description: DENVER

title: The Real I.R.S. Scandal
description: WASHINGTON

title: USA Network Turns to Vignettes to Draw Viewers and Advertisers to Its Daytime Schedule
description: A popular show that takes place on the stoop of a brownstone in Brooklyn is to get national television exposure as a cable channel seeks new ways to engage viewers and woo advertisers.

title: The Migrant Cash Lifeline
description: WASHINGTON

title: Scandalous vs. Scandal Lust
description: I have watched in recent days as a parade of conservatives have used specific and real governmental missteps to justify their wide-ranging paranoia and irrational hostilities. Aha!

title: On the Plus Side ...
description: Lets try to come up with some positive thoughts about the recent political fortunes of the Obama White House:

title: DAmato Puts Money on Democrat in Race for New York Mayor
description: He was the rough-and-ready boss of the New York State Republican Party for a quarter-century, the senator from the suburbs who helped make liberal a dirty word in American politics.

title: Phipps Familys Plan Breeds Success
description: The Phipps family stable is half the size that it once was but still spends more than $4 million annually maintaining a band of mares, raising their foals into racehorses and paying exorbitant fees for the mares to couple with the finest stallions. Over nearly a century, the family has invested hundreds of millions of dollars in the horse business.

title: Mandela Fades Amid Battles Over Who Will Claim Legacy
description: JOHANNESBURG  Smile! the visitor implored, an edge of forced bonhomie in his voice, as he held up a cellphone camera to take a snapshot.

title: Baffling Rise in Suicides Plagues the U.S. Military
description: After Specialist Freddy Hook, a medic with the Armys 82nd Airborne Division, killed himself in 2010, the trail of possible causes seemed long.

title: After Attacking The A.P., a Peace Offering
description: After coming under scorching bipartisan criticism for secretly going through the phone records of reporters at The Associated Press in a leak investigation, the Obama administration now says it supports a law that might have prevented this outrageous conduct.

title: Pension Predators
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has done retirees and military veterans a great service by ordering New Yorks top banking regulator to investigate pension advance firms that persuade customers to sign over all or part of their monthly pensions in exchange for immediate cash payments. The payments, advertised as advances, are, in fact, cleverly disguised loans that can carry ruinously high interest rates and eventually strip older citizens of their meager assets.

title: Take Politics Away From the I.R.S.
description: President Obamas decision on Wednesday to dismiss the acting commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service was a largely symbolic demonstration of anger and authority. The official, Steven Miller, was not directly involved in the misguided decision to single out Tea Party groups for special scrutiny in granting tax exemptions. What is more important is Mr. Obamas promise to clarify the extremely vague tax laws, which are the root cause of the problems in both the I.R.S. and the political system.

title: Denmarks Welfare State
description: To the Editor:

title: The Psychiatrists Manual, Analyzed
Replacing Donnell Library
description: To the Editor:

title: Faster Broadband Speeds: The View From the F.C.C.
description: To the Editor:

title: Angelina Jolies Decision: More Perspectives
description: To the Editor:

title: Google Escalates the Competition in Map Services
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Cartographers, beware: the map wars have begun.

title: Living in Limbo
description: In 2013, a former combat videographer, Kathryn Robinson, described trying to get her life back on track after her return from Iraq left her with P.T.S.D. and thoughts of suicide.

title: Should 501(c)(4)'s Be Eliminated?
Imitation Is the Closest TV Rivals Get to Flattery
description: AS the television upfronts week for the 2013-14 season concludes on Thursday, the broadcast networks and cable channels that have been presenting their wares to advertisers and agencies are signaling a willingness to try borrowing what works from one another.

title: Climbing Number of Strikeouts Reflects a Quest for Power
description: The Hickory Crawdads, an affiliate of the Texas Rangers in the Class A South Atlantic League, are a fascinating case study for modern baseball. Through Tuesday they had played 37 games and led all of the minor leagues in home runs, with 57. They also led the minors in strikeouts, with 396  or 10.7 whiffs per game.

title: Europa League: Chelsea Makes History
description: Chelsea is a European champion. Again.

title: Dont Expand the War on Terror
description: FOR years, many have erroneously claimed that the United States is embroiled in a global war on terrorism. It is not, and thanks to Congress, never has been.

title: State Said to Be Reviewing Pay for Fast-Food Workers
description: The New York State attorney general is investigating whether the owners of several fast-food restaurants and a fast-food parent corporation have cheated their workers out of wages, according to a person familiar with the cases.

title: Emergency Shout
description: Administrivial Goof Alert: My bad. I own this one. If you are solving electronically, there was a clickable Reveal Hint button on the puzzle page that alerted you to an important part of this puzzles answer. I asked to have it added because at this time we do not have the capability to render a visual answer for the MAN OVERBOARD theme. That button has been removed, and I apologize for spoiling the puzzle for some of our solvers.

title: Corrections: May 16, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: A Major League Debut on His 26th Birthday
description: Had it not been for a small fracture in his right ankle, David Adams might have been playing Wednesday nights game against the Yankees instead of for them, and Cliff Lee might have been on the mound wearing pinstripes.

title: Japans Economy Growing at 3.5% Annualized Rate
description: TOKYO  Japans economy grew at a robust annualized pace of 3.5 percent in the first quarter, preliminary data showed, the first sign that the bold monetary and economic policies of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe were starting to bear fruit.

title: A Conflict Is Seen in a Review of a Detectives Conduct
description: Alvena Jennette spent almost 21 years in prison, writing appeals that pointed out irregularities in his murder case, such as how the chief eyewitness changed her story and contradicted another onlooker. In each instance, the office of the Brooklyn district attorney fought back against his claims.

title: Rangers and Bruins Ready to Drop the Puck
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Rangers were in an upbeat mood at practice Wednesday, eager to start their Eastern Conference semifinal series with the Bruins on Thursday night in Boston.

title: Lottery Numbers
Judge Orders Extension of Hotel Program for Hurricane Sandy Evacuees
description: It has been nearly seven months since Hurricane Sandy struck, but a state court judge ruled on Wednesday that New York City cannot end its hotel program for evacuees just yet.

title: Judge Blocks Plan by City for New Taxis
description: A State Supreme Court judge on Wednesday blocked the Bloomberg administrations plan for a near-uniform fleet of yellow cabs, ruling that it violated a New York City provision requiring a hybrid option for taxi operators.

title: After Devastating Blast, Questions in a Texas Town Over Whether to Rebuild or Move On
description: WEST, Tex.  Slowly, painfully, this town is rising from the ashes.

title: Targeting Texas
description: While the Republican Party struggles to resolve fratricidal conflict over gay marriage and immigration reform, there is another elephant in the room: Texas, the last big-state bastion of the right. Neglected by national Democrats since 1992, when Bill Clintons campaign decided to write it off, Texas has emerged as a prime target for partisan realignment.

title: Multiple Proposals on Assault in Military, but Also Disagreement
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, military officials and lawmakers on Capitol Hill are in broad agreement that the sexual assault problem in the military has reached a level of severity that can no longer be tolerated. But that is far different from concurring on how it should be fixed.

title: Heat Close Series Against Bulls With 4th-Quarter Rally
description: MIAMI  Maybe the Miami Heat are so talented that they can afford to relax for long stretches during games. The Heat are the reigning N.B.A. champions, after all, and there was little evidence that the injury-ravaged Chicago Bulls could avoid elimination Wednesday night.

title: Ibanezs Success at Stadium Continues, This Time at Yankees Expense
description: Raul Ibanez was admired and respected for the work he did as a Yankee in 2012, most notably in the playoffs. It was in October that Ibanez electrified Yankee Stadium with three late-game home runs that seemed to defy logic and odds all at once, and made him a temporary legend in the Bronx.

title: On Education, Thompson Tries to Set Himself Apart
description: He would keep mayoral control of the New York City school system, but relinquish control of the board that approves educational policy. He would cease closing schools as aggressively as the Bloomberg administration has been, yet take action against faltering schools.

title: Photo Replay: May 15
description: A view of the day in sports, from the Italian Open in Rome to the Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore.

title: Street-Naming Event Gives Mayoral Hopefuls a Chance to Woo Hispanics
description: Bill de Blasio, the public advocate, ventured a few sentences of Spanish. Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, called on Congress to pass immigration legislation. William C. Thompson Jr., a former comptroller, reminded the audience that his grandparents immigrated from the Caribbean. Adolfo Carrin Jr., a former Bronx borough president, simply urged Hispanics to vote.

title: Court Penalizes a Lawyer Over Slurs in a 9/11 Filing
description: Hardball legal tactics are common in courts, but a California lawyer went too far when he filed court papers on behalf of his client, a widow whose husband died in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, that were nothing more than a vehicle for making personal slurs against a judge, a federal appeals court in Manhattan said on Wednesday.

title: For Troops Needing Psychological Help, Asking Can Be the Toughest Hurdle
description: Memories are the tools that help make, shape and build who we are as people. They can keep you strong. But they can also lead you astray, controlling and altering your thoughts and emotions.

title: North Dakotas Sole Abortion Clinic Sues to Block New Law
description: The running battle over the regulation of abortions entered a North Dakota courtroom on Wednesday, as the states sole abortion clinic sued to block a new law that it says could force it to shut down.

title: Tennessee: Home-schooling Family Is Denied Asylum
description: A federal appeals court ruled Wednesday that a German family could not claim asylum in the United States because it would face penalties in Germany for home-schooling its children.
