The Romeike family wanted to educate five children at home largely for religious reasons, the decision stated, but were prohibited by German law and faced prosecution. The Romeikes moved to Tennessee in 2008 and were granted asylum by an immigration judge, but the Board of Immigration Appeals overturned that decision in 2012. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, ruled unanimously Wednesday that the Romeikes could not prove that home-schoolers were singled out for persecution in Germany, and thus were not eligible for asylum. The family intends to appeal.

title: Illinois: Lawsuits Filed Over Chicago School Closings
description: Parents in Chicago have filed two federal lawsuits opposing proposed school closings. In March, the Chicago Public Schools identified 53 schools that it planned to close to save $560 million over 10 years. The school board will vote on the proposal next Wednesday. The suits, filed Wednesday in Federal District Court for the Northern District of Illinois Eastern Division, say the closings would violate the Americans With Disabilities Act. In a complaint seeking to postpone them for a year, three parents seeking class-action status allege that the closings would pose significant disruption to special-education students. The second suit, which seeks to stop the closings altogether, alleges that they would needlessly uproot, transfer and destabilize the children. The suit further says the closings would violate Illinois civil rights law because the schools fall disproportionately in areas where the vast majority of students are black.

title: Impeccably Bred
description: Horse racing may be a family pastime, but it is also a business  an expensive one  and the Phippses have used savvy methods in improving their stock.

title: Ohio: Abduction Suspect Plans to Plead Not Guilty
description: A lawyer for Ariel Castro, the Cleveland man accused of imprisoning three women in his home for about a decade, said Wednesday that his client planned to plead not guilty to criminal charges. The lawyer, Jaye M. Schlachet, said his client had been demonized in news reports and expressed concern about a fair trial. Mr. Castro, 52, has been accused of kidnapping and raping the women, who vanished between 2002 and 2004. They were rescued last week, along with a daughter that one gave birth to in captivity. A paternity test confirmed that Mr. Castro is the father of the child, who is now 6.

title: Request for Investigation Into Prosecutions Involving Retired Detective Louis Scarcella
description: Kenneth Thompson, a candidate for Kings County District Attorney, is asking Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo for an independent investigation of dozens of prosecutions involving the work of a retired police detective, Louis Scarcella, that have recently come under scrutiny. Related Article

title: Texas: Investigation of Abortion Doctor
description: The Harris County district attorneys office said Wednesday that it would investigate charges that a Houston doctor had delivered live babies during third-trimester abortions and killed them after they emerged, which federal and state laws forbid. The anti-abortion group Operation Rescue made the charges based on statements by three former employees of the abortion doctor, Douglas Karpen, which could not be independently verified. The organization said the doctors actions echoed the charges that led to the murder conviction of Dr. Kermit Gosnell in Philadelphia. Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst said he had read the allegations with disgust, and called for a full investigation.

title: California: Suspensions End for Defiant Students
description: The Los Angeles Unified School District has voted to end the practice of suspending students who are defiant. Concern has grown that zero tolerance disciplinary policies, which sometimes led to suspensions for acts like refusing to remove a hat in class, have disproportionately affected minority students, hindered academic achievement and lowered graduation rates. More than a third of all suspensions result from willful defiance, according district officials. Los Angeles Unified, with more than 600,000 students, is the first large school district in the country to curtail suspensions for defiance, officials said.

title: Washington: Cancer Patients More Prone to Bankruptcy
description: A study of cancer patients in Washington State has found they were twice as likely to file for bankruptcy as people without cancer. The study, led by researchers from the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, linked bankruptcy court records and information from the regional cancer registry on about 200,000 cancer patients, and compared them with a similar group of people from the same area who did not have cancer. Young people with cancer experienced the highest bankruptcy rates, the study found, up to 10 times the rate of bankruptcy filings among older age groups.

title: Onset of Woes Casts Pall Over Obamas Policy Aspirations
description: WASHINGTON  Thwarted on Capitol Hill, stymied in the Middle East and now beset by scandal, President Obama has reached a point just six months after a heady re-election where the second term he had hoped for has collided with the second term he actually has.

title: As Mets Struggle, Collins Keeps Calm
description: ST. LOUIS  Years ago, Terry Collins possessed a far more inflammable personality, one capable of channeling ire toward the players he managed.

title: Christies Contemporary Art Auction Sets Record at $495 Million
description: Record prices for 12 contemporary artists including Jackson Pollock, Roy Lichtenstein and Jean-Michel Basquiat made history on Wednesday night. The sale of postwar and contemporary art at Christies in Rockefeller Center totaled $495 million, the highest sales figure at any art auction.

title: Seeking Calm on the Cancer Ward
description: When people choose to have their leukemia treated aggressively, its a big commitment, more so than for almost any other cancer.

title: In Calculation of Military Rates, the Numbers Are Not All Straightforward
description: As the number of suicides in the military began rising a decade ago, Pentagon officials could often be heard repeating a common defense: The militarys suicide rate was still lower than the rate for civilians of comparable age, sex and race.

title: The Myth of a Perfect Orderly Liquidation Authority for Big Banks
description: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Word of the Day | guffaw
description: guffaw \()g-f, g-f\ noun and verb

title: Forester Is a Standout in Latest Crash Test
description: The 2014 Subaru Forester was the only one of 13 compact crossovers and S.U.V.s to earn the highest rating in a new, more severe front crash test by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. The new Forester was rated Good, and the 2013 Mitsubishi Outlander Sport received the next-highest rating, Acceptable.

title: Two Maos, and Two Views of Chinas Past
description: BEIJING  The spirits of two men called Mao are abroad in China, representing two dramatically different political views  nascent parties, perhaps  in a one-party state. Recently, there has been open hostility between the two camps, as I report in my Letter from China this week. The issue seems especially pertinent today, May 16, the 47th anniversary of the start of the Cultural Revolution that Mao Zedong initiated.

title: House Agriculture Committee Approves Farm Bill
description: WASHINGTON  After a late-night session Wednesday, the House Agriculture Committee voted to approve a $940 billion farm bill, a day after the Senate passed its version, setting the stage for Congress to finally begin work on a new five-year bill.

title: Ceiling Collapse at Shoe Factory in Cambodia Kills 2
description: HONG KONG  A ceiling at a small factory making shoes on the outskirts of the capital of Cambodia collapsed on Thursday morning, killing at least two workers and underlining global worries about factory safety in poor countries.

title: Whats On Thursday
description: 9 P.M. (NBC) THE OFFICE The series comes to an end as, months after the documentary is broadcast, Dunder Mifflin employees past and present reunite for a wedding and a final round of interviews in which hatchets are buried and mysteries are solved. Mindy Kaling, B. J. Novak, Rachael Harris, Dakota Johnson, Joan Cusack and Ed Begley Jr. guest star. A retrospective, featuring interviews with writers, producers and actors; clips of favorite moments; and a behind-the-scenes look at the finale, leads in at 8. Above, a scene from the show.

title: Witness Reports on Texas Tornado
description: Last Updated, 5:15 p.m. At least six people were killed and seven others are missing after multiple tornadoes touched down in and around a small town near Fort Worth, about 65 miles southwest of Dallas, as our colleague John Schwartz reports.

title: News Quiz | May 16, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: What Makes Narendra Modi a Middle-Class Hero?
description: As Indias middle class grows in number and political clout, it has found a new hero in Gujarats chief minister, Narendra Modi, who has emerged with a bold, right-wing narrative in a country with a staunchly socialist past.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, May 16, 2013
description: It should not matter what political stripe youre from. The fact of the matter is the I.R.S. has to operate with absolute integrity.

title: IHT Quick Read: May 16
description: NEWS After the deadly building collapse in Bangladesh, Western retails have begun seeking new production locations with greater urgency. Its not an easy task  complex manufacturing needs already shrink the pool of potential locations. Keith Bradsher reports from Semarang, Indonesia.

title: Test Yourself | English, May 16, 2013
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Back to School, but for the Degree, Not Just the Fun.

title: A Rolling Celebration: The Story of the Candy Cab
description: In the article In the Candy Cab, Sweets That Delight, and Heal, Natalie Kitroeff writes about a cabdriver who tries to make his customers smile.

title: Delhi Gang Rape Suspect in Critical Condition, Lawyer Says
description: NEW DELHI  A defendant in the Delhi gang rape case has been assaulted by other inmates inside Tihar Jail in New Delhi and was being slowly poisoned by the jail authorities, his lawyer said before a local court earlier this week.

title: How Important Is Driving to You?
description: Driving was once considered the ticket to freedom for teenagers eager to be more independent. But has driving lost some of its luster recently?

title: Google Buys a Quantum Computer
description: Google and a corporation associated with NASA are forming a laboratory to study artificial intelligence by means of computers that use the unusual properties of quantum physics. Their quantum computer, which performs complex calculations thousands of times faster than existing supercomputers, is expected to be in active use in the third quarter of this year.

title: Healing in the Aftermath of a Massacre
description: On a Friday afternoon in July 2011, Andrea Gjestvang was preparing to leave the offices of the Norwegian newspaper Verdens Gang, where she was working as a temporary photo editor, when an enormous explosion shook the building, blowing out windows.

title: Deadly Collapse in Cambodia Renews Safety Concerns
description: TREAM TBAL, Cambodia  Survivors described a scene of panic Thursday after a raised storage area collapsed at a footwear factory in this Cambodian village, killing at least two workers, injuring a dozen more and underlining global worries about factory safety in poor countries.

title: Slim Pickings at the eHarmony for Roommates
description: I have not shared a room with another person for an extended period of time since 1998, and I most likely have not yet grasped the practical difficulties of living alongside someone.

title: The Early Word: Fire
description: In Todays Times:

title: The Law Against the Judges
description: CAIRO  In 2006, I watched middle-aged members of the Muslim Brotherhood kneel and pray in the street outside Cairos High Court in front of rows of officers from the riot police. It was a show of solidarity with judges, who were holding their own sit-ins and protests to contest being pressured to sign off on rigged elections by the regime of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: From Fearsome Predator to Mans Best Friend
description: Imagine a wolf catching a Frisbee a dozen times in a row, or leading police officers to a stash of cocaine, or just sleeping peacefully next to you on your couch. Its a stretch, to say the least. Dogs may have evolved from wolves, but the minds of the two canines are profoundly different.

title: A Start-Up Struggles to Market Its iPhone App
description: No one has told me that they got into mobile too soon, is what a savvy venture capitalist told me recently during a meeting in my office. And thats why so many Web site owners are trying to create the right smartphone experience.

title: New Accounting Proposal on Leasing Portends Big Changes
description: Rule makers around the world on Thursday issued a new proposal on accounting for leases that backs off from some of the most controversial aspects of an earlier version. But it would still represent a major change in accounting by requiring many companies to report vastly larger amounts of assets and liabilities than they do now.

title: Crisis of Masculinity? Its the Economy, Stupid
description: LONDON  A senior British politician appears to have punctured some thin-skinned male pride with claims in a speech on Thursday that the nations men are suffering a crisis of masculinity as a result of the economic downturn.

title: Attack on U.S. Military Vehicles Kills at Least 16 in Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A Toyota Corolla packed with explosives rammed a pair of American military vehicles in the Afghan capital, Kabul, on Thursday, setting off a blast that killed at least 16 people, including 6 American military advisers, and shook the relative calm that has prevailed for months in the city, Afghan officials said.

title: A Tornados Mad Dash, and Then Ruins
description: GRANBURY, Tex.  There used to be a house there.

title: JPMorgan Shareholders in the Dark
description: In the middle of a closely watched vote on whether to split the roles of chairman and chief executive at JPMorgan Chase, the firm providing tabulations of the results has stopped giving voting snapshots to the shareholders that sponsored the proposal, Susanne Craig and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook. The firm says the change followed a request from Wall Streets main lobbying group.

title: Gatsby, and Other Luxury Consumers
description: The pages of The Great Gatsby are suffused with romance and dusted with sexual implication, but perhaps the most intensely and disturbingly erotic scene  the one that distills the novels seductive blend of desire and sorrow  involves clothes. Showing off his mansion to Daisy Buchanan, the great love of his life, and Nick Carraway, his diffident, dazzled neighbor, Jay Gatsby opens a cabinet in which his shirts are piled like bricks in stacks a dozen high.

title: T. Rex Walks the Cannes Red Carpet
description: Steven Spielberg ushers in the 3D re-release of Jurassic Park at Cannes.

title: Former BP Chief Emerges as Interim Chairman at Glencore Xstrata
description: LONDON  Tony Hayward was appointed interim chairman of the mining company Glencore Xstrata on Thursday, almost three years after he resigned as chief executive of BP in the wake of a huge oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: McGaughey Marvels at Orbs Development
description: On a quiet Tuesday morning at Pimlico, the Hall of Fame trainer Shug McGaughey looked at Orb, talked about Orb, thought about Orb and kept coming back to the same thing.

title: Wal-Mart Sales Go Cold, and Its Shares Feel the Chill
description: Despite several quarters of controversy over bribery allegations in Mexico, Wal-Mart Stores profitable earnings and strong sales in recent quarters made it a Wall Street darling, and its stock price hit a record high on Wednesday.

title: I.R.S. Approved Dozens of Tea Party Groups Following Congressional Scrutiny
description: Public data from the Internal Revenue Service, which recently acknowledged that agency officials singled out conservative groups for special scrutiny, shows that dozens of Tea Party groups were approved for tax exempt status beginning in May 2012. That was the same month that Representative Dave Camp of Michigan wrote to the I.R.S. asking for information about all social welfare groups that had applied for tax-exempt status in 2010 and 2011, to determine whether the I.R.S. was targeting conservative groups.

title: Thursday Reading: Finding an Air Purifier for Allergy Season
In New York, Are Neighbors Anonymous?
description: Dear Diary:

title: Judge Rules Against British Activists in Goldman Tax Case
description: LONDON  A deal between Goldman Sachs and Britains tax authorities about outstanding payments in 2010 was arranged clumsily but did not break any laws, a judge ruled on Thursday.

title: The Day Diddy Did Do Downton Abbey
description: While it may not be an event quite as historic as World War I or the sinking of the Titanic, some of us will never forget the Great Diddy Downton Abbey Panic of 2013.

title: Royal Bank of Scotland to Cut 1,400 Jobs
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland announced on Thursday that it would eliminate an additional 1,400 job as it continued to reduce operations to bolster profitability.

title: Who You Gonna Bet On?
description: OK, this is different: Jesse Eisinger of Propublica  Propublica!  defending those poor maligned hedge fund managers against the ridicule of macroeconomists.

title: How Elliott and Hess Settled a Bitter Proxy Battle
description: 7:30 p.m. | Updated

title: Intruder Commits Suicide at Paris School
description: PARIS  The French police said on Thursday that a man entered the courtyard of a private Roman Catholic school in the upscale Seventh Arrondissement of Paris and committed suicide with a sawed-off shotgun, shooting himself in the head in front of about a dozen children.

title: The Smith/Klein/Kalecki Theory of Austerity
description: Noah Smith recently offered an interesting take on the real reasons austerity garners so much support from elites, no matter hw badly it fails in practice. Elites, he argues, see economic distress as an opportunity to push through reforms  which basically means changes they want, which may or may not actually serve the interest of promoting economic growth  and oppose any policies that might mitigate crisis without the need for these changes:

title: Can I Bring My Kids? I Asked
description: Taking Sides

title: Can I Bring My Kids? I Never Asked
description: Taking Sides

title: Berkshires Rating Is Cut After S.&P. Revises Its Methodology
description: Standard & Poors cut the credit rating of Berkshire Hathaway one notch on Thursday after changing its methodology for evaluating insurers, but it affirmed the companys overall financial strength.

title: Three Cricket Players Arrested on Spot-Fixing Charges
description: NEW DELHI Three Indian Premier League players and 11 bookmakers have been arrested on charges of spot fixing in cricket matches, the Indian police said Thursday.

title: A Comfortable Fit, Gracefully Worn
description: Jessica Hecht was filming in Albuquerque last year, reprising her role as the lost love of Walter Whites youth on the concluding season of Breaking Bad, when she got a call from Lynne Meadow, the artistic director of Manhattan Theater Club, asking how soon she could be back in New York for a reading of a new play. Ms. Meadow withheld details of the project, The Assembled Parties, not disclosing that it was a Richard Greenberg play until Ms. Hecht had returned from New Mexico.

title: A Dickensian Delay at the I.R.S.
description: A plot device in Charles Dickenss Bleak House follows the interminable case of Jarndyce v. Jarndyce through the English Court of Chancery. The litigation winds on for years until, finally, the costs of litigating the case have consumed the entire estate, leaving nothing for the heirs.

title: Chechen Refugee Questioned in F.B.I.s Inquiry of Bombing
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  F.B.I. agents investigating the Boston Marathon bombing have repeatedly questioned Musa Khadzhimuratov, a Chechen refugee and former separatist fighter who says he had a passing social relationship with one of the two bombing suspects. They searched his familys small apartment here on Tuesday, scouring his computers, subjecting him to a polygraph, and taking a DNA sample.

title: Beckham, at 38, Says Hell Bend It No Longer
description: When David Beckham broke a bone in his left foot before the 2002 World Cup, Tony Blair, then the British prime minister, interrupted a cabinet meeting to express his concern about Englands suddenly uncertain chances. Tabloid newspapers ran photos of Beckhams injured foot on Page 1 and asked readers to lay their hands on the picture in an attempt at mass civic healing.

title: In Store | A Pharmacy for Lower East Siders
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: With Security, Trade Center Faces New Isolation
description: The wreckage had not been cleared from ground zero when planners and neighbors began imagining how the devastation of Sept. 11 could be redeemed, in some way, by a new World Trade Center, one that would be fully joined to the rest of Lower Manhattan rather than standing apart in chilling isolation.

title: After Round 2, One N.B.A. Favorite Still Stands
description: After the first game of the playoffs, right before Russell Westbrooks knee went pop and changed the Oklahoma City Thunders outlook to mostly cloudy with a chance of calamity, the Miami Heat and the Thunder could have penciled themselves in for a rematch of last years N.B.A. finals. Who was going to beat these two, loaded with star players and confidence? They played with that What, us worry? attitude, knowing there was always a switch somewhere they could flip and heroics would just happen.

title: Nicolas Winding Refn on Being One With Ryan Gosling
description: CANNES, France  Perhaps no filmmaker has fetishized male brutality with the monomaniacal focus of the Danish director Nicolas Winding Refn. Yet the 42-year-old filmmaker has never made a traditional action movie. Even his 2011 film, the harsh, neon-lit Los Angeles film Drive, starring Ryan Gosling as a Los Angeles getaway driver, was a chase film with hardly any car chases.

title: Extended Runs for Some Tony Nominees
description: Broadway is often barren during summertime when it comes to plays, as their star actors return to Hollywood for film and television commitments (or go on vacation) after the Tony Awards are announced in June. But several plays have announced that they will not close as early as originally planned.

title: What Were Reading
description: Bloomberg Businessweek: KFC, once the fast-food emperor of China, is suddenly slumping because of competition and food-safety and avian-flu scares  while its once lagging United States business is perking up thanks to its boneless chicken (I Ate the Bones) promotion.   Glenn Collins

title: Geza Vermes, Scholar of Historical Jesus, Dies at 88
description: Geza Vermes, a religious scholar who argued that Jesus as a historical figure could be understood only through the Jewish tradition from which he emerged, and who helped expand that understanding through his widely read English translations of the Dead Sea Scrolls, died on May 8 in Oxford, England. He was 88.

title: Boston Symphony Orchestra Appoints Andris Nelsons as New Music Director
description: Andris Nelsons, a dynamic young Latvian conductor, has been named music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which has lingered without a leader for two years.

title: The Gun Report: May 16, 2013
description: Yesterday, on the Senate floor, Richard Durbin, the Illinois Democrat, gave a nine-minute speech about the continuing gun violence in the months since Newtown, and the Senates inability to pass a universal background check bill. To illustrate the ongoing carnagemore than 4,000 Americans have been killed by a gun since Newtown, he pointed outhe read excerpts from last weekends Gun Report. You can watch his remarks here.

title: Deadly Tornadoes Hit North Texas
description: A series of tornadoes struck towns south of Fort Worth, Tex., on Wednesday night, leaving scenes of devastation.

title: Pebble Raises $15 Million as Wave of Smart Watches Arrives
description: Rumor has it that everyone from Apple to Microsoft is working on smartwatches to compete with the handful that are already arriving on the market.

title: Hilary Mantel: By the Book
description: The author of Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies prefers books with action: I dont like overrefinement, or to dwell in the heads of vaporous ladies with fine sensibilities.

title: Image of the Day: May 16
Hot 97 Summer Jam Lineup Announced
description: Kendrick Lamar, Wale, French Montana and the Wu-Tang Clan will be the among the acts at the annual Hot 97 Summer Jam at MetLife Stadium, the station announced on Wednesday. Other acts on the bill include Chris Brown, Miguel, Fabolous, 2 Chainz, Action Bronson, ASAP Rocky, Joe Budden, Vinny Chase, Smoke DZA, Bodega Bamz, Troy Ave and Kid Ink. The concert will take place on June 2, and tickets are available through Ticketmaster.

title: For Rangers, a Chance to Steal a Victory
description: BOSTON  The Rangers will face a patchwork Bruins defense corps Thursday night, giving them a good chance to steal the opener of their second-round series in Boston.

title: Daily Report: Google Picks Up the Pace in Map Rivalry
description: On Wednesday, Google unveiled a new Google Maps, by far the biggest redesign since it introduced Maps eight years ago. Google announced the redesign at its annual I/O developers conference, where it also showed off new tools for search, photo editing and to-do lists, along with a music service and features for Android and Chrome apps, Claire Cain Miller reports in The New York Times.

title: Marathon Training, Minus the Long Run
description: Before runners cross the start line of the New Jersey Marathon, they hear two things: the bugle call to tell us to get to our post, followed by the ripping chords of Bruce Springsteens Born to Run.

title: Obama Answers Questions on I.R.S. and Benghazi
description: President Obama took questions from reporters on Thursday afternoon as he seeks to regain his political balance in dealing with controversies on multiple fronts and rising expressions of outrage from his Republican adversaries on Capitol Hill.

title: Libya in Mind, Obama Urges Better Security at Embassies
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, seeking to regain his footing amid persistent questions over last Septembers attack in Benghazi, Libya, called on Congress on Thursday to take action to bolster security at American Embassies.

title: Where German Politics Falter, Soccer Succeeds
description: Athens has seen its fair share of violence in its rich history, and as a dark red swastika flag burned brightly against smoke bombs, Syntagma Square descended into anarchy once more. Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany was visiting Greece, and she was not welcome.

title: Buying a House When Inventory Is Tight
description: As the housing market continues its recovery, prospective home buyers in some areas may have found, much to their dismay, that the inventory of houses for sale is somewhat limited, and sellers are receiving multiple offers.

title: JPMorgan Appoints Co-Heads of Global M.&A.
description: 5:19 p.m. | Updated

title: New Jersey Performing Arts Center Announces New Season
description: A symphonic concert devoted to the music of Led Zeppelin, and performances by several Motown greats including Diana Ross and Smokey Robinson, are among the events scheduled for the new season at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark.

title: So Ai Weiwei Was on His Way to a Mothers Day Dinner
description: BEIJING  To celebrate Mothers Day, Ai Weiwei, the Chinese artist and political malcontent, went to dine last Sunday at a restaurant on a famous eating strip in Beijing called Ghost Street.

title: Seeking to Engage Citizens, Athens Turns to New York for Advice
description: Could Michael R. Bloomberg save Athens?

title: Trying to Get to Heaven, Onstage
description: Scott Frankel recalled sitting next to his grandmother at a movie theater in suburban Cleveland, visibly moved as she watched the 2002 Todd Haynes film Far From Heaven, a deconstruction of the Eisenhower-era melodramas of the director Douglas Sirk. He had first seen the film, set in 1957 Connecticut, a few months before in Chelsea with an audience of devoted cinephiles, who nodded approvingly at its evocation of the overripe cinematic style of Sirk and laughed knowingly at its commentary on the past.

title: Amtrak Upgrades Wi-Fi Service on Trains
description: WASHINGTON  After years of criticism of the wireless service on its trains, Amtrak announced on Thursday that it had upgraded its cellular-based Wi-Fi using broadband technologies that will improve the speed and reliability of the Internet in its passenger cars.

title: U.S. Routs Russia to Reach Semifinals at World Championships
description: HELSINKI, Finland  In stunning fashion, the United States beat defending champion Russia, 8-3, on Thursday in the quarterfinals at the International Ice Hockey Federation world championships. It was the most goals allowed by a Russian team in this tournament.

title: Is There Really a Second-Term Curse?
description: President Obama is facing one of his roughest stretches in office after questions about the governments response to the attacks in Benghazi, Libya, the admission by the Internal Revenue Service that it inappropriately targeted conservative groups which sought tax-exempt status, and the revelation that the Justice Department subpoenaed communications by The Associated Press.

title: The Rembrandt of Basketball
description: The first time I talked to Phil Jackson, at a diner, he spontaneously sketched a play on his place mat. I try to keep things professional when Im doing an interview, but I have to admit there was a not-tiny part of me that was squealing, internally: OMG the winningest N.B.A. coach of all time is literally drawing me a play right now, just like he drew Michael Jordan plays during time outs  OMG Ive finally achieved my childhood dream of turning into Michael Jordan. (Phil Jackson, whom I wrote about in this weekends magazine, was leading Jordan to his first championships during the peak years of my adolescence, so the Jordan/Jackson mythology is still plugged into some pretty preprofessional emotional zones for me.)

title: Why Basketball Wont Leave Phil Jackson Alone
description: Everyone wants to know what Phil Jackson is doing.

title: Theater
description: ARKANSAS

title: Behind the I.R.S. Mess: A Campaign-Finance Scandal
description: Lets stipulate that the scandal involving the Internal Revenue Services targeting of conservative nonprofit groups portrays government as if drawn in caricature  an almost Keystone Kops-style comedy of errors on the part of low-level staffers, with a vein of possible political bias.

title: Swipe a Card, Get a Car
description: Car2Go, the car-sharing service in Austin, Tex., from the German luxury-car maker Daimler, has plans to add up to five cities, including Denver, Minneapolis and Montreal, to its North American roster this year. The services fleet of electric and standard Smart cars allows for rentals by the minute and in one direction. It frees drivers from picking up and returning cars to a specific location by letting them use their smartphones to locate available cars and unlock them by scanning their membership cards.

title: Market Report | Carry-On Essentials for Spring Jet-Setters
description: This seasons spring basics are unusually versatile, coming together to carry an outfit from day to night, business class to cocktail hour, the flyover states to the South of France  say, for the Cannes Film Festival, which kicked off yesterday. Here, a roundup of what should be in the jet-setters carry-on, including neutral accessories to complement any outfit and ballet flats with a punch of color. The only thing missing is the trip.

title: Prospect Sent Down Is Told to Keep His Chin Up
description: Shortly after he heard the news that his brief stay with the Yankees was over, Chris Nelson stood in a hallway near the teams clubhouse talking to someone who had been in the same situation: depressed, frustrated and returning to the minor leagues.

title: Spreading the Wealth
description: My husband and I are preparing our wills. We have two adult children: a daughter who is more successful than we are, and a son, who has been down on his luck for years. He also has three young children to educate. Everyone, including our lawyer and close friends, tells us that we should leave our money to them in equal shares to avoid hurt feelings. But that doesnt seem right. Our son needs the money. Still, we dont want to hurt our daughter. What would you do?

title: Pandit Rejoins Banking With Stake in Indian Financial Firm
description: LONDON  Vikram Pandit is getting back into banking.

title: New Apps Arrive on Google Glass
description: Google Glass, the companys Internet-connected glasses, will soon have seven new apps, including breaking news alerts from CNN, fashion features from Elle, Twitter, Tumblr and Facebook posts and reminder notes from Evernote.

title: Pills Tracked From Doctor to Patient to Aid Drug Marketing
description: In the old days, sales representatives from drug companies would chat up local pharmacists to learn what drugs doctors were prescribing. Now such shoulder-rubbing is becoming a quaint memory  thanks to vast databases of patient and doctor information being used by pharmaceutical companies to market drugs.

title: Bruins Marchand Is Expected to Play Game 1, Despite Apparent Injury
description: BOSTON  The big news from the morning skates before Game 1 Thursday was an apparent injury sustained by the pesky Bruins winger Brad Marchand that forced him from the ice. There was no contact or collision; he simply doubled over, apparently in pain, as he was skating and then left the ice.

title: Senate Panel Advances Nominee for E.P.A.
description: WASHINGTON  A sharply divided Senate committee on Thursday approved the nomination of Gina McCarthy to serve as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: The Tale of Wrong-Way McKenry
description: We are no longer accepting comments for this post. Thanks for participating. Well look to do it again.

title: A Case for Getting Far, Far Away
description: For a decade now Ive been obsessed with one of the most overlooked patches of real estate on the American Monopoly board  a place Ive never even seen and that youve probably never heard of called Aniakchak National Monument and Preserve. Aniakchak, which is in Alaska, is the least-visited of the 401 National Park Service properties. Just 19 people stopped by Aniakchak last year, which makes the runner-up, Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial in California  visitors: 533  a logjam of humanity by comparison.

title: Life, Interrupted: Getting Away
description: Like a lot of other cancer patients lying in hospital beds or in chemotherapy suites, I have spent a fair amount of time fantasizing about jetting off to a tropical island. A certain part of me knew that the fantasy was really about escaping my disease, but even so, I made a pastime of watching planes in the sky and dreaming of white, sandy beaches.

title: 2013 Mille Miglia Features Record Entry Numbers
description: BRESCIA, Italy  The 2013 Mille Miglia Storica tribute rally began Thursday evening here in a driving rainstorm, but the inclement weather did little to dampen the enthusiasm of a record entry of 415 starters. The list included a star-studded collection of film actors, musicians, major and minor celebrities, business executives, fashionistas, professional racing drivers and classic-car enthusiasts from around the world.

title: Decoded: Upfronts Get Bigger and Broader
description: The Times's Brian Stelter decodes why television networks are trying to broaden their offerings.

title: Unemployment Rate Falls to Lowest Level in Over Four Years
description: New York Citys unemployment rate fell in April to 8.4 percent, its lowest level in more than four years, as widespread hiring easily offset continued weakness on Wall Street, the State Labor Department reported on Thursday.

title: A Gentlemans Guide to Love & Murder Coming to Broadway
description: The musical comedy A Gentlemans Guide to Love & Murder, which has received critical acclaim in Hartford and San Diego for the dexterous performance of the Tony Award winner Jefferson Mays in multiple roles, will transfer to Broadway this fall, the producers confirmed on Thursday. The musical is to begin preview performances at the Walter Kerr Theater on Oct. 22 and open on Nov. 17, with Mr. Mays (I Am My Own Wife) again playing eight different heirs to the DYsquith family fortune  all of whom become targets for a disinherited distant relative.

title: Poetry Pairing | Prayer for a Bamboo-Flowering Famine
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches Prayer for a Bamboo-Flowering Famine by Karen An-Hwei Lee with the book review Fighting for Scraps by Pankaj Mishra.

title: President Obama on Benghazi Attack
description: At a news conference with Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey on Thursday, President Obama called on Congress to work with his administration to prevent another incident like Benghazi. (NBC)

title: Regulators Overhaul Derivatives Market, but With a Caveat
description: Federal regulators approved new rules on Thursday to shine a light on Wall Street trading, but they also softened a crucial aspect of the plan in the face of lobbying pressure from the nations biggest banks.

title: Groups Press Big Retailers on Safety Overseas
description: A large coalition of religious groups and investors is pressing major American retailers to join a sweeping plan to improve safety in Bangladesh apparel factories, calling on them to act together to force changes in overseas workplaces.

title: Not Heaven; Iowa: Lucas Mann Talks About Class A
description: In his first book, Class A: Baseball in the Middle of Everywhere, Lucas Mann chronicles the year he spent following the LumberKings, a minor league team in Clinton, Iowa, affiliated with the Seattle Mariners. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Mann discussed the teams fan base, the strange incentives of minor league existence and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: President Obama on the I.R.S.
description: During a rainy press conference at the Rose Garden, President Obama addressed the scandal of the I.R.S. specifically targeting conservative groups applying for tax-exempt status.

title: A Historic Immersion Before Whitney Moves
description: About a year ago the Manhattan artist T. J. Wilcox moved his studio from the lower floor of a Union Square building to its penthouse, where he suddenly had 360-degree views. At first I spent weeks just staring out of the window, he said. I pretty much thought it was the end of my art making.

title: Commencement 2013 | Things to Watch, Read, Teach and Do
description: Updated | May 22, 2013 We apologize: the video we used for this lesson seems to have been taken down, though you can, of course, still do the activity ideas weve listed.

title: Woodson Turns to Copeland, but Wont Desert Kidd
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Knicks Coach Mike Woodson made a number of statements Thursday after what could be his teams final shootaround of the 2012-13 season. With the Knicks on the brink of elimination in their Eastern Conference semifinals series against the Pacers, Woodson said he would demand his players be a tougher group in Game 5, which is Thursday night at Madison Square Garden. He also said all five players on the court would need to rebound in order to win.

title: The Sadomonetarists of Basel
description: The WSJ highlights a speech by Jaime Caruana, general manager of the Bank for International Settlements, warning of the dangers of easy money and the need to raise rates now to avert  something or other. And his views matter, says the Journal:

title: Exercise Class, Obedience Not Required
description: DOGS may be our best friends, but that doesnt necessarily make them the easiest exercise partners. The fitness trainer Angi Aramburu thinks otherwise, though, and this spring she started Go Fetch Run, an exercise class in which owners and their dogs can work out and play together.

title: President Obama on Media Shield Law
description: During Thursday's press conference at the White House, President Obama spoke about a media shield law in response to a question about the Justice Department seizing The Associated Press's phone logs.

title: Knicks Losing the Scrum at the 3-Point Line
description: The N.B.A. playoff series between the Knicks and the Indiana Pacers can be seen as a battle for the 3-point line. And, so far, the Pacers are winning.

title: New Provocations From the Belgian Bad Boy Wim Delvoye
description: The Belgian artist Wim Delvoye is known for making his friends perform sexual acts in front of X-ray machines, tattooing live pigs to look like Louis Vuitton handbags (and selling the hides and taxidermied animals from his farm in China) and finding the humanness in processes, like digestion, that dont exactly scream artful. But the show he opened last weekend at the Bowery gallery Sperone Westwater suggests a new maturity.

title: What We See When We Look at Wild Animals
description: Jon Mooallem, the author of last weeks cover story about the mysterious murders of some Hawaiian monk seals, has written often for the magazine about animals and what they mean to us. He has explored same-sex coupling in the animal world (The Love that Dare Not Squawk Its Name), for example, and helping turtles hatch after an oil spill (The BP-Spill Baby-Turtle Brigade). His first book, Wild Ones, published today, is also about animals or, more properly, about looking at people looking at animals.

title: Tortillas in Space
description: http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=AZx0RIV0wss

title: You Are Listening to The New York Times
description: When the San Francisco Giants won the 2010 World Series, the post-victory celebrations got out of control. Revelers smashed windows, got into fistfights and started fires. A Muni bus and the metaverse were both set alight.

title: Savagery, Mulled in Airy Precincts
description: The roof garden at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is one of the lovelier places to go in New York during the warm seasons. Every year its pastoral bliss high above Central Park is complemented by some sort of benign sculpture exhibition, usually three-dimensional works of formal decorum or playful ingenuity.

title: Imran Qureshis Work on the Roof of the Met
description: Mr. Qureshis installation evokes the aftermath of an attack.

title: Obama Names New Acting I.R.S. Chief
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama appointed Daniel I. Werfel, the controller of the Office of Management and Budget, to be the acting commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, the White House announced Thursday.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Frances Ha'
description: Noah Baumbach, the director of Frances Ha, narrates a scene featuring Greta Gerwig, Mickey Sumner and Adam Driver.

title: Nope, Still No Cover-Up
description: Now that the White House has released 100 pages worth of e-mails between the State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency over how to craft post-Benghazi talking points, we know three things.

title: When Rule Books Block the Road, Throw Them Out
description: This interview with  Ashok Subramanian, chief executive of Liazon, an employee benefits company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: Wedding Invitations and Wish Lists Dont Mix

title: Hollande Vows Reform as Critics Grow Louder
description: PARIS  Faced with a deepening economic malaise and mounting public dissatisfaction with his leadership, President Franois Hollande of France said on Thursday that he would go on the offensive, promising new measures to reduce unemployment and harmonize economic policies among the countries using the euro.

title: Theater Talkback: Farewell to Smash
description: The race for the big Tony for best musical is a real nail-biter, right? Will the award go to the front-runner, that splashy old-fashioned musical about a famous screen goddess? Or will there be an Avenue Q-type upset, with the funky downtown show about dueling pop stars taking home the big trophy?

title: Bronx Week Festival
description: The Beatles sang about a love affair so all-consuming that it required Eight Days a Week. The Bronx borough president, Ruben Diaz Jr., must know how they felt; he has taken a page from their songbook for this years annual Bronx Week festival, which takes 11 days to represent adequately the depth and diversity of Bronx culture. The celebrations final weekend is bursting with offerings, many of which, the Miser is happy to report, are free.

title: Killing Reveals the Still-Dark Side of a Gentrifying Capital
description: MEXICO CITY  This sprawling city has been described recently as vibrant (Elle Decor), rich with historical heritage and incredible food traditions (Saveur), scrubbed and safe (New York magazine) and inviting and exciting (Fodors).

title: Recalling the Life of the Party
description: Year after year, the pianist and singer Barbara Carroll recalled on Wednesday evening, she and her close friend Bobby Short used to share tea, cookies and gossip before his shows at the Caf Carlyle, where he held forth for three and a half decades. Ms. Carroll worked as the resident pianist across the hall at Bemelmans Bar for almost as many years. Shorts jovial exit line after their tte--ttes: I gotta go in and cook them greens.

title: Enigma Machines Fetch High Prices at Auctions
description: Late in World War II, fleeing German soldiers tried to destroy the equipment they used for transmitting messages in their Enigma code. Hundreds of salvageable machines, however, were left behind, and the technology, with alphabet keyboards and hidden rotors, still fascinates the public.

title: Silver to Seek Lopezs Expulsion From Assembly Over Harassment Claims
description: ALBANY  Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the New York Assembly, said on Thursday night that he would seek the expulsion of Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, the once-powerful Brooklyn Democrat, over accusations of sexual harassment by multiple women who worked for the Legislature.

title: Republican Drive to Block Cabinet Picks May Spur Change to Senate Rules
description: WASHINGTON  The escalating Senate fight over President Obamas cabinet appointments moved closer to a showdown on Thursday as two nominees headed to their confirmation votes without a single Republicans support.

title: Wheelies: The Return of Honda Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: An Artist With an Ever-Increasing Desire to Disappear
description: Jack Goldstein x 10,000, the first American museum retrospective of this brilliant but elusive artist, is both a celebration and a cautionary tale. It revels in Goldsteins posthumous influence as it reveals the tragic disconnect of his life and his art, the desire to disappear complicated by an intense careerist drive. For his masters thesis exhibition, he had himself buried in a wooden box fitted with a breathing tube; above ground, a blinking red light reassured the audience that he was still alive.

title: A New Spanish Language Consumer Finance Site
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has created a Spanish language Web site, joining a growing list of online resources for Spanish-speaking consumers.

title: Bunker
description: Inside the Ridgewood, Queens, restaurant featuring Vietnamese street-style food.

title: Reaping the Benefits of Lessons Well Learned
description: Flames leap out of a sawed-off oil barrel at the 24-hour scrap-metal yard across the street. Power lines droop, above them nothing but blue. It is practically big-sky country out here on the eastern edge of Ridgewood, Queens, buildings slouching and sun smacking down.

title: A Time When Things Started in Chicago
description: The Third Coast is an odd title for Thomas Dyjas engrossing, wide-angled cultural history of Chicago in the middle of the 20th century.

title: Tucked Away in Downtowns Din
description: B FLAT, the bar in TriBeCa, is a Petula Clark song (2013 remix).

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Frances Ha
description: The director Noah Baumbach appreciates long takes. In this video, he narrates a scene from Frances Ha, which he directed and also co-wrote with the films star, Greta Gerwig. The scene features Ms. Gerwig and Mickey Sumner, who plays Francess friend Sophie. Adam Driver plays Francess roommate Lev. Mr. Baumbach discusses the structure of the scene that mostly plays as a long take with minimal cuts.

title: Frenchman Staves Off Extradition in Diamond Theft
description: METZ, France  The French owner of a luxury car business  accused of masterminding a $50 million million diamond theft at Brussels Airport  temporarily fended off extradition to Belgium on Thursday, arguing that the authorities there had not spelled out his precise role.

title: ESPN to Gain Full Rights to U.S. Open in 2015
description: For decades, the United States Open tennis tournament was a mainstay of broadcast television, along with the Super Bowl, the World Series and the Masters. From Billie Jean King and Rod Laver to Roger Federer and the Williams sisters,viewers knew they could watch superstars, rising talents and upstarts play in the mens and womens finals and semifinals  and more  on CBS.

title: Drug Marketers Use Social Network Diagrams to Help Locate Influential Doctors
description: Consulting companies like Activate Networks use social network diagrams to help pharmaceutical marketers identify prescribing histories and relationships among doctors.

title: A Meet-Up of Freedom, Innovation and Intensity
description: Pam Tanowitz is sometimes described as a deconstructionist of ballet and modern dance. This makes her sound formidably cerebral, and its true that throughout much of last years lecturelike Untitled (Blue Ballet) you had to pinch yourself to stay awake. But The Spectators, her new dance that opened at New York Live Arts on Wednesday, is almost unbearably exciting. Its a return to form that pushes further. The experience it offers a spectator is exhilarating enough to make spectating an inadequate verb.

title: The Overtime Hero Is Anyones Guess
description: If one were forced to guess which Pittsburgh Penguin would score a game-winning goal in overtime, Brooks Orpik would be among the last on the list.

title: Klinsmann Takes 26 to U.S. Camp
description: Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States national team, invited 26 players to a training camp in Cleveland on Thursday ahead of two international friendlies and three World Cup qualifying matches in June.

title: Rodney Graham
description: 303 Gallery

title: Michele Abeles: English for Secretaries
description: 47 Canal

title: At a County Fair, Across the Pond
description: In Exeter, England, Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, tries some jam and cream Thursday as she tours the Devon County Show. The event is a showcase for agricultural livestock and produce, and is also used as a barometer of the countrys agricultural industry.

title: Rafael Leonardo Black: Insider Art
description: Francis M. Naumann Fine Art

title: Wolfgang Tillmans: From Neue Welt
description: Andrea Rosen Gallery

title: Helen Berggruen: The Open Window: Objects, Rooms and Landscapes
description: Fischbach Gallery

title: Pictures of the Day: Myanmar and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Myanmar, the Philippines, Afghanistan and Iraq.

title: From a Moving Van to an Arts Complex
description: JERSEY CITY  MANA Contemporary might be one of the art worlds best-kept secrets. From the outside, at the moment, it looks like what its shell actually is: a cluster of warehouse and factory buildings left over from a grimy industrial age, tucked into the heart of this city.

title: Why National Guard and Reservist Suicide Numbers May Be Misleading
description: More than 80 percent of the services members who committed suicide in recent years had never been in combat. This is one of the many statistics that the Pentagon and researchers are currently struggling to explain. My colleague James Dao and I explore the tragic rising military suicide numbers in an article today.

title: A Fine Line Between Social and Political
description: As everyone from Republican senators to President Obama denounces the Internal Revenue Service for singling out Tea Party organizations for extra scrutiny, it is worth asking how we got to the point that the I.R.S. is supposed to investigate political activities. It is also worth asking whether the tax law is being widely flouted by political groups determined to avoid disclosure of their donors  and whether successive administrations have failed to enforce the law.

title: Breaking the Mold
description: In Helene Weckers first novel, two more than usually disoriented foreigners emerge onto the streets of 1899 New York. One is a golem, a clay woman fashioned near Danzig, then shipped across the ocean as the wife of a man who inconveniently dies on the voyage. The other is a jinni from the Syrian desert, trapped inside a copper flask until a hapless tinsmith sets him free during a routine repair. It was ludicrous, thinks the surprised tinker. Such things were only stories. But then, the only alternative was to conclude that hed gone mad. There is in fact plenty of madness in this clever story, but the magic of it often makes more sense than the ways of the humans with whom the golem and the jinni now live.

title: Whats Real Today (Check Again Soon)
description: Digital makes, and the art world takes. Thats reality today. So A Different Kind of Order, the title of the International Center of Photographys fourth triennial, and its best yet, is apt.

title: The PG Lives of X-Rated Stars
description: A Teaser of I Love Your Work by Jonathan Harris on Vimeo.

title: Presidential Politics and the I.R.S.
description: The Timess Sam Tanenhaus explains how some of President Obamas predecessors, including Richard Nixon, used the I.R.S. as a political weapon.

title: Michaels Still the Top Name for New York Babies, and There Are Reasons
description: Updated, 6:15 p.m. | After half a century, New York still loves Michael very, very much.

title: Doctor and Patient: A Gothic Love Story
description: The 19th-century French neurologist Jean-Martin Charcot is best remembered as a teacher of William James and Sigmund Freud, and also for the haunting, fascinating photographs he collected of patients in various states of symptomatic mental distress. Like other important figures in the history of medicine, he is a complicated figure in retrospect, at once a charlatan and a pioneer, a monster and a modernizer.

title: Justice Dept. Lost Track of Terrorists, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department temporarily lost track of two former terrorists who had participated in its witness protection program and until recently did not disclose the fictitious identities it created for terrorism-linked witnesses to the agency that generates watch lists, allowing some who were on the no-fly list to take commercial flights under their new names, according to a new report.

title: Pieces Fall Into Place, Ending Six-Game Skid
description: ST. LOUIS  The Mets, starting to feel suffocated under the burden of losing, found a moment of relief Thursday afternoon.

title: A Deduction Unevenly Used
description: A new report from the Pew Charitable Trusts reinforces what many economists have been saying for some time: the mortgage interest deduction primarily benefits high-income homeowners.

title: If 27 Is Old, How Old Is Grown Up?
description: One day an unexpected tax refund arrives in the mail, and Frances, giddy over this windfall, decides to spend it treating a young man to dinner. (His name is Lev, he is played by Adam Driver, and this is the only time I will mention Lena Dunham or Girls in this review.) The restaurant rejects her credit card and wont take a debit card, so Frances sets off through the black-and-white streets of New York in search of an A.T.M. Sprinting back to the table, she trips and sprawls headlong onto the sidewalk, the full calamity of her fall blocked from the cameras view by a parked car. Then she gets up and keeps running.

title: 36 Hours in Texas Hill Country
description: There are two ways to think about the Texas Hill Country. Physically, it spreads across the undulating Edwards Plateau, with Austin to the east and San Antonio to the south. Near the center is Fredericksburg, which was once the main show in these parts, but no longer. To get a feeling for the Hill Country in the second sense  the state of mind where cool mingles with tradition, and industriousness and idleness are equally esteemed values (depending on the time of day)  head out among the limestone knolls full of live oak groves and cypress-lined creeks, and to the gritty pin-dot towns built largely of native stone. Here youll find a delicious tension between rural and refined. Inns and restaurants are bringing a clever touch to Lone Star hospitality and mythology, and with the vineyards and boutique farms (lavender, olives), some people make comparisons to Napa Valley or even Provence. But those assessments ignore something fundamental: the Hill Country  being Texas at its finest  is like nowhere else in the world.

title: A Taste of Texas
description: A mesquite-smoked meal is just part of a trip through Hill Country.

title: Beyond the Pale as Well as the Els
description: The elite residents of the Upper East Side from Fifth Avenue to Park generally balked once they got to Third Avenue, the elevated train forming a last barrier between the gentry and the working class. But a few visionaries breached that Chinese wall, including the developers of 333 East 68th, who braved the forbidden zone, adding white-gloved doormen in among the tenements.

title: New Jersey Lawmakers Use Manhattan City Hall to Push Tobacco Plan
description: It had all the trappings of a city news conference, including a starring role for the City Council speaker. But the topic at hand in City Halls Red Room on Thursday was New Jersey.

title: Slower Schedule for Soaps as Web-Based Series
description: Just two weeks after they transported the television soap operas All My Children and One Life to Live to the Internet, the producers have decided to cut in half the release schedule for each show to two days a week each, from four days.

title: Gladiatorial Combat: The Battle of the Big
description: The Chelsea gallery scene regularly stages clashes of titans, but an especially elaborate cage match is under way right now.

title: The Sounds of Tunisia, Mixed With the Worlds
description: Two very different kinds of current music from Tunisia  one for the concert stage, one for the dance floor, both wide open to global connections  were part of the French Institute Alliance Franaises monthlong World Nomads Tunisia festival on Wednesday night. At the institutes auditorium, Ghalia Benali performed songs that were rooted in Tunisia but that could float east or west. Then, at the meatpacking district club Catch, disc jockeys from the Waveform collective in Tunis wielded laptops and mixers in music that moved from molten and experimental to crisply propulsive.

title: J.C. Penneys New Plan Is to Reuse Its Old Plans
description: J. C. Penney already brought back its old chief executive. Now it is restoring his old strategies.

title: This Weeks Movies: May 17, 2013
description: The New York Times critics on Frances Ha, Augustine and Star Trek: Into Darkness.

title: Club Trio Inspired by Gees Bend Quilters
description: A sanctified rumble moved through Jaimeo Browns show at Drom in the East Village on Tuesday night. It began as Mr. Brown, a well-traveled drummer in his mid-30s, played a cymbal roll over a sampled gospel vocal; it ended, about an hour later, at a fever pitch. What came in between was changeable in its dimensions but steadfast in its purpose.

title: Homebodies Quiver and Soar Amid Bits of Domesticity
description: As the company model in contemporary dance disappears in favor of a project-driven approach, its harder for dancers to find sustaining work. But for those performers who still dream of joining a company, Hubbard Street Dance Chicago, a repertory troupe led by Glenn Edgerton, is an actual fish in the sea.

title: Theater Listings for May 17-23
description: Theater

title: Woodpecker
description: From The Handsome Familys album Wilderness on Carrot Top Records

title: Comedy Listings for May 17-23
description: Comedy

title: Movie Listings for May 17-23
description: Movies

title: Pop and Rock Listings for May 17-23
description: Pop

title: Jazz Listings for May 17-23
description: Jazz

title: Ducking Rain and Competition at Cannes
description: CANNES, France  For many, the Cannes Film Festival summons up shimmering images of beautiful men and women drifting up a red carpet as photographers shout their names. Leo! Carey! Leo! Carey!

title: Eli Zabars Carnegie Hill Town House
description: An Upper East Side resident for over 35 years, Manhattans famed food purveyor shows off his family home.

title: The Flip Side of Clamor
description: For those so inclined, there are many places to perch in Eli Zabars four-story Carnegie Hill town house.

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for May 17-23
description: Classical

title: Dance Listings for May 17-23
description: Dance

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for May 17-23
description: Art

title: Beckhams Best
description: Some highlights of David Beckhams best goals over his long career in England, Spain, the United States and France.

title: Spare Times for Children for May 17-23
description: Sideways Stories From Wayside School

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Google the Competitor, and a Site Crasher
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Spare Times for May 17-23
description: Internet Week New York (Monday through May 27) Like the Internet itself, this annual Web festival  the sixth  will offer something for everyone, with workshops, panel discussions, parties and performances. On Wednesday at 3 p.m., Randi Zuckerberg, bottom left, the chief executive of Zuckerberg Media and an older sister of Mark Zuckerberg, will talk about her business at a keynote address at festival headquarters, the Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street, Chelsea.

title: Hollywoods Freebies
description: How not to economize: rent Buster Keatons The General on iTunes for $3.99, as my husband and I did a couple Fridays ago, and then purchase it the next night for $12.99 when your kid begs to watch it again. Much better to visit Open Cultures Web site instead, where you can find links to, among other things, 525 oldies in the public domain and other free films (be sure to scroll down to see the list, rather than using the search bar).

title: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 8
description: The Bats blog again tests our readers predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, tea leaves, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

title: New Jersey Hospital Has Highest Billing Rates in the Nation
description: BAYONNE, N.J.  The most expensive hospital in America is not set amid the swaying palm trees of Beverly Hills or the luxury townhouses of New Yorks Upper East Side.

title: J.&J. Unit Phasing Out All-Metal Hip Devices
description: The orthopedic unit of Johnson & Johnson said Thursday that it was phasing out production of all-metal replacement hips, a move reflecting an industrywide trend to abandon the once widely used implants because of high early failure rates.

title: Hollywood Does Arabia, From A to B
description: You may not agree with every observation in Michael Singhs documentary Valentinos Ghost. But this engrossing examination of American perceptions of Arabs and the Arab world gets you thinking.

title: Willa Cathers Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Hearts, Minds, Bodies
description: To the Editor:

title: Take It
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding Florida
description: To the Editor:

title: Be True to Your Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Long Journey to College, but I Was Never Alone
description: Sush Krishnamoorthy, a student from New Delhi, is part of The Choice class that includes student-bloggers from Nairobi, Kenya; Topeka, Kan.; Seattle; Rogers, Ark.; Las Vegas; New York City; and Hunting Valley, Ohio. Her final post is below.  Tanya Abrams

title: Balloon Animals and Snow White
description: Images from new exhibitions of works by Jeff Koons and Paul McCarthy.

title: Chilean Judge Upholds Manslaughter Charges Linked to 2010 Tsunami
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  A judge dismissed an appeal to suspend involuntary manslaughter charges against four government officials accused of failing to issue a tsunami alert after the 8.8-magnitude earthquake that struck Chile in 2010.

title: What Elliott Management Sees in NetApp
description: What does Elliott Management see in NetApp Inc.? A lot of potential to improve a stagnant stock price.

title: An Intrepid Foundling and Her Unlikely Mentor
description: Guy Pearce is an award-winning actor with dozens of film and television roles on his rsum, but in 33 Postcards he is eclipsed by an unknown young actress named Zhu Lin, whose charming performance gives this sweet if not very credible film its heart.

title: Juvenile Inmates Found to Be at No Greater Risk for Prison Rape
description: Youth advocates have long argued that juveniles incarcerated in adult prisons and jails are at heightened risk for rape and other forms of sexual abuse because of their age. But a government survey released on Thursday found that juveniles did not report significantly more sexual victimization than adult inmates.

title: Just Us Girls, They Thought. Oops.
description: One of the funnier television comedies in recent years has been The League, a bawdy FX series about a fantasy football league. Fans of that show might expect a lot of laughs from Black Rock, since it was written by a League cast member, Mark Duplass, and stars another, Katie Aselton, who also directed it.

title: Clip: Pieta
description: A scene from "Pieta," directed by Kim Ki-duk.

title: In a Vicious Sadist, the Faintest Glimmer of Soul
description: Morally cunning and with a tone as black as pitch, Pieta, the 18th film from the South Korean director Kim Ki-duk, is a deeply unnerving revenge movie in which redemption is dangled like a cat toy before a cougar. The beast in question is Kang-do (Lee Jung-jin), a merciless bag man for a powerful moneylender who cripples slum-dwelling debtors to collect on their insurance claims. As cold to himself as to his clients, he lives in a comfortless flat where the entrails from the previous nights chicken dinner still decorate the bathroom floor. So when a strange woman (Cho Min-soo) begins to stalk him, claiming to be the mother who abandoned him long ago, Kang-do barely hesitates: he rapes her.

title: Performing From Space, Canadas Low-Orbit Star
description: OTTAWA  As far as YouTube hits go, Canadas contribution has not yet approached the popularity of South Koreas Gangnam Style. And perhaps because of the limitations of weightlessness, the music video lacked any dance moves at all.

title: Out of Necessity, Yanks Call Up Betances
description: Before the 2012 season, Dellin Betances was a top 50 prospect in baseball and one of the Yankees most promising young players. But after a season in which he posted a 6.44 earned run average, Betances dropped off top prospect lists and was thought to be far away from making the majors.

title: Keeping Kosher in Nigeria, a Tiny but Fervent Minority
description: Are the Ibo people of Nigeria a lost tribe of Israel? A longstanding tradition among the Ibo says they are, and points to similarities in Ibo and Jewish cultures: a prescribed day of rest, circumcision (male, that is), the prohibition of pork. And now some Ibo have embraced Judaism, considering it the religion of their ancestors.

title: As Japan Courts Growth, Europe Keeps Up Its Love Affair With Austerity
description: BERLIN  For years, Japan and Europe have been the sick men of the world economy. This week, their paths diverged.

title: New Fracking Rules Proposed for U.S. Land
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Thursday issued a new set of proposed rules governing hydraulic fracturing for oil and gas on public lands, moving further to address industry concerns about the costs and reporting burdens of federal regulation.

title: Battle of the Bullhorns as a Wind Project Beckons
description: From the initial proposal in 2001, the Cape Wind project  130 turbines across a 24-square-mile stretch of Nantucket Sound  has stirred furious dissent. The installation would be the nations first offshore wind farm, reducing the fossil fuel emissions around coastal Massachusetts and helping to develop a clean-energy industry. But residents howl that the project would despoil a pristine seascape, damage fishing grounds, foul ferry and air traffic and even disrupt the religious practices of the Wampanoag tribe.

title: Greece: Teachers Abandon Strike Plan
description: Greek high school teachers on Thursday called off a planned strike after the government essentially banned it by enacting an emergency law that threatened strikers with arrest or dismissal. The teachers were unable to attract widespread political and public support for the planned Friday walkout, and after the governments move a vote by the teachers failed to secure a majority. Only 23 percent voted in favor of joining the strike. The two main labor unions also refused to back the proposed strike, instead staging a four-hour walkout on Thursday that disrupted public services and flights. The teachers object to the governments plans to increase their working hours, fearing the move will lead to job cutbacks. Amnesty International condemned the governments blanket prohibition on the teachers right to strike, describing the use of an emergency law as unnecessary and disproportionate and a human rights violation.

title: Sudden Impulse, and a Warrior Is Born
description: At the end of 2008, Tim DeChristopher, a young economics student at the University of Utah, strolled into a federal auction of oil and gas drilling rights to prime Utah wilderness. Although he was opposed to the auction, which he considered illegal and unethical, he had no plans to disrupt it, but when he was mistakenly handed a paddle, he chose to use it, knowing that he had no way to pay for the parcels he would eventually win.

title: A Benz With a Virtual Chauffeur
description: HAMBURG, Germany  Hangar doors slid open to reveal a fleet of white Mercedes-Benz vehicles arrayed on a rain-slicked runway.

title: That Elusive Seat at the U.N. Table
description: The United Nations currently has 193 member nations. The dream of, and the work toward, member status for Palestinians is the subject of State 194, an intelligent, evenhanded Israeli documentary by Dan Setton about a two-state solution for coexistence. Mr. Setton, a Peabody Award- and Emmy-winning director and producer, was inspired by a 2009 radio speech by Prime Minister Salam Fayyad of the Palestinian Authority, who left office last month.

title: The Morning Nine
description: The horses for the 138th running of the Preakness Stakes are listed in order of post position with comments by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Both have also selected their win-place-show horses for the race. The morning-line odds were set by Frank Carulli of Pimlico Race Course.

title: Clips, Quips and Snips: A Wrap-Up of Upfronts
description: HERE is a look back at some highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the annual upfronts week, which took place from Monday through Thursday as television executives offered Madison Avenue previews of their schedules for the 2013-14 season.

title: Jockey Is Atop the Favorite, and All of Racing
description: BALTIMORE  It was a claiming race with a modest purse of $30,000, but Joel Rosario strode into the paddock of Belmont Park last Sunday with the laser focus that has made him the top jockey in America. He was riding the mare Delightful Dawn for the first time, but had watched video replays of her races and knew she liked to stalk the leaders and try to get past them in the stretch.

title: Uzbek Man in Idaho Is Held in Bomb Plot
description: WASHINGTON  Federal authorities arrested an Uzbek man on Thursday in Boise, Idaho, on charges that he provided a foreign terrorist group with help in building an explosive device.

title: A Last Stand for Nature Against Mighty Odds
description: The back-to-basics title of Elemental seems to herald another pious lesson about a world out of balance, but the filmmakers, Gayatri Roshan and Emmanuel Vaughan-Lee, have made a documentary that is more about environmentalists than about environmentalism. Following an indigenous Canadian activist, a crusading government official in India and a struggling inventor, this sensitively scored film complicates the typical missionarys-progress arc by acknowledging its would-be heroes weaknesses and the day-to-day obstacles to doing good.

title: Concerns Arise on U.S. Effort to Allow Internet Wiretaps
description: Surveillance can be a tricky affair in the Internet age.

title: Apple Fights Back in Antitrust Case Over E-Book Prices
description: WASHINGTON  Dont mess with the legacy of Steve Jobs.

title: Syria Begins to Break Apart Under Pressure From War
description: CAIRO  The black flag of jihad flies over much of northern Syria. In the center of the country, pro-government militias and Hezbollah fighters battle those who threaten their communities. In the northeast, the Kurds have effectively carved out an autonomous zone.

title: Obama Tells Pentagon Leaders Sexual Assault Is Shameful
description: WASHINGTON  With arrests in the military continuing to shadow its program to combat sexual harassment, President Obama summoned the Pentagons senior leaders to the White House on Thursday, telling them that the levels of sexual assault across the armed services were a disgrace that undermined the trust essential for the military to carry out its mission effectively.

title: Debating the Legal Basis for the War on Terror
description: WASHINGTON  A top Pentagon official said Thursday that the evolving war against Al Qaeda was likely to continue at least 10 to 20 years and urged Congress not to modify the statute that provides its legal basis.

title: Aiming for the Top, Again
description: On Wall Street, the wheel of fortune can spin around and around, from enormous cash bonuses and luxurious perks one year to the unemployment line the next.

title: Outrunning Assassins, Sulky Daughter in Tow
description: For his first film in English, the German director Philipp Stlzl travels a long way from the cheeky flirtations of Young Goethe in Love to Erased, a bearable if unremarkable composite of the Taken movies and Three Days of the Condor.

title: Gunshots on Warm Spring Evenings
description: NEWARK  A FEW Saturdays ago, at the early evening hour when children linger outside to wring the last fun they can from the day, a series of gunshots split the air near the corner of Chadwick and Avon Avenues. Everyone scattered. After the cops arrived and taped off the intersection and determined that no one at the scene had been hit, the street slowly stirred back to life.

title: Learning From Litigation
description: LOS ANGELES  MUCH of the discussion over the Affordable Care Act has focused on whether it will bring down health care costs. Less attention has been paid to another goal of the act: improving patient safety. Each year tens of thousands of people die, and hundreds of thousands more are injured, as a result of medical error.

title: How Latin Culture Got More Gay
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  BRAZIL is potentially poised to become the third and largest country in Latin America to legalize same-sex marriage, following a judicial order on Tuesday. Argentina was the first, in 2010, after the government brushed aside objections from Cardinal Jorge Bergoglio of Buenos Aires, now the pope. The Uruguayan legislature followed suit last month. Mexico City has allowed such unions since 2010, and the Mexican state of Quintana Roo since 2011.

title: Stacks of Bibles, and Graphic Novels
description: To readers of philosophy, logos means reason and rational argument. To readers of the Gospels, it is the word of God made incarnate in Jesus Christ. But for seekers of all kinds on the Upper East Side, Logos is also a cozy bookshop with a lumpy recliner and a black cat named Boo Boo, who sleeps near a stack of Bibles.

title: Can Obama Save Turkey From a Syrian Quagmire?
description: WASHINGTON  WHEN Turkeys prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, met President Obama at the White House on Thursday, the most pressing topic was the war in Syria. Turkey has not faced a threat on this scale since Stalin demanded territory from the Turks in 1945.

title: Neighborhood Joint: Logos Bookstore
description: Logos, on the Upper East Side, caters to readers looking for religious texts, fiction, holiday cards, or chats about life and faith.

title: Foxconn Audit Finds a Workweek Still Too Long
description: Foxconn Technology, the company that manufactures Apples popular iPads and iPhones, has made substantial progress toward improving safety and other working conditions at three of its Chinese plants dedicated to making Apple products. But it has not yet achieved the most difficult goal: reducing the average workweek to the maximum allowed by Chinese law, a global monitoring group said on Thursday.

title: When Governments Go Bad
description: Government, Clinton Rossiter once wrote, is something like fire: Under control, it is the most useful of servants; out of control, it is a ravaging tyrant.

title: The Jets Quarterback Vortex Has Sanchezs Head Spinning
