description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  David Garrards locker contained a football, a couple of pairs of sandals and some deodorant. A few workout shirts hung on a bar, and a Jets hat rested on a shelf. It looked as if he had stepped away for a few minutes, to take a shower or answer a phone call, and not wandered straight into retirement.

title: Russia Sends More Advanced Missiles to Aid Assad in Syria
description: WASHINGTON  Russia has sent advanced antiship cruise missiles to Syria, a move that illustrates the depth of its support for the Syrian government led by President Bashar al-Assad, American officials said Thursday.

title: A President Tries to Regain His Footing
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama was in the middle of a careful answer to a question about whether anyone in the White House knew that the Internal Revenue Service was targeting conservative groups, when the rain started to fall. Intermittently, at first; then a steady patter.

title: Cold War Malaise at Launch Control
description: It sounded like an alternative ending to Dr. Strangelove, subtitled: How They Grew Careless Managing Nuclear Missiles. Seventeen Air Force officers assigned to launch control for nuclear-tipped Minuteman missiles were removed from their posts last month for violating safety and code protection procedures and showing poor attitudes.

title: Scandal Machine
description: When politicians want to turn scandals into metaphors, actual details of wrongdoing or incompetence no longer matter. In fact, the details of the troubles swirling around the White House this week are bluntly contradicting Republicans who want to combine them into a seamless narrative of tyrannical government on the rampage.

title: The Murky World of Hospital Prices
description: Last week, the federal government made public a vast trove of information on the list prices charged by hospitals for a large array of procedures commonly performed on hospitalized patients. It was a good start toward providing greater transparency in hospital billing, which has long been shrouded in secrecy. But it fell short of providing full information that patients need to make informed decisions about which hospitals to use and which insurance to buy.

title: A Lower Standard for Drunken Driving
description: It is surprising how few drinks can impair a drivers judgment. A report from the National Transportation Safety Board estimates that alcohol-impaired driving contributes to thousands of deaths and tens of thousands of serious injuries each year. It is right to urge states to reduce that toll by lowering the allowable blood-alcohol concentration for drivers from 0.08 percent to 0.05 percent.

title: Too Drunk to Drive
Mold After the Hurricane
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking Justice for Black Farmers in Loan Bias Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Different Ways of Looking at the I.R.S.
Genetic Testing for Women at Risk of Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Surveillance of The A.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: I.M.F. and the Global Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial on Guatemalan Civil War Carnage Leaves Out U.S. Role
description: MEXICO CITY  In 1999, President Bill Clinton went to Guatemala and apologized. Just two weeks earlier, a United Nations truth commission found Guatemalan security forces responsible for more than 90 percent of the human rights violations committed during the countrys long civil war.

title: A Prudent Move by Rose, if Not a Popular One
description: CHICAGO  The Bulls exit from the playoffs with a 3-point loss to the Miami Heat will only add fuel to Chicagos latest sports furor. Much of the city is livid that Derrick Rose did not return to the court after a year of rehabilitation from knee surgery.

title: Rebuilding of Mali Faces Daunting Obstacles, Despite Outside Aid
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The outpouring of support may be more a sign of nervousness than altruism.

title: Weiners Wife Didnt Disclose Consulting Work She Did While Serving in State Dept.
description: The State Department, under Secretary Hillary Rodham Clinton, created an arrangement for her longtime aide and confidante Huma Abedin to work for private clients as a consultant while serving as a top adviser in the department.

title: G.O.P., Energized, Weighs How Far to Take Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON  The investigations ensnaring the White House have unified the Republican Party, energized a political base shattered by election losses and given common purpose to lawmakers divided over a legislative agenda.

title: Veecks Son Dusts Off Old Idea and Crowdsources the Umpiring
description: ST. PAUL  The left-handed batter tried to check his swing in the first inning. In a reflex honed through thousands of innings behind the plate, Dwight Childs, a catcher for the St. Paul Saints of the independent American Association, pointed up the third-base line, appealing for a swinging strike call.

title: Nerdy Passions of the Stand-Up Patriot
description: As the cultural status of stand-up comics has risen, these restless gypsies who moved from hotels and coffee houses to comedy clubs and alternative rooms have migrated in growing numbers to the theater. One pioneer is Colin Quinn, who after two solo shows on Broadway (the first in 1998), now mounts off Broadway a pleasingly funny amble through American history in Unconstitutional.

title: Love Away From the Battlefield
description: The clash of armies is not to be heard during Natasha, Pierre and the Great Comet of 1812, the vibrant, transporting new musical adapted from a potent slice of Tolstoys War and Peace. True, Napoleon is nominally present, presiding with a stern semi-smile over the proceedings from within a copy of a Jacques-Louis David portrait. But the roiling sounds of battle do not intrude on the romantic drama unfolding before us in Dave Malloys freshly imagined pop opera, which opened on Thursday night at a custom-built cabaret called Kazino, in the meatpacking district.

title: Dangerous When Leaked
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  You can always get on my good side by stretching DR. STRANGELOVE across the middle of a grid. Oddly, the name of the Peter Sellers character hasnt been seen since 1988, so we might as well consider it sort of a debut. Its crossed by SILICON VALLEY, another debut, and the other two 13s include DEATH IN VENICE, another favorite of mine and POST-MODERNISM. Were off to a good start on this Josh Knapp puzzle.

title: 16 Accused of Smuggling Cigarettes Worth Millions
description: One of the men had once lived in the same Brooklyn building as the personal secretary of a senior Hamas member, the authorities said. Another was something of a father figure to the terrorist who fatally shot at a van full of yeshiva students on the Brooklyn Bridge. And a third is said to have once received an investment from Omar Abdel Rahman, the so-called blind sheik, who is now serving a life sentence for a terrorism plot.

title: Man May Face Jail for Refusing to Testify in Bomb Case, Again
description: A 24-year-old self-described Brooklyn anarchist may be headed to jail after refusing on Thursday for the second time to testify before a grand jury believed to be examining the explosion of a homemade bomb that damaged an armed-forces recruitment center in Times Square in 2008.

title: De Blasio Offers Plan to Help Immigrants Assimilate
description: Bill de Blasio, the New York City public advocate and a Democratic mayoral candidate, unveiled a set of initiatives on Thursday that he said were intended to help integrate more undocumented immigrants into the mainstream.

title: Case Casts Harsh Light on Family Art Business
description: For years, high-end auctions at Sothebys and Christies have featured a familiar tableau  members of the Nahmad family spread out in the front row, sometimes six or seven people across. Little known outside the art market but a pivotal force within it, the family, whose worth is estimated at $3 billion, has amassed one of the largest collections of Impressionist and Modernist art in the world, including one of the largest holdings of Picasso in private hands. They did it with a purchasing style that has never been subtle: they chase as many as a third of the works offered in an evening and then warehouse them for years until it is the right time to sell.

title: Quinn Camp Excoriating Thompson on DAmato
description: Early in the mayoral race, Christine C. Quinn, the New York City Council speaker and presumed Democratic front-runner, has tended to stay above the fray, sometimes defending herself but rarely initiating an attack.

title: For M.T.A., Flood Plan Is Still a Work in Progress
description: Inside a crew room at the new South Ferry subway station, once flooded wall to wall with the waters of Hurricane Sandy, transit officials on Thursday offered a sobering progress report on a system that continues to feel the storms effects.

title: Trial Opens in the Killing of a Young Basketball Star
description: In the final moments of her young life, she danced in the playground next to her apartment building with her big sister and friends, joyfully oblivious to the bloody turf fights roiling from block to block all around her.

title: Lawyer Criticizes Brooklyn Prosecutor Over TV Show
description: A decision by the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, to let his office be the subject of a six-part CBS News series has prompted another volley of criticism  this time from a lawyer complaining that the show, Brooklyn D.A., would prejudice prospective jurors when his client goes on trial.

title: Lottery Numbers
Scientists Agree Overwhelmingly on Global Warming. Why Doesnt the Public Know That?
description: THE HAGUE  Most climate scientists agree that global warming is caused by human activity, according to a new survey of published papers on climate science.

title: Missouri: Diocese Settles Abuse Case
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph has settled a lawsuit for $600,000 brought by the family of a girl who was 2 years old when Rev. Shawn Ratigan took pornographic pictures of her in 2006. The diocese discovered hundreds of lewd photos of young girls on Father Ratigans laptop in 2010, and the case involving the 2-year-old is one of several civil suits against the priest and the diocese brought by the girls and their families. Father Ratigan pleaded guilty last year and is awaiting sentencing. His bishop, Robert W. Finn, was convicted on a misdemeanor charge of failing to report suspected child abuse to authorities.

title: Fecal Matter Found in Public Pools
description: More than half of water samples from about 150 public swimming pools in Atlanta contained traces of fecal matter, a level of contamination that is most likely similar to levels across the country, researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found in a study.

title: Louisiana: 2 Arrested in Shootings at New Orleans Parade
description: The police in New Orleans arrested two brothers and charged them both with 20 counts of attempted murder in connection with a shooting spree at a parade on Sunday that left 20 people wounded, 3 of them in critical condition. Akein Scott, 19, was arrested late Wednesday night and Shawn Scott, 24, was arrested on Thursday morning. The police also arrested and charged four others, ages 19 to 32, for providing comfort and aid to Akein Scott after investigators identified him as the likely gunman. The police said that the younger brother was a member of a gang, and several news outlets reported that he had been targeting a rival gang member from another neighborhood, who is recovering from bullet wounds. Akein Scott was already out on bail for gun and drug possession charges. His bail on the attempted murder charges was set at $10 million.

title: House Votes Again to Repeal Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  One by one, they queued up in the aisles of the House of Representatives, eager for their one minute to unload on President Obamas signature legislative achievement.

title: Urging Government Action on Water, Roads and Power in Texas
description: Touting Texas low taxes and light regulations, Gov. Rick Perry has relished trying to poach jobs from other states. In February, he described building a business in California as next to impossible. Last month, he warned Illinois entrepreneurs to get out while theres still time.

title: Two Congressmen Invite Texans From Both Parties to Breakfast
description: Kevin Brady and Pete Gallego have a lot in common. They are both Texans. They entered the State Legislature together in 1991. And each now serves in the United States Congress.

title: Eclipsing D.C. in Home Stretch of Legislature
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: Teetering Knicks Gain Foothold
description: Elimination hovered over the Knicks, menacingly, like the cartoon version of death, waving his pointed sickle, threatening their postseason existence. The end seemed near Thursday night, with only the details to be determined and the last rites recited.

title: Bipartisan House Group Reaches Preliminary Immigration Deal
description: A bipartisan group in the House working on an overhaul of the nations immigration laws reached a deal in principle Thursday evening, aides said. The group plans to introduce its bill in June.

title: On Overtime Rush, Bruins Slip Past Rangers
description: BOSTON  Henrik Lundqvist held off a Bruins overtime barrage for more than 15 minutes, kicking out shots left and right, hearing vulcanized rubber clanging off the goal posts behind him. Finally, at 15 minutes 40 seconds of the extra session, he was beaten by Brad Marchand.

title: Man in Much-Viewed Web Video Is Arrested in Connection With New Jersey Killing
description: A hitchhiker who became an Internet sensation early this year when he used a hatchet to hit a man who had struck a utility worker with his car was arrested on Thursday night, on charges that he killed a man in his home near Elizabeth, N.J., on Sunday, the authorities said.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Seeking a Milestone, Pettitte Instead Joins a Long List of Injured Yankees
description: At some point, the Yankees rash of injuries will reach the point of absurdity. Perhaps Thursday was the night.

title: Benfica: A Curse to Rival the Bambinos
description: It is not quite the Curse of the Bambino, but the hoodoo that the Hungarian coach Bela Guttmann put on Benfica in the early 1960s was alive and well on Wednesday when the Portuguese club lost to Chelsea in the Europa Cup final  its seventh consecutive loss in a continental championship match.

title: Word of the Day | notoriety
description: notoriety \no-t-ri--te\ noun

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 17
description: It is not that Syria is melting down  it has melted down. So much has changed between the different parties that I cant imagine it all going back into one piece.

title: Corrections: May 17, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: A Warhol Painting Is the Star of a Modest Auction
description: After the historic $495 million sale of postwar and contemporary art at Christies, there was considerable curiosity surrounding Phillipss far more modest one on Thursday evening.

title: Some Relief for Smith, From Critics and Slump
description: A warm ovation greeted J. R. Smith when he checked into Game 5 on Thursday with about five minutes left in the first quarter, but there was always a sense that the tenor could change quickly, and boos would re-emerge, if Smiths current trend continued plummeting downward.

title: Lawmakers Show Concerns About Googles New Glasses
description: Eight members of Congress on Thursday formally demanded that Google address a range of privacy concerns about its new wearable technology device, Google Glass.

title: Concussion Sidelines Pacers Hill
description: Pacers point guard George Hill flew on the team plane to New York and participated in a shootaround on Thursday morning. But 90 minutes before Game 5, the team announced he was out with a concussion  a potentially pivotal turn of events in the Eastern Conference semifinal matchup with the Knicks.

title: Steve Jobss Widow Steps Onto Philanthropic Stage
description: Marlene Castro knew the tall blonde woman only as Laurene, her mentor. They met every few weeks in a rough Silicon Valley neighborhood the year that Ms. Castro was applying to college, and they e-mailed often, bonding over conversations about Ms. Castros difficult childhood. Without Laurenes help, Ms. Castro said, she might not have become the first person in her family to graduate from college.

title: Marchand Feels Pain in the Morning and Inflicts It at Night
description: BOSTON  For a good hour Thursday, Bruins fans were seriously worried about Brad Marchands status for Game 1 of the teams Eastern Conference semifinal series against the Rangers.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) RIGOLETTO Michael Mayer, who won a Tony Award for directing Spring Awakening, made his Metropolitan Opera debut with this Verdi work, in a new production known as the Rat Pack Rigoletto, which moved events from a decadent 16th-century Italian court to the Las Vegas strip around 1960. The Polish tenor Piotr Beczala is the Duke, here a Sinatra-like playboy whose entourage includes the world-weary comedian Rigoletto, sung by the Serbian baritone Zeljko Lucic. The German soprano Diana Damrau, above with Mr. Lucic, plays the innocent Gilda, Rigolettos daughter and the victim of the predatory Duke. The Italian Michele Mariotti leads the ensemble in what Anthony Tommasini, writing in The New York Times, called an excellent outing for this rising conductor. Mr. Tommasini also noted that Mr. Mayer had modeled Rigoletto on aggressive comics like Don Rickles, who could crack up Sinatra. But the vagueness of the concept undermines Mr. Lucics otherwise affecting performance, he added, writing the production was a frustrating mix of inventive and half-baked thinking.

title: Game 5: Knicks vs. Pacers
description: Carmelo Anthony provided the offense, Tyson Chandler the muscle and Chris Copeland the 3-point shooting in the Knicks win over the Pacers.

title: Game 1: Rangers vs. Bruins
description: With the help of Brad Marchand, the Bruins edged the Rangers in overtime of Game 1 in the Eastern Conference semifinal series.

title: For Idol, a Mild Finale to a Bumpy Season
description: If this was the year that American Idol, the deeply influential but troubled singing competition, hoped to prove its worth as a minter of future music stars, it came up short. If this was the year it hoped to bring stasis to its lately evolving judges panel, it also missed the mark. And if this was the year it hoped to demonstrate continued dominance over the other vocal contest shows that have arrived in the wake of its juggernaut success, then consider that strike three.

title: News Quiz | May 17, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: A Conversation With: Cricket Board Official Niranjan R. Shah
description: Niranjan Rasiklal Shah, 68, is one of the vice presidents of the Board of Control for Cricket in India, or B.C.C.I., which is among the worlds richest sporting bodies. He has been associated with the cricketing body for well over 30 years, serving as the boards secretary for two terms.

title: IHT Quick Read: May 17
description: NEWS Russia has sent advanced antiship cruise missiles to Syria, a move that illustrates the depth of its support for the Syrian government led by President Bashar al-Assad, American officials said Thursday. Michael R. Gordon and Eric Schmitt report from Washington.

title: In Age Before Fergie Time, a Managers Finest Hour and a Half
description: As a mark of how Alex Ferguson has come to embody soccers biggest club, it is often said the Scottish manager became Manchester United. But before Ferguson was United he was something else. He was Aberdeen Football Club.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, May 17, 2013
description: The question was written by Katherine Schulten. It comes from the article The Art of Repetition.

title: Obstacles Get in the Way of Obamas Second Term Goals
description: In the news analysis article An Onset of Woes Raises Questions on Obama Vision, Peter Baker writes about the frustrations of President Obamas still early second term.

title: What Would Your Dream Home Be Like?
description: Do you ever dream about what your perfect house would be like? Would it be a grand mansion with Greek-style columns and a vast front lawn? Or a cute colorful cottage on the beach? Maybe a loft apartment in the middle of a big city?

title: After 25 Years, Confronting Alienation in Astoria
description: Photographers have long turned to New Yorks ethnic enclaves for stories of cultural tenacity in the face of sweeping change. When Niko J. Kallianiotis came to Astoria, Queens, on a 1987 family visit from Greece, he got none of that.

title: Republicans Expand I.R.S. Inquiry, With Eye on White House
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional Republicans, not resting with the Internal Revenue Service scandal, are moving to broaden the matter to an array of tax malfeasances and intimidation tactics they hope will ensnare the White House.

title: The Early Word: Rain
description: In Todays Times:President Obamas recent woes have energized and unified Congressional Republicans, but the G.O.P. is taking a measured approach in its responses to the controversies that have ensnared the president and his administration, as the party seeks to avoid the kind of backlash that followed President Clintons impeachment trial, Jonathan Weisman writes.

title: Long Journey to College, but I Was Never Alone
description: Applying to college has been a long journey, one that I could not have made alone. In the beginning, my dream of attending college in the United States with limited funds seemed to be just that: a dream. However, I am grateful to have had friends and family who were always supportive.

title: Daily Report: Workweek Still Too Long at Apple Supplier, Audit Says
description: Foxconn Technology, the company that manufactures Apples popular iPads and iPhones, has made substantial progress toward improving safety and other working conditions at three of its Chinese plants dedicated to making Apple products. But it has not yet achieved the most difficult goal: reducing the average workweek to the maximum allowed by Chinese law, a global monitoring group said on Thursday, Vindu Goel reports in The New York Times.

title: This Week in the Global Arts Guide
description: The Chinese artist Cai Guo-Qiang is well-known for creating pyrotechnic spectacles and for his epic installations.

title: Race to the Top
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  While the U.S. Supreme Court considers whether American universities should take account of race when they admit new students, Brazil is implementing what are arguably the most radical affirmative action measures for universities in the West.

title: A Grrrls Life
description: Fliers, lyrics and zines from Kathleen Hanna, the vocalist and songwriter for the band Bikini Kill.

title: The Plane Was About to Crash. Now What?
description: I woke to a nudge. The pilots going to make an announcement, the flight attendant said. I palmed at my eyes, nodded and looked around, feeling my hangover creep back in. The girl next to me was flicking at her nails while she paged through a fashion magazine. I slumped back against the window after the flight attendant passed. White clouds blanketed the sky floor.

title: Does the Postal Service Owe Me Money?
description: I recently sent a parcel via U.S. Express Mail. It was guaranteed to be delivered the next day by noon. The final delivery scan was at 12:03 p.m. I am entitled to a full refund of the postage I paid. However, the difference between noon and 12:03 is negligible  it did not affect me or the recipient. I simply needed the item delivered overnight and received the service I paid for. Im fully satisfied. Is it ethical to request a full refund under these circumstances? ROSS NIZLEK, BURLINGTON, VT.

title: Khaled Hosseini on How the Iraq War Hurt Afghanistan
description: In your new book, And the Mountains Echoed, one of the main characters is an Afghan-born physician in America, like you. He is embarrassed that hes sweating the details of his new home theater while his countrymen are suffering. Do you have similar guilt?  Of course. I always have. The only reason Im not where they are is just pure luck, its just a stupid genetic lottery. Its an unmerited gift to have this life. My books became successful way beyond any reasonable expectation and were about those people on the streets. I felt that in some way I had profited from their wretchedness.

title: Julie Delpy Dreams of Being Joe Pesci
description: Julie Delpy has many funny lines in the new film Before Midnight, but the funniest one  in which she mockingly runs through her boyfriends lackluster sexual routine, a line that starts with Kissy, kissy and ends with the sound of snoring and is otherwise far too graphic to repeat here  is delivered with such vigorous crudeness that I couldnt resist asking her to recite it for me in person. Which she did, over and over, despite the fact that we were surrounded by fellow diners at the Chateau Marmont in Los Angeles.

title: Europeans Rate Their Neighbors
description: Pew Research Center released a report this week about decaying sentiment in the European Union, based on its polls showing disintegrating support for the mission of the union. Of all the tidbits in the report, though, this table is probably the most interesting:

title: Who Made That Motorcade?
description: Here is a fine new word, wrote an Iowa sports columnist in 1911. Back then, the slang term motorcade  a riff on cavalcade  described any kind of derring-do by a team of drivers. Before there was a highway system, auto enthusiasts tore off on 1,000-mile safaris to prove the mettle of their horseless carriages. In 1912, representatives of Indiana car companies traveled the Midwest in a motorcade that drove into towns accompanied by a rain of confetti and a blast of organ music  pipes were hooked up to the fan shaft of one of the cars.

title: Rajat Guptas Lust for Zeros
description: Late one Friday morning, Rajat Gupta was rushing through security at Philadelphia International Airport, carry-on in tow, when his cellphone rang. When Gupta heard from Goldman Sachs, on whose board he sat, it was often from its chief executive, Lloyd Blankfein. But on this morning, it was Gregory K. Palm, his old Harvard Business School classmate and the banks general counsel, on the line. Palm sounded unusually serious. So Gupta asked if he could call him back from the other side of security.

title: George Sauers Love-Hate Connection With Football
description: George Sauer was on his way to a possible Hall of Fame career when, in 1971, he suddenly retired, at age 27. By that time, he was the most prominent of a group of players who had become harsh critics of the game and its role in American society. For Sauer, the decision to walk away was also personal. Sauer died on May 7 of congestive heart failure in Westerville, Ohio, after battling Alzheimers disease. He was 69. A few thoughts:

title: At Google Conference, Cameras Even in the Bathroom
description: 6:55 p.m. | Updated

title: Elliott and Hess Shake Hands
description: BITTER STANDOFF AT HESS GIVES WAY TO SETTLEMENT | It wasnt until dawn on Thursday, just hours before the annual meeting, that the Hess Corporation finally settled a proxy fight waged by the activist hedge fund Elliott Management. The oil company agreed to give Elliott three board seats in exchange for the funds support of the companys slate of five directors; all told, nine new directors are joining the board, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced reports.

title: Cooking the Books
description: A survey of officers and employees of large companies in 36 countries in Europe, the Middle East, Africa and India found that a fifth of them were aware of financial chicanery at their own company.

title: A Troubling Survey on Global Corruption
description: CORRUPTION is a growth business.

title: Why Indian Elites Like to Call Themselves Middle Class
description: If you are an Indian reading this, you are very likely among the top 10 percent in the country, since you have Internet access. It is also very likely that you, just like me, consider yourself middle class, though we are not anywhere close to the middle of this country in income or standard of living. We may well have trended the hashtag #IamSoMiddleClass last month, but being in the top decile of a 1.2 billion population, perhaps its time to ask #WhyICallMyselfMiddleClass?

title: Friday Reading: Marathon Training, Minus the Long Run
France Fights Racism by Outlawing Race
description: LONDON  In a move aimed at undermining the bogus foundation of racist ideology, Frances National Assembly has decided to drop the word race from the countrys laws.

title: European Auto Sales Rebound, but With an Asterisk
description: European auto sales broke an 18-month losing streak in April, industry data showed on Friday. But dont pop open the Champagne just yet: the increase was mostly a trick of the calendar.

title: A Skittish Bird at the Airport
description: Dear Diary:

title: Too Much Talk About Liquidity
description: Antonio Fatas is annoyed at Gillian Tett, who talks to the I-see-bubbles crowd and assumes that they have The Truth  namely, that those crazy central banks are flooding the world with liquidity, driving asset prices to crazy levels, and it will all end in terrible grief. Pretty much the same discussion weve been having about the armageddon hedgies.

title: Andrew Masons Life After Groupon
description: Andrew Mason is back.

title: The Rabbis Campaign
description: JERUSALEM  The two presiding rabbis of Israels Chief Rabbinate  one Ashkenazi, the other Sephardic  completed their 10-year term three months ago, but they were asked to stay until new chief rabbis are elected. The new rabbis cant be chosen until a so-called electing body  150 members, including mayors, rabbis and other assorted appointees  is selected by a committee of five, comprising two politicians, two rabbis and a judge appointed by the minister of religious affairs. And the new electing body cant be selected until Israeli politicians can agree on how.

title: Objects | Chris Lehrecke and Gabriella Kisss Wooden Wonders
description: The furniture designer Chris Lehrecke and the jewelry designer Gabriella Kiss have been married for more than two decades, and their upstate studios are a stones throw from one another. Given their mutual affinity for nature  he treats wood in an organic way, and her subject matter includes plants and insects  its a bit surprising that theyve never done a big project together. Until now, that is. After the Storm, a collection that makes its debut on Monday at Ralph Pucci International, is the couples first major collaboration. Although the show features solo designs by each (wooden tortoises and lily-pad tables by Kiss, and tree-mushroom-shaped wall shelves by Lehrecke, to name a few), their joint efforts include a series of pieces in white oak designed by Lehrecke with cast-bronze pulls (also mushroom-shaped) by Kiss. The long, lean chest of drawers shown here, which incorporates a branch from a dead oak tree, is $22,000 at Ralph Pucci International (44 West 18th Street).

title: That Hideous Strength
description: The FT has an interesting article on problems with Irish GNP (not GDP) accounting; essentially, measured Irish income is being inflated by foreign companies with no real activity there that nonetheless find ways to make profits materialize in a low-tax jurisdiction. We sort of knew this was happening  that, for example, a lot of the apparent rise in productivity was just a shift to pharma companies that produce a lot of reported value-added but add little to the Irish economy. But the new ESRI report suggests that the problem is bigger than realized.

title: For Extra Credit: A Little Light Reading on Press Rights
description: With press rights very much in the news this week, here are some of the most noteworthy pieces Ive come across on the subject.

title: That 90s Show
description: I picked a good week to be away  and I am still away, mostly, although playing a bit of hooky on the notebook right now. For it has been the week of OBAMA SCANDALS, nonstop.

title: Reporter Turned White House Spokesman Enjoys the Hot Seat
description: WASHINGTON  For the better part of a decade, Jay Carney sat slumped in his tiny chair in the White House briefing room, parsing, challenging and at times pillorying the words of an array of press secretaries.

title: The Quads Content Is On the Move
description: Thank you for visiting The Quad. This blogs regular features, including live game analysis, game previews and other coverage, can now be found on the college football and college basketball section fronts. This change in presentation will provide readers with single destinations for all important college football and college basketball news.

title: The Problem With the Feds Easy Money Policies
description: My most recent column incited a robust and welcome discussion. But few of my many critics, including Paul Krugman on his blog and many commenters on DealBook, seem to have engaged with my main point.

title: The On-Par Content Is On the Move
description: Thank you for visiting On Par. This blogs regular features, including live tournament analysis, news and notes from Bill Pennington, Karen Crouse and others, and other coverage, can now be found on the golf section front. This change in presentation will provide readers with a single destination for all important and timely golf news.

title: Did the A.P. Leak Put the American People at Risk?
description: Attorney General Eric Holder tried the other day to justify the governments secret spying on The Associated Press. He condemned an apparent leak to the A.P. regarding a foiled (remember that word, foiled) terrorist plot hatched in Yemen, which he said posed a dire threat to national security.

title: The Fifth Downs Content Is On the Move
description: Thank you for visiting The Fifth Down. This blogs regular features, including live game analysis, news and notes from Judy Battista, Ben Shpigel and others, fantasy football analysis and other coverage, can now be found on the pro football section front. This change in presentation will provide readers with a single destination for all important and timely N.F.L. news and analysis.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Kitchn: Another widely misunderstood Southern staple: grits. The same as polenta? Not really.  Julia Moskin

title: The On the Run Blog Content Is On the Move
description: Thank you for visiting the On the Run blog. This blogs regular features, including news and notes about the New York City Marathon and live race analysis, can be found on our main sports section front. No changes have been made in the reporting, editing and other resources devoted to our marathon coverage. Thank you for reading.

title: Is It Smart Pricing to Create the Appearance of a Discount?
description: An article in The New York Times reports that  since the departure of Ronald B. Johnson, the former chief executive  J.C. Penney has gone back to some of its old pricing strategies, including this one: Penney has already started to reverse Mr. Johnsons overhaul by restoring a pricing system in which it artificially marks some items up and then down to give the appearance of a discount.

title: Common Core Practice | Pigs, Cicadas and Wrestling
description: As you know if youve been reading these posts, Jonathan Olsen and Sarah Gross have made reading and writing with The Times a focus in their ninth-grade humanities classes since September.

title: Olympics Blog Content Is On the Move
description: Thank you for visiting the Olympics blog. This blogs regular features, including news and notes about the 2014 Sochi Games, can be found on our main sports section front. No changes have been made in the reporting, editing and other resources devoted to our Olympics coverage. Thank you for reading.

title: Women Know More About Finances Than They Get Credit For
description: ON occasion, when my female friends and I are sitting around talking, the issue of money will come up. And generally, most will readily admit that they dont know anywhere near as much about their family finances as they should.

title: Ask Well: Coated vs. Uncoated Aspirin
description: Question:

title: Hofstra Student Fatally Shot in Home Invasion Near Campus
description: A 21-year-old college student was shot and killed early Friday on Long Island after an armed man broke into the home she shared with her twin sister, held her hostage and then engaged in a gun battle with the police, the authorities said. The man who forced his way into the home was also killed.

title: A Big Man Still Dreams of the Big Time
description: Honolulu  The Blind Side meets The Great Caruso.

title: Jorge Rafael Videla, Jailed Argentine Military Leader, Dies at 87
description: Jorge Rafael Videla, the military junta leader who oversaw a ruthless campaign of political killings and forced disappearances during Argentinas so-called Dirty War against dissidents in the mid-1970s, died on Friday in the Marcos Paz Prison in Buenos Aires, where he was serving a life sentence for crimes against humanity. He was 87.

title: First Rentals: Native New York Style
description: For young New Yorkers seeking their first postcollege apartment in the city, the setting of ones childhood can cast a long shadow. The home where they grew up, whether it was a Classic 6 or far more modest, can leave a strong imprint.

title: For Acclaimed Wagnerian, Less Excess
description: SALZBURG, AUSTRIA  On a cool afternoon in March, a crowd filled the Festspielhaus here to see the German conductor Christian Thielemann lead the Dresden Staatskapelle in Wagners Parsifal. It was the dress rehearsal, three days before the productions premiere as the opening-night attraction of the Salzburg Easter Festival and an early celebration of Wagners 200th birthday, which falls on Wednesday.

title: Injuries Mount, but Girardi Still Believes
description: Joe Girardi was not supposed to have the kind of career he did. Not as a player with limited speed and power, from Peoria, Ill., who was undrafted until his senior year at Northwestern. Coaches had to believe in him along the way.

title: A Trophy by a Tower
description: Seeking to tap into the trophy apartment craze that has gripped New York Citys luxury market, Joseph Moinian, the developer of the W New York Downtown Hotel and Residences, is bringing a $40 million duplex penthouse to the market.

title: Where the I.R.S. Investigation May Go From Here
description: If Washington scandals have taught us anything, it is that the most trouble comes from the cover-up, not the conduct.

title: A Fresh Approach to Soft-Shell Crabs
description: I once worked for an old-school chef who claimed that everything sold better with the name amandine (or almondine as it was called, incorrectly, on the menu).

title: Balanchines Palm-Fringed Muse
description: LOS ANGELES  Unlike certain 20th-century artists who found themselves miserable in Hollywood  F. Scott Fitzgerald comes to mind  George Balanchine was fond of the place in the 1930s. He loved the orange groves, Romanoffs glamorous bote and choreographing dances for movies.

title: This Weeks Movies: Star Trek Into Darkness, Frances Ha and Augustine
description: This weeks video includes reviews of Frances Ha, Augustine and Star Trek: Into Darkness. Read all of this weeks reviews here.

title: New in the Review
description: New in the Review

title: In a Life of Moves and Commutes, the Wifes the Steadying Anchor
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: Are You My Father?
description: At a party in 1960s Manhattan, a beautiful blonde named Constance meets a professor of poetry many years her senior. After a brief and not especially rigorous courtship, she agrees to become his wife. And, perhaps unsurprisingly, this psychologically fragile young woman  whose emotional and sexual frigidity is strongly signposted right from the start  seems trapped and unhappy, resisting her husbands apparently good-hearted attempts to make her feel loved and secure. Meanwhile, across town, her sister, Iris  equally beautiful and blond, but with a disheveled, bohemian promiscuity and a deliciously described aptitude for being not withholding with the cleavage  is engaged in an affair with a man who plays the piano in the bar of a shabby hotel. When Constance is introduced to this married lush from Miami, his very presence so unsettles and (she imagines) repulses her, that she persuades him to break off his affair with Iris. Who promptly falls apart.

title: Pop and Jazz Music
description: CALIFORNIA

title: Family Feuds
description: Was Matt mean to Ann? How is Robins health? Is Charlie, that nocturnal man about town, really suited to rise-and-shine rigmarole? That most readers need no help in supplying context  the players here are Matt Lauer and Ann Curry on NBCs Today show, Robin Roberts on ABCs Good Morning America and Charlie Rose on whatever that daytime CBS program is called these days  is a testament to how personally so many millions of viewers take their morning TV. Specifically, its a toothbrush-holding thumbs-up to their watch-it-then-and-there network morning TV, an impressive distinction (not to mention a relic) in a DVR-time-shifted world of countless cable and Internet options.

title: Mother of Children Slain in Nanny Case Is Pregnant
description: Just over six and a half months after two of their children were found fatally stabbed in their Upper West Side apartment, Kevin and Marina Krim announced to the world this week that Ms. Krim is pregnant.

title: Aberrations and Apparitions
description: Heres a paragraph you might find a little strange: Micah had ridden three times, got thrown once. He found horses hard to read. Their thoughts might go back to the beginning of horse time, or they might be afraid of a candy wrapper on the ground. He was wary of anything that big that bit.

title: Love Me. Leave Me Alone.
description: Loneliness can be divided into two types: transient and chronic. The first is more common than the second, meaning most people feel lonely sometimes and some people feel lonely most of the time. Transients arent interesting. Like hunger or fatigue, their loneliness comes and goes and isnt defining: talk to them for an hour and they forget it. Chronics, though, are another story. They feel lonely playing games and being with family and moving through crowds and having sex. They can rack up thousands of Facebook friends and build a nation of Twitter followers, and it doesnt matter. They know they are inescapably alone.

title: When Words Sing
description: If you spend a lot of time with audiobooks, you start paying close attention to the people who read them, and probably develop a stable of favorites. Listeners know that the best narrators can make a good book take wing and a merely decent book grow more engaging. They can carry us through the dry parts of nonfiction, and might get us to try something we otherwise might not have. (Thats how I ended up enjoying Elmore Leonards Stick  I wanted to hear the great Frank Muller.) A mediocre reading? Well, I stop listening, and if its a book I really need to read, I switch to paper.

title: Funny Talk
description: Interstate 95 between New York and Washington, D.C., is no ones idea of a pleasant piece of real estate, and that went double for a recent Sunday afternoon. Fuming at the stop-and-go jam, I jabbed at the radio, looking for something, anything, to divert me from the conga line to nowhere.

title: An Audible Feast
description: In a foreshortened life that didnt make 62, Ernest Hemingway got a lot down on paper. If, by his middle and later years, enough of it seemed self-parodying and sometimes even mawkish, great swaths of it remain immortal  and not just the early work, as some critics would claim. Hemingway changed the look and sound of American speech on the printed page. But how did he get so much work done, the stories, the novels, the nonfiction (not to mention the thousands of letters he wrote), amid all that wasteful boozing and boasting, the depressions, the freakish accidents, the bouts of soaring blood pressure, the stark-awake and Seconal-stoked nights?

title: Present at the Creations
description: To understand the career trajectory of John Hay (1838-1905), one should imagine Colin Powell, George W. Bushs first secretary of state, as having somehow served John F. Kennedy, 40 years earlier, as a personal assistant. Between Hays time as Abraham Lincolns secretary and Theodore Roosevelts top diplomat, the United States changed even more than it did between Kennedy and Bush. Hay saw the country disintegrate during his first months with Lincoln, but in his last years with Roosevelt he was helping to construct a democratic-imperial colossus, getting America ready for the American century.

title: In the West, Old and Bland May Win the Race
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Say it again: they are too bland. Say it again: they are too old. Say it again: they are once again the favorites in the West.

title: Humane Society
description: What an easy, delightful way to spend a weekend, curled up on the sofa, a vase of daffodils unfurling in a warm room as rain streams down the window and, close at hand, two new books by Elinor Lipman. More addictive than that bag of peanut M&Ms: a collection called I Cant Complain: (All Too) Personal Essays. More delicious than my cup of steaming cocoa: a new novel, The View From Penthouse B, a tender, funny story of two middle-aged sisters. Food was constantly on my mind as I read, because Lipmans books are marvelous pantries. The pages of her 10th novel are replete with bouillabaisse and roast chicken, ripe with exotic fruits and rich with marzipan and macaroons.

title: A Solo Trip Takes a Mother Home
description: For years, I was lost in that delicate dance of working and raising young children. Breakfast at 7. Clothes picked out. Backpacks filled. Off to school. Drive to sports  or music lessons  or friends houses. Dinner. Homework. Bed. And in between babies naps and play dates and taxiing, I fit in my real job  online teaching and academic advising. Phew.

title: Man of His Words
description: For an author who spent seven years writing The Recognitions (1955), a big, elbow-straining novel that most people didnt read, and the next 20 years writing J R (1975), an almost-as-big novel that most people also didnt read, it will come as no surprise that William Gaddiss selected letters are consumed with worries about how little money his books are making, how few people understand them and how he plans to pay his bills until the next book comes along. As he writes his literary agent, Candida Donadio, in the mid-1970s, just when J R was failing to secure a much-needed paperback rights advance:

title: The Office Ends the Way It Began: Modestly
description: Theres a temptation for a long-running television comedy to go out with a high-concept twist  the Seinfeld trial, the Newhart bad dream, the Frasier plane ride. The Office was having none of that on Thursday night, when it closed its nine-season run on NBC with an episode that was in keeping with the shows modest, utilitarian style.

title: The Gun Report: May 17, 2013
description: Yesterday, Marylands governor, Martin OMalley, signed a bill that made the states gun laws among the strictest in the nation. Under the new legislation, anyone buying a handgun will have to submit fingerprints to obtain a license. The bill also bans 45 types of assault weapons; gun magazines will be limited to 10 bullets; gun ownership by people who have been involuntarily committed to a mental health facility will be banned; and police will be able to suspend the licenses of gun dealers who fail to comply with record-keeping obligations.

title: Big Data Is Watching You
description: How can you resist a book whose first chapter begins: Have you ever peeked inside a friends trash can? I have. Trash is like ones sex life, the book continues, the less said about it, the better.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: JACOBS FOLLY  By Rebecca Miller  Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE PRICE OF INEQUALITY,  by Joseph E. Stiglitz. (Norton, $16.95.) The top 1 percent of Americans control some 40 percent of the nations wealth. This disparity, Stiglitz argues, isnt the result of uncontrollable technological and social change; it stems from the unrestrained power of well-heeled interests. In this comprehensive counterargument to both neoliberalism and laissez-faire theories, the author, a Nobel laureate and economics professor at Columbia, examines the effects of inequality on the economy, democracy and globalization.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE SLEEPWALKERS: How Europe Went to War in 1914,  by Christopher Clark. (Harper, $29.99.) A Cambridge professor offers a thoroughly comprehensible account of the polarization of a continent, without fixing guilt on one leader or nation.

title: Inside the List
description: DUCK SEASON: Phil Robertson, the backwoods Louisiana patriarch and hunting entrepreneur who stars on the A&E reality show Duck Dynasty, rules the hardcover nonfiction list this week  his memoir, Happy, Happy, Happy (written with Mark Schlabach), is new at No. 1. Its not the first best seller the show has spawned, either: The Duck Commander Family, by Phils son Willie and daughter-in-law Korie (with Schlabach again), is at No. 7 in its sixth week, riding the coattails of a season finale that drew 9.6 million viewers last month. Happy, Happy, Happy takes its title from Robertsons catchphrase, and presents itself as a rustic guide to the good life  one chapter, Redneck Caviar, declares that Rule No. 11 for living happy, happy, happy is to suck the head of a crawfish (youll want to do it again and again). Part of the Robertsons charm is that they seem genuinely well adjusted, like the Waltons hairier cousins; every episode ends with a family prayer and a dinner prepared by Phils wife, Kay, whom he married when he was 16 and she was 15. If you can find a nice, pretty country girl who can cook and carries her Bible, he advises readers, now, theres a woman. She might even be ugly, but if she cooks squirrels and dumplings, then thats the woman you go after.

title: Paid to Be Good
description: Linnea is a good kid from a home that lies somewhere in that wide gray zone between stable and chaotic, more dysfunctional than not  in other words, an emblematic American household. Her stepdad is O.K., her younger half-brother is pretty cool, her stepsister is a mean girl and a bully; but Linnea loves her mom, and since she cant remember her feckless, long-lost father, she doesnt really miss him. Theirs is a typical blended family, so sadly representative that the nightmare that demolishes their relative peace and turns Linnea into an unreachable, volatile teenager is a school shooting  a signature American tragedy. Suffice it to say that the details of that awful day are blood-chilling and unbearable. As survivors go, Linnea is especially unlucky. Shes earned her trauma, and she wears it like a badge.

title: Bigger Than Soccer Itself
description: For a while, Thursday seemed like a perfect day for goodbyes. And in a way, the timing was perfect. It is, after all, graduation season. David Beckham kicked things off by announcing he would graduate to being just a global icon, minus the soccer-playing part. The Knicks seemed poised to move on to the golf-playing portion of their season with an elimination game against the Indiana Pacers, but decided to stick around, perhaps just to annoy people, including their doomsaying fans. But we did say goodbye to Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvists perfection and any chance the N.B.A.'s Western Conference playoffs would be moderately fun to watch.

title: Beautiful Creatures
description: The golden age of childrens literature  beginning in the 1860s with Charles Kingsleys Water-Babies and Lewis Carrolls Alices Adventures in Wonderland and ending with the publication of the Winnie-the-Pooh books in the 1920s  earned its name by turning stories into luminous contact zones for adults and children. A million golden arrows point to Neverland, and you can reach Oz by passing through a gate studded with glittering emeralds. The heft of Or else! in cautionary tales about children going up in flames after playing with matches was replaced with the incandescent beauty of What if? Writers aspired to lure children into fantasy worlds that would leave them, as Frances Hodgson Burnett put it, breathing quite fast with excitement, and wonder, and delight.

title: Dance
description: CALIFORNIA

title: Classical and Opera
description: ARIZONA

title: Heading North, With an Appetite
description: Rachel Cartwright teaches biology at California State University Channel Islands and has been studying trends in habitat use in humpback whale mother-calf pairs in Hawaiian waters. This is her final post.

title: Anthologies That (Mostly) Stand the Test of Time
description: Fiction anthologies dont always stand the test of time. There is, surrounding prize anthologies especially, an inevitable whiff of Ozymandias  these were the best writers of their day, the editors proclaimed, yet who today has heard of most of them? But I love old anthologies partly for the light they cast on the flip side of the Ozymandias legend: sure, the king will crumble into dust just like the rest of us, but he still managed to create great works while he lived. And even if were not familiar with all of the writers in these volumes, they still wrote some pretty good stories in their time. Look on their works, ye Mighty, and celebrate.

title: Jorge Rafael Videla, Argentine Military Leader, Dies
description: Jorge Rafael Videla oversaw a ruthless campaign of political killings and forced disappearances during Argentinas so-called Dirty War against dissidents in the mid-1970s.

title: Smoke Permeates Nonsmoking Hotel Rooms
description: Staying in a nonsmoking room in a hotel that allows smoking elsewhere does not prevent exposure to tobacco smoke, a new study reports.

title: A Toehold for China on Wall Street
description: Shaolin-style martial arts. A plate-spinning acrobat. Musicians playing the dizi, a Chinese bamboo flute, and the yangqin, a hammered dulcimer.

title: The 5.5.13 Issue
Inside the New York Times Book Review: The Golem and the Jinni
description: This week, Helene Wecker discusses her novel The Golem and the Jinni; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; David Carr talks about David Sedariss Lets Explore Diabetes With Owls; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: The Monarch as a Work in Progress
description: A solo exhibition devoted to the art of Chris Levine opened at the Fine Art Society Contemporary in London today. Levine,who created pictures of the Olympic Stadium and the Shard skyscraper for our London Issue last year, is perhaps best known for his holographic portrait of Queen Elizabeth II (above, but you have to see it in person to fully appreciate its 3-D-ness). The work was produced as part of an assignment a decade ago by the Jersey Heritage to commemorate the Isle of Jerseys 800 years of allegiance to the British crown. A similar picture that was ultimately chosen to be the organizations commission was printed on a 100-pound note for the queens diamond jubilee last year.

title: Making a Hard Choice for a Soft Landing
description: In the romantic comedy Silver Linings Playbook, Pat emerges from a mental institution and finds new love with a dark-haired loose cannon named Tiffany. Pat is bipolar, a condition that reveals itself mainly in manic episodes of aggressive optimism. He runs for miles a day in a trash bag vest to make himself sweat more, fixates on his ex-wife and keeps score of his lifes silver linings.

title: Home on the High Line
description: In the whitewashed art galleries of West Chelsea, parents pushing baby carriages are now as commonly seen as quirky art students, while the recently opened Avenues: the World School has brought streams of well-heeled school children flowing through 10th Avenue.

title: Griner Effect May Change the Game at Baylor
description: From the day in 1983 when he graduated cum laude from Baylor University, Tim Smith fit the profile of a star alumnus. He went on to earn an M.B.A. at Harvard and to lead an information technology company with 300 employees. The business school at Baylor invited Mr. Smith to speak to classes about entrepreneurial finance, and he was named twice to its advisory board.

title: State Legislator Facing Expulsion Says Hell Resign
description: State Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, the once-powerful Brooklyn Democratic leader who has been accused of sexual harassment by several women, said on Friday that he would resign. But his offer only inflamed an uproar over his behavior because, a few words later, he said the resignation would not take effect for five weeks, and then he would run for a seat on the New York City Council.

title: The Other Climate Science Gap
description: Much has been made this week of the gap between what the public thinks about the consensus among climate scientists over the human factor in global warming and the actual level of consensus. The discussion has centered on a new study reviewing how anthropogenic global warming was characterized in more than 12,000 climate science papers between 1991 and 2011. More than 97 percent of the papers stating a cause for warming, the authors found, pointed to humans. In contrast, surveys consistently show that Americans are pretty evenly divided when asked whether they think scientists agree that humans are causing global warming.(Readmy e-mail exchange with two authorsfor more background.)

title: I.R.S. Chief Apologizes Amid Scandal
description: Steven T. Miller, the acting I.R.S. commissioner who has resigned, called the agencys actions obnoxious, but told the House Ways and Means Committee they were not motivated by partisanship.

title: Perilous Fantasies Stoked by a Naf
description: The Master Builder, Ibsens mysterious 1893 drama of ambition and erotic obsession, is staged far more rarely than the familiar (and generally less mystic) dramas of his major realist period. The Brooklyn Academy of Music is remedying the lack this spring with a major new production starring John Turturro as the title character, Halvard Solness, the dream-drunk architect who seems to bring about good luck and ill fortune in equal measures.

title: Objects | Lets Stay Together
description: To the relief of men everywhere who struggle with pairing their shirts to their pants, this season designers proposed the idea of matching sets. Whether in the form of head-to-toe prints, like Calvin Kleins digitized floral jacket, shirt and shorts, or the monochromatic uniforms put forth by Dior or Prada, these are tops and bottoms that make the biggest statement when worn together. One less decision to make in the mornings!

title: Heeding Master, Heart in Mouth
description: Its kind of like, you know, going to the lions den, Dallas Akins says before performing Trinculos monologue from Shakespeares Tempest for the actress Kathleen Turner. She seems like someone you wouldnt want to mess with.

title: Hip-Hop Freshmen Rule the Roost
description: Every year since 2008, the hip-hop magazine XXL has anointed a group of up-and-coming rappers as part of its Freshman Class, giving over a months cover to a gaggle of relatively little-known faces. But as the Internet has become more vital in building hip-hop careers, these lists arent gambles so much as aggregates of established online wisdom.

title: An Anarchic Genius, Remapping a Genre
description: Its a good time to be the former Melvin Kaminsky of Williamsburg, Brooklyn  known to the world as Mel Brooks. Now 86, this Oscar-, Tony- and Emmy-winning writer, director, performer, producer and indefatigable comic force of nature will receive the American Film Institutes Lifetime Achievement Award on June 6 in Los Angeles. Mel Brooks: Make a Noise, an American Masters portrait, will be shown on Monday on PBS (check local listings), and History of Mel Brooks Part I, a film retrospective, runs through July 21 at the IFC Center. (The program also includes David Lynchs Elephant Man (1980), made under the Brooksfilms banner.)

title: Stroke by Stroke, He Nailed Arcadia
description: One of the more sibilant names in American art belongs to the 19th-century landscape artist William Trost Richards (1833-1905), the best-known of the all-but-forgotten Pre-Raphaelite offshoot that sprang up briefly in the United States during the 1860s. The group avoided the flamboyant narratives of their English counterparts and the Romanticism of the Hudson River School. Instead, they focused on meticulously realistic renderings of nature.

title: Telling the Truth on Fees, Warts and All
description: Heres a sales pitch you dont often hear: Let us invest your money. You can count on a return of 3 percent, though there is a chance it will be less. But we can guarantee this return for 10 years.

title: Family Boredom, Upended by a Tutor
description: Wedged between Onegin on Monday and Don Quixote on Friday is a gem, as American Ballet Theater continues its season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Opening on Tuesday is the company premiere of Frederick Ashtons A Month in the Country. Choreographed in 1976, this ballet is a retelling of Turgenevs play about a young tutors impact on a Russian household. Ashton set his work, in which the narrative unfolds as a series of exquisitely detailed moments, to Chopin as arranged by John Lanchbery.

title: Visions of College, Colored by Money
description: Themes of money, working, class, affluence and the economy increasingly figure in college application essays.

title: College Essay Nods to Immigrant Parents
description: Regis High School student Lyle Li reads from his college application essay about the hard work of his immigrant parents to secure a better education and a better life for him.

title: Book Review Podcast: Unusual Immigrants in New York
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Susann Cokal reviews Helene Weckers new novel, The Golem and the Jinni, which follows two folkloric creatures who emerge onto the streets of 1899 New York. Ms. Cokal writes:

title: 10 Questions for the Tax Men of Congress
description: The chairmen of the House and Senate tax-writing committees, Representative Dave Camp, Republican of Michigan, and Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, suddenly find themselves at the center of action in Washington. They have joined forces to push for an overhaul of the nations tax code, which could pave the way to a budget deal between President Obama and Congress. And they have jumped to investigate the controversy surrounding the I.R.S.s targeting of conservative groups that has dominated front pages for the last week.

title: Hunting for Syrian Hackers Chain of Command
description: Its the question of the moment inside the murky realm of cybersecurity: Just who  or what  is the Syrian Electronic Army?

title: Long Island City Is Where?
description: As soon as Marni and Chaz King found out they were to become parents, she wanted to move to a bigger place. But he thought they could squeeze more time from their rental, a large one-bedroom in a postwar Murray Hill building.

title: On Night of Big Finales, Office Rises and Idol  Falls
description: On a busy night of finales for television favorites, The Office regained a little of its former glory, Scandal demonstrated it may have more glory to come and American Idol looked like a pale shadow of past glory.

title: Standing Out From the Crowd
description: I wonder if Princeton should be poorer.

title: Ghosts of Game 6 Favor the Knicks, but Theyre Old, Too
description: Reggie Miller rose from his broadcasters seat late Thursday night, resplendent in a dark gray suit, and smiled at the familiar sight of a reporter whose deadline playoff stories he had helped rewrite almost two decades ago.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Humans and Mutants Working Together
description: New to the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week, at No. 2, is Uncanny Avengers, written by Rick Remender and illustrated by John Cassaday. The series is about a team of heroes composed of the recently feuding X-Men and Avengers, who are attempting to show the world that humans and mutants can peacefully coexist. For many years, the X-Men were the jewel in Marvels publishing crown, but the Avengers, under Brian Michael Bendis, soon became the top dog. Lately, both teams have been serviced by creators at the top of their game. (Mr. Bendis is writing an X-Men book and Mr. Remender, who had been writing an X-Men book, is now chronicling the adventures of this hybrid team.)

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Brattleboro, Vt.; Mass.; Logan, Ohio
description: Strolling of the Heifers, Brattleboro, Vt. This weekend parade and festival honors the regions economic engine, its cows. On June 8, farmers will lead their prized heifer calves through the towns center, with horses, mules and other animals following. The Slow Living Summit, which ends June 7, will feature food vendors and exhibits related to sustainable farming and eating. On June 9, cycling tours of 15 to 60 miles will visit some of the areas farms and woodlands.

title: The Truth About Investment Costs
description: Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column about the real cost of fees, taxes and inflation on investments. While most financial advisers already disclose their management fees, there are fees in the investments themselves. And, of course, taxes and inflation take their toll.

title: The Mississippi Marine Brigade
description: In Americas modern wars, Special Forces have played a key role in hunting down and destroying enemy guerrillas. During the Civil War, the Union employed a similar outfit: the Mississippi Marine Brigade. But officials quickly came to the conclusion that, unlike todays units, the brigade was more trouble than it was worth.

title: Album From American Idol Winner Is on the Way
description: Interscope Records and the production company behind American Idol are wasting no time in bringing an album by this seasons winner, Candice Glover, to market. Billboard reported that the 23-year-old soul singers debut album, titled Music Speaks, will be out as soon as July 16.

title: Village Voice Loses 2 of Its Most Prominent Writers
description: The Village Voice continued to shed crucial parts of its staff as it was announced on Friday that Michael Musto, the papers gossip columnist, and Robert Sietsema, its restaurant reviewer, have left the weekly paper.

title: The Sweet Spot: Villains in Black Hats
description: In this weeks episode, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about villains in the movies. Scary, huh?

title: Emeli Sand Wins at Ivor Novello Awards
description: The Scottish singer and songwriter Emeli Sand won two prizes at this years Ivor Novello awards in London, taking home the trophies for best song musically and lyrically and for most performed work.

title: In the Shadow of a Fortress, a Moveable Feast
description: Its not difficult to work up an appetite in Kotor, a historic city on the Adriatic coast of Montenegro. You just climb the 1,350 stone steps to the medieval fortress of St. Ivan looming above the old city. Once there, youll find views of the sparkling blue Bay of Kotor, among the best in the Balkans. On the way down, youll probably crave a hearty snack.

title: The Sweet Spot: Take a Walk on the Dark Side
description: In this weeks episode, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about villains in the movies. Scary, huh?

title: That Bracing Antidote, Self-Mockery
description: In her new film Hes Way More Famous Than You, directed by Michael Urie, Halley Feiffer plays a bumbling narcissist named Halley Feiffer who, dumped by her boyfriend, fired by her agent and drowning in alcoholism, finds herself riding a high-speed, downhill skid. Maybe its because she offered sexual favors to Ben Stiller, with whom she appeared in The House of Blue Leaves on Broadway. Or drunk-dialed Jesse Eisenberg, her boyfriend in The Squid and the Whale, one too many times. Or made it obvious to her doppelgnger, Mamie Gummer, that she hated her for being Meryl Streeps daughter.

title: Sunday Dialogue: An Economy in Transition
description: Readers discuss how to adapt to a changing job market.

title: Saudi Web Sites Under Attack After Surveillance Accusations
description: The Saudi Interior Ministry said Friday that several government Web sites have come under attack in a campaign hackers are calling #OpSaudi.

title: New Selection Process for Kennedy Center Honors
description: After fielding criticism for an ad hoc and secretive selection process, the Kennedy Center Honors for lifetime achievement in the performing arts announced a revision of its selection process on Thursday, The Washington Post reported.

title: Jets Goodson Faces Drug and Gun Charges
description: Jets running back Mike Goodson was arrested early Friday morning and charged with possession of marijuana and of a loaded firearm, the New Jersey State Police said.

title: After the Denial Letter Arrives
description: If youve been rejected for the Department of Veterans Affairs Aid and Attendance (A&A) benefit, there are steps you can take to get your application reconsidered. But first, a warning: Do not do what the V.A. denial letter suggests you do, as that may only bring you years more of delays. And second, youll need to invoke the spirit of Winston Churchill in his 1941 speech to the Harrow School: Never give in  never, never, never, never, in nothing great or small, large or petty, never give in.

title: Wheelies: The Supersonic Bloodhound Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Popcast: Punk as Fashion, Music and Theory
description: Discussing punks origins and its legacy, and answering the question: why did punks hate hippies?

title: In Zuccotti Park, a Demonstration of Love
description: When the movement that became known as Occupy Wall Street took over Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan in September 2011, the next two months unfolded in a staccato of rallies, passionate appeals for more-direct democracy, marches that sometimes led to noisy confrontations with the police  and arrests.

title: Image of the Day: May 17
The Forever War
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee held a hearing on Thursday about the 2001 Authorization for the Use of Military Force, the legislation that gave President George W. Bush the authority to wage war against those who planned, authorized, committed or aided the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: The Swashbuckler and the Teenager
description: Once upon a time, when old movies traveled the crackling airwaves and before everything in black-and-white had been banished to TCM, Errol Flynn was one of the kings of late-night TV. Countless hours of school-night sleep were sacrificed to Captain Blood, The Sea Hawk, The Adventures of Robin Hood and Flynns cry of Welcome to Sherwood!

title: Popcast: Punk as Fashion, Music and Theory
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Arts current show Punk: Chaos to Couture tells a fractured story of mid-70s origins  Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLarens Seditionaries shop in London, Richard Hell taking scissors to his hair and T-shirts in New York  and influences, leading to designers like Martin Margiela, Junya Watanabe and Gareth Pugh. But it doesnt tell much about the concurrent development of punks music, nor about its basic impulses and ideals, whether utopian, social-realist or primal.

title: Rajat Guptas Lust for Zeros
description: As Rajat Guptas appeal is scheduled to be heard next week, Anita Raghavan, a DealBook contributor, has examined the circumstances that led to his partnership with Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire head of the Galleon Group hedge fund.

title: Frances Same-Sex Marriage Legislation Ruled Constitutional
description: PARIS  Frances constitutional high court on Friday rejected legal challenges to legislation that grants same-sex couples the right to marry and adopt children, clearing the legal text for passage into law by President Franois Hollande, who said he would do so on Saturday. The leftist majorities in both houses of Parliament passed the legislation last month amid mass demonstrations by opponents of same-sex marriage and an acrimonious political debate. Legislators from the right challenged the constitutionality of the law before the high court, the Constitutional Council, but it was widely expected that the legislation would be approved. In its ruling, the Constitutional Council found that the law would not create a right to a child for same-sex couples, a contention made by some opponents of the legislation. Those opponents say they fear the new law will open the way to medically assisted procreation for lesbian couples and the use of surrogate mothers, neither of which are legal practices in France.

title: A Sensation That Youve Had Before
description: Its all right if youre not up to date on Versus, the Versace label first popular in the early 1990s, then revived a couple of years ago. The British designer J.W. Anderson, hired to create a capsule collection, has done such a good job distilling the flavor of Versus, you wont feel youve missed a thing.

title: Dusting Off Items in Foxs Attic
description: Its been almost a year since 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment introduced the Fox Cinema Archives series, a line of manufactured-on-demand DVDs modeled on Warner Home Entertainments admirable Warner Archive Collection.

title: The Flop Looms as Studios Lean on Blockbusters
description: For the big Hollywood film studios, this summer could turn out to be Apocalypse the Day after Tomorrow: Clash of the Blockbusters. Or maybe Armageddon 2  Revenge of the Critics.

title: How Scandal Hit Its Season Highs
description: Another broadcast television season has reached its end, and while the overall ratings paint a somewhat dire picture for the networks, some success stories, like ABCs Scandal, exist.

title: Making Tamarind Spiced Nuts
description: Melissa Clark shows how to make a sweet and salty snack, perfect for pairing with a cocktail.

title: 3 Foreign Companies Invest in U.S. Project to Export Liquid Gas
description: In a sign that the United States shale gas boom is making global waves, two Japanese conglomerates and a big French energy player signed agreements on Friday to invest up to $7 billion in a liquefied natural gas project in Louisiana.

title: Cocktail Snacks With Verve
description: For many years, one of my favorite places to meet someone for a cocktail was the King Cole Bar at the St. Regis Hotel. I loved the moodiness of the dark-paneled room, the whimsy of the Maxfield Parrish mural behind the bar.

title: Hardly Into the Sunset
description: The news that David Beckham is retiring from soccer somehow seems a prelude rather than an exit, the day we all knew would come for the British superstar  oops, sorry, global icon. Just saying those words sends a shiver of up the spine. Giorgio Armani was so on it when he got Becks to pose in his underwear. Seeing a billboard in Milan of his oil-rubbed body in his white GAs could really take the edge off a lousy day of shows. Beckham in his briefs, like Marky Mark in his briefs, and a host of other hot dudes, was always going to be the treat that people wanted to see. The rest of fashion was just window dressing for the strip tease.

title: Starter: With Costata, Chef Goes Back to the Future
description: Starter, an occasional column, takes a look at newly opened restaurants.

title: Faced With Overload, a Need to Find Focus
description: We are thrilled to introduce a new weekend column to DealBook called Life@Work by Tony Schwartz. Tony is one of the worlds top thought leaders on the workplace and getting the most out of people. He is a productivity maven and advises many of the Fortune 500 on how to build the right culture as the founder of the Energy Project. Earlier his year, he wrote a popular article for The New York Timess Week in Review, Relax! Youll Be More Productive. Weve followed Tony for many years  using some of his tips and tricks ourselves  and were excited to be able share his insights regularly on DealBook.

title: Driving the Juke Joint Trail
description: I expected my juke joint pilgrimage to feel like a peripatetic wake. Decades ago, blues luminaries like Charley Patton, Robert Johnson and Sonny Boy Williamson traveled across the South, guitar or harmonica in hand, from joint to joint for just enough money and food to get to the next one. In doing so they laid the foundation for nearly every form of popular American music that would follow.

title: Still Got the Blues
description: In Mississippi, hanging onto the spirit of juke joints.

title: Going Backcountry, Three Ways
description: A man dangling 65 feet up in a poplar tree is a man with a new perspective. Not just because of the view, although it was impressive, since this particular poplar was atop one of the Blue Ridge Mountains in Virginia. The dangling man suddenly could see a lot of things differently.

title: A Populated Park and Conservation in the Anthropocene
description: Earlier this week, I spoke at the 20th meeting of the Adirondack Research Consortium.* This coalition of scientists and institutions has focused on providing data and analysis that can help sustain the ecological and economic integrity of New Yorks 6-million-acre, 120-year-old Adirondack Park.

title: Hotels Warm Up With Local Accents
description: While sleek minimalism set the tone for urban boutique hotels in the 1990s, rustic elements are warming up the newest crop of small hotels. These trendsetters emphasize their sense of place through local themes, building materials, restaurant fare, entertainment or a combination of them all.

title: A Sense of Place, on the Plate
description: Locavorism, that culinary buzzword, seems to be everywhere these days. But a restaurants dedication to regional cuisine can mean more than having a relationship with local farms and purveyors. Here are a few spots around the country that celebrate their stamping grounds in ways that go beyond ingredients.

title: In Louisville, a School for Spirits
description: Its been a long time since scofflaw drinkers were forced to resort to bathtub gin. But after whipping up a batch of diluted grain alcohol flavored with juniper berry concentrate for about 40 curious students at a Moonshine University class in Louisville this winter, Colin Blake celebrated the end of Prohibition. Happy Repeal Day, everybody! he said.
