In the morning, there are at least eight places where you can buy coffee on 40th Street in Manhattan between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, including the cart where the lady says Hi, beautiful! and puts your $1 cup in a brown paper bag with a little white napkin.

title: Next Up for the Spurs: A Look in a Mirror
description: In a league dominated by superstars, the San Antonio Spurs built the most mundane of dynasties. There was never any question that Tim Duncan belonged on the short list of the greatest power forwards in N.B.A. history, or that Tony Parker and Manu Ginobili were fantastic players, but the team was seemingly easy to forget in a world of Kobe Bryants and LeBron Jameses.

title: Pacers Hill Is Working His Way Back From Concussion
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Pacers point guard George Hill participated in the teams shoot-around Saturday as part of the exertion testing he must pass to be cleared to resume play after sustaining a concussion in Game 4 of Indianas playoff series against the Knicks.

title: Cashman and Injury-Riddled Yanks Keep Dealing
description: Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman continues to tweak his roster at the margins, making yet another move aimed at upgrading the talent on a team riddled with injuries. Late Friday, he acquired infielder Reid Brignac from the Colorado Rockies for cash and designated Alberto Gonzalez for assignment to make room on the roster.

title: Confusion and Staff Troubles Rife at I.R.S. Office in Ohio
description: During the summer of 2010, the dozen or so accountants and tax agents of Group 7822 of the Internal Revenue Service office in Cincinnati got a directive from their manager. A growing number of organizations identifying themselves as part of the Tea Party had begun applying for tax exemptions, the manager said, advising the workers to be on the lookout for them and other groups planning to get involved in elections.

title: Grizzlies Make Up for Lack of Flash With Grit
description: When Tony Allen was interviewed on live television after an otherwise meaningless midseason game in 2011, nobody could have known that he would wind up altering the culture of the Memphis Grizzlies, or that the words he delivered would soon adorn billboards and T-shirts, posters and towels.

title: Orb Fails to Deliver for Baltimore-Born Owner
description: BALTIMORE  When Orb rallied in the slop May 4 for a Kentucky Derby victory, the first for the trainer Shug McGaughey and the Phipps family, it evoked images of horse racings rich past and made it seem as if they had all been there before.

title: In Shadow of the Stonewall Inn, a Gay Man Is Killed
description: Mark Carson did not hide that he was gay, and when he went out on the town he would often head to Greenwich Village, where years before he was born, much of the struggle for gay liberation unfolded. Yet late Friday night, just blocks from the Stonewall Inn, among the most important landmarks of that struggle, he was confronted with a man screaming antigay slurs, who then stalked him before pulling out a silver revolver and fatally shooting him, the police said.

title: China Embraces Corporate Social Responsibility
description: With its projects challenged by activists energized by Myanmars democratic opening, China has been trying to repair its tarnished reputation.

title: So Far, the Battery Charger Is Working in Japan
description: A GENERATION ago, Japan was a colossus on any investing map of the world.

title: A Life-Changing Trip
description: MY parents came from a working-class area in the north of England. Being bohemians at heart and wanting to follow the sun, they quit their jobs in London in the mid-1960s and moved to the Mediterranean coast. I was conceived on the Italian Riviera, in Lerici. My father, a painter, felt that Italy was already overexploited so they moved to Spain. I was born in Barcelona but we lived in a nearby beach town with bad roads and worse water.

title: Whats Pro-Business?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Right Corporate Directors
description: To the Editor:

title: When Medical Bills  Weigh on Job Applicants
description: To the Editor:

title: What Stock to Buy? Hey, Mom, Dont Ask Me
description: OVER the last few weeks, as the stock market has reached new highs, my thoughts have turned to my 85-year-old mother.

title: With Simona De Silvestro
description: With Danica Patrick driving in Nascar full time, Simona De Silvestro is the top woman of IndyCar racing. De Silvestro, a 24-year-old from Switzerland, was trying to qualify this weekend for her fourth Indianapolis 500, which takes place next Sunday. She was rookie of the year in her first Indy 500 in 2010, with a 14th-place finish. Four races into the 2013 season, she is ninth in the IndyCar Series standings after three top-10 finishes. This is her first season with KV Racing Technology.

title: In Leading the Yankees, Cano Makes His Boss Take Notice
description: Hal Steinbrenner was at Yankee Stadium on Saturday morning, saying hello to players and fans before the Yankees game against the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Rookie Defensemen Blunt Rangers Attacks
description: The result of one Stanley Cup game does not determine a series, but the Rangers will need to make adjustments if they hope to beat the Boston Bruins.

title: With Mets Back to Being Punchless, Hefner Remains Winless
description: CHICAGO  A pattern has developed for the Mets in this young season: when Jeremy Hefner pitches, the Mets lose.

title: Sonys Unwanted Genre: Suspense
description: NOWHERE is the opulence of Old Hollywood more palpable than on the Sony Pictures lot in Culver City. Arching just inside the front gate is an eight-story rainbow. This grand $1.6 million sculpture, a condition of a lot expansion, rose last year and became a symbolic link between past glories  The Wizard of Oz was filmed here  and current ones. Years of cutbacks have taken the shine off many studios, which now look like glorified factories. But Sony has preserved its lot as a perfect little movieland town: executive suites overflow with orchids, and cafes border a new park where employees sip lattes and stretch on the grass.

title: From Germany, Playing a Sport He Once Gave No Thought
description: Several years later, Donald Lutz recalls the scene with a mix of amusement and embarrassment. He was a camper at Major League Baseballs International European Academy in Italy, and the other teenagers lined up to get the autograph of an instructor. Lutz followed their lead, but he did not know why he should care about having Rod Carews name on a baseball.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Chatter for Sunday, May 19
description: If the next start-up that becomes Facebook happens to be one of our kids, thats what we are looking for.

title: Highlights: Oxbow Derails Orbs Crown Quest With Win in Preakness Stakes
description: BALTIMORE  Oxbow, one of three starters for the Hall of Fame trainer D. Wayne Lukas, held off Itsmyluckyday by a length and three-quarters to win the 138th running of the Preakness Stakes on Saturday at Pimlico Race Course.

title: Befitting
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Jean OConor not only appears to be making a debut today, but she is also pulling the old switcheroo on us. What starts out as a very good idea becomes a berry good one, if you get my drift.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 19
description: The White House battled several controversies last week, facing questions not only about the September attack in Benghazi, Libya,but also about the targeted scrutiny of conservative groups by the Internal Revenue Service and the seizure of phone records from The Associated Press by the Justice Department.

title: New York Schools Chief Warns Against Changes
description: Warning that the fate of New York City education was hanging in the balance, Dennis M. Walcott, the schools chancellor, suggested on Saturday that the school system was at risk of falling into disarray in the hands of a new mayor.

title: Concern for Scottish Banks in Independence Effort
description: LONDON  An independent Scotland could find its banks too big to rescue in the event of another crisis, according to a British government report that compares the Scottish financial sector with those of debt-laden Iceland and Cyprus.

title: The Old Men and the Ice
description: BOSTON  The demands of old age were a theme here on Saturday. On the one hand was the Bruins Jaromir Jagr, at 41 the oldest player in the series. On the other was Rangers Coach John Tortorella, talking about how older players were affected by what they did  or didnt do  during the lockout.

title: Police Say Officer Mistakenly Killed Hofstra Student in Hostage Standoff
description: A 21-year-old Hofstra University student who was killed in a home invasion on Friday was mistakenly shot in the head by an officer who fired eight times at a man who was holding a gun to the students head and then pointed it at him, the police said on Saturday. Seven of the bullets hit the man, who was also killed.

title: The Health Toll of Immigration
description: BROWNSVILLE, Tex.  Becoming an American can be bad for your health.

title: Disputed Election Sends Malaysian Politician Back to Fight on the Streets
description: KUANTAN, Malaysia  Not long ago he was flirting with the idea of semiretirement, maybe a teaching job at an American university. But now Anwar Ibrahim, the leader of the Malaysian opposition, former political prisoner and longtime bugbear of the establishment, says those plans are firmly on the shelf.

title: A Prison Sites Future Stirs Up the Ghosts of Its Notorious Past
description: MAZE, Northern Ireland  On a quiet country road south of Belfast, only the sudden appearance of a watchtower and portions of walls offer any hint of what was once Europes most notorious prison. After the last inmates walked out the gates in 2000, the bulldozers moved in, leaving little of the top security fortress intact.

title: Coach Says Hagelin Stinks on Power Play
description: BOSTON  The Rangers power play has been bafflingly ineffective, and one of the biggest mysteries is why the speedy left wing Carl Hagelin does not skate on it. He is the teams second-highest playoff scorer with 5 points in eight games, its plus-minus leader at plus 5, and a player praised often by Coach John Tortorella.

title: On Hong Kong Shelves, Illicit Dirt on Chinas Elite
description: HONG KONG  Visitors from mainland China climb the narrow stairs to a cramped room here filled with forbidden delights: shelves of scandal-packed exposs about their Communist Party masters.

title: Switzerland and Sweden to Play for Gold Medal
description: STOCKHOLM  Switzerland will play Sweden in the gold medal game of the International Ice Hockey Federation world championships after beating the United States, 3-0, in the semifinals on Saturday. The Islanders prospect Nino Niederreiter scored the winning goal midway through the second period.

title: Banned in China, but Popular in Hong Kong
description: These are some of the books, prohibited in China, that have been selling well in bookstores in Hong Kong, according to booksellers.

title: Two Kings of Racing Spoil Orbs Bid for Crown
description: BALTIMORE  They are a couple of old guys, D. Wayne Lukas and Gary Stevens, and for nearly 30 years, they have fallen in love on the racetrack, traded harsh words off it and fallen back in love enough times to be made honorary Kardashians. Trainers fire riders. Jockeys cheat on trainers with faster horses.

title: A Sampling of Pakistans Troubles
description: A train journey across Pakistan presents sweeping landscapes and troubling images of a country plagued by natural disasters; sectarian, nationalist and Islamist violence; poverty; and corruption.

title: Pakistan, as Seen Through Its Railways
description: At every major stop on the long line from Peshawar to the turbulent port city of Karachi lie reminders of why the country is a worry to its people, and to the wider world.

title: After Decades of Neglect, Pakistan Rusts in Its Tracks
description: RUK, Pakistan  Resplendent in his gleaming white uniform and peaked cap, jacket buttons tugging his plump girth, the stationmaster stood at the platform, waiting for a train that would never come. Cutbacks, Nisar Ahmed Abro said with a resigned shrug.

title: Criticism of Veterans Affairs Secretary Mounts Over Backlog in Claims
description: The 30-second Web video has the edgy quality of a campaign-season attack ad, including ominous music, grainy photos and a closing demand: Its time for new leadership.

title: Seeing Transparency as a Burden
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: As Towns Say No, Signs of Rising Resistance to Smart Meters
description: BRADY, Tex.  In October, the City Council of this Central Texas town voted unanimously to purchase advanced electric meters, known as smart meters, for the city-owned electric utility. But some residents resisted, and the smart meter vote played a large role in last weekends recall of the citys mayor and the electoral defeat of two council members.

title: With Cliburn Gone, Competition Tries to Adjust
description: On Wednesday, 30 pianists from 13 countries will gather at a hotel ballroom in downtown Fort Worth for a drawing of names, a tradition that will establish the performance schedule for the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition.

title: Kenneth Waltz, Foreign-Relations Expert, Dies at 88
description: Kenneth N. Waltz, a pre-eminent thinker on international relations who was known for his contrarian, debate-provoking ideas, not least his view that stability in the Middle East might be better served if Iran had a nuclear weapon, died on May 12 in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: With Consensus and Money, State Takes on Mental Health Care
description: SAN ANTONIO  Ray Gutierrezs green eyes twinkle and his cheeks dimple with a shy smile when he looks across the table at Evita Morin, the former intake worker at Haven for Hope, who he said helped save his life.

title: Christine White, Actress in a Classic Twilight Zone, Dies at 86
description: Julia Wilson wore pearls and a face of reassurance as she and her husband, Robert, took their seats on an airplane operated by Gold Star Airways half a century ago. Robert Wilson had just been released from a sanitarium. Six months earlier he had suffered a mental breakdown  on an airplane.

title: U.S. Titles End Up in Familiar Hands
description: Gata Kamsky and Irina Krush have turned the United States Championships into something of their personal playground in the last several years, and this year was no different.

title: Joseph Farman, 82, Is Dead; Discovered Ozone Hole
description: Joseph Farman, a British researcher whose single-minded and at times officially derided study of atmospheric changes in the Antarctic established the existence of a hole in the ozone layer over the South Pole approximately the size of the United States  one of the most important environmental discoveries of the 20th century  died on May 11 in Cambridge, England. He was 82.

title: William Miles, Maker of Films About Black History, Dies at 82
description: William Miles, a self-taught filmmaker whose documentaries revealed untold stories of black America, including those of its heroic black soldiers and of life in its signature neighborhood, Harlem, where he himself grew up, died on May 12 in Queens. He was 82.

title: Amenities in the Sky
description: A new apartment building being constructed at 432 Park Avenue will be the tallest residential building in the Western hemisphere.

title: Sky High and Going Up Fast: Luxury Towers Take New York
description: Only 10 floors have been completed in what is intended to be the tallest residential building in the Western Hemisphere  a slender, 84-story tower on Park Avenue at 56th Street in Manhattan. But the top penthouse is already under contract for $95 million.

title: Bullet Kills Girl, 14, Riding M.T.A. Bus in Queens
description: A 14-year-old girl was shot in the head and killed on Saturday evening as she rode a Metropolitan Transportation Authority bus in Queens, the police said.

title: Lottery Numbers
Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 19
description: The I.R.S. is pretty dysfunctional to begin with, and this case brought all those dysfunctions to their worst.

title: Knicks Path Through Playoffs Is Blocked
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Carmelo Anthony launched himself from the baseline, rising swiftly, his arm cocked, his eyes on the rim, carrying the Knicks playoff existence, a citys hopes and his own postseason legacy with him. In that moment, ever so briefly, all things still seemed possible: A date with the Miami Heat. A run to the finals. A championship.

title: George Johnston, Eric Price
description: George William Johnston and Eric Quinn Price were married Saturday on Gibson Island in Maryland. Judge M. Brooke Murdock of Baltimore Circuit Court officiated at the home of Jonathan Hyde, a friend of the couple.

title: Daniel S. Chao, Jeffrey E. Berkowitz
description: Daniel See Chao and Jeffrey Edward Berkowitz are to be married Sunday evening at Oxon Hill Manor, an event space in Fort Washington, Md. Rabbi Erica Asch is to officiate.

title: Stephanie Wertkin, Zachary Gold
description: Stephanie Bess Wertkin and Zachary Robin Gold were married Saturday evening at Waters Edge, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Melissa Zalkin Stollman officiated.

title: Andrea Lofgren, William Schneider
description: Andrea Ruth Lofgren and William Joseph Schneider were married Saturday at Battery Gardens, a restaurant and event space in Manhattan. Sara Curtin, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Colleen Darnall, Zachary Dietz
description: Colleen Rebecca Darnall and Zachary Dale Dietz were married Monday by the Rev. Gary B. Putnam, a United Methodist minister, at the Full Moon Resort in Big Indian, N.Y.

title: Sara Lindenbaum, Joshua Goldfarb
description: Sara Elizabeth Lindenbaum is to be married Sunday to Capt. Joshua Lawrence Goldfarb. Rabbi Philip Billy Lewkowicz is to officiate at the Omni Tucson National Resort, a hotel in Tucson, with Cantor Avraham Alpert taking part.

title: Carol Duh, Terence Leong
description: Carol Jiarou Duh and Terence Yuwen Leong were married Saturday at the Central Park Conservatory Garden in New York. Monica Weiss, an officiant of the American Ethical Union, officiated, with Joan Javier-Duval, a candidate for ministry with the Universal Unitarian Church, assisting.

title: Alexandra Tegenborg, James Weichert Jr.
description: Alexandra French Tegenborg, a daughter of Patricia L. French of Bedminster, N.J., and Lars A. Tegenborg of Rutherford, N.J., was married Saturday to James Martin Weichert Jr., the son of Pamela M. Weichert and Mr. Weichert of New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Patrick G. ODonovan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, where he is the pastor.

title: Sarah Nam, Gordon Liao
description: Sarah Hyunee Nam and Gordon Yu Liao were married Saturday at Harvards Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Jonathan L. Walton, a Baptist minister and the Pusey Minister of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Glenna Gross, Daniel Fix
description: Glenna Drew Gross, a daughter of Kim Johnson Gross and David E. Gross, both of Rye, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Daniel Brett Fix, a son of Barbara Fix of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Milton S. Fix. Rabbi Israel Singer is to officiate at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Alix Rogers, John Flynn
description: Janine Alix Rogers and John Patrick Flynn were married Saturday at the Old Marylebone Town Hall in London. Mark Tiller, a ceremonies and registration officer, officiated. Next Sunday, the Rev. Louise L. Kingston, an Episcopal priest and an aunt of the groom, will perform a second ceremony at the Villa Cortine Palace Hotel in Sirmione, Italy, before friends and family.

title: Dina Gordon, Robert Kinner
description: Dina Gordon and Dr. Robert Luke Kinner were married Saturday in Philadelphia. Gabrielle Kaplan-Mayer, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts.

title: Daphne Hasbani and J.J. Balaban
description: Dr. Daphne Maya Hasbani and Jack Jeffrey Balaban are to be married Sunday. Rabbi Lauren Grabelle Herrmann is to perform the ceremony at the Cira Center in Philadelphia.

title: Alexandra Epstein and William Gordon
description: Dr. Alexandra Sara Epstein, the daughter of Dr. Karen T. Isselbacher and Dr. Alan Epstein of Newton, Mass., was married Saturday evening to Dr. William Joseph Gordon, the son of Stasi A. Lubansky and Dr. Bruce R. Gordon of New York. Rabbi Elias J. Lieberman officiated at the Seaport Hotel in Boston.

title: Kurt Roggin, Jimmy Serrano
description: Kurt Landon Roggin and Jimmy Israel Serrano were married Saturday at the Plaza Hotel in New York. Lisa Traina, who was ordained by the Life Unification Church, officiated.

title: Alice Suh, Edward Jou
description: Alice Jean Suh and Edward Shih-Tong Jou were married Saturday at the Hotel Monaco in Washington. The Rev. Heather Sawyer Zempel, a minister of the National Community Church, officiated.

title: Paulette Aniskoff, Matthew Tinning
description: Paulette LaRay Aniskoff and Matthew Reid Tinning were married Saturday evening at WeatherLea Farm and Vineyard in Lovettsville, Va. Malcolm Forbes Baldwin, the owner of the farm and a civil celebrant licensed by the County of Loudoun, Va., officiated.

title: Rachael Shapiro, Daniel Lipton
description: Rachael Adams Shapiro and Daniel Seth Lipton are to be married Sunday at India House, a private club in New York. Sheera Ben-David, a cantor and friend of the couple, is to officiate.

title: Sara Nelson and Sam Radin
description: Sara Nelson and Sam Radin were married Friday evening at the Century Association in Manhattan. Ira Silverberg, a Universal Life minister and friend of the couple, officiated.

title: Genevieve Thornton and Grey Baker
description: Genevieve Marie Thornton, the daughter of Linda and Peter Thornton of Bronxville, N.Y., was married Saturday to Grey Donaldson Baker, a son of Kathryn and Geoffrey Baker of Washington. Canon Norman N. Lynas, an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Church in Hamilton Parish, Bermuda.

title: Hsin-Mei Hsu, Oscar Tang
description: Hsin-Mei Agnes Hsu and Oscar Liu-Chien Tang were married Saturday in Irvington, Va. The Rev. Dr. Barbara A. Cullom, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at Historic Christ Church.

title: Sarah Pickard, Philip Michaelson
description: Sarah Naree Pickard and Philip Aaron Michaelson were married Saturday evening at the Birchwood Country Club in Westport, Conn. Rabbi Mark Lipson officiated.

title: Salua Baida, David Mack
description: Salua Vianeey Baida, a daughter of Maria de los Angeles Baida of El Paso, Tex., and the late Miguel Baida Nazif, was married Friday evening at the Dyker Beach Golf Course in Brooklyn to David Joseph Mack, the son of Irene Pasyanos and Fredric E. Mack, both of Middletown, R.I. Hope Mirlis, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated.

title: Crystal Hung, Ronald Ho
description: Dr. Crystal Hung and Ronald Ho were married Tuesday at San Francisco City Hall. Estrella Bryant, a deputy marriage commissioner for San Francisco County, officiated.

title: Alpana Gowda, Rajat Batra
description: Dr. Alpana Raghava Gowda and Rajat Batra were married Saturday at the Peterloon Mansion in Cincinnati. Pandit Ramesh Rajamani officiated.

title: Katharine Bosland, Royal Kastens III
description: Katharine MacLean Bosland and Royal Frederick Kastens III were married Saturday in Richmond, Va. The Rev. Nicholas G. Bacalis performed the ceremony at SS. Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Cathedral.

title: Stephanie Janssen, Wallace Krantz Jr.
description: Stephanie Ann Janssen and Wallace Eugene Krantz Jr. are to be married Sunday evening at the Green Building, an event space in Brooklyn. Emily N. Voorhees, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, is to officiate.

title: Thomas Mizer, Travis McGhie
description: Thomas Patrick Mizer and Matthew Travis McGhie were married Saturday at the Castello Plan, a wine bar in Brooklyn. Nicole Burley, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Alison Jill Rauch, Martin Seth Burger
description: Alison Jill Rauch and Martin Seth Burger were married Saturday evening at Brae Burn Country Club in Purchase, N.Y. Rabbi David J. Gelfand officiated.

title: Melody Calvo, Reeve Hohlt
description: Melody Ann Calvo and Reeve Canfield Hohlt were married Saturday at Meadowood Napa Valley, a resort in St. Helena, Calif. Kimberly Thompson, a California marriage commissioner, officiated.

title: Caitlin Elen, Louis Morin III
description: Caitlin Marie Elen, the daughter of Leslie Elen and Robert W. Elen of Los Angeles, was married Saturday evening to Capt. Louis George Morin III, the son of Doris K. Morin of Irvington, N.Y., and Mr. Morin Jr. of New York. The Rev. Dr. Robert A. Schuller, a minister with the Reformed Church in America, and the son of the televangelist Robert H. Schuller, officiated at the Lakeside Golf Club in Burbank, Calif.

title: Aja Falker and Shukree Tilghman
description: Aja Iman Falker and Shukree Hassan Tilghman were married Saturday at Central Baptist Church in St. Louis. The Rev. Dr. Robert Charles Scott, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Ashley Ford, Patrick Haggerty
description: Dr. Ashley Elizabeth Ford, the daughter of Dorothy A. Ford and Jack R. Ford of Spring Lake, N.J., was married Saturday to Patrick Andrew Haggerty, a son of Janice Haggerty and Daniel L. Haggerty of Lawrenceville, N.J. The Rev. Msgr. Thomas A. Luebking, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Catharine Church in Spring Lake, with the Rev. Raymond A. Schroth, also a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the groom, taking part.

title: It All Led Up to the Ringing of Bells
description: Diana Al-Hadid and Jonathan Sinclair Lott are to be married Sunday at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens. Bruce Smith, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.

title: A Scientist and the Value of Meddling
description: Alexandra Buck McCullagh and Riley Sutthoff Newman were married Saturday at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco. The Rev. Jude A. Harmon, an Episcopal priest and a minor canon at the cathedral, performed the ceremony.

title: Carolina Aguilar and Julian Dawes
description: Carolina Hildegard Aguilar, the daughter of Renate Porges de Aguilar and Carlos F. Aguilar of Comus, Md., was married there Saturday evening to Julian Morgan Dawes, a son of Nicholas M. Dawes and Rosemarie Dawes of Millburn, N.J. Gordon Ron Tomlinson, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life Minister for the occasion, officiated at a farm owned by the brides family.

title: Corrections: May 19, 2013
description: METROPOLITAN

title: Preakness Stakes Replay
description: Oxbow derailed Orbs Triple Crown quest by winning the Preakness Stakes. Orb finished fourth.

title: Hills Return at Point Guard Gives Pacers Needed Lift
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The news came late in the afternoon again, as time ticked toward another potentially series-deciding game against the Knicks, but this time it was good news for the Indiana Pacers: George Hill, their starting point guard, had been cleared to play.

title: Stephenson Gives Indiana Energy, Points and Signature Play
description: INDIANAPOLIS  There were four minutes left, the game was tied and the ball was in Carmelo Anthonys hands  a circumstance the Knicks would not complain much about late in Game 6 on Saturday. But with Paul George on his left hip, and Roy Hibbert looming in the paint, Anthony tried to skip a pass over his shoulder to J. R. Smith on the wing.

title: Game 6: Knicks vs. Pacers
description: After a 54-win regular season and a division title, the Knicks were eliminated from the playoffs, losing on the road for the third time in the series.

title: Pakistans Special Relationship
description: Nawaz Sharif tells President Obama about Pakistans special relationship.

title: The Mythical 70s
description: Matt OBrien is probably right to suggest that Michael Kinsleys problems  and those of quite a few other people, some of whom have real influence on policy  is that theyre still living in the 1970s. I do, however, resent that thing about 60-year-old men

title: A Night of Swan Songs at Saturday Night Live
description: 9:13 a.m. | Updated

title: Ending the Secrecy of a Childs Addiction
description: Almost two years ago my wife and I became aware that our 22-year-old son, William, was using heroin. At the time he was already seeing a psychotherapist. Over the next two years we added an addiction psychiatrist, out-patient treatment, treatment with Suboxone, in-patient detox, in-patient treatment, out-patient treatment, out-patient detox, treatment with Vivitrol, more out-patient treatment, another in-patient treatment, more out-patient treatment, a revolving door of well over a dozen trips to and from the emergency rooms of at least four different hospitals, an attempt to work with another addiction psychiatrist, Alcoholics Anonymous, Narcotics Anonymous, and a home life fraught with tension, despair, sometimes hopeful during intermittent periods of sobriety, and always filled with the apprehension of misfortune.

title: Disruptions: Helper Robots Are Steered, Tentatively, to Care for the Aging
description: In the opening scene of the movie Robot & Frank, which takes place in the near future, Frank, an elderly man who lives alone, is arguing with his son about going to a medical center for Alzheimers treatment when the son interrupts him. I brought you something, he says to Frank. Then the son pulls a large, white humanoid robot from the trunk of his car.

title: Launchings by North Korea Raise Tensions
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea launched a short-range projectile into waters off its east coast on Sunday, as South Korea condemned the Norths provocations and urged it to accept a proposal for dialogue.

title: Latest Knicks Failure Has Its Roots at the Top
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Another season of not-good-enough ended, unofficially, with a grim-faced James L. Dolan leading a lock-step entourage in a quick-striding getaway across the bowels of Bankers Life Fieldhouse. Dolan, the bewildering strongman of a Madison Square Garden empire that includes the Knicks, wasnt waiting around for the buzzer to sound on a deflating Eastern Conference semifinal series and one more championship-less N.B.A. season.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE 2013 BILLBOARD MUSIC AWARDS Tracy Morgan hosts this ceremony, broadcast live from the MGM Grand Garden Arena in Las Vegas and honoring Billboard chart toppers from March 12, 2012, through March 10, 2013, in genres including R&B, rap, pop, country, rock, Latin and alternative. Justin Bieber, Chris Brown, Selena Gomez, Bruno Mars, Miguel, Macklemore & Ryan Lewis, Taylor Swift, Christina Aguilera, Pitbull, Jennifer Lopez, Will.i.am, Nicki Minaj and Lil Wayne are scheduled to appear. Prince, above, will perform and accept the Billboard Icon award, given to an enduring legend in music. Madonna will receive the Top Touring Artist award, honoring the years highest-grossing concert touring act.

title: Killing of Pakistani Politician Shakes New Voting Round
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Voters in an upscale district of Karachi turned out in low numbers on Sunday for a repeat of the parliamentary election there, a day after a prominent official in a major political party was gunned down in the area, officials said.

title: Charges Filed in Killing of Gay Man in Greenwich Village
description: In Greenwich Village, there are different worlds. There is the world of wealthy people who own their own brownstones or live in stylish new apartment buildings. There is the world of gay men and lesbians and the bars they go to. And there is the world of heterosexuals and the bars they go to.

title: Star Trek Into Darkness Is No. 1 at the Box Office
description: The Enterprise encountered some choppy air in North America over the weekend  namely strong holdover ticket sales for Iron Man 3 and The Great Gatsby  but hit warp speed in foreign markets, resulting in stout overall results for Star Trek Into Darkness. James T. Kirk and crew were No. 1 at movie theaters in the United States and Canada, taking in about $70.6 million over the weekend, for a total since opening on Imax screens on Wednesday of $84.1 million.

title: Obama Urges Morehouse Graduates to Keep Setting an Example
description: ATLANTA  President Obama came to Morehouse College, the alma mater of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., on Sunday to tell graduates, 50 years after Dr. Kings landmark I Have a Dream speech in Washington, that laws and hearts and minds have been changed to the point where someone who looks just like you can somehow come to serve as president of these United States.

title: White House Aide Calls Criticism of Obama Offensive
description: A senior adviser to President Obama mounted a combative defense of the administration on Sunday, saying the controversies enveloping the White House were the result of Republican lawmakers trying to drag Washington into a swamp of partisan fishing expeditions, trumped-up hearings and false allegations.

title: Miamis Stadium Problems Cloud Bid to Host Super Bowl in 2016, and Beyond
description: Perhaps the most telling handicapping of the contest to host the 50th Super Bowl came in a grammatical slip from one of the bidders less than two weeks ago.

title: Yahoo to Buy Tumblr for $1.1 Billion
description: The board of Yahoo, the faded Web pioneer, agreed on Sunday to buy the popular blogging service Tumblr for about $1.1 billion in cash, the companies announced Monday, a signal of how the company plans to reposition itself as the technology industry makes a headlong rush into social media.

title: Who Cares Who Did It? Why Is More the Issue
description: Set in Vancouver in the same way Rookie Blue is set in Toronto  very subtly, so as not to confuse or turn off American viewers  ABCs new imported crime drama, Motive, offers a common Canadian trade-off. Its reasonably smart, reasonably interesting and reasonably well acted without being particularly good.

title: Now That Dad Is Dead, Lets Compete for Prizes
description: The Goodwin Games, a sitcom that begins Monday on Fox, appears as if it intends to take a gag that has been the basis for individual episodes of various comedies and stretch it out for the life of the series. The surprise is that at least from the peppy pilot, its possible that this might actually work reasonably well.

title: Back From War, Columbia Slugger Is Dreaming of the Major Leagues
description: Joey Falcone, a slugger for Columbia, knows what to do when he finds himself pressing at the plate. He eases his grip on the bat, takes a deep breath and assumes a more relaxed stance.

title: Hezbollah Aids Syrian Military in a Key Battle
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian government forces backed by Lebanese fighters from the militant group Hezbollah pushed Sunday into parts of Qusayr, a strategic city long held by rebels, according to an antigovernment activist and pro-government news channels. If the advance holds, it would be a serious setback for opponents of President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Braiding Hair and Issues About Race
description: When readers of Americanah first meet its Nigerian-born heroine, Ifemelu, she has come a long way in life. She holds a fellowship at Princeton. She is the absolute love of my life to the man she is dating, a black American named Blaine, who teaches at Yale. She writes a blog about racial issues that features her irreverent, hectoring, funny and thought-provoking voice, as one online admirer puts it, though readers of Americanah may find it more leaden. And she has an old flame in Nigeria, Obinze, who has never gotten over her.

title: Singing a Happier Tune in Cannes
description: CANNES, France  The applause for Joel and Ethan Coens wonderful new film, a comedy in a melancholic key called Inside Llewyn Davis, started someplace around the midway mark. Prompted by the hilariously inane Please Please Mr. Kennedy, sung by Oscar Isaac, Justin Timberlake and Adam Driver  who play three bearded 1961 folkies warbling and strumming through a space-race ditty  the Cannes audience started to laugh and clap. By the time the film ended, the clapping, laughing and whooping critics at the 66th Cannes Film Festival were over the moon.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: An Underground Pool Drying Up
description: Portions of the High Plains aquifer are being depleted.

title: A Writing Class Focused on Goodbyes
description: The suicide note  and Im being deadly earnest  is moving, strange, harrowing and peculiar literature, said Simon Critchley, an author and philosophy professor at the New School. Peoples interest in them is almost pornographic.

title: Watching Musicians Evolve Onstage
description: Whenever a respected jazz musician  the pianist Chick Corea, say  encounters a musician a few generations younger, some kind of tutorial takes place. But now its likely that those younger musicians  the 17-year-old pianists Beka Gochiashvili and Gadi Lehavi, say  arent the only ones being tutored. The relationship becomes public, through concerts and recordings and interviews and practice-room YouTube videos, much faster than it ever did before. Some of us enjoy seeing wisdom transferred; were willing to buy into that relationship, or even triangulate ourselves into it in some indirect way.

title: Decisions, Decisions: Taking Over for Vonnegut
description: In Kurt Vonneguts 1993 play Make Up Your Mind, the character Roland Stackhouse invents a therapy for people who have trouble making decisions. Vonnegut was all too familiar with the syndrome. He wrote several drafts of the play but was unable to settle on a final script. One version was briefly staged in 1993 and then consigned to a drawer with 11 other variations.

title: Broadways Largest Theater, the Foxwoods, Appears to Have Buyer
description: May 20 | Updated

title: They Fathom Distinctive Languages
description: At first glance, Pat Metheny and John Zorn might seem to come from different planets. Mr. Metheny, 58, is a guitarist whose music has resonated broadly throughout jazz and instrumental pop, a dazzling virtuoso with a warm human touch. Mr. Zorn, 59, is a saxophonist of firm avant-garde conviction, a natural polarizer and provocateur.

title: Reunited, and It Feels So New
description: Even after you bag a charismatic, young new boyfriend, its hard to let go of the one who got away.

title: Young, Yes; Youthful, Sometimes
description: When it comes to classical music these days, the kids  relatively speaking, of course  are all right. The news that the Latvian conductor Andris Nelsons, 34, has been named music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra is the latest in what has felt like a youth trend in major American ensembles.

title: Blood Despite Kinship
description: Aurangzeb, Atul Sabharwals dark fable about corruption and family ties, begins with a quote from Horace: Deep in the cavern of the infants breast, the fathers nature lurks, and lives anew. And it borrows its name from the Mughal emperor who imprisoned his father (Shah Jahan of Taj Mahal fame) and killed his brothers and son. Mr. Sabharwals movie has echoes of both : Blood will tell  evil lurks in the evil mans son, goodness in the good mans. But also blood will flow  kinship, in certain ruthless precincts, is no guarantee of safety.

title: The Cabaret of an Actress Inspired by Jerome Kern
description: The comparison of a soprano with a nightingale goes back at least to the time of Jenny Lind, the 19th-century opera diva known as the Swedish nightingale. The term evokes a sweet, soaring voice in the night with an otherworldly aura. I thought of that on Friday evening as I listened to the glorious, richly hued timbre and fast vibrato of Rebecca Luker singing the Jerome Kern repertory at 54 Below.

title: Opposites, in Their Pivoting and Flailing, Offer Intrigue
description: At the start of 35  a new work by the choreographer Aynsley Vandenbroucke, three dancers spread out along the horizontal length of the Chocolate Factory. Its a little like looking at a window display. Their corporeal offerings are, by turn, luscious and stark; each dancer, obscured by fabric, is lost in her own world to create a scene that wavers between intimacy and cool formality.

title: Yahoo Is Said to Have Reached a Deal for Tumblr
description: Yahoos board has agreed to buy the popular blogging service Tumblr for about $1.1 billion in cash, people with knowledge of the agreement said on Sunday, Nick Bilton and Michael J. de la Merced report in The New York Times. It is the biggest acquisition yet under Yahoos chief executive, Marissa Mayer. Read more

title: Crunchy Bit
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  I started in the southeast for this one, lured by the easy toehold of Yes, MAAM and film star ANNA Paquin. At first, I thought that the theme might have to do with having As be the only vowel in the grid, but then I ran into the EMUS at 55 Down and was proven wrong. Desperately, fatally wrong.

title: Glenn Milgram at Honors Bridge Club
description: Glenn Milgrim of New York City was the main architect of the Red Hook charity event at the Honors Bridge Club in Manhattan on May 8. It was therefore fitting that he and his partner, R. Jay Becker of New York City, had the highest score.

title: A Parking Lot With a Beat
description: The map of Electric Daisy Carnival, the two-day electronic dance music festival that began on Friday at Citi Field, was also a map of genres and subgenres. In 11 hours of continuous music from five stages, there were pop tunes and blasts of noise, immediate thrills and inexorable buildups, cheap shots and rich experiments.

title: Newest Yankee Joins Long List of Infielders
description: The Yankees injury-riddled season has included a frequent shuttling of backup infielders, from Eduardo Nunez to Corban Joseph to Chris Nelson to Alberto Gonzalez, who even pitched a third of an inning in relief in a blowout loss to Seattle during his short stay.

title: Calling the Shots From the Couch
description: Jamie Epstein, a New Jersey lawyer, was watching the final round of the Players Championship on his laptop when the leader, Tiger Woods, drove the ball into the water on the 14th hole. Epstein was incredulous when Woods made his subsequent drop roughly 250 yards from the pin. From where Epstein sat, at a Whole Foods cafeteria, it appeared that Woodss ball had crossed the hazard at the front of the lake, a couple of hundred yards closer to the tee.

title: Movie About a Severed Leg Seeks Backers via Crowdsourcing
description: LOS ANGELES  Will Ed Cunninghams movie about a loose leg find its footing on Kickstarter? This week should tell.

title: Public Outrage Over Factory Conditions Spurs Labor Deal
description: STOCKHOLM  For a global retailer, it was the worst kind of publicity.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include sales of existing homes for April (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and sales of new homes for April (Thursday); and durable goods orders for April (Friday).

title: Charlie Rose to Host a Show in Prime Time on PBS
description: Viewers can already wake up with Charlie Rose on CBS This Morning, and wind down their day with his late-night PBS newsmaker interview program. If that is not enough, Mr. Rose, who has been called the hardest working man in television, will soon be hosting a Friday night prime-time PBS show, as well.

title: Pearl Theater Company Unveils Schedule
description: The Pearl Theater Company, the Off Broadway troupe that mounts classic plays and new works dealing with classical themes, has announced its 2013-14 season. The world premiere of And Away We Go by Terrence McNally (Master Class, Ragtime)  which was delayed earlier this year because of financial troubles for the company that have since been resolved  is scheduled for Nov. 12. The season will start on Sept. 3 with George Bernard Shaws You Never Can Tell. That is to be followed by And Away We Go (Nov. 12 to Dec. 15); Jean-Paul Sartres No Exit (Feb. 25 to March 30); and The Rivals, by Richard Brinsley Sheridan (April 22 to May 25).

title: A Young Outfielders Timely Homer and a Sliver of Promise for the Mets
description: CHICAGO  For all the talk about how bright the Mets future could be, the organization has a weighty task ahead finding capable position players to eventually array around their vaunted young pitchers.

title: Electric Daisy Carnival
description: Scenes from the electronic dance music festival at Citi Field in Queens.

title: Schools Add to Test Load, Just to Assess the Questions
description: English tests? Check. Math tests? Check. Summer vacation? Not so fast.

title: The Persistence of the Lolita Syndrome
description: Ever since the details of the Jimmy Savile case started to come to light, I have, like some philosophical gumshoe, been pursuing an investigation into the possible intellectual origin of his mentality. In other words, I have been looking into what has loosely been referred to as the culture of abuse, which may or may not have been a factor at the BBC, or what Michel Foucault would have called the epistm  a kind of conspiracy at the level of language and ideas and metaphor that (in this context) could conceivably promote or justify the sexual exploitation of young girls. (Alongside its continuing Savile review, the BBC has also promised to examine the case of Stuart Hall, another broadcaster, who has pleaded guilty to indecently assaulting 13 girls over three decades.)

title: Inequality and Growth, Discussed
description: Ive been in transit all day, so no column in tomorrows paper. Incidentally, I saw evidence of impressive investment in infrastructure while away  unfortunately, by beavers, not state and local governments:

title: Bearing Witness at Terrorism Trials
description: Perhaps a meal was not the ideal setting to talk about something as unappetizing as a hunger strike. But there was no way, even with lunch on the table, to avoid that grim topic with Karen J. Greenberg, who has made herself an expert on matters of torture, terrorism trials and the military prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba.

title: Telecoms Big Players Hold Back the Future
description: If you were going to look for ground zero in the fight against a rapidly consolidating telecom and cable industry, you might end up on the fifth floor of the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law in New York.

title: Breakdowns Leave Rangers Reeling
description: BOSTON  The Rangers were trailing by 3-2 and feeling pretty good about their chances when they came out for the third period Sunday afternoon.

title: Tech Industry Pushes to Amend Immigration Bill
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The technology industry got much of what it wanted in a bill that overhauls federal immigration law.

title: Slow Response by Georgians to Mob Attack on Gay Rally
description: MOSCOW  Georgian television captured clear images as a mob of more than 20,000 attacked a small gay rights march in downtown Tbilisi on Friday, sending at least 14 people to the hospital.

title: A Season of Families, Vampires and Aliens
description: BASED on what the broadcast networks shared with Madison Avenue last week about the coming season, it seems as if the quintessential new series for 2013-14 is a comedy about a family of vampires from space moving in with relatives on earth.

title: Italian Team Seeks Change in Americas Cup Wind Limits After Sailors Death
description: More than a week after the death of British sailor Andrew Simpson in a training accident, none of the four Americas Cup teams have withdrawn from the competition, which is still scheduled to begin in early July in San Francisco.

title: Dagestans Shadow War, Fought by Many Tsarnaevs
description: KHASAVYURT, Russia  The slender man of 22, a former guerrilla fighter, was making another hangdog, penitent appearance at the behest of city officials here. It was brainwashing that led him to take up arms against the state and go to the forest, he said, and his sincere desire was to forget that it had ever happened.

title: Israeli Report Casting New Doubts on Shooting in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  The images seen around the world were shocking: a young boy being shot dead as he crouched behind his father at a dusty junction in Gaza in September 2000. But the facts behind the images have been disputed almost from the start, and on Sunday, the Israeli government asserted that there was no evidence for the original account of the event, which was that the boy was hit by Israeli bullets  and that it was even possible that neither the boy nor his father had been struck by any bullets at all.

title: Bold Growth Plans at Hollywood Studios
description: LOS ANGELES  Film counts are down. Production is going elsewhere. And yet big Hollywood studios are planning to expand.

title: Russia Expels Former American Embassy Official
description: MOSCOW  A former senior Justice Department official at the American Embassy here was declared persona non grata and barred from Russia this month, according to people familiar with the case, possibly because he had rebuffed an effort by the Russian Federal Security Service to recruit him as a spy.

title: Indonesian Strongmans Legacy Remains a Matter of Debate
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Tree-lined Cendana street in an upscale neighborhood in central Jakarta has not changed much in recent decades, save for the demolition of a few Dutch colonial homes in favor of modernist villas. Yet the former resident whose home once took up the entire middle of the block initiated dramatic changes in his country, and 15 years after he disappeared from Indonesias political scene, debate still rages about whether they were for better or worse.

title: The Day the Music Died in Mali
description: EVERYONE has heard of censored songs, like Billie Holidays Love for Sale, which was banned from ABC radio in 1956 because of its prostitution theme. Most are familiar with the censorship of artists, like the Dixie Chicks, who had their music blacklisted from country music stations across the country after they criticized President George W. Bush. But banning music in its entirety?

title: Celebrating Inequality
description: THE Roaring 20s was the decade when modern celebrity was invented in America. F. Scott Fitzgeralds Great Gatsby is full of magazine spreads of tennis players and socialites, popular song lyrics, movie stars, paparazzi, gangsters and sports scandals  machine-made by technology, advertising and public relations. Gatsby, a mysterious bootlegger who makes a meteoric ascent from Midwestern obscurity to the palatial splendor of West Egg, exemplifies one part of the celebrity code: its inherently illicit. Fitzgerald intuited that, with the old restraining deities of the 19th century dead and his generations faith in man shaken by World War I, celebrities were the new household gods.

title: How to Legalize Pot
description: THE first time I talked to Mark Kleiman, a drug policy expert at U.C.L.A., was in 2002, and he explained why legalization of marijuana was a bad idea. Sure, he said, the government should remove penalties for possession, use and cultivation of small amounts. He did not favor making outlaws of people for enjoying a drug that is less injurious than alcohol or tobacco. But he worried that a robust commercial marketplace would inevitably lead to much more consumption. You dont have to be a prohibitionist to recognize that pot, especially in adolescents and very heavy users, can seriously mess with your brain.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Education, Vision and the Mayors Race
description: The Democratic candidates for New York mayor, whirling around the boroughs on the debate-and-forum carousel, have been struggling for advantage and the attention of tuned-out voters. But they have had no trouble infuriating the Bloomberg administration, which seems to be getting touchier about criticism as it heads to the exits.

title: Derivatives Reform on the Ropes
description: New rules to regulate derivatives, adopted last week by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, are a victory for Wall Street and a setback for financial reform. They may also signal worse things to come.

title: Eavesdropping on Internet Communications
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has a new plan to intercept Internet messages, calls and video chats. Instead of requiring companies like Skype and Google to build surveillance capabilities into their services as it suggested in 2010, the F.B.I. now proposes fining companies that fail to comply with court-ordered wiretaps.

title: How a Change of Pace Helped Decide the Preakness
description: Two races, two entirely different pace scenarios, each with a significant impact on the outcome.

title: With Wheelchair and Lively Baton, Levine Commands Carnegie Hall
description: Against all odds, James Levine is back.

title: What Guilt Does the U.S. Bear in Guatemala?
Finding Time and Money to Cook
Potential Donors to Enroll America Grow Skittish
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administrations efforts to raise private money to carry out the presidents health care law have provoked such a strong partisan uproar that potential donors have become skittish about contributing, according to several people involved in the fund-raising program.

title: The Wolf of Isle Royale
description: To the Editor:

title: Calling Attention to the Bias Against Roma
description: To the Editor:

title: The Furor Over Benghazi
description: To the Editor:

title: Cutting Carbon Emissions

description: To the Editor:

title: Stockholder Power Faces Test at JPMorgan
description: Jamie Dimon and the 10 other directors of JPMorgan Chase take the stage in Tampa, Fla., on Tuesday, to face shareholders who can take comfort in a rising stock price and a prospering bank.

title: Hackers From China Resume Attacks on U.S. Targets
description: WASHINGTON  Three months after hackers working for a cyberunit of Chinas Peoples Liberation Army went silent amid evidence that they had stolen data from scores of American companies and government agencies, they appear to have resumed their attacks using different techniques, according to computer industry security experts and American officials.

title: Knicks Illusion Was Convincing, but Magic May Run Out
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The gap between expectations and reality stung hard, leaving Carmelo Anthony to split the difference Saturday night in his final postgame soliloquy of the season.

title: In Decision to Enter Home Near Hofstra, a Life-or-Death Calculation
description: When a Nassau County police officer confronted a gunman holding a college student hostage in her home on Friday night, he was forced, in an instant, to make a life-or-death calculation: Open fire and risk hitting the hostage, or hesitate and risk losing the hostage and being killed himself.

title: Delays Likely for Days as Officials Seek Cause of Connecticut Train Collision
description: Two days after a pair of passing Metro-North Railroad trains collided near Fairfield, Conn., injuring scores of people and clogging travel across wide swaths of the Northeast, transit officials said Sunday that crews had removed most of the 16 damaged cars from the rubble, with the help of two cranes.

title: Lottery Numbers
Hedge Fund Owner Gets Subpoena to Testify
description: Steven A. Cohen has received a subpoena to testify before a grand jury in the governments insider trading investigation into his hedge fund, SAC Capital Advisors, a development that signals a newly aggressive phase in the multiyear inquiry, according to lawyers and executives briefed on the case.

title: Three Bruins Rookies Turn Trouble Spot Into a Strength
description: BOSTON  The Boston Bruins injury-riddled defense has been one of the major topics of discussion surrounding the team this postseason. With three defensemen out, the opportunity for others to shine has presented itself. Several of those replacements have produced in unlikely ways.

title: Head of The A.P. Criticizes Seizure of Phone Records
description: The head of The Associated Press said on Sunday that the Obama administrations secret seizure of two months of its phone records, revealed this month, was unconstitutional, and had already diminished journalists capacity to report on the government.

title: Timeline: Jamie Dimon, the Chief of Too Big to Fail
description: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive and chairman of JPMorgan Chase, is wrestling with the fallout from a multibillion-dollar trading loss.

title: Girl Fatally Shot on Bus Wasnt Target, Police Say
description: For Daja Robinson, a 14-year-old Queens girl, a friends birthday party on Saturday afternoon was a chance for celebration and the mark of a relatively new responsibility  going out and coming home on her own.

title: Game 2: Rangers vs. Bruins
description: The Rangers defense broke down against the Bruins in Game 2 with goalie Henrik Lundqvist giving up five goals. Boston leads the series, 2-0.

title: Fresh Israeli Face Plays Down Dimming of Political Star
description: TEL AVIV  To say Yair Lapid has been on a roller coaster would be an understatement. One recent headline blared about his meteoric rise and fall, another said he had gone from political darling to national whipping boy.

title: British Leader Faces Rising Tide of Criticism From His Own Party
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Camerons leadership came under mounting strain on Sunday over European policy and social issues, with one senior figure saying Mr. Cameron had lost control of the Conservative Party.

title: Many of Spains Sephardic Jews Still Waiting for Citizenship
description: MADRID  Six months after announcing a significant easing of the naturalization process for Sephardic Jews, the Spanish government has yet to put the rules into practice, leaving many applicants for citizenship frustrated.

title: North Korea Seized Chinese Boat
description: HONG KONG  China revealed on Sunday that North Korea seized a Chinese fishing boat this month and detained its crewmen, who remain in custody, an episode likely to worsen recent discord between the two.

title: Chinese Official Arrives in India, Hoping to Focus on Trade
description: NEW DELHI  Still bruised and somewhat bewildered by a recent border dispute with China, Indian government officials welcomed the Chinese prime minister, Li Keqiang, on Sunday for his first trip abroad since assuming office in March.

title: The Tumblr and Instagram Deals: A Tale of the Tape
description: By agreeing to buy Tumblr for about $1.1 billion, Yahoo has struck the biggest social media deal in years, putting it up against the $1 billion* acquisition of Instagram by Facebook.

title: The Rails Scoreboard
description: How The Rails contributors are doing with their predictions through the first two legs of the Triple Crown (using a 3-2-1 point breakdown for win-place-show). Patricia Barnstable-Brown, a co-host of the celebrity-packed Barnstable Brown Gala, earned 3 points as a guest picker in the Kentucky Derby, and Mayor Stephanie C. Rawlings-Blake of Baltimore scored 1 point in the Preakness.

title: Emotional Swing for English Soccer Club
description: WIGAN, England  Just up a narrow alley from the shops in the center of town here, away from all the singing and chanting and shouting, there is a tiny square. This is where The Face of Wigan is, its expression unflinching and its aura unbowed. A statue crafted from stainless steel, The Face of Wigan rises nearly 20 feet tall  it is a giant head sitting on a block  and features a molded visage with sleepy eyes, a sharp nose and, perhaps most notably, a stiff, staid, solid upper lip.

title: Scrutiny of Silver Continues as Lopez Is Set to Resign
description: On Monday morning, the nameplate marking Assemblyman Vito Lopezs desk in the New York State Assembly chamber will be removed, and his official Web site will be taken down.

title: Lack of Water Has Lasting Effects in Kansas and Texas
description: Vast stretches of Texas and Kansas farmland lying over the High Plains Aquifer no longer support irrigation.

title: Heat Pose Stiffer Test for Pacers Strengths
description: In six games against the Knicks, the Indiana Pacers defense snuffed out drives and smothered the 3-point line. Anchored by Roy Hibbert, their mammoth center, the Pacers laid claim to the all-important area surrounding the basket and would not be moved, holding the Knicks to 46.3 percent shooting in close.

title: At Worlds, Sweden Wins Gold, and U.S. the Bronze
description: STOCKHOLM  Ending the so-called home ice curse, Sweden defeated Switzerland, 5-1, to win the gold medal at the International Ice Hockey Federation world championships on Sunday. Earlier, Alex Galchenyuk scored twice in the shootout to give the United States a 3-2 win over Finland in the bronze medal game.

title: Wells Dry, Fertile Plains Turn to Dust
description: HASKELL COUNTY, Kan.  Forty-nine years ago, Ashley Yosts grandfather sank a well deep into a half-mile square of rich Kansas farmland. He struck an artery of water so prodigious that he could pump 1,600 gallons to the surface every minute.

title: I.R.S. Inquiry Status Told to White House in April
description: WASHINGTON  The chief White House lawyer, Kathryn Ruemmler, learned last month that a Treasury inspector general had concluded an audit of the Internal Revenue Services targeting of conservative groups, weeks before the matter became public, according to a senior White House official.

title: Navajo Confront an Increase in New H.I.V. Infections
description: GALLUP, N.M.  A surge in H.I.V. infections on the Navajo reservation here has doctors and public health workers increasingly alarmed that the virus that causes AIDS has resurfaced with renewed intensity in this impoverished region.

title: Duel Is Not a Sure Deal for the Belmont
description: BALTIMORE  They have spent the last six months getting ready for the Triple Crown races, a series open only to 3-year-olds and the one time a year that horse racing occupies valuable real estate in the consciousness of the casual sports fan. So the day after the Preakness is always bittersweet for horsemen: they must either go home or go on to the Belmont Stakes, the final and most punishing leg of Americas classic races.

title: Virginia G.O.P. Pleases Crowd With Barbs About I.R.S.
description: RICHMOND, Va.  In the first Republican road test of a potentially torrid campaign issue, speaker after speaker at the partys Virginia state convention over the weekend inveighed against the governments targeting of conservative groups to inspire and motivate activists.

title: A Sport Less in Need of a Strong Runner Than a Strong Voice
description: BALTIMORE  Once again, the sport of kings has failed to recreate history.

title: Gillette Taps Superman to Connect With Customers
description: LOS ANGELES  How does Superman shave? If he is a Man of Steel, impervious to nearly everything, what could possibly remove that formidable stubble?

title: Suburbs Share of Poor Has Grown Since 2000
description: The suburbs, which in 2000 accounted for 29 percent of the regions poor people, a decade later were home to 33 percent of metropolitan New Yorkers living below the federal poverty level, according to an analysis of the latest census results.

title: Many Fronts in Fighting Obesity
description: Sugar, and especially the high-fructose corn syrup that sweetens many processed foods and nearly all soft drinks, has been justly demonized for adding nutritionally empty calories to our diet and causing metabolic disruptions linked to a variety of diseases. But a closer look at what and how Americans eat suggests that simply focusing on sugar will do little to quell the rising epidemic of obesity. This is a multifaceted problem with deep historical roots, and we are doing too little about many of its causes.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 20
description: Thats prime land. Ive raised 294 bushels of corn an acre there before, with water and the Lords help. Its over.

title: Redeeming Bangladesh
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Larger Union That Enforces Immigration Opposes Bill
description: A labor union representing 12,000 federal officers who issue immigration documents will join forces on Monday with the union representing deportation agents to publicly oppose a bill overhauling the immigration system that is making its way through the Senate, arguing that the legislation would weaken public safety.

title: Word of the Day | solemnity
description: solemnity \s-lem-n-te\ noun

title: Whats on Monday
description: 9P.M. (HBO) INSIDE OUT: THE PEOPLES ART PROJECT The French Street artist known by the initials J R and by his ubiquitous sunglasses and fedora, above, built his reputation on billboard-size photographic portraits of everyday people in urban settings, starting with his friends as they illegally painted their names on the Mtro and on roofs in Paris. In 2011 he won a TED Prize, given annually to a person with a bold vision to prompt global change. The result was the Inside Out Project, which challenged residents of often perilous and politically unstable environments to generate their own photographic messages  no logos or hate messages allowed  and send them to him. J R then printed giant images of the photographs and returned them to their creators, to be pasted up in a place with meaning. This documentary, directed by Alastair Siddons, follows J R as he travels the world to motivate communities to define their most important causes. More than 130,000 people have pasted messages in some 10,000 places in 100 countries, including Brazil, Tunisia, Pakistan, Mexico, South Africa, Thailand, France and the United States. The exhibitions are documented at insideoutproject.net.

title: Deciding the Future of the Arctic
description: THE HAGUE  One only need study the history of the Northwest Passage  the formerly consistently frozen channel north of North America  to better understand the effects of global warming on the Arctic.

title: Corrections: May 20, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Wigan Lingers at the Exit Door
description: Wigan Athletic played its final game in Englands Premier League on Sunday. Wigan, which won the F.A. Cup this season, was relegated to the second-tier League Championship.

title: Cadmium Rice Is Chinas Latest Food Scandal
description: BEIJING  Cadmium rice, as its dubbed, or rice laced with levels of the metal cadmium that exceed national safety standards, has become the latest food scare in China, sparking a health and P.R. scandal in a nation long used to  and deeply worried about  unsafe food.

title: William M. Fine, Who Helped Shape Drug Laws, Dies at 86
description: William M. Fine, a former magazine publisher and retailer whose research for Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller helped shape New York States stringent narcotics laws, died on Friday in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 86.

title: J. Hyde Crawford, Fashion Illustrator, Dies at 82
description: J. Hyde Crawford, a fashion illustrator who drew countless newspaper advertisements of women wearing high-end clothing, but who may have left his most memorable image on the mundane but must-have accessory known as the shopping bag, died on May 11 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 82.

title: News Quiz | May 20, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: India Arrives at the Arctic
description: NEW DELHI India was recently inducted as a permanent observer in the Arctic Council, whose permanent members include the United States, Canada, Sweden, Norway, Russia, Denmark, Finland and Iceland. The other new observers include China, Singapore, South Korea, Japan and Italy, marking the first time that the Arctic Council has inducted observers from Asia.

title: A Prince Charming Moment
description: Dear Diary:

title: Japanese Government More Optimistic on Recovery
description: HONG KONG  The Japanese government struck a more confident note on the economys prospects Monday, and a survey showed that manufacturing sentiment had turned positive for the first time in a year  the latest sign that Prime Minister Shinzo Abes policies were taking hold.

title: Test Yourself | Math, May 20, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article 17 Years to Hatch an Invasion.

title: Do You Wish You Could Return to Moments From Your Past?
description: Nostalgia is a sentimental yearning for how things used to be or how they were for a brief moment.

title: IHT Quick Read: May 20
description: NEWS Prime Minister David Camerons leadership came under growing criticism in Britain on Sunday, with a senior former minister asserting that Mr. Cameron had lost control of his party over European policy, and a Cameron ally reportedly describing local activists as swivel-eyed loons. Stephen Castle reports from London.

title: North Korea Launches Missiles for 3rd Straight Day
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea launched two short-range projectiles into waters off its east coast for a third straight day on Monday, officials here said, despite warnings from the United States and South Korea against increasing tensions.

title: A Glimpse Into the History of Slavery
description: In the article Haunting Relic of History, Slave Cabin Gets a Museum Home in Washington, Robbie Brown writes about the process of bringing this artifact to the Smithsonian Institution.

title: North Korea Releases Chinese Fishing Crew
description: HONG KONG  North Korea has released a Chinese fishing boat and its crew, ending a dispute that threatened to exacerbate strains with China, according to Chinese news reports on Tuesday.

title: Bombing Kills Key Figure in Northern Afghan Province
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber disguised as a police officer killed 14 people on Monday, including the head of a provincial council in northern Afghanistan, officials said.

title: College Plans Always Work Out, Even When They Dont
description: Its hard to think back to my life eight months ago, when I started writing this blog, and really comprehend everything thats happened to me. I think, in large part, thats because if you had told the Will Walker from the summer of 2012 that his life was going to be this good, he wouldnt have believed you.

title: R.B.S. Appoints New Chairman for Asia
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland announced a new chairman for Asia on Monday, in the latest high-level executive change at the bank.

title: Daily Report: Yahoos Deal for Tumblr
description: The board of Yahoo, the faded Web pioneer, agreed on Sunday to buy the popular blogging service Tumblr for about $1.1 billion in cash, people with direct knowledge of the matter said, a signal of how the company plans to reposition itself as the technology industry makes a headlong rush into social media, The New York Times reports in Mondays editions.

title: Attacks in Iraqi Cities Raise Fears of Renewed Sectarian Conflict
description: BAGHDAD  A wave of car bombings and shootings hit cities in Iraq late Sunday and on Monday, killing at least 76 people and wounding more than 250, medical and security officials said. Some news agency reports put the overall toll even higher, at 86 or more dead.

title: Storm in a Dipping Bowl Over Europes Olive Oil Rule
description: LONDON  Even the most fervent supporters of the European Union would acknowledge that its bureaucrats occasionally display an unrivaled talent for shooting themselves in the foot.

title: Skullcandy Cuts the Cord, and Offers Better Sound
description: Completing its move into the realm of gaming headsets, Skullcandy last week released the flagship product, the Plyr1, in its new audio line.

title: Revisiting the Crack Babies Epidemic That Was Not
description: This weeks Retro Report video on crack babies (infants born to addicted mothers) lays out how limited scientific studies in the 1980s led to predictions that a generation of children would be damaged for life. Those predictions turned out to be wrong. This supposed epidemic  one television reporter talks of a 500 percent increase in damaged babies  was kicked off by a study of just 23 infants that the lead researcher now says was blown out of proportion. And the shocking symptoms  like tremors and low birth weight  are not particular to cocaine-exposed babies, pediatric researchers say; they can be seen in many premature newborns.

title: Crack Babies: A Tale From the Drug Wars
description: Retro Report: In the 1980s, many government officials, scientists and journalists warned that the country would be plagued by a generation of crack babies. They were wrong.

title: Musharraf Granted Bail in the Killing of Bhutto
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  After weeks of legal setbacks, Pakistans former military ruler, Pervez Musharraf, won a small victory on Monday amid media speculation that the military is seeking to free the former army chief from a tangle of court cases.

title: Blood
description: The series is featuring occasional works of fiction. This is one.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Michael Pollan on Why Bacteria Arent the Enemy
description: Michael Pollan, food author, activist and journalism professor, wrote this weeks cover story about the organisms with which we share our bodies  and how were dependent on them. His book Cooked: A Natural History of Transformation came out last month. His last article for the magazine was about Californias Proposition 37, which proposed that genetically modified foods carry a label.

title: This Week in Small Business: Gordon Ramsay Calling!
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.
