description: Christian Borle, a Tony winner for Peter and the Starcatcher, and Shuler Hensley, who this spring has picked up several  prizes for playing the title role in Off Broadways The Whale, are among the performers announced on Tuesday for the new season of City Centers long-running Encores! revival series.

title: Music Awards Worthy of a Tony
description: The Billboard Music Awards dont have the following of the Grammys or even the American Music Awards, but as Sunday nights show demonstrated, they certainly hold their own in terms of drama. The actual performances were easily upstaged by a seemingly well-lubricated Kid Rock complaining about lip-syncing (an obvious dig at Selena Gomezs enthusiastically danced but suspiciously perfect rendition of Come and Get It); Ms. Gomez giving her on-and-off boyfriend Justin Bieber the evil eye as he collected one of his two awards, then gleefully embracing her BFF Taylor Swift when Ms. Swift beat him out for Top Artist, and then Mr. Bieber apparently near tears when he approached the stage to accept the fan-voted Milestone Award as a good portion of the room loudly booed him. The last even prompted a bewildered Tweet from a famous ex-football player.

title: African-Americans See Debt Reduction as Top Priority
description: Paying down debt is the top financial priority for African-Americans, who have higher levels of debt  particularly, student loan debt  than the general population, a biennial survey from Prudential Financial finds.

title: A Concert 17 Years in the Making
description: Plenty of people are getting itchy over the impending cicada emergence, which will soon bring a deluge of noisy, affection-starved insects predicted to number in the billions  yes, billions  out of the ground during the coming weeks as part of a 17-year gestation cycle. But for the composer, jazz improviser, author and philosopher David Rothenberg, all the buzz about the cicadapocalypse is music to his ears  and timely promotion for his new book and CD.

title: Wall Street Advocacy Group Turns to Former Lawmakers
description: Wall Streets top advocacy group is finally getting with the program.

title: Metro-North to Resume Full Service
description: Full service for both the Metro-North Railroad and Amtrak is expected to return on Wednesday morning to the area affected by the train collision near Fairfield, Conn., but to the surprise of some riders, limited operations between Midtown Manhattan and New Haven resumed on Tuesday afternoon.

title: Irregularities Suspected at Hong Kong Mercantile Exchange
description: 4:01 p.m. | Updated

title: Image of the Day: May 21
Senators Rookies, Pressed Into Action, Prove Much More Than Fill-Ins
description: OTTAWA  When the Ottawa Senators last made it to the Stanley Cup finals in 2007, Jean-Gabriel Pageau was 14. Now Pageau, an Ottawa native, is part of a group of Senators rookies having an impact on Canadas lone team remaining in the 2013 playoffs.

title: U.S. Quietly Monitors Foreigners Departures at the Canadian Border
description: WASHINGTON  Hundreds of thousands of foreigners passing into Canada from the United States have unwittingly been a part of a grand experiment by the Department of Homeland Security to crack down on visitors who violate laws governing the length of their stay.

title: Aide Charged With Abuse of Power in Georgia
description: MOSCOW  The Georgian authorities charged one of President Mikheil Saakashvilis top political partners with embezzlement and abuse of power on Tuesday, in the new governments most decisive move yet against Mr. Saakashvilis pro-Western team, which came to power in the 2003 Rose Revolution and dominated Georgian politics for nine years.

title: Disarming Senators, Apple Chief Eases Tax Tensions
description: WASHINGTON  Timothy Cook came to the lions den on Capitol Hill on Tuesday, prepared to face down lawmakers furious over evidence that Apple, the famous company he runs, had avoided paying billions in taxes. By the time Mr. Cook walked out, the big cats on a Senate committee were practically eating out of his hand.

title: Israel Extends Zone for Fishing Off Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  Israel said Tuesday that it would permit Palestinians to fish up to six nautical miles off the Gaza coast, canceling the limit of three nautical miles that was imposed after Gaza militants fired rockets into Israel in March.

title: Immigration Bill in the Home Stretch
description: The Senate Judiciary Committees markup of the comprehensive immigration bill, S.744, resumes at 2:30 this afternoon with only 20 amendments left to consider. For the Congress That Never Does Anything, this is a remarkable accomplishment. In five long sessions spread over three weeks, the committee has steadily plowed through dozens upon dozens of amendments, rejecting many of the worst ones and adopting some of the best.

title: A $2,400 Fine for an Airbnb Host
description: Back in December, I wrote a column about Nigel Warren, who was facing the prospect of thousands of dollars in fines from New York City for renting his room in a two-bedroom apartment out on Airbnb. A city inspector believed he was breaking the law, but the city ended up dismissing the charges right before the column appeared.

title: Jessica Biel Goes Mod at Cannes
description: The Girl: The actress with her husband, Justin Timberlake, leaving Le Grand Journal studio in Cannes, France.

title: Former President of Iran Disqualified From Race to Succeed Ahmadinejad, State TV Says
description: Last Updated, 4:40 p.m. Irans state television announced Tuesday that Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a two-term former president who called for greater freedom during protests in 2009, had been barred from running in next months election to succeed President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad. BBC News reports that the list of approved candidates presented by the state broadcaster also did not include the name of Esfandiar Rahim Mashaei, Mr. Ahmadinejads handpicked successor.

title: Bike-Share System for New York Is Built With Ideas From Around the World
description: There is a hopeful prediction, kicking around in cycling circles as New York Citys bike-share program nears its introduction to a skeptical public: Soon enough, the thinking goes, the scheme will prove so popular that New Yorkers will insist they invented it.

title: Right-Wing Writer Kills Himself in Notre-Dame Cathedral
description: PARIS  An essayist popular among French nationalists and on the political far right killed himself near the altar of the Cathedral of Notre-Dame here on Tuesday afternoon, authorities said.

title: Bring Back Ken Starr
description: Republicans are howling for President Obama to name a special prosecutor to investigate the Internal Revenue Services targeting of Tea Party groups. The president should call their bluff.

title: The Still Life Tradition in Pop Art
description: Acquavella Galleries

title: A Meteorologists View of the Tornado
description: A conversation with Jeff Masters, the director of meteorology at Weather Underground, about why tornadoes often hit central Oklahoma.

title: A Tornado, a Tragedy and an Ordinary Day
description: For me, its an ordinary day. Busy. Some things will go right, some things wrong. A child will have a tantrum, or at least a pout. Well be late getting somewhere. Im waiting for the plumber; my washer has a leak. Stuff like that.

title: 49ers and Texans Win Bidding for Super Bowls
description: With unusual unanimity and speed, N.F.L. owners awarded the 50th Super Bowl to the San Francisco area on Tuesday and gave the 51st to Houston, shutting out Miami and sending a message to the city about the need for stadium renovations before the leagues showcase game returns.

title: Wheelies: The Joint-Venture Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Living in | Carmel, N.Y.
description: A 60-mile commute to New York City comes with more modestly priced housing.

title: A Quiet Hamlet, Loyally Defended
description: The hamlet of Carmel in Putnam County, N.Y., its broad vistas unscathed by suburban sprawl that has taken its toll elsewhere, attracts homeowners seeking a refuge from the hassles of city life and the burdensome costs of owning a home closer to Manhattan.

title: How Would You Like Your Drink?
description: Which twist of fruit brings out the best in a gin and tonic  lime or lemon? We sounded out eight gin experts on the subject.

title: Pathways to America: Teaching About Immigration Changes
description: Overview | After years of debate and false starts, the United States Senate and House of Representatives stand on the verge of a comprehensive overhaul of Americas immigration laws. But are legislators taking the right approach?

title: Married to the Marines
description: When I graduated from college, I planned on being the next Diane Sawyer. My hubris took me to a small television station down south where I was a general assignment reporter until one day when the military reporter, Mark Dent, up and quit. I volunteered to fill in. That was 1997, long before The Longest War began.

title: Cannes Film Festival: James Franco on Adapting Novels and Multitasking
description: CANNES, France  In a tailored Gucci suit and a scruffy short beard, James Franco was sitting on a dock behind the Grand Palais of the Cannes Film Festival, his mirrored aviator sunglasses reflecting the yachts nearby. Photographers were setting up lighting rigs for consecutive five-minute photo shoots, for which he would smile gamely, shrug and move on.

title: Fallen Goldman Director Appeals for a New Trial
description: 8:28 p.m. | Updated

title: ESPN, Despite Growth, Is Cutting 300 to 400 Jobs
description: ESPN is cutting 300 to 400 jobs through layoffs and by leaving positions unfilled. The reductions are small in a company with more than 6,500 employees but surprising because ESPN is such a robust part of the Walt Disney Company.

title: 4 Arrested in Attack on Georgia Gay Rights Demonstration
description: MOSCOW  Georgian police have arrested four men who took part in a mob attack on a gay rights demonstration in Tbilisi that injured dozens, the Georgian Interior ministry announced Tuesday.

title: Steven Sebrings Fourth-Dimensional Perspective
description: Its dope, isnt it? asked Steven Sebring in his Lower Manhattan studio. He was gazing at what he calls the Rig, a 10.5-by-15-foot igloo-like silver contraption (or geodome) designed to capture the form and movement of the subject standing inside from every imaginable angle. Sebring, a fashion photographer and award-winning filmmaker, used the device to create Revolution, a three-year effort on display for three days at the 69th Regiment Armory. The multimedia exhibition pays simultaneous tribute to the 19th-century English photographer Eadweard Muybridge and to Marcel Duchamp, whose abstract classic Nude Descending a Staircase, No. 2 drew inspiration from Muybridges pioneering stop-motion imagery. The device contains 100 synchronized cameras that shoot in predetermined sequences, allowing Sebring to capture form and movement from numerous perspectives simultaneously  for example, his muse, Coco Rocha, spinning and dancing (as seen in Discovery, the first clip above). He can then present the results in numerous forms, including film, photographs and sculpture.

title: The Beatrice Inn
description: Inside the West Village restaurant where the thing to do is to look and listen.

title: New Drug May Help Some Asthmatics, Study Finds
description: A new asthma drug being developed by Sanofi and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals may help patients whose condition is not well controlled by existing medicines, according to the results of a small clinical trial released Tuesday.

title: On Suicide, Does Density Disprove Durkheim?
description: Responding to my Sunday column, Nate Cohn of the New Republic dismisses the idea that theres any link between the recent rise in middle-aged suicide rates and the attenuation of various forms of social and economic belonging from marriage to churchgoing to stable employment. Rather, he argues, the only definite driver of suicide rates seems to be population density:

title: Kids (and Teachers) in Peril, From Oklahoma to Oregon
description: What is it in human nature that leads to children dying in collapsed schools in the face of predicted, even inevitable, disasters?

title: Next Xbox Will Face New Array of Rivals
description: REDMOND, Wash.  Microsoft is betting it has a new way to win the wallets of consumers.

title: Dimons Pyrrhic Victory
description: The Pyrrhic victory Tuesday for Jamie Dimon is a defeat for corporate governance.

title: Depardieu, Newly a Russian, Will Play Frenchman in Chechnya
description: MOSCOW  Grard Depardieu may have renounced his French nationality as a protest against high taxes and became a citizen of Russia instead, but on Tuesday he said he would play a Frenchman in a movie to be filmed in Moscow and in Grozny, the capital of Chechnya.

title: Gin, Tonic and a Dash of Restraint
description: Sipping a good gin and tonic is like finding a 20th-century oxford shirt in the closet and realizing that you can still wear it downtown tonight without looking out of step with the century were stuck in.

title: The New Flickr Is Pretty, but Is It Social?
description: On Monday, just a few hours after Yahoo officially announced it hadpurchasedTumblr for $1.1 billion, the companyunveiled a newversion of Flickr, a photo-sharing Web site.

title: Giving the Second Ingredient Its Due
description: The major components of a gin and tonic are right in the name of the cocktail. Though tonic is clearly secondary, it cannot be ignored or waved in the vague direction of the spirit, as some bartenders do with vermouth when making a martini. Tonics flavors are assertive, easily discernible and crucial to the composition. Without it, a gin and tonic is simply a bad martini.

title: The Gin and Tonic Revival
description: This is a fine time to be a G&T drinker  especially in New York.

title: Brokerage Firm to Pay $7.5 Million Fine to Regulators
description: 7:26 p.m. | Updated

title: Jessica Walter on the Return of Arrested Development
description: This week were talking to members of the cast of Arrested Development, leading up to the return of the series, on Netflix, on Sunday. Previously we spoke with Jason Bateman and Jeffrey Tambor. An interview with Will Arnett will appear on Wednesday.

title: Argentines Win the 2013 Mille Miglia
description: BRESCIA, Italy  A sky-blue 1927 Bugatti T40, driven by Juan Tonconogy of Argentina, on Saturday won the 2013 edition of the Mille Miglia Storica. Mr. Tonconogy, and his co-driver, Guillermo Berisso, arrived at the finish line shortly after 10 p.m. in the re-enactment of the famed Italian road rally. They had left the start line here at 7 p.m. on Thursday, embarking along with 415 competitors on a 1,000-mile odyssey to Rome and back, through 196 cities on the Italian peninsula.

title: Feeling Supersonic: Give Me Gin and Tonic
description: http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_detailpage&v=p29MG7wn4F8

title: A Pearl Buck Novel, New After 4 Decades
description: Forty years after being written, an unpublished novel by Pearl S. Buck, the Nobel laureate and Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist, will be released this fall, her publisher said on Tuesday.

title: A Tornado-Prone Areas Latest Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Vegetarian in Tapas-Happy Barcelona
description: Im not a vegetarian, but I play one in this column.

title: Restaurant Report: Bubbledogs in London
description: Londons restaurant scene can seem awash with culinary redundancies. How many more ramen soup bars can the city really support? Do we really need another Peruvian restaurant with a bespoke pisco bar? So its a delight when clever culinary novelty hits town. To wit: Bubbledogs, a restaurant opened last August that revels in its Champagne selection, but substitutes hot dogs for caviar on its menu.

title: Hotel Review: Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles
description: Rates

title: The View From West 12th
description: If we have a shred of sanity left, those of us who never stop thinking about what were eating have to wish that once in a while we could turn back the clock. We start to miss the days when you could go out to dinner without all the food talk: the have you been there yet? interrogations, the name-dropping of pop-up ramen stands and celebrity milkweed foragers, the tableside decipherings of what is on your plate, moving counterclockwise from the cod milt gelatin resting in a pickled starlings nest.

title: Front Burner
description: To Indulge: Parade of Treats for the Summer

title: Dense and Organic, a Sum of Many Parts
description: Green Garden, the young British singer Laura Mvulas most popular song, is a fleet track, built by adding one percussion part at a time underneath Ms. Mvulas smooth, emphatic, optimistic vocals, which are quickly complemented by dense, intricate harmonies that sometimes come out straight, and sometimes through a digital filter.

title: Rival Says Promotion of Quinn Memoir Is Political Spending
description: When Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker and currently the front-running candidate for mayor, signed a deal to write a memoir that would be published in the lead-up to the primary election this year, it seemed like a fairly ingenious move. The book, and any attendant publicity, would allow her to get her personal story, including the way she coped with her mothers death when Ms. Quinn was 16 and her later struggle to come to terms with her homosexuality, in front of potential voters at a critical moment in the election cycle.

title: Cheekily Hopscotching Across Genres
description: Funny how the substitution of a single pronoun  I for you  can transform a Broadway standard into a whimsical joke. That trick was effected by Laura Benanti on Monday evening at 54 Below, where her revised version of On the Street Where You Live became a comic ode to West 54th Street, where she grew up, not far from the club in which she was performing. Being a Broadway baby, even in Manhattan, she recalled, she felt estranged from her peers in matters of musical taste.

title: Off the Menu
description: Headliner

title: The Rubble of Berlin Reverberates in the Rubble of Detroit
description: Last week I happened to make three interrelated discoveries:

title: Pictures of the Day: Oklahoma and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Oklahoma, Gaza, Somalia and Kashmir.

title: An Honor for the Creator of the GIF
description: Among the thousands of file formats that exist in modern computing, the GIF, or Graphics Interchange Format, has attained celebrity status in a sea of lesser-known BMPs, RIPs, FIGs and MIFFs. It was honored as a word of the year in 2012, and Tuesday night, its inventor, Steve Wilhite, will be accepting a lifetime achievement award at The Webby Awards.

title: Imagining a Past That Isnt His Own
description: Bill Chengs first novel, Southern Cross the Dog, is dedicated to a long list of his favorite bluesmen, from Son House and Pinetop Perkins to Muddy Waters and Blind Willie McTell.

title: Fried Rice and Noodles, and More Than a Dollop of Drama
description: Plan your evening carefully if you choose to see The Golden Dragon, a play by the acclaimed German writer Roland Schimmelpfennig being presented by the Play Company at the New Ohio Theater. Heres a suggestion: should you eat before, avoid Chinese. Also Thai. And Vietnamese.

title: On View | Steven Sebrings Revolution
description: Sebrings film, which pays tribute to the 19th-century English photographer Eadweard Muybridge, and to painter Marcel Duchamp, goes on display for three days at the 69th Street Regiment Armory.

title: Latest Quincy Jones Hyphenate? Manager
description: Normally, it would have been a valedictory moment.

title: Revisiting a Breakthrough With Roots in the Disco Floor
description: A packed dance floor was the appropriate greeting for the pioneering producer Giorgio Moroder, 73, on Monday night at the Brooklyn club Output. Billed as Mr. Moroders first live disc-jockey set, it was part of the monthlong Red Bull Music Academy series, which is drawing connections between the past and present of dance music, hip-hop, electronic music and experimental rock.

title: How to Clean a Soft-Shell Crab
description: You may have a nice fishmonger who will clean your soft-shell crabs for you, a reasonable thing for a shopper to request. But if youre not squeamish, its easy to do at home before preparing them for cooking, as I do in my column this week. Its a simple a process of removing the gills and the apron, and snipping off the eyes and mouth, similar to cleaning a fish.

title: After the Tornado, a War Zone
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  THIS morning, the day after a monster tornado ripped through Moore, Okla., there was a moment between sleep and clear waking, when it was possible to forget what had happened and what lay ahead. But then we remembered. People we love are still missing. Our children are trapped.

title: Rescue Team at a Beach Tries to Save the Summer
description: All along the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens, where Hurricane Sandy had laid waste, workers and officials are rushing to restore beaches in time for Memorial Day weekend. But while Rockaway Beach and Jacob Riis Park are slated to reopen for swimming on Saturday, one of the peninsulas most remote  and, lately, most beloved  beaches will remain closed.

title: Manga, Blood-Red, in Three Dimensions
description: The first thing you notice about Fred Ho and Ruth Margraffs Deadly She-Wolf Assassin at Armageddon!, now at La MaMa, is the elegant simplicity of the set, created by Anka Lupes and augmented by Chad McArvers gentle lighting. A long stripe of fluorescent red, ornamented with shapes suggesting carvings on a sword hilt, crosses the floor; overhead, taut red lines of rope intersect, like laser beams in darkness. Red also predominates in the gorgeous costumes (also by Ms. Lupes)  red, and black, and leather. This meeting of cool design with blood-red passion drives this martial arts tale, which touches familiar bases yet feels fresh, dynamic and fully realized.

title: Bellini: Prosecco and Peach Pure
description: A quick crowd-pleaser that brings ripe summer peaches together with sparkling wine.

title: Obama Announces Members of Election Commission
description: After tapping two of the nations pre-eminent election lawyers to lead an effort to study the way Americans vote, President Obama on Tuesday announced his intention to appoint eight additional members to a presidential commission designed to improve the electoral process after voters faced long lines and other obstacles in last years elections.

title: A Keynesian Victory, but Austerity Stands Firm
description: To go by the statements of most mainstream economists, one would be forgiven for believing this is the best of times for Keynesian economics.

title: Gin and Tonic, With Kumquat and Clove
description: The addition of kumquats and cloves puts a satisfying twist on a favorite summer classic.

title: Perma-Stimulus, Again
description: Jonathan Chait tells me that the new anti-Keynesian paladin is James Buchanan, who supposedly showed that stimulus, however worthy, can never be reversed. The elevation of Buchanan comes from Charles Lane at the Washington Post, who name-checks me as one of those naive Keynesians who doesnt get it (and misuses the in the long run we are all dead line to boot).

title: Send Us Your Questions About Drones
description: 12:03 p.m. | Updated  Answers from Mark Mazzetti, Eric Schmitt and Scott Shane have been posted.

title: Hotshots of Street Basketball
description: A labor of hoophead love by Bobbito Garcia and Kevin Couliau, Doin It in the Park: Pick-Up Basketball, NYC is a survey of New Yorks outdoor courts and the players who live on them.

title: Nursing Home or Frat House?
description: Its not clear whether 3 Geezers! is trying to celebrate people of advanced age or mock them, but it doesnt really matter. Either way, this is one terrible movie.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Spherical Amazon and Teenage Exodus
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: White House Says Journalists Should Not Be Subject to Criminal Action in Leak Cases
description: The White House said on Tuesday that it did not think the Justice Department should threaten criminal action against journalists who report on sensitive national security matters, distancing itself from a recent case in which a television correspondent was targeted as a possible co-conspirator in a leak investigation.

title: Finding the Economic Roots of Apples Taxable Product
description: The hearing by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations on Tuesday focused on Apples shifting of offshore profits. Apples tax planning stems from an almost metaphysical issue: What is the value of an iPhone?

title: Radio Host Finebaum Joins ESPN
description: Paul Finebaum, the radio host known for his popular college football show, has joined ESPN, The Wall Street Journal reported Tuesday. His reported start date is Aug. 1.

title: Literary Lion and a Very Good Sport
description: Plimpton!, a documentary about the journalist and editor George Plimpton, is a skilled portrait of a literary light shadowed by his public profile. The film, written and directed by Tom Bean and Luke Poling, tacitly suggests a reconsideration of its subject, who deserves it.

title: Just One Look | Resort Gets the Floral Treatment at Oscar de la Renta
description: Oscar de la Rentas Resort 2014 collection was in full bloom today, complete with rose resin-casted earrings, violet taffeta flowers and tulip-embroidered lace. A standout in the bouquet of skirts, dresses and gowns on view in the designers showroom this afternoon was the indigo floral bubble peplum cocktail dress. The look was topped off with classic sapphire crystal drop earrings, matte red lips and a low ponytail tied with a black-netted bow. The secret to this modern garden look is the butterfly brooch nestled on the lower back of the dress.

title: With His Magic Touch, Buffett May Be Irreplaceable for Berkshire
description: Acquisitions usually come with a nice premium for the seller. But when Warren E. Buffett is the buyer, there is typically something of a discount.

title: Muslims Linked to Riots Given Prison Terms in Myanmar
description: BANGKOK  A court in Myanmar sentenced seven Muslim men to prison on Tuesday on charges related to the spasms of religious violence two months ago that left more than 40 people dead and chased thousands of people from their homes in central Myanmar.

title: Austerity Wins!
description: A look at the budget deficits and economic growth of some European countries versus the United States.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,208 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Landmarks Commission Votes to Preserve  Bialystoker Building
description: The citys Landmarks Preservation Commission voted unanimously on Tuesday to preserve the Bialystoker Center for Nursing and Rehabilitation, a nine-story Art Deco building on the Lower East Side at Clinton Street and East Broadway.

title: Before and After: 360 Views From Moore, Okla.
description: Panoramic images taken Tuesday are compared with the same locations before the storm from Google Maps Street View.

title: Football and Footwear: The Burress Collection
description: The news release seemed like a punch line to an untold joke. Pittsburgh Steelers wide receiver Plaxico Burress, who spent nearly two years in prison after accidentally shooting himself in the right thigh through a pair of sweat pants while at a trendy New York nightclub, was set to host a rooftop party at, you guessed it, a trendy New York nightclub introducing his new mens luxury hosiery line.

title: Raf Simons and a New Informality
description: Chanel and Dior have certainly upped the resort/cruise game, with Karl Lagerfeld going to Singapore for a Chanel show of cricket bats and cardigans, and Raf Simons setting down in Monaco. Like most people, I looked at both collections online and I have to say I thought Mr. Simonss Dior collection was fascinating.

title: Murray Withdraws From French Open
description: PARIS  The Big Four is still alive and well as a tennis concept, but bringing Novak Djokovic, Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal and Andy Murray together in the same Grand Slam tournament is proving increasingly elusive.

title: Bouquets for January (Its Called Resort)
description: The far-flung, long-winded resort collections have begun, and nobody seems too thrilled about it, least of all Oscar de la Renta.

title: Folk Remedy Extracted From Captive Bears Stirs Furor in China
description: CHENGDU, China  It was, at first glance, a rather modest initial public offering by a small Chinese company seeking to expand production of the key ingredient used in traditional remedies said to shrink gallstones, reduce fevers and sooth the aftereffects of excessive drinking.

title: Bruce S. Fowle
description: Mr. Fowle, 75, is the founding principal of FXFowle Architects. The firm, which was started in New York as Fox & Fowle Architects in 1978, has designed many projects throughout the city, including Three and Four Times Square and The New York Times Building. Mr. Fowle is working on the expansion and renovation of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: A Fight Against Milking Bears for Bile
description: The use of bear bile for traditional Chinese medicine cures is a growing industry in China, but it is also increasingly controversial thanks to an escalating animal rights movement.

title: Hefner Looks for Ways to Help His Old Hometown in Oklahoma
description: With the full extent of damage from a tornado that tore through the Oklahoma City area on Monday still being assessed, Mets pitcher Jeremy Hefner was considering ways to aid his old hometown.

title: To de Blasio, City Hall Shouldnt Be All About Manhattan
description: Bill de Blasio drives a gas-sipping Ford hybrid and cultivates tomatoes and peppers from his backyard in brownstone Brooklyn.

title: The Rise  and Decline  of the Drones
description: The pace of United States airstrikes in Yemen and especially Pakistan has slowed. The strikes in Pakistan are all believed to have been carried out by drones; those in Yemen have sometimes used jets or cruise missiles in addition to drones.

title: Rice Tainted With Cadmium Is Discovered in Southern China
description: HONG KONG  Government officials in southern China sought on Wednesday to calm public ire about toxic substances menacing the regions main food staple, rice, after the city of Guangzhou said that nearly half the rice tested at restaurants this year held excessive cadmium, a heavy metal that can cause cancer and other illnesses.

title: Project in Paris Reflects Citys Ambitions for the Suburbs
description: PARIS  The Paris of grand monuments, stately boulevards and haute cuisine is justly famous. But the city is also the hub of the worlds fifth-largest economy, with more than two million people grappling with 21st-century problems of global competitiveness, immigration and assimilation, and a chronic shortage of affordable housing.

title: A Magnet for Shoppers Is Getting a Makeover
description: Mitra Suleiman drives seven hours to Central Valley, N.Y., from her home in Ottawa, Canada, every year in search of a bargain.

title: In Europe, a Fed President Urges Quantitative Easing
description: FRANKFURT  A top official of the Federal Reserve on Tuesday urged the European Central Bank to take more aggressive action to restart growth, warning that the euro area risked becoming mired in the same kind of economic stagnation that has plagued Japan for two decades, with far-reaching implications for the global economy.

title: Maryland: One Less Charge in Wikileaks Case
description: The government on Tuesday dropped one charge against Pfc. Bradley Manning, the confessed source of vast archives of government documents made public through WikiLeaks, as pretrial hearings wrapped up. The trial begins June 3. The judge said prosecutors had decided not to pursue the charge that Private Manning, 25, had leaked a classified State Department cable in February 2010 knowing it could harm the United States. A military legal spokesman said prosecutors told the court Tuesday that they had accepted Private Mannings plea to the lesser offense of leaking the cable. A conviction would have added eight years to his sentence. In February, Private Manning confessed to providing about 700,000 documents to WikiLeaks, pleading guilty to several charges carrying a penalty of up to 20 years in prison in a bid for leniency. But prosecutors decided to pursue more serious charges, which could result in life without parole.

title: Miami Workers Bribed, and Shortchanged, Venezuelan Banker, U.S. Says
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  There may be no honor among thieves, but there certainly is no shortage of chutzpah.

title: Strapped Knicks Stress Continuity, Not Change
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Twelve months from now, the Knicks hope to be playing in the Eastern Conference finals, competing for the right to win a championship, with a roster nearly identical to the one that just collapsed in the second round.

title: One Response to Apple Tax Strategy May Be to Copy It
description: The image of the American income tax law is of horrible and immense complexity.

title: Exploring the Business of Horse Breeding on Real Sports
description: A segment on horse breeding called Behind the Barn Door will be part of the 194th edition of Real Sports With Bryant Gumbel, which debuts Tuesday at 10 p.m. Eastern on HBO.

title: Long Putters? How About Slow Play, Drugs and Phrankenwoods?
description: The governing bodies of golf have spoken about anchored putting. Hopefully, they were just clearing their throats.

title: A Group Taking Politics and Military Strategy to the Same Extremes
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  When a militant attack devastated a busy street in Kabul last week, it was like a headline from the early days of the war: the insurgent movement Hezb-i-Islami had killed six American military advisers in a suicide bombing so powerful that it knocked a heavily armored Chevrolet Suburban yards down a crowded street.

title: Why Im Not a Vegan
description: On my recent book tour, I spoke with a number of people about my take on a positive direction for the American diet. Ive been semi-vegan for six years and in the book (called VB6, for Vegan Before 6 p.m.[1] ), I argue that this strategy, or one like it, can move us toward better health.

title: 2-Year Term for a Father Who Avoided Child Support
description: A man who fled the United States to avoid making child-support payments and was labeled the countrys most-wanted deadbeat parent by federal authorities when his unpaid support climbed above $1 million was sentenced on Tuesday to two and a half years in prison.

title: MetLife Will Repatriate an Offshore Reinsurance Unit
description: MetLife, the nations largest life insurer, said Tuesday that it would make its business more transparent by moving some deals for hedging risk back to the United States from offshore, pleasing regulators but underwhelming the stock market.

title: Bernard Waber, Childrens Author, Is Dead at 91
description: Bernard Waber, a childrens-book author and illustrator whose most famous creation was a rope-skipping, ice-skating Manhattanite named Lyle who happened to be a crocodile, died on Thursday at his home in Baldwin, N.Y. He was 91.

title: South Carolina: General Faces Adultery Investigation
description: The commander of the Armys training center at Fort Jackson, S.C., was suspended from duty Tuesday while he is investigated for adultery, Army officials announced. The officer, Brig. Gen. Bryan T. Roberts, is facing allegations of misconduct that include adultery and a physical altercation, Army officials said. They cited privacy restrictions and the requirements of the inquiry in declining to identify the woman or to describe the altercation. According to an Army biography, General Roberts was commissioned in 1983 and has served in Iraq and in Germany, at the Pentagon and in the White House Military Office. The inquiry comes as a number of senior officers have come under scrutiny for misbehavior and as the military struggles with its record on reducing sexual harassment and sexual assault.

title: A Stadium in Queens Is No Walk in the Park
description: Inserting a soccer stadium into the green lungs of Queens County is not an incursion of the Yankees into Mets territory, nor is it an invasion of the dangerously furrin sport of soccer into sacred American territory.

title: Army Tries a Reality Style for Recruitment
description: FOR decades, the Army has been portrayed in television series produced by Hollywood, among them Combat, The Gallant Men, M*A*S*H, China Beach and even The Wackiest Ship in the Army. Now, the Army is joining with the actor Ricky Schroder to produce commercials, styled like a television reality series, that are intended to help find recruits.

title: Arizona Law on Abortions Struck Down as Restrictive
description: A federal appellate panel struck down Arizonas abortion law on Tuesday, saying it was unconstitutional under a long line of invariant Supreme Court precedents that guarantee a womans right to end a pregnancy any time before a fetus is deemed viable outside her womb  generally at 24 weeks.

title: Opinion From 9th Circuit Court of Appeals
description: A federal appellate court panel struck down on Tuesday Arizonas restrictive abortion law.

title: For U.S. Companies, Money Offshore Means Manhattan
description: Like some of the nations prominent chief executives, Apples Timothy D. Cook has a simple proposal to help spur the economy and encourage corporate tax compliance: give American companies a tax break to bring to the United States untaxed profits parked overseas.

title: Chinas Brutal One-Child Policy
description: LONDON  ZHANG YIMOU, the celebrated film director and arranger of the 2008 Summer Olympics opening ceremony in Beijing, was accused last week of being the latest high-profile violator of Chinas one-child policy. The Peoples Daily, the Communist Party mouthpiece, alleged that Mr. Zhang had fathered seven children with four different women.

title: The View From an Oklahoma Basement
description: EDMOND, Okla.  IT seems I am one of the few lucky people in the Oklahoma City area to have a basement. Before the tornadoes rolled through on Sunday and Monday, I spread an old rug on the basement floor, ringed it with pillows and blankets, and deposited my 5-year-old daughter in the middle wearing a helmet, shoes and socks, long pants and long sleeves and a pair of SpongeBob shades. We brought down batteries, a radio, flashlights, a kerosene lamp and matches, bottled water, bags of almonds, dried mango, potato chips, my laptop, my phone, my Kindle. And a dozen plastic dinosaurs. My daughter is really into dinosaurs. My husband spent the two days dashing up and down the stairs, unwilling to turn off the live coverage on the big screen.

title: Tell Me How This Ends
description: SANLIURFA, Turkey  Ive been traveling to Yemen, Syria and Turkey to film a documentary on how environmental stresses contributed to the Arab awakening. As I looked back on the trip, it occurred to me that three of our main characters  the leaders of the two Yemeni villages that have been fighting over a single water well and the leader of the Free Syrian Army in Raqqa Province, whose cotton farm was wiped out by drought  have 36 children among them: 10, 10 and 16.

title: Stop-and-Frisk on Trial
description: Judge Shira Scheindlin, of Federal District Court in Manhattan, got to the heart of the problem with the New York Police Departments stop-and-frisk program on Monday, after hearing testimony for two months in the civil rights case, Floyd v. City of New York. The plaintiffs charge the department with illegally detaining hundreds of thousands of people on the streets each year not because of suspicious behavior but because of their race.

title: Another Chilling Leak Investigation
description: With the decision to label a Fox News television reporter a possible co-conspirator in a criminal investigation of a news leak, the Obama administration has moved beyond protecting government secrets to threatening fundamental freedoms of the press to gather news.

title: Sex Offender Village
description: Op-Doc | A small community known as Miracle Village, surrounded by sugar cane fields in South Florida, has become a refuge for more than 100 registered sex offenders who seek to rebuild their lives.

title: Sex Offender Village
description: For this Op-Doc video, we visited a small community in Florida known as Miracle Village, where more than 100 registered sex offenders have settled since 2009. Surrounded by sugar cane fields, the community has become a rare refuge for them as they try to rebuild their lives in one of the only communities that will have them: stringent residency requirements make it almost impossible for them to live anywhere else.

title: F.A.A.s Concerns Hold Up Use of Wildfire Drones
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As wildfire season begins in Western landscapes that were covered in smoky haze for weeks at a time last summer, the federal governments firefighters are exploring the use of small remote-controlled drones with infrared cameras that could map a fires size and speed, and identify hot spots, a particular danger.

title: Plaza Towers Elementary School
description: At least seven children died when the storm destroyed the school, which lacked safe rooms to shelter students and teachers. Some students tried to find shelter in hallways, bathrooms, and closets.

title: Genocide Trial of Guatemalan Ex-Dictator May Have to Restart
description: MEXICO CITY  A day after Guatemalas highest court threw out the genocide verdict against a former dictator, Gen. Efran Ros Montt, lawyers on both sides of the case said Tuesday that his entire trial would probably have to be repeated.

title: City Agrees to Faster Cleanup of PCBs in Schools
description: With smoke and tar from faulty light fixtures leaking into New York City public school classrooms at alarming rates, the Bloomberg administration said on Tuesday that it would cut in half the time it needed to replace them.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 22, 2013
description: "I couldnt hear anything but people screaming and crying. It felt like the school was just flying.

title: Jail for Man Refusing to Testify in Bomb Case
description: A federal judge ordered on Tuesday that a Brooklyn man be sent to jail for refusing to testify before a grand jury believed to be looking into a homemade bomb that exploded in front of an armed forces recruitment center in Times Square in 2008.

title: Staten Island Wholesale King Pleads Guilty to Bank Fraud
description: A Staten Island man who wrote $82 million in worthless checks over a two-week period as part of an ambitious fraud scheme pleaded guilty on Tuesday to several counts of bank fraud.

title: Iran and Hezbollah Support for Syria Complicates Peace-Talk Strategy
description: MUSCAT, Oman  As evidence grows of increased Iranian support for the Syrian government, the Obama administrations strategy to bring the bitter fighting there to a close faces more challenges than ever.

title: Bronx Officer Is Accused of Hiring E-Mail Hackers
description: It was the sort of discovery that is usually the mark of good police work: A Bronx detective came upon an online criminal enterprise that offered  for a low price  to hack into private e-mail accounts.

title: A Well-Honed Disaster Response Network Activates New Yorkers
description: Michael Kenny started his Tuesday in the Bronx, his usual workplace, but he was packed and ready for the road. He had been for the entire month. By early afternoon, he was in Dallas, the first leg of a trip to Oklahoma City and its suburbs.

title: City Executive Always Had Eyes on the U.S.
description: Ferran Soriano, the Manchester City executive who was instrumental in the Premier League clubs decision to become part of Major League Soccer, has long viewed the United States as fertile ground for soccer.

title: Serving Up Schlock
description: Networks are generally leery of shows that are set in the past.

title: Transactions
description: Recent Sale

title: A Sleeper Scandal Awakens for Obama, Post-Election
description: WASHINGTON  The allegations had all the makings of a perfect election-year scandal that might threaten President Obamas chances for a second term and re-energize a listless Tea Party movement: an activist president, running an overbearing government, treating conservative groups unfairly by wielding the federal taxing power to undermine his adversaries.

title: Corrections: May 22, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Prison Was Awful, but He Likes the Video Version
description: BEIJING  When the rebel artist Ai Weiwei was illegally detained in 2011, he recounts, his young paramilitary guards asked him to sing for them. He belted out decades-old Communist revolutionary tunes, and they were stunned that he knew them, he said.

title: An Imperfect Immigration Bill Survives
description: The bipartisan immigration bill that passed the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday has many serious hurdles ahead. It is the most serious and worthy attempt to fix immigration in a generation, but it cannot help reflecting the poisoned politics of today, with its heavy tilt toward needless border enforcement and a deficiency in equal rights.

title: Where K-I-S-S-I-N-G Occurs
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Todays theme reminds me of the classic headline from a 1935 issue of Variety magazine Sticks Nix Hick Pix, which topped an article about the incorrect assumption of the film industry that rural people wanted to see movies that depicted low-income, rural life. At that time, it seems, everyone wanted the escapist fun that could be found in the merrier depictions of the upper class.

title: As Chinese Leaders Visit Nears, U.S. Is Urged to Allow Counterattacks on Hackers
description: WASHINGTON  With President Obama preparing for a first meeting with Chinas new president, a commission led by two former senior officials in his administration will recommend a series of steps that could significantly raise the cost to China of the theft of American industrial secrets. If milder measures failed, the commission said, the United States should consider giving companies the right to retaliate against cyberattackers with counterstrikes of their own.

title: Tornadoes: What We Know
description: The Timess Henry Fountain explains why scientists deemed the tornado Oklahoma an EF5 and why these fast-moving storms can cause so much damage.

title: Chicago School Closings May Leave Some Communities Without Old Lifelines
description: CHICAGO  Long after the last school bell scatters children back across this city each day, Tzia Ford is more often than not still inside Mary McLeod Bethune Elementary School.

title: A Rarity: a New Yankee the Yankees Developed
description: BALTIMORE  David Adams was preparing for a road trip with his teammates at Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre a couple of weeks ago when he was made aware of several news reports speculating that he might be called up by the Yankees. Adams, a versatile infielder, decided to squeeze a few extra items in his suitcase, just in case.

The Trauma of Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Weak on Food Inspection
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Student, 18, Arrested for Sex with Teammate, 14
description: MIAMI  Kaitlyn Hunts parents insist that their daughter, a Central Florida high school senior, is being prosecuted for sex crimes only because her lover was another girl. The state attorney says that gender makes no difference; the age of the two girls is at the crux of the case.

title: Debate Aside, Number of Drone Strikes Drops Sharply
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama embraced drone strikes in his first term, and the targeted killing of suspected terrorists has come to define his presidency.

title: Boos Outnumber Hits as the Mets Lose Again
description: The Citi Field crowd made its presence felt at precisely two moments Tuesday during the Mets 4-0 loss to the Cincinnati Reds.

title: For Tea Party Groups, Shades of 2010
description: They are getting the band back together.

title: The Good Hughes Is Not Quite Good Enough
description: BALTIMORE  Phil Hughes confronted the fading memory of his last start by taking the mound Tuesday night at Camden Yards and throwing four straight fastballs. For much of his herky-jerky season, it had been a pitch with extreme results. Unhittable one start and uncontrollable the next, the Hughes fastball had been as fickle as a windblown paper airplane. It has been a painstaking quest for him to prove he can throw it and produce results.

title: Why No Safe Room to Run To? Cost and Plains Culture
description: The Web site for the City of Moore, Okla., recommends that every residence have a storm safe room or an underground cellar. It says below-ground shelters are the best protection against tornadoes.

title: Pictures of Loss in Oklahoma
description: Social media sites are quickly building lost-and-found databases of the people, pets and photos that many lost during a killer tornado that ripped through Oklahoma on Monday.

title: As Jet Stream Moved North, Moist Air Barreled Into Plains With Deadly Results
description: Until an outbreak of tornadoes in the past week, this year had been a relatively quiet one for twisters in the Midwest and Plains states.

title: Cavaliers Win N.B.A. Draft Lottery
description: Three times previously, Pat Williams had represented the Orlando Magic at the N.B.A. draft lottery with the best probability to land the No. 1 pick. Armed with various horseshoes and rabbits feet for luck, his success rate was perfect.

title: Arrest Affidavit of Kaitlyn Hunt
description: Kaitlyn Hunt, 18, was arrested in February and charged with lewd and lascivious battery. Ms. Hunt had a sexual encounter with a 14-year-old girl.

title: F.B.I. Raid Renews Focus on Ballpark Deal in Rockland
description: RAMAPO, N.Y.  When federal agents last week spent seven hours extracting documents and computer files from Town Hall here, attention immediately turned to the financing of a local ballpark. The stadium was the subject of a withering state audit last year suggesting officials inappropriately mingled private and public enterprises for a risky development.

title: Cuomo Signs Deal With Mohawks to Protect Casino Territory
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and St. Regis Mohawk tribal leaders signed an agreement on Tuesday to ensure the Mohawks keep their exclusive casino territory in northern New York while paying the state $30 million in gambling proceeds that have been withheld.

title: 2 More Antigay Attacks Are Reported in Manhattan
description: Just hours after hundreds of people held a rally in Greenwich Village to protest the killing of a gay man last week, two men were violently assaulted in separate attacks in downtown Manhattan because of their sexual orientation, New York City officials said on Tuesday.

title: Lottery Numbers
Heinrich Rohrer, Physicist, Dies at 79; Helped Open Door to Nanotechnology
description: Heinrich Rohrer, who shared the 1986 Nobel Prize in Physics for inventing a microscope that made it possible to see individual atoms and move them around, an achievement that led to vastly faster computing and greatly advanced molecular biology, died on Thursday night or early Friday morning in Wollerau, Switzerland. He was 79.

title: Aleksei Balabanov, 54, Russian Film Director, Dies
description: Aleksei Balabanov, a Russian director whose films fused grisly violence, sardonic humor and rock music to convey a darkly compelling vision of his chaotic society after Communisms collapse, died on Saturday near St. Petersburg. He was 54.

title: After Decades, Boots Are Back on Campus
description: The Great Hall of City College, a carved stone and stained glass chamber so collegiate Gothic it could be mistaken for one in Cambridge, Mass., or Cambridge, England, is crowned by a mural that enshrines scholarship as an Olympian endeavor.

title: Bruins Take Control of Game and Series
description: Everything the Rangers depended on to avoid falling to the brink of elimination failed to make a difference Tuesday night. Not home ice. Not the heroics of their Vezina Trophy finalist goaltender. Not another favorable disparity in penalty calls.

title: Many Changes to a Blue Suit
description: A look at the various versions of Supermans costume over the years.

title: With a Shot and Some Wacky Bounces, a Good Night Goes Astray for Lundqvist
description: Until the third period, the Rangers Vezina Trophy-winning goaltender Henrik Lundqvist was at his best, again.

title: Game 3: Rangers vs. Bruins
description: The Rangers 2-1 loss to the Bruins on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden left them trailing in the series, 3-0.

title: Harold Shapero, American Neo-Classical Composer, Dies at 93
description: Harold Shapero, a composer who was a central figure of American Neo-Classicism, a school of composition that thrived in the 1940s and 50s, died on May 17 in Cambridge, Mass. He was 93.

title: Scott Campbells Jailhouse Tattoo Rigs
description: Where does a true believer in tattoo culture go for inspiration? For Scott Campbell, the answer was Mexican prisons.

title: Rossi Finally Back on the Field
description: MILAN  It was suitably fitting that Giuseppe Rossi would make his eagerly anticipated return to soccer against Pescara at the Stadio Adratico. His family originally came from the relatively penurious central Italian region of Abruzzo. When Referee Andrea De Marco signaled for the striker to enter in the 64th minute as a substitute for Juan Cuadrado, the New Jersey native let out a beaming smile on the touchline.

title: Gearing Up for Anniversary, Public Library to Display Original Copy of Bill of Rights
description: The New York Public Librarys original copy of the Bill of Rights will be exhibited for the first time in decades this fall, the library is to announce on Wednesday with the state of Pennsylvania.

title: Massachusetts Employees Will Keep Their Health Plans
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: Can Statins Cut the Benefits of Exercise?
description: An important new study suggests that statins, the cholesterol-lowering medications that are the most prescribed drugs in the world, may block some of the fitness benefits of exercise, one of the surest ways to improve health.

title: Word of the Day | niggle
description: niggle \ni-gl\ verb

title: North Korean Envoy Visits Beijing Amid Concerns About U.S.-Chinese Relations
description: BEIJING  A senior North Korean military officials visit here Wednesday appears to have been organized on short notice, and was probably prompted by North Koreas concerns about a planned meeting between President Xi Jinping of China and President Obama, analysts said.

title: Tensions Flare in Asian Seas, Now Involving Taiwan
description: BEIJING  The world is growing used to reports of aggressive diplomatic and military behavior by China over ownership of the South China Sea and the East China Sea, resulting in regular standoffs mostly with Japan, Vietnam and the Philippines, some of the other claimants to disputed seas and islands there.

title: Sharks Tie Up Series With Kings
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Brent Burns helped San Jose jump off to a fast start with his second goal of the postseason and the Sharks tied their second-round series against Los Angeles at two games with a 2-1 victory over the Kings in Game 4 on Tuesday night.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 7 A.M. (USA) DUPLICITY (2009) She  Julia Roberts as the long-legged Claire, standing in a flowery dress in a garden, looking bored  is C.I.A. He  Clive Owen (above with Ms. Roberts) as Ray, on whom a suit becomes a brazenly sexy uniform  is MI6. Five years after meeting over frozen drinks at a barbecue and ending up in bed, they decide to abandon their respective governments and go to work on opposite sides of the beauty products industry, with puffed-up executives portrayed by Paul Giamatti and Tom Wilkinson. Its a caper movie, a love story, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this film, written and directed by Tony Gilroy, an extra-dry corporate satire. However you describe it, Duplicity is superior entertainment, the most elegantly pleasurable movie of its kind to come around in a very long time. At 9:30 in Notting Hill (1999) he (Hugh Grant this time) is a bashful London bookstore owner whos not quite sure hes ready to reopen his wounded heart for business. She (Ms. Roberts again) is a Hollywood diva  but also, as she says, just a girl, standing in front of a boy, asking him to love her. You know the rest. The movie has lots of glossy charm, Janet Maslin wrote in The Times, even if Ms. Roberts and Mr. Grant seem less like lovers than members of a support group for the desperately attractive.

title: Japan Keeps Monetary Policy Steady Amid Deflation Fight
description: TOKYO  The Bank of Japan stood pat on monetary policy Wednesday amid market anxiety over volatility in bond markets, which has threatened to undermine the countrys battle to end deflation and stimulate growth in the giant economy.

title: News Quiz | May 22, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Kashmir Pressing Delhi for Aid for Quake-Hit Victims
description: NEW DELHI After an earthquake in Jammu and Kashmir state on May 1 left thousands of people homeless and caused 6 billion rupees in infrastructure damage, state officials said Tuesday that they are petitioning the central government for a special relief package.

title: Joining Race for Mayor, Weiner Finds Few Allies
description: It may be the loneliest mayoral campaign in memory.

title: Test Yourself | Math, May 22, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article New York State to Ask Smartphone Makers to Help Prevent Thefts.

title: Garcetti Is Elected Mayor of Los Angeles, Thwarting Opposition of Labor Unions
description: LOS ANGELES  Despite the citys most powerful unions having spent millions on behalf of his opponent, City Councilman Eric Garcetti handily won his bid to become the mayor of Los Angeles on Tuesday, receiving 54 percent of the vote.

title: IHT Quick Read: May 22
description: NEWS Hezb-i-Islami, a powerful and feared player in the fight against the Soviets and later in Afghanistans civil war, is now widely seen as a spent insurgent force that poses little military threat. Instead, on the eve of the American troop withdrawal, Hezb-i-Islamis real strength now lies with its political party. Matthew Rosenberg reports from Kabul.

title: How Much Slang Do You Use? What Are Your Favorite (Printable) Words?
description: Have you ever used Urban Dictionary, the crowdsourced collection of slang words that, according to a front-page New York Times article, is now even being used in courtrooms?

title: Team to Investigate Fatal Indonesian Mining Collapse
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The Indonesian government and a United States-based mining company will appoint an independent team to investigate the collapse of a training tunnel last week near the companys operations in the remote Papua region that killed 28 local workers, officials said Wednesday.

title: Many City Voters Say Weiner Shouldnt Run for Mayor
description: An increasing number of New York City voters do not support the prospect of former Representative Anthony D. Weiner jumping into the election for mayor, according to the latest survey from the Quinnipiac University Polling Institute.

title: The Early Word: Approved
description: Todays Times

title: Sony Pondering Spinoff Proposal From a Big Investor
description: TOKYO  Sony said on Wednesday that its board was considering a proposal from the hedge fund Third Point to spin off part of its entertainment business, but it emphasized that the discussions were preliminary and that it had not set a time to respond.

title: The Skeptics Curse
description: TEL AVIV  In late September 2000, at the beginning of the second Palestinian intifada, the French TV station France 2 aired some 60 seconds of footage allegedly showing the killing of a Palestinian boy in the Gaza Strip.

title: A Photographers Dispatch from Mt. Everest
description: KHUMBU GLACIER It was nearly 60 years ago this month that Tenzing Norgay, the Sherpa guide, and Sir Edmund Hillary from New Zealand scaled the highest peak in the world, Mount Everest.

title: What Cant You Make With Chickpeas?
description: Im partial to chickpeas  or garbanzo beans, if you prefer  and not because they were among the first legumes I ever ate. (My mother would open a can and put them out at parties, with salt and pepper; you can do better than that. Sorry, Mom.) They have what to me is an irresistibly robust and nutty flavor, and a texture that can run from crunchy to tender.

title: Why Alternative Lenders Should Set Some Standards
description: In my loan brokerage, the phone often rings with small-business owners who want cash quickly for a wide variety of reasons. They may be in a desperate situation, or they may be so fed up with the local banks that they dont even want to try that route. Or perhaps theyve been told by friends how frustrating it can be to apply for a Small Business Administration loan.

title: Unexcited? There May Be a Pill for That
description: Linneah sat at a desk at the Center for Sexual Medicine at Sheppard Pratt in the suburbs of Baltimore and filled out a questionnaire. She read briskly, making swift checks beside her selected answers, and when she was finished, she handed the pages across the desk to Martina Miller, who gave her a round of pills.

title: Daily Report: Apples Chief Charms Capitol Hill
description: Timothy D. Cook came to the lions den on Capitol Hill on Tuesday, prepared to face down lawmakers furious over evidence that Apple, the company he runs, had avoided paying billions in taxes. By the time he walked out, the big cats on a Senate committee were practically eating out of his hand, Nelson D. Schwartz and Brian X. Chen report in The New York Times.

title: Afghanistans Karzai Says No Circumstances Allow Him to Seek Another Term
description: NEW DELHI  Seeking to dispel widespread rumors that he will find a way to cling to power beyond the end of his second term next year, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan said Wednesday that there was no circumstance that will allow me to stay as president.

description: One lingering mystery in the investigation of the Boston Marathon bombings is whether the dead suspect, Tamerlan Tsarnaev, played a role in the unsolved murders of three men, one of them his best friend, in a Boston suburb in 2011.

title: From Anthony to James, Georges Life Doesnt Get Easier
description: For six games over the last two weeks, Paul George of the Indiana Pacers had one of the tougher assignments in the N.B.A. playoffs. His job was to guard the Knicks Carmelo Anthony one on one, to keep the offensive damage that Anthony can inflict to a minimum, to do whatever he had to do, within the rules, to wear down one of the leagues top scorers.

title: A By-the-E-Book Education, for $5 a Month
description: Dennis Abudho and his family of five children live in a one-bedroom house without electricity in Bandani, an informal settlement in Kisumu, Kenya. Abudho is active in the PTA at Bridge International Academy in Bandani, where his four oldest children (three boys and a girl) are in baby level, first, third and fifth grade. You might not expect someone like Abudho  who said he is a casual laborer, operating a bread machine at a local mill and bakery  to have four children in private school. But he can afford it  the cost of school for each child at Bridge, including books and materials, is the equivalent of $5.16 a month.

description: Felicia Ortiz, a teacher in the Bronx, offers her opinion on Anthony D. Weiner's mayoral candidacy.

Amanda Kavajian
description: Amanda Kavajian, a bartender from Forest Hills, Queens, offers her opinion on Anthony D. Weiner's mayoral candidacy.

title: Alien, Yet Familiar
description: BURBANK, Calif.  In a dimly lighted editing suite here on the Warner Brothers lot, blinds drawn for maximum secrecy and walls decorated with signs and posters celebrating Star Wars, Indiana Jones and Game of Thrones, Zack Snyder was discussing his philosophy on the totemic character who arguably gave rise to every fantasy series of the last 75 years: Superman.

title: How Dimon Won
description: After months of behind-the-scenes lobbying by JPMorgan Chase officials, Jamie Dimon won shareholder support on Tuesday to keep his chairman role. Only 32.2 percent of the banks shares supported a resolution to split the chairman and chief executive jobs, compared with about 40 percent of the shares voted last year. JPMorgans stock rose as much as 2.6 percent on Tuesday, before closing up 1.4 percent, at $53.02.

title: Jonathan Fogel
description: Jonathan Fogel, a retired butcher from Forest Hills, Queens, offers his opinion on Anthony D. Weiner's mayoral candidacy.

title: Come See Me in the Country This Summer. Im Begging.
description: I have a thing about summer in the country, which is kind of a Don Juan complex with grass: I want it, I want it, I want it, and then when I get it Im bored.

title: Lori Ellison
description: Lori Ellison, a painter visiting Gramercy Park, Manhattan, offers her opinion on Anthony D. Weiner's mayoral candidacy.

title: The Clothesline Towers of Bushwick
description: Dear Diary:

title: Egypts President Announces Release of 7 Officers Abducted in Sinai
description: CAIRO  President Mohamed Morsi on Wednesday announced the release of seven Egyptian security officers who had been kidnapped nearly a week ago in the lawless Sinai Desert, ending days of mounting anxiety over the governments apparent inability to secure even its own soldiers and the police in the area.

title: Lessons for Silicon Valley on Capitol Hill
description: There were two stark object lessons for the technology industry in Congress on Tuesday. One showed the power of influence. The other showed the power of the iPhone.

title: Vote Allegations Rattle Eurovision Song Contest
description: LONDON  Tension has been rising between Russia and neighboring Azerbaijan since the weekend over an alleged vote-rigging scandal whose reverberations are being felt across Europe.

title: Idol Worship
description: The satirical artist Francesco Vezzoli has always seemed more enchanted by movie stars and velvet ropes than by ivory towers. Still, curators cant get enough of him. This month the Italian-born bon vivant embarks on an artistic tour that he is calling The Trinity. The event kicks off at the MAXXI national art museum in Rome, where his bedazzled portraits of pop stars like Lady Gaga will be on display alongside his needlepoints of various saints. Then, this fall, he will dismantle a deconsecrated 19th-century Italian church and rebuild it at MoMA PS1 in Queens. Vezzoli finishes up at the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art, with a show focusing fittingly on his obsession with all things cinematic. Asked if, at 41, a global retrospective might be premature, Vezzoli says, I see this project more like a parody of a Cher farewell tour, a silly movie launch or a Fitzcarraldo experience  something extravagant and certainly not celebratory, at least in my intentions.

title: New Yorkers Respond to Weiners Candidacy
description: New Yorkers voiced their opinions on Anthony D. Weiners candidacy for mayor, weighing in on his past and potential as a candidate.

title: Societal Ills Spike in Crisis-Stricken Greece
description: ATHENS  Five euros only, just 5 euros, whispered Maria, a young prostitute with sunken cheeks and bedraggled hair, as she pitched herself forward from the shadows of a graffiti-riddled alley in central Athens on a recent weeknight.

title: Not Worried About a Little Baby Fat
description: I was showing my favorite photograph of the baby to an acquaintance. She commented on the girls sweet thighs sticking out of her flowered onesie and her kissable cheeks, and I said, with maternal pride, Shes such a chubby bunny. The other woman seemed mildly horrified that I would call my daughter chubby, even in an admiring way. Dont worry, she said. Shell grow out of it.

title: Facing Uphill Battle, Christie Challenger Will Begin TV Ad Campaign
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has raised more than three times as much money as his challenger in his bid for re-election this year, has already run two television advertisements and, according to the latest polls, has approval ratings in the 70 percent range. He would seem well on his way to his goal of winning the election in November by a historic margin, big enough to propel him to the front of the Republican primary for president in 2016.

title: Indonesia Links Ownership of Banks to More Access Elsewhere
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesia will insist on greater access to the financial systems of Singapore and other countries as a condition for approving the purchase of local banks by foreign financial institutions, a central bank spokesman said on Wednesday.

title: What Do You Think About Weiners Mayoral Run?
description: In a video announcing his mayoral run, Anthony D. Weiner acknowledged that I made some big mistakes, and I know I let a lot of people down.

title: Overseas Chinese: A Foreigner at Home
description: BEIJING &#8212 Your Chinese is terrible! Arent you ashamed as a Chinese?

title: Anthony Weiner's Announcement Video
description: Trying to ressurect his political career, Mr. Weiner announced a bid for New York City mayor.

title: Fed Endorses Stimulus, but the Message Is Garbled
description: WASHINGTON  Despite signs of improvement in the job market, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, and most other Fed officials signaled Wednesday that they remained cautious about easing back too quickly on their efforts to stimulate the economy.

title: Austria Gives Ground on Banking Secrecy at Meeting of European Union Leaders
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union inched closer to ending bank secrecy on Wednesday when Austria agreed to eventually start sharing personal bank account information with other countries as long as similar rules also applied to tax havens like Switzerland that are not part of the 27-nation bloc.

title: The Night Heron
description: A night out at an illicit club built in a water tower in Chelsea.

title: Whatever Happened to the Big Bad Wolf?
description: Once upon a time, the Big Bad Wolf was a mighty fearsome fellow. In the folkloric tales of Aesop and the Grimms, he terrorized small children and other helpless critters. He blew down houses in Disneys Three Little Pigs, and in The Three Little Wolves, a somewhat sinister Silly Symphony cartoon from 1936, after the Nazi ascent to power, he is saddled with a German accent.

title: Senators Resilience Starts with Anderson
description: OTTAWA  Senators goaltender Craig Anderson has had his share of ups and downs in his career, which is why Ottawa Coach Paul MacLean was confident he would bounce back despite being pulled after giving up three early goals in Game 2 of their playoff series against Pittsburgh. Anderson responded in Game 3 with 49 saves in a 2-1 double-overtime victory.

title: Tornado Aid Fires Up Budget Debate
description: The Timess Peter Baker on the fiscal arguments beginning to burn through Congress, touched off by President Obamas promise to help victims in Oklahoma.

title: Burgers and Bun Kebabs
description: KARACHI  Its a measure of Pakistanis obsession with eating that even the elections held on May 11  fiercely contested, marred by violence  are being discussed in culinary metaphors. The contest in Karachi has been called a clash between the burgers and the bun kebabs, between the Westernized youth and middle-class locals.

title: CBS to Keep Airing Tony Awards Through 2018
description: CBS announced Wednesday morning that it would continue what has become a 35-year tradition for the network, by agreeing to a deal with The Broadway League and the American Theater Wing that will extend its rights to broadcast the annual Tony Awards show through 2018.

title: The Return of Anthony Weiner
description: Anthony Weiner, having forgiven himself for the sex-texting scandal that forced him out of Congress, now asks New York City voters to do the same. He has entered the mayors race, via an online video posted late last night  an odd time to kick off a campaign, but at least too late for the tabloids to blanket the newsstands this morning with page-one penis jokes.

title: Water Tower in Chelsea Manifests a Secret Life
description: A trapdoor in the water tower opened when the guests approached. Thumping live music, candlelight, chatter and the sound of clinking glasses emerged, as well as a helping hand.

title: What Were Reading
description: Lifehacker: Ive always noticed that some chefs cut their lemons lengthwise to squeeze the juice instead of through the Equator as do most home cooks, but never thought about why. Turns out theres a good reason: you get more juice.  Melissa Clark

title: Aston Martin Shows the CC100 in Germany
description: Among the many 100th birthday activities Aston Martin had going on during last weekends Nrburgring 24-hour race, almost lost in all the events was the introduction of the CC100 Speedster Concept.

title: Seeking Clarity on Terrible Tornadoes in a Changing Climate
description: As I explained earlier this week, questions related to any impact of human-driven global warming on tornadoes, while important, have almost no bearing on the challenge of reducing human vulnerability to these killer storms. The focus on the ground in Oklahoma, of course, will for years to come be on recovery and rebuilding  hopefully with more attention across the region to developing policies and practices that cut losses the next time. (With this in mind, please read John Schwartzs great feature, Why No Safe Room to Run To? Cost and Plains Culture.)

title: Speeding Customs
description: The Chicago OHare International Airport will be the first airport in the United States to implement Automated Passport Control, a new technology designed to expedite customs clearance, the Chicago Department of Aviation announced recently. The program is expected to help travelers with American passports move more quickly through the United States border clearance process by allowing them to enter passport and other information at self-service kiosks instead of using paper declaration cards. The touch-screen technology, developed by the Vancouver Airport Authority and United States Customs and Border Protection, is already in use at Vancouver International Airport. Thirty-two kiosks are expected to be installed at OHare by July 1.

title: A Brief Encore for Little Syria: Sights, Sounds and Even Smells
description: Little Syria hasnt been so Syrian in a long while.

title: House Hunting in Morocco
description: A restored 19th-century riad in Marrakesh, with five bedroom suites, is on the market for $1.3 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Morocco
description: A RESTORED 19TH-CENTURY HOME IN MARRAKESH

title: Cannes Film Festival: Miikes Honest Cop, Winding Refns Wallpaper
description: CANNES, France  The laughter started again when the soulful thug adrift in Only God Forgives slid a hand in his dead mothers eviscerated belly, seemingly going for her womb. The mother, played by Kristin Scott Thomas with long, bleached-blond hair and her usual hauteur, has come to Bangkok because the eldest rancid fruit of said womb, Billy, has been murdered. Mom demands that her youngest, Julian (Ryan Gosling), do something. Its complicated, he says  but alas, it really isnt, despite the nods to Macbeth or Hamlet, Michael Mann or William Friedkin and whatever  explaining that Billy raped and killed a 16-year-old girl. Im sure, Mom replies, he must have had his reasons.

title: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  The Internal Revenue Service official who first disclosed that the agency had targeted conservative groups for special scrutiny, and in doing so ignited a controversy that has ensnared the White House, denied on Wednesday that she had ever provided false information to Congress. She then invoked her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination and declined to testify at a House hearing on the agencys actions.

title: A Fitting Screen Protector for the iPhone 5
description: While clear film phone screen protectors can be a good idea, applying them requires a lot of patience and some skill. Otherwise you end up with a bubble-filled membrane that is hard to type on and see through.

title: Calliopes Chocolate Hazelnut Ice Cream
description: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tweaked for home cooks.

title: Tiny Mall Kiosks Make a Surprisingly Big Impact
description: Typically bound by short-term leases, displaying products made by others, and run by first-time entrepreneurs with limited capital, shopping mall carts and kiosks have long been considered an unsophisticated small-business underclass. More recently, however, these small-footprint retailers have come to be seen as possessing surprising potential.

title: DNR by Another Name
description: Id like to bring you up to speed on whats going on, the doctor said. He had a red goatee and was wearing a white coat. He said that my father had pneumonia and needed a breathing machine, and that he also had sepsis and acute lung injury. The statistics are not too good, he said solemnly. Around 40 percent of people who are just like him will die from this.

title: Suspect in Antigay Attack in East Village Is Arrested
description: The suspect in an antigay assault in the East Village  one of two that took place hours after a Monday rally to protest the killing of a gay man last week  turned himself in at a Bronx police station, the police said on Wednesday.

title: Robin Roberts to Write a Memoir
description: Robin Roberts, the Good Morning America anchor who has chronicled her bout with life-threatening illnesses before millions of viewers, will write about it in a new memoir, her publisher said on Wednesday.

title: The Envelope Please: Maimuna Abdi Yussuf
description: In her final blog post, Maimuna Abdi Yussuf, a Somali student at African Leadership Academy, looks forward to her days as a freshman at Duke University.
