The latest addition to the to-do list of Ms. Michele, a star of the Fox musical comedy-drama, is a book that she will write for the Harmony Books imprint of Random Houses Crown Publishing Group, the publisher said Thursday.

title: What the Congress-Led Government Thinks It Got Right
description: NEW DELHI In its last report card before the national elections, the Indian government acknowledged it was coming off a year of sluggish economic growth but promised citizens that it could bring back high growth rates seen in the first eight years the governing coalition has been in power.

title: Rue21 to Sell Itself to Apax for $1.1 Billion
description: Rue21 said on Thursday that it would sell itself to Apax Partners for about $1.1 billion, including debt, as private equity firms continued their pursuit of purveyors of fashion.

title: Fed Fears Shake Global Markets but Fade on Wall St.
description: Investors are contemplating a future without support from one of the biggest engines of the global economy in recent years: the Federal Reserve.

title: The Gun Report: May 23, 2013
description: Vanessa German is an artist in the Homewood neighborhood of Pittsburgh, Pa., which Rachel Maddow has called Americas most dangerous neighborhood. German likes to paint on her front porch, which attracted the interest of neighborhood children, who began asking her, Whatcha doin? and Can we do it, too? Soon her porch was filled with kids, birthing a project called Love Front Porch. While she admits her beloved town is rife with gun violence, she writes on her Web site, Ive seen acts of love and bravery here that would leave you slack-jawed and damp-eyed with awe.

title: Heartburn Tied to Throat Cancer
description: Frequent heartburn increases the risk for throat cancer, a new study has found, and over-the-counter antacids may provide protection.

title: A Double Helping of Humor
description: After years of trafficking in the crass, cheap laughs of Hollywood sitcoms, what could be more bracing for two youngish thespians than the chance to linger over nuances as they rehearse Shakespeare?

title: Poetry Pairing | Three Hundred Thousand More
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches Three Hundred Thousand More by James Sloan Gibbons with the article Birthplace of Memorial Day? That Depends Where Youre From by Campbell Robertson.

title: Abortion After 20 Weeks
description: On the list of treasured Republican pastimes, trying to outlaw abortion and imposing a right-wing agenda on the District of Columbia (which is heavily Democratic and lacks any representation in Congress) both rank high.

title: Maria Semple: By the Book
description: The author of Whered You Go, Bernadette calls Franzen her big daddy  My favorite kind of book is a domestic drama thats grounded in reality yet slightly unhinged.

title: What Were Reading
description: Details: Are chefs growing as weary of kale as their customers are? Maybe thats why some of them are turning to collard greens.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Computer Piracy
description: Ready or not, computer piracy comes when you least expect it.

title: The Changing Face of Community Colleges
description: Students at community colleges increasingly come from low-income families, as I mention in an article for Thursdays newspaper about a new report. The trends, in their simplest terms:

title: Dot Chat: From Energy Campaigners to Solar Finance Entrepreneurs
description: 3:15 p.m. | Updated |I spent 45 minutes earlier today in an invigorating online discussion of new models for financing small solar-energy installations. The participants were Billy Parish, who at 31 is a founder of Mosaic, a company through which small investors can earn interest financing the installation of solar panels, and Andreas Karelas, the executive director, of RE-volv, a nonprofit revolving fund also financing solar projects.

title: New York Led Region in Population Growth Since 2011, Census Shows
description: New York added more people since 2011 than all the other cities in the metropolitan area combined, according to a new analysis of census results released Thursday.

title: Questions in London Killing Echo Boston Bombing
description: LONDON  The questions being raised on Thursday after the brutal killing of an off-duty soldier on a London street echoed many of the questions raised after the Boston marathon bombing just five weeks before. Were the suspects lone wolves or part of a wider conspiracy? Were they radicalized Islamists or disaffected locals? Were they motivated by events overseas or mouthing the rhetoric of someone elses fight?

title: The Composer Wears Many Hats
description: Theres no question that the composer Dave Malloys Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812 breaks many of the rules that have accrued around American musical theater, from its mostly unrhymed lyrics and sung-through libretto, adapted from a small portion of Leo Tolstoys War and Peace, to the eclectic blend of classical and electro-pop sounds.

title: Why Did the Pacers Sit Hibbert?
description: From the looks of the N.B.A. playoff schedule, it appeared the leagues first instinct was to pencil in the Miami Heat for the N.B.A. finals. The first two games of the Western Conference finals came and went before the Heat players even had to dig their sneakers out of the closet. But perhaps realizing that the Spurs-Grizzlies series was going to alienate fans who cling to the idea that basketball is fun and involves scoring a lot of baskets, or realizing that fans had paid money for tickets to the foregone conclusion that is the Heat-Pacers series (hey, people go to movies when they know the ending, too), well, the N.B.A. relented and had an actual game in the Eastern Conference finals Wednesday night.

title: Why I Write About My Daughters O.C.D.
description: Not long ago, I published an essay in the Timess Opinionator section: Two-Way Mirror: Facing a Daughters O.C.D., about my daughter Lucys treatment for obsessive-compulsive disorder and Tourette Syndrome, as well as my own history of mental illness. By doing so, I became what Phoebe Maltz Bovy, a blogger for The Atlantic, calls a parental oversharer, a writer mining [her] childrens lives for material. I disagree with Ms. Bovys diagnosis, but she raises valid questions. Should parents write publicly about the lives of their children? What, if anything, should be off-limits? How much is too much?

title: The Future of High-Tech Immigrants to the U.S.
description: The Timess Sean Patrick Farrell talks to foreign graduate students studying technology at the University of California, Berkeley, about the jobs they will be starting after they graduate and their lives in the United States as immigration reform looks to be gaining momentum. One Chinese student tells Sean that if she cannot get visas to stay in the U.S.  currently required each year  then she will go home to Shanghai and probably start her own business there.

title: North Korea Envoy Agrees to Dialogue, China Says, in Possible Sign for Nuclear Talks
description: BEIJING  A North Korean envoy visiting China said his country would accept the proposal by Chinese officials to open up dialogue, the state-run China News Service reported Thursday, a possible signal that the North would agree to talks on its nuclear program.

title: Objects | Rachel Comeys Sculptural Swimwear Through a Photographers Lens
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Last 15 Feet at Vicksburg
description: Gen. Thomas E.G. Ransom woke early on May 22, 1863. The Union brigade commander and his senior officers had spent part of the previous night reconnoitering the formidable enemy defenses that protected Vicksburg, Miss. Now, as the morning sun burned bright and hot, the general and his aides went in search of a vantage point to continue their observations. They soon found a spot near the camp of one of the regiments in Ransoms Brigade, the 72nd Illinois Infantry, and struck up a conversation with its officers.

title: Science Group Criticizes Politicians for Global Warming Distortions
description: Its great to see the Union of Concerned Scientists offering nonpartisan criticism of elected officials for distorting  in both directions  whats known about the role of human-driven global warming on several fronts, from tornado ferocity to hurricane losses.

title: In Mideast, Kerry Plays Down Pessimism on Peace
description: JERUSALEM  As he embarked on another round of meetings with Israeli and Palestinian leaders on Thursday in an effort to revitalize the peace process, Secretary of State John Kerry acknowledged the doubts being expressed on both sides over his chances of success.

title: Excerpt: 'Peter and the Starcatcher'
description: The prologue from the prequel to the classic Peter Pan story, at New World Stages.

title: Zoo Chiefs First Tweet Stars a 650-Pound Tortoise
description: James J. Breheny, director of the Bronx Zoo, is a self-described dinosaur when it comes to technology. Im an animal guy, he said. Im not a techno guy.

title: Cheers and Taunts in Candidates Circuslike Return to Political Stage
description: He was the wisecracking know-it-all, asking a voter originally from Wyoming if his old neighbors have running water and indoor plumbing there yet.

title: Rangers Bench Brad Richards for Game 4
description: Brad Richards will not be in the lineup Thursday night when the Rangers play an elimination game against the Boston Bruins in their N.H.L. Eastern Conference semifinals series at Madison Square Garden. The Bruins lead the series, three games to none.

title: Nine Years Later, Once More
description: Where did the time go? Has it really been nine years since we last saw Celine and Jesse, in Paris, rekindling the romance that first sparked nine years before that, in Vienna? Luckily (for us and for them) they are still together, having hatched a pair of sweet blond twin girls and glided, or maybe stumbled, into their 40s. And, of course, because they are played by Julie Delpy and Ethan Hawke, Celine and Jesse are still better looking than most of the rest of us, and still have quite a lot to say about themselves, each other and the world.

title: For Randolph, the Challenge Is Offense
description: The overtime period of San Antonios 93-89 win over the Memphis Grizzlies in Game 2 of the Western Conference finals Tuesday night amounted to an ugly microcosm of the preceding 48 minutes: a mess of disjointed, almost reluctant offense punctuated by rare glimmers of grace.

title: The Trajectory of Suicide
description: Since Ive been writing about the recent uptick in suicide rates, I should link to Newsweeks big new piece on the same trend, which offers a good survey of how self-slaughter has become one of the worlds leading causes of death. The pieces author, Tony Dokoupil, actuallygoes a little bit further than I would: Given how much of suicides new statistical prominence is explained by the (happy) decline in other ways of death, and given that suicide rates were dipping in the U.S. up until the turn of millenium, Im not sure that the language of epidemic quite makes sense at this point; I think the Center for Disease Controls formulation,an increasing public health concern, is a more appropriate way of putting it. The big question, as my column tried to suggest, is where the current trend is going, and whether the upward movement is likely to persist. And here the Newsweek essay has a good distillation of the case for pessimism:

title: Mothers With Cancer
description: Ensconced in Babyland, I attend the relentless rhythms of soothing my visiting 3-month-old grandson, who cannot seem to sleep more than 40 minutes at a stretch. I have determined to jettison all other obligations with two exceptions: providing meals for my nursing daughter and reading a memoir lent to me by a friend who must have known how it would move me. In The Kitchen Congregation, Nora Seton mourns the death of her mother, a novelist, from cancer at age 56.

title: Warm Welcome at Deutsche Bank Meeting, Followed by Rancor
description: FRANKFURT  Anshu Jain, co-chief executive of Deutsche Bank, had barely spoken two sentences to shareholders Thursday when he was interrupted by applause. It wasnt what he said that pleased the audience so much as the language he used: German.

title: Regulator Cites Flaws in Ernst & Youngs Audit Procedures
description: The United States regulator of accounting firms said on Thursday that a Big Four firm, Ernst & Young, had been too willing to trust figures supplied by corporate executives instead of evaluating them independently and had failed to improve its procedures even after being told to do so.

title: Getting Change Fees Waived for a Canceled Flight
description: Airlines take a lot of heat for indifferent customer service  and its often justified. But I recently had a pleasantly reasonable experience with American Airlines, although it did take a little time to resolve.

title: Advice on How to Preserve Your Old Photos and Records, and Your Digital Media
description: Bertram Lyons will answer questions relating to archiving and preserving family history and stories: analog and digital.

title: Help With Breast-Feeding
description: For nursing mothers, traveling light is an oxymoron. But one hotelier is at least reducing the load a bit. The Hard Rock Hotel Chicago, in partnership with Medela, a manufacturer of breast pumps and breast-feeding accessories, recently introduced the Nursing Mothers Amenity Program. For $30 per stay, guests are provided with hospital-grade breast pumps, mini-refrigerators, microwaves, cooler bags, ice packs and bra pads. The hotels concierge staff is trained to handle nursing-specific requests, like how to safely send expressed milk.

title: Amtrak Extends Contract of Its President
description: WASHINGTON  Amtraks board of directors on Thursday extended the contract of the companys president, Joseph H. Boardman, who has led the government-owned railroad corporation to record growth in ridership and revenue.

title: Fine Settles an Inquiry Into Selling of I.S.S. Vote Data
description: Institutional Shareholder Services, the biggest independent adviser to shareholders on corporate elections, agreed to pay a fine on Thursday to settle civil charges that it failed to stop an employee from improperly selling confidential vote data.

title: An Artists Most Dynamic Creation Is a Place
description: Kellam Clark did not set out to build an artist colony. He set out to build a boat.

title: Portia de Rossi on the Return of Arrested Development
description: This week were talking to members of the cast of Arrested Development, leading up to the return of the series, on Netflix, on Sunday. Previously we spoke with Jason Bateman, Jeffrey Tambor, Jessica Walter, and Will Arnett. An interview with David Cross will appear on Thursday afternoon.

title: Student Loan Bill Passes House, Setting Up Face-Off
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Thursday passed legislation to head off a doubling of student loan interest rates on July 1, instead tying rates to prevailing market trends and ending federal subsidies.

title: Image of the Day: May 23
Paid Parental Leave Policies at Disney, Fitch and Others
description: Earlier this year, I wrote a column on the dismal state of paid parental leave in the United States, which trails most of the world.

title: Analysis of Key Points From Obamas Speech on Drones
description: In his first major speech on counterterrorism of his second term, President Obama on Thursday opened a new phase in the nations long struggle with terrorism by announcing that he is restricting the use of unmanned drone strikes, which have been at the heart of his national security strategy.

title: Figuring Out How to Help Small-Business Owners
description: I get a fair number of e-mails from my readers. A couple of weeks ago one arrived from a gentleman named Michael Bloch. He wrote:

title: Cockroaches Know What Not to Eat
description: New research published in the journal Science shows that some German cockroaches have evolved a highly effective defense against sweet-tasting poison baits, avoiding them altogether.

title: Pivoting From a War Footing, Obama Acts to Curtail Drones
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly a dozen years after the hijackings that transformed America, President Obama said Thursday that it was time to narrow the scope of the grinding battle against terrorists and begin the transition to a day when the country will no longer be on a war footing.

title: Wily Cockroaches Find Another Survival Trick: Laying Off the Sweets
description: Everyone knows that cockroaches are the ultimate survivors, with enough evolutionary tricks up their carapaces to have thrived for 350 million years and to have completely adapted to the human species.

title: Obamas Speech on Drone Policy
description: Following is a transcript of President Obamas speech on U.S. drone and counterterror policy, as provided by the White House:

title: Law and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Reflections on Our Most Popular Found Poetry Contest Yet
description: Back in March, we invited you to enter our Fourth Annual Found Poetry Student Contest, and 971 of you did, sending in verse that was so interesting and intricate that its taken us more than a month to read, reread, discuss and winnow it.

title: Boy Scouts Vote on Gay Youth Members
description: In an op-ed this week for USA Today, Wayne Perry, president of the Boy Scouts of America, mused that somehow, Scouting has become one of the focal points in the debate on homosexuality. The reasons behind that somehow are not too obscure. Mr. Perry asserted in the same op-ed that the B.S.A. is part of the fabric of this nation and delivers the nations foremost youth program of character development and values-based leadership training. How is it surprising that such a large, vital organization would attract criticism for its longstanding policy of excluding gay members and leaders?

title: Against Amanda
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Brink
description: To the Editor:

title: The Church and the State of Matrimony
description: Americans have always been a religiously diverse people, even as the definition of what counts as diversity has changed. In 1774, members of the Continental Congress protested the idea of bringing in a chaplain to lead prayers: We were so divided in religious sentiment, one of them explained, that we could not join in the same act of worship. Overwhelmingly Protestant, they nonetheless recognized the significant differences of theology and practice that divided Anglicans from Presbyterians, Baptists from Quakers.

title: Anthony D. Weiner on the Campaign Trail
description: Mr. Weiner made his first public appearances on Thursday after announcing his mayoral bid on Wednesday.

title: Used Computer, $116,000 or Best Offer
description: More than a decade ago, at a vintage computer fair in Silicon Valley, Dag Spicer had an opportunity to buy an original Apple-1 for $2,000. He passed. Any regrets? Not really, he said.

title: Ethan Coen Play to Open Atlantic Theater Company Season
description: Women or Nothing, a full-length play by the Academy Award-winning filmmaker Ethan Coen, will be given its world premiere on Sept. 16 at the Linda Gross Theater as part of the Atlantic Theater Companys 2013-14 season. The work, directed by David Cromer, is the first of six productions the company plans to stage next season. Previews are to begin Aug. 28.

title: Covered or Not
description: ISTANBUL  There is a huge poster near the town hall of the Istanbul borough where I live. It shows a brunette wearing a telephone headset, cheerfully answering the municipal helpline. She isnt wearing a headscarf.

title: Taking a Spin Around a Dirt Track in a Pro Lite Unlimited Racing Truck
description: LAKE ELSINORE, Calif.  Casey Currie drummed in one message last Friday during our laps around the track at Lake Elsinore Motorsports Park: Slow! Slow down! Slow into the turn! Currie, 29, who has motorcycles and Baja 1000 trucks, had good reason to worry.

title: Food Matters | Steakhouse Art That Goes Against the Grain
description: Nasser Azam, a 49-year-old London-based artist, is used to dealing in extremes. He once took an 11-day trip to Antarctica to paint large-scale abstract canvases outdoors, intentionally leaving the work on a frigid ice field overnight so it could be roughed up by the elements. Another time, Azam boarded a specially modified aircraft in Star City, Russia, and painted two triptychs honoring Francis Bacon while the plane flew in parabolas, thus enabling its artist-passenger to conduct his work in zero gravity. More recently, at Londons City Airport, Azam unveiled Athena, Britains tallest bronze sculpture. Azams debut in the United States, this week, is also marked by a certain degree of monumentality. His work has gone on permanent display in a steakhouse.

title: Some in Congress Grow More Wary of Selling Sprint to SoftBank of Japan
description: 11:09 p.m. | Updated

title: David Cross on the Return of Arrested Development
description: This week were talking to members of the cast of Arrested Development, leading up to the return of the series, on Netflix, on Sunday. Previously we spoke with Jason Bateman, Jeffrey Tambor, Jessica Walter, Will Arnett and Portia de Rossi. An interview with Michael Cera will appear on Friday.

title: Teams Need Help, but Jackson Stays on the Perimeter
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J.  On book tour, Phil Jackson is an inveterate news media flirt, a trending tweet waiting to happen.

title: President Obama on Drones
description: At the National Defense University, the president delivered the first major speech on counterterrorism of his second term and announced a shift in his administrations use of drones.

title: 36 Hours in Auckland, New Zealand
description: Admittedly, few fly all the way to New Zealand just to visit Auckland, the countrys largest city. Most aim to explore the otherworldly landscapes with which, thanks to the silver screen, this remote nation has become associated. But before delving into the cinematic beauty of the North Island countryside, discover the San Francisco-steep streets and regenerated neighborhoods of newly vibrant Auckland. This multicultural city, home to a third of all Kiwis, has recently welcomed a raft of bars, boutiques and restaurants that highlight locally made products, from excellent craft beer and wine to fashion and art. And none of it has anything to do with orcs or rings.

title: Scenes From Auckland
description: From water and wine, to culture and cuisine, take a tour of this New Zealand city.

title: New Lures for Locals in Buffalo
description: Some of the citys once-blighted stretches are now stirring with new culinary and shopping options.

title: Giants Back Will Have Knee Surgery
description: Fullback Henry Hynoski, who injured his left knee Wednesday during the Giants opening off-season workout, will have surgery Friday that could keep him out until the beginning of the regular season or longer. Hynoski injured the medial collateral ligament and also had a chip fracture of the lateral plateau in his knee.

title: Whitman Says H.P. Is Not Mortgaging the Future
description: 5:06 p.m. | Updated Coming off a quarterly earnings report that pleased investors even as revenues fell, Hewlett-Packards chief executive, Meg Whitman, declared Thursday that we feel good about where we are.

title: The Flamboyant Cars of Liberace
description: Behind the Candelabra, the new HBO movie about Liberace, has a scene in which he drives up to his Hollywood home (its actually Zsa Zsa Gabors home, but thats another story.) in a Mercedes-Benz 450SL, and arrayed around the driveway is a collection of cars as flamboyant as the entertainer.

title: Aiko Hachisuka
description: Eleven Rivington

title: A Rush to Recruit Young Analysts, Only Months on the Job
description: For Wall Streets top young analysts, landing at a prestigious investment bank out of college was the easy part. Now comes the fierce competition to line up a high-paying job at a prominent buyout fund, just months into their first professional jobs.

title: Defense in Trayvon Martin Case Raises Questions About the Victims Character
description: MIAMI  Intending to draw a fuller, perhaps more negative portrait of Trayvon Martin, the unarmed teenager who was shot and killed by George Zimmerman in early 2012, a lawyer for Mr. Zimmerman released new material on Thursday that depicted Mr. Martin as troubled at school and enamored of a gangsta culture.

title: Americas Cup Boats Returning to Water
description: The Americas Cup returned to something closer to normal on Thursday as two more of the teams involved in sailings premier competition hit the water for the first time since the death of the sailor Andrew Simpson in a training accident on May 9.

title: European Soccers Biggest Star May Be a Song
description: LONDON  The song does not have a catchy hook, mostly because its lyrics are in three languages.

title: Bananas, Anyone? The Bluths Are Back
description: In 2003, when Arrested Development had its premiere on the Fox network, the countrys biggest comedy hits were the broad, safe Everybody Loves Raymond and Friends. Social networks like Twitter and Tumblr hadnt been invented yet. Only 30 percent of American households had DVD players; only 3 percent had digital video recorders. Bingeing was a term associated with food, not television.

title: A Family Reunion, After the Cruise
description: Perhaps youve heard that Arrested Development is back.

title: Marc Quinn: All the Time in the World
description: Mary Boone

title: Don Voisine
description: McKenzie Fine Art Inc.

title: The Past and the Future Come Together at Parsons
description: At Wednesday nights annual graduation gala held by Parsons the New School for Design, a fund-raising event that brought in nearly $1.7 million for the schools scholarship fund, four students took home the schools top awards.

title: Pacers Lapse Wasnt Coachs Alone
description: Pacers center Roy Hibbert had one of the cruelest rejections of the postseason when he blocked a Carmelo Anthony dunk attempt in the fourth quarter of Indianas Game 6 victory over the Knicks. But when LeBron James of the Miami Heat, the Pacers next opponent, powered his way to the rim for the game-winning basket in the final moments of Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals, Hibbert was not even in the game.

title: Simon Hanta
description: Paul Kasmin Gallery

title: The Corrosive Effect of Apples Tax Avoidance
description: The shameful thing about Apple Inc.s ability to structure its business to avoid United States taxes was not that it did it. In fact, as Apple executives tried to point out at the Senate hearing at which their tax strategies were detailed, they could have chosen to pay much less in American taxes than they did.

title: Service for 9-Year-Old Is the First for Two Dozen Tornado Victims
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Three days after one of the most destructive tornadoes to strike Oklahoma in decades, people here filed into a mortuary chapel on Thursday morning amid heavy rain and flashes of lightning for the first of two dozen funerals.

title: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 9
description: The Bats blog again tests our readers predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, tea leaves, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

title: European Parliament Moves to Limit Scope of Eventual U.S. Trade Deal
description: BRUSSELS  The European Parliament passed a resolution on Thursday demanding that the free-trade pact now under discussion with the United States exempt audiovisual industries so that countries like France could shelter their movie businesses from foreign competition.

title: Beach Season Begins at Coney Island
description: The Misers crew spent a lovely Mothers Day a couple of weeks ago, strolling the Boardwalk at Coney Island. Though the sun was blazing in a clear sky, the temperature was spring-ish, and a brisk wind blew sand wildly across the beach. To our amazement, one fearless young couple waded into the surely icy waves for a refreshing dip in the Atlantic.

title: Obama Heckled During Guantnamo Speech
description: At the National Defense University, the president discussed his administrations efforts to close down the facility at Guantnamo Bay and was repeatedly confronted by a protester.

title: Third-Century Cutlery at Auction; Schoolgirls Samplers
description: The London silver dealer Jane Penrice Benson How was notorious for ushering shoppers out of her gallery if she suspected that they were uninformed. When one dismissed customer swore never to return, Mrs. How replied that that promise affords me the greatest possible relief.

title: Disability and Discrimination at the Doctors Office
description: In his 60s, overweight and in a wheelchair, the patient had been seeing doctors and nurses regularly for his diabetes. Only recently had they discovered a pressure sore after someone had finally, as he put it, wanted to examine at my backside.

title: The Mind Inside
description: Denise Sherer Jacobson, 63, was born with cerebral palsy, but she lives a full, active life.

title: Market Report | Peaches and Apricots From Spring Collections
description: Shades of peach and apricot are popping up everywhere, from ripe summer fruits to printed shirtdresses and python skimmers. Here, warm pieces to mix and match, including a leather-trimmed picnic basket for those first outdoor picnics.

title: The Politics of Second Chances
Obamas Speech on Counterterrorism
description: At the National Defense University, the president delivered the first major speech on counterterrorism of his second term.

title: Euro Tuner Cars Rally For Cheesesteaks
description: Last Saturday, I rode shotgun in an all-black BMW M3. Behind the wheel was Andrew Pollock, 26, an engineer from New Jersey, who had allowed me to be his co-pilot for the fourth annual Euro Philly Cheesesteak Run, a road rally that culminated at Tony Lukes Cheesesteaks in South Philadelphia.

title: SakaMai
description: Inside the Japanese restaurant on the Lower East Side that is respectful of tradition but not bound by it.

title: A Sake Lounge, Casual or Dressy
description: Order skate at SakaMai, and what arrives is not a frond of delicate flesh but a stack of broken wings, still threaded with cartilage and lustrous as capiz shells. They are corrugated and chewy, having been dried like jerky and broiled until the edges are curled to ocher. In Japan, they would appear with mayonnaise, but here the dip is yogurt, silkier, its tang intensified by yuzu kosho, a swirl of lemon, salt and chile.

title: Three Quick Rules: Be In, Be Real and Be Bold
description: This interview with Brad Garlinghouse, chief executive of YouSendIt, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: The Disabled List, More Popular Than Ever
description: Quirks of the Game is a regular feature on The Timess sports blogs.

title: Op-Doc: Ode to Bike Sharing
description: In this animation, a New Yorker looks forward to the citys bike share program and reminisces about riding his bike when the city was very different. The back story of the video can be read here.

title: Tax Protest in Britain Focuses on Google
description: In Britain, the debate over tax-reduction strategies employed by American technology giants is taking a populist turn.

title: A Calculus With Chalk, Stones and Walnuts
description: The excellent exhibition of Mel Bochners mind-bending, defiantly modest early Conceptual sculptures at Peter Freeman is a post-Minimalist time capsule. It provides a startlingly real sense of the attitude and physical ethos of SoHos experimental, artist-generated beginnings in the late 1960s and early 70s while showcasing some of the most singular art that the era produced.

title: The End of the Perpetual War
description: President Obamas speech on Thursday was the most important statement on counterterrorism policy since the 2001 attacks, a momentous turning point in post-9/11 America. For the first time, a president stated clearly and unequivocally that the state of perpetual warfare that began nearly 12 years ago is unsustainable for a democracy and must come to an end in the not-too-distant future.

title: Changing the World, Step by Step
description: WASHINGTON  Any exhibition honoring Diaghilevs Ballets Russes is likely to be a blast of color. When the company was born in 1909, its designers Alexandre Benois, Lon Bakst and Nicholas Roerich combined hues with an intensity hitherto unknown on Western stages. Its final premiere, in 1929, was George Balanchines ballet The Prodigal Son, whose designs by Georges Rouault had, deliberately, the glow of stained-glass windows. In between, great colorists like Picasso, Matisse, Sonia and Robert Delaunay, Mikhail Larionov and Natalia Goncharova passed through like a shower of meteors.

title: Food Matters | Alan Birds New Eatery Opens in a Five-Story Town House
description: After heading the kitchen for 15 years at the Ivy, an iconic and celebrity-studded restaurant and private club in London, the chef Alan Bird decided it was time to depart and spread his wings. We wanted to create a stylish space that had the feel of a members club, but also felt inclusive rather than exclusive, he said of his newest restaurant, Bird of Smithfield, which opened in the industrial and vibrant neighborhood of Farringdon last week.

title: Film No Evil
description: Sixty-eight years after the collapse of the Thousand Year Reich, Nazis remain a persistent presence on American screens. With their eye-grabbing iconography, they provide easy cartoon villains for action films (Inglourious Basterds), add moral import to dubious melodramas (The Reader), fuel entire cable channels with documentary reconstructions of their crimes and on rare occasions motivate actual works of art.

title: Samsung Reports 10 Million Sales of New Phone
description: Samsung Electronics new flagship smartphone, the Galaxy S4, is selling even faster than its popular predecessors.

title: When Photography Imitates Voyeurism
description: The Neighbors, an exhibition now at the Julie Saul Gallery in Chelsea, is, as you may have read, angering many residents of a certain TriBeCa building. Arne Svensons photographs, which he shot using a telephoto lens from inside his own apartment across the street, capture people at home through their windows. The neighbors, who were unaware they were being photographed, are somewhat obscured  bending over, back to the window, head turned, behind a curtain  and therefore mostly unidentifiable. But the subjects are recognizable to themselves, and maybe others.

title: The Price of Victory
description: ON the day Paris was liberated from Nazi occupation, two trucks screeched to a halt in front of the Ritz. Out jumped several dozen French Resistance fighters, armed to the teeth and led by a burly American with a large mustache. The French irregulars were so in awe of the man they referred to as le grand capitaine that they had taken to copying what the photographer Robert Capa called his sailor bear walk and machine-gun diction, spitting short sentences from the corners of their mouths.

title: Their Own Petard
description: The most revealing moment in Janet Malcolms new collection of essays and profiles, Forty-One False Starts, comes toward the end of A Girl of the Zeitgeist, her 1986 piece about Ingrid Sischy, who was then the editor of Artforum. The reader can hardly help noticing that while Sischy is the titular girl, she is not much in evidence in the piece itself, which is largely a portrait gallery of various art-world blowhards and monomaniacs. Malcolm admits that she hoped Sischy would be some sort of strikingly modern type, some astonishing new female sensibility loosed in the world. What she found instead is that Sischy was, to put it simply, a good person: a pleasant, intelligent, unassuming, responsible, ethical young woman. Naturally, Malcolm concludes, I . . . turned away in disappointment.

title: City Gives the Gardens Owners a Deadline on Penn Station
description: The owners of Madison Square Garden have been given an ultimatum: Make life more bearable for the hundreds of thousands of commuters who shuffle daily through the corridors of Pennsylvania Station crammed beneath the arena or face eviction.

title: The Year of Pricing Audaciously
description: Early last year, the virtual sales center at One57 set the tone for a year of astronomical listings in the high-end residential real estate market.

title: Rapinoes Lyon Club Is Upset in Womens Final
description: LONDON  One of the main attractions that drew Megan Rapinoe to Lyon earlier this year was the clubs complete and utter dominance. Lyon had won two straight European championships, shredded all comers in the French league by N.F.L.-like scores and was often referred to as the female games equivalent to Barcelona. In many ways, that comparison was an understatement.

title: British Leaders Liberal Turn Sets Off a Rebellion in His Party
description: LONDON  First, a prominent Tory called the partys rank and file swivel-eyed loons. Then the populist politician Nigel Farage called Prime Minister David Cameron and his Tory-led government a bunch of college kids. Then The Daily Mail called Mr. Farage, the leader of the U.K. Independence Party, a pint-guzzling eccentric.

title: Beauty and Blight, Sharing Common Ground
description: The artists behind Black Maps, Windscape, The Silence of Dogs in Cars, Garry Winogrand and The Green Florigeum remind us that the commonplace can be eternal.

title: Comedy Listings for May 24-30
description: Comedy

title: Search for the Unicorn
description: Images from the exhibition at the Cloisters.

title: These Artists Draw Blood
description: Writing last year in Slate, Farhad Manjoo made a convincing case that in the era of Jon Stewart; The Onion; the wiseacres on Twitter and Facebook; and the crowd-sourced humor that appears everywhere on the Web, political cartoons as a form are on life support.

title: Movie Listings for May 24-30
description: Movies

title: Retired Artist Pops His Head Back Up
description: Nobody really believed Maurizio Cattelan when, on the eve of his retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum two years ago, he announced his retirement.

title: For a Hasidic Woman, Weighing the Personal Against Larger Duties
description: The story told by Rama Burshtein in Fill the Void, her remarkable debut feature, has an almost classical simplicity. Shira (Hadas Yaron), a young woman living in an ultra-Orthodox enclave in Tel Aviv, faces a choice not unlike those faced by the heroines of Jane Austen novels and Hollywood romantic comedies. Which man will she marry? For Shira, this is an especially agonizing question because it forces her to weigh the claims of family loyalty, religious duty and her own desires.

title: Theater Listings for May 24-30
description: Theater

title: Pop & Rock Listings for May 24-30
description: Pop

title: Pictures of the Day: England and Elsewhere
description: Photos from England, Oklahoma, Afghanistan and Norway.

title: TV Spreads Its Blanket for Summer Viewing
description: When it comes to television, were in a bull market for doomsayers. Its the end of the broadcast networks, as their signals are pirated and their quality is eclipsed by cable and online shows. Its the end of commercial TV, as the advertising dollars move to the Internet. Its the end of entertainment, as attention spans shrink to the length of a YouTube video.

title: Jazz Listings for May 24-30
description: Jazz

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for May 24-30
description: Classical

title: I.R.S. Suspends Official at Center of Storm
description: WASHINGTON  Lois Lerner, the head of the Internal Revenue Services division on tax-exempt organizations, was put on administrative leave Thursday, a day after she invoked the Fifth Amendment and declined to testify before a House committee investigating her divisions targeting of conservative groups.

title: Voice of Arab Spring Offers Defiance and Melody
description: The Tunisian singer Emel Mathlouthi, a gentle firebrand whose song Kelmti Horra (My Word Is Free) became an anthem of the Arab Spring, made an enthralling New York debut at the French Institute Alliance Franaise on Wednesday night. In Arabic she sang, We are free men who are not afraid/We are the secrets that never die/And we are the voice of those who resist.

title: Branzino to Complement a Floral, Summery Wine
description: Its about time to try on all things floral and summery. For wines like that, consider Greece, especially the assyrtikos from sun-drenched Santorini. And alongside the wines (including some blends and moschofileros, which can also be bright quenchers), I propose branzino, known in Greece as lavraki. Sandro Romano, the new chef at Armani Ristorante, prepares the fish with a barely warm arugula sauce that offers a nice touch of bitterness and acid to complement the wine.

title: A Recognizable Style, From the Moment It Starts
description: Founded in 2001, Gotham Chamber Opera made its name with nimble, creative productions of older works, occasionally venturing into the 20th century but going no further than Britten and Piazzolla.

title: Dance Listings for May 24-30
description: Dance

title: Working Up a Sweat, Crawling and Wrestling
description: In the dim light you can discern a body. Its crumpled, contorted. There seems to be white powder in its hair, white makeup on its skin. It rises to pose in bent shapes. At times it also moves quickly. But then it sinks back down and the lights go out.

title: Cuomos Attack on Weiner? Its Now Called a Joke
description: ALBANY  Have you heard the one about the governor and the missed punch line?

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for May 24-30
description: Art

title: That Horn, Sure, but Theres a Lot More to This Creatures Magic
description: The Metropolitan Museum is an excellent place to hunt for mythical beasts. Look in almost any gallery of art made before 1900 and youll find dragons, sphinxes, centaurs, hydras, phoenixes and griffins. The Cloisters, the Mets medieval branch at the northern tip of Manhattan, offers multiple sightings of a particularly elusive creature: the unicorn, star of the celebrated Unicorn Tapestries.

title: Jostling for Position in Last Lap at Cannes
description: CANNES, France  By Thursday afternoon at the film festival here, over glasses of Ctes de Provence, the battle lines had been firmly drawn and the Palme dOr hypothetically awarded. The winner, amateur prognosticators huddling in the festival headquarters confidently or cautiously predicted, surely would be Inside Llewyn Davis or The Great Beauty or Blue Is the Warmest Color or Nebraska. Never mind that it was only Day 9 and that the actual awards dont take place until Sunday evening. For many, the 66th Cannes Film Festival was leveling off toward another grand finale.

title: The Avenue in Its Well-Behaved Youth
description: Lower Second Avenue isnt much these days, a honky-tonk collection of East Village tenements, not to be mentioned in the same breath as Fifth Avenue, and for a century and a half just another number.

title: As Greek as the Sea
description: The white wine grapes of Greece  with names like moschofilero, roditis and assyrtiko  sound a bit scary, like alien beings. But I think of them as the constituents of a parallel universe in which crowds of people embrace these wonderfully refreshing, intriguing whites, rather than default to generic summer white wines like pinot grigio. I imagine this for the assyrtiko, especially.

title: Spare Times for Children for May 24-30
description: WAVE HILL

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Racing the Machines and Twitter Brain Surgery
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Senate Confirms a Judge, but Rancor Remains
description: WASHINGTON  Frustrations in the Senate over the slow pace of approval for President Obamas second-term cabinet deepened Thursday even as the Senate voted 97 to 0 to confirm Mr. Obamas nominee for a long-vacant seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: Boy Scouts Lift Ban on Gay Youth
description: Voting members of the Boy Scouts of Americas National Council cast their ballots today in support of a resolution to allow openly gay boys to join scouting troops.

title: Boy Scouts End Longtime Ban on Openly Gay Youths
description: GRAPEVINE, Tex.  The Boy Scouts of America on Thursday ended its longstanding policy of forbidding openly gay youths to participate in its activities, a step its chief executive called compassionate, caring and kind.

title: This Weeks Movies: May 24, 2013
description: The New York Times critics on Before Midnight, Fill the Void and We Steal Secrets: The Story of Wikileaks.

title: Spare Times for May 24-30
description: MEMORIAL DAY PARADES

title: Kalimotxo: A Poor Mans Sangria
description: This Basque-country classic is an easy-to-make twist on sangria, without all the fruit chopping.

title: Q & A
description: Too Many Condo Units Rented Out

title: Cantina Band: An Amaro-Tinged Cocktail
description: Cucumber, gin and ginger beer are a few of the ingredients in this summer drink.

title: Reducing Refinancing Expenses
description: New York homeowners looking to refinance an existing mortgage dont have to pay the states mortgage recording tax all over again. Yet they may end up doing so if their lenders dont cooperate.

title: One Built a Pipeline for Secrets, and the Other Pumped Them Out
description: The title of Alex Gibneys new documentary contains what sounds like a cheeky ad slogan for the embattled organization WikiLeaks. In fact, the phrase we steal secrets is spoken by Gen. Michael V. Hayden, a former director of the National Security Agency and the Central Intelligence Agency, when he is explaining how government activities that involve secrets in turn require secrecy.

title: Losing a Boyfriend, the Best Way Possible
description: I was married for one week and already felt like an authority on the subject. On April 1, 2013, Christopher and I took the ferry to Staten Island and stood before a dignified and genuinely funny City Hall clerk, while down in Washington the Supreme Court was considering two watershed cases. Gay marriage was seriously trending.

title: The Short Story of Lydia Daviss Man Booker Prize
description: Lydia Davis was awarded the Man Booker International Prize yesterday. Its hard not to be pleased when someone wins a prestigious literary award for writing stories as short as this one:

title: Calming the Anxiety
description: Initial reactions to a drop in Japans stock market leveled off.

title: Old Faces in New Places
description: When a monument wakes up, you notice. Its been more than 40 years since the Metropolitan Museum of Art rethought what many considered its raison dtre, its galleries of European paintings.

title: You Say GIF, I Say GIF
description: Is it GIF with a hard g, or jif like the peanut butter? The Times took to the streets with the co-creator of the popular blog Mr. GIF to find out the answer.

title: Abruptly, She Lets Down Her Hair
description: If you eliminated its obtrusively perky soundtrack and revised its dishonest feel-good ending, The English Teacher would be a very different  and much better  movie. Instead, this would-be comedy, directed by Craig Zisk from a screenplay by the married writers Dan and Stacy Chariton, is perversely determined to make you laugh. Youre more likely to squirm, though, at what seems as incongruous as a Chekhov play staged in clown costume. At least it is not dull.

title: Shrinking Corporate Tax Base
description: The contribution of corporations to the government has been shrinking for decades, encouraged more recently by a shift among millions of companies to avoid the corporate income tax altogether and pay through the individual income tax code.

title: Tiny Folk in a Big War of Good Versus Evil
description: As you watch its characters zoom through a lush forest on the backs of hummingbirds, the gorgeous 3-D adventure comedy Epic suggests a warmer, fuzzier Avatar, with a green heart. Directed by Chris Wedge, the movie is a hymn to nature rendered in phantasmagoric detail as refined as anything Ive seen in a computer-animated family film. But as beautiful as it is, Epic is fatally lacking in visceral momentum and dramatic edge.

title: North of Berlin, a Quiet Land of Lakes
description: When I moved to Berlin more than a decade ago, I read that what seemed to be hundreds of construction cranes across the city could swerve and escalate in tandem, a triumphant chorus of reunification and progress. There was a lot of talk back then about what the new country would look like and how East Germany would reinvent itself.

title: Rick Atkinson to Write Trilogy about the American Revolution
description: Having conquered the best-seller lists with his trilogy about World War II, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author Rick Atkinson will be taking three-book aim at another conflict: the American Revolution.

title: A Circle of Life Exit
description: Ive worked closely with my boss for four years. He has been a really generous mentor, but Ive gone about as far as I can at our company. Recently, I was offered an amazing position by a competitor, and I took it. I expected a difficult conversation with my boss, but nothing like what I got. He practically said, You are dead to me. What should I do? I feel terrible and unsure of myself.

title: Alabama Republican to Retire From House
description: Representative Jo Bonner, Republican of Alabama, will resign from Congress this fall to take a job at the University of Alabama.

title: A Sidewalk Mystery, Solved
description: Soon after the new year, Jonathan Lipsmeyer noticed something strange and new at the corner of Atlantic Avenue and Court Street in Brooklyn, where two of the boroughs busier commercial strips meet.

title: Do They Want to Go Faster? Yes, Indeed
description: Your auto insurance policy probably has clauses specifying whether you are covered for damage from missiles, falling objects, riots, civil war, earthquakes, hail, radioactive contamination, discharge of a nuclear weapon. But its time once again to check that it also addresses whether you are insured against accidentally driving onto the set of a Fast & Furious movie.

title: Liechtenstein Rising
description: Of the 24 players in the final round of womens singles qualifying at the 2013 French Open, there are a lot of the usual suspects. Three Americans. Three Russians. Three Czechs. But on the uppermost line of the draw, the letters LIE signal a new arrival: Stephanie Vogt, of tiny, landlocked Liechtenstein (population 36,000).

title: Orb Looking Good, but Belmont Status Still in Question
description: The Belmont Stakes is a little over two weeks away, and the big question is whether Orb, the impressive Kentucky Derby winner who faltered in the Preakness, will compete. If he does, the race will be cast as a showdown between the Derby winner and the Preakness winner, Oxbow, and will help the race gain some needed buzz.

title: A Fresh Home for Familiar Paintings
description: Photos from the new European galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Greek Hero in an All-American Tale
description: Inspired by true events, A Green Story is like the tribute reel at a retirement dinner. Or a lengthy advertisement for Earth Friendly Products, whose retired founders achievement it celebrates. But however you might describe it, A Green Story cannot be applauded for its moral complexity. This stately film lays out the good, the bad, the sad and the proud in stark patterns, to mostly soporific effect.

title: Neighborhood Joint: Connollys
description: Connollys, a sprawling Irish pub on West 45th Street, offers a taste of the bayou near Times Square.

title: Its Not About You
description: Brad DeLong and Dan Drezner wearily continue the policing of Michael Kinsley. Ill leave it in their hands. But may I say that there is a serious pundit lesson here  namely, that its not about you.

title: Perfect Together, but Alas, They Must Part
description: If we learned anything at all from Avatar, its that insulting the intelligence of the audience is no guarantee of a films downfall. Which is good news for A Wedding Invitation, a Pan-Asian romantic melodrama that virtually pokes you in the eye with its fakery. After going to the trouble of hiring attractive stars, placing them in glossy locations and photographing everything with the slickness of a BP public relations campaign, the South Korean director Oh Ki-hwan sacrifices all to a story (by Qin Haiyan) less grounded in reality than a convention of alien abductees.

title: Amid the Din, Les Bons Temps Rouler
description: Its Saturday night in Times Square, and on the top floor of a sprawling Irish pub called Connollys, a driving Zydeco band is in full cry: accordion, fiddle, bass, washboard, drums and a saxophone. Several dozen couples try to master a peculiar dance step rarely seen outside of southwest Louisiana. A handful of regulars has it down; its a sort of buoyant three-step shuffle. Others are catching on quickly, while a rhythmically challenged few totter around, content to avoid pileups.

title: Dissertation Tests a Grad Students Sanity
description: Anyone who has ever confronted a dissertation deadline with blank pages and a paralyzed mind will identify with Nancy, Please, a darkly comic psychodrama about academic pressure and irrational paranoia.

title: Restoring a Sag Harbor Eyesore
description: SAG HARBOR  From what will be the rooftop terrace of a penthouse at the transformed Bulova Watchcase factory here, the sweeping views of church steeples, Main Street shops, Peconic Bay and the port of this historic maritime village resemble a William Merritt Chase landscape painting. The vistas are the crowning glory of the long-awaited $40 million restoration and retrofit of the 1881 factory into a 64-unit luxury condominium complex.

title: Rule on Serving Olive Oil Stirs Ridicule and Anger in Europe
description: BRUSSELS  With the European economy reeling from austerity and joblessness, the European Union took time last week to focus on something rather smaller in scale: it approved a measure that would ban restaurants from serving olive oil in cruets or dipping bowls.

title: Bid in France to Add Courses in English Raises Fear for Language
description: PARIS  The reaction was loud, swift and fierce this week to a proposed law that would allow French universities to teach more of their courses in English, a measure that a well-known scholar had called a suicidal project that would lead to Frances sacrificing its language to Americanization disguised as globalization.

title: Saturday Night Benefit Planned for Coney Island Mermaid Parade
description: What do Amanda Palmer, Abel Ferrara, Alt-Variety Magazine and Insectavora, the fire-eating tattooed lady, have in common? All of them will join forces on Saturday night at a fundraising benefit to support this years endangered Mermaid Parade in Coney Island.

title: In Tax Overhaul Debate, Large vs. Small Companies
description: In Americas contentious tax reform debate, it is seen as C-Suite versus Main Street.

title: British Attack Suspect Followed Fringe Preacher Once Considered a Laughingstock
description: As my colleagues John F. Burns and Alan Cowell report, one of the two knife-wielding assailants who killed an off-duty soldier in London on Wednesday, who then calmly spoke to witnesses while waiting for the police to arrive, has been identified as Michael Adebolajo, a Briton of Nigerian heritage who converted to Islam about a decade ago.

title: Gun Manufacturers Say Assault Weapons Ban May Push Them Out of Connecticut
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn.  In a state desperate to maintain and revive its industrial base, Mark Malkowski thinks he should be getting gold stars.

title: Orioles Reliever Says, Go, Rangers!
description: BALTIMORE  Orioles reliever Jim Johnson was asked Tuesday whether he had a few moments to discuss the Rangers-Boston Bruins playoff series.

title: Accolades for German Party on Anniversary, but Votes? Perhaps Not
description: LEIPZIG, Germany  It is a sign of the challenges facing the Social Democratic Party in Germany that when it celebrated its 150th anniversary on Thursday, the two guests of honor were a struggling foreign socialist leader, President Franois Hollande of France, and the socialists main domestic opponent, Chancellor Angela Merkel.

title: Content Marketing Beckons to an Executive From a Digital Agency
description: THE expression People vote with their feet was not coined on, or about, Madison Avenue. Still, in the advertising business, the jobs that top executives change agencies to take can signal potential areas of growth for the industry  or, at least, areas they believe will provide them, and clients, lucrative opportunities.

title: Director of Hirshhorn Museum Resigns Over Stalled Bubble Project
description: Richard Koshalek, the director of the Smithsonian Institutions Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, said on Thursday that he was resigning after the board of trustees failed to reach a consensus on the future of a long-planned project to cover the museums interior courtyard with a temporary inflatable bubble.

title: Obama Lifts Moratorium on Transfer of Detainees
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday lifted a moratorium on repatriating low-level inmates from the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, to Yemen and, in a surprise move, announced the creation of a new Pentagon position to spearhead the transfer of detainees.

title: 4 SAC Executives Subpoenaed in Insider Trading Inquiry
description: Four senior executives of the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors have received subpoenas to testify before a grand jury as part of the governments intensifying investigation into insider trading at the firm, according to people briefed on the case.

title: Detective Convicted of Attempted Murder in Queens
description: A veteran New York City police detective once assigned to the mayors security team was convicted of attempted murder and reckless endangerment on Thursday for shooting a man while off duty, the Queens district attorney said.

title: Suicide Bombings in Niger Kill Dozens in Dual Strikes
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Two groups of suicide bombers rammed vehicles full of explosives into a military base and a French-owned uranium mine 150 miles away in the West African desert nation of Niger early Thursday, killing at least 26 people, including 21 soldiers and five bombers, Nigerien officials said. They said a sixth bomber appeared to be holding several Nigerien soldiers hostage inside the base.

title: Griffin, Although Unable to Show Off His Speed, Proves He Can Still Thrill
description: ASHBURN, Va.  Robert Griffin III, clad in burgundy shorts and a long-sleeve shirt, took a five-step drop, planted his surgically repaired right leg and unleashed a sharp spiral toward a teammate downfield. Dozens of cameras clicked. Reporters scribbled notes. It was, as far as these things go, a pretty big deal.

title: New Strife in Darfur Leaves Many Seeking Refuge
description: ZAM ZAM CAMP, Sudan  They are the new faces in a place they would rather not be, and the meager scraps sheltering them from the blazing desert sun are a testament to their sudden arrival: tents of scruffy tarpaulin propped up on crooked wood branches no higher than four feet tall.

title: Turning Lives Around, and Saving the State Money
description: From age 12 on, Teofilo Ramos had been a great worker: delivery boy, day laborer, soup kitchen chef, reliable hand at drywall, trusted caretaker in a Hasidic village. So it was no surprise that he wound up at midlife behind the counter of a deli on Rockaway Beach Boulevard in Far Rockaway, Queens  12 hours a day, six days a week, drawing coffee from an urn, and slicing meat and swabbing floors.

title: Prefab Lives!
description: Its an exciting time for modular building, especially in New York, and as someone who has been deeply immersed in the world of prefabrication for over a decade, I am glad to see the much-maligned building technology finding its proper niche. Its the killer app for the modular industry.

title: Five Americans in Paris
description: PARIS  On a cool and blustery afternoon, Jack Sock, 20, of Lincoln, Neb., won his second qualifying match at Roland Garros and found himself surrounded by French teenagers bearing cellphone cameras.

title: Seasides Last Summer?
description: SEASIDE PARK, N.J.  LAST summer, three months before Hurricane Sandy, before the bay flooded Seaside Park and the ocean razed the boardwalk in Seaside Heights, my grandfather passed away. For six decades, he had been a central figure down the shore, the owner of Sonnys & Rickeys Arcade, a man generous to the scores he befriended and formidable to the hundreds he employed. I was his namesake, so the honor of writing his eulogy fell to me. So I wrote it and read it, and hoped some justice had been done to what wed lost. Then the local police led his funeral procession along the length of the boardwalk, from Seaside Park to Seaside Heights.

title: Abuse Victim Seeks Ouster of U.S. Swimming Officials
description: A woman who was sexually abused as a teenager in the 1980s by a Hall of Fame swimming coach used the occasion of his sentencing Thursday to demand the departure of three leaders in USA Swimming who she said knew about the coachs misconduct and failed to act.

title: The Corporate Tax Dodge
description: WHILE a Senate report detailing Apples aggressive tax sheltering of billions of dollars of overseas income grabbed headlines this week, little notice was paid to a surreptitious thrust at tax minimization that was announced at nearly the same moment.

title: A Cyberattack Campaign for Syria
description: WASHINGTON  LAST week Syrians lost access to the Internet for the second time in a month. While the Assad regime claims the lapses were the result of a faulty network link, the evidence suggests that they were deliberate efforts by the government to hamper the oppositions ability to communicate inside the country and with the outside world.

title: Scoutings Move Toward Equality
description: The Boy Scouts of America voted on Thursday to discard part of its discriminatory policies about gay Americans and to allow openly gay boys to participate in its activities. The decision was made by about 1,400 delegates attending a national convention in Grapevine, Tex. It was a major step for one of the countrys oldest and most influential youth organizations that as recently as a year ago rejected any change in its membership policies.

title: Japan the Model
description: A generation ago, Japan was widely admired  and feared  as an economic paragon. Business best sellers put samurai warriors on their covers, promising to teach you the secrets of Japanese management; thrillers by the likes of Michael Crichton portrayed Japanese corporations as unstoppable juggernauts rapidly consolidating their domination of world markets.

title: Lottery Numbers
The U.S., Russia and Syria
description: To the Editor:

title: Cervical Cancer Vaccine
description: To the Editor:

title: Paths to Reliable Medical Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: The Genocide Trial of Guatemalas Former Dictator
description: To the Editor:

title: Miamis High-Flying, Low-Key Role Player
description: MIAMI  The Birdman is most comfortable when he is soaring above the chaos, over the rim, poised to swat the basketball away or to slam it home. Elevation has always suited him best.

title: New Terror Strategy Shifts C.I.A. Focus Back to Spying
description: WASHINGTON  For more than seven years, Mike  a lean, chain-smoking officer at the Central Intelligence Agencys headquarters in Virginia  has managed the agencys deadly campaign of armed drone strikes. As the head of the C.I.A.s Counterterrorism Center, Mike wielded tremendous power in hundreds of decisions over who lived and died in far-off lands.

title: Congress Stepping Up Its Efforts Against Sexual Assault in Military
description: WASHINGTON  House Speaker John A. Boehner on Thursday called the rise of sexual assaults in the military a national disgrace as lawmakers in both chambers of Congress moved closer this week to legislation to address the problem.

title: NOAA Predicts Extremely Active Hurricane Season
description: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration issued its 2013 Atlantic hurricane outlook on Thursday, with a warning that the United States could be hit by up to six major hurricanes this year. The seasonal average is three.

title: Abruptly, P.&G. Chief Ends Career of 33 Years
description: In a surprise move, Procter & Gamble, the worlds biggest consumer products company, said on Thursday that its chief executive had resigned and was being replaced by his predecessor, Alan G. Lafley.

title: Taxi Fleet Owner Files Complaint Against Bloomberg
description: He took control of New York Citys public schools. Got smoking banned from bars and restaurants. Even the specter of term limits was not too daunting a barrier for him to make a third run at New York Citys highest office.

title: In Myanmar Outpost, a Fading Orwellian Link
description: KATHA, Myanmar  George Orwell created his first novel, Burmese Days, a scathing portrait of the imperious attitudes of the British, from this former colonial outpost on the banks of the mighty Irrawaddy River. His brutish characters swilled too much whiskey at a whites-only club, and wilted in the vaporous heat. A train that crawled through the jungle from Mandalay provided a lifeline to the outside world.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 24, 2013
description: Our systematic effort to dismantle terrorist organizations must continue. But this war, like all wars, must end. Thats what history advises. Its what our democracy demands.

title: Banks Lobbyists Help in Drafting Financial Bills
description: WASHINGTON  Bank lobbyists are not leaving it to lawmakers to draft legislation that softens financial regulations. Instead, the lobbyists are helping to write it themselves.

title: Twitter Lets Brands Reach Viewers of Their TV Ads
description: For those inclined toward social media, using Twitter while watching television has become a ritual, with viewers commenting on everything from sports events to nighttime dramas. On Thursday, executives from Twitter discussed how they planned to capitalize on that activity by allowing advertisers to send ads to people who are watching specific programming.

title: California Puts Tentative Price on Health Policies Under New Law
description: California, widely seen as a model for how individuals will buy health insurance under the new health care law, announced Thursday that 13 insurers had been chosen to sell policies through the insurance marketplace  or exchange  being created under the law.

title: Obama, in Nod to Press, Orders Review of Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama ordered a review on Thursday of the Justice Departments procedures for legal investigations involving reporters, acknowledging that he was troubled that multiple inquiries into national security leaks could chill investigative reporting.

title: Pressure Mounts on Vaunted Secrecy of Switzerlands Banks
description: GENEVA  Now that Luxembourg and Austria have given ground on bank secrecy rules, the spotlight has turned to Switzerland, a country famous for the anonymity it provides in equal measure to the rich, the famous and those who want to hide their money.

title: Post-Hurricane Aquarium to Partly Reopen With Lower Cost and Half the Animals
description: A sea lion named Clio swam to the edge of her pool for a look at a passer-by. Inside an exhibition building, a diver in scuba gear scrubbed a rock formation as queen angelfish and cownose rays glided past.

title: One Perhaps Having One Too Many
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Well, heres the deal: Im all for innovation and for pushing the envelope to see where the future of puzzles might be, but to put it nicely, Im not convinced that this is it. Sorry, Joe Krozel. I think youve jumped the cruciverbal shark on this one. I may be in the minority here, but Ill explain my position.

title: Corrections: May 24, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Its Streets Are Paved With Drama
description: Theres this funny thing that can occur when youre watching a play, a development in that hazy somewhere between suspension of, and stymieing of, disbelief. It happens when enough of a world has been created onstage so that you care about it and the people who inhabit it  and then something goes awry, stops short or simply parts ways with your own sensibilities, so that you feel that an injustice has been done to that world by the same people who made you care about it in the first place. Excitement withers, followed by creeping frustration.

title: Heckled by an Activist, but Getting the Last Word
description: WASHINGTON  At times on Thursday, it seemed President Obama was taking part in a debate rather than giving a speech.

title: Holiday on Monday: Memorial Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Kerry Meets With Israelis and Palestinians to Revive Peace Process
description: JERUSALEM  Injecting a sense of urgency into his mission to revive the moribund peace process, Secretary of State John Kerry held a round of meetings Thursday with Israeli and Palestinian leaders.

title: Yahoos Design Chief to Depart
description: Tim Parsey, the senior vice president of user experience design at Yahoo, is leaving the company, he said in an interview Thursday.

title: Opposition Discusses Its Approach to Syria Talks
description: ISTANBUL  Members of Syrias main political opposition group on Thursday began three days of talks to elect a new leader and formulate their positions before an expected international conference in Geneva next month that is meant to pave the way for negotiations on a possible transitional government in Syria.

title: A Wife With Powerful Ties Is an Unexpected Architect of a New York Comeback
description: When Chelsea Clinton wanted to make a low-key visit to the hurricane-stricken Rockaways last fall, she arranged to take a trip with her close friend Huma Abedin, a longtime aide to Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Little Bit of Luck Helps Rangers Keep Brooms Away
description: The game, the series, their season  they all very nearly ended for the Rangers on Thursday night, but maybe this is how their revival begins. With the opposing goaltender sprawled on the ice, decked by an invisible force, as the puck slides into the net. With one of the leagues best defensemen gifting a goal on a careless play. With a makeshift lineup, assembled as if by a hunch, withstanding surge after surge.

title: In Review of Brooklyn Cases, So Many Obstacles
description: To determine whether Shabaka Shakur was wrongfully convicted of double-murder almost 25 years ago, investigators need to locate an elusive eyewitness, a parolee with a history of substance abuse whom nobody has been able to find.

title: A Final Peek at Bloombergs Tax Returns
description: It is so hard to keep track. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg bought a 12th residence last year, but his staff overlooked it when first explaining his finances to reporters.

title: Bonnie Faubus Salcido, Who Opposed Segregationist Brother, Dies at 93
description: Bonnie Faubus Salcido, a sister of Gov. Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas and the only member of his family to openly oppose him for trying to block the integration of Little Rock Central High School during the Souths racial troubles of the 1950s, died on May 9 in Fresno, Calif. She was 93.

title: Obama Defies Critics With State Dept. Choice
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama defied Republican critics on Thursday by nominating to a high-ranking State Department job an official involved in editing controversial talking points about the attack last year in Libya.

title: Steve Forrest, Performer on Film and TVs S.W.A.T., Dies at 87
description: Steve Forrest, a strapping actor known to television viewers as Lt. Dan Harrelson on the 1970s action series S.W.A.T., died on Saturday in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 87.

title: Mets Hefner and Yankees Wells Are Symbols of Their Teams Seasons
description: Although the Mets have won the World Series twice, a total that eight active teams cannot match, their fans have taken a battering over the years and are generally resigned to the notion that their team will usually not be any good and that the ball will rarely bounce the Mets way. This season, they may have a point. Memorial Day has yet to arrive and already the Mets sit 10 games out of first in the National League East, even though Matt Harvey has emerged as one of the best pitchers in baseball.

title: Racing the Clock and a Storm: A Way of Life in Tornado Alley
description: MOORE, Okla.  A half-hour  maybe.

title: Civil Rights Firebrands Fraud Case in Georgia Now Has Others Treading Softly
description: MARIETTA, Ga.  In the state where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was born and a legacy of lynching still informs politics, it is never easy to suggest that a leader of the civil rights movement might be a thief.

title: Debating Doctors Compensation
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Winning Goal by Kreider Offers Flashback to 2012
description: The Rangers needed something close to a miracle to stay alive against the Boston Bruins. Seven minutes into overtime Thursday night, Chris Kreider provided the intervention they were seeking.

title: Word of the Day | glutinous
description: glutinous \glt-ns, gl-t-ns\ adjective

title: S.E.C. Changes Continue as Obama Names 2 Senate Aides for Posts
description: President Obama continued his shake-up of the Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday, naming two Senate aides to senior posts at the Wall Street regulatory agency.

title: Iginla Adds a Veterans Touch to the Penguins Run
description: OTTAWA  With only two goals in nine games entering Wednesday, Jarome Iginla was causing some to wonder when he would find the back of the net again.

title: Partial Labrum Tear for Anthony
description: The left shoulder injury that bothered Carmelo Anthony throughout the playoffs turned out to be a partial tear of his labrum, according to a magnetic resonance imaging examination taken this week.

title: GTT
description: DALLAS

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) AUDRA McDONALD IN CONCERT: GO BACK HOME In this Live From Lincoln Center season finale, recorded on May 9 at Avery Fisher Hall, Ms. McDonald, above  the five-time Tony Award winner and the host of this PBS series  performs works from Go Back Home, her first solo album in seven years. The playlist features songs by Rodgers & Hammerstein, Adam Guettel, Michael John LaChiusa, Adam Gwon and Stephen Sondheim, who once hailed Ms. McDonalds voice as one of the glories of the American theater.

title: Game 4: Rangers vs. Bruins
description: Chris Kreider scored in overtime as the Rangers staved off elimination.

title: Crusade for Term Limits Brings Together Some Unlikely Allies
description: For proponents of term limits in Texas  a group that defies partisan stereotyping  May has been a disappointing month on the state and local levels.

title: The Joys of No Income Tax, the Agonies of Other Kinds
description: When Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana wanted to sell his plan to replace his states income tax with a higher sales tax, he pointed to Texas as both the problem and the solution.

title: Sprinter Aiming for Olympics as a Rugby Player
description: LONDON  Carlin Isles once competed against Tyson Gay and Justin Gatlin while trying to become an Olympic track athlete. Now 23, Isles has abandoned that goal. Sort of. He might make it to the 2016 Summer Games in Rio de Janeiro, but not on the track.

title: News Quiz | May 24, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: With Session Ending, Perry Takes the Reins
description: Look at your calendar. Its about to be Perry time.

title: Champions League Preview: History and Redemption on Line for Bayern
description: For a team that has lost five of its last six Champions League finals, Bayern Munich has no shortage of motivation going into Saturdays game against Borussia Dortmund at Wembley.

title: An Agreement Opens Some Chinese Audit Papers to the U.S.
description: Accounting regulators in the United States and China announced on Friday in Beijing that they had reached an understanding that could give American fraud investigators access to work papers of Chinese audit firms. Until now, American efforts to see such papers have been rejected.

title: Champions League Preview: Dortmund Resilience Will Be Tested Without Gtze
description: Well, this is it. The pinnacle 90 minutes of any clubs season. On Saturday in London, Borussia Dortmund tackles the hardest challenge it is ever likely to meet: the opportunity to win the UEFA Champions League against the biggest of German rivals, Bayern Munich.

title: Once Again, the Heat Are Not the Knicks
description: MIAMI  To advance to the Eastern Conference finals, all the Indiana Pacers had to do was turn up the defensive pressure, prod Carmelo Anthony and J.R. Smith into tough shots and wait for the Knicks supporting cast to wilt. Containing the Miami Heat, however, is an entirely different task, as Pacers Coach Frank Vogel made clear on Thursday, while taking a slight dig at the Knicks.

title: Weiner Joins the Fray
description: Anthony D. Weiner, the former congressman who was forced from office after a texting scandal, re-emerged on New York's political stage when he appeared in the Bronx at a forum for mayoral candidates.

title: IHT Quick Read: May 24
description: NEWS President Barack Obama on Thursday said he would impose a higher standard on the use of drone strikes, and he sought to renew his effort to close the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. Peter Baker reports from Washington.

title: After Grisly Death, Scrutiny on British Security Agency
description: LONDON  Pressure mounted on Friday for MI5, Britains domestic security agency, to explain how two men with years of involvement with extremist Islamic groups were left free to kill an off-duty soldier this week, striking him with their car in a London suburb and then hacking him repeatedly with butchers cleavers.

title: 5 Climbers Feared Dead on Himalayan Peak
description: HONG KONG  Five climbers, including a noted Hungarian mountaineer, are missing and feared dead after apparently trying to descend from the worlds third-highest mountain, Nepalese officials said Friday.

title: Beyond the Swimming Pool: The Checkered History of Chlorine
