description: PARIS  When golden poppies blanket the hills of Northern California, its the annual season to dispatch my daughter  a summertime American  for home.

title: The Early Word: Calculations
description: In Todays Times

title: Kljestan: Back in U.S. Camp, and Back in the Champions League
description: CLEVELAND  As the United States national team prepares to start its busy summer with an exhibition on Wednesday night against a powerful Belgian team, the game will have added meaning for Sacha Kljestan since he will be facing off against some familiar faces.

title: The Next Kevin Brownlow Drafts Her Summer Plans
description: The Douglas Fairbanks Jr. of 1928 and the Douglas Fairbanks Jr. of 1929 are not so different to me. In fact, when I think of him, even in his old age, he is always young, a well-preserved specimen of modern manhood, perpetually 23 and dashing as the day is long.

title: Rocket and Gun Attacks Add to Fears That Syrias Strife Is Reaching Lebanon
description: HERMEL, Lebanon  Four rockets hit this village near the Syrian border on Tuesday afternoon, badly wounding a woman who was sitting under an olive tree in her yard, residents said. Shortly before, gunmen killed three Lebanese soldiers at a border checkpoint in the Bekaa Valley, adding to fears that the crisis in Syria is spilling into Lebanon.

title: Daily Report: The Fast-Approaching Future of Driverless Cars
description: Last month, on a freeway from Jerusalem to the Dead Sea, John Markoff sat in the drivers seat of an Audi A7 while software connected to a video camera on the windshield drove the car at speeds up to 65 miles an hour  making a singular statement about the rapid progress in the development of self-driving cars, he writes in The New York Times.

title: China Divides Europe in Fight Against Tariffs
description: HONG KONG  Adroitly alternating the threat of a trade war with the lure of its huge import market, China appears to have driven a deep wedge between Germany and the rest of the European Union. And it may even have caused a rift within the German business world.

title: This Week in Small Business: Be a Plumber
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: The Case for a Profit Motive in Conserving the Environment
description: I think you may appreciate this recent chat I had with Mark Tercek, the president of The Nature Conservancy and co-author of Natures Fortune: How Business and Society Thrive by Investing in Nature.

title: Europe Seeks to Press Russia and Syria on Arms
description: PARIS  The European Unions decision to lift its arms embargo on Syria, after a bitter, 13-hour debate in Brussels, is intended to put pressure on Russia and President Bashar al-Assad of Syria before peace talks scheduled in Geneva next month, with a message that the West will not allow the rebels to be defeated, senior European diplomats said Tuesday.

title: China Adds Sparkle to Champagne Sales
description: LONDON  Frances Champagne producers will doubtless be raising a glass or two this week to toast a decision by authorities in China, one of their fastest growing overseas markets, to recognize the uniqueness of their product.

title: Hope Amid the Dams and Dangers
description: Jeff Opperman, a senior freshwater scientist with the Nature Conservancy, took a once-in-a-lifetime trip down the Mekong River in Southeast Asia with his wife and two children, ages 8 and 10. This is his final post. Previous posts can be found here.

title: Tuesday Reading: The New Rules for Sunscreen
Despite Wades Decline in Scoring, Nobody Is Counting Him Out
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Miami Heat Coach Erik Spoelstra went out of his way on Monday, as he has done many times the past three seasons, to paint a glowing picture of Chris Bosh. Describing Boshs role, Spoelstra said, Its to be our most important player, the way he always is.

title: Masterworks for One and All
description: AMSTERDAM  Many museums post their collections online, but the Rijksmuseum here has taken the unusual step of offering downloads of high-resolution images at no cost, encouraging the public to copy and transform its artworks into stationery, T-shirts, tattoos, plates or even toilet paper.

title: In Performance: Larry Pine in Death of Walt Disney
description: Larry Pine plays the title character in Lucas Hnaths new play, A Public Reading of an Unproduced Screenplay About the Death of Walt Disney, a darkly comic riff on the Disney legacy. In this scene Walt talks about some of the celebrities, politicians and evildoers who were fans of Disney films. The show continues through June 9 at SoHo Rep.

title: I Spy on the Train
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Truth About Millennials (in Boomer Eyes)
description: Will boomer writers please give millennials a break?

title: In Stock Offering, Coty Seeks Up to $1 Billion
description: Coty sees plenty of investor appetite for celebrity-branded cosmetics, disclosing on Tuesday that it was hoping to raise as much as $1 billion from its forthcoming initial public offering.

title: Europe Warns Google It Could Face Further Concessions
description: BRUSSELS  The European Unions top antitrust official warned Google on Tuesday that the American company might need to make further concessions to settle a case concerning its hugely lucrative online search and advertising businesses.

title: Peace Talks With Syria
description: Complications on the rise for the coming Syria peace talks.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Advertising Hall of Achievement, Washington, which honors industry professionals ages 40 and younger, selected its inductees for 2013. They are Adam Bain, president for global revenue at Twitter; B. Bonin Bough, vice president for global media and consumer engagement, Mondelez International; Robert Candelino, vice president of branding for skin care, Unilever; Tara Walpert Levy, managing director for ads marketing at Google and YouTube; Lynn Lewis, global managing partner, J3 UM, part of Universal McCann; Todd Pendleton, chief marketing officer at Samsung Telecommunications America; and Emmanuel Seuge, head of global sports and entertainment at the Coca-Cola Company. Ms. Lewis will also receive the Jack Avrett Volunteer Spirit Award, for public service. The honors are to be presented on Nov. 5 at a luncheon at the Beverly Hilton hotel.

title: The Cloud Company: People or Money?
description: Online technologies have made us question lots of assumptions. What is privacy? Which is better, ownership or sharing? Is the crowd wiser than a lone genius?

title: A Ferrari Extravaganza at the RM Villa Erba Auction
description: CERNOBBIO, Italy  A Ferrari works racecar driven by three world champions  a Pininfarina-sculpted 1953 340/375 MM Berlinetta Competizione  sold at an RM Auctions event held here Saturday for a stunning $12,812,800.

title: Procyclical Policy for Germany
description: OK, like Brad DeLong, Id like to move on. Lets stipulate that:

title: Seeking an Exit From Uranium
description: The world leader in uranium enrichment, Urenco, is plumply profitable and has at least 10 years of steady work lined up. So why is it up for sale?

title: No Partisan Fire at the Shore: An Obama-Christie Reunion
description: POINT PLEASANT BEACH, N.J.  Politics makes strange beachfellows. President Obama and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey affirmed this notion, and enjoyed its benefits, on Tuesday in a drizzly reunion on the Jersey Shore, seven months after Hurricane Sandy punished the famous coastline and united them in an unlikely political partnership.

title: A Worried Israel Prepares for War
description: TEL AVIV  Six months ago, as rocket fire was falling on Tel Aviv, my six-year-old daughter had to pay her first visit to a bomb shelter. On Monday, she had to pay her second and third visits.

title: What Were Reading
description: Westchester Magazine: Classic hot dogs. Artisanal hot dogs. Hot dogs topped with peanut butter and grape jelly.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Indictment of Liberty Reserve S.A. on Charges of Money Laundering
description: Read the full indictment of Liberty Reserve S.A. on charges of money laundering.

title: Found Poem Favorite | The City Went Soft
description: Almost 1,000 people took us up on the challenge we issued in our Fourth Annual Found Poem Student Contest to make verse from any Times article or articles they liked. It took us weeks to choose our favorites, but weve finally settled on 12.

title: Dance in the Birthplace of Pesto
description: BOGLIASCO, Italy  The Ligurian region of Italy is better known for its magnificent coastline and its delicious cuisine (the birthplace of pesto!) than for dance. But Danza Contempo Ligure, a small festival based in Genoa, suggests that there is no shortage of choreographic activity. The final day of the new weeklong festival took place in Bogliasco, a small coastal village just beyond the Genoa city limits. The location was the Villa dei Pini, the grand house that belongs to the Bogliasco Foundation, an organization that provides residencies to artists and humanities scholars, and the participating choreographers made fine use of the villas beautiful gardens and coastal location despite unseasonally chilly weather.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Daniel Bergner on the Female Viagra
description: Daniel Bergner, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this weeks cover story about the development of a pill to stimulate female desire. His new book, What Do Women Want?: Adventures in the Science of Female Desire comes out next week.

title: SAC Could Give the Justice Dept. a High-Value Target
description: The subpoenas issued to executives at SAC Capital Advisors to testify before a grand jury provide a powerful indication that prosecutors have made the firm the focus of their latest effort to crack down on insider trading. Unfortunately for SAC, it may also be a case of being in the wrong place at the wrong time.

title: The Challenges of Raising Prices and Competing With Online Retailers
description: At the last She Owns It Business Group meeting, the owners talked about several issues related to pricing. This post focuses on the prices charged by the two family businesses in the group, and the particular challenges of selling a product that is sold online for less.

title: Home Prices Rise, Putting Country in Buying Mood
description: Americans are in a buying mood, thanks largely to the housing recovery.

title: The Gun Report: Memorial Day Edition
description: Remember 6-month-old Jonylah Watkins, who was shot and killed on March 11 while sitting in her fathers lap in a minivan in Chicago? Authorities said Monday that the man accused in the shooting, which also wounded her father, was seeking revenge for the theft of a video game console. Koman Willis, a documented gang member with 38 previous arrests, was charged with first-degree murder.

title: Divided Court, in 2 Rulings, Makes It Easier to Challenge Criminal Convictions
description: WASHINGTON  In a pair of 5-to-4 decisions that divided along ideological lines, the Supreme Court on Tuesday made it easier for inmates to challenge their convictions.

title: Indian Cows Find Patrons in U.S.
description: BARSANA, Uttar Pradesh  The cows status as a sacred being in Hinduism is increasingly being threatened as more wealthy Indians, even Hindus, are turning carnivorous, as Gardiner Harris of The New York Times recently reported. Meanwhile, the increasing demand for beef is driving gangs to steal cows that are wandering around Delhi so that the animals can be sold to slaughterhouses.Still, cows have plenty of protectors in India, and even beyond its borders. Thousands of miles away, Indian citizens living in the United States regularly send money to cow shelters in India like Mataji Gaushala, located in Barsana, near Mathura in Uttar Pradesh.

title: New Ways to Use Ancient Grains
description: Ancient grains seems to be a new buzz phrase in the world of whole foods (or maybe Ive been missing something for a long time). The words describe grain varieties that have been eaten as staples for hundreds if not thousands of years. Some of these have fed people in far-flung parts of the world for a very long time but have been of little interest as a food on the American market. Grains like sorghum have been grown here but fed primarily to animals, whereas sorghum has been a staple for centuries in Africa and India.

title: Online Currency Exchange Accused of Laundering $6 Billion
description: The operators of a global currency exchange ran a $6 billion money-laundering operation online, a central hub for criminals trafficking in everything from stolen identities to child pornography, federal prosecutors in New York said on Tuesday.

title: Sorghum Salad With Cucumbers, Avocado and Cherry Tomatoes
description: One thing Ive learned about cooking sturdy grains like this (and the other grains were working with this week) for salads is that they will absorb dressing better if you let them cook until they burst or splay. In the case of sorghum, the grain is done after 50 minutes, but if you let it go for another 10 the grains will burst and the lemon juice and olive oil wont slide off.

title: Mack Emerman, Founder of Criteria Recording Studios, Dies at 89
description: Mack Emerman, a jazz lover whose hobby recording bands at nightclubs led him to found Criteria Recording Studios in Miami, where dozens of celebrated pop and rock records were made, died on May 17 in Miami Beach. He was 89.

title: Who Will Stay the Longest? Spurs Have Edge on Red Wings
description: For a while this playoff season, the San Antonio Spurs and the Detroit Red Wings were locked in a battle for supremacy in the team that wouldnt go away category and they were taking this battle quite seriously, despite coming at it from vastly different directions. The Red Wings were a somewhat faded version of their dynastic selves, stalwarts having retired and a new generation of players making Wings fans check their programs repeatedly, but still, making the N.H.L. playoffs for a 22nd straight season  and needing a big late-season push to do it  forced everyone to stop and pay homage.

title: Women in Congress Confront the Military on Sexual Assault
description: WASHINGTON  Shocking the gridlocked Congress into action, a half dozen or so bipartisan female senators are escalating their war on sexual crimes in the military and deploying their outrage, clout and legions of supporters against a rigid military structure and its male-dominated ranks.

title: A Rare, Pristine Subway Station: See It While You Can
description: Whats spotlessly clean, freshly painted and doesnt have rust stains and grime oozing down the walls like the backdrop of an 80s horror/dystopian future flick? Chances are good that your first answer would not be a New York City subway station (except for some of the stations on the Upper East Side, which dont really count).

title: Image of the Day: May 28
The Only Investing Pattern That Matters Is Behavioral
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at The BAM Alliance. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published this year. His sketches are archivedon the Bucks blog.

title: Anti-Polio Campaign Worker Is Shot Dead in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A volunteer in a polio vaccination campaign was killed and her colleague wounded in an attack by militants near Peshawar on Tuesday, a district administration official said.

title: Popular Governors, and Prospects for 2016
description: Last month, we examined the most unpopular governors facing re-election in 2014. Many of the governors with the poorest job approval ratings were Republicans in Democratic-leaning and swing states.

title: Kipling Letter Says He Borrowed Promiscuously for The Jungle Book
description: While Rudyard Kipling spun beloved characters out of creatures like a bear, a tiger, a snake and a panther for his classic story collection The Jungle Book, he may have been a bit of a vulture himself and made monkeys uncles of his readers  at least according to a letter that suggests he made use of outside sources for a portion of the work.

title: At the Biennale, Venices Locals Stage a Show of Their Own
description: Every other year, the art world descends on Venice for the Biennale, a six-month-long flurry of artistic activity. This years Biennale, which opens for previews tomorrow, comprises an international exhibition, 88 different national pavilions and a host of collateral events and shows. The missing piece of the pie, according to Caroline Corbetta, the curator behind Il Crepaccio, a tiny exhibition space based out of the window of a restaurant in Milan, is the involvement of the young artists who actually live and work in Venice. Every two years their city becomes the real center of the art world, but they draw no particular benefit in terms of visibility, Corbetta said.

title: One Area in Which Congress Excels: Naming Post Offices
description: Pillory Congress all you want as do-nothing or dysfunctional, as its critics often have. But in one respect, lawmakers in the Capitol are remarkably productive: they name post offices like nobodys business.

title: Wheelies: The Happy German Worker Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Tamping Down Expectations on Chinas Growth
description: The prospects for Chinas economy look so challenging for the remainder of 2013 that increasing numbers of usually cheerleading investment bank economists are cutting their rosy growth forecast for China. The release last Thursday of preliminary manufacturing data for May, which surprisingly indicated a contraction in manufacturing activity, was just one more in a series of weak data points.

title: Jarring Injuries Marked Previous Bruins-Penguins Series
description: The Boston Bruins and the Pittsburgh Penguins dont have a lot of playoff history between them. What they do have  at least from the Boston perspective  as they head into the Eastern Conference finals, which starts in Pittsburgh on Saturday night, is a history of cheap shots and dirty plays that felled two Bruins, one of them the widely admired Cam Neely, who was entering the prime of his Hall of Fame career.

title: Seared Tofu With Sugar Snap Peas and Sesame Seeds
description: In Whats for Dinner?, a column appearing every other week on Diners Journal, Melissa Clark answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

title: Rebecca Hall to Make Broadway Debut in Revival of 85-Year-Old Play
description: The British actress Rebecca Hall will make her Broadway debut next winter in a revival of Sophie Treadwells 1928 play, Machinal, playing a young woman who rebels against the cultural norms of 1920s America, Roundabout Theater Company announced on Tuesday. Ms. Hall is a regular presence on London stages, including in several Shakespeare productions directed by her father, Peter Hall. She performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 2009 in the Bridge Project productions of The Winters Tale and The Cherry Orchard.

title: Lulzsec Hacker Pleads Guilty
description: 6:27 p.m. | Updatedwith additional comments from prosecutors and the defendant.

title: Finding the Route to Happiness
description: Travel booking sites have caught on to the fact that people are willing to pay a little extra to avoid headaches like a four-hour layover in Dallas-Fort Worth airport. Hipmunks agony rating, for example, sorts flights by price, duration and the number of stops.

title: Two Globe Reporters Plan Book on Marathon Bombings
description: Two Boston Globe reporters have made a deal to write the definitive book on the Boston marathon bombings and their aftermath, their publisher said on Tuesday.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Our Regulatory System
Judge in Trayvon Martin Case Puts Limits on Defense
description: MIAMI  Lawyers for George Zimmerman, who is charged with second-degree murder in the killing of Trayvon Martin, will be barred from mentioning Mr. Martins marijuana use, history of fights or high school suspension during opening statements in Mr. Zimmermans trial, which begins June 10.

title: Dean in E-Mail Searches Steps Down at Harvard
description: The undergraduate dean at Harvard will step down this summer, she and the university announced on Tuesday, months after she came under fire for her handling of a search of some junior faculty members e-mail accounts.

title: After Day 1, a Look at the Bike Share Program
description: On Monday, New York Citys bike share program finally reached the streets  unlocking 6,000 bikes for public use across more than 300 stations in Manhattan and Brooklyn. With the skies clear and the streets relatively bare because of the Memorial Day holiday, riders engaged in a series of trial runs and joy rides, saving the commuting for Tuesday morning.

title: Hobbled Vandeweghe Falls to Shvedova in First Round
description: PARIS  Coco Vandeweghe shrugged off a disastrous first set but could not overcome a determined Yaroslava Shvedova of Kazakhstan, losing, 0-6, 6-3, 2-6, in a rain-interrupted first-round match at the French Open Tuesday.

title: Obama to Name New Leader of Economic Advisers Council
description: WASHINGTON  The White House is expected to name Jason Furman, the deputy director of the National Economic Council, as the chairman of the presidents Council of Economic Advisers, according to a person familiar with the matter who declined to comment on the record.

title: Grape-Nuts Wants You to Climb Every Mountain
description: A venerable cereal brand is using an anniversary as a way to reintroduce itself as well as to introduce a line extension meant to appeal to more contemporary tastes.

title: Taxing the Rich
description: For my sins (and, yes, an honorarium too), Im doing this. So its worth putting out some of the basics.

title: Incentives to Start a 529 College Savings Plan
description: College graduation season is in full swing, marking an annual rite of passage  and serving as a reminder that higher education isnt getting any cheaper. One option available to help families put away money for college, and avoid borrowing too much, is a 529 college savings plan.

title: The World As Wonkblog Sees It
description: Jonathan Chaits Atlantic profile of Josh Barro, the Bloomberg View blogger and columnist whos gradually transitioned from reform-minded center-right pundit to entertaining scourge of the contemporary G.O.P., has launched a lot of discussion about conservative reform projects in general, and (for my sins) Ill probably write a post or two on that theme later this week. To start with, though, I think its worth saying something in response to this post from Ezra Klein, which uses Barros recent arc as a case study in the Republican Partys intellectual self-marginalization:

title: A Brief, Useless Note On Being Bashed
description: Fairly often I receive comments or other communications asking me to respond to X or Y, who has said Z about me and/or my arguments. For the most part, I am not going to oblige. Why?

title: Returning Wood to the Cooking Fire
description: When Matthew Semmelhack and Mark Liberman, the owners of AQ in San Francisco, open their new restaurant nearby later this year, they wont have a stove. Or an oven.

title: Health Care Is Spread Thin on Alaskan Frontier
description: BETHEL, Alaska  Americans in some rural places fret at how far away big-city medical help might be in an emergency, or at the long drives they are forced to make for prenatal care, or stitches, or chemotherapy.

title: Tough Politics, Easy Math
description: No two governors better represent the Tea Party ethos than Governors Rick Perry of Texas and Jan Brewer of Arizona. As required by the rigid ideology of the far right, the two are pretty much in sync on the major issues of the day  like gun control.

title: After the Thaw: Outdoor Fun in Berlin
description: Berlin might be a young, vibrant, creative city, but during the long, cold dark winter all that youth and vibrancy and creativity is cooped up indoors. This winter was particularly long and cold: average March temperatures were below freezing and it snowed on Good Friday.

title: Haas Happy to Escape First Round at a Major
description: PARIS Tommy Haas of Germany raced to a 7-6 (4), 6-1, 6-3 victory over Guillaume Rufin of France on Tuesday to reach the second round of the French Open.

title: Bankia Shares Tumble After a New Stock Issue
description: MADRID  Shares in Bankia, the giant Spanish mortgage lender that was at the heart of the countrys banking crisis, fell sharply on Tuesday after a large share issue that was meant to herald a new start.

title: Chinese President to Seek New Relationship With U.S. in Talks
description: BEIJING  Chinas new president, Xi Jinping, took a hands-on approach on Monday while meeting with President Obamas national security adviser to prepare the agenda for the California summit meeting between the two leaders next week.

title: Rutgers Athletic Director Faces New Questions
description: In the weeks since Rutgers hired Julie Hermann to forge a new path for the universitys athletics program, which was still reeling from the fallout of a coaching abuse scandal, Rutgers officials have unexpectedly had to defend their selection of Hermann against accusations of her misconduct dating to a coaching job she held in the 1990s.

title: Valeant Shows How M.&A. Can Favor the Brave
description: Valeant Pharmaceuticals shows how some M.&A. favors the brave. Buying $8.7 billion Bausch & Lomb is the biggest deal yet for the acquisitive company, but it comes with huge cost savings that investors glorified. Chief executives elsewhere should take note.

title: Chinas Central Bank Has Its Own Worries
description: HONG KONG  While developed economies have worried whether international investors will keep showing up at their bond auctions if their central banks keep printing money, China has had a different worry.

title: Central Banks Act With a New Boldness to Revitalize Economies
description: When James Bullard, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, arrived in Frankfurt last week, he issued an unusual public warning to the European Central Bank: Be bolder.

title: Father and Son Travel Across America to Meet Veterans
description: Amber Atchley has held more than one mans life in her hands. She served as an Army medic in Iraq, where her skill kept some soldiers together and alive under enemy fire. Youd think with such experience, Amber could become a civilian paramedic, but her military training does not automatically qualify her for those jobs.

title: A Setback Made Possible by a Big Leap Forward
description: The American Alex Kuznetsov, a runner-up at the 2004 French Open juniors, was unable to find similar success in his first appearance in the main draw of the mens event, falling to a fellow wild card, Lucas Pouille, in straight sets Tuesday.

title: Tragedies Inspire Sock in French Open Breakthrough
description: PARIS  Not since the era of Andre Agassi and Jim Courier have American fans had anyone to genuinely get excited about in the mens draw at Roland Garros. But after watching Jack Sock over the past week, it seems Sock, a big-serving Nebraskan, may develop into a clay-courter of note in the years to come.

title: The Suicide Debate, Revisited
description: Last week I had an exchange with The New Republics Nate Cohn over whether the seemingly strong state-by-state link between population density and suicide rates meant that trends in religious affiliation and family structurecould be discounted as drivers of therecent rise in suicide. Now Sean Trende of RealClearPolitics has very kindly supplemented those ramblings with some actual regression analysis, which suggests that our entire focus on density was misplaced:

title: Hudson Countys Bounty
description: The family restaurants of Hoboken and Jersey City.

title: Only the Food Is Exotic
description: When I was growing up in the 1970s in Hudson County, N.J., there was plenty to complain about: toxic waste, political corruption, blighted buildings. The one thing people never knocked was the food.

title: Q&A: Sending an Automated Vacation Reply With Outlook.com
description: Q.

title: Ending the Friendly Fat Talk
description: In the Health section, Jan Hoffman writes that Fat Talk Compels but Carries a Cost. Whats fat talk? Heres her example:

title: Metro-North Track Worker Fatally Hit by Train in Connecticut
description: 4:46 p.m. | Updated A Metro-North Railroad track foreman was struck and killed by a commuter train on Tuesday near a rail station under construction in West Haven, Conn., the authorities said.

title: Europes Reservations on Immigration Grow
description: BASEL, Switzerland  Carolina Porta Nova, 19, had dreams of becoming a schoolteacher in her native Portugal. But the grinding recession, government cuts to education and an unemployment rate of about 40 percent among young people put an end to those plans.

title: An All-Terrain Sound System
description: Known primarily for its emergency radios and backup batteries, the Etn Corporation broadened its offerings last year with the Rukus Solar, a wireless boombox. This week, Etn introduced the Rukuss smaller sibling, the Rugged Rukus.

title: Newborn Rescued From Sewer Pipe in China Reportedly in Good Condition
description: Video broadcast repeatedly on Chinese state television in recent days showed the rescue of a newborn who spent his first few hours on Earth trapped in a sewer pipe directly beneath the toilet where his mother said she had unexpectedly given birth.

title: Push for Antiracism Bill Leads to Rift in Greek Coalition
description: ATHENS  The issue of how to deal with a surge in racist violence in Greece opened a rift within the countrys fragile governing coalition on Tuesday, when its two junior parties said they would push ahead with an antiracism bill over the objections of the conservative senior party.

title: Clinton Aides Are Focus of Subpoena for Benghazi Talking Points
description: WASHINGTON  Several top aides to Hillary Rodham Clinton, the former secretary of state, are targets of the latest subpoena for information about the drafting of talking points after the siege last fall on an American compound in Benghazi, Libya.

title: Broadway Attendance Fell Six Percent This Season
description: Attendance at Broadway shows shrank by 6.2 percent during the 2012-13 theater season to its lowest level in eight years, with theater producers blaming Hurricane Sandy as well as a weak lineup of musicals and plays during the fall and winter. Approximately 11.57 million people attended Broadway productions during the season, compared to 12.33 million in the previous one, according to statistics released on Tuesday by the Broadway League, the trade association of theater owners and producers. The last time that attendance numbers were so low was the 2004-5 season, which drew 11.53 million people.

title: The Holiday Masses Descend, and Bruckner Reverberates
description: There may be some systemic problems within the field of classical music. But now and then something happens that makes you feel proud of institutions and the music-loving public. One such event is the New York Philharmonics annual free Memorial Day concert at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, which took place on Monday night. For this program, the music director Alan Gilbert conducted the orchestra in just one work: Bruckners 60-minute Symphony No. 3 in D minor.

title: Tomic Retires From First-Round Match, Drama Trailing as He Limps Off
description: PARIS  When Bernard Tomic took the court for his first-round match Tuesday, he was in a rare position for a professional athlete: much more attention was focused on who was in the crowd than who was on the clay.

title: Criticisms, Favorite Gags and Other Reactions to the New Arrested Development
description: Its been just over 60 hours since the new season of Arrested Development started streaming on Netflix. Some superfans had the fortitude to watch all 15 episodes not long after sunrise on Sunday morning. Many of the rest of us are working our way through the show as much as the commitments of daily life will allow. But just about everyone has an opinion about favorite Bluth family moments from the new episodes, and whether its been worth the time to binge on the show.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Pakistan, Afghanistan, England and Syria.

title: Joe Is New York
description: A new ad from the Lhota campaign focuses on the candidates history in New York City,

title: Chinese Filmmaker in Deal to Make Films for Theaters and Online
description: BEIJING  Zhang Yimou, Chinas most famous filmmaker, on Tuesday announced a partnership to make movies with a Beijing-based production company, Le Vision Pictures, best known for distributing its content online.

title: The Ties That Bind Two TV Siblings
description: Showtimes Homeland and the Israeli television series on which its based, Prisoners of War, are like an experiment in genetics: Sharing DNA but raised by different parents in different environments, theyre entirely distinct while maintaining a strong family resemblance. Also, theyre both very good.

title: Renovation Plans in Limbo, Roland Garros Faces Future
description: PARIS  Another days play at the French Open was about to begin, and the tournaments director, Gilbert Ysern, sat in his office chair with clenched fists and delivered a series of mock blows to his own chin.

title: A Mayor for Every New Yorker
description: The Catsimatidis campaign released its first television ad of the race.

title: If You Like  Melissa  Etheridge,  Try Serena Ryder
description: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons generation.

title: Triple Play: Week 8 Results
description: None of the players in Question No. 1 were very Ruthian, but Pablo Sandoval, Carlos Santana and Nick Swisher all hit one home run to be the correct answers.

title: Thinking Big: Four Visions of a New Penn Station
description: The Municipal Art Society asked four design firms to draw big: Reimagine the ideal Pennsylvania Station and Madison Square Garden. We think its an important part of the process, for people to start to see ideas, said Vin Cipolla, the societys president, in an interview. The present station isnt sustainable  it cant meet the needs of New Yorkers and the needs of the region.

title: The Roving Runner Rides a Bike
description: On a day like Memorial Day  clear skies, comfortable temperatures, day off from work  I would normally ride the subway to a corner of the city and do some exploring on the run.

title: The Ad Campaign: Lhotas First Ad Highlights Biography
description: Joe Is New York, a 30-second television advertisement for Joseph J. Lhotas campaign for the Republican nomination for mayor, will run on cable channels across New York City starting on Thursday. The spot was produced by Wilson-Grand Communications.

title: If You Think You Can Dance, Keep It to Yourself
description: Can everybody please stop dancing?

title: Still Young, Even at 50
description: Since 1984, the New York Youth Symphony has awarded commissions to 102 composers age 30 and under, whose works have won three Pulitzer Prizes and the Grawemeyer Award, among other accolades. Those commissioned by the ensemble include Michael Torke, Aaron Jay Kernis, Augusta Read Thomas, Kevin Puts and Derek Bermel.

title: Creating One World of Uninterrupted Movement
description: Its a famous part of dance history that Diaghilevs Ballets Russes blasted color across the stages of Western Europe and America in the early 20th century, as were reminded in a new show at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. Yet, oh! How even those costumes and dcors would pale beside the gloriously bright hues of DanceAfrica last weekend.

title: Street Style: Paint Splatter
description: The best of readers photos from the week of May 20.

title: Salvation Taco and Taqueria Tlaxcalli
description: Inside two taco restaurants located in Murray Hill and the Bronx.

title: Florida Teenager Loses French Open Debut
description: PARIS  Lauren Davis of Boca Raton, Fla., rallied from a disastrous first seven games to make a match out of a rout. But she still lost, 6-0, 7-5, to Kristina Mladenovic on Tuesday in the first round of the French Open.

title: Two Roads Down Mexico Way
description: Expectations are everything.

title: A Nation, Its Seams Fraying
description: If you were to take apart George Packers ambitious new book, The Unwinding, as if it were a cars engine, and spread the parts across your garage, youd essentially be looking at 5 large pieces and 10 small ones  the nuts and bolts and cotter pins.

title: Original Six Rivalry Goes to a Game 7
description: The postmortems began a few days ago for the N.H.L.s top team, the Chicago Blackhawks, who were down, 3-1, to the Detroit Red Wings. Pause the grim epitaphs, for now. The Blackhawks have made a sharp turnaround in the Western Conference semifinals, winning Game 5 in Chicago and Game 6 in Detroit to force a Game 7 at the United Center on Wednesday.

title: Three Measures of Central Banks Effectiveness
description: As the financial and economic crisis of 2008 and 2009 deepened, governments relied heavily on their central banks to lift their economies. Central banks, however, possess only a few limited, but powerful, tools. And it isnt always clear whether their actions  or lack of actions  are even responsible for the results. But increasingly central bankers are being bolder in their attempts to get the worlds major economies moving again.

title: FIFA Congress Takes Flight in Mauritius
description: The Dodo, a flightless bird native to the island of Mauritius, has been extinct since late in the 17th century.

title: Restaurant Report: LEscalier in Cologne, Germany
description: There are a couple of German words for restaurant, but most of the people who use them were around before the Wall fell. The younger generation, raised on a diet of American movies and European solidarity, just says restaurant. Yet though language may be headed in an international direction, an increasing number of German chefs are cooking with a more native idiom, sometimes combining it with other cuisines in intriguing ways.

title: Hotel Review: The J House Greenwich in Riverside, Conn.
description: Rates

title: How It Looks to Think: Watch Her
description: My only real problem with Hannah Arendt is that its not a mini-series. Arendt was a writer of long books and a maker of complex arguments, so the two hours of Margarethe von Trottas ardent and intelligent film about her are bound to feel somewhat superficial. And the movie, even as it answers a hunger for engagement with the life of an extraordinary mind, may also awaken an appetite for more. Arendts work, a heady amalgam of philosophy, history, journalism and political theory, does not easily align with the academic fashions of the moment.

title: Onstage Tasting Menu in a Feast of One-Acts
description: Its spring, which means its time for the Ensemble Studio Theaters annual marathon of one-act plays, now in its 34th year. Series A (the first of three), which features five short works, starts out weak but finishes strong.

title: Off the Menu
description: Headliner

title: Excerpt: 'Dancing Fools'
description: The new series on ABC Family combines video clips with a dance competition.

title: A Little Meat Goes a Long Way
description: Recipes using different meats, cooking techniques and, of course, vegetables.

title: Make Peace With Meat
description: I probably eat a third as much meat as I used to and, on the not-rare (three times a week?) occasions that I do indulge, I eat less of it.

title: The Ad Campaign: Catsimatidis Emphasizes Business Background
description: It is perhaps no surprise that the first mayoral candidate to begin running a costly television advertisement is the wealthy businessman John A. Catsimatidis, a Republican with a $3 billion fortune at his disposal. (His ad went up a few days before one for a Republican rival, Joseph J. Lhota, is to appear.) Eager to increase his name recognition and unhampered by spending limits because he is not participating in New York Citys voluntary public matching funds program, Mr. Catsimatidis commissioned this highly biographical 60-second ad, which will be shown on cable and broadcast television, from the Victory Group, which is based in Florida. The firm has worked with former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: 16 Not-Quite-Meatless Recipes
description: A selection of recipes by Mark Bittman, all of which use pork, beef, lamb or veal as supporting or even bit players, letting vegetables and grains move to center stage.

title: Historic Tujagues Will Remain Open in New Orleans
description: Tujagues, the historic New Orleans restaurant in the French Quarter whose fate had hung in the balance since its owner died in February, will continue serving brisket and Sazeracs, it was announced Tuesday.

title: Front Burner
description: To View: The Influence of His HomelandLike his grandfather Diego Rivera, the artist Pedro Diego Alvarado-Rivera takes his inspiration from his native Mexico. His oils are vibrant, ripe still-life and landscape paintings that focus on the countrys fruits and vegetables, like his Sandia Melonera, right. A sampling will be on display through June 30: Refined Abundance II is at Ruiz-Healy Art, 900 Park Avenue (79th Street) by appointment from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Monday to Friday, ruizhealyart.com, (212) 452-1662.

title: Wines for an Asian-Style Stew
description: Wine with Chinese food may seem counterintuitive, but the combination can work quite well, especially with the gentler spicing of Cantonese cuisine. Many wine lovers take advantage of bring-your-own-bottle policies to drink great wines at Cantonese restaurants. You could open either red or white with the Asian-style vegetable-and-veal stew in Mark Bittmans Flexitarian column this week, as long as the wine has lively acidity so it isnt buried under the assertive flavors of the food. I would lean toward a white, like a peppery grner veltliner, especially one of the more age-worthy specimens. An Austrian riesling would also work well, and for a full dose of umami, why not a fino sherry? Among reds, a fresh, fragrant Chinon or Bourgueil from the Loire Valley would match well, and if you prefer a bolder wine, maybe a zinfandel from the lighter side of the spectrum.

title: Rift Over Air Crash Roils Polands Artists
description: WARSAW  On a foggy April morning in 2010, the Polish presidents plane crashed over Smolensk in western Russia, killing him and 95 other members of Polands political and military elite, traumatizing the nation and opening a bitter political divide over what caused the disaster. Now the fissures have spread to the cultural realm, as filmmakers, writers and artists fiercely debate how  or even whether  to portray this still-visceral history.

title: Canal Street, 4:59 P.M.
description: Does he make it? See below.

title: Jesper Justs Paradoxical Danish Pavilion at the Venice Biennale
description: The menagerie of exhibitions opening this week at the 55th Venice Biennale are a celebration of internationalism. But the pavilions dotted throughout the Giardini and beyond can also feel like a study in displacement, with the art and architecture mounted by various nations feeling less like a representation of those countries identities and more like a reflection of the globalized playground that is the contemporary art world.

title: Discuss Rape and Justice in Pakistan With Reporters From The Times and Frontline
description: Readers of The Lede are invited to join a discussion of the issues raised by the documentary Outlawed in Pakistan, to be broadcast Tuesday night on PBS. The film, part of the Frontline series, followed the case of Kainat Soomro, a young woman who accused four men of gang-raping her when she was just 13 years old.

title: The Ceremonial First Pitch
description: Baseballs ceremonial first pitch was once reserved for dignitaries and sitting presidents. Today nearly anyone can take the mound.

title: Shrinking Corporate Tax Base
description: Corporate taxes have fallen substantially as a share of the economy even while profits have increased.

title: In the Arena With a Smile  and a Bull
description: Lupita Lpez, 34, is one of only a handful of women to be awarded the title of matador.

title: Witnesses Describe Killings in Syria to BBC
description: As my colleagues Anne Barnard and Hania Mourtada reported earlier this month, residents, opposition activists and human rights monitors in Syria said that hundreds of civilians were killed by forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad in two Sunni Muslim enclaves in the largely Alawite and Christian province of Tartus.

title: Tejada, Still Working on His Swing, Remains Atop the Order
description: Ruben Tejadas swing remains a project, one that will play out in plain sight as he continues to man the Mets leadoff spot.

title: Some Germans Balk at Plan to Use Drones to Fight Graffiti
description: BERLIN  Germans have no trouble agreeing that the graffiti covering many of the nations commuter trains in a most un-Germanic scrawl is intolerable. But what they cannot agree on is the main railway operators proposed cure: small drones to patrol the rail yards by night.

title: As Hurricane Season Nears, Con Ed Shows Off Equipments New Protections
description: Before another big tropical storm can surge into the Consolidated Edison substations that were flooded by Hurricane Sandy, it will have to breach a mile of concrete walls and steel gates.

title: Drab Office in New Jersey Gets the Cinderella Treatment
description: PLAINSBORO, N.J.  Novo Nordisk, the Danish pharmaceutical company, moved into its North American headquarters here this month, after a $225 million gut renovation transformed an aging structure into a glassy corporate campus updated for a modern work force.

title: Baseball Stadium Bolsters El Pasos Resurgence
description: EL PASO  Staccato explosions cracked across the cloudless desert sky, to be drowned out by a deeper rumble that shook the earth as this citys 10-story former City Hall came rolling down upon its foundation in a blinding cloud of dust and debris in mid-April.

title: Obama and Christie: Moderate Friendship
description: On the Jersey Shore, Gov. Chris Christies friendly welcome toward President Obama suggested he cared little about criticism from Republicans.

title: Colorado: Court Upholds System for Financing Schools
description: Colorados highest court on Tuesday rejected a major challenge to how the state finances public schools, saying the system, while imperfect, conforms to the State Constitution. The ruling by the Colorado Supreme Court, which overturned a lower courts decision, handed a stinging defeat to parents and school districts that argued that the financing formula was fundamentally unfair and unbalanced, and widened the gaps between have and have-not school districts. Many state officials welcomed the courts ruling. They said it would remove the heated educational battle from the courts and return it to the hands of elected lawmakers, who have already taken steps to try to improve how Colorado finances its schools.

title: Nike Chooses to Sever Its Ties With Livestrong
description: Nike stuck by Tiger Woods in the wake of his infidelity and gave Michael Vick an endorsement deal after Vick had served time in prison for his role in a dogfighting ring, which included killing dogs that underperformed.

title: Myles J. Horn
description: Mr. Horn, 62, is a real estate investor and developer who specializes in co-op and condominium conversions and the acquisition of large blocks of unsold shares and units. He is currently involved in a major renovation of the Printing House, a residential building in the West Village where he and his partners own the majority of the apartments.

title: Angelo J. Errichetti, 84, Camden Mayor Convicted of Bribery, Dies
description: Angelo J. Errichetti, a former two-term mayor of Camden, N.J., whose career as a state Democratic power broker ended in the early 1980s when he was ensnared in the Congressional corruption scandal known as Abscam and served nearly three years in prison, died on May 16 at home in Ventnor, N.J. He was 84.

title: Rivera Throws First Pitch and Last in His First Blown Save of Year
description: 1:16 a.m. | Updated

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,209 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Keeping It Zany in a Losing Year
description: Baseballs postgame ritual of interrupting an on-field interview with a shaving cream pie to the face is a comforting one, sometimes even for the recipient. It neatly punctures the me-first notion so prevalent in sports; even a players moment in the spotlight can be taken from him by his teammates. Watching a utility player slap some shaving cream in the face of a $15-million-a-year All-Star is the kind of humility delivery system most people can really get behind.

title: SoftBank and Sprint Win National Security Clearance for Deal
description: 7:32 a.m. | Updated with official announcement

title: Transactions
description: Recent Sale

title: Can You Eat Too Little Salt?
description: TRAPANI PROVINCE, Sicily  Here on Sicilys west coast, there are two main crops: olives for oil and grapes for wine. There was once a third: salt.

title: With Few Clues, Afghan Pathologists Try to Put Names to Torture Victims
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  When the mortal remains of a man named Nawab were brought to what is, in effect, the Kabul C.S.I. on April 30, they all fit easily into a wooden crate small enough to carry under one arm.

title: A Hotel Company Is Hobbled by a Deal Struck in Bad Times
description: If you are reading this column by the pool at the Delano South Beach in Miami Beach or while hanging out at the bar at St. Martins Lane Hotel in London or the Royalton in Manhattan, you may not be aware that behind the scenes of your comfortable surroundings, all is not well.

title: Anti-West Hard-Liner Gains in Iranian Race
description: TEHRAN  At his first presidential campaign rally, Saeed Jalili on Friday welcomed the cheers of thousands of young men as he hauled himself onto the stage. His movements were hampered by a prosthetic leg, a badge of honor from his days as a young Revolutionary Guards member in Irans great trench war with Iraq.

title: With Money at Risk, Hospitals Push Staff to Wash Hands
description: At North Shore University Hospital on Long Island, motion sensors, like those used for burglar alarms, go off every time someone enters an intensive care room. The sensor triggers a video camera, which transmits its images halfway around the world to India, where workers are checking to see if doctors and nurses are performing a critical procedure: washing their hands.

title: A Front-Runner Emerges in Irans Election
description: Saeed Jalili, 47, who many say has been groomed for a top position in Irans establishment, is by far the most outspoken hardliner among the eight candidates approved to run.

title: The Trouble With Taxing Corporations
description: Everybody does it.

title: Interleague? Fans Shrug in Down Year for Baseball
description: Even during other down years, the Mets were guaranteed of at least one thing: selling out their home games against the Yankees. Since the advent of interleague play in 1997, these games determined temporary bragging rights within New York City and had an edge to them that put fans in every seat.

title: What to Watch on Day 4 at the French Open
description: Two picks for first-round matches to watch on Tuesday (Benoit Paire vs. Marcos Baghdatis and Jamie Hampton vs. Lucie Safarova) were not able to be completed because of intermittent rain, but they remain recommended viewing for Wednesday.

title: Officer Shot in Head in 2012 Makes an Arrest Near the Same Spot
description: For Police Sgt. Kevin Brennan, his visit to the Bushwick Houses on Tuesday was supposed to be uneventful. He was there to familiarize himself with where he had been on the night of Jan. 31, 2012, when he was shot in the head. The trial of the man charged with trying to murder him is approaching, and Sergeant Brennan needed to prepare.

title: Subway Ballet
description: Young men perform daring aerial dances in a crowded New York City subway car.

title: Switzerland Weighs Deal in Tax Cases
description: The Swiss government is considering a proposal to disclose bank client names and pay a multibillion-dollar fine to the United States to help resolve a long-running dispute between the two countries over the handling of tax-evasion cases, American and Swiss sources briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

title: Subway Ballet
description: The first time I saw these young men perform, in a tightly packed New York City subway car, I imagined we were all flying. I later learned that their dances and aerial moves were named the part-time stripper, walking on air and the Kid and Larry. Their physicality, bravado and humor captivated me. While some riders considered them a nuisance, I felt they transformed the subway car into a remarkable sort of public theater.

title: In Thailands Schools, Vestiges of Military Rule
description: SAMUT PRAKAN, Thailand  Put aside for a moment the image of Thailand that tourists often see, a laid-back, anything-goes country of libidinous night life.

title: My Near Miss
description: IT was probably our eighth or ninth admission that day, but my intern and I had given up counting. I was midway through my medical residency, already a master of efficiency. You had to be, or youd never keep up. This one was a classic eye-roller: a nursing home patient with dementia, sent to the emergency room for an altered mental status. When you were juggling patients with acute heart failure and rampant infections, it was hard to get worked up over a demented nonagenarian who was looking a little more demented.

title: Shuttle Diplomacy, Kerry Style
description: Secretary of State John Kerry has seemed perpetually in motion in the Middle East since he assumed office, shuttling from one meeting to another with top Israeli and Palestinian officials over the last four months in an effort to revive peace negotiations. He has divulged few details, and his overall strategy is unclear. But it would be foolish to write off his peacemaking diplomacy, as some have. So far, he seems to be moving in a determined and encouraging fashion on a series of interlocking steps.

title: Exceptions to Harsh Rules
description: On Tuesday, the Supreme Court handed down two important criminal procedure decisions, both allowing defendants to seek habeas corpus review of their convictions in federal court. The 5-to-4 majority, with Justice Anthony Kennedy joining the courts four moderate liberals, reached the right result in each case. But, in a larger sense, the two decisions show how much the scope of habeas review has been curtailed by the Supreme Court in the last three decades, so that it now must work around earlier precedents to avoid doing injustice.

title: How to Get a Job
description: Underneath the huge drop in demand that drove unemployment up to 9 percent during the recession, theres been an important shift in the education-to-work model in America. Anyone whos been looking for a job knows what I mean. It is best summed up by the mantra from the Harvard education expert Tony Wagner that the world doesnt care anymore what you know; all it cares is what you can do with what you know. And since jobs are evolving so quickly, with so many new tools, a bachelors degree is no longer considered an adequate proxy by employers for your ability to do a particular job  and, therefore, be hired. So, more employers are designing their own tests to measure applicants skills. And they increasingly dont care how those skills were acquired: home schooling, an online university, a massive open online course, or Yale. They just want to know one thing: Can you add value?

title: The Wisdom of Bob Dole
description: Bob Dole no longer recognizes the Republican Party that he helped lead for years. Speaking over the weekend on Fox News Sunday, he said his party should hang a closed for repairs sign on its doors until it comes up with a few positive ideas, because neither he nor Ronald Reagan would now feel comfortable in its membership.

title: Finding Democrats to Run Where Republicans Win
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D.  Many Democrats in this state and beyond saw in Stephanie Herseth Sandlin an ideal candidate to help the party retain the Senate seat that Tim Johnson is giving up next year.

title: Candidate for Irans Presidency Defends Record as Nuclear Negotiator
description: The brief campaign ahead of next months presidential election in Iran might lack the passion of 2009, when rallies in support of opposition candidates set the stage for the mass protests that followed the vote, but one of the candidates injected some passion into the race on Monday when he showed a flash of anger during an interview on state television.

title: Tonights Honored Guest on the Mound, a Backflipping Frog
description: Shortly before a recent game at Citi Field, four dancers in skin-tight, metallic green body suits slunk toward the pitchers mound, where a man wearing a red tuxedo and top hat stood waiting.

title: Ensuring Justice in the Military
Facebook Says It Failed to Bar Posts With Hate Speech
description: Facebook on Tuesday acknowledged that its systems to identify and remove hate speech had not worked effectively, as it faced pressure from feminist groups that want the site to ban pages that glorify violence against women.

title: 2 American Embassy Officials Are Shot in Venezuela Strip Club
description: LIMA, Peru  Two staff members of the American Embassy in Caracas, Venezuela, were shot and wounded at a strip club there early Tuesday, according to officials.

title: By Not Speaking Up, Wilpons Send the Wrong Message
description: There was one painfully awkward moment late Tuesday afternoon in an otherwise gracious endeavor by the Mets to honor Mariano Rivera before his last scheduled appearance at Citi Field. In an apparent slip of a usually tied tongue, Jeff Wilpon, the Mets chief operating officer, more or less conceded the season.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 29, 2013
description: "If Al Capone were alive today, this is how he would be hiding his money.

title: Wal-Mart Is Fined $82 Million Over Mishandling of Hazardous Wastes
description: Wal-Mart Stores pleaded guilty Tuesday to improperly dumping hazardous waste in California and Missouri, agreeing to pay almost $82 million in fines.

title: President of Scandinavia
description: WASHINGTON  Like many others in our business, Jonathan Alter says he is on fire about the Justice Departments snooping on reporters and attempting to criminalize investigative journalism, including labeling the respected Fox News Washington correspondent James Rosen a co-conspirator in a leak investigation.

title: Prostitutes Testify in Defense of Pimps at Sex Trafficking Trial
description: To hear the testimony of the women who worked for them, Vincent George Sr. and his son were not the violent and manipulative sex traffickers that prosecutors described, but, rather, the heads of a happy extended family working together for a brighter collective future.

title: A Mogul Comes to Lunch, and He Doesnt Hold His Tongue
description: JERUSALEM  Sheldon G. Adelson is perhaps best known as a conservative casino mogul who spent tens of millions of dollars last year trying to defeat President Obama. But he is a larger-than-life lightning rod in Israel, too.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: Palace Not One of Premier Leagues Jewels
description: It was somewhat predictable that Kevin Phillips, a seasoned veteran of the League Championship, would score the winner in a playoff final.

title: Looking Within
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Todays puzzle by Gary Cee will force you to look inward whether you like it or not. Dont worry if introspection really isnt your thing; all hes asking you to do is figure out which words make up phrases using the word in that he has managed to cross (symmetrically, yet) six times in his puzzle.

title: Defendant in Terror Case Gets Lawyer of His Choice
description: A lawyer who is under federal indictment in Syracuse and under federal investigation in Manhattan will be able to represent a high-profile defendant in a terrorism case, a judge ruled on Tuesday.

title: France: Man Dies From New SARS-Like Infection
description: A 65-year-old man infected with a virus causing SARS-like symptoms died Monday, health authorities said, the first French patient to be killed by the condition known as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome. The man, who died of multiple organ failure in an isolation chamber in a hospital in Lille, is believed to have been infected while vacationing in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, in April. He was first hospitalized late last month, shortly after his return to France, with symptoms described only as digestive problems. While hospitalized, he infected a neighboring patient who remains hospitalized. The virus, known as a coronavirus, has killed 23 of the 44 people confirmed infected since September, most of them in Saudi Arabia.

title: Its Dark, but We See You: Release the Horseshoe Crabs
description: A police helicopter thundered over a darkened Jamaica Bay in fast pursuit of a boat with no lights and a load of ill-gotten quarry.

title: Making His Mayoral Debate Debut at Education Forum, Weiner Basks in Attention
description: He took off his jacket and rolled up his shirt sleeves, setting himself off visually from the four other men onstage. When asked a question, he stood up to answer, holding the microphone as though he were roaming the room at a town hall, while the other candidates remained sedately seated. At moments he seemed to mock the debate rules, answering one question, Ive got no bloody idea, and at one point offering to give his instant rebuttal to another candidate.

title: A Salvadoran at Risk Tests Abortion Law
description: MEXICO CITY  Beatriz spends her days in a hospital room, anxiously watching her belly grow.

title: Lottery Numbers
Solar Industry Anxious Over Defective Panels
description: LOS ANGELES  The solar panels covering a vast warehouse roof in the sun-soaked Inland Empire region east of Los Angeles were only two years into their expected 25-year life span when they began to fail.

title: A Law That Keeps Gun Makers Smiling
description: Two pictures.

title: Has Apple Lost Its Cool? Its Chief Says No
description: RANCHO PALOS VERDES, Calif.  It has been a rough year for Apple. The company has battled fierce competitors like Samsung, come under scrutiny for tax avoidance and watched in dismay as its stock price took more dips and turns than a roller coaster.

title: FEMA Promotes Its Wireless Emergency Alert System
description: THE Federal Emergency Management Agency is releasing new public service advertising this week, created in conjunction with the Advertising Council, to educate Americans about its wireless emergency alert system.

title: Ex-President of Guatemala Faces Judge in Manhattan
description: A former Guatemalan president who was extradited to the United States last week in a money laundering case pleaded not guilty on Tuesday in a New York courtroom.

title: At Political Clubs, Fight for Endorsements in Mayoral Race Is Under Way
description: At 10 oclock on a humid, rainy night last week, in the back room of a church in Park Slope, a dramatic standoff was taking place between some members of the Lambda Independent Democrats of Brooklyn, the boroughs gay political club, and a group of supporters of Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker and mayoral candidate.

title: Marshall Lytle, 79, Bassist With Bill Haley, Dies
description: Marshall Lytle, whose spirited, percussive bass work was heard on one of rock n rolls seminal recordings, Rock Around the Clock by Bill Haley and His Comets, died on Saturday at his home in New Port Richey, Fla. He was 79.

title: Jean Bach, Jazz Documentarian and Fan, Dies at 94
description: Jean Bach, a lifelong jazz zealot whose fascination with a photograph of the titans of jazz gathered in front of a Harlem brownstone in 1958 led her to make a prizewinning movie about that moment, A Great Day in Harlem, 36 years later, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.

title: How Liberty Reserves Virtual Currency Works
description: How prosecutors say Liberty Reserves money laundering scheme operated.

title: John C. Bierwirth, Leader of Grumman in Time of Uneasy Transition, Dies at 89
description: John C. Bierwirth, who led the Grumman Corporation, one of the nations largest aircraft makers, through challenging times in the 1970s and 80s, died on Sunday at a hospice in Freeport, on Long Island. He was 89.

title: The First Pitch Loses Its Exclusivity
description: A look at the ceremonial first pitch in major league baseball, then and now.

title: Recessions Save Lives
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: Is It Better to Walk or Run?
description: Walking and running are the most popular physical activities for American adults. But whether one is preferable to the other in terms of improving health has long been debated. Now a variety of new studies that pitted running directly against walking are providing some answers. Their conclusion? It depends almost completely on what you are hoping to accomplish.

title: Volckers Aim: Responsive Government
description: As chairman of the Federal Reserve, Paul A. Volcker tamed inflation. More recently, he took on the countrys biggest banks in an effort to force them to give up lucrative but risky Wall Street-style trading.

description: lascivious \l-si-ve-s\ adjective

title: Unlike Liberty Reserve, Bitcoin Is Not Anonymous  Yet
description: 12:34 p.m. | Updated This post was changed to properly reflect the change in Bitcoins value.

title: Pacers Hold Off Heats Charge and Even Series
description: INDIANAPOLIS  This is not the first time the Miami Heat and the Indiana Pacers have been tied 2-2 in a playoff series. Just last year, in the Eastern Conference semifinals, the teams were deadlocked heading into a Game 5 in Miami.

title: Mets Stun Rivera and Yankees in Ninth
description: Terry Collins, the Mets manager, admitted on Tuesday afternoon that he once allowed himself to worry about Matt Harvey, his young ace, before big occasions. He feared the fiery pitchers emotions would boil over amid lofty circumstances. But Collins said he knew better now, after watching Harvey thrive one start after another.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 9 P.M. (NBC) HEALING IN THE HEARTLAND: RELIEF BENEFIT CONCERT  Blake Shelton organized this concert, to be broadcast live from the Chesapeake Energy Arena in Oklahoma City and featuring performances by his wife, Miranda Lambert, above; Reba McEntire; Vince Gill; Luke Bryan; Rascal Flatts; and Ryan Tedder of OneRepublic. The event will raise money for the United Way of Central Oklahoma May Tornadoes Relief Fund, which will help finance recovery and rebuilding efforts in the state after the tornadoes that devastated Moore and the surrounding area on May 20.

title: 2-Child Limit for Some Muslims Brings New Scrutiny to Myanmar
description: HONG KONG  When President Thein Sein of Myanmar went to the White House last week, President Obama had praise for the countrys transition to democracy but warned Mr. Thein Sein that violence against Muslims had to stop and that their rights needed to be recognized.

title: News Quiz | May 29, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Pakistan Says U.S. Drone Killed Taliban Leader
description: WASHINGTON  Less than a week after President Obama outlined a new direction for the secret drone wars, Pakistani officials said that a C.I.A. missile strike on Wednesday killed a top member of the Pakistani Taliban, an attack that illustrated the continued murkiness of the rules that govern the United States targeted killing operations.

title: Papua New Guinea Acts to Repeal Sorcery Law After Strife
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The Parliament of Papua New Guinea has voted to repeal the countrys Sorcery Act and to reinstate the death penalty in certain cases to help stem an increase in violence against people accused of practicing black magic.

title: IHT Quick Read: May 29
description: NEWS The Swiss government is considering a proposal to disclose bank client names and pay a multibillion-dollar fine to the United States to help resolve a long-running dispute between the two countries over the handling of tax-evasion cases, according to American and Swiss sources briefed on the matter. Lynnley Browning reports.

title: Wrestling Supporters Push to Save Sport at the Olympics
description: Supporters of wrestling have gathered forces in St. Petersburg, Russia, where they will make a major push on Wednesday to preserve their sport as an Olympic event at the 2020 Summer Games.

title: Test Yourself | Math, May 29, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article Rivera Again Finishes Where He Left Off.

title: Examining the Millions of Germs Living in Our Homes
description: In the article Mapping the Great Indoors, Peter Andrey Smith writes about scientists efforts to map the microbial biodiversity living in our homes and buildings.

title: Bachmann, Facing Inquiries, Will Not Seek Re-election in 2014
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Michele Bachmann, the Minnesota Republican whose status as a leading Tea Party voice in Congress has faded in the wake of a failed bid for president and a widening investigation into her campaign spending, said Wednesday that she would not seek re-election.

title: C.E.O.s Dont Need to Earn Less. They Need to Sweat More.
description: One recent Thursday, G. Steven Farris, the chairman and C.E.O. of the poorly performing oil-and-gas company Apache, stood before a few hundred shareholders who were about to vote on his salary. Farris, who was hoping to earn well over $10 million for this year, listed a number of his accomplishments. Were the No. 1 driller in the Permian Basin, he said, referring to the oil reserves in West Texas and New Mexico. But some shareholders, most likely mindful of the companys falling stock price, noted that the proposed pay package seemed out of whack. Still, the tally was a nail-biter: 49.8 percent of the votes favored giving Farris the bump.

title: Is Drinking and Driving Still a Problem for Teenagers?
description: Research shows that high school students are drinking and driving less than they were 30 years ago, and the number of people killed by drunken drivers is down by more than half. Still, about 10,000 people die each year in traffic accidents involving impaired drivers.

title: Bill W.  Famous, Yet Seldom Seen
description: Kevin Hanlon and Dan Carracino figured they would face a steep learning curve when they started making their first documentary in 2004. They expected to make the usual newbie mistakes when it came, for example, to finding the right visuals. But considering their subject, they should have known better.

title: The Rail Bookshelf: One Book at a Time
description: After the hubbub and sensory overload of the Kentucky Derby, I always take a few days to explore Lexington, Ky. These are peaceful days. I usually visit the Keeneland Library researching topics for future stories. But there are so many books, and so little time. This year, I decided to check out Lexingtons award-winning used book store, Black Swan Books.

title: British Defense Chief Confirms Detentions of Afghans at Base
description: LONDON  The British Defense Ministry on Wednesday confirmed that it had been holding up to 90 Afghan detainees for months at a military base in southern Afghanistan, after legal action filed by some of the detainees lawyers in Britain raised human rights objections.

title: The Early Word: Beachheads
description: In Todays Times

title: Dymaxion Car Plans Resurface
description: Every once in a while, a car so brilliant and forward thinking comes along, it just cant be ignored. Only it can. Some have a few moments of glory  the Tucker Torpedo, the General Motors EV1, and perhaps even the Fisker Karma, for example  and others dont. The three-wheel Dymaxion car is one of those; the teardrop-shaped, 1930s-vintage car of the future that never made it into production.

title: Suntory Plans Big I.P.O. for Its Food and Beverage Unit
description: TOKYO  Suntory Holdings got approval from the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Wednesday to list its food and soft drinks unit, paving the way for what is expected to be Asias biggest initial public offering this year.

title: Unpaid Internships for Sale
description: HONG KONG  Meet the new 21th-century student: Angelika Lisek is originally from Poland, studied finance in Glasgow, interned at the Shanghai branch of a U.S. wealth management firm and is currently on an exchange program in Hong Kong.

title: Man Held in France in Attack on Soldier
description: PARIS  The French police on Wednesday arrested a 21-year-old man described as a convert to Islam who they said had confessed to stabbing a French soldier on Saturday in a Paris suburb.

title: What Indian Firms Should Know About U.S. and U.K. Corruption Laws
description: The increasing number of high-profile corruption investigations of multinational companies, initiated in the United States and Britain, highlights the significant risks faced by foreign businesses that may be tempted to pay bribes in India. But could the enhanced American and British enforcement efforts ensnare Indian companies as well?

title: The Unsung Heroes of Fast-Growth Companies
description: Academia and media tend to focus on leaders. As a result, they often miss the importance of the unsung heroes in disruptive, fast-growth companies who make sure the disruption is carried all the way through the company.

title: Stuck in the Shadow of Affluence
description: How the epidemic of empty, foreclosed homes in Chicagos poorest neighborhoods ignited a new form of guerrilla activism.

title: The Death and Life of Chicago
description: On a 100-degree day last summer, on Chicagos southernmost edge, Willie Fleming, who goes by J. R. (It stands for Just Righteousness), crept up to an abandoned ranch house shrouded in overgrown weeds. The overwhelmingly poor and black neighborhood sits beside a 150-acre, 1,500-unit public-housing complex and is about as far  literally and figuratively  from the Loop as you can get and still be in Chicago. Nearly a quarter of the homes in the area had been empty for at least two years. Usually when J. R. scouts for properties to break into and take over, he looks for ones with unmown grass, a sign of vacancy and disregard. But this was excessive. I dont come back here without my air gun, he said, backing away. A young couple next door had set up lawn chairs on the sidewalk. An infant in only a diaper tottered around them. Thats the dead-dog cemetery, the man announced, motioning to the ranch house.

title: Global Economy Is Rebounding, O.E.C.D. Says
description: BERLIN  The global economy is slowly regaining its strength, driven largely by the rebound of the United States and Japan, but record-high unemployment in Europe continues to drag on efforts to recover in that region, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said Wednesday.

title: U.N. Rights Council Passes Resolution Calling for End to Fighting in Syrian Town
description: GENEVA  The United Nations Human Rights Council overwhelmingly passed a resolution on Wednesday that calls for an immediate end to fighting around Qusayr, a strategic Syrian town, and condemns the intervention of foreign combatants on the governments side in the Syrian civil war.

title: Myanmar Struggles to Put Down Buddhist Attack on Muslims
description: BANGKOK  Security forces on Wednesday struggled to bring peace to a northern city in Myanmar after Buddhist mobs set fire to a mosque, a Muslim school and shops, the latest outbreak of religious violence in Myanmar and a sign that radical strains of Buddhism may be spreading to a wider area of the country.

title: Does Spains History Provide a Lesson in Syrias Civil War?
description: LONDON  In the debate over the rights and wrongs of foreign intervention in Syria, some have sought parallels in an earlier internal struggle that divided nations: the Spanish Civil War.

title: Im JOYCE. Now Stop Bothering Me
description: I had a dream last night that I was walking down Fifth Avenue wearing nothing but a nametag but it was O.K. because it was Nametag Day and New York was a friendlier, nicer place. Somebody even offered me a trench coat, saying, Keep it, JOYCE. Thats when I knew it wasnt real and woke up. New Yorkers are just not that nice.

title: Feeling For | H. Sterns Ocean-Inspired Gold-and-Diamond Bracelet
description: Looking again to nature as its muse, the Brazilian jewelry house H. Stern follows up the space-influenced Copernicus collection with its Iris collection, which draws its shapes from the sea. Rounded seashells, curved octopus arms and spherical sea urchins take form in gold earrings and rings. The standout piece in the series is a rose-gold bracelet, backed with noble gold (H. Sterns unique blend of 18-karat yellow gold and 18-karat white gold) and covered in cognac-colored diamonds, that evokes the motion of crashing waves.

Weiner announced his candidacy for mayor of New York City recently  and rather oddly, in a video that surfaced online late at night and then disappeared  it was good to see the reporter David Halbfinger take a hard look at the videos assertions, fact-checking them aggressively and in real time.

description: Apple has hired Lisa P. Jackson, who served as chief of the Environmental Protection Agency during President Obamas first term, to serve as the companys senior environmental adviser, Tim Cook, Apples chief executive, announced on Tuesday.

title: Mixing Gin and Politics
description: ISTANBUL  Of all the gin joints in all towns in all the world, she walks into mine, is Humphrey Bogarts classic moan in the film Casablanca. Moments later, he draws hungrily on a cigarette.

title: You Wouldnt Like Him When Hes Angry: Peter Sarsgaard Joins The Killing
