description: When you sign up Peter Sarsgaard to be on a show like The Killing, its probably safe to assume you dont want him to play the rigidly moral chief of police or the squeaky-clean neighbor next door. Sure enough, when Mr. Sarsgaard joins this AMC crime procedural for its third season, and in his first television role since starring in films like Boys Dont Cry, Kinsey and Shattered Glass, he will be playing the part of Ray Seward, a death row inmate, set to be executed in 30 days for the murder of his wife.

title: Chinas Big Food Deal
description: The Shuanghui Group of China agreed on Wednesday to buy the American meat processor Smithfield Foods for about $4.7 billion, the two companies announced on Wednesday.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Guardian: Virginia Woolfs great-niece, a recovered anorexic, suggests that her aunt also had from the disease. This adds yet another layer of poignancy and complexity to a woman who once wrote, One cannot think well, love well, sleep well, if one has not dined well.  Melissa Clark

title: Sarah Szes Triple Point
description: An installation at the Venice Biennale is a series of carefully assembled environments using everything from ladders and paint cans to scraps of paper and remnants of photographs.

title: Sarah Sze: The Stones of Venice
description: VENICE  Everyone is anxiously waiting to get into the Biennale, which opens to the art world here on Wednesday and to the public on Saturday. But those who have already arrived can take an early peek at the work of one artist.

title: Napoleon Perkins Loses His Leg
description: Napoleon Perkins dragged himself toward the plank road behind the Chancellor house, shot and shells plowing up the ground all around him and apple blossoms drifting into his hair. Moments before, during some of the fiercest fighting at the Battle of Chancellorsville in Virginia, Perkins had been unhitching one of his horses from a Fifth Maine artillery caisson when a rebel shell struck him in the right leg just above the knee. At first he did not realize how badly he had been wounded; but when he tried to walk to the rear, his leg buckled and nearly severed in two. Perkins managed to reach the road and began to crawl across it, but could go no farther. Dizzy but still conscious, he watched the Chancellor house and the nearby woods catch fire and burn, killing many of his comrades who had been similarly wounded in the fight, but could not flee the flames.

title: Britain Plans I.P.O. for Postal Service
description: LONDON  Britain is preparing to privatize Royal Mail, the countrys postal service, whose origins date to 1516 and the carrying of post for Henry VIII and the Tudor court.

title: What Preferential Treatment? James Fouls Out
description: INDIANAPOLIS  In 765 career regular-season games, LeBron James had fouled out of four of them. In 127 playoff games, he had fouled out once. Then came Tuesday night.

title: Two M.L.S. Teams Ousted in Open Cup
description: Orlando City and Charleston, currently the first- and second-place teams in the United Soccer Leagues Pro division (the third tier in the U.S. Soccer pyramid) scored upsets over teams from Major League Soccer Tuesday night in the third round of the 100th edition of the U.S. Open Cup tournament.

title: Goals Content Is On the Move
description: Thank you for visiting Goal.This blogs regular features, including live match analysis, player ratings from key matches, reader discussion, news and notes from Sam Borden, Jack Bell, Andy Das and others, can now be found on the soccer section front.

title: Found Poem Favorite | The Young, Toiling Underground
description: This poem, one of 12 winners of our fourth annual Found Poem Student Contest, was written by Raji, 15, from Morganville, N.J., and comes from the article Children Toil in Indias Mines, Despite Legal Ban.

title: The Unlikely Activist
description: Jemima Khan may live the grand life of an English aristocrat, but behind the famous boyfriends and the important hair is a serious political journalist and a budding documentary film producer. Her latest project? Taking on WikiLeaks.

title: Tata Motors Quarterly Results Beat Estimates
description: LONDON  Tata Motors, Indias largest automaker, on Wednesday reported a 37 percent fall in its fourth-quarter profit, to 39.45 billion rupees (about $700 million), compared with the same period a year earlier. Revenue rose 10 percent, to 560 billion rupees.

title: Questions Raised Over Intended Target of Maoist Attack
description: NEW DELHI On May 25, a convoy of cars carrying senior leaders of the Congress Party and others was attacked by the Maoist guerrillas in southern Chhattisgarh in central India. It was one of the most audacious attacks by the Maoists, who now work under one umbrella group called the Communist Party of India (Maoist).

title: Risk of Bank Failures Is Rising in Europe, E.C.B. Warns
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank warned on Wednesday that the euro zones slumping economy and a surge in problem loans were raising the risk of a renewed banking crisis, even as overall stress in the regions financial markets had receded.

title: When Your First Company Is Working, but Another Is Beckoning
description: Uptown Treehouse is a seven-person company, based in Los Angeles, that creates social media campaigns for media and product companies. Just three years old, it earns an annual profit of more than $300,000 on revenue of $1.3 million.

title: How to Help Google Plus Help Your Photos
description: Google wants you to spend more time with Google Plus, and to get you to do so, it is going to put your photos in a better light, literally.

title: What Do 50 Shades of Grey and a Desire Pill Have in Common?
description: Several times in the course of editing Daniel Bergners cover story this past Sunday on drug trials for a new female-desire pill, I thought about the 50 Shades of Grey phenomenon. Bergners story is about women who lose interest in having sex. But when you dig a little, you find out that what these women really lose interest in is having sex with their long-term partners. And the women who are taking part in the drug trials are desperate to again feel some lust for their spouse.

title: Hamilton Keeps the Angels Waiting
description: LOS ANGELES  Josh Hamilton was scratched from the lineup Tuesday after hurting himself during batting practice at Dodger Stadium. He had back spasms and was not available off the bench.

title: A Picket-Fence Experience
description: People who live in Queens Village will tell you that the neighborhood lives up to its name. Residential and calm, with a distinct commercial center, it is often described as feeling like a small town.

title: The Trouble With Treats
description: Children often have a baffling relationship with food. One child is terrified of cheese; another will eat nothing but. One 4-year-olds beloved slice of watermelon tastes like soap to his 7-year-old sister. Two new picture books celebrate the love, the dislike and the occasional fear inspired by two of (most) childrens favorite foods: watermelon and lollipops.

title: A Handel Mini-Festival to Highlight American Classical Orchestra Season
description: The American Classical Orchestra, a period-instrument band founded by the conductor Thomas Crawford at the Old Fairfield Academy in Connecticut in 1985, and more recently thriving in New York City, will present a Handel mini-festival as part of its 2013-14 season at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Image of the Day: May 29
Goodbye, Michele Bachmann
description: At a time when moderate Republicans are worrying about their partys rightward momentum, theres good news for them and bad news for Democrats and political reporters. Rep. Michele Bachmann, the Tea Party Republican from Minnesota who was regarded as a presidential contender for a nanosecond in 2012, announced today that she would not seek a fifth term in the House of Representatives.

title: Skipping the Gas Pump, and Getting Fuel From a Deep Fryer
description: Gerard Lynn says he has found a way to buck the prices at the gas pump. He makes his own biodiesel from the used cooking oil of a Bronx fish and chips restaurant.

title: Lobbying for the Greater Good
description: Earlier this month, scientists reported that the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere had reached 400 parts per million. Its an alarming milestone, to be sure, but, alas, there is no shortage of dire warnings about global warming. What is lacking is the political will to address the problem. The big question is, what useful steps can citizens take to build that will?

title: Google Overhauls Gmail to Take On E-Mail Overload
description: On Wednesday, Google introduced a new in-box design for its e-mail service, Gmail.

title: On Broadway, More Chuckles Than Guffaws
description: It was not a great season for comedy on Broadway. But it was a good one  which from a certain nostalgic perspective may be even better.

title: Mulgrew Miller, Influential Jazz Pianist, Dies at 57
description: Mulgrew Miller, a jazz pianist whose soulful erudition, clarity of touch and rhythmic aplomb made him a fixture in the postbop mainstream for more than 30 years, died on Wednesday in Allentown, Pa. He was 57.

title: Which Start-Up Should This Entrepreneur Pursue?
description: We just published a case study about a young entrepreneur, Aseem Badshah, who is torn between two ventures and needs to decide where to focus his time and energy.

title: The Occasionally Not So Big Three
description: Sometimes the Miami Heat become bored with themselves, the whole dominating-the-N.B.A. thing being a bit on the dull side. Their losses are a bit like the times when your older brother plays you in the driveway and shoots with only his left hand. Maybe the Heat players are just trying to challenge themselves: O.K., were up by 3 with just over five minutes to go. What if LeBron fouls out, we let Indiana score a bunch in a row, Dwyane gets called for something like traveling in the final minute and then we see what happens? Got it? Lets go!

title: Wheelies: The Luxury Truck Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: E.U. States Win Leeway on Deficits
description: BRUSSELS  Retreating slowly from tough austerity policies that have been widely blamed for leaving 27 million Europeans out of work, the European Unions executive arm said Wednesday it would allow France, Spain and five other nations more time to meet mandatory budget deficit targets.

title: American Pork Goes to China
description: The chief of Smithfield Foods says an acquisition by Shuanghui International of China is an opportunity for the Chinese to learn about American food safety standards, explains Michael J. de la Merced.

title: Flawed System Suits the Shareholders Just Fine
description: Shareholders cant be counted on.

title: Tips on Archiving Family History, Part 1
description: Readers sent dozens of questions about archiving and preserving family history and stories to Bertram Lyons, an archivist at the American Folklife Center of the Library of Congress in Washington. He manages digital archives relating to folklife, including StoryCorps, which records and collects oral histories. In addition to academic workshops, he participates in public outreach, answering questions from people interested in preserving audio and visual material in analog and digital media, as well as related documents.

title: Grubman: Dish/Sprint Numbers Dont Add Up to Shareholder Value
description: Jack Grubman is a consultant to the telecommunications industry through his firm Magee Group. He was a top-ranked telecommunications research analyst on Wall Street in the 1980s and 1990s. In 2003, he settled a lawsuit with the Securities and Exchange Commission over accusations that his work for investment banking clients led him to publish misleading research reports on companies that his employer, Citigroup, advised. As part of the settlement, in which Mr. Grubman did not admit or deny the allegations, he was barred from the securities industry. Mr. Grubman has no role either as an adviser or an investor in any of the companies discussed in this essay. This is his first public commentary since his settlement a decade ago.

title: Reuters Names New Head of News Operation
description: Thomson Reuters has hired Andrew Rashbass, chief executive of The Economist Group, to take on a newly created role overseeing the sprawling Reuters news operation.

title: 5 Stops on a California Cheese Trail
description: Marcia Barinaga was showing me and seven other visitors around her ridge-top sheep ranch overlooking the long, slender finger of Tomales Bay and the hills of Point Reyes National Seashore in Marin County, north of San Francisco. As she told us about her flock of 100 East Friesians in a pasture where some of the less timid sheep had gathered around, she bussed the pinkish, wet nose of a ewe. It was an offhand gesture but a telling one, revealing a deep affection for the animals that provide the milk she transforms into cheese in the style of her Basque ancestors.

title: Discovering New York, Beyond Manhattan
description: Ever since Greg Young became one-half of The Bowery Boys, the podcast about New York City history he started with his friend Tom Meyers in 2007, visitors to the Big Apple have sought out his tourism recommendations. Forgoing Manhattan, Mr. Young, an amateur historian and Missouri native, sends them to the outer boroughs, to sites that are offbeat but still truly unique to New York City and not overrun with crowds. And they are outdoors, a plus for the summer ahead.

title: Black Flag Returns, in Two Permutations
description: LAS VEGAS  Two singers, two gigs, two cities and stages, the same opening song. Its not my imagination, it begins, drawled. Pause, and then a yell: Ive got a gun at my back!

title: Anatomy of a Scene: The East
description: Zal Batmanglij, the director of The East, narrates a scene from the film.

title: Mary Meeker Peers Into the Future of Mobile, Wearables and Facebook
description: RANCHO PALOS VERDES, Calif.  Mary Meeker, the Internet analyst, has become something of a legend in the tech world for her annual Internet Trends report.

title: The Gun Report: May 29, 2013
description: Its been long reported that the N.R.A. is a front for the nations gun manufacturersBusiness Insider revealed in January that the gun industry and its corporate allies have given the organization between $20 million and $52.6 million since 2005. But did you know the N.R.A. gets paid by the gun? Buried in a recent behind-the-scenes chronicle of the N.R.A.s national convention in the Daily Beast is this striking fact:

title: Rate Stories
description: Ive been getting some questions about the recent rise in long-term interest rates. Those rates are still at levels that would have seemed absurdly low not long ago  but they are up significantly from a few months ago. What should we make of this move?

title: The Nature of Suffering: Gary Greenberg Talks About The Book of Woe
description: This week, the American Psychiatric Association published the fifth edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders. In The Book of Woe, Gary Greenberg, a practicing psychotherapist, criticizes the manual while investigating the history of mental suffering and our attempts to find scientific answers for it. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Greenberg discussed the fifth edition, the ties between the psychiatric and pharmaceutical industries, the effectiveness of antidepressants and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: Reducing Overhead
description: Traveling light, without checking bags, saves passengers time on arrival and money in fees. Now, American Airlines has introduced a new incentive: people traveling with one personal carry-on item that fits under the seat in front of them and do not use the overhead bin can board earlier than some others. And customers dont have to decide in advance; if they have carry-on bags that they were planning to place in overhead storage but wish to board early, they can gate-check one bag at no charge. (The typical fee is $25.) The carrier expects the system to reduce average boarding time, speed departures and thus increase on-time arrivals.

title: A Passengers Bill of Rights
description: The trade group representing major cruise lines has recently adopted a passenger bill of rights that includes several measures suggested this year by Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York. The Cruise Lines International Association adopted 10 rights, including access to backup power, professional emergency medical care; timely information and crews properly trained in emergency and evacuation procedures. The rights apply to American passengers and those who buy their cruise in North America on North American member cruise lines, regardless of the flag the ship sails under. Mr. Schumer called the bill of rights a step in the right direction but said that he had questions on the content and its enforcement.

title: House Hunting in ... Ireland
description: A CONTEMPORARY WATERFRONT HOUSE IN COUNTY CORK, IRELAND

title: House Hunting in Ireland
description: A modern farmhouse property on the coast of County Cork, priced at $2.6 million, consists of three structures with a total of five bedrooms.

title: What Not to Say at the Bedside
description: Having breast cancer four years ago taught Letty Cottin Pogrebin, 73, a lot about being a good friend to someone who is sick.

title: Calls of the Forest
description: Mary E. Blair is a postdoctoral researcher in the American Museum of Natural Historys Center for Biodiversity and Conservation, where she coordinates the Enhancing Diversity in Conservation Science Initiative.

title: Man Killed in the Village Is Remembered as Outgoing and Private
description: Mark Carson, a gay man who was shot to death in Greenwich Village this month, had a favorite phrase he used when people heckled him on the street. Hed say, Pay it and pump, which means dont pay it any attention, keep moving, said Alonzo, 33, an online radio host who said Mr. Carson had been his best friend since they were teenagers on Webster Avenue in the Bronx.

title: Much to His Surprise, Fiery Tortorella Is Out
description: As Rangers coach, John Tortorella was a creature of certitude  opinionated, volatile and confident to the point of arrogance. He drove his players to throw themselves in front of shots, occasionally criticized them in public and often insulted members of the news media. On Monday, as the Rangers packed up their locker room at the end of another season without a Stanley Cup, Tortorella spoke like a man certain he would be around to fix the team. He even said he was looking forward to training camp in the fall.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: The East
description: The director Zal Batmanglij, who was profiled in a recent Arts & Leisure article, has made his second film, a thriller titled The East (May 31) that he wrote with Brit Marling. In this video, he narrates a scene featuring Ms. Marling and Shiloh Fernandez and discusses his interest in a spy thriller made using a smart phone and some paper clips and aluminum cans.

title: Hibbert Has Been Imposing at Both Ends
description: For the first two months of the season, Roy Hibbert looked like a terrible investment. The Pacers had given Hibbert, a 7-foot-2 center, a four-year, $58.4 million contract, the maximum he could be paid under N.B.A. rules, and he seemed to be regressing.

title: Grab Some Popcorn: Big Screen With Big Sound Coming to BAM
description: The movie palace is making a return to Brooklyn this summer. The Harvey Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music will be home to the Steinberg Screen, a 35-foot-by-19-foot digital projection screen, with 42 accompanying surround-sound speakers. That will make the theater, a centerpiece of live productions and concerts, the largest cinema in Brooklyn able to show both 3-D and conventional films, according to BAM officials, who are to announce the new installation on Thursday.

title: Why Summer Isnt That Much Fun
description: David: Now that Memorial Day has come and gone, I feel that summer has truly started. I love this time of year and not only because I look amazing in poplin and any outfit involving spaghetti straps.

title: Economist Flees as Russia Aims Past Protesters
description: MOSCOW  A prominent, liberal-minded economist has fled Russia under pressure from government investigators, as the Kremlins yearlong crackdown moves beyond protesters and their leaders to elite power brokers who are suspected of supporting them.

title: A Fuzzy Image for Federer
description: As the French Open started this week, tennis fans were buzzing about Rafael Nadals attempt to win his unprecedented eighth championship, Novak Djokovics pursuit of his first title, Maria Sharapovas new boyfriend (the 21-year-old Bulgarian player Grigor Dimitrov) and the former champion Roger Federers surprise decision earlier this month to cut his Samson-like locks. His newly shorn look, on global display during his first-round match Sunday (the 17-time Grand Slam titleist won in straight sets, and did the same Wednesday), prompted sharply divided reactions.

title: Shooting Suspect Seeks to Represent Himself in Trial at Fort Hood
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist charged in the deadly shooting rampage at Fort Hood in 2009, asked a judge on Wednesday to allow him to release his team of court-appointed military lawyers so he can represent himself when his trial starts in four weeks.

title: Israeli Plan to Conscript Ultra-Orthodox Advances
description: JERUSALEM  Under popular pressure to fulfill campaign promises to make the burdens of citizenship more equitably shared, an Israeli government committee on Wednesday approved a proposal to phase out wholesale exemptions from military service for ultra-Orthodox Jewish men.

title: Burdette Loses Track of Score, Then the Match
description: Mallory Burdette was beginning to pull ahead of No. 4 Agnieszka Radwanska in their second-round match Wednesday morning on Court 1 at the French Open. But when Burdette briefly got ahead of herself, that all changed quickly.

title: Homes for $820,000
description: An 1840 Greek Revival in Maine; a country place in Kentucky; and a 1997 house in San Antonio.

title: What You Get for ... $820,000
description: SAN ANTONIO

title: Another Man Convicted in 2011 Killing of an Officer
description: A Queens man who participated in a botched drug robbery that led to the shooting death of a New York police officer was convicted of second-degree murder and burglary on Wednesday, becoming the fourth member of his robbery crew to be convicted or to plead guilty.

title: Nasdaq Is Fined $10 Million Over Mishandled Facebook Public Offering
description: Nasdaqs parent company will pay the largest fine ever levied against an exchange for poor systems and decision making both before and after the bungled Facebook initial public offering.

title: U.S. Women on the Rise as Family Breadwinner
description: Women are not only more likely to be the primary caregivers in a family. Increasingly, they are primary breadwinners, too.

title: Soul Doctor to Bring a Singing Rabbi to Broadway
description: Is there still a sizable Jewish audience for Broadway shows? The musical Soul Doctor may shed light on the purchasing power of Jewish theatergoers from the New York region, who were once the backbone of Broadway, an industry that now caters primarily to tourists.

title: Henry Morgentaler, 90, Dies; Abortion Defender in Canada
description: Dr. Henry Morgentaler, Canadas most heralded and vilified abortion doctor, who was assaulted and imprisoned for defying restrictive laws but who won the landmark Canadian Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion nationally in 1988, died on Tuesday at his home in Toronto. He was 90.

title: Food Matters | St.-Tropezs Sophisticated New Palate
description: No one saw it coming. This summer in St.-Tropez, people arent just talking the usual fame and fashion, theyre talking food. Food? In St.-Tropez? Mais, oui! In fact, the only new Michelin three-star restaurant in France this year is La Vague dOr in St.-Tropez, and Bruno Doucet, the hottest bistro chef in Paris, opened a branch of his famously epicurean La Regalade at the sleek Benkirai Hotel last summer.

title: Meet James Gorman, C.E.O. and Music Agent
description: On Wall Street, its not uncommon for children to follow their parents into finance. However, Caroline Gorman, the daughter of Morgan Stanleys chief executive, James Gorman, appears headed down a much different path.

title: How to Make Bank Bail-Ins Work
description: Regulators want banks to be able to go bust like ordinary companies. That means bondholders taking the pain if a bank fails. But if debt investors are to shoulder the risk of suffering a loss, they will need more confidence about what lurks in banks balance sheets.

title: New Flickr: Vast Space for Storage, at No Cost
description: If you ever want to see just how much whining a million Interneters can produce, try giving them something wonderful at no charge.

title: Knife Attack, Not Vehicle Strike, Killed British Soldier, Police Say
description: LONDON  The soldier who was killed on a London sidewalk last week died of multiple incised wounds that he suffered after he was hit by a car, and not from the impact of the vehicle, the Metropolitan Police said in a statement on Wednesday, giving a few details from the findings of a postmortem examination.

title: Going Without Gluten
description: It was probably inevitable that gluten, the current scourge of American diets, be eliminated from makeup as well. Even trace amounts, absorbed through lips or eyes, can impact those with celiac disease. The benefits to the rest of the population are less clear, but nonetheless a number of beauty brands, like the ones below, are capitalizing on the current mass aversion to the grain-derived protein.

title: Cooking With Leaves
description: Aside from looking beautiful, your dinner can be wrapped in a green leaf for a number of reasons. This culinary technique protects food in a secure, impermeable package. Said leaf-wrapped food  meat or fish or savory mixture  may then be grilled, steamed or roasted. In the process, the leaves add a unique flavor and perfume to the dish.

title: Citys Largest Public Employees Union Endorses Liu
description: In a boost to his embattled mayoral campaign, John C. Liu, the city comptroller, received the support on Wednesday of the citys largest public employees union, District Council 37.

title: Philharmonic Maps Out a Kaleidoscopic Biennial
description: When the New York Philharmonic announced its 2013-14 season in January, it sketched out a major new initiative, the NY Phil Biennial, in broad terms and a sprinkling of intriguing details. On Wednesday, the orchestra filled in more of the blanks, making clear that it is expanding its contemporary-music activities well beyond the composer residencies, the new-music series Contact! and the special events that it has embraced since Alan Gilbert took over as the Philharmonics music director four years ago.

title: Kremlin-Owned Network Hires Larry King
description: Last Updated, Thursday, 6:40 p.m.>The Russian governments satellite news network Russia Today, or RT, announced on Wednesday that it had hired Larry King to host a mold-breaking political talk show for its American channel.

title: Unheralded American Tries to Change That
description: A year ago at the French Open, Varvara Lepchenko was the last American standing, beating Sloane Stephens by a day. With her fourth-round showing, she realistically booked a spot on the United States Olympic team.

title: A Second Democrat Calls for Silver to Resign
description: ALBANY  And then there were two.

title: Snapshots From Venice
description: Highlights from the Venice Biennale by the chief art critic Holland Cotter with updates each day.

title: Dance New Amsterdam Files for Bankruptcy
description: After years of struggles, including possible eviction because of unpaid rent; cash flow problems; trouble getting foundation support; and the loss of a major rental partnership, Dance New Amsterdam, a dance space in Lower Manhattan, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, the centers board announced on Wednesday.

title: Hosting a Dog? Check Your Insurance Coverage
description: What could be more comforting than heading out of town and leaving your dog not at a cramped kennel, but at the home of a canine-loving friend?

title: An Endorsement Thats a Blessing
description: LEN, MEXICO  When Pope Benedict XVI retired in February, becoming the first pope to step down in 600 years, Vatican officials were bombarded with vexing questions, including some that may have seemed oddly trivial: What would he wear on his feet? Would he keep the signature red shoes of the papacy?

title: Food Chronicle
description: POOR MANS FEAST  A Love Story of Comfort, Desire, and the Art of Simple Cooking  By Elissa Altman  Chronicle, $27.50.

title: The Signature Strikes Program
description: Toward the end of a May 27 article in The Times about President Obamas speech in which, among other things, he mentioned setting new standards for ordering drone strikes against non-Americans, there was this rather disturbing paragraph:

title: Mozart Never Made It to America, but His Violin and Viola Are On the Way
description: Though he made his way all around Europe in his brief lifetime, Mozart never found his way to the United States. But a violin and viola that he owned and played will be making their first American appearances early next month, in concerts in Boston and New York. Both instruments will be heard at Jordan Hall during the Boston Early Music Festival, when the violinist Amandine Beyer and the violist Milos Valent offer a chamber music program with the pianist Kristian Bezuidenhout and the clarinetist Erich Hoeprich (June 10). The instruments will also be on display at the festivals exhibition on June 12.

title: Newsweek Is Put Up for Sale
description: Newsweek, the once-venerable magazine that experienced one of the most precipitous declines in media over the last decade, is up for sale.

title: Was Wali ur-Rehman an Imminent' Threat?
description: Wali ur-Rehman, deputy leader of the Pakistani Taliban, was killed by a drone strike in the North Waziristan area of Pakistan early Wednesday morning.

title: Another World to Conquer
description: Aby Rosen, already a real estate mogul and world-class art collector, is now setting his sights on the citys night-life scene.

title: Making His Life the Party
description: The Paramount Hotel in Times Square may not have hosted a spectacle like this since the 40s, when Billy Rose, the hallowed New York showman, trotted out 6-foot-tall showgirls for Broadway divas and Hollywood stars.

title: Suicide Bombers Attack a Red Cross Compound in Eastern Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In a shock to humanitarian aid workers, suicide bombers in eastern Afghanistan on Wednesday assaulted the offices of the International Committee of the Red Cross, an organization that has worked in the country for more than 30 years without suffering a concerted attack and has received praise from all sides.

title: For Medicare, Immigrants Offer Surplus, Study Finds
description: Immigrants have contributed billions of dollars more to Medicare in recent years than the program has paid out on their behalf, according to a new study, a pattern that goes against the notion that immigrants are a drain on federal health care spending.

title: I.P.O. for Empire State Building Wins Backing of Shareholders
description: After more than a year of intense behind-the-scenes battles, stakeholders that own the Empire State Building approved a plan this week to sell the 102-story tower as part of an initial public offering.

title: Josphine De La Baume, A Life Kissed by Success
description: Tiny, curvy and with a voice scratchy from cigarettes, Josphine de La Baume was picking at a plate of sauted greens at the Bowery Hotel. Outside, on a sunny April afternoon, a line of paparazzi waited impatiently.

title: An Inside Look at the Beatles: Ringos Photos
description: During his lengthy solo turn in A Hard Days Night, Ringo Starr takes a walk around London with a camera, snapping pictures and getting into trouble. Perhaps because of that image, Mr. Starr came to be thought of as the biggest shutterbug among the Beatles, and until he lost much of his collection in a fire in Los Angeles in 1979 he was believed to be the groups unofficial archivist and memorabilia collector.

title: Bachmann: Three Missed Opportunities
description: The Timess Michael D. Shear highlights the ways Michele Bachmann could have changed politics but didnt.

title: Daft Punk Is No. 1 on Album Chart
description: A long-awaited album by a beloved act, drenched in the sound of vintage disco-funk, gets a lot of advance promotion and opens at No. 1 with a bang. No, not Justin Timberlakes latest, The 20/20 Experience. This week that accolade belongs to Daft Punk, the robot-hatted French dance duo, whose comeback album, Random Access Memories (Daft Life/Columbia), has a big start on the Billboard chart.

title: Another Young American Woman Advances
description: PARIS  Jamie Hampton won three three-set matches to reach the semifinals in Brussels last week, and she went the distance again Wednesday to send off 25th-seeded Lucie Safarova, 7-6 (5), 3-6, 9-7, in the first round of the French Open.

title: World Coffee Champions
description: Pete Licata of Parisi Artisan Coffee in Kansas City, Mo., won the  2013 World Barista Championship on Sunday in Melbourne, Australia, becoming only the second American to win the competition, which was established in 2000.

title: Tech Career Advice From Googles Women
description: The women at Google are outnumbered by the men, as is the case at almost all technology companies. Even so, talented women are playing major roles in building new technology, and they have some advice for others in the field.

title: No Hard Feelings, as Ratner Gives $1 Million to Academy Museum
description: LOS ANGELES  Brett Ratner is not one to hold a grudge.

title: New York City Wants to Revive Old Voting Machines
description: New York City has spent $95 million over the past few years to bring its election process into the 21st century, replacing its hulking lever voting machines with electronic scanners.

title: Re-Imagining Penn Station
description: New Yorks Pennsylvania Station is a dog of a transit hub. So, the citys Municipal Art Society invited architectural firms to dream up ways to turn the station into a suitably grand gateway to the nations largest city. Four top firms submitted plans that are dramatic, exciting and sadly improbable. They all face two monumental hurdles.

title: Newly Released Books
description: Call it octogenarian chic: This months collection offers a pair of novels that feature old guys rallying for second chances. And there are two aggressively imaginative short story collections that resist any labels whatsoever.

title: American Contractor Held in Cuba Loses a Lawsuit
description: MEXICO CITY  A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit against the United States by an American contractor serving a 15-year sentence in Cuba for distributing communications equipment there under a State Department program, ending an effort to press the Obama administration into a financial payout and a more vigorous push for his release.

title: In Match That Fulfills Potential, Monfils Dazzles Home Crowd
description: PARIS  Ernests Gulbis and Gal Monfils had never played a tour-level match against each other, but by the end of the third set of their match Wednesday at the French Open, they were chatting like old friends, joking about how long it was taking to resolve their tennis conflict on the Philippe Chatrier Court.

title: A Calculator to Compare Closing Cost Options
description: Anyone who has ever bought a home knows how confusing it can be to decide on the best financing options. Is it better to pay closing costs upfront or build them into the cost of the loan and pay them over time?

title: Seeing Chechnyas Wonders, Long Before Getting There
description: Six years after starting to think about Chechnya, the disputed Russian republic that became the setting for his acclaimed new novel, Anthony Marra visited for the first time last summer, signing up on the Internet for something called The Seven Wonders of Chechnya Tour.

title: A New Castle in the Realm of Fiction
description: Jeannette Wallss new novel, The Silver Star, is systematically built, each brick put in place for a reason. Its easy to understand why writing fiction makes Ms. Walls so methodical. Her memoir, The Glass Castle, told a far more painful story, and Ms. Walls surely knows that her personal history colors perceptions of whatever else she writes. The Glass Castle remains on best-seller lists eight years after it first appeared.

title: Spandex (Mostly) on, Those Pole Dancers Return
description: If ever there was a movie deserving of a sendup, its Paul Verhoevens 1995 turkey Showgirls. The lurid story of the rise of Nomi Malone from hitchhiker to pole dancer to Las Vegas star, the movie has a script (by Joe Eszterhas) that practically parodies itself. Its ruthless female rivalries, maudlin dialogue and tawdry show-business abuses are catnip for any devotee of camp.

title: Take My Team  Please
description: A curious pattern has emerged in recent years in which people high up in the Mets organization take shots at the team.

title: Senior Editor at Poetry Magazine Gets the Top Job
description: Don Share, a poet with 10 books to his credit, has been named the 12th editor of Poetry Magazine, the Chicago-based publication founded by Harriet Monroe in 1912.

title: A Vegan With a Dark Side
description: Venus flytraps are sort of my spirit animal, David Klasfeld said, referring to the lusty pink and green plant tattoos curling around his bicep. Theres a line from Little Shop of Horrors: they say the meek shall inherit, and for some reason people are always telling me how humble I am. But I do know what Im doing, and if anything Im trying to be aggressive.

title: Hundreds Celebrate Frances First Gay Marriage
description: PARIS  Two men wed in the southern city of Montpellier on Wednesday in the first legal marriage between people of the same sex in France.

title: Berkshire Unit in $5.6 Billion Deal for Nevadas Largest Electric Utility
description: The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett dived back into the acquisition pool on Wednesday with a large bet in the energy sector. MidAmerican Energy Holdings, a unit of Mr. Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway, agreed to buy Nevadas largest electric utility, NV Energy, for about $5.6 billion.

title: Letters Threatening Mayor Tested Positive for Ricin
description: Two letters that contained threats to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg  one addressed to him, the other to a lobbyist who works on his gun control campaign  have tested positive for the deadly poison ricin, the authorities said on Wednesday.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Afghanistan, Colombia, Spain and Vatican City.

title: Andy Cohen, Playing to a Tough Room
description: Few industries are as ripe for parody as fashion, and yet few comedians have managed to get so much as a snicker out of a roomful of designers when they all come together for their annual awards night each June. Many have tried. Tracey Ullman spoofed the recession in 2009. Last year, Seth Meyers reprised Marc Jacobs in drag, which is a tough act to follow.

title: Some Grub With Your Rub?
description: The farm-to-table trend that has sprouted up in dining rooms across the country is now finding its place in spa rooms from Laguna Beach, Calif., to Cambridge, Mass, with natural ingredients being grown on sprawling produce farms and in hotel rooftop gardens for the sole purpose of being picked, blended and then slathered on clients skin.

title: On Piano, but Lauding a Trumpeter
description: What does the Brazilian jazz pianist and singer Eliane Elias have in common with Chet Baker? Not much, I would venture. But Ms. Eliass new album, I Thought About You (a Tribute to Chet Baker), is her take on songs associated with the cool jazz trumpeter and singer whose music evokes a faraway gaze into a cloudy sky. Its release coincided with Ms. Eliass Tuesday evening opening at Birdland, where she led a group that included Marc Johnson on bass, Steve Cardenas on guitar and Mauricio Zottarelli on drums.

title: A Gala in Venice to Toast Chinas Most Famous Dissident
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: More Seek a Slice of the Pie
description: Who says pizza delivery is just for dorm rooms and childrens birthday parties?

title: A Dose of Russian Music Spikes Up an American Season
description: Every season by New York City Ballet is, in quantitative terms, the envy of the ballet world. During its current six-week season, for example, the company dances no fewer than 38 ballets. The first 25 were all to American music. Now the company is adding other fare, chiefly to music by Russian composers  principally Stravinsky and Tchaikovsky.

title: 6 Bosnian Croats Convicted of Killing Muslims During War
description: PARIS  Six Bosnian Croats were found guilty on Wednesday of persecuting and murdering Muslim civilians during the 1992-95 Bosnian war. The United Nations tribunal in The Hague that tried the six former fighters said the crimes were part of an ethnic cleansing campaign in Bosnia that was planned and coordinated by the leaders of neighboring Croatia.

title: Winning the MRSA Battle in Hospitals
description: Treating every single patient who enters an intensive care unit with special disinfectant soaps and ointments drastically reduces the spread of the drug-resistant bacteria MRSA and cuts the rate of bloodstream infections in hospitals, a new study shows.

title: Comics Mother of the Weird Stuff Is Moving On
description: For Karen Berger, a day at the office used to mean happily invading other peoples dreams and bringing them to life. As the executive editor of the Vertigo imprint at DC Comics, she oversaw illustrated tales of fantasy, speculative fiction and outcast characters who did not fit into the publishers mainstream lineup of costumed adventurers.

title: Promises, Promises
description: Async nightmares, the pyramid of doom, nested callback hierarchy, control flow: If you are familiar with any of these terms, you should be familiar with JavaScript promises.

title: Having Fun Is Hard Work
description: As the 1990s waned, every upper middle-class woman in New York City seemed to be carrying a version of the same shoulder bag: a rectangular zippered tote with Kate Spade appliqud in lowercase on the front, as if on a name tag for summer camp.

title: Month of Breaking News Lifts CNN and Fox, but Sinks MSNBC
description: A second straight month of big breaking events proved one thing: MSNBC is a television news channel that does not gain any advantage when news is being made.

title: Its Happy, Its Danceable and It May Rule Summer
description: Students in this years high school musical at the School of the Future in Manhattan were milling around the auditorium before a performance the other day, when a senior hooked his phone to the sound system and played a new song he had found online. The beat was pure 1970s disco  smooth vocals, a funky syncopated guitar riff riding over a tight drum-and-bass groove.

title: Voters Speak, and Amazon Orders Shows
description: Amazon, which has put its foray into original television programming up to a democratic vote, has ordered five series that will be offered on Amazon Prime, the companys subscription service.

title: UJA-Federation of New Yorks Womens Philanthropy
description: The UJA-Federation of New Yorks Womens Philanthropy pro-am is the worlds most successful single-session charity bridge game. It was started 49 years ago by Tubby and Sam Stayman and Victor Mitchell.

title: Pace Picks Up in Fast Data Storage
description: Get ready for some serious competition in what has been one of the sleepier, multibillion-dollar technology businesses.

title: Modified Wheat Is Discovered in Oregon
description: Unapproved genetically engineered wheat has been found growing on a farm in Oregon, federal officials said Wednesday, a development that could disrupt American exports of the grain.

title: A Necessary Stop
description: The breakout star of Punk: Chaos to Couture, the new fashion exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is neither the maverick designer Vivienne Westwood nor modern punks like Gareth Pugh and the sisters of Rodarte, but a toilet. At the shows entrance, visitors are immediately confronted with a re-creation of a filthy restroom of CBGB, the Bowery club that was one of the birthplaces of punk, as it would have appeared in the mid-1970s  drawing reactions, at least among those who remember the original facilities, ranging from amazement to ire. There are three urinals, two toilets with the seats up, two sinks, a bare light bulb, a brick wall, countless used cigarette butts and a whole lot of graffiti, mostly the names of the bands that performed at the club.Patti Smith once said all the action happened in the toilets, according to Andrew Bolton, the curator of the exhibition, and it is a place where history is literally written on the walls.

title: Former Bush Official Said to Be Obama Pick to Lead F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama plans to nominate James B. Comey, a former hedge fund executive who served as a senior Justice Department official under President George W. Bush, to replace Robert S. Mueller III as the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to two people with knowledge of the selection.

title: Scouting Report
description: Summer Hours

title: An Espresso Machine Called PrimaDonna
description: A different sort of person might test out the PrimaDonna S, a new espresso maker from DeLonghi, and rave that it brews barista-grade espresso in one minute. They might marvel at its fully automatic grinder with 13 settings, its dual heating systems (one for espresso, the other for heating and frothing milk) or the way a high-tech machine capable of making espresso, cappuccino, caff latte and macchiato drinks at the touch of a button has been ingeniously designed to fit into a slim, stainless-steel box.

title: The Rewards of Grafting
description: Bigger, juicier, better-tasting tomatoes, and more of them.

title: In Defense of Grafting
description: Grafted heirloom tomatoes are the hot tamale in the garden this year. And it makes sense when you think about it.

title: Guarding a Fleet of Cooking Vessels
description: As the familys Sunday morning pancake and bacon chef, I have long scorned my stoves front-left burner for its inability to distribute heat evenly. My quest for uncharred bacon, I knew in my bones, would fail unless the gods dropped a Viking range in my lap.

title: At Rutgers, Its Time to Move On
description: Politicians and other critics are calling for more firings at seemingly dysfunctional Rutgers University, but William C. Rhoden says its time for everyone to take a deep breath.

title: Salt-and-Pepper Shakers
description: Matthew Lightner likes food with an element of surprise. As the executive chef of Atera, an 18-seat TriBeCa restaurant with two Michelin stars, he delights diners with a combination of foraged ingredients, technical innovation and unexpected presentations.

title: Shopping for Salt-and-Pepper Shakers
description: Matthew Lightner, the executive chef of Atera, goes shopping for the most commonplace (and commonly overlooked) fixture on the dining table.

title: Theyre Called Troubles for a Reason
description: In the grim opening to James Marshs Shadow Dancer, a girl in Belfast sends her kid brother out on an errand and smack into the turmoil of British occupation in 1973. Cut 20 years later to the girl, now a young woman, riding the London Underground, destination unknown. Until, that is, her strange behavior reveals a new calling as an I.R.A. soldier.

title: Red Rooms
description: A St. Petersburg apartment decorated to provoke conversation about a dark era in Russias history.

title: Back in the (30s) U.S.S.R.
description: Midway through the restoration of a stately old top-floor apartment in one of this citys fashionable neighborhoods, the owner swiveled to adopt an entirely new plan. It was more than a shift in the color scheme.

title: In the Trees, Away From It All
description: A lofty brand of architecture is on display in the new reality television series Treehouse Masters.

title: Houses for Dreamers (and Kids)
description: Pete Nelson, an owner of TreeHouse Workshop, outside Seattle, is an expert in his field: the design and building of treehouses. Such a distinction once guaranteed a book deal and, indeed, Mr. Nelson has written several lavishly illustrated books on the subject. But these days, being an expert at an esoteric trade more likely leads to a reality show, and on Friday Treehouse Masters has its premiere on Animal Planet. It follows Mr. Nelson, who is 50, and his crew as they build one over-the-top arboreal home after another.

title: Otherworldly Glow
description: A customer walked in and said, I expected you to be an 85-year-old fortune teller, said Melissa Benovic of Mosaic Lamps, in the East Village. Earlier this year, Ms. Benovic, who is in fact 35, opened the 300-square-foot boutique with her fianc, Ilker Arslan, 36, a native of Turkey. They were inspired by a visit they had made three years ago to the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul, where they saw shop after shop selling glass-mosaic lamps tinted emerald, ruby and cobalt. The fixtures, which have brass fittings and are lighted with LEDs, are not for reading, or for threading a needle. They are mood-setting, Ms. Benovic said. Theyre warm, and calming. Prices range from $55 for a 10-inch-high lamp to $2,500 for a 43-inch-long chandelier. 208 East Sixth Street (Cooper Square). Information: (212) 228-1964 or mosaiclampsnyc.com.

title: Plenty of Frames, but Not a Picture in Sight
description: Last week, at the Wanted Design show in New York, the Miami-based designer Luis Pons presented five furniture groups that incorporate picture frames. In the collection called Frame, for example, classical picture-frame moldings are applied to minimal 1950s-style credenzas, dressers and nightstands, concealing drawers, as shown here. Mr. Pons created his first Frame prototype in 2005, and has made custom versions since. But standard sizes and finishes are now available for the first time.

title: Namaste, My Little Chickadee
description: Michele Quan, originally a jewelry designer who made her name as a founder of the company Me&Ro, became a ceramist almost a decade ago and now works in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Many of her handmade stoneware and porcelain objects, including garlands and bells, are meant to dangle from trees. This is also the case with her latest: stoneware birdhouses. I imagined these becoming part of the landscape, and how beautiful they could be, moving with the wind, with the ever-changing background, she said. The tubular birdhouses are punctuated by a central hole sized for chickadees, bluebirds, wrens, sparrows and warblers. Other openings are for ventilation and drainage. Each piece is hand-painted, in motifs including stripes, flowers, stylized leaf clusters, a sun and moon, and Sanskrit calligraphy reading Om mani padme hum, the mantra of the bodhisattva of compassion. A hemp cord is attached for hanging. Prices range from $250 to $475. Information: mquan.com.

title: Sales at Flor, Maine Woolens and Others
description: Furniture, appliances, kitchen and bath accessories and flooring, from B&B Italia, Clive Christian NY, SieMatic and Hastings Tile & Bath, among others, will be up to 85 percent off during the Architects and Designers Building sample sale, June 3 to 7 (the Next vanity at Hastings Tile & Bath, regularly $2,010, will be $804); 150 East 58th Street (Lexington Avenue), (212) 644-2766, adbuilding.com.

title: A Cup Is at the Heart of a Trademark Dispute
description: First came the tattoo, etched across the knuckles of Sam Penixs right fist in 2009. It said I [coffee cup] N Y, the bold red cup leaping out from the black letters.

title: How to Pick a Winner?
description: In the race for this years Council of Fashion Designers of America awards, the field is unusually competitive.

title: Rhode Islands Chafee to Join Democratic Party
description: BOSTON  Gov. Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, the only Independent governor in the nation, plans to switch to the Democratic Party as he faces a tough re-election fight next year.

title: Video: At Rutgers, Its Time to Move On
description: The Rutgers athletics program has gone from one scandal to the next over the last two months. An abusive basketball coach and the athletic director lost their jobs and were replaced by a coach with a faulty rsum and an athletic director with a questionable past. All of that has brought Robert L. Barchi, the university president, fully into the cross hairs of his critics.

title: Soldier Is Expected to Plead Guilty in Afghan Massacre
description: Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, the soldier charged with killing 16 Afghan civilians in what is considered the deadliest war crime by a single American soldier in the post-9/11 era, will plead guilty to avoid the death penalty, his lawyer said Wednesday.

title: Welcome Sight at the Stadium: Jeter Playing Catch
description: A handful of Yankee fans who showed up early on Wednesday to watch batting practice saw something to help soothe the wounds from two losses to the Mets.

title: As Glaciers Melt, Alpine Mountains Lose Their Glue, Threatening Swiss Village
description: GRINDELWALD, Switzerland  Marco Bomio recalls that bright Sunday morning in June 2006 as if it were yesterday. Mr. Bomio, 59, a school principal and mountain guide, attended a religious service on a high mountain meadow to mark the founding of a local guide group.

title: Bachmanns Retirement Reduces Electoral Risk for G.O.P.
description: Some Democrats are giddy that the Tea Party provocateur and four-term incumbent Michele Bachmann has announced her intention to retire from Congress  but her decision may allow Republicans to avoid a toss-up race in what would otherwise be a reasonably safe district for the G.O.P.

title: Twelve Tries to Indy Victory
description: Tony Kanaan, winner of the Indianapolis 500 after 12 tries, discussed his lucky charm and life after the race.

title: More Aggressive Action Urged to Curb Hospital Infections
description: Treating every patient who enters an intensive care unit with special disinfectant soaps and ointments greatly reduces the spread of MRSA, or methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, and cuts the rate of bloodstream infections in hospitals, a study shows. Currently, patients admitted to the I.C.U. are screened for MRSA, and those found to harbor it are placed in isolation. But a study published Wednesday in The New England Journal of Medicine found that using disinfectant soaps and ointments on every I.C.U. patient reduced bloodstream infections by up to 44 percent.

title: Prosecutor in Argentina Sees Iranian Plot in Latin America
description: BUENOS AIRES  The special prosecutor investigating the 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center here that killed 85 people released a report on Wednesday claiming that Iran had set up intelligence stations in different parts of Latin America with the aim of carrying out terrorist attacks directly or through Hezbollah, the powerful Lebanese militant group.

title: California: Arrest in Disneyland Blast
description: A Disneyland employee was arrested after a small explosion in the parks Mickeys Toontown area, the police said Wednesday. The employee, Christian Barnes, 22, was arrested Tuesday on suspicion of possessing a destructive device; he was being held on $1 million bail. Police believe a dry ice bomb was used Tuesday in a trash can. No one was injured.

title: Roam the World and Keep the Cellphone on a Budget
description: Getting ready for a summer vacation abroad? Then you have a lot to anticipate: fine food, great wine, historical museums  and thousand-dollar cellphone bills.

title: A Boost for Players Who Are Far From the Top
description: PARIS  At the time, it was the best achievement of his burgeoning career. Somdev Devvarman was 18, had just finished playing juniors, and was a few months from starting at the University of Virginia, where he become a two-time N.C.A.A. singles champion. He was a wild-card entry into a futures event, the lowest rung in mens professional tennis. He did not expect to win. He did.

title: The Lock Gets an Update
description: RANCHO PALOS VERDES, Calif. Yves Bhar, an industrial designer, has helped shape the look of Jawbone headsets, the OUYA gaming console and worked with companies such as Samsung and Puma, and the One Laptop Per Child project.

title: Woodss Strong Start Is Lost in PGA Tour Drama
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  The Surreal World, a reality TV show produced by PGA Tour Commissioner Tim Finchem and featuring a rotating cast of several dozen golfers from diverse backgrounds who interact on a different course each episode, is being pre-empted this week for a breaking news story.

title: Tracing Images and Heeding Voices to Learn the Basics of Reading
description: Whatever magical addictive power was infused into my iPad in the factory, it seems to have the strongest effect on my children, who are 2 and 4 years old. They dont use the tablet just for silly games. They also love the applications that mix together education and play.

title: New Jersey Sent Welfare Checks to Prisoners
description: Reining in welfare, unemployment benefits and state pension costs have become standard rallying cries for Republican politicians  particularly those with an eye on the White House. But Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, who has often talked about his own cost-cutting credentials, was told on Wednesday that the state had been a bit too generous under his watch.

title: Dish Raises Its Bid for Clearwire
description: What is Dish Networks chairman, Charles W. Ergen, up to?

title: Lewis A. Yocum Dies at 65; Repaired Arms and Careers in Baseball
description: Dr. Lewis A. Yocum, one of baseballs most renowned orthopedic surgeons, who saved the careers of the Washington Nationals young pitching stars Stephen Strasburg and Jordan Zimmermann and numerous other major leaguers, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan Beach, Calif. He was 65.

title: Rodman Not First Choice for North Korea Trip
description: Offended by criticism that Dennis Rodmans basketball diplomacy was a marketing gimmick for their season finale on North Korea, the creators of Vice, a new HBO newsmagazine with a penchant for daredevilish themes, said Wednesday that Mr. Rodman had improved the program but was not even their first choice.

title: Amid Protests Over Free Tuition, Mayor Urges Graduates to Donate
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg opened his address to newly minted Cooper Union graduates on Wednesday with a few well-researched jokes about some of the colleges best-loved institutions: the notoriously difficult professor; the grueling senior project; the campus watering hole.

title: Clarence Burke Jr., Singer in the R&B Hit O-o-h Child, Dies at 64
description: Clarence Burke Jr., the lead singer of the Five Stairsteps, a sibling rhythm-and-blues group that had its best-known hit in 1970 with O-o-h Child, died on Sunday in Marietta, Ga. He had turned 64 the day before.

title: 2 Diplomats Met Uneven Fates in Benghazi Uproar
description: WASHINGTON  The political tempest over last Septembers deadly attacks on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, has left a path of dented careers in its wake. But as with many storms, the residual damage is proving to be distinctly uneven.

title: Documents Show Obama Officials in Tension Over British Banks
description: Government documents have recently emerged that offer a rare behind-the-scenes glimpse into the Obama administrations decision-making as it prepared to take actions against two big British banks.

title: Detroits Davos
description: ONCE a year, business and political leaders from metropolitan Detroit travel to an island resort that bans all motorized vehicles and talk about the regional economy.

title: Ecology Lessons From the Cold War
description: CORVALLIS, Ore.  TODAY the effort to preserve the planets biodiversity is often seen as a campaign to save the whales for their own sake, or to give polar bears a few more winters on the Arctic ice. But in the 1950s, when the concept was first discussed, it was understood that far more was at stake. The conservation of variety, as it was called during the early years of the cold war, was no less than a strategy of human survival.

title: Gitmos Other Prisoner
description: On the front page of its Memorial Day weekend edition last Friday, USA Today ran an arresting article under the headline: From Boyhood to the Battlefield. The photo of a young boy with a baseball bat over his shoulder, staring forthrightly into the camera, promised a feel-good holiday story, a promise quickly dashed by the headlines smaller type: These children of 9/11 died fighting its war.

title: Winning the Close Ones Is Working Fine for the Kings
description: LOS ANGELES  For a team that has been to the summit, the defending Stanley Cup champion Los Angeles Kings have managed to conquer quite an assortment of new challenges this postseason.

title: Otto Muehl, Actionist Artist And Provocateur, Dies at 87
description: Otto Muehl, an artist whose work combined sex, violence, gastronomy and bodily effluence with unbridled abandon, died on Sunday at his commune near Faro in southern Portugal. He was 87 and had lived in Portugal since 1997, when he was released from an Austrian prison after being convicted of having sex with minors.

title: Members of Rutgers Panel See Flawed Hiring Process
description: On Tuesday afternoon, as politicians and major Rutgers donors were publicly criticizing the university for hiring Julie Hermann, an athletic director with a checkered history, the leaders of the search committee sent an e-mail to the groups members assuring them that the process that led to Hermanns hiring had been fair and transparent.

title: Belief Is the Least Part of Faith
description: Some Sundays ago, I was part of a sermon in my universitys church. It was the kind of ecumenical church in which Id grown up. The minister and I sat on the proscenium above the congregation and below the stained-glass windows, and spoke about the ways that evangelical Christians understood God  a subject on which I had written a book. Afterward, there was a lunch open to the community. The questions people asked as we ate our avocado-and-cheese sandwiches circled around the puzzle of belief. Why do people believe in God? What is our evidence that there is an invisible agent who has a real impact on our lives? How can those people be so confident?

title: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., a lightning rod of Republican attacks during President Obamas first term, is now contending with a new round of criticism over the Justice Departments campaign against leaks to the news media.

title: Bachmann Bows Out
description: Minnesotas rhetorical Molotov-cocktail-throwing congresswoman, Michele Bachmann, will not be returning to the House of Representatives. (Pause for applause.)

title: Michele, Heres the Bell
description: If Michele Bachmann leaves Congress, does that mean the end of the Light Bulb Freedom of Choice Act? That was pretty much my favorite Michele Bachmann piece of legislation.

title: The School-to-Prison Pipeline
description: School officials across the country responded to a surge in juvenile crime during the 1980s and the Columbine High School shootings a decade later by tightening disciplinary policies and increasing the number of police patrolling public schools. One unfortunate result has been the creation of a repressive environment in which young people are suspended, expelled or even arrested over minor misbehaviors  like talking back or disrupting class  that would once have been handled by the principal.

title: An Opening to Strengthen Chemical Regulations
description: A bill co-sponsored by eight Democrats and eight Republicans was introduced in the Senate last week to revise the Toxic Substances Control Act, which governs the regulation of chemicals used in consumer products and manufacturing processes. Almost everyone agrees that the law, enacted in 1976, is badly flawed because of the complexity, costs and delays it imposes on regulating chemicals.

title: A Deal That Could Benefit Mobile Users
description: A federal government committee has cleared the proposed acquisition of Sprint by SoftBank, a Japanese telecommunications company, after securing concessions from both of them that should address national security concerns about the deal. Though they still have to clear a few more hurdles, the deals approval by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States is encouraging news.

title: Salvadoran Court Denies Abortion to Ailing Woman
description: MEXICO CITY  El Salvadors highest court on Wednesday denied an appeal from a woman with a high-risk pregnancy to be allowed to undergo an abortion, upholding the countrys strict law banning abortion under any circumstances.

title: What to Watch on Day 5 at the French Open
description: With the tournament back on schedule after Tuesdays postponements, here are six second-round matches worth viewing during Thursdays action at Roland Garros. The rain, however, may again throw things off schedule.

title: An Ode to John Tortorella
description: John Tortorellas lasting legacy with the Rangers will not, alas, be a Stanley Cup. Instead, he will mostly be remembered for his verbal sparring with the New York news media. This is one way of depicting that. But sometimes moments like these require poetry. Here is an appreciation of Tortorella, using his own words from his Rangers tenure:

title: Is Obamacare Too Complicated to Succeed?
Metaphor for Dysfunction
description: To the Editor:

title: The Greatest Dangers to Liberty
description: To the Editor:

title: Psychiatry on the Scientific Spectrum
description: To the Editor:

title: When the Jersey Shore Meets the Hamptons
description: To the Editor:

title: Keep the Money Flowing to Community Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: Travels of the President Under a Microscope in an Era of Belt Tightening
description: CHICAGO  Perhaps it is nothing more than an accident of timing that as federal workers brace for a summer filled with unpaid furlough days, their leaders are traveling the nation and globe on trips that exude luxury.

title: Giants Sign Linebacker Bosworth
description: Linebacker Kyle Bosworth, the nephew of Brian Bosworth and a former Jacksonville Jaguar, was signed by the Giants, according to Twitter account postings by Bosworth and his agent. An undrafted free agent signed out of U.C.L.A. in 2010, Bosworth played in every Jacksonville game last season. He started the first five games and made 53 tackles with one interception. Bosworth, 26, has periodically been used at middle linebacker.

title: Chances of U.N. Peace Talks on Syria Appear Dim as Both Sides Dig In
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Antagonists in the Syrian conflict appeared to harden their negotiating positions on Wednesday, further dimming the possibility that the United Nations would be able to convene talks in coming weeks aimed at halting the civil war despite intensified diplomatic pressure from both the United States and Russia.

title: Sallie Mae Will Split Old Loans From New
description: The nations largest private student lender, Sallie Mae, is cleaving itself into two companies  a move that will create a new home for more than $100 billion of student loans amid broad concerns from federal authorities and consumer advocates that graduates hobbled by debt are increasingly falling behind on their payments.

title: Williams Rolls, as Wozniacki and Keys Exit
description: PARIS  It is a measure of Serena Williamss form whether her news conferences focus on the match just finished or on broader topics.

title: No Link Seen Between Child Stimulant Use and Later Drug Abuse
description: An analysis published Wednesday by the American Medical Association said children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder who take stimulant medication do not have a lower risk over all for later substance abuse, contradicting the longstanding and influential message that such medicines tend to deter those with the disorder from abusing other substances.

title: Chinas Food Deal Extends Its Reach, Already Mighty
description: If you dined on tilapia recently, chances are it came from China. And that artificial vanilla you just used to make cookies? It, too, may have made the same long journey to your kitchen in the United States.

title: Venezuela: New Details in Strip Club Shooting
description: American officials on Wednesday provided new details about the two employees of the embassy in Caracas who were wounded in an early-morningshooting in a strip club on Tuesday. The State Department said that one of the men was a member of the United States armed services and the other was a civilian. Both men worked in the office of the defense attach, but the State Department and the Department of Defense would not say whatthemen did there.

title: No More Comments
description: Coach John Tortorellas dismissive remarks toward New York reporters did not lead to his firing by the Rangers, but his over-the-top terseness became his trademark.

title: Corrections: May 30, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Firm Last Words
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  As Ive mentioned, there is no need to feel like you are going crazy when you solve a puzzle like todays grid by Julian Lim, because I am here to do that for you. We here at the Wordplay offices realize that you have a choice of crossword blogs to read, so we like to thank you by offering frequent tests of my sanity as a public service. Youre welcome.

title: Why Cant America Be Sweden?
description: Daron Acemoglu, an eminent economist at M.I.T., has ignited a firestorm by arguing that contemporary forces of globalization bar the United States from adopting the liberal social welfare policies of Scandinavian countries.

title: Italy: Oldest Known Torah Scroll Found, Scholar Says
description: An Italian scholar said Wednesday that he had discovered the oldest known complete Torah scroll, dating from the 12th to the 13th century. The roll, which contains the Pentateuch, or five books of Moses, was stored in the library of the University of Bolognaand mistakenly catalogued as a document from the 17thcentury.Mauro Perani, a professor of Hebrew, said that the scroll was written and its segments of sheepskin sewed together between 1155 and 1225. He said that it was not the oldest known biblical text, but it was the oldest scroll of the Pentateuch found so far. Two independent studies corroborated the scrolls age through carbon-dating tests, the university said.

title: In Raising Scores, 1 2 3 Is Easier Than A B C
description: TROY, N.Y.  David Javsicas, a popular seventh-grade reading teacher known for urging students to act out dialogue in the books they read in class, sometimes feels wistful for the days when he taught math.

title: Iraq: Bombing Kills Members of Wedding Party
description: Adding to Iraqs recent spasms of violence, a car bomb killed about 20 people in a wedding party in a Baghdad neighborhood on Wednesday and wounded more than 50 others, according to officials. This what happens in Iraq, said Harish Ahmed, one of the wounded relatives. We were here to celebrate a wedding in a try to bring a smile; instead it becomes a nightmare. Bombs in another Baghdad neighborhood, near a market, killed 12 other people, The Associated Press reported.

title: Jury Convicts Officer Over False Claim of Drug Deal
description: A New York City police officer was convicted on Wednesday of falsely claiming that he saw two men conducting a drug deal in West Harlem last year, the authorities said.

title: Lottery Numbers
Back-to-School Shopping Campaigns, Already?
description: ALTHOUGH tens of millions of children have not finished the school year, Madison Avenue is already feverishly getting ready for the next one.

title: Anonymous Payment Schemes Thriving on Web
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Eight years ago, Ernie Allen, the head of the International Center for Missing and Exploited Children, called the heads of major banks and credit card companies. Why, he wanted to know, were they letting child pornographers move illicit profits through their systems?

title: Employers Get Leeway on Health Incentives
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration issued a final rule on Wednesday that gives employers greater leeway to use employee wellness programs, with financial rewards and penalties for workers worth up to 50 percent of the premium as an incentive to exercise, quit smoking, lose weight, eat more healthful food and lower cholesterol and blood pressure.

title: Hospital Caring for an Heiress Pressed Her to Give Lavishly
description: For the last 20 years of her life, Huguette Clark, a wealthy and reclusive copper heiress, lived in a Manhattan hospital room, shades drawn, door closed. She played with dolls, watched cartoons and followed the Bush v. Gore hanging chad debacle. (She favored Gore.)

title: The Huguette Clark Files
description: Lawyers for distant relatives of Huguette Clark, the reclusive copper heiress who lived her final two decades at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan, have obtained internal documents that, they contend, show the hospital took advantage of Ms. Clark to get her to donate millions.

title: First and Short Have That Third-and-Long Feel
description: There was a premise that carried the Mets through the winter and into the start of this season. Though the present was not to be dismissed, one eye would be cast toward the future, when a collection of young pitchers and a homegrown infield would help re-establish a winning team in Queens.

title: As Bike Share Begins, Other Cities Scoff Over Fanfare (and Complaints)
description: A cyclist in London compared New York City to teenagers who think they invented sex.

title: Sudden U-Turn for a Crosstown Rivalry
description: As the Yankees and the Mets prepared to meet on Monday in the first game of this seasons Subway Series, they were two teams traveling in opposing directions. The Yankees, despite an overwhelming list of injured stars, had earned a reputation as scrappy overachievers who had somehow crafted a first-place record.

title: Brooklyn Prosecutors Office Is Accused of Detaining Trial Witnesses
description: The office of the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, routinely detained trial witnesses against their will in hotel rooms as a part of forced interrogations, according to depositions taken in a civil rights lawsuit against the city, calling into question whether strong-handed tactics by prosecutors played a role in dozens of troubled convictions already under review.

title: Police in Brooklyn Are Told Not to Seize Condoms of Prostitutes
description: It has been a paradox of New York City government long assailed by aid groups for sex workers: the Health Department hands out millions of condoms to stem the spread of deadly diseases, while the Police Department collects condoms as evidence in arrests for prostitution.

title: In Feud, Working Families Party Turns Tables on Prosecutor
description: When the Staten Island district attorney called for a special prosecutor to investigate one of New York Citys political parties, he went to unusual lengths to keep his motivations secret, seeking special permission to file his request under seal.

title: Americans Find Belgium Too Tough to Handle
description: CLEVELAND  In the first game of a busy summer schedule, the United States national soccer team was convincingly defeated by a powerful Belgian team, 4-2, on Wednesday night at FirstEnergy Stadium in Cleveland.

title: Thompson Sees No Need to Bar a Police Tactic
description: The aggressive era of stop-and-frisk policing in New York City is, in every sense of the word, on trial: the subject of a high-stakes federal court case, scorching denunciations from civil rights leaders and emotional calls for its dismantlement by liberal lawmakers.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, May 30, 2013
description: Its a three-dimensional problem that you have to attack. And it just takes time.

title: Chicago Caps Series Comeback With Overtime Goal
description: CHICAGO  Blackhawks defenseman Brent Seabrook picked up the puck in the neutral zone and carried it across the Detroit blue line. He measured his shot for a moment and fired.

title: Venezuela: Anger Over Colombian Presidents Meeting With Opposition Leader
description: The Venezuelan government reacted angrily to a meeting on Wednesday between an opposition leader and President Juan Manuel Santos of neighboring Colombia. The foreign minister of Venezuela, Elas Jaua, threatened to terminate his nations role as a facilitator of peace talks between Colombia and that countrys largest rebel group. Mr. Jaua lashed out in a television broadcast at Mr. Santos for meeting in Bogot, Colombia, with the opposition leader Henrique Capriles Radonski, who narrowly lost an April election won by Nicols Maduro, the handpicked successor of Venezuelas longtime president, Hugo Chvez. Mr. Chvez died in March. President Santos has taken a step that, it must be said, will lead in a painful way to the derailing of the good relations we have, Mr. Jaua said. He said that Mr. Maduro had recalled the countrys representative to the peace talks to discuss the situation. Colombia and the rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, began peace negotiations in Havana last fall. Mr. Santos had praised Mr. Chvez, who had close ties to the FARC, for helping bring them to the table.

title: Picasso in the Sun
description: During the years he spent in the Mediterranean, he was surrounded by the things he loved  the water, the sun, Jacqueline Roque  igniting the last great outpouring of his genius.

title: Choosing the Next Head of the Federal Reserve
description: 9:56 p.m. | Updated to clarify that precise impact of Volcker Rule depends on final form.

title: For New Doctors, 8 Minutes Per Patient
description: At a social gathering not long ago, a colleague and I exchanged stories about residency training, fondly remembering the patients who had helped us grow both as doctors and as people.

title: Word of the Day | paranoia
description: paranoia \per--ni-, pa-r-\ noun
