title: Joblessness Shortens Lifespan of Least Educated White Women, Research Says
description: Researchers have known for some time that life expectancy is declining for the countrys least educated white women, but they have not been able to explain why. A new study has found that the two factors most strongly associated with higher death rates were smoking and not having a job.

title: Universities Team With Online Course Provider
description: Coursera, the California company that offers free college classes online, is forming partnerships with 10 large public university systems and public flagship universities to create courses that students can take for credit, either fully online or with classroom sessions.

title: In 10th Start, Hefner Earns His First Victory
description: One persistent topic of conversation that has bothered Jeremy Hefner all year can finally be put to rest. On Wednesday night, after nine failed attempts, he won his first start of the season.

title: A Resurgent Kucova Says Goodbye on Her Own Terms
description: PARIS  You would not normally expect a 31-year-old Slovakian journeywoman who last held a world ranking 18 months ago to end her career surrounded by a throng of journalists, but Zuzana Kucovas last hurrah has not exactly been a typical farewell.

title: Renting a Vintage Home in Ho Chi Minh City
description: HO CHI MINH CITY  Rosie Pollard and Rick Stockley were not planning to move in October 2011, but a surprise offer prompted them to reconsider.

title: Whats On Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (Fox Movie Channel) THE DEPARTED (2006) Martin Scorsese directed and William Monahan wrote this adaptation of the Hong Kong film Infernal Affairs (2002). In Bostons South End the Irish gangster Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson) reigns as the king of organized crime and stays one step ahead of the state police by inserting a snitch (Matt Damon) into the department. Responding in kind, a state police captain (Martin Sheen) asks Billy Costigan (Leonardo DiCaprio, at left above with Mr. Nicholson), a cadet with a propensity for violence, to go undercover and infiltrate Costellos crew. Mr. Scorseses sureness of touch, particularly when it comes to carving up space with the camera, keep the plots hall of mirrors from becoming a distraction, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. The plot thickens, then reaches full boil among further complications, dirty dealings, blood on the floor and excellent performances from Alec Baldwin and Mark Wahlberg (as detectives), who own their every scene. The film won four Oscars, including ones for best picture, best director and best adapted screenplay.

title: News Quiz | May 30, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: For Farmers Fearing Drought, Auroville Offers Some Lessons

They have good reason to worry: with the agriculture sector contributing nearly 15 percent to Indias gross domestic product last fiscal year, a lackluster monsoon could be disastrous for farmers and, in turn, the wider economy.

Azam Ahmed reports from Kabul.

description: The crowdfunding platform Emphas.is has helped 60 photographers finance their personal projects and books over the past two years. Now, it is trying to help finance itself.

title: The Early Word: New Direction
description: In Todays Times

title: One Lap of America: The More Civilized Descendant of Cannonball Run
description: Americas most recent age of rebellion may have reached its symbolic peak in the late 1960s  and its symbolic conclusion with the election of President Ronald Reagan  but in the 1970s, a more insidious spirit of rebellion thrived. Having lost the innocence of the 60s, it was the sort of anything-goes madness that lurks just below the surface of mainstream culture, taking advantage of every opportunity to make the Man look like a powerless imbecile. It was out of this mischievous cultural undercurrent that the Cannonball Baker Sea-to-Shining-Sea Memorial Trophy Dash was born.

title: Daily Report: Systems for Moving Anonymous Cash Abound Online
description: Experts say there are hundreds of Internet payment systems that do not require users to identify themselves, making it difficult to seize on money laundering operations, Nicole Perlroth reports in The New York Times.

title: Suspect in Soldiers Killing Is Charged in London
description: LONDON  One of two men suspected of hacking to death a soldier in London last week appeared in court on Thursday to face charges of murder and possessing an illegal firearm.

title: Mountain Populations Offer Clues to Human Evolution
description: In the hearts of evolutionary biologists, mountains occupy a special place. Its not just their physical majesty: mountains also have an unmatched power to drive human evolution. Starting tens of thousands of years ago, people moved to high altitudes, and there they experienced natural selection that has reworked their biology.

title: Team Taco
description: Family is where you find it. For restaurant people, family is often the people at work: Method-actor captains and decent-sculptor waiters; tattooed chefs de partie, willowy hostesses, bookish sommeliers and the four cousins from Puebla who keep the whole enterprise afloat. They gather once a day in the dining room, well before your dinner, to eat their own.

title: The Small Picture: Thinking About Succession
description: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that captured the soul of their businesses in a single shot.

title: Colum McCanns Radical Empathy
description: In Colum McCanns apartment, on the ninth floor of an elegant building just off Central Park, theres a room where he writes that looks as if it were airlifted in from the woods. Its all rough-hewed floorboards and shelves made of unvarnished pine and two-by-fours and a long, thick cedar slab for a desk. At one end of that desk theres a space that used to be a closet, but at McCanns request, the friend who built the office took off the door and put a platform in there, and this is where McCann writes, in the cupboard, as he put it. It concentrates my vision. No windows, two very tight walls. He sits on a couple of cushions with his computer on his lap. On the wall beside him are dozens of messages scrawled by friends and kids and fellow writers and some by McCann himself: What is the source of our first suffering? It lies in the fact that we hesitated to speak. It was born in the moment when we accumulated silent things within us. Keep yourself away from answers, but alive in the middle of the question. Stay rotten. Hi, Dad, I love you.

title: Petraeus Back in Spotlight, via Wall St.
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts announced on Thursday that it had hired David H. Petraeus, a retired four-star general and former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, as chairman of the new KKR Global Institute.

A kid in Kinky Boots tests out his first pair of red high heels; a few blocks away a young Michael Jackson struts across the stage in Motown the Musical.

title: A Rising Stars Self-Destruction
description: TOKYO  Two weeks ago, Toru Hashimoto, the popular, media-savvy mayor of Osaka, was a depreciating asset in Japanese politics. The co-leader of the Japan Restoration Association, he was watching his four-year old experiment in political theater slide into irrelevance. Support for his political party, which finished a strong second in the House of Representatives election only five months ago, was now down below 5 percent and falling.

description: Q.

title: Perry Chen and Theaster Gates on Community-Driven Creativity
description: The Kickstarter co-founder Perry Chen understands how communities can fuel creativity. The artist Theaster Gates knows how creativity can invigorate a community. What happens when they put their heads together?At first glance, an Internet entrepreneur and an artist seem to operate in different creative spheres. Yet Perry Chen, the co-founder and C.E.O. of the crowd-funding Web site Kickstarter, and Theaster Gates, a Chicago art star-cum-urban planner, actually think they have a lot in common. Kickstarter began in 2009, and since then the site has raised more than $500 million for 40,000 projects  from Iraq war documentaries to Brooklyn restaurants  revolutionizing the way creative ideas are financed in the digital age. Theaster Gatess artistic practice, which encompasses everything from sculpture to a roving choir, is in its way just as groundbreaking. On his own block on the South Side of Chicago, Gates has engineered a miniature urban utopia, turning the once-blighted buildings that surround him into artist residencies, a library and even a cinema house that shows works by aspiring filmmakers from the neighborhood. Both Gatess and Chens work may inspire social change, but its the power of creativity, not of compassion, that spurs them from one genre-defying innovation to the next.

title: With Windows 8.1, a New Start That Looks Familiar
description: Yes, Microsoft is bringing back some comforting hallmarks of its Windows operating system, including the Start menu. No, it is not chucking out the modern, touch-friendly, tile-based look of Windows 8, the new version of the software that has sent much of the PC industry, many pundits and some computer shoppers into a tizzy.

title: For Kolkata Rape Victim, a Lonely Wait for Justice
description: KOLKATA, West Bengal In February 2012, a woman was gang-raped in a moving car after she was offered a lift from outside a nightclub on Kolkatas Park Street. Unlike the majority of rape victims in India, she decided to report the crime, not only to the Park Street police, but also to the media. With her back to the TV cameras, her frizzy hair being her only identifying feature, she fielded questions from journalists.

He claims he is considering eliminating the 60-vote threshold to approve judicial and executive nominees.

title: Homage Paid to Rite of Spring, With Stravinsky and Without
description: LONDON  Wednesday was the 100th anniversary, to the day, of the first performance of The Rite of Spring, the Stravinsky-Nijinsky collaboration at the Thtre des Champs-lyses in Paris that marked a revolutionary, game-changing moment in modern music and dance. There were celebratory performances all over the world of various versions of Rite  at the Thtre des Champs-lyses, the Maryinsky Ballet performed Millicent Hodson and Kenneth Archers reconstructed version of Nijinskys ballet alongside a new version by the German choreographer Sasha Waltz.

title: Whats Wrong With the Breadwinner Moms Study
description: In 40 percent of all households as of 2011, according to a new release from Pew Social Trends, the mother was either the sole or primary source of family income  the breadwinner. Thats up from 11 percent in 1960. A total of 5.1 million of those breadwinners (37 percent) are married mothers who have a higher income than their husbands, and 8.6 million (63 percent) are single mothers. Is there a social consensus to be found by lumping together those disparate groups?

title: City Discloses New Location of 9/11 Victims Remains
description: For more than a decade, relatives of World Trade Center victims had been accustomed to walking through Memorial Park on East 30th Street on their way to a tranquil chapel under a big white tent. There, they could pay their respects to the dead, knowing that the victims remains were nearby, carefully stored  though out of sight  beneath the same tent top.

title: Artistic Director of Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet Steps Down
description: Benoit-Swan Pouffer has resigned as the artistic director of Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet, the troupes executive director, Greg Mudd, announced on Thursday. Mr. Pouffer, who served as the artistic director since 2005, resigned roughly two weeks ago and left to pursue other opportunities, according to a statement released by the company.

title: Going Public With Cancer
description: While attending a young adult cancer conference, the Life, Interrupted columnist Suleika Jaouad reflects on how revealing her cancer experiences has helped her build a community.

title: Man Sentenced in Plot to Kill Saudi Ambassador
description: An Iranian-American used-car salesman from Texas who was accused of plotting to hire assassins from a Mexican drug cartel to murder Saudi Arabias ambassador to the United States was sentenced to 25 years in prison on Thursday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Official Pushes for End to Roaming Fees in Europe
description: BERLIN  Neelie Kroes, the European commissioner who was the scourge of American tech companies like Oracle, Microsoft and Intel, urged European Union lawmakers Thursday to abolish cellphone roaming charges.

description: This poem, one of 12 winners of our fourth annual Found Poem Student Contest, was written by Megan, 18, from Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Life, Interrupted: Going Public With Cancer
description: Cancer is not something that makes you want to share. Its something that makes you want to hide, Suleika Jaouad says in the latest installment of the Life, Interrupted video series. In Going Public With Cancer, Ms. Jaouad offers a glimpse of her new life as an advocate for young adults with cancer as well as the friendships she has made as a result of going public with her illness.

Democrats Key to Holders Fate
description: The Timess Jonathan Weisman on which Democrats to watch as Eric Holder faces increasing criticism for his job performance as attorney general.

title: The Rebel Puritan
description: He was the nations idol, wrote the North Carolina diarist Catherine Anne Devereux Edmondson, in anguish at the news of Gen. Thomas J. Stonewall Jacksons death on May 10, 1863. Not a breath even from a foe has ever breathed against his fame. His very enemies reverenced him. As a general proposition, Edmondsons assertion about Jacksons status in the North might be somewhat overstated, but in another sense she was more correct than she most likely knew.

title: Leon Panetta to Write a Washington Memoir
description: Leon E. Panetta, the former defense secretary and director of the Central Intelligence Agency, has struck a deal to write a memoir of his life and career, his publisher said on Thursday.

title: Travel Eh
description: In Toronto to debate with Newt Gingrich (I guess John Lithgow wasnt available), so no time for posting. Service probably wont resume until late afternoon tomorrow.

title: Andrew M. Greeley, Priest, Scholar and Scold, Is Dead at 85
description: Andrew M. Greeley, the Roman Catholic priest and writer whose outpouring of sociological research, contemporary theology, sexually frank novels and newspaper columns challenged reigning assumptions about American Catholicism, was found dead on Thursday morning at his home in Chicago. He was 85.

description: Assume that Cynthia Browns audience, as she addressed the American Geriatrics Societys annual scientific meeting in Texas this month, already knew that hospitalized older adults spend too much time in bed.

title: Who Needs a Tony Nomination? Midlers One-Woman Show Pays Off
description: Bette Midler may have been passed over for a Tony Award nomination for her Broadway play, Ill Eat You Last, but there is no denying that she has become a box-office powerhouse this season. Her one-woman comedy, written by the Tony winner John Logan (Red) about the 1970s Hollywood super-agent Sue Mengers, has recouped its $2.4 million capitalization after eight weeks of performances, the shows producers announced on Thursday.

title: A Great Day for Philosophy
description: Along with the words to be offered here is an interesting artifact a photograph of an assembly of some of the most important and influential philosophers of the latter half of the 20th century on one fine day in April in 1984 in front of the Hyatt Hotel in downtown New Brunswick, N.J.

title: Ann Romneys Two Cents
description: Ann Romney, best known for standing by her husband in his unsuccessful bid for the presidency, decided to unburden herself this morning on the sad state of politics. She said there is a breach of trust between government and the people, which is of course a very bad thing.

title: The Art of Writing About Listening
description: These days I am writing a book about listening to music. Not in the neurochemical way! (Remember the late-90s to late-oughts vogue for books about how your brain reacts to baroque counterpoint, and all that? Oliver Sacks, Robert Jourdain, Daniel Levitin? Are you more engaged with music after reading those books, or do you just ask your hypothalamus what it thinks about the new jams?) I mean listening through, like, the ears.

title: Cinderella Adaptation to Play Off Broadway in 2014
description: Cinderella is one of those characters and stories, like Peter Pan and Alice in Wonderland, that theater directors and writers love to reimagine  and that reliably sell tickets. Rodgers and Hammersteins Cinderella, which began performances on Broadway in January, has regularly surpassed $1 million a week at the box office, and another musical based on the mistreated beauty and her fairy godmother  Ever After  is being developed by Broadway producers and director Kathleen Marshall. But next up is an Off Broadway play, Cinderella/Cendrillon, which will begin performances at New York Theater Workshop in May 2014, the theater announced on Thursday. The adaptation, based on the Brothers Grimm version of the tale, is written and directed by the French theater artist Joel Pommerat, who founded the Compagnie Louis Brouillard in 1990 and has worked at several Parisian theaters. The play has been translated into English and is the fourth and final production of the theaters 2013-14 season.

title: Generation X Hit Hardest By Recession
description: Members of Generation X, now in their late 30s to late 40s, were especially hard-hit by the recent recession, and are at risk for downward mobility in their retirement years, a new report finds.

title: Why Am I at a National Park?
description: Just call us Old Faithfuls. When it comes to supporting the national parks, few have been as reliable as baby boomers. Forget geysers: maybe they should carve a new face onto Mount Rushmore: Washington, Jefferson, Roosevelt, Lincoln and the Unknown Boomer.

title: Belize Protects Antiquities
description: Belize plans to raise the fines for destroying its archaeological sites, according to its tourism agency. The move comes in response to a construction companys recent leveling of part of a Mayan pyramid, above, that dates back some 2,300 years. The ancient site, Noh Mul, which translates as Big Hill, is on private land in the northern part of the country. The government has completed an investigation into the case and plans to charge the company under its antiquities laws, which make it illegal to destroy any ancient monument.

title: Listen Up | A French Movie Star Turned Sultry Singer-Songwriter
description: Lou Doillon was born into French cultural royalty  her mother is Jane Birkin, her father the director Jacques Doillon. So its something of a surprise how much American soul runs through her debut album, Places. She sings in English, in a throaty, charismatic drawl backed by warm, midtempo arrangements that sound like they were laid down in Memphis, not Paris. Doillons half-sister, Charlotte Gainsbourg, was an established actress in Europe who gained a fervent following in the United States only after turning her attention to music. From the sounds of it, Doillon, already a popular model and actress in France, could be on the same path. Verve; $10 on iTunes.

title: Reducing the Corporate Tax Rate Could Stabilize Banks
description: Republicans and Democrats have both expressed a desire to reduce the corporate tax rate from 35 percent to something in the neighborhood of 25 percent, which would be more in line with our major trading partners. The recent attention to the legal loopholes employed by Apple, Google, Starbucks and other multinational corporations to reduce their taxes could threaten the prospects of reducing the corporate rate.

title: Chinas Pork Deal May Hinge on the Risk for an Uproar
description: Who knew that pork could be a national security problem?

title: Tips for Buying and Servicing a Used Hybrid Car
description: Like any used car, a used hybrid vehicle can save you money, both on the purchase price and on the insurance you carry. But there are special factors to take into account when shopping for a hybrid, beyond what youd look for when buying a traditional used car, says John ODell, the green car editor at the automotive site Edmunds.com.

title: At a Dubai Hotel, iPads That Glitter
description: Many hotels offer guests iPads for use during their stay. So how is an upscale hotel to set itself apart? By offering 24-carat gold iPads. The 202-room Burj Al Arab in Dubai lends the logo-engraved devices on a complimentary basis, but anyone wishing to take one home can buy it for AED 37,490 alongside gold iPhones and Blackberrys in the hotel gift shop.

title: Spurs Quietly Become a Two-Way Threat
description: Throughout the San Antonio Spurs impressive postseason march, the N.B.A. cognoscenti have homed in on one laudatory refrain more than any other: The Spurs take away what you do best.

title: 36 Hours in Jackson, Miss.
description: When movie crews descended on Jackson in 2010 to film The Help, based on Kathryn Stocketts novel about the citys maids in the 1960s, they transformed the streets of its trendiest neighborhood into a retro backdrop. Given locals loyalty to mom-and-pop stores like Brents Drugs, where you can still sit at the counter and order a chocolate malt, it didnt take much to pull off cinematic time travel. This year, Jackson will recall one of its most difficult moments  June 12, 1963, when the civil rights activist Medgar Evers was shot in his driveway by a white supremacist. Events this June, including a civil rights city tour, film festival and gala, will celebrate Mr. Everss life.

title: Hints of a Rift After Pakistani Taliban Deputys Death
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  The Pakistani Taliban on Thursday acknowledged the death of their deputy leader in a drone attack, and one subgroup unilaterally announced a successor to his position, portending a possible rift.

description: Thai schools are a drill sergeants dream. Discipline and conformity rule, but some students have begun calling for the abolition of the mechanistic education system.

description: Sofia Coppolas own life is the very picture of elegant discretion. Who better to critique a celebrity-obsessed generation that overshares and hyperconsumes?

description: On April 4, we reported that in ten U.S. states, gun deaths now outpace auto deaths.

title: Mayors Fierce Stand Against Guns Creates Lightning Rod
description: Not long after the Connecticut school massacre in December, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took to television, radio and the Web to demand action on gun control.

title: Why I Want to Choose the Disadvantaged Local School (and Why I Might Not)
description: When I ask other parents of preschoolers in my urban San Diego neighborhood where theyre planning to send their little ones to kindergarten, the name of our local K-5 virtually never comes up. Because of the Choice Program in our district, parents can apply to send their kids to almost any public school in the system. So parents in our neighborhood opt for magnet schools, charter schools or even the garden-variety public school a couple of miles away that gets better test scores than our zone school does. Or they skip the public options altogether and commute to schools with the words Country Day or Our Lady in their names.

title: Unions Press to End Special Trade Status for Bangladesh
description: WASHINGTON  After several deadly factory disasters in Bangladesh  including the collapse of an eight-story garment factory last month that left at least 1,127 people dead  labor advocates are stepping up pressure on the Obama administration, calling for it to convey its disapproval of working conditions in the country by revoking its special trade status.

title: A Workout With Plenty of Bounce
description: A group of 25 men and women jumped to the beat of Lady Gagas Americano in a darkened room amid the glittering of a disco ball, the flashing of neon lights and the streaking of green, blue and red lasers. The scene could have been mistaken for a happening nightclub, but it was actually a recent class at JumpLife, a fitness studio in TriBeCa where the bouncing takes place on personal, low-to-the-ground trampolines, not a dance floor.

title: The Big Bang Theory and The Mary Tyler Moore Show':  A Comparison
description: This past weekends Riff essaylooked at The Big Bang Theory a hit network sitcom that I was late to accept but quick to love. The shows strong ensemble cast also brought to mind an unlikely comparison: The Mary Tyler Moore Show, a more critically lauded success that featured, arguably, the best sitcom ensemble cast of all time. Here, an unscientific analysis of the main characters on Mary Tyler Moore with their surprising Big Bang Theory doubles.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: A Time to Step Back

title: The Brooklyn Breaker of Ancient Codes
description: The events of the past grow more alien as our distance from them increases, receding until they become, finally, unknowable. Unknowable, that is, but for those who take it upon themselves to decode the symbols, to examine what others see as indecipherable or unimportant, to sift a story from the chaff and to resurrect names, places, actions and ideas that would otherwise be lost.

title: Dots, a Highly Addictive Game, Passes 3 Million Players
description: On Sunday afternoon my entire family sat in my sisters living room, fingers jabbing at our iPhones, as we yelled a series of numbers aloud: 124! 217! Oh, I just got to 400!We wereplaying Dots, the highly addictive free game from Betaworks. (I won, with 474 points.)

title: When Painters Showed the War in More Than Blue and Gray
description: If youve seen the awesome, soul-wrenching Photography and the American Civil War at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, you might suppose that a second exhibition about the war would be redundant. Its not. The Civil War and American Art, also at the Met, is a gripping show that sheds further light on how the nation experienced its fratricidal conflict. Organized by Eleanor Jones Harvey, senior curator at the Smithsonian American Art Museum, it is not the broad survey that its title suggests. It is a lean, pointedly selective show, consisting of about 60 paintings, from 1852 to 1877  including outstanding works by Frederic Edwin Church, Sanford Robinson Gifford and Winslow Homer  and 18 photographs taken during the war.

title: Youth Brigade at French Open Is Dwindling
description: PARIS  The last teenager in the mens singles draw at the French Open lasted until 4:04 p.m. Paris time on Thursday, and Lucas Pouille, a young Frenchman, would have been eliminated sooner by Grigor Dimitrov if not for a couple of rain delays.

title: Succession Carousel at General Electric
description: The potential exit of GE Capitals chief shifts the spotlight onto his boss, Jeffrey Immelt. Michael Neal, who has led General Electrics erstwhile high-flying lending unit for eight years, may be soon handing the helm to someone else, according to The Wall Street Journal. His departure raises the question of who will eventually succeed the conglomerates top dog.

title: Cant Smell or Breathe, but Checks Keep Coming
description: Things have changed in Rock Valley in 2016.

title: Weight Loss May Ease Psoriasis
description: Losing weight may help reduce symptoms of psoriasis, a new study shows.

title: This Time, a Growing Economy Stirs Unease
description: The American markets are getting worried again. But this time the fear is refreshingly different.

title: Fastballs, Not Dunks, for 6-Foot-10 Hoosier
description: The gag works because it plays off an easy presumption. Who expects a nearly 7-foot athlete at Indiana University to play anything but basketball?

title: Bloc Challenges Britain on Welfare Rules
description: BRUSSELS  In a move certain to stoke British frustrations with the European Union, the 27-nation blocs executive arm is taking Britain to court over restrictions on who can receive social security benefits.

title: A New Childhood Hazard: Medical Marijuana
description: Accidental ingestion of marijuana may be on the rise, according to a new report.

title: Bank-Friendly Financial Reform
description: Treasury Secretary Jack Lew has defended financial reform recently, but on closer inspection, his defenses are oddly ambiguous.

title: A Lunch That Tastes Like Nostalgia
description: IM in your hands, I told Patricia Volk as she led me through the Beauty Level of Bergdorf Goodman  otherwise known as the basement  into Goodmans Cafe.

title: Eastern Conference Finals Preview
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins and the Boston Bruins have not met in the playoffs in 21 years, but you would not know from the simmering resentment Bruins fans feel toward the Penguins about Ulf Samuelssons hit during the 1991 playoffs that left Cam Neely with a career-shortening leg injury and Matt Cookes blindside hit during the 2009-10 season that gave Marc Savard a career-shortening concussion. Boston forward Milan Lucic noted this week that the Savard hit was still in the back of your mind, but its not the focal point.

title: Western Conference Finals Preview
description: The N.H.L. Western Conference finals feature the 2012 champion Los Angeles Kings and the Chicago Blackhawks, who won the 2013 Presidents Trophy. This matchup features the last two teams from the West to win the Stanley Cup, though each team had its mettle tested by semifinal showdowns that reached seven games.

title: Diverse Mix of Candidates Weigh In on an Obscure Jewish Ritual
description: It is a measure of the multicultural finesse it takes to run for mayor in New York City that seven Democratic candidates  including some of Chinese, Latino, Irish and Italian backgrounds  have staked out positions on an Orthodox Jewish circumcision ritual that is obscure even to most Jews.

title: Clip: 'American Mary'
description: A scene from "American Mary," directed by Jen and Sylvia Soska.

title: At Venice Biennale, Sarah Szes Triple Point
description: VENICE  The Biennale doesnt open to the public until Saturday, but the art world arrived early for a peek. Artists, curators and creators responsible for this vast assemblage of exhibitions here have been on hand to meet, greet and explain their work.

title: Directors, and Twins, Who Distrust the Normal
description: Lots of siblings make movies. The brothers Coen (No Country for Old Men) are Oscar winners. Andy and Lana Wachowski (Cloud Atlas) are a prominent brother-sister team (although Lana was once Larry). But sister directors? And not just sisters, but identical twins?

title: Their Bedside Manners Need Work
description: If Dr. Giggles ever took the Hippocratic Oath, his eyes must have glazed at the abstain from doing harm part. Otoscopes are meant to examine noses and ears, not be plunged into brains. But often in horror movies, doctors dont heal, scalpels arent for surgery and medicine only makes life worse. Fans know that syringes crave eyeballs, not upper arms.

title: Improvised Music at a Purposeful Home
description: SKYE STEELE had just raced through an intricate tune called Man-Made Nemesis last week at ShapeShifter Lab when he tucked his violin under one arm, issuing an invitation in the form of an order. All the musicians in the audience  he called out half a dozen by name  were implored to join his band, the Railroad Rodia, for a chantlike finale.

title: What Is Reform Conservatism?
description: As I noted earlier this week, theres been a lot of liberal discussion of conservative reformers recently, ranging from the Washington Monthlys attempt at a taxonomy of the tendency to Mike Konczals recent piece expressing doubts (echoed by my colleague Paul Krugman) about whether the reforming tendency within conservatism adds up to anything significant at all. Reading through the responses to Konczals post from reformish types, Im in the rare position of disagreeing ever-so-slightly with my friend and co-authorReihan Salam,who writes:

title: A Traveling Tennis Fund-Raising Party Hits Paris
description: PARIS  Since 2006, Robert R. Kinas, tennis fanatic, blood cancer survivor and bankruptcy lawyer with the Las Vegas firm of Snell & Wilmer, has toured the worlds major tennis tournaments with friends and colleagues. They party, play tennis and raise money for cancer research.

title: Rain Room at the Barbican Center
description: The Rain Room is a 5,000-square-foot field of falling water that uses motion detectors to create a dry path for viewers as they walk through a downpour. It is currently installed at the MoMA.

title: The Fall of Gnomes: Tasteful to Tacky
description: Posting statues of bearded gnomes in gardens is considered a kitschy affront to nature. But until well into the 1800s it signified that a homeowner had elite tastes for rustic landscape design and pleasant melancholy.

title: Sexual Violence in India Among Hot-Button Topics at Edinburgh Fringe Festival
description: The gang rape and subsequent death of a 23-year-old woman in New Delhi last year forms the basis for Nirbhaya, a new play by the writer and director Yael Farber, to be presented at the 2013 Edinburgh Festival Fringe this summer. Ms. Farber, whose production of Mies Julie was one of the hottest Fringe shows last year (going on to play in New York and London), has assembled an all-Indian cast for the production, which explores sexual violence through personal stories from the performers.

title: Plenty of Substance in a New Style
description: PARIS  The dress made of tennis balls, the blue hair, the knee socks: together they had come to define Bethanie Mattek-Sands, a fashion iconoclast in a polo-shirt sport.

title: Fastest Network? It All Depends
description: In a survey of 20 cities, Tech Hive found AT&T to have the fastest LTE service in America. An earlier survey of 77 cities by RootMetrics, a company that measures network performance, got similar rankings, but recorded very different speeds.

title: Falling for the Anarchy She Was Sent to Fight
description: The East is a neat little thriller about ends and means and ethical quandaries. The title refers to a mysterious network of anti-corporate militants whose activities  called jams  shade from prankish agitprop toward outright terrorism. The members of the group, who live off the grid in an abandoned house in the wilderness somewhere near the Mason-Dixon line, are determined to hold the poisoners and polluters of the executive class accountable for their actions. Sometimes, as in the case of a pharmaceutical company that has peddled dangerous antibiotics, this means giving the bosses a literal taste of their own medicine.

title: James Among 3 Fined for Flopping
description: MIAMI  It was not exactly Oscar night, but the N.B.A. singled out some of its best actors Thursday, and promptly penalized them for their work.

title: Citys 911 Operators Use Pen and Paper as Computers Fail
description: Emergency operators in New York City have been forced on at least three occasions since Wednesday to resort to using pen and paper to record 911 calls and dispatch workers after their computer system went dark.

title: Andreas Schulze: Windows
description: Team Gallery

title: Laddie John Dill: Elementary
description: Nyehaus

title: Wall Street Turns to Boot Camps to Train New Workers
description: Newly minted university graduates who have landed coveted jobs on Wall Street may have impressive rsums and sought-after references. But often, nuts-and-bolts skills like spreadsheet building and database extraction are not part of university curriculums.

title: Margaret Weber
description: Ramiken Crucible

title: Lisa Ross: Living Shrines of Uyghur China
description: Rubin Museum of Art

title: A Mystery of Smithfields Big China Deal: What Continental Grain Will Do
description: Investors in Smithfield Foods, the pork processor, appeared largely pleased on Wednesday with its proposed $4.7 billion sale to a giant meat producer in China.

title: Gallery | A Melting Pot of Celebrities Makes Immigration Reform Look Fashionable
description: What do the actress Julianne Moore, the funnyman John Leguizamo, the supermodel Christy Turlington Burns and the director George C. Wolfe have in common? Theyre among the 15 celebrities brought together by We Belong Together, a new national initiative to promote immigration reform. On a rainy day last week, this melting pot of talent gathered at a West Village studio to have their portraits taken by the fashion photographer Albert Watson, who immigrated to the United States from Scotland in 1970. The resulting black-and-white photos are the calling card for Fedoras for Fairness, an ad campaign created by We Belong Together that makes its debut today with support from the celebrity activist Rosie Perez. Im really proud of being a first-generation Puerto Rican-American, said the actress, adding that America is supposed to be known as the nation of fairness of democracy and of justice. And right now, the way immigration stands, that is not applied.

title: U.N. Court Acquits 2 Serbs of War Crimes
description: PARIS  In one of the most surprising verdicts of its checkered prosecution of Balkan war crimes, a United Nations court on Thursday acquitted two close aides of the former Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic, spurning the prosecutions demand for life sentences for his once all-powerful secret police chief and the chiefs deputy.

title: Watch Your Back, Even in the Family
description: In the prologue of James Marshs taut, somber conspiracy thriller Shadow Dancer, the 12-year-old Collette McVeigh (Maria Laird), idly stringing beads into a necklace, ignores her fathers request to go out and buy cigarettes. It is 1973 in Belfast, and the city is a powder keg. Her younger brother goes instead, and is shot to death outside the house in cross-fire between British and Irish Republican Army forces. As the McVeigh home erupts in anguished chaos, the father casts a recriminatory glare at Collette, who is guilt-stricken.

title: MARIA PETSCHNIG: Petschnigs
description: On Stellar Rays

title: 20 More Cookbooks
description: THE ANIMAL FARM BUTTERMILK COOKBOOK: Recipes and Reflections From a Small Vermont Dairy. By Diane St. Clair. (Andrews McMeel, $27.99.) A cult is gathering around buttermilk, and St. Clair may well be its high priestess, supplying her product to the French Laundry in California and specialty stores in the Northeast. Buttermilk makes biscuit light, takes the cloying sweetness out of French toast and works wonders in lasagna.

title: Section A, Airplane Fragment
Policy Lessons From Texas
description: Evan Smith, editor in chief of The Texas Tribune, on how the 83rd Texas legislative session may inform the national debate on Medicaid expansion, immigration policy and the Tea Party.

title: Plague of Corruption Rises Anew in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA  Fifteen years ago, Indonesia took its first step toward democracy with the ouster of an authoritarian president. By 2009, the country had one of the most open electoral systems in Asia, with direct balloting to elect government officials, from the president all the way down to district chiefs and mayors.

title: Cooking
description: A great rift has developed in the world of food. On one side, the unapologetic consumers of meat, red-faced and sweaty from their exertions over the barbecue grill and the smoking hog pit. On the other, the gentle leaf eaters, pale but confident  actuarially, ecologically and ethically. Judging by this seasons cookbooks, Team Green seems to be winning in a rout. But the carnivores are not going quietly.

title: Fall Out Boy at Terminal 5
description: The band, back on tour after a nearly four-year hiatus, performed at Terminal 5 on Wednesday night.

title: If Only the Grapes Were the Whole Story
description: Wine has been described as the perfect beverage because the grapes contain all the ingredients necessary to create their transformation. Put grapes in a vat, and over time the yeasts coating the skins set alchemy in motion, converting the sugar in the juice into alcohol.

title: Gardening
description: Why do we have to go all the way around the world to find whats in our own backyard? Gardeners have the answer, and it isnt philosophical; its botanical. The way much of our plant material, as the nurserymen call it, arrived on American soil is as varied and inspiring a story of immigration as you can hope to hear. And for those of you who like what I think of as the grain of sand trend  the world in a bowl of salt or a mackerel  youre in luck. Now we can find the world in a water lily or a ginkgo.

title: Travel
description: The best of this seasons travel books are marked by a generational split. Three footloose writers in their 30s and 40s probe the back alleys of Ho Chi Minh City, the bike-choked streets of Amsterdam and the Taliban-haunted steppes of northern Afghanistan  sometimes paying a price for their curiosity. At the other end of the spectrum stand three recently minted septuagenarians with more than a centurys worth of globe-trotting among them. Yet their own stumbles and setbacks prove that older doesnt always mean wiser.

title: James
description: James, a resident from the West Village, explains why he won't vote for Christine C. Quinn.

title: A Choice Not as Easy as It Looked
description: When my husbands friend Maggie asked him if he would donate his sperm to get her soon-to-be wife pregnant, he said he had to ask me first. Its the kind of hypothetical question one might pose at a dinner party: If your friends, a lesbian couple, ask your husband to donate sperm so they can have a child, would you agree?

title: If Only This Comedian Could Dish It Right Back
description: Watching the parade of comedy heavyweights and cultural heroes assembled for the biographical documentary Richard Pryor: Omit the Logic, my mind wandered to the roast of Pryor by the cast of his 1977 NBC television show. (The unedited version is on YouTube.) As you watch him being flayed by the largely unknown group that included future stars like Tim Reid, Robin Williams, Marsha Warfield, Sandra Bernhard and John Witherspoon  as usual, Pryor was ahead of the times  you cant wait for him to get to the microphone and take revenge. When he does, he ad-libs a 13-minute rejoinder thats as cruel and foul (and homophobic) as you might fear and as coruscatingly funny as you could hope.

title: Retired in America, Reborn in Guatemala
description: Mark Kendalls quietly moving documentary, La Camioneta: The Journey of One American School Bus, is as modest and farsighted as its cast of Guatemalans who make a living resurrecting discarded American school buses. The movie begins in rural Pennsylvania, where yellow buses  decommissioned after 8 to 12 years of use but still in good condition  are auctioned to bidders, many from Central America.

title: No Sitting Duck
description: I am a nanny and work full time for a single family. Occasionally, I take baby-sitting jobs for other families on my free evenings and weekends. On these jobs, I have been asked often, by several different parents, if I will lower my hourly rate because their children will be sleeping for most of the time I am there. I am inclined to say no. My fee is fair. But since Ive been asked so often, I thought I might check with you. How should I handle these requests?

title: European Officials Move to Curb Overfishing
description: PARIS  The European Union on Thursday agreed to an overhaul of the regions fisheries policy, a deal intended to make commercial fishing more sustainable.

title: Section A, The Making of Struggle
Les Misrables Sets Broadway Opening Date
description: A Broadway revival of Les Misrables will run at the Imperial Theater and begin previews on March 1, 2014, with an opening night of March 23, the producer Cameron Mackintosh announced on Thursday. Casting is expected to be announced later this summer. The original production ran on Broadway from 1987 to 2003. A revival from 2006 to 2008 was described by Mr. Mackintosh as ill-conceived.

title: Will Rangers Look to the Past for a New Coach?
description: Almost immediately after the Rangers fired John Tortorella on Wednesday, the idea with the storybook appeal was in the air: Mark Messier as the next Rangers coach.

title: Suspending Disbelief, as 4 Flee Handcuffs
description: Its one thing to watch a magician pull a rabbit out of a hat. Its quite another to watch a movie of the same thing. Movies are themselves a kind of magic, dependent on technological wizardry. Thats why, when watching a film of a humble magic trick, you feel no sense of wonder, for the stunt has already been accomplished in a medium thats all about illusion. So what, you shrug.

title: Mystery in Seattle, but Paris Beckons
description: The Killing, a spooky crime thriller set in a rain-soaked Seattle that was canceled after its second season, then revived, returns to AMC this Sunday for a third season with a new case, a mostly new cast and a conundrum.

title: Candidates on Circumcision Ritual
description: At a Jewish center, mayoral candidates were asked if they backed the city requirement of parental consent forms for metzitzah b'peh, in which a circumciser uses his mouth to suck blood from the wound.

title: Jack Vances Influential Prose Will Live On
The Ad Campaign: Group Frames the Choice as Anyone but Quinn
description: A political action committee dedicated to thwarting Christine C. Quinns mayoral ambitions released three new advertisements on Thursday, featuring New Yorkers explaining why they do not like Ms. Quinn, the City Council speaker, and will not vote for her. The committee, called NYC Is Not for Sale 2013, was founded by the president of Local 1180, which represents communications workers; an animal rights group that has sparred with Ms. Quinn over horse-drawn carriages; and a wealthy businesswoman. It is legally allowed to spend unlimited amounts on political advertising as long as it does not coordinate its activity with a candidate. The ads began running Thursday on several cable channels in the city, and was produced by The Advance Group.

title: Pictures of the Day: Myanmar and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Myanmar, India, France and Czech Republic.

title: Returning With Punk and Pop Cred Intact
description: Fall Out Boy purposefully displayed its punk credentials at Terminal 5 on Wednesday night. Back on tour after a nearly four-year hiatus, with its first studio album since 2008, Save Rock and Roll (Decaydance/Island), Fall Out Boy slammed out its songs to a euphorically squealing, singing, moshing, crowd-surfing full house.

title: Section B, The Search for Shepards Tone
Shifting Geometries and Swirling Dynamics
description: The striking originality of Justin Pecks choreography for In Creases, which had its New York City premiere with City Ballet on Wednesday, is often strange. It includes constantly changing quasi-dramatic situations and pictorial configurations, all formally arranged and fluently connected, as if springing from some private dream world. The arrangement of its eight dancers abounds in novel geometries and other organizations. The patterns and angles change so regularly that its as if the stage itself were revolving.

title: FX Adds to Comedy Slate With a Pilot for Tracy Morgan
description: The cable channel FX continued its aggressive expansion into comedy on Thursday with the announcement that it has signed Tracy Morgan, formerly a star of 30 Rock and Saturday Night Live, to headline a pilot for a new situation comedy.

title: Into the Hormonal Wild
description: Sometimes the strife between parents and their teenage children can be so bitter that even the tiniest set-to is charged with hostility that threatens to erupt into violence. The most amusing  and darkest  moments in Jordan Vogt-Robertss flighty comedy The Kings of Summer, set in suburban Ohio, pit Joe (Nick Robinson), a smart, hormonally overcharged 15-year-old, against his loving but cruelly sarcastic widowed father, Frank (Nick Offerman of Parks and Recreation).

title: Workouts Continue as Belmont Field Swells
description: There is a little more than a week to go before the Belmont Stakes, and many of the contenders completed workouts this week. Some of those will complete a final workout over the weekend or early next week.

title: A Father-Son Outing Goes Terribly Wrong
description: A father-son encounter session tricked out with science-fiction clichs and steeped in motivational uplift, After Earth opens with a teenager, Kitai Raige (Jaden Smith), washing out from some kind of ranger academy. Its a bummer because all he wants to do is please his father (Will Smith, Jadens father), a heroic if unfortunately named general, Cypher. Daddy Dearest has risen having honed tremendous self-control and a useful protective technique, ghosting, which renders him invisible to the monsters plaguing human civilization: the nonbearlike Ursa.

title: Comedy Listings for May 31-June 6
description: Comedy

title: Theater Listings for May 31-June 6
description: Theater

title: Warning: Woman Wields a Scalpel
description: I dont think its really fair that God gets to choose what we look like on the outside, do you? says Beatress Johnson (Tristan Risk) in American Mary, a new horror movie from the twins Jen and Sylvia Soska. So Beatress has had work done. Lots of work: 14 different surgeries to get me to look like this  a nightmare Betty Boop, with a synthetic, cartoonish face to supplement her 50s homemaker dresses and a Kewpie-doll voice uttering the occasional obscene epithet.

title: Movie Listings for May 31-June 6
description: Movies

title: Emma Stone Is Out of Cabaret Revival
description: The movie actress Emma Stone (The Amazing Spider-Man, The Help) has pulled out of the planned Broadway revival of Cabaret, in which she was expected to make her Broadway debut in early 2014 as Sally Bowles opposite the Tony Award-winner Alan Cumming as the M.C. Ms. Stones publicist said on Thursday that the actress now has scheduling conflicts with a feature film that prevent her from joining the musical, which Roundabout Theater Company is planning to mount at one of its Broadway theaters, Studio 54.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for May 31-June 6
description: Pop

title: Jazz Listings for May 31-June 6
description: Jazz

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for May 31-June 6
description: Classical

title: Market Report | The ID Bracelet Gets a Makeover
description: The ID bracelet is making a comeback, but it looks nothing like the standard-issue, heavy chain version that was de rigueur in the 1980s. Instead, todays styles have sparkling diamond accents and clever designs  hospital bracelets fashioned from thin sheets of yellow gold and chain-link bands made of rose gold and closed with a toggle.

title: Section B, Shepards Tone
Dance Listings for May 31-June 6
description: Dance

title:
Museum & Gallery Listings for May 31-
June 6
description: Art

title: Spare Times for Children for May 31-June 6
description: KIDSFILMFEST

title: Spare Times for May 31-June 6
description: TALKS AT THE 92ND STREET Y (Sunday through Thursday) Magic, music and politics  with a dash of fashion  will be in the mix next week during talks at the Y. On Sunday at 7 p.m., the magician Steve Cohen, below, will talk with Dick Cavett, who began his show business career doing magic tricks, and Robert Palumbo, the writer, director and one of the executive producers of a recent History Channel special that featured Mr. Cohen.

title: BBC Faces New Allegations of Sexual Abuse
description: LONDON  Since the case involving the television personality Jimmy Savile came to light in October, the British Broadcasting Corporation has received 152 new allegations of sexual abuse and harassment by 81 current and former employees, the broadcaster said Thursday.

title: Siblings. Cant Live With Them ...
Penn Station, Old and New
description: To the Editor:

title: Fate of the Earth Rests on a Banjo
description: Thanks to groundbreaking work by Hollywood over the years  Men in Black, Coneheads and many more  we know that space aliens are all around us, looking and living like humans. Some of these visitors are downright charming, few more so than the two guys from the planet Hondo in The History of Future Folk.

title: Dyslexia and the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Natural World: Here, Its Had Work
description: Behind a white door in the basement of MoMA PS1, theres a room thats literally freezing cold. Inside are nearly a dozen boulder-size chunks of blue-tinged ice, fragments of a glacier in Iceland recovered by the celebrated artist Olafur Eliasson and transported here to create one of the more chilling artworks in Expo 1: New York, a sprawling, multisite extravaganza including a multitude of installations, shows-within-shows and events relating to the current and future state of our planets ecology.

title: Behold the Latest in Trash Trucks and Police Three-Wheelers
description: When the Unisphere at the 1964 Worlds Fair was brand new, the crowds marveled at the Mercury capsule that had carried Scott Carpenter into space, a replica of a two-person Gemini capsule and, for those who remained earthbound, a Picturephone that could make videocalls. It was the latest in technology, they said.

title: Health Care Innovation
description: To the Editor:

title: Beatriz of El Salvador, Denied a Lifesaving Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Angry Young Man in Kazakhstan
description: Can a crime set you free? For the sullen young man at the center of Student, directed by the Kazakh filmmaker Darezhan Omirbayev, an experimental act of violence seems to yield moral clarity. Set in modern-day Kazakhstan, where the quiet is broken only by brutishness, this classically shot and edited film is a spare yet entrancing tale drawn with precise strokes.

title: Expo 1: New York
description: A look at the multisite show featuring works by Olafur Eliasson, Chris Burden and others.

title: Donald Judds SoHo Home and Studio
description: The building in SoHo where the artist lived and worked off and on for 25 years is opening for public tours.

title: The Artists Force Field, Frozen in Time
description: Things that exist exist, the Minimalist sculptor Donald Judd once wrote, and everything is on their side. His words are in a sense the credo of an empiricist, which was Judds preferred description of himself. He disdained the term Minimalist, along with the whole idea of art movements.

title: Santander Sells 50% Stake in Asset-Management Arm to Investment Firms
description: Banco Santander said on Thursday that it had sold a 50 percent stake in its asset-management arm to two investment firms, Warburg Pincus and General Atlantic, as the bank continues to raise money to bolster its balance sheet.

title: Trapped by an Invisible Force
description: In a few weeks CBS rolls out a mini-series called Under the Dome based on a Stephen King novel. Its about a Maine town cut off from the world when a clear dome materializes over it.

title: Troubled Souls, Screaming to Be Heard
description: The brothers Evangelos and George Giovanis, who directed Run It, have made films before (Taking the Turn and Land of Nod), but the experience doesnt show in their latest. An entwined triptych of sorts unified by invective, slurs and characters demanding that others shut up, Run It is a very patchy affair.

title: The Majesty of Classicism
description: Henry Hope Reed, the cranky genius of classicism who died last month, was expert at turning a phrase in favor of traditional architecture.

title: About Those Visitors From Other Planets
description: Before The X-Files there were cable-television U.F.O. shows, raising spooky questions and little shivers of wonder about the cosmos, with testimony from assorted astrophysicists and freethinkers. Amardeep Kalekas documentary Sirius, which seeks to induce government transparency about extraterrestrial life, rolls out eyewitnesses to U.F.O.s and such, but also cross-pollinates with a more recent vintage of economic doomsaying.

title: Financing for Foreigners
description: The foreigners streaming into New York to buy housing often pay in cash, but with interest rates low, more have been seeking to finance their purchases.

title: Health Law Is Fostering Competition, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON  The new health care law is injecting more competition into health insurance markets nationwide, drawing additional insurance companies into states long dominated by a few carriers, Obama administration officials said Thursday.

title: Two Artists on a Long Construction Journey
description: Theres a reason that breaking rocks is a time-honored form of hard labor. In Triumph of the Wall, the first-time filmmaker Bill Stone all too faithfully records his morbid fascination with a stonemasons attempt to build a 1,000-foot wall on a Quebec estate. Neither the very relaxed pace of this builder, Chris Overing, nor Mr. Stones sporadically amusing neuroses about his filmmaking make for a gripping documentary.

title: No Toys, but a Park Nearby
description: If only New Yorkers knew what all those toy marketers must have known  that the Toy Building North has some of the best views of the citys most striking buildings  it might have become residential long ago.

title: A Good Manager Must Be More Than a Messenger
description: This interview with Roman Stanek, chief executive of GoodData in San Francisco, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: G.O.P. Sizes Up Obama as Midterm Target
description: WASHINGTON  His name wont be on any ballot in 2014. Or ever again, for that matter.

title: Uncle Sam Stands in the Way of Uncle Jack
description: Im just the gay uncle, Jack keeps saying in Glenn Gaylords plodding drama I Do. But is he? The movie shows one thing but insists on another.

title: Neighborhood Joint: The Honorable William Wall
description: The Honorable William Wall is an oasis on the Hudson River that offers urban sailors, and those who just wish they were sailors, a place to relax and have a drink or two.

title: This Weeks Movies: May 31, 2013
description: The New York Times critics on The East, After Earth and The Kings of Summer.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: The Drone War Is Far From Over
description: WHEN people in Washington talk about shrinking the drone program, as President Obama promised to do last week, they are mostly concerned with placating Pakistan, where members of the newly elected government have vowed to end violations of the countrys sovereignty. But the drone war is alive and well in the remote corners of Pakistan where the strikes have caused the greatest and most lasting damage.

title: Federal Program for Distressed Homeowners Is Extended
description: WASHINGTON  Despite signs of revival in housing, the Obama administration announced on Thursday an extension of its principal program for helping distressed homeowners to get mortgage modifications and avoid foreclosure.

title: Will Perry Run Again? And if So, for What?
description: Outside a 2008 meeting of the Republican Governors Association in Grapevine, Tex., a reporter asked Gov. Rick Perry if he was running for re-election.

title: What Happened on Frontier Airlines Flight 727
description: Updated | June 20, 2013

title: Comeuppance for the Rich, at Least on the Screen
description: MEXICO CITY  Why are they taking everything away from us, like in Venezuela? wails Barbie Noble, a spoiled rich girl crammed into a getaway cab with her two brothers as the family flees a police raid on their sumptuous mansion.

title: Heights of Fancy
description: AMES, Iowa  THE installation of the 408-foot spire atop One World Trade Center earlier this month made it, according to some reports, the tallest building in the United States.

title: What I Love | Richard Kind
description: At home on the Upper West Side with Richard Kind, known for his role in Spin City.

title: The Perfect Apartment, From Memory
description: When, back in 2000, the sitcom Spin City moved production to Los Angeles from New York, few could have been happier than Richard Kind, a born-and-bred Easterner who played a clueless press secretary on the long-running series. He and his wife, Dana, bought a grand old house in majestic Hancock Park, complete with marble steps and a living room they never set foot in.

title: Data Point to Radiation Risk for Travelers to Mars
description: Astronauts traveling to Mars, bombarded by the radiation of outer space, would face modestly higher risks of cancer, new NASA measurements confirm.

title: Water Everywhere, and a Drop to Drink
description: ABOARD THE HONORABLE WILLIAM WALL, northeast of Ellis Island  Can anyone entirely explain the unquestionable pleasure of drinking by the sea? Perhaps there is a natural felicity in casually consuming one form of liquid while gazing at another  or perhaps the coastal cocktail is an atavism of our lost amphibian past.

title: Illinois Lawmakers Race for Compromise on Guns
description: CHICAGO  Here in Illinois, the only state in the nation that does not have a statewide law allowing private citizens to carry a concealed gun in public, a Democrat sits in the governors seat and his party holds strong majorities in both chambers of the legislature, where President Obama once served.

title: U.S. Retailers Announce New Factory Safety Plan
description: Feeling pressure from consumer and labor groups for not doing more to ensure factory safety in Bangladesh, Wal-Mart, Gap and numerous other retailers along with the nations main retail federations are seeking to forge a new plan to promote safety in that countrys apparel industry.

title: El Salvador: Doctors Can Induce Birth to Save Woman, Official Says
description: A 22-year-old woman who was denied an abortion by El Salvadors Supreme Court can terminate her pregnancy at the first sign of danger, the health minister, Mara Isabel Rodrguez, said Thursday. At this point, the interruption of the pregnancy is no longer an abortion, Ms. Rodrguez said, it is an induced birth. Doctors say that the woman, known only as Beatriz, is carrying a fetus with a severe birth defect and almost no chance of surviving, and that she faces serious health risks if her pregnancy continues because she has lupus and related complications. After the Supreme Courts ruling, the Inter-American Court of Human Rights called on the government to immediately adopt the necessary measures to protect the life, personal integrity and health of Beatriz. Ms. Rodrguez said the woman could be induced to have either an abdominal or vaginal birth because the important thing is saving Beatrizs life.

title: Seen as Offensive, Beer Can Has a Shortened Shelf Life
description: The special cans of Coors Light beer started popping up in New York City in recent weeks ahead of the coming parade. The vitriol followed soon after with elected officials and others saying that the cans were tasteless and sent the wrong message.

title: In the Run-Up to Televisions Season, a Steady Stream of Ad Sales
description: TELEVISION is an industry known for reruns. So it may be appropriate that the process of selling commercial time before the start of the 2013-14 season is, so far, repeating the process of selling commercial time before the start of the 2012-13 season.

title: Leading a Red Sox Revival
description: PHILADELPHIA  It was not so much that John Farrell was sitting pretty in the visitors dugout Wednesday evening at Citizens Bank Park, his team narrowly holding onto first place in the American League East. More to the point on Farrells location, or relocation, he was nowhere near Toronto.

title: Clinton Hires Ex-State Dept. Aide and Joins Husbands Foundation
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.  Settling the question of whether she would be part of her husbands foundation or start her own, Hillary Rodham Clinton has hired a former State Department aide to join her at what is now being called the Bill, Hillary and Chelsea Clinton Foundation. Until recently it was called the William J. Clinton Foundation.

title: Hate Speech on Facebook
description: Facebook belatedly moved to further restrict hate speech that glorified violence against women after an organized social media campaign caused some companies like Nissan, the automaker, to withhold advertising from the site. The companies said they acted after they became aware that their ads might have appeared next to the offensive content.

title: Grim Task of Identifying Factories Dead Overwhelms Bangladeshi Lab
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  Inside a small government laboratory here, there are about 300 test tubes, each labeled with masking tape and containing an extracted tooth or a shard of bone. Day and night, dozens of these tubes rest on metal trays that vibrate with a motorized monotony. The shaking decalcifies the bone in a process that requires two weeks before material can be gleaned for a DNA profile.

title: Self-Driving Cars for Testing Are Supported by U.S.
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Companies from Silicon Valley to Detroit to Germany are developing cars that park, steer and even drive themselves. Now the federal agency for traffic safety has said it wants to come along for the ride.

title: Bridge Collapse Tears at a Towns Economy
description: BURLINGTON, Wash.  Interstate 5, before last weeks bridge collapse over the Skagit River on the south end of town, was the great pumping arterial source of economic life here. It brought Canadians, shopping for furniture or clothes. It brought day-tripping outlet mall lovers from Seattle. Through an embrace of retailing begun as a town plan in the 1980s, Burlington, population 8,500, grew to have the highest level of retail sales per capita of any city in the state.

title: M.L.S. Club Owner Has Latinos-Only Policy, Suit Says
description: Chivas USA became the 11th member of Major League Soccer nearly a decade ago, beginning play with the cachet that its parent club was Chivas Guadalajara, an immensely popular Mexican team.

title: The Imperfect Immigrants
description: VISNJA GORA, Slovenia  Exactly 100 years ago a man of 22 left this village on the eve of a great war to build a life in the United States. To Ignac Vrhovec, the tired old ground of his homeland was tangled in his ancestors encumbrances and spent by time. After he left, much of that land would change hands, from the Austro-Hungarian Empire, to Italy, to Nazi Germany.

title: The A Train Returns to the Rockaways
description: A time-lapse video of the A train crossing Jamaica Bay, reconnecting the Rockaway Peninsula with the rest of New York City.

title: Getting a Fair Share From Multinationals
No Replacement for Corporate Taxes
description: In response to the recent Senate hearing on tax avoidance at Apple, some pundits have argued that the best solution is to abolish the corporate income tax altogether. Their contention is that multinational corporations  which hold trillions of dollars in mostly untaxed profits offshore  are so complex and so expert at avoidance that even trying to tax them is pointless. It would be better, they say, to quit trying and to raise needed tax revenue in other ways. This would be a completely wrong approach.

title: Promising African Development Fund Collapses
description: The initiative began two decades ago, with the best of intentions, after apartheid fell and southern Africas future brightened.

title: Attacks on Muslims in Myanmar
description: Terrifying anti-Muslim violence surged this week in Myanmar, exposing deep ethnic and religious tensions that are undermining efforts to stabilize the country and move forward with political and economic reforms. Myanmars democratic aspirations can never be fully realized if Muslims, who make up about 5 percent of the population, continue to be attacked and marginalized by Buddhists, the majority of the population. At least 44 people have died since March in sectarian mob violence.

title: The Questions Keep Coming for Rutgers
description: It was a few weeks after Rutgers hired a well-regarded recruiting firm to identify and vet candidates to lead the universitys athletic program, which was still reeling from a scandal involving an abusive coach, when Julie Hermann, a leading applicant, turned to one of the firms final questions.

title: Just in Time for Summer, the A Train Is Fully Restored
description: The trains returned, at last, on a proper beach day, carrying toddlers in sundresses and men in shorter-than-short shorts, high school students prone to impromptu dance-offs and women whose toes dangled from their sandals.

title: Owner Makes All-Out Push for Indian Point
description: At a break in the testimony, a few cordial people took seats near me and introduced themselves. Among them was Norris McDonald, who came to the legislative hearing in Lower Manhattan to testify about the future of the Indian Point nuclear power plant.

title: From the Mouths of Babes
description: Like many observers, I usually read reports about political goings-on with a sort of weary cynicism. Every once in a while, however, politicians do something so wrong, substantively and morally, that cynicism just wont cut it; its time to get really angry instead. So it is with the ugly, destructive war against food stamps.

title: New Rules May Rein In Prosecutors in Leak Investigations
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., under fire over investigative tactics in leak cases, has opened internal discussions over tightening rules on when prosecutors may seek phone logs and other information that could identify reporters sources as he began a series of a meetings on Thursday with leaders of news media organizations.

title: McIlroys Struggles Continue in First Round of the Memorial
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  With so much on his plate, Rory McIlroy used breakfast at Muirfield Village Golf Club to beg Adam Scott for a few morsels on Merion Golf Club, site of the United States Open in two weeks.

title: The Romantic Advantage
description: In the race to be the worlds dominant economy, Americans have at least one clear advantage over the Chinese. Were much better at branding. American companies have these eccentric failed novelists and personally difficult visionary founders who are fantastic at creating brands that consumers around the world flock to and will pay extra for. Chinese companies are terrible at this. Every few years, Chinese officials say theyre going to start an initiative to create compelling brands and the results are always disappointing.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 31, 2013
description: "If I give them blood, I will learn where my father is, which body is his.

title: Franca Rame, Italian Actress and Playwright, Dies at 83
description: Franca Rame, an Italian actress and playwright whose work  including mordant, highly charged critiques of the Italian government, the Roman Catholic Church and the status of women  was often done in collaboration with her husband, the Nobel Prize-winning playwright Dario Fo, died on Wednesday at her home in Milan. She was 83.

title: A New Step in Wrestling With the Bra
description: They are the measurements that many American women (and not a few American men) know so well: 32A, 34B, 36C.

title: Man Tied to Boston Suspect Is Said to Have Attacked Agent Before Being Shot
description: WASHINGTON  A man who was killed in Orlando, Fla., last week while being questioned by an F.B.I. agent about his relationship with Tamerlan Tsarnaev, one of the Boston Marathon bombing suspects, had knocked the agent to the ground with a table and ran at him with a metal pole before being shot, according to a senior law enforcement official briefed on the matter.

title: U.S. Combat Commanders Should Handle War Zone Investigations, Panel Says
description: WASHINGTON  Concerned about possible flaws in criminal proceedings against American troops accused of killing or abusing civilians in a war zone, a Defense Department panel has proposed that investigations and prosecutions of crimes be carried out by a senior commander in the theater of combat and not the branch of the armed services in which the accused serves.

title: At Giants Practice, Just Another Face, if Not Just Another Name
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Kyle Bosworth, the newest Giant, cannot enter a football locker room unnoticed. His name precedes him.

title: Words of Praise, and Loss, for Malcolm Xs Grandson
description: Malcolm Shabazz never knew his grandfather, Malcolm X, but in his struggle to understand his legacy, he learned to quote the man verbatim, his aunt, Ilyasah Shabazz, recalled on Thursday during a memorial service for Mr. Shabazz at a church in Harlem. So studious was Mr. Shabazz that he would correct others, even if only a single word was out of place.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Scintillating Start for a Bruin Who Was Overlooked in the Draft
description: BOSTON  The shot from just inside the left circle made its way past a diving Derek Stepan and through a maze of Bruins and Rangers in front of Henrik Lundqvist. Lundqvist, the reigning Vezina Trophy winner, was a second too late in folding his left arm into his body, and the puck bounced into the net.

title: Bush Terrorism Fight May Be Fodder in F.B.I. Confirmation
description: WASHINGTON  The pending nomination of James B. Comey to be director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation will probably shine a fresh light on some controversial chapters in George W. Bushs war on terrorism, with Republicans more likely than Democrats to question his role in the Bush Justice Department.

title: What Was Once Yours
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  I believe Josh Knapp is feeling a little insecure today, so lets see what we can do to cheer him up. With statements in the northwest like AM I WRONG? and IM HURT, it sounds like he can use all the solace we can provide.

title: Corrections: May 31, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: A Little Groucho Marx, a Little King Solomon
description: Terrible is the temptation to do good! That observation lands with a satisfying sting in the new production of The Caucasian Chalk Circle, by Bertolt Brecht, that opened on Thursday at the Classic Stage Company. With his walking-dead demeanor and a slightly savage glint in his eye, Christopher Lloyd, portraying the narrator in the first part of the play, imbues that wry morsel of philosophy with a vivid jolt of irony.

title: Special Session Puts Governor in Drivers Seat
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: New Animal Law Is Welcome but, at the Outset, Expensive
description: Some Texas animal shelters have until January to comply with a new law that bans the use of compressed carbon monoxide to euthanize dogs and cats. Although the shelter operators say they welcome the change, they also say that adapting to the new requirements will be neither easy nor cheap.

title: Massachusetts: State Sues Over Cod Limits
description: Attorney General Martha Coakley filed a lawsuit on Thursday against the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in an effort to block federal rules that severely limit the amount of cod New England fishermen are allowed to catch annually. Effective May 1, federal regulators cut the catch for Gulf of Maine cod by 77 percent, saying the limit is the only way to rebuild stocks that scientists say are heavily depleted. Ms. Coakleys complaint says regulators violated federal law by not giving due consideration to the economic impact of the cuts on fishermen and by failing to use the best available science.

title: In Wake of Japanese Market Dip, Investors Find Comfort in Higher Factory Output
description: TOKYO  Japan inched closer to the end of deflation and factory output picked up, government data showed Friday, offering proof that the real economy is slowly catching up to the high expectations set by its recent bold economic policies.

title: Returning Teixeira Will Displace Valuable Contributor for Yankees
description: A few years ago, Lyle Overbay was standing at first base at Yankee Stadium chatting with Mark Teixeira, as opposing baseball players often do between pitches. Both men are in the fraternity of first baseman, but at that moment Overbay was a base runner for the Toronto Blue Jays, and Teixeira, the fielder, had only recently joined the Yankees.

title: Varied Enrollment of Disadvantaged Students
description: Undergraduates receiving Pell grants, 2010-11, at selected elite universities.

title: Income-Based Diversity Lags at Some Universities
description: Opponents of race-based affirmative action in college admissions urge that colleges use a different tool to encourage diversity: giving a leg up to poor students. But many educators see real limits to how eager colleges are to enroll more poor students, no matter how qualified  and the reason is money.

title: What to Watch on Day 6 at the French Open
description: On Thursday, 14 second-round singles matches were unable to be completed, including two of the recommended matches (Schiavone-Flipkens and Haas-Sock). Those two remain worthy picks, as do the following six third-round matches. Seeded players cannot play each another until the third round, and as it happens all six selected Friday matches feature two seeds.

title: Where No Mets Have Gone Before
description: Bobby Valentines 1997 Mets were a plucky group of overachievers who won their first Subway Series game against the Yankees, the defending World Series champions, but they did not sweep the series. The 1998 and 99 Mets were brash contenders, but they could not do it, either. Nor could the 2000 Mets, who won the National League pennant, or the 2006 team that went deep into the playoffs.

title: The Campaign Against President Clinton
description: Ahead of the 1998 midterm elections, Republicans tried to use the Monica Lewinsky affair to their advantage to win more Congressional seats.

title: James B. Comey in 90 Seconds
description: The former Justice Department official, named by President Obama to lead the Federal Bureau of Investigation, prosecuted Martha Stewart and stood up to President George W. Bush.

title: New York Business Leaders Plan a Push in Council Races
description: A group of real estate executives and corporate leaders, bracing for the departure of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, plans to spend up to $10 million to make sure the City Council elected this fall is friendly to business.

title: Injury Ends Debate on Whether Tejada Should Be Sent to Minors
description: The Mets predicament at shortstop was simplified Thursday when Ruben Tejada, the regular starter there since last season, was placed on the 15-day disabled list with a strained right quadriceps muscle.

title: Vatican Bank Looks to Shed Its Image as an Offshore Haven
