description: VATICAN CITY  From the cheerful ease with which the newly minted president of the Vatican Bank fielded questions on a recent morning, it could be easy to forget how the bank has long been a mystery wrapped in an enigma, tangled up in some of the most opaque scandals in Italy.

title: Award Is Presented to Top Lacrosse Players
description: Rob Pannell of Cornell and Katie Schwarzmann of Maryland on Thursday won the Tewaaraton Award, given to the top mens and womens players in the country. Pannell, an attackman, helped the Big Red make the Final Four. He finished his career with 354 points, an N.C.A.A. record. Schwarzmann, a midfielder, won the award for a second consecutive year after helping the Terrapins to the N.C.A.A. title game, where they lost to North Carolina in triple overtime.

title: Queens Boy, 13, Wins Scripps Spelling Bee With Knaidel
description: The fourth trip to the Scripps National Spelling Bee was the charm for Arvind V. Mahankali, 13, from Bayside, Queens.

title: James Leads Third-Quarter Charge as Heat Gain Edge
description: MIAMI  There was only one way to cut through the clutter and the mayhem, the flagrant fouls and flopping charges, the sniping and the posturing that threatened to turn the Eastern Conference finals into an angry carnival of sneers.

title: A Few Wins Transform the Mood for the Mets
description: A boisterous song by the rapper Ace Hood called Bugatti reverberated through the visitors clubhouse at Yankee Stadium late Thursday night as the Mets players laughed and bobbed their heads.

title: The Art of Houghton Hall Comes Home
description: An unparalleled collection, including countless works by Rubens, van Dyck and Velzquez, returns to one of Britains finest Palladian houses.

title: Bernard-Henri Lvy on Art and Philosophy
description: Bernard-Henri Lvy, Frances most famous public intellectual, becomes a curator with a heady new exhibition about the eternal struggle for truth.

title: Deeda Blairs Elegance of Conviction
description: Whether shes tackling the complexities of science or style, the medical philanthropist, fashion icon and social mover Deeda Blair approaches all facets of life with quiet but unwavering discipline.

title: Yoga in Africa
description: The language of yoga is universal. That is the message of Robert Sturman, an artist from Santa Monica, Calif., who has traveled across the United States to capture the tranquillity and beauty of yoga. A month ago, Mr. Sturman traveled to Kenya to document the work of the Africa Yoga Project, a nonprofit organization that teaches and employs more than 70 local yoga teachers and conducts up to 300 free yoga classes for more than 5,000 people weekly in orphanages, prisons and other locales throughout the country.

title: Word of the Day | chivalrous
description: chivalrous \shi-vl-rs\ adjective

title: Suspect Sought in Fatal Shooting of Queens Girl on Bus
description: The police identified a suspect on Thursday in the killing of a 14-year-old Queens girl who was shot in the head as she rode a city bus home from a friends birthday party on May 18.

title: Fending Off the Heat of the Dog Days of Spring
description: On Thursday, New Yorkers in Brooklyn rallied to the challenge of the areas first hot day of the season. Eli Belizaire, in Park Slope, tackled an ice cream cone. John Loftin sold cold water at the intersection of Kings Highway and Remson Avenue in East Flatbush. And the driver of a red convertible, with a towel on his head to cool off, decided he might as well go shirtless.

title: Ryan Says Garrard Didnt Shock Jets
description: Coach Rex Ryan said Thursday that the Jets were not surprised when David Garrard, signed to compete for the starting quarterback job, abruptly chose to retire two weeks ago. Garrards decision, spurred by the condition of his left knee, narrowed the competition to Mark Sanchez and Geno Smith. Garrard was placed on the reserve/retired list Thursday.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 8 P.M. (WE) BRIDEZILLAS This reality series kicks off its 10th and final season with the promise that these will be the worst-behaved brides ever. The temper tantrums begin as one woman feuds with her wedding planner, who just happens to be her future mother-in-law, and another (Ariel, above, with her husband, Brook) makes it clear to her entourage that shes the boss. In Marriage Boot Camp: Bridezillas, a new series at 9, five former bridezillas and their husbands share a house as they try to save their marriages with help from counselors, including Jim and Elizabeth Carroll, a married team. And in Pregnant & Dating, a new series at 10, five women with a fondness for highlighting their baby bumps with various permutations of spandex search for Mr. Right as their pregnancies progress.

title: Economist Who Fled Russia Cites Peril in Politically Charged Inquiry
description: MOSCOW  Hours after the economist Sergei M. Guriev said that he had fled Russia because he feared he would be prosecuted in a politically tinged case, Russias largest bank announced that its shareholders had overwhelmingly re-elected him to its board of directors, a show of support that points to rifts within Russias ruling class.

title: News Quiz | May 31, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Speak More Chinese, Ambassador Tells Thais
description: BEIJING  Some Thai police are corrupt and the justice system is slow, but perhaps more importantly, not enough Thais speak Chinese  thats the gist of a long list of complaints by Chinas Ambassador to Thailand, Guan Mu, delivered at a meeting with Thai officials Wednesday on the popular vacation island of Phuket, the Phuket News reported.

title: U.S. Colleges Report 2013 Admission Yields and Wait-List Offers
description: Every year, as one cohort of incoming students is accepted and another crop starts filling out applications, colleges across the country calculate one last measurement of their admission season success: the yield.

title: IHT Quick Read: May 31
description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria displayed a new level of defiance on Thursday, warning Israel that he could permit attacks on the Golan Heights and suggesting that he had secured plenty of weapons from Russia  possibly including an advanced missile system  as his opponents faltered politically and Hezbollah fighters brought momentum to his military campaign to crush the Syrian insurgency. Anne Barnard reports from Beirut, and Neil MacFarquhar from the United Nations.

title: This Seasons Broadway Stages Feature Many Child Actors
description: In the article Broadway Babies, Robin Pogrebin writes that this seasons Broadway shows feature many child actors.

title: Do You Enjoy Reading Tabloid Gossip?
description: What do we find so appealing about watching celebrities like Charlie Sheen and Lindsay Lohan unravel? Do we take pleasure in hearing about their pain? Do their troubles somehow make us feel better about ourselves? Or, are tabloid scandals just entertainment?

title: Tickled by Americas Quirky Coincidences
description: Inauguration day in President Abraham Lincolns time was on March 4. Thats also the photographer Joshua Yospyns birthday  and if youre given to seeing meaning in coincidences, as he is, its a pretty big deal.

title: What They Said: Indias Growth Slumps to a Decade Low
description: The Indian economy grew 5 percent in the 2012-2013 fiscal year, the smallest rise in a decade, according to government data released Friday. The figure, which was in line with a February estimate of the Central Statistics Office, or C.S.O., dampened hopes of a swift revival of a once-booming economy.

title: Protests Block Large Part of Central Frankfurt
description: FRANKFURT  Demonstrators blocked a large swath of central Frankfurt on Friday to protest a variety of issues ranging from economic austerity in Europe to capitalism to labor conditions for workers in developing countries.

title: How to Cure the College Dropout Syndrome
description: Jeffrey Selingo, the former editor of The Chronicle of Higher Education and currently an editor at large there, is the author of a new book, College (Un)Bound. In it, he argues that the higher-education system is both vital to the American economy and broken. (An essay adapted from the book was published in the Education Life section of The Times last month.) My exchange with him, edited slightly, follows.

title: Nashvilles Frist Center Shows Off Art Deco Cars
description: When Nashvilles main post office opened in 1934, New Deal federal government programs were on the rise and the architectural style of federal buildings was stern and modernist. It was one of those big stately, solid buildings suggestive of the federal governments power; tough-looking stone eagles stood sentinel on its facade.

title: Unemployment Hits Record High in Euro Zone
description: LONDON  Unemployment in the euro zone continued its relentless march higher in April, according to official data published Friday, hitting yet another record, amid a prolonged recession and the absence of a coordinated response by policy makers.

title: Does Spelling Matter?
description: LONDON  A professor of English at one of the worlds most venerable centers of learning has outraged language purists by challenging whether spelling matters.

title: Thanks, and I Do Wear Sun Protection Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Lloyds to Sell $5 Billion in Mortgage Securities to Increase Reserves
description: LONDON  Lloyds Banking Group is on a selling spree.

title: How Two Owners Got the Web Sites They Wanted
description: In my last post  The Problem Social Media Cannot Solve  I profiled DCC Waterbeds, a company that makes waterbeds for cows  yes, really  and that generously shared a tale of what went wrong when the owners hired a friend to build a Web site. This week, Ive found two small businesses eager to talk about how they managed to build Web sites they love.

title: Dell Begins Campaign to Support Leveraged Buyout
description: Dell Inc. on Friday began its official campaign to support a proposed $24.4 billion sale of itself to Michael S. Dell and the investment firm Silver Lake, amid continued opposition to the deal.

title: Daily Report: U.S. Says Self-Driving Cars Could Save Lives
description: The Transportation Department says that driverless cars should not yet be allowed, except for testing, but noted that some safety features could save lives, Claire Cain Miller and Matthew L. Wald report in The New York Times.

title: Chinas Ethnic Song and Dance
description: In Chinas worst single outburst of ethnic violence in four years, 21 people died last month in the far western region of Xinjiang. But never mind that. According to the deputy governor of Xinjiang, Shi Dagang, the regions Muslim Uighur population is far too busy treating guests to meat and wine, with song and dance to create any problems.In fact, Shi insisted to reporters this week, The ethnic minorities are simple-hearted and honest, very kind and unaffected. They love guests.

title: Found Poem Favorite | Barbie
description: This poem, one of 12 winners of our Found Poem Student Contest, was written by Scott, 18, from Phoenix.

title: D.I.Y.-Style Public Spaces
description: As more and more educated Americans seek alternatives to suburbs and cars, theyre reframing the demand for public space.

title: A Streetcorner Serenade for the Public Plaza
description: In Brooklyn, the No. 3 subway line ends at New Lots Avenue, where passengers descend from the elevated tracks to what used to be a nasty intersection, trafficked by prostitutes, drug dealers  You name it, as Eddie Di Benedetto, the owner of Caterinas Pizzeria, put it the other day. Not long ago, a coalition of local merchants and community leaders turned to the New York City Department of Transportation, which runs a program to make traffic circles, triangles and streets into pedestrian plazas.

title: Kafkaesque Customer Service
description: Dear Diary:

title: Chinese Buyers for A.I.G. Plane Leasing Unit Miss Payment
description: The consortium of Chinese firms that has agreed to buy the American International Groups airplane leasing division missed a deposit payment, the American insurer disclosed on Friday, threatening to unwind the multibillion-dollar transaction.

title: Japan and South Korea Bar Imports of U.S. Wheat
description: Japan and South Korea suspended some imports of American wheat, and the European Union urged its 27 nations to increase testing, after the United States government disclosed this week that a strain of genetically engineered wheat that was never approved for sale was found growing in an Oregon field.

title: Newt Economic Thinking
description: OK, we had our Munk debate, and I have a few minutes to blog here at Pearson airport; for what its worth, my side won the audience vote.

title: Finding Inner Peace, iPhone in Hand
description: HeartMath, a creator of science-based solutions to reduce stress, recently turned to a stress inducer, technology, to create a tool to help users achieve serenity.

title: Tip of the Week: Make a Mac Screen Recording
description: The QuickTime Player program included with recent versions of Mac OS X can do more than just play back video clips. It can also make a recording of the action on the computer screen, which can be helpful when creating tutorials or demonstrating how to do a task. To get started, just go to the Macs Applications folder and open the QuickTime Player program.

title: Hidden Venice
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The 1913 Belmont: A New Look and a Dubious Upset
description: Fans noticed a new Belmont at the opening of the 1913 season; renovations had altered the familiar plant. Underneath an extensive diagram of the refurbished courses, The Daily Racing Form wrote that, Since racing has been resumed over the most extensive and commodious plant in America it is fitting that readers should have an opportunity to refresh their memories as to its various courses.

title: At HSBC, a Board Member Who Can Keep Secrets
description: LONDON  From spy vs. spy to spy vs. banker?

title: A Conversation With: Author and Filmmaker Vivek Bald
description: The filmmaker and author Vivek Balds book Bengali Harlem and the Lost Histories of South Asian America created a buzz within the South Asian-American community when it was released in November. Mr. Bald documents the histories of seldom-acknowledged groups of early South Asian migrants to the United States, like Muslim silk and cotton traders from West Bengal in the 1880s and Indian sailors who deserted British steamships in the early 20th century. They settled in New Orleans, Harlem in New York and New Jersey and formed strong community bonds with African-American and Hispanic communities.

title: Debt and Growth: The State of the Debate
description: So, after a brief diversion into issues of manners and etiquette, I hope were back to the substance. And there are really three points that have been established; Im not sure that everyone understands that any one of those points is enough to refute most of the debt/deficit discussion of the past three years.

title: Dell Fights Back
description: DELL FIGHTS BACK | The fight over Dell Inc. has climbed to a new level.

title: Confronting Regulators on the JPMorgan Leaks
description: Richard E. Farley is a partner in the leveraged finance group of the law firm of Paul Hastings. He is writing a book titled The Crisis Not Wasted: The Creation of Modern Financial Regulation During F.D.R.s First Five Hundred Days, a book on the creation of modern financial regulation during President Franklin Roosevelts first term of office.

title: OPEC Maintains Its Target for Daily Oil Production
description: LONDON  With the price of oil relatively strong, OPEC decided on Friday to maintain its current target for oil production at 30 million barrels a day, a move the markets had expected.

title: Friday Reading: Keeping Children Away From Medical Marijuana
What Were Reading
description: 101 Cookbooks: Tips on using edible flowers in cooking, just in time for summer.  Melissa Clark

title: Familiar Faces in Strange Places
description: Wake of the Red Witch

title: Q&A: Choosing a Windows Tablet
description: Q.

title: Wheels Calendar for Saturday and Sunday
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: The Heats One-Man Show
description: At some point Thursday night in Game 5 of the N.B.A. Eastern Conference finals LeBron James realized he was not only on a stage but on it by himself. His supporting cast had deserted him, leaving him as a one-man show. He was not the least bit happy about it, but the N.B.A. was not going to give him longer than a quarter to round up his Miami Heat cast members again, and screaming at them wasnt working, so the LeBron Show went on.

title: Losing My Father at War, One Letter at a Time
description: War does not determine who is right  only who is left. Thats what Bertrand Russell said.

title: Office Romance: Renzo Pianos Light
description: This is the first in a series of Instagrams by Kathy Ryan that find romance and beauty in the office life.

title: Hollywood Agent
description: Its a mans mans mans world, James Brown proclaimed in his celebrated wail inside a New York recording studio in 1966  around the same time Beau Rosenwald, the focal character of Matthew Specktors sprawling, atmospheric second novel, American Dream Machine, sires two sons with two different women. One of those sons  the illegitimate one, Nate Myer  is the novels pensive narrator, and he presents his father as a cross between Augie March and Willy Loman: the child of a Queens shoemaker who works his way up from the mailroom of a former vaudeville agency in New York to representing A-list Hollywood stars while earning virulent enemies, a handful of ex-wives and millions of dollars along the perilous, ego-driven way.

title: Dont Be Disgusting
description: In Renaissance Europe, Italy was Etiquette Central, attracting all the fascination and ridicule that go with that honor.

title: Political Cartoons
description: It has been eight years since a set of Danish cartoons portraying the prophet Muhammad incited rioting in much of the Muslim world. In the eyes of many Americans, the protests were incomprehensible, a collective temper tantrum spawned by dopey sketches. Muslims were accused, among much else, of lacking a sense of humor. But what if the outcry reflected less on Islamic culture than on cartoon culture, which has its own history of flare-ups and meltdowns? The question goes to the heart of Victor S. Navaskys thoughtful and deftly illustrated book, The Art of Controversy: Political Cartoons and Their Enduring Power.

title: Center Stage
description: The next time you watch West Side Story, dont believe every word Rita Moreno sings.

title: I Wanna Be Adored
description: Some bands are famous for capturing the spirit of an era. Others are famous, or almost famous, for capturing the spirit of a fleeting moment  a bright, pivotal summer or even a single incandescent show  and then utterly squandering the whole opportunity.

title: Pop Life
description: The cover of Dirty Mind, Princes ingenious/ingenuous 1980 exercise in self-reinvention, threw down a rose-scented gauntlet. It featured a black-and-white shot of a skinny young man who barely seemed out of his teens (he was 22), looking as much the racially and sexually ambiguous wild boy as a nice Minneapolis lad could. Sporting a thin gigolo mustache, a Joan Jett haircut and an open, oversize jacket that he could have swiped from a doorman at the Grand Hotel, Prince topped off his new image with a kerchief, bare chest and thong with a virile little tuft of hair peeking over the bikini line.

title: Can I Use the Same Paper for Multiple College Courses?
description: When I was in college, Id sometimes write a single paper that would satisfy assignments in more than one course. For instance, I once wrote a paper on how The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock expressed satire; I submitted it for assignments in both my poetry course as well as my completely separate satire course. I did not disclose this to either professor. When I share this with people, half call the practice cheating, and the other half call it genius. My niece told me it would certainly be grounds for expulsion at her college. In my mind, I was adding a level of intellectual complexity to my studies. Was this an ethical practice, or was I cheating? JOE, CONNECTICUT

title: Want to Save Civilization? Get in Line
description: The next time youre stuck behind 250 shoppers in a checkout line that snakes around the aisles in a Trader Joes, take a moment to ponder exactly whats going on. Yes, youre standing in a queue. Yes, it can be the pits. Except that, all things considered, its also pretty great.

title: Dwight Gooden Was Not Best Friends With Darryl Strawberry
description: In your new book, Doc: A Memoir, you proclaim your sobriety. But in 1999, you said you were sober in another memoir, Heat, then wound up in jail years later after testing positive for cocaine use. Why should we believe you now?  At that time, I wasnt completely honest with myself. I was still drinking. I had seven years where I only drank, but eventually, I was doing coke and drinking. Alcohol is a direct link to the drugs.

title: The 5.19.13 Issue
They Do the Dos
description: Photographs of hairstylists in New York City.

title: Jason Isbell, Unloaded
description: If you want to know how to cure a hangover, ask a musician, especially one who has recently been in rehab. Pedialyte, thats what you need, Jason Isbell told me. He was standing outside a recording studio in suburban Nashville, lighting a cigarette. Its the stuff you give kids who are dehydrated from diarrhea. Its like 10 Gatorades in one bottle.

title: The Dog Bit Me
description: Three years ago my son was attacked by a dog. Otto was 2 at the time  a towheaded slip of a boy with bright blue eyes and porcelain skin you could practically see through. He was instinctively drawn to dogs, and we didnt see any reason to discourage him. Of course I knew they could nip, and every once in a while break the skin. And I had heard the horrific news stories of those seemingly devil-possessed dogs who leapt on unsuspecting neighbors, inflicting actual, permanent harm. But regular dogs, I had no real fear of them. Not having seen a dog attack, I was completely ignorant about how bad it could be, how, in five seconds, a dog could tear the flesh off your bones. Or worse, the skin off your childs face.

title: Who Made That Ice-Cream Cone?
description: In the early 20th century, eating was still a formal affair, involving napkins, tables and rules of etiquette. Ice cream was served as a delicate sliver on a plate, then savored with a teaspoon.

title: The Hollywood Fast Life of Stalker Sarah
description: One afternoon this winter, Sarah M., better known as Stalker Sarah, was sitting in the back of an In-N-Out Burger fidgeting with her iPhone and plotting how to get her picture taken with Harry Styles, the rakishly handsome frontman of the English boy band One Direction, or one of his bandmates. Sarah was dressed in her usual uniform of black leather jacket, black skinny jeans and black sneakers; her long brown hair was swept back into a neat ponytail, and her wispy bangs gently brushed the top of her signature wire-rimmed glasses, which accentuated her black eyeliner. It was more or less the same look she had worn in photographs over the years with Angelina Jolie, Brad Pitt, Justin Bieber, Julia Roberts, Oprah, Tim Tebow, Levi Johnston, Rod Blagojevich, Kris Humphries and many, many others. More than 6,000 photos of Sarah mugging with celebrities have been uploaded to the Internet. At 17, she is easily the most famous fan in the world.

title: Mrs. Earp
description: The fabled shootout at the O.K. Corral rooted Wyatt Earp deep in the American psyche, or at least in its Western mythology. But Ann Kirschner has cleverly identified a parallel story buried under the debris of history: that of Josephine Marcus, for nearly 50 years Earps common-law wife and a valiant frontierswoman in her own right.

title: Science
description: Dear Professor Wilson:

title: Good Dog
description: For me, reading dog books is always a little bit fraught. Theres just no way around comparing the dogs in the book with the ones that share my home. And mine, you see, are just this side of feral; their virtues include not eating all six of my dining room chairs. I almost never read books about good dogs or working dogs if I can help it, and certainly not about therapy dogs. I mean, what kind of therapy dogs would my dogs make? Is there a person whose life is too neat, or too happy?

title: Such Small Portions
description: From the praise heaped on it by some analysts of Jewish humor, one might almost think the chosen people were chosen for the quality of their jokes. Freuds Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious, which was published in 1905, drew almost exclusively on Jewish stories, because, he maintained, they were the funniest and the most interesting. Salcia Landmann, a scholar of Yiddish who died in 2002, argued that Jewish humor is more acute, more profound and richer in expression than that of any other people.

title: Tennis
description: My timing could not have been better, Jimmy Connors declares in The Outsider, referring to his becoming the worlds top-ranked tennis player in the mid-1970s, just as the sport entered a golden age and was transformed into a big business. Connors could also have been describing his game, which deployed a wacky steel-frame racket and a relentless take the ball on the rise style to win a record 109 singles titles, including eight Grand Slam championships, five of them at the United States Open.

title: Gilded Cage
description: Seven years ago, a drunken woman made a dramatic emphatic gesture in a Manhattan cab that sent one of my vintage faux gold-and-turquoise Schiaparelli clip-on earrings flying somewhere into the back seats nether regions. This is not one of those taxi stories with a happy ending (the sole copy of the manuscript recovered; the priceless Strad delivered in time for the big concert). The driver spent several minutes kindly helping me search. Numbers were exchanged. Forms filed. All in vain.

title: Miami Vice
description: Summer is no time to be virtuous. So before you pack those classic tomes youre determined to read on vacation, let me tempt you with a few guilty pleasures.

title: Superheroes
description: We all know who Superman is. If youre younger than 75, you dont even remember a time when he didnt exist. With the possible exception of Mickey Mouse, the indestructible and incorruptible Man of Steel is surely the most famous fictional character ever created in cartoon form.

title: Classic 70s Television
description: Long after The Mary Tyler Moore Show ended its run, and a New York station was airing back-to-back reruns around 1:30 a.m., I remember watching and hearing the familiar Love Is All Around theme echoing from both my upstairs and downstairs neighbors. As Friends and Seinfeld would later, in its afterlife The Mary Tyler Moore Show became a reassuring, unfailingly funny end to the day, as much a social phenomenon as a sitcom.

title: Winning
description: On Monday, April 15, 1946, Jews observed Passover in Germany for the first time without fear since 1933. On the following Thursday, the League of Nations was dissolved. And on Sunday came the death of John Maynard Keynes. To the average American, however, the momentous weeks main event occurred on Tuesday, April 16  when the unabashed Cardinals fan Harry Truman threw out the first pitch on opening day at Griffith Stadium in Washington, ending the presidential traditions four-year hiatus. (In 1942, faced with the Japanese invasion of the Philippines and the ensuing Bataan Death March, Franklin Roosevelt had deputized his vice president, Henry Wallace, to perform the ceremonial toss.)

title: Doubleheader
description: The first time I played ball against Willie Mays, in 1965, it was impossible to take my eyes off him. At bat, in the outfield and on the bases, he did everything differently from  and better than  anybody else. Mayss style of play could come only from an impressive intelligence and a thoroughly cultivated knowledge of the game.

title: Isner Rebounds and Ends Fifth-Set Struggles
description: It was the first time two American men had faced each other in the main draw of the French Open since 2001, but John Isner and Ryan Harrison compensated for the drought by playing deep into a fifth set, with Isner coming back from down two sets and prevailing, 5-7, 6-7 (7), 6-3, 6-1, 8-6, in 3 hours 50 minutes.

title: Country Living
description: Grotesquerie is a fact of life for certain classes, the wallpaper for folks who dwell beneath a certain rung of the ladder. Those without health insurance, say. Or money for gas. Or dentists. My people were West Virginia factory workers and, as such, immersed in enough gothic absurdity to drown Flannery OConnor. They were bawdy and hard-hewn and never surprised when tragedy befell their lives. They didnt even call it tragedy, since tragedy was a thing that happened to rich folks with something to lose.

title: Prog Rock
description: Oscar Wilde once said, Experience is the name everyone gives to their mistakes. But for men born about a century after Wilde, mistakes tended to have more colorful names, like Yes, Genesis or Emerson, Lake and Palmer. These were the hairy dragon-kings of prog rock (short for progressive), the bands that ruled the FM airwaves of the 1970s, providing black-light initiations for their adolescent male devotees. Even after all these years, prog remains one of the most intrinsically silly of rock fads: concept albums, ornate time signatures, keyboard solos, lyrical ruminations on the tendency of mountains to fall out of the sky.

title: In a Rooftop Gym, a Fitting Tribute to a Beloved Priest
description: In the final years of his life, when his memory was fading but his strength remained solid, the Rev. John C. Flynn paced the halls of a Bronx nursing home, talking with the lonely, smiling to all  and swinging an imaginary golf club.

title: Spy vs. Spy
description: The undisputed master of spy fiction, John le Carr, worked for British intelligence for several years before the international success of his third novel, The Spy Who Came In From the Cold, allowed him to retire from the secret world to become a full-time writer.

title: Downtown
description: Hail, hail, the gangs all here: a galaxy of scoundrels, artists and geniuses commingle in John Strausbaughs ambitious 600-plus-page history of Greenwich Village. Strausbaugh  who presided over this newspapers Weekend Explorer series on New York City and wrote what felt like the entirety of The New York Press in its 1990s heyday  turns a collection of stories and profiles into something less like a textbook than a party spinning happily out of control.

title: Inside the List
description: LORD OF THE LIST: Forty years after his death, in 1973, J. R. R. Tolkien is on the hardcover fiction list again, this time with The Fall of Arthur, an unfinished epic poem that makes its debut at No. 10. Tolkien has had an active afterlife; reviewing the book in The Los Angeles Times last month, Elizabeth Hand noted that it lists nine works published during his lifetime and 24 published posthumously (at least six of which have been best sellers). Hand liked the book, with some reservations:  The Fall of Arthur is a fascinating work, though perhaps more for the Tolkien completist than the casual Lord of the Rings fan, she wrote. It focuses on the bloody aftermath of Queen Guineveres affair with Lancelot, greatest of Arthurs knights, and is surprisingly powerful in its terse depiction of the affairs devastating consequences.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE HANGING GARDEN,  by Patrick White. (Picador, paper, $15.) In this long fragment of a novel that White, the Australian Nobelist, left unfinished at his death 23 years ago, two refugee children are mistreated by a world that, by its lights, means no harm.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE REVISED FUNDAMENTALS OF CAREGIVING,  by Jonathan Evison. (Algonquin, $14.95.) Ben, the 39-year-old narrator of Evisons bittersweet novel, has lost his children in an accident and is losing his wife to divorce. At the end of his rope, he takes a job as full-time caregiver to Trevor, an angry, girl-crazed teenager suffering from Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Together they take a madcap road trip, from Washington State to Utah, to visit Trevors estranged father.

title: New Tricks for Old Grains
description: Everything old can be new again, especially when you are cooking with ancient grains, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health. Ancients grains like farro and sorghum have been dietary staples for hundreds of years, but many of todays eaters are just discovering their hearty flavor and chewy texture. Ms. Shulman writes:

title: Bound for the Hamptons
description: This week we offer our annual Summer Reading issue, which got me thinking about the etymology of beach read. I searched The Timess archive for its first appearance. The recentness  May 2, 1993  was a surprise. In her review of Fearless, Susan Isaacs wrote, Rafael Yglesiass novel deserves better praise than Great page turner! or Super beach read!

title: Lady Vol
description: College coaches have to construct teams  complex organisms  from players who are often just figuring out who they are, as athletes and as adults. Theyre supposed to remember that the pieces they are fitting together, on the court or the field, are also students. And they have to rebuild again and again, with every graduation.

title: Sacred Hoopster
description: In late March, apparently in order to help promote Eleven Rings, Phil Jackson joined Twitter with a splash. His first tweet received attention on various sports Web sites, including USA Todays and ESPN.com, because its text read, in full, 11 champ;ipnsikp[ ringhs. (An ad made the joke clear: he had tried to type while wearing all 11 rings.) Jacksons fingers soon found the correct keys, and he was off and tweeting. One might have expected profound insights from Jackson, whose 11 N.B.A. rings came while leading the Chicago Bulls in the 1990s and the Los Angeles Lakers in the 2000s and 2010s. The news media had long cast him as the Zen master, an intellectual with an interest in Eastern thought who used Buddhism to manage the titanic egos of Michael Jordan, Shaquille ONeal and Kobe Bryant. For the wizened sage mumbling his koans, isnt a medium limited to 140 characters ideal?

title: On Victory Day, Rabbi Honors Red Armys Jewish Veterans
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  When Rabbi Naftali Estulin walked into the synagogue, the men were waiting for him. They had come with canes and walkers and medals. Some wore yarmulkes. Several covered their heads with hats lettered LA VETERAN ASSN WWII.

title: Splish Splash
description: Rain, rain, go away. Kids have always chanted the familiar refrain  gazing out the window wistfully, chin on fist  as if they had the power to make it happen. But these days, whats a little precipitation when there are peevish birds to be flung and other indoor, on-screen distractions? In an era in which the directive Go play no longer implies outside, the idea that rain may affect a childs fun is perhaps a quaint one. But four new picture books remind us that no matter how cosseted we are by technology, a downpour still holds the power to move us.

title: Out and About
description: Aaron Hartzler and Rafe Goldberg grow up mostly as polar opposites. Aaron comes from a fundamentalist Christian Kansas City family; Rafe is a child of modern-hippie Boulder, Colo., (stereo)types. Aaron, the main character in the memoir Rapture Practice, is real; Rafe, the protagonist in Bill Konigsbergs novel Openly Straight, is made up. But both wrestle, over several hundred pages, with their identities. And both share a secret: Theyre liars.

title: A West Hollywood Place-Setting for Christofle
description: Shoppers sauntering along Melrose Place might mistake Christofles pop-up shop for just another beautifully merchandised lifestyle store in a section of West Hollywood, Calif., that includes Marc Jacobs and Isabel Marant. Studio Christofle, as its called, opened in early May and looks unexpectedly eclectic for the home of a venerable French silver company. The styling and merchandising of the 1,100-square-foot space is a result of two strategic collaborations. JF Chen antiques furnished it with pieces like a 19th century Chinese wedding armoire (now styled with Christofle candelabra, pitchers and vases) and Marco Zaninis throne-line Roma chair for Memphis. Arcana: Books on the Arts supplied rare art, architecture, fashion and design books. Christofle has different faces, said Stphane Parmentier, the companys creative director, who organized the store. We are traditional, but we are also youthful and practical.

title: Apes
description: The stories of scientists create new scientists. Alexander von Humboldt  the most famous naturalist of the early 19th century  chronicled his epic expeditions, between 1799 and 1804, in his Personal Narrative of a Journey to the Equinoctial Regions of the New Continent. When a nature-loving student at Cambridge named Charles Darwin read the book, it changed his life. He read passages aloud to his professors and learned Spanish so that he could follow in Humboldts footsteps. Humboldts Personal Narrative, Darwin later wrote, stirred up in me a burning zeal to add even the most humble contribution to the noble structure of Natural Science. At age 22, he embarked on his own voyage around the world, out of which he would develop his theory of evolution.

title: Secrets
description: The secrets we hold as children, especially those born from familial dysfunction, can be particularly pernicious: too young to handle our experience or verbalize our feelings, and mistakenly convinced were at fault for events beyond our control, we develop sophisticated systems of self-defense that become second nature, deeply tied to our identity  until its time to let them go.

title: Literary Excursions
description: On a trip to Tulum last Christmas, I think I managed the true Epicurean ideal of hedonism, sipping gently of the tropical sun, bodysurfing more than I read, reading more than I ate, and eating more than I worried. The entire endeavor was calibrated to maximize pleasure and minimize hardship, and so I learned nothing. I relaxed. I kept myself entertained. I visited the local Mayan ruins and paid more consideration to the vigilant application of sun goop than to the historical artifacts on display. I had joined the neocolonialist community that, through sky miles and vacation days, has effectively turned the developing world into a Sandals resort.

title: Healthy Appetites
description: Lucy Knisley has eaten well all her life, and everything she tastes is apparently a madeleine for some happy memory. She grew up with a mother who worked for David Bouley and an uncle who ran a gourmet shop; the cover of RELISH: My Life in the Kitchen (First Second, paper, $17.99) shows her lifting an olive to her open mouth, her eyes closed in elated anticipation. Its a memoir with only the slightest hints of conflict or struggle, apart from an early scene in which young Lucy is attacked by a flock of geese. (I have since eaten foie gras with great enjoyment and very little guilt, she notes.) She maps out her emotional associations with her favorite foods  Venetian croissants, sauted mushrooms, McDonalds fries and so on  in a breezy clear-line style, lingering over treasured moments, like resting her hand against Richard Serras Tilted Arc during a catering gig. Between chapters, Knisley offers simple, neatly diagrammed recipes (chocolate chip cookies! pesto! sangria!). Her language, like her drawings, is precise and uncluttered: in one of the books liveliest sequences, 12-year-old Lucy and a friend wander through a little Mexican town, discovering treats like sweet corn on a stick, with hot sauce and lime, which turned the corners of our mouths red.

title: Take Back the Asphalt
description: Heres the core section from a great Michael Kimmelman feature on cities in which space normally reserved for cars is being reclaimed  sometimes temporarily, sometimes permanently  for direct human use:

title: Q & A
description: When Sponsors Abandon Units

title: A Mothers Book Is Her Sons Movie
description: Its a view with a room  now youve seen it, Judy Blume said, smiling and pulling shut the shade in her apartment overlooking Central Park West. It was morning and still bright inside her living room, done in soft colors and wood, with stuffed bookshelves and unpretentious modern art. Over the sofa hung a tasteful assemblage of female nudes. (Some were painted by a friend, Lincoln Perry, who is married to the author Ann Beattie. But that is not Ann, Ms. Blume noted.)

title: She Cuts Quickly, and Quietly
description: Back of House, an occasional column, celebrates the unsung characters who animate the restaurant universe.

title: Shakespeare in the Park
description: The Miser has spent more than a few warm summer nights in a seat under the stars at the Delacorte Theater, taking in what may well be the quintessential free summer event in New York City: the Public Theaters venerable Shakespeare in the Park program. This years productions look as promising as ever: The Comedy of Errors runs from Tuesday through June 30, and a musical version of Loves Labours Lost, adapted by the team that brought us Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson, runs from July 23 through Aug. 18.

title: German From Senegal Vies to Break Bundestag Barrier
description: HALLE, Germany  When Karamba Diaby arrived in Germany as a student from Senegal he knew only two things in German: Bundesliga and BMW  the professional soccer league and the automobile manufacturer. The only hitch was that it was October 1985 and Mr. Diaby had landed in East Germany, where comrades frowned on both West German capitalist institutions.

title: Kissing Away the Corporate Tax
description: My column on Wednesday startled some readers. Was I proposing to do away with corporate taxes simply because globalization is making it easier for multinational companies to avoid them? Should we really just roll over and accept defeat?

title: Germany Counts Heads and Finds 1.5 Million Fewer Residents Than It Expected
description: BERLIN  Its as if Leipzig, Hanover and Dresden had disappeared in the blink of an eye, statistically speaking.

title: Movie Review: 'After Earth'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "After Earth."

title: Report Shows Better Outlook for Medicare
description: WASHINGTON  The financial outlook for Medicare has improved because of a stronger economy and slower growth in health spending, and the financial condition of Social Security has not worsened but is still unsustainable, the Obama administration said Friday.

title: Exclusive | Historic West Village Town House at $17.5 million
description: The renovated brick home on Greenwich and Horatio Streets was built in the late 1830s by William Halsey.

title: Renovated by Artists
description: A meticulously renovated brick town house with an adjoining artists studio on a quaint historic corner in the West Village is poised to enter the market for the first time since 1997, when it was rescued from obsolescence by the art dealer Matthew Marks and his partner, Jack Bankowsky, a curator who was formerly the editor of Artforum magazine.

title: I Enjoyed My Sons Bris
description: A few weeks after my sons bris, a friend of mine who had attended the ceremony told me that it looked as if I really enjoyed it. A Catholic from Ecuador and a bris first-timer, he said this without irony or judgment. He had no idea that most moms cower in the corner with covered eyes until the job is complete.

title: This Weeks Movies: After Earth, The Kings of Summer and The East
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on The East, After Earth and The Kings of Summer. Here are all of this weeks reviews.

title: Gaining the Upper Hand
description: With fewer homes on the market in New York City, real estate agents say that the more desirable ones are often receiving multiple offers. Even if the bidding does not escalate to a war, it takes a savvy strategy to beat out the competition.

title: In a Sellers Market, Every Minute Counts
description: If there was any doubt that New York City real estate has become a sellers market, consider the following: open houses are packed to capacity, bidding wars and all-cash offers have almost become the norm, and some listing prices actually rise, not drop, after a home is listed.

title: Did the Mets Sweep, or Were the Yankees Swept?
description: The Mets four-game sweep of the Yankees was both surprising and unprecedented, and it raised interesting questions:

title: Turning a Robber Into the Good Guy
description: Perhaps it says something about Europes economic and unemployment troubles that a man who robs banks for a living is the good guy in The Prey, a French thriller that opens for a run at the AMC Empire 25 in Midtown Manhattan on Friday.

title: Inside the New York Times Book Review: Summer Reading
description: This week, Peter Lattman talks about the new memoir by the tennis star Jimmy Connors; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Alexandra Jacobs discusses Patricia Volks Shocked; Anthony Gottlieb on Ruth R. Wisses No Joke: Making Jewish Humor; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Listen Up | Eleanor Friedbergers 70s Song Craft
description: I think were drawn to the decade we were born in, said the singer-songwriter Eleanor Friedberger, who was born in 1976. I love looking at 70s interiors, textiles or graphic design and thinking, If I could turn this picture into music, what would it sound like? Her songs do sound the way a Barbara DArcy room or Milton Glaser album cover looks: warm, inviting and groovy. Though shes best known as the frontwoman for the Fiery Furnaces, the Brooklyn indie rock band she founded with her brother Matthew more than a decade ago, the release of Personal Record (Merge), her second solo album next week, should solidify her identity as a stand-alone musician. Steeped in the analog sounds of Me Decade icons like Harry Nilsson, Emitt Rhodes and Caetano Veloso, the album is more mellifluous and emotionally resonant than the Furnaces eccentric work. Instead, it builds on the classic song craft of Friedbergers 2011 solo debut, Last Summer, interweaving bossa nova beats and British folk balladry with summer-road-trip rock n roll. Its as relatable  and as much a career high-water mark  as its title suggests. I dont get to hide under a band blanket, she says of flying solo. But it also feels more authentically me.

title: Serious Stuff, With Bare Midriffs
description: For serious ballet fans, there is no other place to be this week than the Metropolitan Opera House, where American Ballet Theater enters the third week of its spring season with its final performance of Alexei Ratmanskys Shostakovich Trilogy, on Monday. The first section, Symphony No. 9, had its premiere during the companys fall season last year, but the remaining two parts (Chamber Symphony and Piano Concerto No. 1) are brand new.

title: Protest in Turkey Turns Violent
description: The fourth day of an Istanbul sit-in turned violent when the police moved in to disperse protesters.

title: Image of the Day: May 31
Crowds Line Up for Manet in Venice
description: VENICE  One of the hottest tickets in town has nothing to do with the Biennale or even contemporary art. Every morning lines can be seen snaking around the Palazzo Ducale as crowds wait to get into Manet. Return to Venice, an exhibition of about 80 paintings, drawings and prints.

title: Marvin Junior, 77, Robust, Earthy Baritone for the Dells
description: Marvin Junior, whose raw but robust baritone served for half a century as the sturdy foundation for the Dells, a Chicago doo-wop and rhythm-and-blues group that was formed when he and most of its other members were in high school in the early 1950s, died on Wednesday at his home in Harvey, Ill. He was 77.

title: Peaceful Protest Over Istanbul Park Turns Violent as Police Crack Down
description: ISTANBUL  Police officers attacked a group of peaceful demonstrators on Friday in Istanbuls Taksim Square with water cannons and tear gas, sending scores of people, protesters and tourists alike, scurrying into shops and luxury hotels and turning the center of this city into a battle zone at the height of tourist season.

title: On Path to Priesthood, and Then He Fell for Her
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: Court Revives Financiers Fraud Suit Against Citigroup Over the Sale of EMI
description: The British financier Guy Hands will have another chance to try to prove his claim that he was defrauded by his longtime bankers at Citigroup.

title: Breaking Out A Prisoners Tale
description: A formal description of Luigi Dallapiccolas one-act Il Prigioniero, a bleak 12-tone opera about a despairing prisoner during the Spanish Inquisition, might not sound like a crowd pleaser. Still, the conductor Alan Gilbert is giving New York Philharmonic audiences a rare chance to experience this sensual and mysterious 1950 work as part of Gilberts Playlist, a series devoted to his favorites. I share his enthusiasm for Il Prigioniero, which I first saw in a wrenching production at the Paris National Opera in 2008.

title: Inside the New York Times Book Review: Summer Reading
description: This week, guests discuss reviews in the annual Summer Reading issue. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Two Mothers, Many Problems
description: On Monday night, ABC Family bids farewell to the trials and tribulations of adolescent pregnancy with the finale of The Secret Life of the American Teenager, at 8, and introduces a different kind of motherhood in its latest original drama, The Fosters, at 9. Created by Bradley Bredeweg (Fly Girls) and Peter Paige (Queer as Folk), with the pop star Jennifer Lopez leading the executive producers, The Fosters charts the twists and turns in the lives of Stef Foster (Teri Polo), a police officer, and her romantic partner, Lena Adams (Sherri Saum), a school vice principal. Together theyre mothers to Brandon (David Lambert), Stefs biological son from a previous marriage, and the adopted twins Mariana (Cierra Ramirez) and Jesus (Jake T. Austin).

title: Strong Bones Start in the Womb
description: Children born to mothers who get more vitamins from their diets develop stronger bones even years later, a new study shows.

title: 1935 Play Becomes A Forget-Me-Not
description: Nobody paid much attention when Cornelius opened in London in 1935, though the play was written by the popular novelist and dramatist J. B. Priestley and starred no less an actor than Ralph Richardson. But this portrait of capitalism, as one character calls it, a game of snakes and ladders  without the ladders, was perhaps too tough-minded for escapist Depression audiences and survived for a mere seven weeks before fading into the twilight of forgotten flops.

title: Keep Calm and Carry On
description: I had just finished facilitating a daylong workshop for a team of leaders at Walmart when I received a voicemail telling me my flight from Bentonville, Ark., that evening had been canceled and I would not be able to get home until sometime the next day.

title: Kerry Castigates Russia Over Syria-Bound Missiles
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State John Kerry on Friday strongly criticized Russias pledge to sell advanced antiaircraft weapons to Syria, suggesting that along with the growing involvement of Iran and Hezbollah in the fighting, the sale threatened to disrupt efforts to negotiate a political settlement and could destabilize the region.

title: Shes Rearming Leonardos Ideas
description: The words military industrial complex are not the first ones that spring to mind when you think about Leonardo da Vinci, but his designs for outlandish weaponry for the powerful Duke of Milan, Ludovico Sforza, his patron, are among his most reproduced drawings.

title: Duets of Disconnection
description: Its a sign of Christopher Wheeldons eminence that his choreography, more than anyone elses today, raises central issues about the nature of ballet. Is it an art of escapism or one that reflects vital features of the world we know? If its an art of ideals, what are they?

title: Looking Back at Lennys Playlist
description: An evening celebrating symphonic jazz, a Stravinsky blowout, a rare 1940s opera revived: Gilberts Playlist, a monthlong festival of the New York Philharmonic, has arrived, honoring the programming proclivities of Alan Gilbert, the orchestras music director.

title: Book Review Podcast: Annual Summer Reading Issue
description: This week New York Times Book Review presents its annual Summer Reading issue, which includes looks at new books about Jewish humor, Superman, Prince, Mary Tyler Moore, Mickey Mantle and Willie Mays, Greenwich Village and much more. Peter Lattman reviews the new memoir by the tennis star Jimmy Connors, The Outsider. Mr. Lattman writes:

title: Big Ticket | Treetop Park Views for $16,575,000
description: Perhaps it was the lure of a free key to exclusive Gramercy Park, but the as-yet-unfinished gut renovation of a historic Salvation Army rooming house at 18 Gramercy Park South by Zeckendorf Development and Robert A. M. Stern, the premier team that produced the premium price precedents set by 15 Central Park West, has recorded its first closing. A floor-through unit on the ninth floor sold for its full asking price of $16,575,000, an amount that escalated to $16,877,493.75 once the transfer taxes kicked in, and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.The 4,207-square-foot residence has four bedrooms and five and a half baths, and provides treetop views of the park and surrounding historic neighborhood with the addition of 35 large windows. The anticipated monthly carrying costs are $11,200. According to the developer, 8 of the available 16 residences, including a $42 million duplex penthouse with four terraces and two pools that was snapped up by Leslie Alexander, the owner of the Houston Rockets, went swiftly to contract for the full listing price despite being bought off the offering plan.

title: Black Flag Revisited, Twice
description: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss Black Flags history, legacy and competing reunions.

title: Mattek-Sandss Aggressiveness Succeeds Against Li
description: After a lost year spent rehabbing various injuries and learning that she had several food allergies, Bethanie Mattek-Sands scored the biggest win of her career Thursday, beating the 2011 French Open champion Li Na in three sets. The match was played in cold and drizzly conditions, but Mattek-Sands followed her game plan to perfection and finished the match with a steely calm as she swung out aggressively and never let up on Li. Mattek-Sands broke Lis serve three times in the third set, hitting out on her return of serve and beating Li at her own game.

title: Off the Charts: Sign of Excess?
description: Margin debt in the United States  money borrowed against securities in brokerage accounts  has risen to its highest level ever.

title: Shades of 2007 Borrowing
description: AMERICAN investors have taken out more margin loans than ever before. That indicates that speculative investing has grown among retail investors, reaching levels that in the past indicated the market was getting to unsustainable levels and might be in for a fall.

title: The Sweet Spot: The Have-Mores
description: Always in fashion, sort of, in this weeks episode David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about materialism and the culture of excess.

title: Loans From a Bank Supported by the Family Tree
description: MANY 20-somethings with a business idea  or a gap between their income and their living expenses  turn to the bank of mom and dad for help. This is hardly new, even if the numbers are increasing.

title: A Mets Fan for Life, and a Deliriously Happy One for a Week
description: Once again I have come to realize that a Mets win over the Yankees makes my heart sing and that four such wins could awaken me from the dead.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: An 1855 Victorian in Franklin Township, N.J., and a Nantucket-style colonial on the Stamford, Conn., waterfront.

title: Despite Protests, Alicia Keys Says She Will Perform in Tel Aviv
description: Alicia Keys said on Friday that she is going forward with a July 4 performance in Tel Aviv that has drawn calls from other artists to cancel as part of a larger cultural boycott of Israel.

title: Movie Review: 'The East'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The East."

title: Bachmann Opponent Says He Will Not Run
description: A Minnesota hotelier who lost a close race against Representative Michele Bachmann last year and was gearing up for a rematch in 2014 has said that he will not run after all  just two days after Mrs. Bachmann, a fiery Tea Party Republican, said she would not seek re-election.

title: After a Tragedy, Calculating the Best Ways That People Can Help
description: UNFORTUNATELY, it has become a sad tradition. An unthinkable tragedy occurs  the shootings at a movie theater in Aurora, Colo., or the bombings at the Boston Marathon. We are stunned, and then  to help the victims, to start the healing, to just feel like we are doing something  we give money.

title: Popcast: Black Flag Revisited, Twice
description: From 1979 to 1986 Black Flag was one of Americas greatest punk bands  maybe one of Americas greatest bands, full stop. But there were more than a dozen different Black Flags during that period, through frequent changes of lineup and at least one change of style. (Around 1983, Greg Ginn, the bands lead guitarist, principal songwriter, record-label boss, musical director, and only permanent member of the group, radically slowed its tempos down.)

title: Why Cant Canada Win the Stanley Cup?
description: The N.H.L.s conference finals will begin on Saturday, and fans in Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles and Pittsburgh can still dream of a Stanley Cup championship. But this year is an unhappy anniversary for Americas northerly neighbor. It is 20 years since the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Los Angeles Kings to win the 1993 Stanley Cup; no Canadian team has won the championship since.

title: Hidden in Plain Sight
description: In the late 1970s, I purchased a half-dozen pocket-size paperback books that bore the name Ed Ruscha. I hadnt heard of the California artist at the time  I just liked the look of his booklets. One was bound with ribbon; the rest were perfect binds. There were no cover pictures; only widely spaced titles typeset in a serif font that I also liked to use, called Stymie Bold. The cover designs were distinct yet understated, reminiscent of small-press poetry collections. Inside were photographic records of what each title promised  Various Small Fires, Thirtyfour Parking Lots, Twentysix Gasoline Stations, Nine Swimming Pools, Crackers (with text by Mason Williams on How to Derive the Maximum Enjoyment From Crackers) and Babycakes (with photographs of, yes, a baby and cakes). They were puzzling yet clearly ironic, prefiguring many books by todays conceptual artists. The critical mass of decidedly mundane pictures gave them their allure. Marcel Duchamps ready-mades and Andy Warhols soup cans had already elevated everyday objects to the status of art, but Ruschas small books brought the ennobled vernacular back down to earth.

title: What I Read That Summer
description: The rites of summer are, by definition, fleeting: the summer romance, the summer job or vacation. Only the books seem to stick. Twelve writers recall their most memorable experiences of summer reading, proving perhaps that if youre looking for an enduring summer romance, a good book might be your best bet.

title: The Gun Report: May 31, 2013
description: Can there be any doubt that we are becoming desensitized to gun violence? Look the first item in todays report. A Chicago teenager who had moved to Californiato escape gun violence!was shot to death when he came home for summer break. The Chicago Tribune ran a story on the killing, but it merited just a few paragraphs at the top of a roundup of overnight shootings. It was awarded three paragraphs at a local news site.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: An Upper West Side co-op with three bedrooms, a West Village duplex loft and a pet-friendly Crown Heights studio.

title: Writing the Blues Into Country
description: NASHVILLE  My life is one very large country song, said LeAnn Rimes. What Ive lived in the last four years is country music at its finest.

title: Week in Pictures for May 31
description: Subjects include a Memorial Day parade in Queens, the bike-share program in Brooklyn and the reunion of President Obama and Gov. Chris Christie on the Jersey Shore.

title: From Gowanus to Bonnaroo
description: Aoife ODonovan knows that her first name is hard to pronounce, her voice is easy on the ears and the path she has chosen  a singer-songwriter-guitarist in New York  can be a brutal one. (Its EEE-fah, now that youre wondering.)

title: Redemption at Port Hudson
description: For Maj. Gen. Christopher C. Augur, his May 21, 1863 victory over Confederate forces at a crossroads near the hamlet of Plains Store, outside Baton Rouge, La., was particularly sweet. Possession of the roads by Augurs division closed the last escape route for the Confederate garrison of Port Hudson, located about 25 miles north and one of the last rebel bastions on the Mississippi River.

title: Vocal Sessions in the Car and News From Outer Space
description: Maybe it was the placement on a coke-fueled episode of Girls, or as the theme song to the MTV reality show Snooki & Jwoww, but the music of Icona Pop has always seemed fit for a neon-tinged night out. Since they broke onto the charts last year with the soundtrack-ready single I Love It (co-written by and featuring the British singer Charli XCX) the Swedish duo has made its name on synthy dance pop with hedonistic lyrics and imagery.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Paris; Sodankyla, Finland; England
description: Paris Jazz Festival, Paris Every weekend from June 9 to July 29, jazz musicians from across the globe will perform in the beautifully lush Parc Floral in the Bois des Vincennes at Pariss eastern edge. Troy Andrews, above, known as Trombone Shorty, who hails from New Orleans and has appeared in the HBO series Treme, will perform alongside his band, Orleans Avenue, on July 14, and the Cuban jazz pianist Roberto Fonseca will play on July 7. Local, though by no means lesser, acts include the Manu Katch Quartet on June 30.

title: Kids These Days
description: T asked a group of authorities on subjects ranging from music to design to literature to profile the most game-changing men and women under 30 in their fields.

title: Eager to Adopt, Evangelicals Find Perils Abroad
description: BOZEMAN, Mont.  As a girl, Danna Hopkins dreamed of having 20 children. Today, she and her husband, Brian, the pastor of an evangelical church here, are building a large family, but not in the way she had imagined.

title: Stosurs Penchant for Clay Developed Over Time
description: PARIS  Approaching the second week of the French Open, one of her favorite tournaments, the Australian Samantha Stosur made a surprising comment: she used to hate clay. As admissions go, it was as if Roger Federer revealed he detested grass or Victoria Azarenka disclosed a previous aversion to hardcourts.

title: SAC Case Tests a Classic Dilemma
description: Imagine the pressure on Mathew Martoma, the 38-year-old former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors charged with insider trading who may  or may not  be in a position to implicate Steven A. Cohen, the hedge funds billionaire founder and owner.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Fletchers Brooklyn Barbecue, a barbecue joint at Third Avenue in Gowanus, has just opened a Manhattan location for the summer, running daily from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. at Pier 57, near West 15th Street and 11th Avenue. The menu includes barbecue sandwiches, wood-smoked chicken and a rotating selection of specials like barbecue hot link sandwiches with peppers and onions.

title: Little Cause for Inflation Worries
description: Periodically I am asked whether we should worry about inflation, given how much money the Federal Reserve has pumped into the economy. Based on the Bureau of Economic Analysis data released Friday morning, this answer is still emphatically no.

title: New York Grand Opera Cancels Central Park Performances
description: Climate change may have officially taken a toll on the opera world.

title: Bookshelf: Baby
description: BABY PARADE  By Rebecca OConnell.Illustrated by Susie Poole.  24 pp. Albert Whitman. $15.99. (Picture book; ages 1 to 4)

title: Reinventions on a Theme: Dinner Table Classics
description: For the modern bride and groom, the right table setting now is mixed and matched.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: The Authority Saves Humanity
description: At No. 2 on our hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week is Volume 1 of The Authority, from DC Comics. The 12 issues included in this edition were written by Warren Ellis and illustrated by Bryan Hitch. The series was originally bought in 1999, and captured some creative magic. The heroes (Jenny Sparks, who embodied the spirit of the 20th Century; Apollo and Midnighter, crime-fighting lovers who were analogues of Superman and Batman; Jack Hawksmoor, who could communicate with and control cities) were captivating, and the artwork was exquisite. The first year found the heroes fighting bigger and bigger threats as a team. The first four issues featured a nation of terrorists who were bred to have Superman-like powers and who were bent on destroying major world cities. The middle story arc featured an invasion from a parallel word. The final four issues featured the team confronting no less than the incomprehensible godlike creator of the solar system that wanted to cleanse the universe of humanity. (The heroes won!) Versions of these heroes continue to be featured in Stormwatch, a monthly series published by DC, but there are only sparks of the audaciousness that were once a hallmark of the series.

title: Buffetts Energy Gamble in Las Vegas
description: Warren Buffett needs luck for his Las Vegas gamble to pay off. Berkshire Hathaways $5.6 billion bet on NV Energy suggests the billionaire investor is coming up short on decent ways to deploy his cash. With electrical utility mergers offering meager synergies thanks to the pounds of flesh demanded by regulators, Berkshire will struggle even to cover its cost of capital.

title: The Sweet Spot: The Have-Mores
description: Always in fashion, sort of, in this weeks episode David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about materialism and the culture of excess.

title: Taliban Deny Responsibility for Attack on Red Cross
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Days after being roundly condemned for targeting the International Committee of the Red Cross, the Taliban on Friday denied any role in this weeks suicide assault against the humanitarian agency, emphasizing that they respected the groups neutrality.

title: Experts Foresee No Detectable Health Impact from Fukushima Radiation
description: The levels of exposure to radiation following the leaks and explosions at the earthquake-damaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station in 2011 were so low that they led today to this important conclusion from experts convened in Vienna by the United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effect of Atomic Radiation:

title: Former Goldman Sachs Partner Fined for Unauthorized Trades
description: Goldman Sachs and Glenn Hadden, one of Wall Streets top traders, have been fined by the CME Group over a Treasury futures trade in 2008.

title: Tennis Goes High-Tech, and Thats Just in the Stands
description: PARIS  Rafael Nadal had taken off his shirt and sat facing away from the box seats in Chatrier Stadium.

title: Doug Quinns Next Act: A Classic Bar
description: The bartender Doug Quinn doesnt dream small.

title: Casanova Drops Some Coins in the Classical Jukebox
description: Mozart meets Mamma Mia!

title: Were Boosting Our Morale, Though We Hate Doing It
description: No one much likes team-building retreats: certainly not the team, often not even the leader. But somehow Rhea Leman, the author of the second play this season built around just such an event, still hopes that we silent observers beyond the fourth wall might feel differently.

title: A Smartphone Challenge in Times Square
description: Stephanie Rosenbloom, The Getaway columnist, takes a smartphone tour challenge in the heart of Manhattan.

title: Money Market Fund Overhaul Is Early Test for Dodd-Frank
description: David Zaring is assistant professor of legal studies at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Summer Soup From Sea and Garden
description: As the days begin to get hot and we lean toward lighter fare, may I suggest ... soup? Not a thick, rib-sticking lentil soup from last season, but a summer soup, and not a chilled one. A soup that is light, brothy and full of vegetables, a satisfying one-dish lunch or dinner.

title: Lets Play: Making Travel a Game
description: IT WAS A SUNDAY AFTERNOON in SoHo and while most New Yorkers were having brunch, Makeda Peters and her boyfriend were on a street corner craning their necks at a seven-story art installation called The Wall, about to embark on whats known among travelers who love puzzles and prizes as a gamified city tour.

title: Bookshelf: Baby
description: Baby Parade, by Rebecca OConnell, and More

title: In the Himalayas, Journeys of Faith and Flowers
description: Deep in the gorge that it carves through the Himalayas, the Alaknanda River rushed beneath a footbridge. On the right bank sat a busy Indian village, Govindghat, its one street lined with spartan hotels and shops brimming with Sikh religious items and souvenirs. On the left bank, a man wearing a frayed sweater-vest and a ski cap greeted me imploringly.

title: Into Indias Himalayas
description: Hiking among pilgrims and towering peaks on the way to two special sites.

title: On a Road Trip in Sicily, Churches Everywhere
description: It happened each time we drove into one of southeastern Sicilys hill towns. It could be a village or a big town, run-down or fixed-up, but as we drove uphill toward the historic center, the vision ahead was always roughly the same: a stunning Baroque church, honey-colored or pale white, decorated with columns or curves, angels or Cupids, shells or leaves, urns or shields, sometimes all of the above. A bell tower might be missing or there might be grass growing between the paving stones, but each of those churches exemplified what unfolds all across this corner of Sicily: an exuberant style that played itself out on facades of churches and palazzi in the wake of a devastating earthquake in 1693.

title: In Tel Aviv, a Port Is Reborn
description: Tel Aviv, a seaside city, has no shortage of waterfront space. It has so much that when its port, Namal, began to fall into disuse four decades ago, overshadowed by a port to the south that became Israels main nexus of sea trade, it was shuttered. No one thought to rehabilitate it. There were plenty of other places to take advantage of the sea.

title: Jewelry, Children and Movie Premieres
description: Jennifer Meyer Maguires jewelry line, which she began designing in 2005, is nominated for a Council of Fashion Designers of America award. A Los Angeles native, Ms. Meyer Maguire, 36, lives there with her husband, the actor Tobey Maguire, and their children, Ruby, 6, and Otis, 4.

title: In Store | A Designer Brings His Quirky Vision to Westhampton Beach
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Section D, St. Jude
The Family Caregiver Turns Pro
description: Everyone who thinks about the so-called work force problem for the elderly can see big trouble coming. Whos going to provide care for the growing number of old people who, even with enormous efforts from family members, will most likely need more help? Or who dont have families? And who prefer, overwhelmingly, to stay in their homes?

title: Haas, Showing Experience More Than Age, Is the Oldest Man Left Standing
description: PARIS  Scouting opponents remains something of an inexact, and not wholly embraced, science in tennis. But even if the young American Jack Sock were the sort to approach a match without so much as a YouTube search or a game plan, his second-round match at the French Open would not have required much advance analysis. Sock was playing Tommy Haas, and if there is a universal truth in sports, it is this: run the old guy around until his legs grow as heavy as a sodden tennis ball.

title: Avoiding Jokers Remorse
description: You know when youve gone too far. You can see it on your interlocutors face. Her eyes widen, her lips purse  it looks as if she has chilling documentary evidence of the gathering cicada swarm.

title: Kyrgyzstan Declares State of Emergency After Clashes
description: MOSCOW  The government of Kyrgyzstan declared a state of emergency on Friday in a remote northern district after the police used tear gas and stun grenades to disperse protesters threatening to seize the countrys largest gold mine.

title: Uneven Outcry Over G.M.O. Foods
description: Genetically altered wheat was found in Oregon, and The Timess Michael Moss discusses why engineered food has long elicited criticism overseas but is just now growing in the United States.

title: Heat Find a Way Around Pacers Big Man
description: The third quarter of Indianas Game 5 loss to the Miami Heat was the culmination of every fear the Pacers had entering the Eastern Conference finals. In those 12 minutes LeBron James summoned his most dominant stretch of the series and his 16 points were more than the entire Pacers team could manage. The Heat also cranked up their defensive intensity and smothered the Pacers, who were nearly twice as likely to turn the ball over as make a basket in the period.

title: Arturo OFarrill to Begin Residency at Harlem School of the Arts
description: The Afro-Latin Jazz Alliance has announced that its founder, the pianist and composer Arturo OFarrill, is now an artist in residence at the Harlem School of the Arts. He joins the choreographer Twyla Tharp, who inaugurated the residency program last fall.

title: A Flagship Becalmed in a Bland Sea
description: The Acura RLX comes off as the sweetest Honda youve ever imagined, but even Acura fans may wonder about a sticker price that can reach $61,000.

title: Fired for Being Gay? Protections Are Piecemeal
description: Jake, a 43-year-old worker at an auto parts warehouse in Ohio, often spends his lunch break in his car. By eating alone, he doesnt have to talk with co-workers about his weekend plans or worry about using the wrong pronoun that could reveal that his life partner of 12 years is another man. Since many of his colleagues drop gay slurs on a daily basis, its a topic he would rather avoid.

title: New Jersey Pushes Gun Control
description: There are two surprising things going on in New Jersey: one, the state legislature, which is famous for either doing nothing or doing the wrong thing, has passed a series of tough gun control measures; and two, its plausible that Gov. Chris Christie will sign some of them.

title: Sections A, B, C and D, Glued Struggle
Nadal Wins and Then Provides Some Off-Court Drama
description: PARIS  Boring? Rafael Nadal has certainly done his part to spice up a rain-interrupted, so far shock-free week at the French Open.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: The solar industry struggles with some growing pains, home prices soar, and Jockey introduces a new system for sizing bras.

title: Brazilian Cement Producer Plans $4.8 Billion I.P.O.
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Brazils largest cement producer, Votorantim Cimentos, is planning to raise as much as $4.8 billion in what would be one of the largest initial public offerings worldwide this year.

title: A Floating Wind Tower Is Launched in Maine
description: One reason that offshore wind has not caught on in the United States is the steep cost of erecting a tower in the water, but researchers at the University of Maine tried another approach on Friday by launching a floating wind machine. It is the first offshore wind installation in United States waters, according to the Energy Department, which helped pay for it.

title: With Students as Backdrop, Obama Warns of Doubling of Loan Rates
description: WASHINGTON  College students, freshly relieved of pressure from term papers and final exams, served as a backdrop for President Obama on Friday as he warned of another impending fiscal deadline: student loan interest rates are set to double in 30 days under current law.

title: Its 2 Diva Judges Gone, American Idol Continues to Revamp
description: Foxs grand  and expensive  experiment in using music superstars to revive its flagging American Idol franchise was officially shut down Thursday night when the two contemporary divas brought in this season, Mariah Carey and Nicki Minaj, both confirmed recent rumors that they would be leaving the show.

title: An Age Gap Bridged by a Love of Animals
description: For Teo Alfero, sauntering onto the patio of a California restaurant accompanied by a pair of leashed wolf-dog hybrids  the kind of regulated or downright illegal progeny of wild wolves who have been mated with dogs  was no big deal.

title: How to Write a Personal Essay That You Know Will Be Torn Apart in the Comments Section
description: Thirteen years ago I wrote a Lives column about retaking the SATs as an adult. I was 28 and felt it was high time I redeemed myself for my original scores, a set of numbers that had stalked me for a decade. In the essay, Evening the Score, I expressed the fear that my abysmal performance would land me in community college, not thinking for a second that I might offend anyone. Yet, I did. While unabashedly Yahooing myself a while later, I discovered I had been granted the (THE!) 2001 Shame Award by the Two Year College Association. It took a minute for the full weight of it to hit me.
