Ever so slowly, the smile spread across my face. I won! Not only was it one of the only awards Id ever received, it proved that someone actually read my piece. My only regret was that I had been given the award in absentia (talk about shameful, I wasnt even invited to that years T.W.C.A. convention, where the honor was announced) and therefore had no plaque or certificate to hang next to my four-year college diploma (which I did in fact earn, despite my standardized-test deficiencies).

title: Big Question for Wearable Computing: Is It Ready for Consumers?
description: Apple and Google seem to agree on one thing: the future of computers will be wearable. Where they disagree is which kind of computers people will actually want to wear.

title: Naval Academy Is Shaken by Students Report of Rape by Athletes
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  As midshipmen were graduating from the Naval Academy here last week, Navy investigators were conducting an investigation into reports that several football players had serially raped a female midshipman at an off-campus party last year.

title: Techs and the City
description: THIS spring New York City is rolling out its much-ballyhooed bike-sharing program, which relies on a sophisticated set of smartphone apps and other digital tools to manage it. The city isnt alone: across the country, municipalities are buying ever more complicated technological solutions for urban life.

title: Trimming Asparagus
description: Melissa Clark demonstrates how to prepare, trim and peel asparagus for any recipe.

title: A Predictable Decline in Hillary Clintons Popularity
description: The controversies surrounding the I.R.S.s targeting of conservative groups and the executive branchs handling of last years attacks in Benghazi, Libya, have yet to have much impact on President Obamas approval ratings (although some slight decline may be hidden by an improved economic mood). But Mr. Obamas former secretary of state, Hillary Rodham Clinton, appears to be have been more affected.

title: Those Rising Bond Yields: Still Low
description: As Floyd Norris notes in his High & Low Finance column, the new fear among market watchers is that the economy is getting too strong. As problems go, that might seem like a high class one to have, but those worries are again the topic du jour Friday, as the yields on 10-year Treasury bills rose again.

title: Innovative and Frighteningly Accomplished  and Not Even 30
description: KIDS THESE DAYS

title: Fallout From Failure of Battery Swap Plan
description: When Better Place, the global electric-car charging company with a home base in Israel, announced last month that it had reached the end of the road, it left behind both bold dreams and valuable assets.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 31
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

title: Week in Review: Skepticism in Washington of American Pig in China
description: Deal Professor says a pork deal may hinge on the risk for uproar. | Records show tension among the Obama administration over British banks. | Sallie Mae will split old loans from new. | Switzerland to allow its banks to disclose hidden client accounts. | Buyout offer brings China into the orbit of Club Med. | Powerhouse of the uranium enrichment industry seeks a way out. | Entrepreneurs help to build start-ups by the batch.

title: Asparagus Adds Green to a Bean Salad
description: Most people associate asparagus and its fresh, strong, grassy flavor with the onset of spring. But as spring wanes and summer advances, there are still stalks at the market, and they work beautifully in a warm-weather bean salad.

title: Snapshots From Venice
description: Highlights from the Venice Biennale by the chief art critic Holland Cotter with updates each day.

title: Such a Doll
description: Doll got mysterious, beautiful deep-set eyes  so keep watching to see how you can do that, too. In her lightly accented English, the speaker, Venus Palermo (VenusAngelic on the Web), is giving makeup tips to her YouTube fans (some 30,000 subscribers to date), her objective to help turn them into living-doll replicas of herself.

title: Small Agreements Between France and Germany Mask Larger Concerns
description: PARIS  After months of strain, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Franois Hollande of France put a brave face on their relationship this week, hoping to mark a new beginning with a joint visit to an exhibition at the Louvre about German thought and painting from 1800 to 1939.

title: Do Newspapers Need Photographers?
description: The Chicago Sun-Times fired all of its photographers on Thursday. Out the door went 28 people, and decades of experience and skill. All at once the paper emptied a deep reservoir of photojournalistic talent. Before Thursday, it had a staff of professionals with broad knowledge of a great city, with the hard-earned ability to tell stories with pictures  the not-so-easy thing that newspaper photographers do every day.

title: Amid Recession and Rising Joblessness, Greeks Fall Prey to Employment Swindles
description: ATHENS  Nearly two years after losing his job as a car salesman and with bills and debts piling up, Angelos started surfing the Internet for postings outside Greece. A small ad on a Web site offering opportunities abroad caught his eye, and he dialed the accompanying contact number and was told about a factory job in Sweden.

title: A Family of Four, Then Five, Now Six
description: Back when Vanessa Hylande and Jesse Peckham lived in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, rents there were rising steeply, so they decided they might as well move to Manhattan. They rented a two-bedroom two-bath apartment in the Archstone on West End Avenue at 64th Street.

title: Holding Its Own vs. Nonhybrids
description: TESTED 2013 Lexus GS 450h

title: Eyes on the Prize, Gadgets at the Ready
description: Psst, buddy: Can I interest you in a $50,000 or $60,000 Acura?

title: The Peoples Car: A Global History of the Volkswagen Beetle
description: After decades of austerity caused first by the Depression and prolonged by the Second World War, the fifties turned into a golden age of the American automobile that saw car registrations jump from 25.8 million in 1945 to 52.1 million in 1955. Lifestyle changes underpinned demand for cars. As the postwar suburban population grew by 43 percent between 1947 and 1953, daily routines, not least those of women who wished to visit the new suburban shopping malls and plazas, increasingly relied on access to individual transport. The car and the housing booms were intimately linked, with average individual expenditure on these items tripling in real terms between 1941 and 1961. By the end of the fifties, 40 percent of American drivers were female  a far higher proportion than anywhere in Western Eu rope. As a dealer told a journalist investigating why Americans bought Volkswagens in 1955, the car was just the thing for the wife to run around town in. Two- car suburbia is where Volkswagen has made its biggest inroads. Market surveys from the fifties and early sixties also revealed that, while over 60 percent of Beetles registered in the United States served as second cars, about two- thirds of the customers who signed a purchase contract in a dealership had attended college. In short, Volkswagen attracted a foothold among the materially secure, white middle class whose members made up the bulk of suburbanites in the fifties.

title: Pictures of the Day: Germany and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Germany, Turkey, the West Bank and Iran.

title: Memoirs of a Hack Mechanic
description: Chapter 36: Alpha Male Behavior Among Car Guys

title: Red Tape and White Knuckles
description: Emerging from the forest under a black sky, I was met with a storm howling across the desolate plateau. The thunder moved nearer with every clap and the rain was ceaseless, coming down in sheets but the ground could no longer absorb it quickly enough and torrents of muddy water flowed past my wheels while huge chunks of the dirt road were disintegrating before my eyes. Overhanging trees and thorn bushes dangled in my path, scratching my face and ripping my waterproofs, allowing yet more rain to soak me quite literally, to the skin. This was wild, high, open country with not a glimmer of civilisation in sight; there were no people living here now, long since driven out in the civil wars slashing and burning of the villages. I longed to see some evidence of the human hand at work, just a hut or a farmhouse, a truck or car. But the only signs of mans existence were grim and sinister, in the shape of rusting tanks at the roadside and the crumbling concrete of improvised roadblocks.

title: The Stewardship of Historically Important Automobiles
description: The desire to respect well-preserved great automobiles is not a new idea. For decades, closet conservators have not come out because of the pristine restoration focus that dominated the hobby. They worried that their scruffy treasure would pale on the show field. They were told a ground-up is mandatory. Was the preservation motivated by parsimony? And of course a trophy was out of the question. The mainstream seemed to abhor imperfection. While acknowledging their vehicle was technical jewelry in every way, they shamelessly changed its colors, trim, and even its design. Scores of unusual animals were sacrificed to add wow to the trim. No nut, bolt, or tie-rod arm escaped the chrome platers tank. Wire wheel spokes scintillated on the podium. Novel colors were protected with clear coat. When it was easier to replace than fix, the choice was easy. Racing damage was a badge of courage.

title: Racing in the Rain: My Years With Brilliant Drivers, Legendary Sports Cars and a Dedicated Team
description: Chapter 3. Ford Advanced Vehicles (1964-1966)

title: Adventuring on the Printed Page
description: Books, even those about cars and motorcycles, cover the world. These titles, culled from publishers recent offerings, chronicle things like Volkswagens global history, Detroit muscle cars, racing in the wet and an intrepid womans solo trip on a trail bike through Africa. Happy vicarious motoring.

title: Querrey Loses Despite Rare Strong Showing on Clay
description: Sam Querrey, the highest-ranked American man at No. 20 and the 18th seed at the French Open, fell in the third round Friday in five fleet sets to local favorite Gilles Simon of France, 2-6, 6-3, 2-6, 7-6 (2), 6-2.

title: Baby Names That Shout Out I Am ...
description: Amory was too F. Scott Fitzgerald, Enzo too Europhilic. Selby was too Brooklyn, Roman too Polanski. And those are just the boy names, a few of the dozens my wife, Joanna, and I have considered in our search to find a name for our baby, due next month.

title: Wheelies: The Electro-Caddy Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: An Espresso Machine for Your Car
description: Weve heard of the Ferrari of espresso makers, but now theres an espresso maker that could probably be used in a Ferrari. As if we needed another driving distraction, a French company has developed a portable espresso maker for the car.

title: The Joy of Naming the Baby
description: Its easy to mock the frenzied baby-naming efforts described in Alex Williamss Baby Names That Shout Out ; the books, the naming consultants, the spreadsheets with categories for government trend data, celebrity naming fads and cultural nuances. Why give so much weight to a name, and put so much effort into it?

title: The Other White Beans
description: In this weeks column, I write about using white beans in a hearty asparagus salad. In this video I show you how to trim the asparagus, but heres more on what beans to use in the salad. I tested several white bean varieties, canned and dried, and the best were dried controne beans, an heirloom variety imported from Italy. They cooked up creamy and velvety, yet remained intact. They are available online and at specialty markets, but they are expensive. The bag I purchased cost $12 for 10 ounces.

title: So How Good Is Magic Against Extraterrestrials?
description: Make a television series about a teenage wizard, and you are bound to be accused of trying to ride the coattails of Harry Potter. And since you have no chance of matching the enduring appeal of J. K. Rowlings Potter books and the movies based on them, the smart move would be to do everything possible to distance yourself from that universe and define your TV show as something completely different.

title: Affordable Care Act Could Be Good for Entrepreneurship
description: The Affordable Care Act is expected to produce a sharp increase in entrepreneurship next year, according to a new report from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, the Urban Institute and Georgetown Universitys Health Policy Institute. The number of self-employed people is expected to rise by 1.5 million  a relative increase of more than 11 percent  as a direct result of the health care overhaul.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 31
description: More photographs.

title: Vitriol Online for Cheerios Ad With Interracial Family
description: The Cheerios spot shows a young girl asking her mother if the cereal is good for your heart. Her mother assures her that is so. The girl runs away with a cereal box, and in the next scene, the girls sleeping father awakes with a pile of Cheerios atop the side of his chest where his heart is.

title: With Imprints and Tie-Ins, Street Lit Is Gaining Muscle
description: He tells stories of the street in hip-hop songs. Now hes putting them down on paper in a different genre: the novella.

title: Talking Inequality
description: Last weeks CUNY event, which involved me talking with people who actually know what theyre talking about:

title: Friday Night Music: Sarah Jarosz, Ring Them Bells
description: Covering Bob Dylan, solo:

title: A Monument in Motion: Rituals of Letting Go
description: On one level, Natalie Greens new dance, Im building a shrine, is exactly what it sounds like. Audience members, dutifully filing into the Chocolate Factorys shadowy basement space, are told to select an object from a long table  among the choices are bone fragments, a piece of rope and a voodoo doll  and to take it to the second-floor theater.

title: Panel Criticizes Prosecutions in Russia
description: GENEVA  The United Nations Committee Against Torture criticized Russia on Friday for prosecuting two human rights groups because of reports they submitted to the committee.

title: Crowd-Sourcing an Opera
description: The creation of a new opera is a chancy proposition. So the American Lyric Theater has come up with a way to bolster budding librettists and composers: invite a crowd of opinionated New Yorkers to a concert reading of a fledgling work and ask them to criticize it. Bring in a living opera legend and let her have a go at it, too. Whatever is left standing, the reasoning goes, has a fighting chance to make it into production.

title: Losing a Paycheck for Being Gay
description: Now that Delaware and Minnesota have legalized gay marriage, there are12 states where same-sex couples can marry. And in the next few weeks, the Supreme Court is expected to weigh in on a constitutional challenge to the Defense of Marriage Act, which defines marriage as between one man and one woman.

title: A Reading of Relief at Annual Book Show
description: E-book sales are no longer growing at a nerve-rattling pace. The unpleasant and expensive price-fixing lawsuit last year, pitting the Justice Department against five major publishers, has been settled. Independent booksellers added 65 stores to their ranks in 2012, according to their trade association, despite competition from Amazon.

title: They Want You to Listen, Not Read
description: Few performing ensembles have as focused a mission as the Locrian Chamber Players, founded in 1994. The group performs contemporary music, but only works written within the last decade, a strong vote of confidence in living composers.

title: Taking the Downside Out of Donations to Disaster Victims
description: Its become a American habit built on compassion: after human-caused disasters, as with natural ones, people reach deep into their pockets to help the victims or their survivors. The Connecticut school shootings and the Boston Marathon bombing are among the recent examples.

title: Two Acts, United Only by Bump and Grind
description: The joys of the slow bump and grind were something Kelly Rowland and The-Dream could agree on when their shared tour came to the Best Buy Theater on Thursday night. But from there, female and male perspectives diverged. When Ms. Rowland wasnt promising delights or giving bedroom instructions, she was singing about relationships under stress from divided loyalties, jealousy, broken promises and outright abuse. By contrast, when The-Dream wasnt exulting in carnal delights, he was usually waiting impatiently for the next opportunity.

title: Serra Work Gains Protected Status in Ontario
description: A battle that has dragged on for years over the protection of an early outdoor sculpture by Richard Serra in a field north of Toronto has finally been settled, in favor of the sculpture.

title: Ask an Orchestra Manager
description: Next up in Metropolitans Q. and A. series is Carl R. Schiebler, personnel manager for the New York Philharmonic.

title: Zac Posen Red Carpet Designs
description: Mr. Posen has fame, talent, celebrity clients and influential friends. Here are some of his designs.

title: Peace Talks Precede Summer Jam
description: For 20 years, Hot 97s Summer Jam has been one of the largest and most influential hip-hop concerts in the country, a wild stadium-sized party where bitter disagreements between artists are often aired, surprise guests are expected and the latest trends are on display.

title: From the Red Carpet to the Bottom Line
description: This February, Zac Posen went to the Oscars. Though he had been in Los Angeles and gone to the parties surrounding the awards several times over the last decade, the designer had never attended the actual ceremony at the Kodak Theater.

title: Vows: Faizah and Zaahir
description: Two young Muslim Americans  he worked in finance, she volunteered with Occupy Wall Street  fell in love despite their differences.

title: Wilson and Willenken Win Goldman Pairs
description: The oldest bridge event in the world still being contested is the Goldman Pairs. It was first played in New York City in 1929. The winners of the 85th Goldman last Sunday at the Eastern States Regional in Manhattan were Alison Wilson and Chris Willenken of New York City. They finished just over two boards ahead of Walter Lee of Sudbury, Mass., and Alex Perlin of Metuchen, N.J. Third were Rozanne and William Pollack, married players from New York City.

description: Did everybody have a chance to put their data points in the ice bucket?

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: States With Protections for Being Gay
description: Twenty-one states and the District of Columbia have laws to protect discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity since the federal govenrment does not.

title: The Right Way to Do the Hillary Step
description: KETCHUM, Idaho  SIXTY years ago this week, as Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay approached the summit of the worlds highest mountain, they were stopped by a 40-foot wall of rock and ice. It was, Hillary later wrote, a formidable looking problem ...We realized that at this altitude it might well spell the difference between success and failure.

title: A Villages Bicentennial Celebrated in Sculpture
description: A tree made entirely of nails graces a 19th-century churchyard. A woman molded in bronze lounges by the library, legs outstretched, face turned toward the sky. Along the shore, a shard of crimson glass atop a towering column of rose-colored granite catches reflections from the Hudson River beyond.

title: Editors Letter | Of Brains and Beauty
description: If this issue has a theme, it would seem to be about what happens when intelligence and rigor are brought to bear in the pursuit of the aesthetic. As we all know, the intellect can be cruel and beauty can be shallow, but when these two get together, they can be a powerful force for good, and even happiness.

title: A New Place to Find Aged Steak
description: The Chophouse Grille, at the end of a short, set-back shopping strip on busy Route 6, is easy to miss. But local residents seem to have had no trouble finding this dining and drinking spot that Toni Vulaj and Matthew Camerino opened nine months ago. An after-work crowd fills the long, inviting bar to overflowing; and to secure a seat in the restaurant section, diners would be smart to have a reservation.

title: Bill Cunningham | Spoke Spinners
description: No waiting for cabs or buses, or on sweaty subway platforms: just unlock a bike and pedal off.

title: A U.S.-Canada Soccer Friendly With Edgy Overtones
description: The womens national teams of Canada and the United States will play a match billed as an international friendly on Sunday afternoon at Torontos sold-out BMO Field.

title: Is There a Fee for That?
description: Most airlines now charge fees for all kinds of things that were free at one time. They can vary greatly from one airline to another and from domestic to international flights.

title: Crowded Tables, Traditional Thai
description: The Elephant Trail restaurant, in Avon, decorated throughout with pachyderms  on sequined wall hangings, a carved wooden mask and glass-covered tablecloths  serves a range of tasty Thai dishes, most of which are prepared with fresh, crispy vegetables and only a moderate amount of chili pepper.

title: Week in Pictures for May 31
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a Memorial Day parade in Queens, the bike-share program in Brooklyn and the reunion of President Obama and Gov. Chris Christie on the Jersey Shore.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Lost in Love in the Maze of a Clever Stage
description: Its the kind of entrance an actor would happily sell his soul for  as the Duke in Twelfth Night, Lea Coco rises slowly from beneath center stage, lounging barelegged atop a gleaming white piano in his silky, undone shirt. What comes next is one of Shakespeares most famous opening lines: If music be the food of love, play on, Mr. Coco tells the pianist riding the stage elevator with him. And play on they do, as Darko Tresnjaks beguiling production unspools from this surprising central image at the Hartford Stage.

title: Aiding the Victims
description: An overview of the funds that have been established to aid the victims of various tragedies since 2001.

title: Dean Brooks, Cuckoos Nest Doctor, Dies at 96
description: Dr. Dean Brooks, the superintendent of the Oregon psychiatric hospital where the Oscar-winning picture One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest was shot  and who had a small, well-received on-screen role as the fictional hospitals superintendent  died on Thursday at his home in Salem, Ore. He was 96.

title: Two Ranger Forwards Have Shoulder Surgery
description: Rangers forwards Ryan Callahan and Carl Hagelin are expected to miss at least part of training camp and perhaps the beginning of next season after each underwent surgery to repair a torn labrum in the left shoulder on Friday.
